title: Tourists snap up British iPads to smuggle into China
news: IT'S the digital version of the slow boat to China. The iPad 2, made in China but yet to go on sale there, is being bought in London and smuggled back into the country where it is manufactured.  It means the Apple tablet is creating extra carbon emissions as it travels halfway across the world and back again. Customers are queuing to buy the iPad 2 at Apple shops in London and send them 6,000 miles back to China. The tablets are bought for their retail price of £399 for a 16GB model and then taken to China, where they sell for £430. The profit is not in this small mark-up but in the 20% Vat - in this case almost £80 - Chinese tourists can reclaim when they take the iPads out of the country. No tax is paid to the Chinese authorities by the smugglers. It means a student who takes home six iPads can fund his trip to London. […]

title: AFTER SEATTLE; Anarchists get organized.
news: For Juliette Beck, it began with the story of the Ittu Oromo, Ethiopian nomads whose lives were destroyed, in vast numbers, by a dam-a hydroelectric project sponsored by the World Bank. Beck was a sophomore at Berkeley, taking a class in international rural development. The daughter of an orthopedic surgeon, she had gone to college planning to do premed, but environmental science caught her interest, and the story of the Ittu Oromo precipitated a change of major. […] Beck likes to call the I.M.F., the W.T.O., and the World Bank "the iron triangle of corporate rule." In her view, these institutions-their leaders, clients, political allies, and, above all, true bosses, multinational corporations-are frog-marching humanity, along with the rest of the planet, into a toxic, money-maddened, repressive future. And she intends to persuade the rest of us not to go quietly. […] Bank officials have consistently vowed to improve this record, to start funding projects that benefit not only big business and Third World elites but also the world's poor. Accordingly, projects with non-governmental organizations and other "civil society" groups, along with efforts to promote access to health care and education, have increased. But Bank contracts are worth millions, and multinational corporations have remained major beneficiaries. In 1995, Lawrence Summers, then an under-secretary at the Treasury Department-he is now its Secretary-told Congress that for each dollar the American government contributed to the World Bank, American corporations received $1.35 in procurement contracts. One of the Bank's major proposals at the moment is for the development of oilfields in Chad, in central Africa, and the construction of an oil pipeline running more than six hundred miles to the coast at Cameroon. The environmental impact of this pipeline is predicted by many to be dire, the benefits to the people in the area minimal. The big winners will, in all likelihood, be the Bank's major partners in the project-Exxon Mobil and CHEVRON. […]

title: $10bn oil payout voided
news: SAN FRANCISCO: An appeal court yesterday voided the $10 billion punitive damages imposed on Exxon Mobil Corporation for the 1989 Valdez oil spill which polluted the Alaskan coast.  The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals said the company should pay damages but $9.74 billion was excessive. A lower court will now decide a new payout. The Exxon Valdez spill smeared black tar across 3900km of the coast of Alaska's Prince William Sound. Commercial fishermen, Alaskan natives and wildlife suffered.

title: Craft capitalism: Just do it yourself; Web market prospers by tapping into an old-style yearning for personal contact
news: The declaration from the Handmade Consortium materialized on a Web site called buyhandmade.org in late October. ''I pledge to buy handmade this holiday season, and request that others do the same for me,'' it said, and you could type in your name to ''sign'' on. Within weeks, more than 6,500 people had done so. ''Buying handmade is better for people,'' a statement on the site read in part, and ''better for the environment,'' because mass production is a ''major cause'' of global warming, among other things. There were links to an anti-sweatshop site and a Wal-Mart watchdog site. The pledge echoed the idealistic language of an environmental advocacy group, but actually the consortium's most prominent member was the online shopping bazaar Etsy, a for-profit entity. Etsy is an online craft fair where individuals from all over the world sell things that they have made. […]

title: Chevron gas project gets state green light
news: SYDNEY: Chevron has received final environmental approval from the State Government of Western Australia for its huge Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) project, two sources familiar with the situation said yesterday. [...] The project was first expected to deliver gas in 2010, but analysts say 2015 is more likely after delays caused by environmental issues.[...] Barrow Island is a nature reserve and the Western Australian Government had laid down strict conditions to protect the environment. Chevron is the operator of the Gorgon project and holds a 50 per cent stake. Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell each have 25 per cent.[...]

title: RIVALS WILL ACCUSE BP
news: […] BP was expected to be hung out to dry by rivals today amid claims money-saving short-cuts and blunders caused the worst oil spill in US history. The oil giant was dragged before Congress, where it faced accusations of favouring cost savings over safety in the days leading up to the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig in the Gulf of Mexico. Executives from rival firms including Exxon Mobil, CHEVRON, ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell were also due to quizzed over the disaster. [...] Millions of gallons of oil have spilled into the Gulf, devastating 120 miles of coastline and making BP chief executive Tony Hayward public enemy number one in the US. [...]

title: Minister's dash to save LNG deal
news: Resources Minister Ian Macfarlane will fly out of the country tomorrow to head off an environmental backlash that threatens to delay $50 billion of liquefied natural gas exports to California. Mr Macfarlane will lobby on behalf of a number of Australian LNG producers, but a focus will be BHP Billiton's plan to establish a floating import terminal off the coast of California. While the $US600 million ($780 million) plan would help solve California's persistent energy problems, it has raised the hackles of the state's powerful environmental lobby. BHP Billiton's Cabrillo Port project would collect LNG shipments in a huge offshore storage tanker and convert them to gas, which would then be moved to the mainland through an ocean-floor pipeline. Local community groups are concerned not just about the effect an accident at the facility could have on the environment, but also the threat of a terrorist attack. As well as meeting members of California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger's administration, Mr Macfarlane will hold discussions with green groups in the state and travel to Mexico, where he will sign an agreement on energy issues. With environmental concerns shaping up as an insuperable obstacle to exporting LNG directly into California, a number of companies are looking at the possibility of delivering natural gas to Mexico, which could then sell it across the border. Mexico last week gave the green light to two projects to establish gas-import terminals, including one by CHEVRONTEXACO, which is developing the Gorgon gas field off the West Australian coast. While Mr Macfarlane said he would promote Australia as a reliable and environmentally safe source of LNG, he also expected the federal government's close ties with the US should help his case. […]

title: Exxon makes first big investment in biofuels
news: Exxon Mobil Corp. said yesterday it will make its first major investment in greenhouse-gas reducing biofuels in a $600 million (U.S.) partnership with biotech company Synthetic Genomics Inc. to develop transportation fuels from algae. Despite record-breaking profits in recent years, the oil and gas giant has been criticized by environmental groups, politicians and even shareholders for not spending enough to explore alternative energy options. One of the company's requirements was finding a biofuel source that could be produced on a large scale. It says photosynthetic algae appears to be a viable, long-term candidate. If the alliance is successful, algae-based gasoline is still several years away and will mean additional, multibillion-dollar investments for mass production. Exxon's biofuels investment is tiny compared with the $29 billion it is spending this year to find new supplies of crude and natural gas.

title: Rival oil companies get a taste of BP's medicine on Capitol Hill
news: Members of Congress tore into the big energy corporations last night for filing almost identical Gulf of Mexico oil spill response plans - which included contact details for a deceased scientist and steps to protect a marine mammal not found in the region's waters. It was an astonishing and sustained verbal battering which undermined attempts by Shell, ConocoPhillips and ExxonMobil to suggest that their working practices differ from those of BP; and that the catastrophe would not have happened if the leaking well had been theirs. [...] An early BP document put the spill rate at between 1,000 and 14,000 barrels a day. A panel of US scientists offered grim news last night warning that the "most likely flow rate of oil today" ranges from 35,000 to 60,000 barrels per day - once more far higher than previously suggested. At the upper end of the range that would mean the equivalent of the Exxon Valdez spill is erupting from the well every four days. [...]

title: US regulator warns over Canada oil pipeline plan
news: President Barack Obama became significantly more likely to block the Canada-to-Texas Keystone XL oil sands pipeline after the US environmental regulator said a government report that in effect endorsed the project was based on "insufficient" research. [...] However, the EPA has agreed with opponents of the pipeline, arguing that trains would not be able to carry anything like the amount of oil that Keystone could - so blocking it would feed through into lower carbon emissions. Cynthia Giles, from the EPA's Office of Enforcement and Compliance Assurance, said the State Department's "analysis should include further investigation of rail capacity and costs, recognising the potential for much higher per barrel rail shipment costs". Ms Giles said the State Department needs to "more clearly acknowledge" the dangers of an oil spill from the pipe to the surrounding environment. Last month, the dangers of oil spills were underlined when an Exxon Mobil pipeline spilled thousands of barrels of Canadian crude in Arkansas. [...]

title: John Sauven: 'I want to claim the arctic region for all of mankind'; The Monday Interview: As his campaign group turns 40, Greenpeace director John Sauven tells Michael McCarthy how he plans to save the Pole from big oil
news: [...] The average September minimum extent of the ice, from 1979 to 2000, was just over seven million square kilometres; this week it is likely to reach a new low of about 4.2 million km2, a 40 per cent drop in a decade. Vast areas of the Arctic are ice-free this week; the long-fabled Northwest Passage is open, and this week you can sail from the Atlantic to the Pacific without going through the Panama Canal or round Cape Horn. It means that climate change is having its most unmistakable effect so far on the fabric of the Earth. Yet it also means that gluttonous eyes are being cast on the Arctic for what it holds, not least its 160bn barrels of oil, both by the "supermajor" oil companies such as Shell and Exxon Mobil, and the countries by which the Arctic Ocean is surrounded - Canada, Russia, the US, Norway and Denmark (via Greenland). [...] "And what we want do," says John Sauven, who is executive director of Greenpeace UK, "is say that this area, which is currently not national territory, this area of sea ice around the North Pole, should be a 'global commons', collectively owned by humanity under the auspices of the United Nations. [...] So now Greenpeace, Mr Sauven says, is planning a global campaign to make the North Pole off-limits. Internalionalised. No development. No oil drilling. No territorial claims. [...]

title: Source of gas-tracer funding fuels probe
news: THE Commonwealth Ombudsman has launched a full investigation into the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Research Economics over greenhouse gas emission research funded by fossil-fuel industries. ABARE has until 8 22 to give Ombudsman John Wood relevant documents after a preliminary investigation last month found grounds to proceed. The Australian Conservation Foundation made a complaint after a series of ABARE reports showing the costs to the community of limiting greenhouse gas emissions. ABARE had set up steering committees to direct research. BHP, EXXON, MOBIL, Statoil, Texaco, the Business Council of Australia and the Electricity Supply Association each paid $50,000 for a seat. CRA and the Australian Aluminium Council each paid $25,000.[…] ABARE information was used by Ministers for public statements and to shape government policies.[…]

title: Greenpeace slams Microsoft, Nintendo's 'toxic' gadgets
news: AMSTERDAM - Microsoft and Nintendo are taking too long to phase out toxic chemicals from their game consoles, Greenpeace said in its latest environmental ranking of leading electronics companies. Nintendo became the first company to score zero out of a possible 10 points in the Greenpeace ranking and provided no information to consumers on the substances it uses or future elimination of hazardous materials, the environmental organisation said.  Microsoft, judged on its Zune MP3 player and Xbox game console, lost points for its pledge to eliminate toxic chemicals only in 2011 and for having no voluntary takeback program. Microsoft said in a statement that it is committed to environmental progress. "In our consumer electronics business, we comply with and exceed all environmental guidelines and regulations," while ensuring the durability, safety and performance of products, the company said. A public relations firm working for Nintendo said it was unaware of the Greenpeace report and was checking. Greenpeace said TV producers Philips and Sharp have poor policies on taking back and recycling outdated products. Greenpeace added the four companies to its quarterly environmental rankings for the first time and put them at the bottom of the list of 18 companies. […]

title: PESTICIDE PANIC
news: NEW DELHI: India's top court has asked local subsidiaries of Coca-Cola and PEPSI-Co to disclose ingredients in the soft drinks they sell here, after allegations they contain high levels of pesticide.  The Supreme Court notice yesterday came after a New Delhi-based independent research body said it found pesticide residue in samples of Coke and PEPSI, 24 times above the limits set by the Bureau of Indian Standards.The Centre for Science and Environment in New Delhi said it carried out tests on 57 samples taken from 11 soft drink brands made by Coca-Cola India and PEPSICO India. The centre said it found a ''cocktail of three to five different pesticides'', all apparently present in ground water used. Both companies had denied the charges, saying the soft drinks they manufacture and sell in India ''comply with stringent international norms and all applicable national regulations''.[…]

title: High-cost oil projects may be wasted, report says
news: More than $1tn (£600bn) is being gambled on high-cost oil projects that will never see a return if the world's governments fulfil their pledge to tackle climate change, says a new report. The Carbon Tracker Initiative (CTI) research found that $1.1tn of capital expenditure is expected in the next decade in expensive oil sands, deepwater and Arctic projects, but that this investment will be lost if policymakers agree to slash carbon emissions. [...] But recently ExxonMobil said it thought it was "highly unlikely" that the world would cut carbon emissions enough in order to tackle dangerous climate change. "ExxonMobil's attitude that the risk of climate action is near zero seems an irresponsible attitude to risk management to me," said Anthony Hobley, chief executive of CTI. [...]

title: CHEVRON SEEKS FEES IN RACKETEERING TRIAL
news: CHEVRON is seeking $32.3 million in legal costs after winning racketeering judgment against attorney Steven Donziger over pollution from oil work in Ecuador; Donziger has filed appeal of ruling (M)

title: International: US court slashes Exxon Valdez damages
news: The US supreme court yesterday threw out a punitive damages order against the oil giant Exxon for one of the world's worst environmental disasters, ordering it to pay the equivalent of two days' earnings for the 1989 Exxon Valdez tanker spill off Alaska. The judges, in a five-three decision, said an original award of $2.5bn (£1.27bn)in punitive damages against Exxon was excessive. Instead, it ordered the company to pay $507.7m to about 33,000 Alaska fishermen and other victims of the spill.[...] Greenpeace's US director, John Passacantando, commented on the ruling: "For the court to require a company that posted the highest quarterly results in US corporate history in February to pay a mere $500m in punitive damages to affected Alaskans makes a mockery of justice."[...]

title: Chips are down for Irish high-tech boom
news: Environmental objections to INTEL's plans for a huge expansion at a microprocessor plant are worrying the industry, writes Douglas Dalby.  INTEL'S blueprint for a E2billion (£1.4billion) expansion of its chip-manufacturing plant in Co Kildare, Ireland, threatens to split the local community and leave the Irish government's plans for inward investment in real trouble.  The heritage trust, An Taisce, the local planning alliance and a resident in the town of Leixlip have lodged objections to the project, known as Fab 24-2.[…] The organisation is concerned that there is no reference made to the European Union's Seveso directive, which is a mandatory emergency plan governing the prevention of chemical accidents. This includes fire services. […] INTEL has largely succeeded in cultivating a pristine image. Media photographs of the sprawling Leixlip plant invariably portray employees in white boiler suits involved in the production of the cutting-edge technology responsible for driving over 80% of the world's computers.  But to make omelettes, eggs have to be broken. Some critics prefer to emphasise the flipside of chip processing; the 21 exhaust stacks that dot the factory skyline and emit a mixture of steam and acidic gases, although there is no suggestion that the company has ever breached Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) guidelines.[…]

title: Nigeria; Oil Communities Want Role in Repairs of Vandalised Pipelines
news: COMMUNITIES affected by oil spill in Delta State have asked oil companies operating in the Niger Delta to engage people of the area in the repairs of vandalised pipelines, declaring that a situation whereby the oil companies would bring in expatriates to effect the repairs while the natives are neglected was unacceptable. The communities, under the aegis of the Movement for the Emancipation of Oil Impacted Communities, through a letter addressed to the management of the Pipelines Products and Marketing Company (PPMC), Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC) and CHEVRON Nigeria Limited demanded that oil companies operating in the Niger Delta should urgently conduct an Environmental Post-Impact Assessment and engage members of the affected communities in effecting repairs. […] According to the letter: "we condemn in its entirety all spillages caused by suspected act of vandalisation been aided by top PPMC and SPDC staff and security agents. We therefore demand that oil companies should henceforth give oil spill mapping, clean up, remediation and restoration jobs to any of our qualified persons or companies. It is obvious that engaging our people and companies for any of the repair jobs shall go a long way to bring about permanent peace and cordial relationship between the oil companies and any of our affected communities. "It is an established fact that the areas where we live have been polluted and degraded by oil spillage, as such we will not henceforth allow outsiders who are not in any way related to our communities or those already managing and benefitting in the affairs of this country, to also use their majority position and riches to take away jobs that we can do to ameliorate our sufferings. However, any attempt by the oil companies to contract out any of the jobs without considering our indigenous companies and people from our communities particularly those with a recommendation from communities where a job is expected to be carried out shall henceforth be at your own risk" it stated.

title: Extract from An Inconvenient Truth
news: THERE is a misconception that the scientific community is in a state of disagreement about whether global warming is real, whether human beings are the principal cause and whether its consequences are so dangerous as to warrant immediate action. [...] The misconception that there is serious disagreement among scientists about global warming is actually an illusion that has been deliberately fostered by a relatively small but extremely well-funded cadre of special interests, including EXXON MOBIL and a few other oil, coal and utilities companies. These companies want to prevent any new policies that would interfere with their current business plans that rely on the massive unrestrained dumping of global warming pollution into the Earth's atmosphere every hour of every day.

title: Nation bids adieu to Trudeau: A roundup of the events, big and small, that made news this week.
news: […] Exxon appeal rejected. The U.S. Supreme Court rejected an appeal by Exxon Mobil of a $5-billion U.S. court penalty imposed on the company in connection with the infamous Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989. The oil-tanker spill was the worst in U.S. history, polluting 1, 600 kilometres of coastline. The Exxon appeal focused on the alleged misconduct of a bailiff who escorted the jury to and from court during the 1994 trial. The bailiff, Don Warrick, was reported to have pulled out his gun one day, taken out a bullet and made remarks about a juror who had become confused and distraught during the jury deliberations. But the Supreme Court said it agreed with the trial judge and appeal court that Warrick had not prejudiced Exxon's ability to get a fair trial. An Exxon official said the company has other appeals pending against the $5 billion in punitive damages. […]

title: Environment, Social and Governance Supplement: Case Study: Technology Sector - Sustainable and responsible investing
news: […]. That is to say, the issue is not only for public authorities concerned to reduce energy consumption, but is also reflected in a genuine competitive advantage on the market. For example, the recent success of the company AMD in the face of its powerful competitor INTEL is explained to a great degree by the technological progress it has made in dual-core microprocessors, which consume less energy while performing better.[…] The interest paid by some NGOs and by public authorities to the question of waste and hazardous substances is not recent. In 1989, the United Nations adopted the Basle Convention on the export of hazardous substances. Following that first international reference framework, national initiatives have succeeded one another, supported by a series of European directives from 2003 to ensure that waste management in the technology sector is fully taken in hand by producers and distributors. This ever more urgent regulation is leading companies in the sector to make provisions and to organise themselves differently. Waste management combined with the directives concerning hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment not only involves the introduction of recycling processes but also fundamental changes to manufacturing processes, underlying R&D expenditure, the review of product design and so on. In the technology sector, a research institute (AMR Research) has estimated that 2 per cent of companies' revenues in the sector should be allocated to meeting these standards. For its part, the European Commission has estimated a total cost of between E650m and E1.05bn per annum for the Europe of the 15. The impact may also be positive to the extent that companies that are innovative concerning respect for the environment may concentrate on increasing their market share by highlighting this competitive advantage. Dexia AM sustainability analysts believe that the importance of the management of waste and dangerous substances is reaching a peak in the sector. In the next five years, we think that the relevance of management of waste products reaching the end of their life cycle will be a constant issue for companies. On the other hand, it is anticipated that the question of hazardous substances in products will increase in relevance in the future, many companies still not having fully factored the consequences of the new legislation.

title: Exxon pays $2.64 million to settle EPA complaint
news: Exxon Mobil Corp. has paid $2.64 million to settle a complaint by the U.S. EPA that the company disposed of and improperly handled polychlorinated biphenyls on an offshore oil and gas platform. The incident occurred in the Santa Barbara Channel, off the Southern California coast, in violation of the federal Toxic Substances Control Act. Two large electrical transformers leaked nearly 400 gallons of PCB-contaminated fluid between 2002 and 2005, according to the EPA. Exxon allowed one of the transformers to leak for almost two years before repairing it, according to the agency. Exxon also failed to provide workers who cleaned up the leaked fluid with protective clothing or equipment to protect against direct contact with and inhalation of PCBs, according to the EPA.[...]

title: MORE TOXIC SLUDGE FEARED IN WATERWAY
news: WORKERS BUILDING a park on Newtown Creek hit underground toxic sludge that must be pumped out and trucked away, environmental advocates and elected officials charge. Councilman David Yassky (D-Greenpoint) and activists from the group Riverkeeper charge the discovery highlights severe environmental contamination along the North Brooklyn waterway - just across from the city's planned Olympic Village in Queens. "This is the tip of the iceberg," said Yassky, who together with Riverkeeper has filed a high-profile lawsuit against EXXONMOBIL over a decades-old 17-million-gallon oil plume lurking nearby beneath Greenpoint. The activists are calling on the city and state to move aggressively to clean up the area. "Newtown Creek is lined with dozens of toxic sites and underground oil spills as well as 20 sewer outfalls," said Basil Seggos, chief investigator of Riverkeeper.[...]

title: Metro Business; Business Group Backs G.E. on PCB's
news: New York corporations closed ranks yesterday around General Electric in its opposition to dredging PCB-contaminated sediment from the Hudson River. The Business Council, the most powerful business lobbying group in New York State, said in an announcement in Albany that vengefulness by G.E. critics must not be allowed to guide policy at the federal Environmental Protection Agency. "To them, big corporations like G.E. are evil polluters, who must be punished," the president of the council, Daniel Walsh, said in a letter to the federal agency. In December, the agency plans to announce its decision on how best to deal with PCB hot spots in the Hudson River north of Albany. G.E. legally discharged the PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls) into the Hudson until 1977, when the chemicals were banned by the federal government. G.E., with its own scientific studies and a television public relations campaign, is trying to convince the federal agency that dredging is not the best solution. The company says that the river is getting cleaner, and that PCB's are not a cancer-causing agent in humans, despite federal officials' statements that it probably is. PCB's were used as insulating material in transformers and other electrical equipment. They have been linked to cancer in laboratory animals.

title: PCB BLOOD LEVELS NORMAL, EXPERT SAYS IN RAIL SUIT PEOPLE LIVING NEAR THE PAOLI YARD SAY THEY ARE AT RISK OF ILLNESS. THEY WANT LIFELONG TESTS TO BE PAID FOR.
news: Neighbors of the Paoli Railroad Yard who have sued over long-term exposure to PCBs have "normal" levels of the synthetic chemical in their blood, a toxic-chemicals expert testified yesterday. John Whysner, an expert on health risks and exposure to toxic chemicals, said he examined the neighbors' blood tests and found that their blood levels of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, were no different from those of the population at large. "I did not find any significant exposure of the residents," Whysner testified after attorneys for the PCB manufacturers and users began calling witnesses to refute the neighbors' claims.  Twenty-six neighbors of the train-repair facility are suing Monsanto Co., General Electric Corp. and Westinghouse Electric Corp., along with SEPTA and the City of Philadelphia, in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia. The neighbors contend that their properties were contaminated and that they run the risk of serious illnesses stemming from long-term exposure to PCBs from the rail yard. PCBs have been linked to cancer, liver disease and other illnesses in animals. Two neighbors say they suffer from illnesses directly linked to PCBs. […]

title: Irvings break oil ranks to back Kyoto: East coast mavericks: 'Anything that helps the environment is good for everybody,' Arthur Irving says
news: HALIFAX - Arthur Irving, head of Irving Oil Limited, operators of Canada's largest oil refinery and a chain of gas stations, has broken ranks with petroleum industry colleagues and declared the Kyoto accord good for Canada. […] Although their views have not been unanimous, executives with Canada's oil and gas industry fought hard last year to persuade Ottawa not to ratify the climate-change agreement, saying it would increase the costs of exploring and producing petroleum, reduce the demand for oil and gas products and threaten Canadian jobs. Despite such criticisms from the industry and from leaders such as Ralph Klein, the Alberta Premier, Parliament ratified the international accord in December. Under Kyoto, Ottawa is obliged to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases in Canada to 6% below 1990 levels by 2012. […] Unlike such counterparts as CHEVRON Canada and Petro-Canada, Irving Oil also shuns any membership in industry associations such as the Canadian Petroleum Products Institute. […] One source, who asked not to be named, said it may be easier for the Irvings to support Kyoto than many Calgary-based firms, because Irving Oil does not rely for its profits on Canadian crude. While the costs of producing and refining Canadian petroleum may be higher under Kyoto, many foreign oil sources will not be affected. […]

title: INSIDE
news: At Debate, Mayor Is Conspicuous by His Absence Fernando Ferrer, left, the Democratic mayoral candidate in New York, and Thomas V. Ognibene, the Conservative, at a debate in Harlem last night. A lectern was reserved for Mayor Bloomberg, who skipped the event.   PAGE B1Pataki's Ground Zero Rebuke In an extraordinary rebuke to Gov. George E. Pataki, members of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board deplored Mr. Pataki's decision to bar the International Freedom Center museum from the memorial area of ground zero while the matter was pending before the board.   PAGE B1 G.E. to Dredge the Hudson Nearly three decades after PCB's were found in the upper Hudson River, GENERAL ELECTRIC has signed a binding agreement to dredge the dangerous chemicals from 43 miles of river bottom. The project is expected to cost $700 million and take at least six years.   PAGE B3 […]

title: Baby care
news: When it comes to baby care, it seems that convenience trumps being environmentally friendly every time. The disposable nappy sector is worth £398m and  accounts for more than a third of total sales in the baby market.  The category  has shown steady growth of 1.53% in the last year, according to TNS.   "Mums are  busy and convenience is still  high on the agenda," says Marc Hardenberg, MD of Hardenberg,  UK distributor of the Angelcare nappy bin. "It will be a long, long, time before recyclable or washable nappies take over from disposable ones.  Growth within the nappy category is driven by superior products that meet the needs of mums and their babies, adds Usama Alqassab, babycare brand manager at PROCTER & GAMBLE, manufacturer of Pampers.   That's not to say baby product companies are  ignoring the eco agenda. Baby bottle maker Bibi has  produced a new recyclable, disposable bottle.  Pampers has reduced its nappy weight by 40% and packaging by 80%, while Huggies manufacturer  Kimberly-Clark has signed up to the Carbon Trust's carbon labelling scheme,  minimising materials that go into nappies to reduce the amount of wastage. […]

title: Financial: Exxon chief backs carbon tax
news: The world's biggest oil company, Exxon Mobil, has softened its hardline position on climate change by throwing its weight behind a tax on carbon emissions. In a significant shift in stance, Exxon's chief executive, Rex Tillerson, told an audience in Washington that he consid-ered a tax to be a fairer route to curbing emissions than a cap-and-trade system of pollution allocations.[...] Until recently, Exxon was reluctant even to concede that greenhouse gas emissions were responsible for global warming. The company has faced mounting pressure over its environmental policies, culminating in a shareholder rebellion at its annual meeting last year led by members of the oil-rich Rockefeller family.[...]

title: Mayor voted for Wal-Mart, against Tarpon
news: An open letter to Beverley Billiris, mayor of Tarpon Springs. Dear Ms. Billiris: As a snowbird from Toronto who has been coming to Tarpon Springs each winter for eight years and now owns property here, I attended the meeting last Tuesday night. I left at midnight. […] I am a local high school student who likes to follow current events. […] These last few months I have taken down many illegally placed signs that in essence say "Wal-Mart is bad for our environment! Everyone should hate them!" Is polluting our town with your signs and flyers any better? How many trees did you all have to cut down to create these signs saying that Wal-Mart is going to cut them down? That is hypocrisy at its worst I am also appalled at the ignorance many people have displayed on this issue. It will hurt small businesses in the area? Which ones? If I know the area as well as I think I do, the only businesses in the area are the antique shops. If I am not mistaken, Wal-Mart has yet to add an antique section to their stores. Also, how is it going to hurt the Greek heritage of our city? It's not like they are opening up shop in the middle of the Sponge Docks. That would attack the heritage. […] Residents of Pinellas County should let these corporate giants know they are committing an environmental atrocity by boycotting the Wal-Mart name. There were/are plenty of other sites along the U.S. 19 corridor to be had for this big box store. They certainly went through a great amount of time and effort to destroy the Anclote River and its wildlife. Please e-mail or write or call the Gov. Jeb Bush's office. Appealing to the state is the only hope of saving the river now. […]

title: Exclusive: Make food and drink corporations 'account for water usage', says scientist; Food production's effect on water supplies must be investigated and properly recorded, warns Professor Tony Allan
news: Supermarkets and food producers should be made to account for the amount of water they use if critical global shortages are to be prevented, a leading expert on the resource has said. With 90 per cent of water used by society being taken up by food production, Professor Tony Allan believes water usage must be formally recorded in company filings to ensure that the true costs of production are recognised. Mr Allan told The Independent it is vital that major companies, such as Coca-Cola and Kraft, together with powerful supermarkets including Walmart, take a lead in establishing measures to "capture the value of water".

title: COMPANY NEWS; EXXON TO GET $300 MILLION IN A PARTIAL SETTLEMENT
news: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would receive $300 million from Lloyd's of London and about 250 other underwriters in a partial settlement of a lawsuit to recover expenses from the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. Exxon had sought more than $1 billion from its insurance companies and underwriting syndicates for the tanker accident and oil spill. The insurers refused to pay, saying the accident was caused by the company's negligence. The company, based in Irving, Tex., still has $250 million in unresolved claims pending with Lloyd's and other underwriters. Exxon spent $3 billion to clean up the spill and to settle lawsuits.

title: My Say: The climate change revolution
news: The world is in the midst of a great political transformation, in which climate change has moved to the centre of national and global politics. For politicians in persistent denial about the need to act, including US President George W Bush, Australian Prime Minister John Howard, and Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper, there is no longer any place to hide. The science is clear - man-made changes in climate are being felt, and the electorate's demand for action is growing. Though unlikely just a few months ago, a strong global agreement by 2010, one that will set a path for action for decades to come, now stands a good chance of being implemented. Political leaders in countries that produce coal, oil, and gas - like the US, Australia, and Canada - have pretended that climate change is a mere hypothesis. For several years, the Bush administration tried to hide the facts from the public, deleting references to man-made climate from government documents and even trying to suppress statements by leading government scientists. Until recently, Exxon Mobil and other companies paid lobbyists to try to distort the public debate. […]

title: INTERVIEW: CHEVRON takes on Ecuador's government; CHEVRON General Counsel Charles James and other company officials sat down with Platts Oilgram News Managing Editor Beth Evans in New York October 10 to discuss developments in Ecuador, including what the company calls a "partnership" between the new leftist President Rafael Correa and plaintiffs seeking a multi-billion-dollar settlement from an environmental lawsuit that could result in a decision against the oil major. James left his position as US assistant attorney general for antitrust to join CHEVRON five years ago.
news: This case appears to be heating up. What has changed? James:...we now have the government of Ecuador who has come out and effectively joined a partnership with the plaintiffs. What you have now is the president and...senior people in the government actually appearing with the plaintiffs and exhorting the court to not only finalize the litigation, but do it fast. From our standpoint this is now a considerably different kind of a situation and one in which we're being denied justice, the rule of law is being abandoned, the laws of Ecuador are being violated...we would like the international community, the legal community to understand that this has become a farce because as it moves forward we are going to defend ourselves in every conceivable forum and what we want to make sure is people understand why. […] Sara McMillen, CHEVRON chief environmental scientist: The plaintiffs...have repeated things so many times that they've kind of become jungle legend and they get repeated over and over again like the $6 billion number. Petroecuador came out and said 'We can remediate each of these pits?264 of them that are left that are their responsibility?for $80,000 a piece.' If you add that up that's around $25 million. Some environmental groups have railed against CHEVRON in Ecuador and at least one investment firm has tried unsuccessfully to pass a shareholder resolution about Ecuador. Has this affected CHEVRON's "green" investors? James: No. If you look at the history of how those resolutions have fared with our investors, every year they have to reword it to get through the little knothole of securities laws...because every year it gets rejected. If you look at the data, you will see that CHEVRON's perception among that community has actually improved over a period of time. […] Petroecuador is one of the worst operators in this business from an environmental standpoint...We've not been operating in Ecuador since 1990 and there is a long-standing record of degradation since then. […]

title: WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
news: [...] STUDY PUTS UK TOP FOR PRIVATE EQUITY The UK is the most attractive place to set up private equity businesses, an Investec Fund Finance survey of UK buy-out chiefs has found.[...] CHEVRON FACES FINES OF UP TO £53M OVER BRAZIL OIL SPILL US oil giant CHEVRON is facing fines that could total $83m (£53m) as a result of an oil spill off the coast of Brazil and could face a temporary ban on operating in the country. The oil company has said it accepts full responsibility for the accident, which Brazilian regulators say has seen more than 416,000 litres of oil leak into the Atlantic in the past two weeks.[...]

title: Beijing clarifies why Coke, PEPSI made top polluters list
news: BEIJING, Aug. 20 (Xinhua) - Beijing authorities said Thursday US soft drink giants PEPSICO and Coca-Cola reach Chinese standards for waste water emission but they have potentials to further reduce emission. The Beijing Development and Reform Commission (DRC) and Beijing Environmental Protection Bureau (EPU) published Monday an environmental watch list which included the two companies among the "key water polluting factories". Any enterprises that discharge pollutants to water, no matter whether they reached standards or not, are considered as polluting factories, said a spokesman with the EPU. By the term "key water polluting factories", it means the enterprises use a large amount of water and belong to chemical, medicine, electric, beverage, brewage and food manufacturing, the spokesman said.PEPSICO and Coca-Cola are comparatively large users of water and belong to the beverage industry, so they were listed, he said. "The listed companies have reached the Chinese standards for pollutants emission," he said. "But there is no best, but better, in environmental protection." If these companies adopt advanced technologies, use clean energy and raw materials, reduce pollutants emissions and increase energy efficiency, they can play a model role for other companies and make more contribution to the environmental improvement of Beijing, he said.[…]

title: Legal & Legislative:
news: XTO Energy has been charged with eight criminal violations stemming from a 2010 accident in which more than 50,000 gallons of wastewater was spilled at a natural gas well site in Pennsylvania. State Attorney General Kathleen Kane said the wastewater flowed from a storage tank into a local waterway near the community of Penn Township. According to Kane, XTO is being charged with five criminal counts of violating the Clean Streams Law and three counts of violating the Solid Waste Management Act. XTO, an Exxon Mobil subsidiary, said it would challenge the charges. In 7, XTO reached a settlement with the US Environmental Protection Agency over the same spill. [...] Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) said last week that it expects to pay $565 million in legal settlements and claims from a 2010 natural gas pipeline explosion in the San Francisco Bay suburb of San Bruno. [...]

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; Nature Is Served At a New Resort
news: IT'S hard to think that the two resorts I visited last month could be in the same universe, let alone the same state. A family reunion took me to Disney World in Orlando, where three dozen of us had breakfast with Mickey, among several otherworldly events. When the family said farewells on Sunday, I drove north 75 miles on Florida's Turnpike and on Marion Country roads to the Refuge at Ocklawaha. At the Refuge, an eco-resort, I slept on a top-notch mattress in a small new cabin with windows and screened doors flung open to the sound of frogs and peepers, fading at dawn to rich bird cries. […] Elsewhere on the Eco-Front[…] The Cheeca Lodge, along with many other hotels, is now leaving cards in rooms telling guests how to indicate which towels should be replaced, and offering the option of changing the sheets every other day instead of every day. Le Centre Sheraton in Montreal has a hang card saying that towels in the tub will be replaced, not those on the rack. At the Grovesnor Resort at Disney World, in addition to a towel notice, a card said: "Please place glass, plastic and paper materials next to your guest room trash can. Our staff will gladly have these item recycled for you." The paper napkins we got in WALT DISNEY World were tan and marked "100 percent recycled paper," although they seemed negligible in a trashcan that was otherwise overflowing with plastic cups and delicatessen containers.[…]

title: Green group split on cash for cans; Recycling - Coca-Cola caught in row
news: A split has emerged at Keep Australia Beautiful on whether to support the cash-for-cans recycling proposal, despite its national organisation lobbying against it with Coca-Cola. The West Australian and South Australian branches support the national deposit scheme over other recycling proposals being suggested by the national body. The NSW branch, whose president is the Premier Barry O'Farrell, is against the recycling scheme. [...] The national Keep Australia Beautiful group received a quarter of its funding for community grants from Coca-Cola, raising concerns from other environmental groups over its "disturbing" relationship with the beverage giant. [...] The executive director of the South Australian branch, John Phillips, said the beverage industry had fought "tooth and nail" against the national container deposit scheme. "The beverage industry puts a lot of false information or twists to how a container deposit scheme works," Mr Phillips said. South Australia had the best recycling rates in Australia with a cash-for-cans scheme, he said. [...]

title: Nigeria; Mobil Denies Estate Firm On Oil Spill Compensation
news: Mobil, an affiliate of American oil giant, ExxonMobil, has distanced itself from an estate firm, Sam Udoa-Akagha & Partners, for allegedly embarking on sales of forms purportedly on behalf of the oil major in anticipation of payment of compensation for the oil spills in the area. Executive Director of Mobil, Mrs. Gloria E. Essien-Danner in a statement argued that the oil major had no contractual relationship with any organisation or persons in Akwa Ibom State for the handling of compensation to any individual or communities in the state. The oil firm specifically said "there is no relationship between MPN and Sam Udo-Akagha & Partners for the payment of compensation or any other issue", as the laws of Nigerian were clear on the procedure for the payment of compensation for damage caused by an oil spill. But in a sharp reaction, the Managing Partner/Chief Executive Officer, Sam Udo-Akagha and Partners, Mr. Isang Udo-Akagha regretted the position of MPN and strongly denied selling the controversial compensation forms with intention to defraud members of the public. Following the May 2010 oil spillage, he explained that the affected communities in Eket and Esit Eket LGAs through the apex socio-cultural body of the Ekid nation, Ekid People's Union contacted them for professional services.[...]

title: Barrow to push over Gorgon gas site
news: THE Western Australian Government wants Canberra to help meet the $1 billion cost of switching the site for the proposed Gorgon gas plant from environmentally sensitive Barrow Island to the mainland. The Australian has learned the state Government, fearing a backlash from environmentalists opposed to the use of the Barrow Island Class A nature reserve, has argued there should be a reallocation of revenue sharing from the $6 billion project between the federal and state governments. […] The partners in the project claim it would cost up to $1 billion more to make an onshore site economic compared to the costs of processing the gas on Barrow Island. […] CHEVRONTEXACO on Tuesday said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to buy two million tonnes of gas a year from Gorgon in a deal worth up to $12 billion. Shell is also negotiating to buy a similar volume, with the aim of having the project producing early in 2008. […] Negotiations with the federal Government to secure a better revenue sharing arrangement for the project. A commitment by the Gorgon joint venturers to meet stringent quarantine management procedures proposed by the Environmental Protection Authority. […]

title: Coalition calls up moguls to carbon panel
news: THE Coalition will today announce a top-level panel of business leaders has agreed to advise it on its direct action carbon policy as the Greens signalled yesterday they would push for a carbon price well above $20 a tonne. Opposition climate action spokesman Greg Hunt will unveil a business advisory panel including the head of Coca-Cola Amatil Terry Davis, Westfield Retail Trust chairman and former Reserve Bank member Dick Warburton and former Western Mining boss and ex-Business Council of Australia president Hugh Morgan. title: Nigeria; Exxonmobil Resumes Oil Shipments After Akwa-Ibom Spill Clean-Up
news: Oil giant, ExxonMobil, has resumed oil deliveries from Nigeria after cleaning up a spill from an offshore platform in Akwa Ibom State. A statement issued by the company yesterday reads in part: "Mobil Producing Nigeria, operator of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)/MPN joint venture), today, confirms that it has lifted the force majeure it declared on May 12, 2010."[...] It would be recalled that the Minister of Environment, John Odey, had met with ExxonMobil top management in 6 and ordered the company to clean the spill. "ExxonMobil needs to show more caution in terms of the management of oil spills", Odey said, noting that because ExxonMobil's operation is offshore, any spillage will affect the shorelines, and it could go far beyond the area of operation.

title: Anger at oil chief's$400m retirement package
news: Investors and environmental campaigners condemned a$400m (pounds 214m) retirement package for the boss of EXXON MOBIL, the man known as the "Darth Vader of global warming" for his denial that carbon emissions cause climate change. Protesters descended on the annual shareholder meeting of the world's largest oil company's in Dallas, Texas, amid fury over the lavish lifestyle that it plans to fund for Lee Raymond, who retired after 12 years as chairman and chief executive. EXXON has been condemned by green groups for fuelling the world's addiction to oil by opposing the Kyoto treaty on reducing emissions and refusing to invest a penny in alternative energy sources. [...]

title: Bad Apple
news: Apple has flunked the "first global exam" to rank the green credentials of electronics companies, greenpeace.org said. Rated on their use of toxic chemicals and electronic waste policies, "only Dell and Nokia scraped a barely respectable score" while the maker of the iPod music player finished fourth from bottom in a field of 14. Al Gore might call this "an inconvenient truth" -the title of the former presidential candidate's film that gives warning of environmental disaster and has won plaudits across the planet. He sits on the Apple board.

title: Communications - Case Study - Oxfam a 'critical friend' of food firms
news: Oxfam International had the world's largest food and drink companies in its sights when it launched its Behind the Brands campaign. The global campaign ranks the social and environmental policies of the world's 10 biggest brands by analysing their agricultural policies, public commitments and supply chains. The companies, including Coca-Cola, Danone and Mars, are then ranked on scorecards hosted on a specially created campaign microsite. […] Erinch Sahan, private sector policy adviser at Oxfam GB, says: 'The tone of the campaign is that of a critical friend. We don't want to demonise companies, but we do want to put pressure on them. These are brands that people know and love, and consumers have a right to expect more from them. 'We want to encourage people to put pressure on the companies without it being a threatening or boycotting exercise.' […] The website features a petition that members of the public can sign, urging the companies to take action. […]

title: Louisiana sues oil companies over erosion
news: NEW ORLEANS (AP) The oil and gas industry has cost Louisiana hundreds of thousands acres (hectares) of coastal land that serve as a natural buffer against flooding from hurricanes, officials in charge of New Orleans-area flood protection say in a lawsuit seeking to hold dozens of companies responsible. Corrosive saltwater from a network of oil and gas access and pipeline canals has killed vegetation and swept away vast amounts of soil, the Southeast Louisiana Flood Protection Authority-East"s board of commissioners claims in the lawsuit, which was filed Wednesday in Orleans Parish Civil District Court. [...] "Even the industry recognizes they are responsible for some of the land lost, and it"s not an insignificant amount," said board vice president John Barry, author of "Rising Tide: The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 and How It Changed America." About 100 companies are named as defendants in the lawsuit, including Apache Corp., BP America Production Co., Chevron USA Inc., ConocoPhillips Co., Exxon Mobil Corp., Shell Oil Co. and The Pickens Co. Inc. Officials in the oil and gas industry said they will vigorously defend against the lawsuit. [...]

title: Businesses' green opportunities are wide, but complex; Efforts must be credible and make financial sense
news: It's not surprising that the pages of Joel Makower's latest book, Strategies for the Green Economy, are printed on paper made from 100% post-consumer, de-inked fiber. That's paper that has been used by consumers and collected through various recycling programs. Makower, editor of GreenBiz.com, practices what he preaches. He's spent the last 20 years advising companies on green strategies and marketing, and has written books such as The Green Consumer and The E-Factor: The Bottom Line Approach to Environmentally Responsible Business. […] *How do you make sense of a world in which green hopes far outweigh green habits? *Should you focus on what looks good to outsiders or what really matters in terms of your company's impact and potential to create value? *Do you cater to short-term expectations or dig in for the long term, even if you have to take some financial hits along the way? The green opportunities for businesses of all sizes are numerous, but it's a complex playing field that hasn't found its footing since the hoopla that surrounded the first Earth Day -- 18 years ago. Back then, "it seemed like a floodgate of greener products was about to open," Makower writes. "Large consumer product companies such as PROCTER & GAMBLE and Unilever were dipping their corporate toes into the green waters, with the expectation they would eventually dive in." Fully 26% of all household products introduced in 1990 boasted a green claim, according to the Marketing Intelligence Service, which tracks product launches. "We could smell change coming," Makower remembers. It didn't. One problem was that many of the products didn't live up to their hype, he writes, and labeling claims were found to be inaccurate, unverifiable or simply meaningless, he recalls. Ouch. Part of the problem, of course, was that many of the terms being used -- safe, Earth-friendly, non-toxic, organic and natural -- had no legal or generally accepted definitions. […]

title: Mackenzie pipeline proposal in jeopardy
news: A string of new demands from a key aboriginal group in the North may have dealt a body blow to plans for a multibillion-dollar natural gas pipeline down the Mackenzie Valley."We're studying the implications of this," said Hart Searle, spokesperson for the Calgary-based consortium that includes Imperial Oil, Conoco Canada, Shell Canada and Mobil Oil Canada.[…] The terms and conditions of a pipeline be negotiated through the Deh Cho land-rights process with the federal government. Revenues and royalties from oil and gas development in Deh Cho be shared with local communities. Community impact and benefits agreements be in place before the project proceeds. Deh Cho representatives be allowed to participate in environmental assessment research.[…] An alternative pipeline route is being studied by an American consortium, which includes Phillips, British Petroleum-Amoco and EXXON-Mobil. The consortium is looking at the possibility of shipping gas from Alaska undersea to the Mackenzie Valley and then to Alberta.[…]

title: Protests in India Deplore Soda Makers' Water Use
news: Just as the threats of a boycott against American soft drinks because of the war in Iraq appear to have petered out, COCA-COLA and PepsiCo are caught in a whole new controversy here over the water consumed by their bottling plants in southern India.      The village government of Pudussery, a rural community in the Palghat district of Kerala state, said last week that it had revoked the water-use license of the Pepsi bottling plant there because the plant had depleted the community's groundwater to the point of causing a shortage. The license was not due to expire until 2005.  A plant belonging to Hindustan COCA-COLA Beverages in nearby Perumatty was denied a license renewal last month on similar grounds. The company appealed to the Kerala High Court, which reversed the village's decision.COKE and Pepsi, two of the most visible American brands in India, dominate the country's $1.2 billion market for soft drinks, one of the world's fastest growing. They compete fiercely to sell carbonated drinks and, increasingly, bottled water.[…] Both PepsiCo and Hindustan COCA-COLA insist that they have not overused water resources. […] Hindustan COCA-COLA said studies had shown that its bottling operations were not affecting groundwater reserves. […] Kerala is one of the few regions of India where Communist parties dominate politics, and organizing against COKE and Pepsi went further there than in most other parts of the country. […] Local Communist leaders are unmoved. "If we don't stop this unlimited exploitation of groundwater, the ecological damage will be very serious," said Krishna Das, a member of Parliament from Palghat district. […]

title: Experts worry about cleanup of Arctic oil spills; Ice interferes with normal methods of purging oil after accidents
news: As the world's energy industry begins a cautious return to Arctic waters, environmentalists, scientists and governments are increasingly concerned about its ability to clean up after the accidents some say will inevitably follow. "There continues to be no effective method for cleaning up an oil spill on ice," said Samantha Smith, director of the World Wildlife Fund's Arctic program. […] Last March, a U.S. Arctic Research Commission report concluded that nearly all the techniques used to clean up oil spills in southern waters are useless or nearly so in the North. […] Industry is already moving. On Dec. 2, Devon Energy filed plans with the National Energy Board to drill the first offshore well in Canada's Beaufort Sea in 13 years. Although Devon will drill close enough to shore to be on stable ice, energy majors including Talisman, BP, Anadarko and CHEVRON also have multiyear exploration licences in the Beaufort, some of which are considerably further out. […] Ms. Smith points out that because the Arctic is a low-energy environment, it takes much longer for industrial impacts to fade. As well, Arctic marine species tend to concentrate in certain areas at certain times of the year. An accident in one of those places during the short summer growing season - also the easiest time of year for exploration - would be catastrophic, she said.  "If it's at the wrong place at the wrong time, you could actually wipe out a good portion of the population. Oil spills, particularly offshore in the Arctic, can have very big effects, maybe bigger than some other parts of the world."[…]

title: Multinationals warn of cost of failure to cut emissions
news: COCA-COLA and Unilever have given warning that their profits could halve over the next decade unless they reduce their emissions, as business leaders in Copenhagen called for a global fixed price on carbon dioxide. The two companies acknowledged that green taxes and regulation would cause profits to fall 47pc by 2018 in the consumer goods sector if no effective action was taken. Unilever and Coca-Cola both announced that they would reduce the carbon footprint of their supply chains at the Copenhagen Business Day, a conference running parallel to the political summit. [...] There were further tensions among business leaders when Yvo de Boer, UN executive secretary for the climate negotiations, attacked companies for failing to come up with specific financial proposals to help governments raise funding to tackle climate change. "While you're doing a lot of talking about what you want and what governments have got to do, I'm hearing less about what you've got to offer,'' he said. [...]

title: Orangutans vanish from their forest home as high street giants slake their thirst for palm oil: Plantations are destroying the habitat of the Sumatran apes, leaving just 200 of them struggling to survive. And it is the global cosmetic industry's use of 'dirty' oil that is partly to blame, reports Gethin Chamberlain in Rawa Tripa: FIGHT FOR EXISTENCE
news: Even in the first light of dawn in the Tripa swamp forest of Sumatra it is clear that something is terribly wrong. Where there should be lush foliage stretching away towards the horizon, there are only the skeletons of trees. Smoke drifts across a scene of devastation. Tripa is part of the Leuser Ecosystem, one of the world's most ecologically important rainforests and once home to its densest population of Sumatran orangutans. As recently as 1990, there were 60,000 hectares of swamp forest in Tripa: now just 10,000 remain, the rest grubbed up to make way for palm oil plantations servicing the needs of some of the world's biggest brands. Over the same period, the population of 2,000 orangutans has dwindled to just 200. […] "One of the big issues is that we simply don't know where the palm oil used in products on UK supermarket shelves comes from. It may well be that it came from Tripa," says Usher. In October, the Rainforest Foundation UK singled out Superdrug and PROCTER and Gamble (particularly its Head and Shoulders, Pantene and Herbal Essences hair products) for criticism over the use of unsustainable palm oil. A traffic light system produced using the companies' responses to questions from the Ethical Consumer group also placed Imperial Leather, Original Source and Estee Lauder hair products in the red-light category. A separate report by Greenpeace, also issued in October into Sumatran palm oil production, accused PROCTER and Gamble and Mondelez International (formerly Kraft) of using "dirty" palm oil. The group called on the brands to recognise the environmental cost of "irresponsible palm oil production". According to the Rainforest Foundation's executive director, Simon Counsell, part of the problem is that even companies that do sign up to ethical schemes, such as the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, cannot be certain that all the oil they receive is ethically produced because of the way oil from different plantations is mixed at processing plants. "The smaller companies sell to bigger companies and it all gets mixed. Even those companies making some effort cannot be certain that what they are getting is what they have paid for," he said. Driving out of Tripa, the whole area appears to have been given over to palm oil plantations; some long-established, 20-25ft tall trees in regimented rows, others recently planted. Every now and again there is a digger, driving a new road into what little forest remains, the first stage of the process that will end with the forest burned and gone and replaced with young oil palms. […]

title: Evacuations Ordered Near Two Nuclear Plants After Warnings of Small Leaks
news: WASHINGTON -- Japanese officials issued broad evacuation orders on Saturday for people living near two nuclear power plants whose cooling systems broke down as a result of the earthquake. The officials warned that small amounts of radioactive material were likely to leak from the plants. The power plants, known as Daiichi and Daini and operated by Tokyo Electric Power, experienced critical failures of the cooling systems after the plants were shut down, as they were during the quake. About 45,000 people were affected by the evacuation order at the Daiichi plant, where those living within a six-mile radius were told to leave. The evacuation of the second plant was for a one-mile radius because ''there is no sign that radiation has been emitted outside,'' an official said. Failure of the cooling systems allowed pressure to build up beyond the design capacity of the reactors. Small amounts of radioactive vapor were expected to be released into the atmosphere to prevent damage to the containment systems, safety officials said. They said that the levels of radiation were not large enough to threaten the health of people outside the plants, and that the evacuations had been ordered as a precaution. Nuclear safety officials focused initially on the Daiichi plant. But by Saturday morning Japan had declared states of emergency for five reactors at the two plants, an escalation that added to worries about the safety of nuclear facilities in the quake-prone Japanese islands. The Daiichi and Daini plants are 10 miles apart in Fukushima Prefecture, about 150 miles north of Tokyo and close to the quake's epicenter off the coast. The plants' problems were described as serious but were far short of a catastrophic emergency like the partial core meltdown that occurred at the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa., in 1979. A Japanese nuclear safety panel said the radiation levels were 1,000 times above normal in a reactor control room at the Daiichi plant. Some radioactive material had also seeped outside, with radiation levels near the main gate measured at eight times normal, NHK, Japan's public broadcaster, quoted nuclear safety officials as saying. The safety officials said there was ''no immediate health hazard'' to residents from the leaks, which they described as ''minute,'' and people were urged to stay calm. […] With the steam-driven pump in operation, pressure valves on the reactor vessel would open automatically as pressure rose too high, or could be opened by operators. ''It's not like they have a breach; there's no broken pipe venting steam,'' said Margaret E. Harding, a nuclear safety consultant who managed a team at GENERAL ELECTRIC, the reactors' designer, that analyzed pressure buildup in reactor containments. ''You're getting pops of release valves for minutes, not hours, that take pressure back down.'' […] Daiichi, which is formally known as Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, was designed by GENERAL ELECTRIC and entered commercial service in 1971. It was probably equipped to function for some hours without emergency diesel generators, said David Lochbaum, who worked at three American reactor complexes that use G.E. technology. […]

title: GE might get bill for Hudson River cleanup
news: General Electric, put on notice this week that it'll probably have to pay $ 500 million to clean up the Hudson River, may also have to pay millions of dollars for damage its toxins caused to fish, animals and the boating industry. Officials at the Environmental Protection Agency confirmed Wednesday that they will move forward with a plan to dredge toxic chemicals from the bottom of the Hudson, one of the largest cleanup projects ever conceived. The EPA hopes the dredging purges the Hudson of PCBs, toxic chemicals GE once used to make electrical equipment in two factories in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls. The company dumped more than a million pounds of PCBs in the river from the 1940s to 1977, when the chemical was banned. […] Federal and state officials declined to speculate on how large a bill GE might be stuck with. They say they're several years from finishing a damage assessment. But other companies have had to shell out millions of dollars to compensate for natural resources destroyed in much smaller environmental disasters, such as oil spills. […]

title: BP threatened with legal case over safety of all its oil rigs: Campaigners want drilling halted at one Gulf platform and checks on all North Sea facilities
news: BP will come under further pressure tomorrow when a US consumer advocacy group, lawyers and a whistleblower will call for safety checks on all the company's rigs in the North Sea.[...] Rival oil companies such as ExxonMobil and Shell are known to have been offering help to BP with technical back-up in the Gulf but the wider industry has been distancing itself from BP. title: Sarah Palin emails:Treasure trove or waste of paper?; So far, there are no bombshells in the thousands of Sarah Palin emails released this week. But they reveal a fuller, more nuanced picture of one of the most powerful and controversial women in US politics today.

title: Lithuanian PM expects new shale gas taxation rules to be adopted this fall
news: Lithuanian PM expects new shale gas taxation rules to be adopted this fall[...]  VILNIUS, Sep 16, BNS - Lithuanian Prime Minister Algirdas Butkevicius expects that the government and the parliament this fall will approve new rules for taxing shale gas exploration and production, which will be favorable for investors and will open the way for launching a new tender for a shale gas production license. [...] The Environment Ministry proposes that shale gas production should not be taxed in the first three years, but not longer than until the start of 2020, and then be subject to a 15 percent tax rate. It is also proposed that 90 percent of the tax proceeds should go into the central government's budget and the remaining 10 percent to the local governments of locations where share gas is extracted.[...] The US energy company CHEVRON in October 2013 withdrew its bid for a shale gas exploration license in Lithuania, citing changes in the fiscal, legislative and regulatory climate as the reason.[...]

title: Conservation concern over gas pipeline
news: Torres Strait Islanders and Aborigines are divided over plans to build a $2 billion gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea to North Queensland. The pipeline, to be built by the petroleum giant CHEVRON, will extend almost 1,900 kilometres from Lake Kutubu in PNG's southern highlands, through the Kikori River delta and across the Torres Strait and Cape York Peninsula to Townsville. It has been warmly embraced by the PNG and Queensland governments but is opposed by conservationists, who claim it will damage the wilderness values of Cape York Peninsula.A spokesman for the Cairns and Far North Queensland Conservation Council, Mr Gavin McSadzean , said the pipeline would be an energy source for mining and other developments which could not otherwise proceed. "We believe this has the potential to help open up all sorts of undesirable developments on Cape York Peninsula," Mr McSadzean said. […]"Something like this has the potential to stuff up our lifestyle and there are a whole heap of environmental questions that need consideration," he said.[…] The company's technical manager, Mr Mike Metcalf, said care would be taken to minimise damage.

title: IN BRIEF
news: WASHINGTON: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has discovered carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide in the atmosphere of another planet, in a key step for finding extraterrestrial life. […] ANCHORAGE: The millions of dollars Exxon Mobil Corp has surrendered as punishment for the Prince William Sound oil spill have started hitting the streets, nearly 20 years after the disaster. Commercial fishermen who joined in the lawsuit against Exxon reported receiving direct deposits in their bank accounts this week. Paper cheques are expected to be sent next week. The payments mark the beginning of a process to distribute $US383 million ($582million) among nearly 33,000 commercial fishermen and other plaintiffs.

title: Legal Analysis: Macondo's worrying example
news: HIGHLIGHT: The US authorities' response to the Macondo blow-out has triggered copy-cat behaviour by other governmental bodies. This means environmental damage liability is emerging as one of the biggest single exposures for energy players and their risk carriers. Nigeria, Brazil, Ecuador and China. What do they have in common? In the last 12 months they have each sought to impose enormous liabilities on oil companies for pollution incidents that massively exceed, on a per barrel basis, the fines that have been or may be imposed upon BP by the US authorities for the Macondo/Deepwater Horizon spill. [...] The recent Nigerian fine of $5bn on Shell for the Bonga FPSO incident amounts to $125,000 per barrel of oil spilt. And the Chinese have imposed a fine on ConocoPhillips that is approaching nearly $1m per barrel of oil. The claim being brought by the Brazilian public prosecutor against CHEVRON amounts to a staggering $4.5m per barrel of oil spilt. [...] The $20bn civil damages claim brought in Brazil against CHEVRON for the Frade spill is also explained in the court pleadings as being primarily informed by its environmental impact. [...]

title: Multinational firms included in Chinese environmental blacklist
news: Excerpt from report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency). Beijing, 27 October: Nestle Shanghai, Changchun PEPSI and Panasonic Battery (Shanghai) Co. Ltd. These are just three subsidiaries of some of the world's leading multinationals that have been included on a blacklist for violating environmental regulations in China. The list has been compiled by a Beijing-based NGO, the Institute of Public and Environmental Affairs, headed by renowned Chinese environmentalist Ma Jun."The blacklist was drawn up according to the information released by local environmental protection bureaus across China over the past three years," said Ma."Those multinational companies have violated the basic environmental laws and regulations of China," Ma said. [passage omitted] "I was surprised by the finding," said Ma, who has been an environmental consultant for many multinational companies. "These companies require their Chinese partners to obey strictly environmental regulations. But they violate the regulations themselves." Ma said.[…] In general, however, the multinational companies are better than Chinese enterprises at protecting the environment, Ma said.[…]

title: IN BRIEF; Airport Plans
news: The Board of Legislators is reviewing a decision by a State Supreme Court justice in White Plains blocking a proposal by General Electric to build a $20 million hangar and seven-acre extension of a runway for company jets at Westchester County Airport, the Board's Chairman, George S. Latimer, said last week. Justice John P. DiBlasi ruled last month that the Board and former County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke failed to conduct an adequate analysis of the hangar's environmental impact before approving construction within 1,000 feet of the Kensico Reservoir in Valhalla.  A coalition of Hudson Valley, Westchester and Bronx environmental groups sued the Board and the county for violating state environmental laws. The plaintiffs, including the Riverkeeper Fund, the Croton Watershed Clean Water Coalition, the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater and the New York Public Interest Research Group, among others, said the project would supplant natural habitat with concrete and other impenetrable manmade materials and permit storm water runoff and pollutants from the airport to degrade the water supply. General Electric officials have said that the project would not harm water quality and would comply with environmental regulations. Chairman Latimer, who was one of three Legislators voting for further study of the GE proposal under the previous administration, said that if members of the current Board wanted to appeal Judge DiBlasi's decision, they should do so.

title: National News Briefs; Exxon Valdez Skipper Again Denies Fault
news: The Exxon Valdez skipper, Joseph J. Hazelwood, is asserting again that the 1989 accident that led to the spill of 11 million gallons of oil in Prince William Sound was not his fault. In an interview with the CBS News program "60 Minutes" to be shown on Sunday, Mr. Hazelwood blamed the third mate, Greg Cousins, who was on the bridge and did not turn the tanker away from Bligh Reef despite orders to do so.  Mr. Hazelwood told CBS that he realized the world viewed him "as some drunken fool," but he denied having been intoxicated on March 24, 1989, when the tanker struck the reef, hours after leaving Valdez, Alaska. He said he had at least three drinks of vodka earlier that evening, but he said his mistake was to leave Mr. Cousins in charge as the tanker moved from the Valdez Arm into the sound. "I never would have left the bridge if I had any idea about what was going to happen," Mr. Hazelwood said. Mr. Cousins could not be reached for comment. In the 1994 civil trial against Exxon, which resulted in a $5 billion verdict against the company, Mr. Cousins said he was not sure why he had not ordered the right turn that would have taken the tanker away from the reef.

title: How the Met Office operates; THE WEATHERMEN
news: THE Met Office operates as a subsidiary of the Ministry of Defence but charges customers, including the taxpayer, for its various services.[…] Last year, the Met Office unveiled a new £33million super-computer, which is capable of carrying out 100 trillion calculations every second. The IBM computer, which is housed in a room the size of two football pitches in Exeter, was supposed to help improve accuracy in forecasting and provide data on the hazards of climate change. But there was criticism after it emerged that the machine had a huge carbon footprint, producing tons of carbon dioxide a year.[…]

title: Only two species have recovered since Exxon Valdez spill
news: A decade after the Exxon Valdez spilled millions of litres of crude oil off Prince William Sound in Alaska, most of the fish and wildlife species that were injured have not fully recovered, a new report said Tuesday.
