Only two out of the 28 species listed as being injured - the river otter and bald eagle - are considered to have recovered, said the report, by a coalition of U.S. government and Alaska agencies working to help restore the region.

title: Go green while waiting for green products
news: HAVE you ever thought that the information and communications technology (ICT) equipment that you use and throw away contribute to increasing energy consumption and e-waste every year? Well, the United Nations Environment Programme estimates that about 50 million tonnes of e-waste are generated worldwide each year at an annual rate of three to five per cent. Although we can't deny the benefits that ICT products bring about, their usage has placed a heavy burden on our natural resources.  The amount of water and energy used for producing these products is high, and the energy these products consume during their use is high, too. Realising the effects such products have on the environment, major ICT vendors are now moving towards producing what they term as "green IT". Research company Forrester Research says vendors like Hewlett-Packard, IBM, Dell, INTEL and Sun Microsystems are investing significant resources in their green initiatives such as energy-efficient servers, data centre power and cooling solutions, cleaner manufacturing and device recycling programmes. These solutions are said to use less energy, but produce the same computing power. On the consumer side, companies like Apple, HP and Dell are said to be in the process of producing green PCs, which are made from non-toxic materials, can run on low energy, and built to be taken apart. These new machines are also highly upgradable and have a longer life of up to eight years. Forrester Research points out that new environmentfriendly products may be slightly more expensive than regular products, but their total cost of ownership will be lower and in the long run its usage costs will be lower as well. These green products, however, will only be in real production in the next two or three years. For the time being, we as consumers can play our part. For example, we can practise refurbishing used equipment, or donating used IT equipment to schools, charities or emerging countries. By doing this, not only can we save our environment, but also play our part in helping our community.

title: Sun makes green claim for server chip
news: LOOKING to leapfrog its rivals, computer maker Sun Microsystems has announced an "eco-friendly" server chip it claims will improve performance and require less electricity than competing microprocessors. The UltraSparc T1 processor, codenamed Niagara, has eight computing engines on a single chip, each core capable of handling up to four tasks at once.  The company expects to ship systems based on the processor by the end of the year. The new chip uses about 70W of power on average, considerably less than the 150W to 20W required by server chips from Intel or IBM, Sun said.[…]

title: A small but cool way to change the world; In the first in a new series of features looking at innovation in the Tees Valley, environment correspondent KELLEY PRICE investigates NanoHex - a revolutionary cooling system that could slash greenhouse gas emissions on everything from high-speed trains to data centres, which is being commercialised at Wilton.
news: HAVE you ever thought about how much CO² your daily Google quests send into the atmosphere? The search engine giant, which hit the headlines last week over internet use in China, runs some of the most efficient data retrieval centres in the world and has launched a green energy division because it cannot buy enough renewable electricity to satisfy its needs. But every time a search button is pressed - and 213 million are pressed every day - a little bit of carbon goes shooting into the atmosphere as somewhere a vast internet brain gets going on your request. Now Wilton-based Centre for Process Innovation (CPI) has begun a three-year pounds 7.5m search of its own - to turn cutting-edge nanotechnology into the world's most efficient liquid coolant for computer server farms. It looks like a bowl of dirty bathwater -but the state-of-the-art process uses particles so small that a few million would fit on to a pin head. Experts at CPI have teamed up with lead NanoHex partner Thermacore, based at Ashington, and a consortium of front-running European companies and research centres to bring the groundbreaking product to market.  Thanks to CPI's efforts, through its Enterprise Europe Network (EEN) initiative in partnership with One North East, around pounds 5.5m has been awarded from the EC's Framework 7 funding for research and development. […]

title: A clash of law firms in CHEVRON-Ecuador suit
news: Lawsuits are flying in the bitter dispute over allegations that CHEVRON is responsible for polluting a Rhode Island-size swath of the Amazon rain forest in eastern Ecuador over more than 25 years of oil drilling and exploration. One of the law firms in the pollution case against CHEVRON, Patton Boggs of Washington, has sued the oil giant and its outside counsel, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, accusing them of using threats, bogus litigation strategies, and attacks on its reputation to derail the case. The suit, filed Monday, is in response to a complaint by CHEVRON filed Oct. 2 against the Ecuadoran plaintiffs and some of their lawyers. The CHEVRON complaint names Patton Boggs, the Philadelphia law firm Kohn, Swift & Graf, and others as coconspirators, but not defendants, in an alleged scheme to defraud and extort the company. "It has become quite clear that the company will not be content until there remains no attorney left in this country who will dare provide representation to the Ecuadorean plaintiffs," says the Patton Boggs lawsuit, filed in federal District Court in Washington.[...]The complex case began in the early 1990s, when a group of indigenous people and settlers from the Amazon rain forest in eastern Ecuador represented by Kohn Swift and others filed suit against TEXACO, which later merged with CHEVRON, in federal District Court in Manhattan. They alleged that waste by-products from oil-drilling operations had polluted ground and surface water.[...]

title: CHEVRON shifts offshore in $500m Bight Basin push
news: [...] ENERGY giant CHEVRON is preparing to spend almost $500 million on oil and gas exploration as part of a massive push into the Bight Basin off South Australia, in a departure from its primary focus on LNG projects in Western Australia. [...] The Bight Basin, part of the Great Australian Bight, is believed to be highly prospective and is similar in size to the Gulf of Mexico. [...] But the push into the basin has angered green groups, which point to BP's record as operator of the Deepwater Horizon rig that exploded in 2010, killing 11 workers and spilling an estimated 4.9 billion barrels of oil across Gulf of Mexico waters and beaches.[...]

title: Scott, Amundsen ... and now BP. How middle management conquered Antarctic: Coca-Cola and oil company fund 'life changing' course for executives near pole
news: They marched up the glacier, a sharp wind slicing at their faces, buoyed by the thought that they had joined an elite club of people who have stepped on the remote mainland of Antarctica. At their destination - a pristine white ridge mid-way up an enormous slab of ice - the men and women unfurled their flags. The corporate banners of a dozen companies, including BP, Kroll and Coca-Cola, fluttered above the last great wilderness. One man took a photo of a Coke bottle wedged in the ice. Another stripped to his boxer shorts. This week, the graduates of a controversial new brand of leadership training returned to their desks. For its corporate supporters, who paid £16,000 per employee for the trip, the course instills executives with teamwork skills and, crucially, an environmental conscience. For its critics, including a few of last week's participants, it is an indulgent booze-cruise on ice masquerading as corporate social responsibility. [...] Finally, each member of the course was asked to deliver a 30 second speech. Nearly everyone said the experience had changed them. They promised to do more for climate change and said they would make sure their boss sent someone on next year's course. [...]

title: Fighting climate change, one lawsuit at a time; BUSINESS OF GREEN
news: Over the past two decades, tobacco companies and asbestos makers have paid billions of dollars in liabilities for harming consumers with cigarettes and insulation. Now companies responsible for emitting greenhouse gases may face similarly costly legal bills for contributing to dangerous levels of global warming. […] Led by Ned Comer, a Gulf Coast resident left homeless by the storm, the plaintiffs are seeking compensation from dozens of companies, including ExxonMobil and Duke Energy, on the grounds that these companies' emissions directly contributed to global warming, which in turn raised the temperature of seawater in the Gulf of Mexico and intensified the strength of the hurricane. ''We can prove how much carbon these companies have pumped into the air with great precision,'' said Gerald Maples, a lead lawyer in the case. Among his claims against oil and coal companies: conspiracy, for funding misinformation about the reality of global warming; conducting activities that led to saltwater and hazardous materials entering plaintiffs' properties; and damages for loss of business and emotional distress. […]

title: $3.5 Billion Africa Pipeline Expected to Pass
news: With American support, the World Bank is expected to approve on Tuesday a $3.5 billion project to develop an oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about the potential for corruption and environmental damage. […] The proposed 663-mile pipeline, which would link oil fields in landlocked Chad to the Atlantic Coast of Cameroon, has stirred an outcry among environmentalists and antipoverty crusaders. They say the project will provide a boon to corrupt African officials, dislocate indigenous peoples and harm ecologically sensitive areas. The senior American official said critics had "very legitimate concerns." But after more than two years working with the oil companies, officials and independent figures in both countries, he said, planners have come "a very long way" in addressing them. […] Environmental groups contend that the companies have failed to set aside adequate money to clean up an oil spill, allocating less than $1 million, despite Dutch researchers' citing a need for $28 million. […] In addition, the support clears the way for Exxon Mobil, CHEVRON and Petronas to seek additional financing before investing $3 billion of their own, she said, adding, "It's the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval." […]

title: Nigeria; Oil And Gas Exploration And Exploitation in the Niger Delta: The Social And Demographic Challenges
news: The careless attitude of oil corporations to the dangers of oil spills led to the death of eight kids and an adult at Akassa recently. ERA monitors who visited the scene learnt that the kids met their waterloo when they bathed in the water. […] The main oil company operating in there was TEXACO, a US firm. The report also stated that "Oil industry experts had declined to comment publicly on the incident but suggested the slick might have contained toxic chemicals or chemicals used for cleaning out oil tanks" Platforms. Drilling platforms are platforms of conflict in more senses than one. They have direct impact on the environment and can significantly affect the aquatic population if they are located near spawning grounds. Besides the noise and vibrations, the water may get heated beyond tolerance levels. Pipelines. […] Oil and Conflicts. […] Conflicts between and within communities are the outcome of divisive strategies of oil companies who derive a dubious benefit from such divisions. […] In the report, Oil for Nothing, Global Exchange points accusing fingers straight at CHEVRON, Shell, Mobil, Elf and AGIP, saying they "act as a destabilizing force, pitting one community against another, and acting as a catalyst together with the military with whom they work closely to some of the violence racking the region today." Compensations for Deprivation. […]

title: The green list: Gas guzzlers: Half of the top 10 global giants still don't get it. Sally Uren reports
news: Six of the 10 largest companies on the globe come from one of the oldest and historically most carbon-intensive sectors in business: oil and gas. Between them, the oil majors shown in our table account for 91% of the total emissions of CO2. That says a lot about the scale of the challenge we face in moving to a low-carbon world. ExxonMobil takes the dubious prize for the highest emissions, responsible for 146m tonnes of carbon dioxide per annum, equivalent to the annual emissions of the United Arab Emirates. ExxonMobil is also the worst offender when it comes to total emissions relative to sales, a staggering 436 tonnes per $1m. By contrast, BP is nearly twice as efficient in its operations, emitting 261 tonnes of carbon dioxide per $1m in sales. […] Between them, the top 10 companies emit the same amount of carbon dioxide per annum as the entire UK. This is a significant amount of carbon dioxide, and in the case of four of the top 10 companies - Exxon, CHEVRON, Toyota and ConocoPhilips - individual emissions are heading in the wrong direction, with overall greenhouse gas emissions increasing between 2005 and 2006. This is at a time when scientists, politicians and economists have reached consensus that we need a serious reduction in global carbon emissions, and we need it now. […] More effort required. […]

title: BP shatters green reputation
news: [...] Producing crude oil from the tar sands - a heavy mixture of bitumen, water, sand and clay - found beneath more than 139,859 sq km of prime forest in northern Alberta, an area the size of England and Wales combined, generates up to four times more carbon dioxide than conventional drilling. The booming oil sands industry will produce 100 million tonnes of CO2 (equivalent to a fifth of Britain's entire annual emissions) a year by 2012, ensuring that Canada will miss its emission targets under the Kyoto treaty, according to environmentalist activists. The oil rush is also scarring a wilderness landscape: millions of tonnes of plant life and topsoil are scooped away in vast open-pit mines and millions of litres of water are diverted from rivers. Up to five barrels of water are needed to produce a single barrel of crude and the process requires huge amounts of natural gas. The industry, which now includes all the major oil multinationals, including the Anglo-Dutch Shell and American combine Exxon-Mobil, boasts it takes two tonnes of the raw sands to produce a single barrel of oil. [...]

title: Nigeria; Akpabio Sets Up Committee On N26.5 Billion Oil Spill Fund
news: In order to douse further tension in the core oil producing areas in Akwa Ibom State, the State Government has set up a committee comprising management staff of ExxonMobil and leaders of the host communities to discuss and proffer solutions to the payment of the N26.5 billion oil spill compensation due the territory in the state. [...]

title: TALE OF TWO VISIONS; Behind the De Soto debacle
news: Pinellas County's move to expand concessions at Fort De Soto Park died a sudden death last week after residents raised a full-throated outcry. The County Commission office was swamped with more than 1,000 telephone calls and e-mails within a week. Some commissioners said the outpouring topped any in memory. While the Fort De Soto plan shocked some, it was rooted in a yearslong effort to expand county park services and to open public land to moneymaking ventures that offset operating costs. "It wasn't like we sat around one night and said, yeah, let's do this," said assistant county administrator Jake Stowers, after the commissioners' decision. "It was a thought-out process. And quite honestly, I guess we misjudged some of the feeling in the community."[…] By 6 2005, the county had assembled a master plan that Stowers said reflected comments from the workshops. The plan called for "energizing" parks such as Fort De Soto with outdoor concerts, cafes and art exhibits.[…] Enlisting private companies to boost services at public parks is nothing new, said Paul Cozzie, Pinellas' parks and recreation director.[…] St. Petersburg environmentalist Lorraine Margeson helped rouse the opposition. She said the county failed to understand how precious unspoiled land in development-heavy Pinellas is to residents. Some plan advocates said embracing Hollywood's ideas would have little impact on the park, whose 1,136 acres are home to a beach ranked the best in the nation last year. Margeson finds that laughable. "I'm sorry, but that is just such baloney," she said. "These were not modest improvements." The county is now negotiating with PEPSI, Pinellas' official soft drink, about expanding the number of soda machines at parks. The arrangement could be worth $3.2-million to the county over 10 years. Other than the PEPSI deal, county officials say there are no plans to allow private businesses to operate in parks. They are not backing away from the concept, however - the current concessions at Fort DeSoto will be offered for the time being - but officials say they will act cautiously after the Fort De Soto plan backlash.[…]

title: Exxon CEO's endorsement should prompt politicians to take a fresh look at the idea; New life for carbon tax
news: Shocking news on the environmental front has gone almost unnoticed in Canada's news media. The boss of Exxon Mobil Corp. last week aligned himself with Al Gore, David Suzuki and Michael Ignatieff in urging Washington to adopt a carbon tax. That's right, Exxon Mobil - the company that Greenpeace once dubbed Climate Criminal No. 1. Rex Tillerson, chief executive of the company that puts a CO2-belching tiger in your tank, said that a carbon tax - that is, a tax on products that cause greenhouse-gas emissions - would be far more effective against global warming than the alternative cap-and-trade approach. The world's largest oil company has thus abandoned the fossil-fuel industry's united front for cap and trade. The industry sees cap and trade as the lesser of two evils. [...] Why urgent? Because the horse has almost left the barn. Barack Obama, who takes over the White House next week, favours cap and trade and says putting it in place will be a priority.[...]

title: G.E. Hangar Plan Is Blocked in Court
news: A justice in State Supreme Court in White Plains yesterday blocked a proposal by General Electric to build a $20 million hangar for company jets at the Westchester County Airport, lawyers for both sides in the case said. Justice John P. DiBlasi ruled that the County Board of Legislators and former County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke failed to conduct an adequate analysis of the hangar's environmental impact before they approved it in December. The hanger would have been built 1,000 feet from the Kensico Reservoir. Donald Stever, a lawyer for General Electric, said that the company had not yet decided whether it would appeal the judge's ruling. A coalition of Hudson Valley, Westchester and Bronx environmental groups had filed a lawsuit contending that the county's approval of the proposal violated state environmental laws. The groups maintained that the project and lease agreement would replace more than seven acres of forest and wetlands with concrete and asphalt and allow storm water runoff, de-icing agents and pollutants to enter the reservoir. General Electric officials have said that the project would not harm water quality and that it complied with environmental regulations. Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for Westchester County, said county officials were reviewing the ruling.

title: US court slashes payout over Exxon Valdez disaster
news: THE US Supreme Court has thrown out the record $US2.5billion in punitive damages Exxon Mobil Corp was ordered to pay for the disastrous 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill off Alaska.[...] The Exxon Valdez supertanker ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989, spilling 50million litres of oil. The spill spread oil to more than 1900km of coastline, closed fisheries and killed thousands of marine mammals and sea birds.[...] In Alaska, Riki Ott, a fisherman, scientist and environmental activist in the Prince William Sound town of Cordova, where most of the area's fishing fleet is concentrated, was disappointed.[...] John Passacantando, executive director of the environmental group Greenpeace USA, said the ruling ``makes a mockery of justice''.[...]

title: COMPANY NEWS; CHEVRONTEXACO TO CLEAN UP EMISSIONS AT 5 REFINERIES
news: CHEVRONTEXACO has agreed to spend $275 million to clean up emissions from five oil refineries, the Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday. The settlement is expected to cut harmful air emissions by 10,000 tons a year at the five refineries, which account for more than 5 percent of the nation's refining capacity, government officials said. The refineries are in Richmond and El Segundo, Calif.; Pascagoula, Miss.; Salt Lake City; and Kapolei, Hawaii. CHEVRONTEXACO will also pay a $3.5 million civil penalty and spend more than $4 million on further emission controls and other environmental projects in communities around its refineries, a Justice Department statement said.

title: At suppliers' factories, a grim backdrop to Apple's shine
news: The explosion ripped through Building A5 on a Friday evening last May, an eruption of fire and noise that twisted metal pipes as if they were discarded straws. […] That system has made it possible for Apple and hundreds of other companies to build devices almost as quickly as they can be dreamed up. […] But the workers assembling iPhones, iPads and other devices often labor in harsh environments, according to employees inside those plants, worker advocates and documents published by companies themselves. Problems range from difficult working conditions to serious safety issues. Employees work overtime in excess of legal limits, in some cases seven days a week, and live in crowded dormitories. Some say they stand so long that their legs swell so they can hardly walk. Underage workers have helped build Apple products, and the company's suppliers have illegally disposed of hazardous waste and have falsified records, according to company reports and advocacy groups who, in China, are often considered reliable, independent monitors. […]

title: Garrett last Gorgon bar -- Green light for $50bn gas project awaited
news: THE welfare of the Barrow Island mouse, the spectacled hare-wallaby, the golden bandicoot and burrowing bettong -- not to mention the flatback turtle -- are all that stands in the way of the $50 billion Gorgon gas contract with China. As Australia eyes the biggest export deal in its history, Environment Minister Peter Garrett faces the task of deciding by September 8 whether the Gorgon project passes key environmental tests, even as his ministerial colleagues tout the project as a national bonanza. Mr Rudd and his senior ministers have praised the giant Gorgon liquefied natural gas plant on Barrow Island, west of the port of Dampier in Western Australia's booming Pilbara region, all week.[...] In an unusual move, Mr Rudd congratulated ExxonMobil and the Gorgon partners, Chevron and Shell, on the progress Gorgon has made to date. [...] But a Greens spokesman said Barrow Island had 24 known species that are either endangered or extinct on the mainland of Australia.``To sign off on a deal before environmental approval is recklessly damaging to the future biodiversity of the area,'' the spokesman said. The Greens warned the spectacled hare-wallaby, golden bandicoot, Barrow Island mouse and the burrowing bettong were endemic to the island and at risk of extinction, and added there was also a threat to sea turtle populations in the area. ``The Humane Society International applied to have Barrow Island listed as National Heritage in 2006, but this was rejected by the commonwealth,'' the spokesman said.[...]

title: Coke has a bottler of a headache in India
news: LEGAL battles have rarely appeared as lopsided as the stoush between Coca-Cola and the villagers of southern India. By the end of the month, a court in the southern Indian state of Kerala is due to decide whether villagers from the bottom of the social hierarchy have the right to deny water to the world's most omnipotent commercial brand. The judgement will mark the latest skirmish in a bitter dispute between Coke and several rural communities that accuse it of parching and polluting their villages - charges the company rejects. As the protests grew, farmers and anti-globalisation activists united to launch a modern-day "Quit India" campaign against the soft drinks giant, appropriating the name of Mahatma Gandhi's 1942 call for independence from British rule. Coke's great rival, PEPSI, has been heavily criticised, too, but has failed to arouse anywhere near as much anger. A decision in favour of the villagers would be a major blow to the multinational. While Coke says it would appeal such a verdict, the biggest and most technologically advanced Coke plant in India could be closed for good. Such a ruling would provide a boost to a movement seeking to empower India's most vulnerable people in the face of a rapidly spreading corporate culture. "These companies ... are destroying our social fabric," says environmentalist Vandana Shiva. "If the Kerala court supports [the villagers'] fight for justice, that fight will be replicated across India. The subversion of basic rights, like those over water, by big companies will be stalled."[…]

title: Pragmatism rules on Barrow Island
news: Government and Greens opposition aside, the Gorgon gas project will go ahead -- if it can find customers, says energy writer Nigel Wilson. JOHN Howard this week finally buried the concept that the federal Government will fund the relocation of the $6 billion Gorgon gas project away from Barrow Island. […] The Gorgon partners repeatedly have said it would cost more than $1 billion to relocate the project on the mainland or anywhere else. Barrow Island is a Class A nature reserve. The Gorgon gas development is being pursued by an unincorporated joint venture. CHEVRONTEXACO, with a four-sevenths interest, is the operator. Shell has a two-sevenths interest and Exxon Mobil a one-seventh interest. CHEVRONTEXACO is also the operator of the Barrow Island oil operation, which began pumping oil on the environmentally sensitive island more than 40 years ago. After giving the WA Government enforceable undertakings against the risk of environmental damage at Barrow, the Gorgon partners are not keen to reopen the debate on whether the project would be better off elsewhere. […]

title: U-turn on review of park's impact
news: A specific study on how a Disney theme park would affect the environment will be done after the Government announced a change in the rules yesterday.  Theme parks in general will be added to a list of developments which must have an individual Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA).  The changes were made by the Environmental Protection Department (EPD) after the South China Morning Post revealed the specifics of the proposed Disney project would not be studied by themselves, but only as part of a broader study.   The Government had said it was planning to rely on a "cumulative" overall assessment of the impact of a large tourism development which "included a theme park".[…]  Friends of the Earth, which had threatened to apply for a judicial review if the specific impact of the Disney project was not addressed, welcomed the move. […]

title: No EC decision on shale gas regulation as yet - commissioner in Vilnius (updates)
news: [...] Lithuanian Minister of Environment Valentinas Mazuronis said that EU ministers were scheduled to discuss shale gas regulation at a meeting in Vilnius later in the day. Large-scale shale gas production takes place in the United States, but European countries have different positions on the issue. Critics say hydraulic fracturing used for the extraction of shale gas may cause huge environmental damage. The Government of Lithuania is yet to decide whether to allow US company CHEVRON to explore for shale gas in Western Lithuania. Supporters say shale gas extraction would be an alternative to Russian gas and would bring economic benefit to the state.

title: AGA fights to enlarge its market share
news: Gas. THE Australian Gas Association is taking off its gloves in the fight to win a greater market share for gas in power generation. AGA chief executive Peter Dalkin said there was concern natural gas's share of the primary energy market had plateaued in the past four years. He said the association "had to decided to face fully impediments to industry". A main platform of the association's new war machine will be the greenhouse issue. Electricity generation by gas, as opposed to coal or diesel, significantly reduced greenhouse emissions but the association had been "pretty relaxed" about the issue in the past, Mr Dalkin said. ASA chairman Grant King said a key industry forum -Change and Challenge for Australia's Gas Industry -to be held in Brisbane tomorrow -would mark the start of work on a new industry strategy to help ensure gas consumption growth. […] Nevertheless, a recent ABARE study concluded Australian energy consumption would be 6087 petajoules by 2015 compared with 4810 now.[…] A large portion of the growth assumes the go-ahead for CHEVRON's proposed $2.4 billion pipeline to link Papua New Guinea gas fields to Queensland. The proponents of the pipeline have said sufficient customers can be found to justify the pipeline but a go-ahead from Comalco for a proposed $1.5 billion alumina project in Gladstone would provide a significant boost to the project's development.

title: Commission softens chemical rules
news: The European Commission has softened plans for new environmental rules on the use of chemicals which European industry and the Irish Government have criticised as costly and unworkable.Changes to the text of the regulations were made by the Commission this week after receiving about 6,000 comments from European firms, governments, lobby groups and individuals.Several environmental groups yesterday criticised the decision to water down the proposed regulations, and Greenpeace warned that the weaker rules would enable industry to continue using chemicals that caused infertility. The Government had lobbied strongly against the proposed rules and warned the Commission they would cost jobs across several industry sectors.It is understood the Tanaiste, Ms Harney, was concerned that the new rules would pose a threat to the State industry's global competitiveness, and place a major financial burden on multinational firms such as INTEL.[…]

title: What's Kind to Nature Can Be Kind to Profits
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC would like you to know that it makes the world's most efficient electric generators, part of its Ecomagination program of clean technologies. BP, which used to be an abbreviation for British Petroleum but is now the company's official name, is promoting itself as ''Beyond Petroleum,'' with solar cells and wind. […] These industrial Goliaths want to be Jolly Green Giants. They have investors to impress and public images to maintain so that they can pursue high-profile projects that need government approvals. They may also have profit motives; most of the green technologies that make money now are profitable only because of government tax incentives or subsidies. But if oil and natural gas become expensive enough, some technologies could become commercially viable on an unsubsidized basis. […] Business is going green for many reasons, not just the most obvious one, public image. There is also competitive advantage. […] GENERAL ELECTRIC, which once polluted the Hudson River with PCB's as it manufactured transformers, now promises that it will invest $1.5 billion annually in research in cleaner technologies by 2010, up from $700 million in 2004. G.E. also says it will reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 1 percent by 2012. With business as usual, the company says, it would have increased those emissions by 40 percent. […]

title: Nigeria's Escravos gas project starts up
news: Nigeria's Escravos gas project, Delta state, officially began late last year.  The project -- 6,650 b/d of LPG and 1,740 b/d of condensate from 165 MMscfd of gas -- is the first attempt to rid Nigeria of incessant flares that have lit the Delta skies.A joint venture of CHEVRON Nigeria Ltd. and Nigerian National Petroleum Corp. (NNPC), the project began processing gas in November 1997.NNPC and CHEVRON are joint partners in the exploration of oil and utilization of the country's resources.  NNPC owns 60% of the project, CHEVRON, the operator, 40%. […]Operator CHEVRON Nigeria Ltd. believes that the Escravos project will enable the joint venture to utilize a significant portion of the gas reserves, thus reducing gas flaring.[…]Project rootsOften, the major stumbling block to gas utilization has been disposal of residue gas from processing: It makes no sense to build a gas plant and end up flaring much of the gas.[…]As a result, about 75-80% of the associated gas is still flared, representing a loss of economic and environmental benefits, while only 25% is utilized as fuel gas in the field or re-injected.[…]THE AUTHOR. Marizu A. Nwokoma is a gas engineer with CHEVRON Nigeria Ltd. with 2 years' experience in the industry. […]

title: Corporate logos get softer for harsh economic times
news: The world economy is in a midswan dive. Wallets are in lockdown. So how does a company get people to feel just a little bit better about buying more stuff? (And perhaps burnish a brand that has taken some public relations lumps?) Behold the new breed of corporate logo - nonthreatening, reassuring, playful, even childlike. Not emblems of distant behemoths, but faces of friends. ''A logo is to a company what a face is to a person,'' said Michel Tuan Pham, a professor of marketing at the Columbia Business School, in New York. ''It's hard to memorize facts about a person when you only know their name but you haven't seen their face.'' […] Friendly flourishes: Kraft Foods has joined Amazon.com and Hasbro, all represented by logos that smile. And to further lighten the corporate mood, whimsy in the form of sprigs and bursts has been appended to several big brands. Wal-Mart's old mark was navy blue, but it felt Red State. The company has been under heavy attack for its labor and environmental practices, bruising its brand in bluer quarters. A major image overhaul is under way, and a new logo is starting to appear across the United States. The military-style Wal-Mart star has given way to a yellow twinkle that punctuates a new message: This is a company that cares, with fast and friendly service and a fresh, innovative outlook, according to Linda Blakley, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman. Ms. Williams, of Wharton, said the softer Wal-Mart logo serves another purpose: to stand apart from the bright reds and louder typography of its main competitors, Kmart and Target. While Target's design says bold and cutting-edge, Wal-Mart's sends a signal that it is approachable and sincere, she said.

title: Court turns down Alaskan village, again, on damage claims from GHG emissions
news: A federal appeals court has ruled that, in keeping with the US Supreme Court's line of thinking, the Clean Air Act displaces federal common law of public nuisance when it comes to greenhouse gas issues. The court denied a tiny Alaska village's arguments for millions of dollars from oil and power companies, plus the largest US coal company, to compensate for land loss the village attributes to climate change. But the battle against the nation's largest emitters -- ExxonMobil, BP, Shell Oil, American Electric Power, Duke Energy, Peabody Energy and others -- raised by the coastal village may not be over. Matt Pawa of the Pawa Law Group in Boston, which represented the Village of Kivalina, home to Inupiat Native Alaskans, said last week he was still consulting with his client to determine what would be the next step. [...]

title: How we learnt to embrace our waste
news: Confronting the enormous cost of our wasteful ways, we've turned to recycling, composting and even worm farms to help us clean up our act.[…]  Says Sue Dawson, director of environmental policy at the NSW EPA: "Instead of taking waste as a given - albeit a resource we were now trying hard to recycle/re-use - the impetus was to look back a step, and discover how we could avoid waste being created in the first place." […] "Some motor vehicle manufacturers, particularly VW and BMW, have proactively started to design cars so they can later be disassembled, upgraded, and parts re-used or recycled, instead of sent to the wreckers. "The computer and business machine industry, a culprit in producing massive waste, has responded to criticism. In America, IBM and Xerox are among companies who have viewed the introduction of industry take-back and product stewardship legislation as a given, and adopted new design-for-the-environment strategies," says Dawson.The guidelines are to consider re-use and recycling at the initial design stages, then follow a later-life hierarchy of redistributing computer equipment to new customers if it is in working order, restoring and repairing it, converting it to another product, or salvaging and recycling parts and materials, so nothing is sent to landfills.[…]

title: Oil and Water; In 1, the tanker Jessica spilled its cargo near the; Galapagos Islands. Here's how the disaster ranks; among the EXXON Valdezes of history
news: ATLANTIC EMPRESS (1979)  Litres of oil spilled: 391 million  Estimated damage: $150 million (all currency in U.S. dollars) […] EXXON VALDEZ (1989)  Litres of oil spilled: 42 million  Estimated damage: $8 billion.    Joseph Hazelwood (right) captained his crew right into an Alaskan reef, dumping oil in the waters of Prince William Sound. EXXON has already paid $3 billion in cleanup costs and fines, but it is appealing an additional $5-billion charge in punitive damages.[…]

title: Contaminated soil cleaned up by bacteria at Toronto site  Sunoco says land can be redeveloped as entertainment complex after inexpensive treatment used in EXXON spill removes oil, diesel fuel
news: Contaminated soil from a former fuel plant in Toronto's industrial port has been rendered harmless by a process that encourages microscopic bugs to feast on pollution.  In one of the largest and most successful cleanup projects of its kind, the site of the Sunoco fuel storage and lubricant packaging operations was treated over the past three months with harmless bacteria already living in the soil.[…]  First proved effective on a large scale when it accelerated the cleanup of part of the EXXON-Valdez oil spill in Alaska, the method is especially good at dealing with organic compounds such as hydrocarbons from the petroleum industry. The bacteria attack the compounds by eating the carbon bonds that hold them together. The hydrocarbon is then broken down into benign carbon dioxide and water.[…]

title: Ghana; Everyone is a Winner From Gas Project - Say World Bank Officials
news: The construction of pipes and concrete structures, being the first phase of Ghana component of the West African Gas Pipeline Project in Tema has started. […] According to the Senior Environment Officer of the World Bank Group, Robert McDonough the Bank staff of the West African Gas Pipeline are working very hard to ensure the first gas is delivered by December 2006. He said the next phase would be to build a compressor station in Nigeria before off-shore pipelines would be constructed. […]McDonough debunked fears of environmental degradation that would come with the project, stressing that whatever environmental hazards that would accompany the project would be negligible. […] Asked what would happen should Ghana discover gas in large quantities, McDonough said Ghana could ship the gas through the pipeline since Ghana partly owns the pipeline. Ghana has 16.3 percent of the WAPCo's shares, two representatives on the Board's company and one or more positions in the executive management. CHEVRON TEXACO, Shell, Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation and Shell Development Company of Nigeria own 36, percent, 17, percent and 18 percent respectively. […] They said the interest of CHEVRON and other multi-nationals in the project is driven by the profit motive. McDonough however says the World Bank is interested in reducing world poverty and would not allow the petroleum companies to rip-off consumers. […]

title: ENERGY; Exxon shrugs off climate change business fears
news: [...] Exxon Mobil Corp. sees little threat to its asset base from the growing fears about climate change, although critics accused the company of taking a remarkably rosy view given the dire warnings in the latest United Nations' climate report. The Irving, Tex., energy giant has waded into the debate over the so-called "carbon bubble" in which environmentalists and some institutional investors suggest that companies with large reserves of coal or oil could face significant financial losses as the world moves to reduce carbon dioxide emissions that result from burning those fossil fuels. [...] A group of institutional shareholders - including some of the biggest pension plans in the United States - have urged major energy companies to provide better assessment and disclosure of the risk to their business plans if the global government embraces a "low carbon" future. [...] "As always with Exxon, it's two steps forward and one step back," Andrew Logan, director of the oil and gas program at Ceres, a non-profit organization that has spearheaded the carbon disclosure effort, said Tuesday. [...]

title: FEAR BUBBLES UP FROM NEW CHEVRON SPILL
news: Heard on the Street column on harsh market punishment of CHEVRON and other oil companies over recent, relatively minor spills since BP's disastrous Gulf of Mexico spill last year drove politicians to get tough with offenders; graph (M)

title: Activists vow to continue oil rig protest
news: ENVIRONMENTAL activists trying to stop an oil drill ship from moving yesterday vowed to swim in front of it for as long as they could. Greenpeace said swimmers surrounded the Stena Carron 100 miles north of Shetland almost 24 hours ago to stop it leaving for a drilling site in deep water in the North Sea. The swimmers are wearing drysuits and dived into the North Sea after legal threats put an end to earlier action. Swimmers and kayakers are taking it in turns to surround the ship. The first group of four swimmers left Greenpeace's Esperanza ship at 1.30pm yesterday by inflatable speedboat and got into the water, halting  their target's journey. One of the swimmers, Leila Deen, said: It's just crazy that i' s up to us to do this when this oil ship should be stopped by a government ban on deep water drilling. But we're going to continue blocking the Carron for as long as we can. It comes after Greenpeace activists spent four days in a  survival pod  dangling off the vessel's anchor. The ship's operator, US energy giant CHEVRON, was granted an injunction at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Friday night ordering the campaigners to move on safety grounds.

title: MTBE Class Action
news: Residents of 16 states have filed a class-action lawsuit against 10 oil companies, charging them with negligence and conspiracy to conceal potential environmental and public health risks associated with the fuel additive methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE).  The suit, which was filed last month in Madison County Circuit Court in Illinois, names as defendants Atlantic Richfield, BP Amoco, Citgo, Conoco, ExxonMobil, Equilon, CHEVRON, Phillips, Shell, and Texaco.  MTBE became the most widely used oxygenate after the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments required gasoline in densely populated areas to contain 2.7% oxygen by weight.

title: Brazil wants closure
news: Brazilian federal prosecutors have called for CHEVRON and the drilling contractor Transocean to shut down their operations in the country after an offshore oil spill last month. They are suing the companies for $10.6 billion (£6.8 billion) in compensation for alleged environmental damage caused by the spill. The order to suspend operations, if granted, could close off some of CHEVRON's most promising oilfields. The company, which has already been fined $28 million by the authorities, has said that it takes full responsibility for the spill. (Emily Ford)

title: 3 dominant oil firms split on global warming
news: The U.S.-European rift on global warming extends to the world's three dominant oil companies. BP Amoco P.L.C. and Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which are based in Europe, have joined the campaign to reduce global warming. EXXON MOBIL Corp., which has its headquarters in Irving, Texas, remains outside the campaign, arguing in newspaper advertisements and speeches for a more cautious approach. President Bush will argue for the approach that EXXON MOBIL prefers when he meets with European leaders today in Sweden. He will press for more research into climate change rather than setting levels immediately for pollutant reductions as the European Union wants to do. BP, Shell and EXXON all want the same thing: to make money while the use of their core products - oil and natural gas - is under attack as a likely cause of global warming. Burning oil and natural gas creates carbon dioxide, whether the purpose is to drive cars, power air conditioners, or illuminate rooms. Scientists label carbon dioxide a "greenhouse gas" because they believe its emission into the atmosphere contributes to the rise in the Earth's temperature known as global warming. The initial response of the oil industry was to question this theory, which defines EXXON MOBIL's approach to this day. The company says it views global warming and the "potential" for human-induced climate change seriously. But it opposes restrictions on greenhouse-gas emissions without further research on the causes of climate change.[…] Reducing greenhouse-gas emissions makes good business sense when it results from cutting energy use and, therefore, a company's costs. EXXON MOBIL is reducing its greenhouse-gas emissions that way, too. "We haven't thrown a target out there," said Ken Cohen, vice president for public affairs at EXXON MOBIL. "We're just doing it."

title: Kazakhs halt Shell oil project
news: Shell has run into trouble over another big oil project in the former Soviet Union with the government of Kazakhstan halting development of the Kashagan field alleging environmental violations and cost over-runs in a move with ominous similarities to the Sakhalin-2 row. Shell is one of a number of western partners in the Agip Kazakhstan North Caspian Operating Company along with ENI of Italy and ExxonMobil of America in the Kashagan field - one of the biggest oil discoveries ever with commercial reserves of up to 16bn barrels of oil.[...]

title: Shale criminal charges stun drilling industry
news: Pennsylvania Attorney General Kathleen Kane's decision to prosecute a major Marcellus Shale natural-gas driller for a 2010 wastewater spill has sent shock waves through the industry. But environmentalists Wednesday hailed the prosecution of the Exxon Mobil Corp. subsidiary as a departure from the soft treatment they say the industry has received from Pennsylvania regulators. "We have been very concerned about enforcement in the Marcellus, and we welcome the attorney general's taking an active role," said Myron Arnowitt, Pennsylvania director of Clean Water Action. [...] Industry leaders said the prosecution of a company for what they called an inadvertent spill creates a hostile business environment. [...]

title: Corrections
news: An article on 7 18 about a lawsuit by New York State seeking the cleanup of an oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the number of defendants. (The error was repeated in an article on 7 19 about cleanup efforts at the site.) The suit names only one company -- Exxon Mobil -- not five. The state had previously signaled its intent to sue four other companies -- BP, CHEVRON, KeySpan and Phelps Dodge -- but did not do so.

title: Environmentalists play the Exxon Valdez oil spill card again on the Great Barrier Reef
news: Andrew Jeremijenko on ABC2 News Breakfast yesterday on the threat from grounded coal carrier Shen Neng 1. WE've seen in the Exxon Valdez that there have been long-ranging effects and we shouldn't be allowing these things to happen. Andrew Wight on Fairfax's Brisbane Times on March 25 2009 plays the Exxon Valdez card: QUEENSLAND authorities had failed to heed the lessons of the Exxon Valdez oil spill and have responded inadequately to the massive catastrophe unfolding on Moreton Bay, experts said yesterday. Occupational and environmental medical specialist, Andrew Jeremijenko said history was repeating itself off the southeast Queensland coast. ``Moreton Bay is just as vulnerable as Prince William Sound. As more of the oil gets to shore, we are going to see the same effects occur [as in Alaska],'' he said.[...]

title: Programme summary of Uzbek TV "Axborot" news 1600 gmt 4 Jan 12
news: [...] 2. 0135 The agrarian and water economy committee of the Senate, the Uzbek parliament's upper house, holds a seminar in Samarqand on issues of the development of the agricultural sector in the region. Video shows a meeting; interviews. [...] 6. 2100 Foreign news: People on the Earth might watch meteor shower these days; One dies and about a dozen receive injuries in a storm in UK; Austrian police arrest a couple on charges illegal sale of steroids; Rescue work of reefer Irina in the Sea of Okhotsk becomes complicated due to strong wind; Ecuadorian court upholds a ruling that CHEVRON should pay 18bn dollars for environmental damage.[...]

title: It's Gosford and Wyong v COCA-COLA
news: TWO Wyong councillors have mounted an unprecedented show of support for Gosford council in its legal battle with COCA-COLA Amatil. Councillors Greg Best and Doug Eaton have put a notice of motion to discover what assistance can be offered to Gosford in its legal fight with the bottling behemoth. COCA-COLA has filed an action against Gosford council after it was refused permission to treble its water extraction and bottling activities. The company's proposal would see 41 million litres per year extracted for its Peats Ridge plant -- 0.2 per cent of the Coast's total water use. Mr Best yesterday raised the matter formally at a Gosford-Wyong Joint Water Authority Meeting, which resolved to support the move. Mr Best said the unifying motion made the message to COCA-COLA Amatil clear. "It's making a very unambiguous statement on behalf of the Central Coast -- hands off our water supply," he said.[…] The motion will be put before Wyong council on May 25. Mr Best said he expected strong support for the proposal, given the Coast was in its worst drought for 100 years. But COCA-COLA Amatil has publicly declared it is confident of a victory in the Land and Environment Court. Company spokesman Alec Wagstaff said the company's planned activities would not adversely affect the local water supply.[…]

title: Turtles threatened by gas project in Australia
news: As the rising sun spread its warming rays across the beach, the sand stirred almost imperceptibly to reveal the tiny beaks of three flatback turtle hatchlings. The peak nesting season is just drawing to a close for the threatened species, found only in Australia. [...] Now, they are facing a new threat: development.[...] Chevron and its minority partners in the venture, EXXON MOBIL and Shell, say that Barrow is the only commercially viable location for the plant, which will liquefy gas piped from the Greater Gorgon gas fields 70 kilometers, or 43 miles, out to sea before it is then poured into enormous tankers. The companies say that the project can coexist with the wildlife on Barrow and have made public hundreds of documents justifying their position and detailing plans to offset the impact the project will have.[...] Environmentalists, however, dispute the contention of the partners that only Barrow will do, and say that not even their best efforts can prevent such a large project from causing irreversible damage to the unique environment of the island. In 6, the state of Western Australia's own Environmental Protection Authority agreed, rejecting the project.[...]

title: CORPORATE REPORT: CHEVRON
news: US Court of Appeals dismisses bid by CHEVRON to block group of Ecuadoreans from collecting  $18.2 billion judgment over environmental damage; separately, prosecutor in Brazil plans to file criminal charges against CHEVRON and some managers over offshore oil spill (S)

title: The EXXON Valdez of Macquarie St
news: NUDIST MP Richard Jones has tarnished his green credentials by dumping his rundown car and its growing oil puddle at Parliament House while he tours the world for a month. The engine oil slick underneath the mid-1980s Toyota Corona Avante has led to the car being dubbed by fellow MPs as "the EXXON Valdez of Macquarie Street".[…]

title: Ogilvy's sacking by CHEVRON highlights conflict of interest issue
news: [...] CHEVRON's decision to end its relationship with two Ogilvy agencies after it "uncovered a serious, material conflict of interest" calls attention to the challenge firms continue to face sorting client conflicts, agency leaders tell PRWeek.[...] On the surface, the termination appeared to result from the actions of one account director. Felipe Benitez from Ogilvy PR gave a presentation about "Strategic Communications for Environmental Defense" to Amazon Watch, a nonprofit that represents indigenous peoples in the Amazon Basin. Amazon Watch supports a decades-long, multi-billion dollar lawsuit that claims CHEVRON subsidiary TEXACO is responsible for environmental damage to the Ecuadorian rainforest. Sometime after Benitez's May 9 presentation , the multinational energy giant terminated its contract with both Ogilvy PR and Ogilvy Government Relations. The latter was a key lobbying firm for CHEVRON in the US on a number of issues, including the lawsuit in Ecuador that recently expanded to Canada.[...] Amazon Watch, of course, is not a competitor of CHEVRON. But its interests are diametrically opposed to those of the multinational energy company.[...]

title: BUSH SCALES BACK OIL-DRILLING PLAN IN GULF OF MEXICO
news: The Bush administration sharply scaled back its plans today to drill for oil and natural gas in the Gulf of Mexico, trying to defuse an issue that has pitted President Bush against his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida. […] Administration officials acknowledged that the decision reflected the president's efforts to find a way out of a political quandary that involved family ties, splits in the Republican Party and attacks by environmentalists on Mr. Bush's energy policies. […] CHEVRON, BP, Exxon Mobil, ARCO and Shell Oil are among the corporations seeking to drill in the eastern gulf. The companies promoted drilling in the area as environmentally safe and economically sound. While the revised plan was praised by some Florida environmentalists, most national environmental groups are opposed to any new drilling in the gulf and were quick to criticize the administration's compromise plan. They argued that offshore drilling poses the threat of oil spills. Drilling also pollutes the water, they said, while pipelines needed to transport oil and gas create hazards when crossing coastal wetlands. […]

title: 'Downwinders' case finally goes to court
news: SPOKANE, Wash. -- Dolores Hein never thought much about the winds that sweep across the rolling wheat fields in eastern Washington until 1980, when the eruption of Mount St. Helens, 300 miles to the west, dropped nine truckloads of ash on her family's farm just south of here. That led Hein to wonder whether any radioactive material had drifted over to the farm from the Hanford nuclear research site, which is only 145 miles west of the farm. Could that explain her husband's thyroid cancer and two daughters' thyroid disease? In 1986, after the U.S. government made public files documenting the secret releases of radioactive emissions from Hanford during World War II and the Cold War, Hein joined more than 2,300 other "downwinders" in the region in suing the companies that built and operated Hanford for the government during those years. […] What's at stake If the jury sides with the plaintiffs, the financial awards could run to tens of millions of dollars. Any awards would be paid by the U.S. government, because its agreement with its contractors, DuPont and GENERAL ELECTRIC, protects the companies from liability. The government is paying the contractors' legal fees. The (Spokane) Spokesman Review, citing government documents, reported in 2000 that those fees had topped $60 million. The report could not be independently confirmed. Attorneys for DuPont and GENERAL ELECTRIC argue there is no connection between residents' illnesses and Hanford. […]

title: Kyoto could affect your portfolio's health
news: [...]  In the energy-intensive chemical industry, companies will need to prepare for higher operating costs because of higher energy prices and adjust their product pipeline to satisfy the demand for clean technology-related specialty chemicals. E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. is the leader in this sector. The company has a sophisticated GHG emission reduction strategy, trades emission credits and developed a clean energy fuel cells business in 2001. [...]  In the oil and gas sector, BP PLC, Statoil of Norway and Royal Dutch/Shell Group are in front of the pack. Shell and BP have invested the most in the solar, wind and the hydrogen economy. Both BP and Statoil have shifted assets from coal to gain greater natural gas exposure in recent years. EXXON MOBIL Corp., in contrast, denies it makes any contribution to global warming and despite having the highest GHG intensity in its operations, is alone among oil majors in not having a GHG emissions reduction strategy in place. [...]

title: Pepsi aims to cut plastic use with lighter bottles
news: PepsiCo Inc. is reducing the amount of plastic it uses in bottles of some non-soda drinks, in the latest move by beverage companies to appeal to consumers concerned about environmental waste and global warming. [...] Pepsi, Coca-Cola Co., Nestlé SA and others have been shrinking the weight of polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, bottles in recent years as public criticism of plastic bottles has grown. Environmental activists say plastic bottles create waste and increase consumption of oil, the basic ingredient. Last year, Nestlé introduced a 12.5-gram half-litre bottle for its Poland Spring, Deer Park, Ozarka and other brands. Coke has "lightweighted" its Dasani bottle. The moves also help companies reduce costs as they grapple with increased prices of commodities. [...]

title: CHEVRON case 'may hurt' investments in Indonesia
news: [...] The ongoing investigation over alleged fraudulent practices within energy giant CHEVRON's environmental remediation project in Riau province may harm the investment climate in Indonesia's oil and gas sector, a top official has said. Upstream oil and gas regulator BPMigas chief R Priyono said yesterday the supervisory body had been concerned that the case development would make oil and gas investors "think twice" before signing production-sharing contracts (PSCs) in the sector. "We are worried because basically all disputes coming up from projects under PSCs should be settled under the civil code instead of the criminal law. Investors will see [the CHEVRON case] as a bad precedent," he said. The executive was commenting on an investigation at the Attorney-General's Office (AGO) over alleged graft practices in CHEVRON's bioremediation project at its oil fields in Riau. Bioremediation is a method to normalise soil that has been contaminated by waste from oil production activities.[...] After further investigation, the AGO concluded that the bioremediation programme was not successfully implemented as planned because the soil at CHEVRON's oil fields in Riau was still polluted.[...]

title: Calpine can sell Solutia claim
news: A Manhattan judge granted Calpine Corp. permission to sell a $140 million unsecured claim against bankrupt Solutia Inc.that has been trading for more than the recovery proposed for unsecured creditors. […] After Solutia filed for Chapter 11 on Dec. 17, 2003, it rejected its lease with Calpine and sought to buy its steam elsewhere, which resulted in a two-year battle over a $500 million claim asserted by Calpine. The two reached a settlement this 8 that reduced Calpine's claim to $140 million, court documents said. Solutia was formed in 1997 when PFIZER Inc.subsidiary Pharmacia, once part of Monsanto Co., spun off most of its chemicals businesses to shareholders as an independent entity. The spinoff left Solutia with hundreds of millions of dollars in yearly liabilities for environmental cleanup, litigation and employees' healthcare. Calpine filed for Chapter 11 in the Manhattan court on Dec. 20, 2005.

title: A dialogue of the deaf with US climate sceptics
news: The Heritage Foundation persists in claiming everything we are told about global warming is not true, writes FRANK McDONALD [...] IT WAS up close and personal, the confrontation we had last week at the Heritage Foundation, a right-wing think-tank in Washington 12 European environmental journalists facing four of its policy wonks, all of them working assiduously to thwart President Barack Obama's efforts to curb American carbon emissions.[...] The preparedness of poorly-educated people to hold on to peculiar beliefs in the face of evidence that disproves them is one thing. Much more insidious is the warped world view propagated by the Heritage Foundation, which receives substantial funding from Exxon Mobil; coincidentally, there's an Exxon filling station next door.[...]

title: Business value remains elusive in social networks
news: FOUR years into the rise of online social networking, its business value to most of the corporate sector, and the most effective way to tap into that value, remain elusive.[...] To a lesser extent, other parts of the entertainment business and a handful of consumer goods firms have also tried to interact directly with users, and broaden their approach beyond simply viewing social networks as another set of web pages to advertise on. [...] This is especially so for services using Web 2.0 approaches such as real-time micro-blogging (the likes of Twitter and Friendfeed), in which communication is even more fragmented and informal than in blogs, email or chat forums -- but, just like these other types of information, instantly becomes part of an indelible digital record. That is why Twitter users were so surprised a few weeks ago when a representative of ExxonMobil, the world's most valuable company, appeared to be tweeting away on the company's behalf about issues as diverse as proposed changes to US oil regulations and past environmental disasters. It swiftly emerged that ``Janet'', the ``community evangelist (sic) at ExxonMobil Corp'', had nothing whatsoever to do with the firm, despite her vigorous tweets in its defence (''@1WineDude, did you know that the Valdez spill wasn't even one of the top 10 worst spills in history'').[...]

title: India set to sign $12.5b contract for Gorgon gas
news: India is expected to sign its single biggest trade deal with Australia within two months, once it finalises the terms of a $12.5 billion deal to buy liquefied natural gas from the controversial Gorgon gas project planned at Barrow Island. Fourteen months after Indian officials first revealed their hopes to buy gas from the $15 billion Gorgon development, Indian group Petronet LNG yesterday confirmed it was negotiating a 25-year contract to take 2.5 million tonnes of LNG from Gorgon annually. […] A spokesman for US energy giant CHEVRON, which manages the proposed 10 million tonnes a year LNG venture with a 50 per cent stake, said yesterday CHEVRON was not the seller, having already committed most of its share of output to customers in Japan. […] ExxonMobil, which holds the remaining 25 per cent stake in Gorgon, has long been viewed as the most likely supplier to Petronet, of which it also owns 10 per cent. ExxonMobil already supplies Petronet from its Rasgas LNG joint venture in Qatar. […] Conclusion of the Petronet deal should help clear the way for a final investment decision on the massive Gorgon project by the middle of the year, following last month's crucial environmental approval by the State Government for construction of the 10 million tonnes a year LNG plant on Burrup Island, subject to strict conditions. The approval overturned a ruling by the Environmental Protection Authority that building the plant on Barrow Island posed too great a threat to the Pilbara population of the flatback turtle, as well as other plants and animals. Though Barrow is the site of Australia's oldest operating oilfield, it is also an A-Class nature reserve. […]

title: At 40, Earth Day takes on a corporate look; Some express chagrin as past targets become sources of support
news: So strong was the antibusiness sentiment for the first Earth Day in 1970 that organizers took no money from corporations and held teach-ins  ''to challenge corporate and government leaders.''   Forty years later, the day has turned into a premier marketing platform for selling a variety of goods and services, like office products, Greek yogurt and eco-dentistry.[…]   To many pioneers of the environmental movement, eco-consumerism, creeping for decades,  is intensely frustrating and detracts from Earth Day's original purpose. « This ridiculous perverted marketing has cheapened the concept of what is really green,'' said Denis Hayes, who was national coordinator of the first Earth Day and is returning to organize this year's activities in Washington. ''It is tragic.''  Yet the eagerness of corporations to sign up for Earth Day also reflects the environmental movement's increased tolerance toward corporate America:  Many ''big greens,'' as leading environmental advocacy organizations are known, now accept that they must take money from corporations or at the least become partners with them if they are to make real inroads in changing social behavior.[…] This year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be in Times Square to announce measures to reduce New York's impact on the environment. Using the same stage, Keep America Beautiful, an antilittering nonprofit organization, will introduce ''dream machines,''  recycling kiosks it is introducing with PEPSICO. The machines are meant to increase the recycling rates for beverage containers, which is estimated at about 36 percent nationwide.  Of course,  a fair portion of the more than 200 billion beverage containers produced in the United States each year are filled with PEPSICO products like Mountain Dew and Aquafina; such bottle trash contributes to serious pollution on beaches, oceans and inland waterways.   Still, Matthew M. McKenna, president and chief executive of Keep America Beautiful, and a former PEPSICO senior vice president, said he jumped at the opportunity to have his former employer introduce its new kiosk at the event.   ''We are not being asked to encourage the purchase of PEPSI or the consumption of their products,'' he said. ''We are asked to deal in the field with what happens when they get thrown out.'' […]

title: HP joins IBM on recycling potentially toxic 'e-waste'
news: After years of recycling computer equipment south of the border, high-tech giant Hewlett-Packard Co. has finally made it possible for Canadians to properly dispose of their dusty old PCs, laptops, printers and computer monitors, much of the equipment containing toxic materials. Environment Canada estimates that nearly 200,000 tonnes of old computer equipment and other "e-waste" will require proper disposal over the next three years. Much of it currently goes to landfill sites, where substances such as mercury, lead and cadmium can leach out and potentially contaminate ground water. Hewlett-Packard hopes that Canadians will be willing to pay a small fee - ranging from $20 to $52, depending on product type and quantity - to make sure the obsolete equipment is properly refurbished for charities or recycled in an environmentally friendly fashion. "One of the main reasons we're offering this service is because, frankly, our customers are asking for it," said Frances Edmonds, manager of environmental health and safety for Hewlett-Packard (Canada) Ltd. "They're faced with old computers and monitors sitting in their closets and they don't know what to do with them." Consumers or businesses looking to take part in the take-back program can register at www.hp.ca/recycle on the Internet. A credit-card payment can be made for 10 or fewer items, including any computing product and peripherals such as scanners and printers. HP, which recently merged with Compaq Computer Corp., said the program accepts all brands of computer products, including names such as Apple, IBM and Dell. […]

title: SWITCHED ON -; CHIP IN FOR THOSE IN NEED
news: IF YOU received a new computer for Christmas, why not extend the season of goodwill by donating your old kit for recycling. Not only will you be uncluttering your own home but you will be helping people to whom even an ageing PC can make a big difference and doing your bit to help save the planet.  Each year, 1.5 million computers end up being dumped in the UK alone. Yet most of these PCs can be fully functioning with a small amount of refurbishment.  Alida Baxter is looking forward to word-processing, and learning how to e-mail and use the Internet thanks to a refurbished computer from Recycle-IT (www. recycle-it. ltd. uk) - a not-forprofit organisation that takes PCs destined for landfill and puts them back into use.[…]  The charity is looking for Pentium IBM-compatible machines. "Anything that runs Windows 95 or a more recent system, " says Jaf.[…]

title: G.E. Resumes Hudson Dredging, With Limits by E.P.A.
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC resumed dredging for contaminants in the upper Hudson River on Tuesday afternoon after shutting down operations in response to tests that showed that chemicals from the cleanup had traveled several miles downstream. The Environmental Protection Agency, which had ordered the dredging halted on Friday, said that operations would restart in stages and initially be confined to only three of 11 sites on the river where the dredges had been operating. Additional dredging areas may be added pending another round of water sampling, said Kristen Skopeck, a spokeswoman for the agency. Water tests conducted about five miles south of Fort Edward in Washington County, where most of the dredging is under way, showed that levels of the chemicals known as PCBs exceeded water quality standards. E.P.A. officials has asked GENERAL ELECTRIC, which is overseeing the cleanup, to find methods for confining the sediment disturbed by the dredging to each site and keep PCB levels down elsewhere in the river. […] Two GENERAL ELECTRIC factories discharged PCBs for three decades beginning in the 1940s before PCBs were banned in 1977 as a health threat to people and wildlife. That led to the federal designation of nearly 200 miles of the river, from Hudson Falls, N.Y., to the southern tip of Manhattan, as a contaminated Superfund site. […]

title: Nigeria pipeline issues hit Shell, ExxonMobil
news: Yet more oil output affected in volatile Niger Delta [...] The incidence of oil spills has pitted foreign oil companies, including Shell, CHEVRON and Total, against communities in the Niger Delta who claim the oil spills have ravaged their farmlands and polluted their environment. The companies however, blame the majority of spills on sabotage attacks on pipelines and production facilities by thieves, who steal crude and petroleum products. A United Nations Environmental Program (UNEP) report in 8 2011 blamed the Nigerian government and multinational oil companies for 50 years of oil pollution in the Niger Delta.

title: Companies Weigh Federal Labels for Gene-Engineered Ingredients
news: With Washington State on the verge of a ballot initiative that would require labeling of some foods containing genetically engineered ingredients and other states considering similar measures, some of the major food companies and Wal-Mart, the country's largest grocery store operator, have been discussing lobbying for a national labeling program. Executives from PEPSICO, ConAgra and about 20 other major food companies, as well as Wal-Mart and advocacy groups that favor labeling, attended a meeting in 1 in Washington convened by the Meridian Institute, which organizes discussions of major issues. The inclusion of Wal-Mart has buoyed hopes among labeling advocates that the big food companies will shift away from tactics like those used to defeat Proposition 37 in California last fall, when corporations spent more than $40 million to oppose the labeling of genetically modified foods. ''They spent an awful lot of money in California -- talk about a lack of return on investment,'' said Gary Hirshberg, co-chairman of the Just Label It campaign, which advocates national labeling, and chairman of Stonyfield, an organic dairy company. Instead of quelling the demand for labeling, the defeat of the California measure has spawned a ballot initiative in Washington State and legislative proposals in Connecticut, Vermont, New Mexico and Missouri, and a swelling consumer boycott of some organic or ''natural'' brands owned by major food companies.[…] For more than a decade, almost all processed foods in the United States -- like cereals, snacks and salad dressings -- have contained ingredients from plants with DNA that has been manipulated in a laboratory. The Food and Drug Administration, other regulators and many scientists say these foods pose no danger. But as Americans ask more pointed questions about what they are eating, popular suspicions about the health and environmental effects of biotechnology are fueling a movement to require that food from genetically modified crops be labeled, if not eliminated.[…]

title: Brazil"s Environment Institute fines CHEVRON for oil spill
news: Brazil"s Environment Institute on Friday ordered US oil giant CHEVRON to pay another fine related to the early November oil spill off the coast of Rio de Janeiro. The agency, known as Ibama, ordered CHEVRON to pay US$5.4 million for failures in the company"s emergency plan. Ibama earlier fined CHEVRON US$28 million for environmental damages caused by the spill. The agency said it discovered an "absence of equipment in the emergency vessels and a delay in the first response to the spill," the statement read. Prosecutors previously announced legal action against CHEVRON, its Brazilian unit and Transocean, seeking US$11 billion over the spill last month at a production well at the Frade field, 370 kilometres off Rio de Janeiro state. The well is located 1,200 metres below the ocean surface. The state-run National Petroleum Agency calculated that some 3,000 barrels of crude were spilled.[...]

title: Regulation & the Environment
news: Shareholder resolutions are gate-crashers at corporate annual meetings?demanding attention, raising unwelcome questions and annoying the hosts. […] Shareholder resolutions, which appear on proxy statements and are voted on at annual meetings, "press companies to be socially and environmentally responsible," according to the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility (ICCR). "The goal of most investors is to get companies to take steps we think they need to take to protect shareholder value," said Andrew Logan, senior program manager with Ceres, a coalition of investor funds and environmental and public interest organizations. […] In 2004, shareholder resolutions at Apache, Anadarko Petroleum and Marathon Oil asked the companies to assess how they were responding to "rising regulatory, competitive and public pressure to significantly reduce carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions." Each of the companies urged shareholders to reject the resolutions. Marathon is "already addressing the issues raised in the proposal," said the company's proxy statement. The report requested by the proposal would not help the company reduce its emissions or improve its environmental performance, the statement said. The proposals were rejected, but each received significant support, ranging from 27% at Marathon to 37% of shares voted at Apache. Similar resolutions at CHEVRONTEXACO and Unocal also were rejected, with 9.4% and 6.75% of shares voted, respectively, in support of the proposals. This year, climate change resolutions were withdrawn at all five of these companies, as well as Tesoro Petroleum, "after extensive negotiations" with the resolutions' sponsors, several investor groups said in a joint statement. The companies are "more publicly acknowledging that global warming is a serious issue [and] are pursuing or have agreed to pursue a wide range of actions that investors believe will reduce [their] exposure to climate risk."[…]

title: Dish the dirt and clean up your act
news: […] Ecover has a history of standing alone. Set up in 1980, it started life on the shelves of health food shops, chosen only by hardcore green enthusiasts. Back then, its aim was the same: to make cleaning products from plant and mineral based substances that biodegrade easily. Twenty-six years later, after considerable product improvement, Ecover jostles for space in most leading supermarkets. Sales were up 30 per cent last year; it sells to 22 countries (it's the No 2 green cleaner in the States). As it encroaches on the territory of the big players, Unilever and PROCTER & GAMBLE, a significant proportion of us are taking notice. According to a recent survey by the Energy Saving Trust, 34 per cent of us use green cleaning products daily.[…] The WWF says it is concerned about the impact of chemicals, such as artificial musks, on wildlife as well as human health. "They build up in our waterways, harming aquatic life," says Elizabeth Salter Green, the head of the WWF's toxics programme. "I wouldn't want to say that all ingredients made from petrochemicals are bad, but there are certainly troubling ones, with complex structures, that don't break down easily." Then there's the sustainability issue.[…]

title: Well-Oiled Machine
news: PRIVATE EMPIRE ExxonMobil and American Power By Steve Coll [...] Unsurprisingly, Exxon Mobil runs one of Washington's biggest lobbying operations, with not only a well-staffed office on K Street (where a Democratic director was smoothly brought in to replace a Republican after the 2008 elections) but some 20 additional former senators, representatives, legislative aides and others under contract. Yet this book isn't so much a story of Exxon Mobil's influence over the American government. [...] Exxon Mobil executives care less about Americans' belief in climate change, Coll suggests, than they do about Americans' belief in punitive damages from lawsuits.
