[…] If I would have been allowed into Canada I would have given a speech pointing out that the oil industry is perhaps the world's single greatest climate culprit. Just five global corporations - BP-Amoco, Exxon-Mobil, Shell, Texaco and CHEVRON - produce oil that contributes some 10 per cent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions - by far the major global warming gas. In the speech I never gave, I was ready to tell my audience that the petroleum industry is also continuing to relentlessly destroy the health and well-being of local communities and ecosystems where profits from oil are to be found. Be it in the mangrove swamps of the Niger Delta, the far reaches of the Amazon basin, or the fragile environs of the Arctic, oil generates social and ecological havoc. […] Instead, I found myself being treated like a common criminal in what appears to have been a paranoid Canadian government effort to assert that Calgary was not to be another Seattle. Unfortunately, what happened to us was no isolated incident. Rather, it is part of an emerging pattern of harassment of activists protesting free trade and globalization. This trend is clearly characterized by various government initiatives to pre-empt protest. […] Amit Srivastava works with the Transnational Resource & Action Center, a San Francisco-based non-profit group which advocates for human rights, environmental justice and corporate accountability.

title: Bush Mulls Resumed Energy Drilling Off Alaska
news: President Bush is considering whether to lift the 17-year-old moratorium on energy drilling in the waters off southwestern Alaska, a White House spokeswoman said Sunday, which would allow oil and gas companies to try to tap into more than five trillion cubic feet of natural gas that lies beneath rich fishing grounds. […]  In a letter to President Bush on Friday, a coalition of environmental groups, including the Wilderness Society, the Sierra Club and the Natural Resources Defense Counsel, citing the impact of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, called the bay ''an economically critical salmon fishery,'' adding that ''it provides essential habitat for the endangered northern right whale.'' […] Asked about the potential impact of an outer continental shelf leasing program confined to the southern waters of the bay, Mr. Passacantando said: ''The energy industry ultimately gives you things that look like the Exxon Valdez. It was because of the threat of this kind of spill that that leases were initially rescinded.'' He was referring to a handful of oil leases that were granted in the southern part of Bristol Bay in 1988, then bought back by the federal government after the Exxon Valdez supertanker, with a captain who had been drinking, ran aground on Bligh Reef in March 1989. The tanker ruptured and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the sound. […]

title: City puts off accepting annexation study
news: Annexation of land south of the city and construction of a proposed Wal-Mart Supercenter on some of that land are two separate issues, not a cause-and-effect scenario, City Attorney David LaCroix said Monday night during the Crystal River City Council meeting. […] After the decision was made Monday night to put off a vote on accepting the annexation study until the council's Oct. 27 meeting, the council discussion focused mostly on the philosophy and process surrounding annexation. LaCroix and Mayor Ron Kitchen urged council members to consider annexation and potential development distinctly. "All that's being asked is that you consider annexing land," LaCroix said. "If you annex property, you aren't beholden to anybody to approve anything." His remark hardly eased the concerns of business owners along U.S. 19 who fear the congestion, environmental hazards and costs future development would bring if the involuntary annexation goes through. […]

title: Can depots to increase
news: CASH for cans depot operators need only sort beverage containers into nine categories, rather than 24, after changes to legislation. Northern Territory Environment Minister Peter Chandler said: "For depots this means less handling of product, making operations simpler and more profitable, which will result in more depots entering the market. "For Territorians, it means shorter wait times at depots and more locations to deposit your containers." Mr Chandler said changes were instigated after the container deposit scheme was struck down in the Federal court after it began operating.It came to a standstill in March 2013 after Coca-Cola Amatil won a case against the NT Government, which then had to prop up the scheme at a cost of $1 million a month until the Mutual Recognition Act could be secured in 8.

title: To Dredge or Not to Dredge? PCB Study Is Neutral
news: A long-awaited study released yesterday by the National Academy of Sciences about PCB pollution and the various strategies for cleaning it up does not endorse a plan by the federal Environmental Protection Agency to dredge the Hudson River. But neither does it reject the proposal.  The study's summary -- the full text will not be issued for several months -- goes out of its way to say that it will provide no final answers to a question that has become a high-stakes issue among competing political, economic and environmental interests in New York: what is to be done with the river?  "Many readers expect this report to recommend remediation options," the report says. "However, the committee strongly believes that making such recommendations is not appropriate" because the study focused on how to make cleanup decisions in general rather than on any specific case. But in the politicized debate over the river that has erupted since the E.P.A. announced its nearly half-billion-dollar dredging plan in December, even playing the subject down the middle could give both sides new ammunition. The study flatly states, for example, that PCB's are a dangerous and potent long-term poison in the environment. That rejects arguments by General Electric, which discharged the PCB's into river from its factories for 30 years until the mid-1970's, and has contended ever since that the danger is exaggerated. […]

title: The frightening power of ENGOs
news: Independent researcher Vivian Krause has dug up a lengthy list of recent grants by the U.S.-based Tides Foundation to hold up oil sands development (See "The war on Canadian oil" in Tuesday's Post). She makes the excellent point that many of these "charitable" donations go to environmental NGOs whose standards of objectivity in no way comply with tax exempt status. [...] The very fact that ENGOs are funded by some of the greatest capitalist foundations on Earth shows how those foundations have been captured by forces that many of their founders would have considered repugnant. [...] Significantly, Coca-Cola already kisses the ring of its ENGO masters by supporting campaigns such as WWF's "Last Ice Area," which not merely promotes alarmism about the Arctic but condemns Arctic oil drilling and promotes much greater power for the WWF in setting policy. Coca-Cola is all too typical in appearing to believe that it can buy off more radical ENGOs by appeasing the more moderate. [...]

title: Drivers urged: Boycott Esso and help to save the planet: A unique partnership between leading environmental pressure groups is hoping to force the oil giant EXXON into action on climate change. Anthony Browne and Ben Summerskill report on the latest show of consumer power
news: […]  Now Esso - the company that tells the world to 'put a tiger in your tank' - could be brought to its knees by an alliance of environmentalists in the most profound British demonstration of consumer activism since Barclays Bank was forced to pull out of South Africa. The biggest consumer boycott campaign for a generation will be launched this week when Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth try to force Esso, and its American parent the oil giant EXXON, to abandon its opposition to the Kyoto climate change agreements. If the initiative is successful - the two pressure groups alone have more than 500,000 British members - economists estimate that Esso sales in Britain could be reduced by more than pounds 1 billion a year.  'EXXON gave George W Bush more than Dollars 1m towards his election campaign,' said Greenpeace director Stephen Tindale. 'As soon as he was elected, he said that the US would pull out of international agreements to stop global warming. The firm is abusing their global power to stop worldwide action on climate change.' The Stop Esso initiative will be launched on Tuesday by Bianca Jagger. 'Too often as individuals we feel powerless,' the veteran human rights and environmental activist told The Observer . 'This campaign is a way that people can make a difference. We can say enough, we can say stop. We will make our voices heard.' […]

title: Nigeria; Delta Women Ready for Fresh War Against CHEVRONtexaco
news: FIVE months after the women of Ugborodo, Nigeria, captured the world's attention with an 11 -day protest against oil giant, CHEVRONTexaco, they are angry again, this time over what they say are the firm's broken promises. CHEVRONTexaco ended 7's peaceful occupation of their massive Escravos Oil Terminal, Delta State with promises of investment for the local area. Now the press have gone and, local people say, so has any sign of investment in the Ugborodo fishing community, a collection of Itsekiri-speaking villages. "You can see that our community is gradually going into extinction," says 72-year-old Jahaetan Omadeli, one of the women whose 7 protest shut down the production and export of 180,000 barrels of crude per day. "Our land is being eaten up by erosion and oil pollution. And CHEVRON is not doing anything to arrest the drift," she said, warning that battle lines were once more being drawn up against the US-based oil giant. […]

title: Planet matters
news: Low-impact living: Have you ever noticed how the shape of laundry detergent changes from year to year? From big-box powder, to compact powder, to liquid, to tablet. Aside from their shape and odour, the popular clothes-cleaning potions and powders do not differ greatly from one another. The six leading brands that you are most likely to find in your supermarket - Ariel, Bold, Daz, Fairy, Persil and Surf - are made by just two multinational companies: PROCTER & GAMBLE and Unilever. We've used each and every one of them in our house over the years, but I wouldn't know the difference. Although, being pigheadedly resistant to advertising, we've stuck to powders, and more recently, tablets, because the latter are smaller, and thus kinder to the environment: less stuff to pack and transport, and less packaging to recycle. Yet, in a report in last month's Ethical Consumer magazine (published by the Ethical Consumer Research Association, a British non-profit organisation devoted to human rights, environmental sustainability and animal welfare), the biggies come out bottom in their "Ethiscore" league table. Persil and Surf score 1.5 out of 20, and the other four mentioned above garner two points each. All lose marks in areas of environment, human rights, animal welfare and sustainability.[…]

title: The real story may reside in the boardrooms of major companies
news: [...] The Bella Center, the size of a big-city airport, is climate change's ground zero. Some 30,000 participants swarm into the convention buildings every day. The mob includes some of the planet's brightest scientific, technical, development, economic and political minds, from paleoclimatologists, who can tell you what the weather was like 100,000 years ago, to Chinese negotiators who know as much about U.S. carbon cap-and-trade "architecture" as many U.S. senators. [...] For them, the challenge goes beyond "primum non nocere," the doctors' oath to do no harm. It means "Do some good while you still can" and their focus is on climate change, the planet's gravest threat. Call it legacy seeking, or ego massaging. Take Muthar Kent, the chief executive officer of Coca-Cola, a ubiquitous brand that is not exactly synonymous with environmental responsibility. The company's energy use for making, packaging and distributing carbonated drinks is extraordinarily high and Mr. Kent knows it. So what is Coke doing about it? Coke is restructuring itself from the bottom up to become a low-carbon, water-neutral company, he said at a Copenhagen Climate Council speech on Saturday. [...]

title: WWF has 'sold its soul' to global business: Book claims that the conservation group is being used by global firms to 'greenwash' polluting activities
news: WWF International, the world's largest conservation group, has been accused of "selling its soul" by forging alliances with powerful businesses which destroy nature and use the WWF brand to "greenwash" their operations. The allegations are made in an explosive book previously barred from Britain. The Silence of the Pandas became a German bestseller in 2012 but, following a series of injunctions and court cases, it has not been published until now in English. Revised and renamed Pandaleaks, it will be out next week. Its author, Wilfried Huismann, says the Geneva-based WWF International has received millions of dollars from its links with governments and business. Global corporations such as Coca-Cola, Shell, Monsanto, HSBC, Cargill, BP, Alcoa and Marine Harvest have all benefited from the group's green image only to carry on their businesses as usual. [...]

title: Ecuador pollution trial sets up in jungle; After debate, soil tests begin at former TEXACO site
news: Jungle vegetation, barking dogs and curious onlookers now provide the backdrop for deciding the fate of an environmental-damage lawsuit possibly worth $6-bil against CHEVRONTEXACO. […] Scientists and technicians?with those appointed by the plaintiffs garbed in white hazmat suits?began taking soil samples the afternoon of Aug 18 at one of the sites which CHEVRONTEXACO cleaned up as part of a government-approved, $40-mil remediation project after a TEXACO subsidiary ended operations in Ecuador in 1990. CHEVRON and TEXACO merged in 2001. The tests are meant to prove whether there exists left-over pollution which continues to damage the environment and health of some 30,000 Amazon-area settlers and indigenous tribes, as plaintiffs claim. […] CHEVRONTEXACO lawyer Alberto Callejas reiterated his company's position in comments which lasted for more than two hours in the muggy climate, while journalists and other observers, including human rights activist Bianca Jagger, looked on. "Risks to human health due to our oil operations do not exist at these sites," Callejas said. […] CHEVRONTEXACO says tests will show that any hydrocarbons which remain have been treated or contained so as not to be harmful to humans or the environment. […]

title: CHEVRON confident of getting green light
news: Gorgon owner CHEVRON Corporation has "every confidence" that its LNG project will go ahead, saying it believed it could persuade the Government of the environmental benefits of building it on Barrow Island. In rejecting the Gorgon plan, the EPA said it held fears for the island's flatback turtles, the impact of dredging on coral reefs during construction and the threat to Barrow's bandicoot population and other wildlife from introduced pests. There is also concern that five species of miniature shrimps, two species of small cave-dwelling fauna and two species of scorpion-like millipedes will be harmed by the development. The EPA believes these nine species are not found anywhere else in the world.  EPA chairman Wally Cox said the proposal in its present form "cannot meet the EPA's environmental objectives and is considered environmentally unacceptable". He said the EPA was particularly concerned about the "lack of science" on the flatback turtle numbers. It was CHEVRON's responsibility to provide adequate information about this, Dr Cox said. But CHEVRON's Greater Gorgon Area general manager Colin Beckett said he was convinced his company could win over the Environment Minister Mark McGowan. […] FIELDS APART. WHAT CHEVRON WANTS TO DO. CHEVRON Corporation is the operator of the Gorgon venture which also involves Shell and ExxonMobil. […] WHAT NOW. The EPA's report is subject to an appeal until 6 20. Appeals are then considered by the independent appeals convenor Garry Middle. Mr Middle will prepare a report for Environment Minister Mark McGowan on any appeals. The Minister is required under legislation to consult with the State Development Minister who is Premier Alan Carpenter. The Minister then takes into consideration both the EPA's and the convenor's reports. If the proposal is rejected, CHEVRON has the option of submitting a new application for another site, including a mainland site.

title: Environmental group takes on Coca-Cola Israel, saying it's running a 'smear' campaign against deposit law
news: Coca-Cola Israel and other bottlers are trying to convince the Knesset to abolish deposits on beverage containers, according to the Israel Union for Environmental Defense. The campaign has three main components, according to a letter the environmental group sent to Coca-Cola'sinternational headquarters in Atlanta on February 20: a smear campaign in the press attempting to link bottle collection with criminal elements"; an alternative draftbill relating to packaging of commercial goods; and expansion of the sidewalk network of voluntary recycling cages instead of improving deposit redemption facilities and accessibilityas required by law. In the letter the Union for Environmental Defense asked Coca-Cola headquarters to sanction the Israeli franchise. [...]

title: Green rating of British bus firms leaves Google and Apple behind
news: [...] Ahead of the United Nations Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 6, Eiris examined the ethical record of all the 2,063 companies in the FTSE All-World Developed Index of large companies, giving them an A-to-E grading. Among the world's 50 biggest companies, all four given the lowest E grade were - perhaps unsurprisingly - oil and gas producers: ExxonMobil, CHEVRON, ConocoPhillips and Occidental.[...] CHEVRON Along with the other major oil and gas producers, including ConocoPhillips and Occidental Petroleum, CHEVRON is given the lowest ranking. ExxonMobil Scoring an E too, the world's biggest company is criticised in the Eiris report for doing too little on "biodiversity, climate change and water management".

title: GUSH MONEY! EXXONMOBIL MAY BE EYING BP TAKEOVER
news: THIS IS THE IRONY of the oil tycoons: Exxon, which caused an infamous 1989 spill in Alaska, may now buy up BP, which is still spewing oil in the Gulf of Mexico. [...] The Exxon Valdez tanker spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound was the worst U.S. oil spill until the April 20 Deepwater Horizon blast began sending oil into the gulf at a rate that matches the Exxon Valdez spill - every 10 days. [...] Meanwhile, millions of gallons of oil were spewing unchecked into the Gulf of Mexico again after BP removed a faulty well cap and began to install a new one that could stop the leak this week.[...]

title: Science Snippets
news: RARE EAGLES SET TO SOAR AGAIN[...] EAGLES that have not been seen in Irish skies for over a century may soon be flying high over the country once again, if a five-year wildlife project is successful.[...]DISPUTE OVER GLOBAL WARMING[...] A US-BASED non-profit organisation has fingered global petrol company EXXONMOBIL for smudging the truth about global warming. Science watchdog, the Union of Concerned Scientists, said the company channeled nearly $16US million ($24S.5 million) over a seven-year period up to 2005 to environmental groups, hoping they would play down the effects of global warming, reported Reuters. An EXXONMOBIL spokesman dismissed the report, saying it was an attempt to mislead the public about the company's environmentally friendly stand.

title: Variety of Projects Vying for Grants From $19.5 Million Oil Spill Fund
news: For decades, oil seeped from the refineries that once occupied parts of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and pooled under nearby homes and businesses, into a plume roughly the expanse of 50 football fields. The total oil spill, estimated at 17 million to 30 million gallons, remains one of the largest in United States history, a distinction the neighborhood is not exactly proud of. But it is about to start receiving its consolation payments. The first grants from a $19.5 million fund, part of a settlement between ExxonMobil and the state, are about to be announced. The aim of the fund is to make lasting environmental improvements in Greenpoint and address current environmental concerns. [...]

title: Energy Producers Make Case For More Coastal Drilling
news: About 150 miles southeast of New Orleans, an oil drilling ship the size of two football fields with a wide hole in its hull and a 200-foot derrick on its deck is back in operation. […] But even as oil companies push out into the gulf's deeper waters, two devastating recent storms have raised questions about the wisdom of placing so many energy bets in this high-risk region. The gulf's entire output -- more than a quarter of domestic oil and gas supplies -- was interrupted by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, and still remains far below prehurricane levels. Oil companies, however, are not walking away. In fact, they're planning just the opposite. […] These areas -- off California, from Georgia to Maine, and in the parts of the gulf close to Florida -- have been closed to new exploration since 1981 after a series of environmental disasters that fostered a sharp political reaction against the oil industry. […] Some members of Congress have been seeking to lift the federal moratorium, arguing this would make the nation's energy supplies more secure. But the move is unlikely to succeed in the face of a coalition of environmental groups and politically powerful coastal states like Florida and California, whose Republican governors argue it would be detrimental to tourism and threaten the appeal of their coastlines. Oil industry executives say they have learned from past disasters and argue they can now safely drill along any coast. They contend that if the nation is unwilling to make hard trade-offs between scenery and sources of energy, its prosperity will be put at risk. […] Most of the major oil companies are planning to step up investments in the gulf over the coming years. [CHEVRON said on Monday that it was moving ahead with a $900 million development called, without irony, Blind Faith. The field, discovered in 2001, has potential reserves of 100 million barrels of liquids, and is expected to start producing in 2008.] […]

title: CAN WE REALLY SAVE THE PLANET; ANALYSIS; Environment editor Rob Edwards asks whether capitalism can deliver on the imperatives of the Stern climate review
news: SOMETHING shifted last week. One of the world's leading economists put a cost on the climate chaos being caused by pollution, and everyone sat up and started to take notice. With the publication of Sir Nicholas Stern's review of the economics of climate change, the argument suddenly seems to have got serious. It's no longer just scientists and environmentalists worried about humanity who are demanding urgent action, it's bankers worried about the bottom line. […] According to Hans Verolme, director of WWF's international climate campaign, the window of opportunity for preventing dangerous climate change is rapidly closing. "Ministers need to chart a course for deeper emission cuts, " he said. "We must work together to develop a safer, cleaner and more energy-efficient world." THE INTERNATIONAL POLLUTERS. THE latest figures compiled by the United Nations show that emissions of greenhouses gases such as carbon dioxide from the world's two biggest polluters, the US and China, are rapidly rising (see graphic).[…] THE INDUSTRIAL POLLUTERS. LAST week the oil industry won the backing of the DEPArtment of Trade and Industry for a major push to open up the so-called Atlantic Frontier, west of the Shetlands, for oil and gas exploitation. Five leading oil corporations - BP, Exxon, CHEVRON, Total and Dong - met officials in London to discuss how best to extract the four billion barrels of oil the area could contain, without apparently worrying about the pollution it would cause. Similarly the aviation industry, one of the fastest-growing sources of greenhouse gases, is lobbying for a huge growth in the UK's airport capacity. The number of flights is expected to treble by 2030, the industry says, so major expansions are required at airports across the country, including Glasgow, Prestwick and Edinburgh. […] WILL ANYTHING CHANGE? […]

title: Britain to allow shale-gas drilling; But government places controls on controversial 'fracking' technique
news: The British government gave the go-ahead Thursday for exploratory hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, to extract natural gas from shale-rock deposits. Because of the environmental concerns about the controversial technique, which include the risk of water pollution, the government called for stringent controls on fracking. [...] U.S. prices are lower largely as a result of the increased production of shale gas in that country, despite the opposition of environmentalists. [...] But there is strong opposition to gas in Europe, particularly in Western Europe. France, for instance, which is viewed as having some of the most promising shale oil and gas prospects, particularly in the Paris area, has banned fracking. The German state of North Rhine-Westphalia has formally halted the practice, and Lower Saxony state, where Exxon Mobil has done some drilling, has refused to let the company continue. [...] The main concerns, which have quickly spread to Europe from the United States, center on hydraulic fracturing, the practice of pumping large quantities of fluids into wells to loosen the rock formations and enable the gas to flow. The fear is that the fracking fluids might escape from the wells and pollute drinking water and the surrounding countryside. [...]

title: TEXACO Goes on Trial in Ecuador Pollution Case
news: When Rene Arevalo draws water from his well, it is brown and gummy, requiring him to run it through a makeshift filtering system outside his wood-plank home in the jungle outside this town. Like thousands of other people here, he suspects the water was fouled by the waste an American oil company dumped across miles of Amazonia in its 20 years of operations. After all, he and his five children live across from a separation plant once operated by a TEXACO affiliate, their house built on a mound of dirt that covered a pit where wastewater was dumped. […] Now, about 30,000 people affected by the waste are hoping that a lawsuit, accusing CHEVRONTEXACO of dumping 18.5 billion gallons of waste into open, unlined pits, will lead to a full-scale cleanup. This week, the California-based company, an energy giant created in 2001 when CHEVRON merged with TEXACO, went on trial here in a case that, if successful for the plaintiffs, could establish a new way for American companies to be held accountable for environmental degradation in foreign countries. […] For environmental advocates, the case is shaping up as a major fight against energy projects in Latin America. Poor villagers, organized by international environmental groups, have been increasingly fighting in Latin America against such projects as a natural gas pipeline in Peru and exploration of Amazonian rain forests here. […]

title: Climate hard line costs IPA support; EXCLUSIVE
news: Some of the world's largest companies have dropped financial support and membership of free-market think tank the Institute of Public Affairs amid concern at its vociferous campaign against action on climate change. Petroleum giants ExxonMobil and Shell and large miners are among the multinationals that have confirmed leaving the Liberal-linked IPA, led by party member John Roskam, who this year was compared to Jesus Christ with his disciples by Opposition Leader Tony Abbott. [...] ExxonMobil confirmed it had not been a donor for "several years" as did Shell. Neither company would be drawn on its reasons for leaving. [...]

title: Look out for cancer in your PEPSI: watchdog
news: AS AMERICANS prepare to guzzle gallons of PEPSI on the Fourth of 7, an environmental watchdog group is warning the soda contains a worrisome level of a carcinogen. PEPSICO Inc. says it is rejiggering its formula to remove 4-methylimidazole, a caramel coloring, from its product, but Center for Environmental Health said the chemical was found in drinks it recently tested. Coca-Cola was also forced to remove the chemical after California passed a law mandating drinks containing carcinogens come with cancer-warning labels. A study linked 4-methylimidazole to cancer in lab rats, but not humans.

title: Big-box history in the making; Accepting Wal-Mart's proposal for a green-friendly outlet in Vancouver could revolutionize the retail industry, GARY MASON writes
news: In his examination of Vancouver's evolution from a scraggly town on the edge of the rain forest to a poster child of modern-day urbanism, author Lance Berelowitz suggests the city's success has, at times, had as much to do with historical happenstance as it has any carefully conceived plan. […] Wal-Mart estimates the green-friendly features will help cut energy use by 37 per cent, water use by 48 per cent and carbon dioxide emissions by 40 per cent. It will cost Wal-Mart $30-million, twice as much as it spends building a normal store.  Despite the company's response to Ms. Roberts's demands, there is still much opposition. Those who don't want the store claim it would hurt smaller local businesses, create traffic congestion and increase greenhouse emissions. Various surveys and studies undertaken by the company, city hall and others have shown that most of these concerns have no basis in fact - still, the plan could meet its death when council members vote.  Personally, I think that would be a shame. […]

title: Campaign on to switch off FACEBOOK for Earth Hour; Toronto woman aims plea at founder Mark Zuckerberg
news: How does a gal go about campaigning to shut down FACEBOOK in support of Earth Hour? On FACEBOOK, obviously. Toronto resident Angie Bird, 26, set up a FACEBOOK page to publicize her plea to the site's founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg: switch off the 500-million user site and draw unprecedented awareness to the energy conservation initiative.  "It's getting a lot of attention," says Zoe Caron, climate policy and advocacy specialist For World Wildlife Fund Canada. Bird had this message for Zuckerberg in a YouTube video posted to her page: "Imagine you just changed your FACEBOOK status to 'Mark Zuckerberg just saved the world, LOL!' " Earth Hour is an environmental initiative started in 2007 in Australia - where Bird is originally from - aimed at convincing people to power off in support of lowering carbon emissions, the primary cause of climate change. In 2009, 88 countries participated and the CN Tower switched off its lights. Last year, 128 countries signed up.[…] FACEBOOK's press team has not responded - yet - to Bird's campaign, and didn't answer requests for comment from the Star. But the World Wildlife Fund, which organizes Earth Hour, has lent Bird support from chapters as distant as Denmark and India. WWF Canada wants to bring her on board as a volunteer, says Caron.[…] Though Bird decided to focus on FACEBOOK because she thought it could reach the largest audience, the site has in the past come under fire for its own emissions. In 1 of last year, FACEBOOK announced it had broken ground on the location of its first custom data centre, which will house thousands of servers where users' information is stored. The company claimed it would use energy-efficient techniques in powering the data centre, but Greenpeace criticized FACEBOOK for using coal to power the centre and not committing to 100 per cent green energy sources. Its page "Unfriend Coal" has more than 56,000 "likes." Data on how much carbon emissions are released by using the Internet are difficult to pin down. Google's own official estimate is that one search emits 0.2 grams of carbon dioxide, though other estimates have put that figure much higher.

title: Nigeria; BP's $20 Billion As Game-Changer in Oil Spill Management
news: "BP's $20 billion compensation payment, just like that, is going to be a game-changer in community relations and environmental management!" An oil executive said in a discussion of last week's piece.[...] Last week US President Barack Obama, who had said all along that he would "make BP pay", made the company commit to $20 billion compensation guarantee and an apology to the US.[...] Obama is smart. The use of an escrow fund prevents a repeat of the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill situation when compensation payment was prolonged for about 20 years by litigation.[...] Last week Environment Minister, John Odey cautioned ExxonMobil about oil spills off the Niger Delta, saying that although the spills were relatively small he was worried by their frequency and the damage they could do to fragile coastal communities.[...]

title: Kazakh fine for CHEVRON unit (folo) OPEC's optimism sends oil to record Crude tops $86 as cartel shrugs off chances of economic decline in U.S.
news: CHEVRON's venture in Kazakhstan was fined 37 billion tenge, or $307 million, over a government claim that it had damaged the environment by maintaining ''excessive'' stockpiles of sulfur from oil production, Bloomberg News reported Monday from Almaty. A Kazakh regional court accepted the Environment Ministry's allegation and halved the penalty from the 74.4 billion tenge sought in 7 from the TengizChevroil venture, Nursapa Primashev, chief justice of the court in the city of Atyrau, said by telephone. Maria Karazhigitova, a spokeswoman for TengizChevroil, said by telephone: ''We will appeal to the upper court. The venture does not agree with the decision.'' TengizChevroil is the biggest oil exporter in Kazakhstan. Russia and Kazakhstan, the biggest oil producers among the former Soviet republics, are exerting pressure on foreign energy companies. The Kashagan project that is run by Eni of Italy is fending off Kazakh government claims for a greater cut of profit at a time of record-high oil prices. The Russian government ordered action against a Shell-run operation that eventually prompted Western companies to sell a significant stake of the project to Gazprom.

title: It's not easy being green
news: Ilyse Hogue brought Sandy Weill to the negotiating table in April 2003 and persuaded CITIGROUP Inc. to take responsibility for the environmental consequences of its loans. Now she is trying to get 10 other major financial institutions to follow the megabank's lead. Hogue, 34, is the director of the global finance campaign for Rainforest Action Network. The campaign is trying to stop major banks, investment houses and insurance companies from financing projects that hurt the environment, particularly rain forests. Hogue is currently negotiating with Bank of America, Goldman, Sachs & Co., John Hancock Financial Services Inc., J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., SunTrust Banks, U.S. Bancorp, Wachovia Corp. and Wells Fargo & Co. If they don't agree by Earth Day (April 22) to the same environmental principles that CITIGROUP now supports, she says that she will revive some of the publicity tactics, including protest marches, that worked with CITIGROUP. […] In her new job, Hogue decided to focus on CITIGROUP. The bank was financing companies and projects that she says were either mining, logging or producing fossil fuels irresponsibly. It was also an appealing target for Hogue because Citi, she knew, was an industry leader. At the time, CITIGROUP was the finance adviser for the Camisea gas project in Peru, which called for drilling in an area the Smithsonian deemed as one of world's most biologically diverse and pristine. The initial exploration killed half of the Nahua tribe by introducing influenza and whopping cough, according to the Rainforest Action Network. The bank is no longer funding the Camisea project. Hogue approached CITIGROUP in April 2000, but the bank failed to change its policies, so Hogue took to the streets. She organized protest marches aimed at Citi, one of which was held in Los Angeles in 8 2000, in the midst of the Democratic Party's national convention. "It was early in the campaign, but from the level of enthusiasm I realized we struck a nerve," Hogue says. Over the next three years, she launched more creative approaches. During the holiday season carolers arrived at CITIGROUP's global headquarters on New York's Park Avenue to sing parodies of Christmas carols, such as "Oil Weills" to the tune of Jingle Bells. On Valentine's Day, Weill received hundreds of cards, asking him to show a little love for the planet. Large banners were hung across the street from CITIGROUP's headquarters mocking the bank's Live Richly marketing campaign, saying, "Global destruction and global warming, we're banking on it."In April 2003, three years after the initial negotiations failed, CITIGROUP relented. Weill himself came to the negotiating table, and the bank agreed to a new environmental initiative, publicly accepting responsibility for the environmental consequences of its loans. "Sandy Weill was concerned about his legacy, so we were able to appeal directly to him," says Hogue, adding that Weill was not "educated" about these issues, but once they got his attention, he was interested in doing the right thing.

title: Ottawa moves to ban gas additive MMT 'I'd rather be guilty of caution,' minister says
news: The federal government has promised to reintroduce a bill that would prohibit the use of a gasoline additive claimed to be toxic to the nervous system. Environment Minister Sergio Marchi says the government will reintroduce legislation to outlaw methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl, or MMT, a compound that replaced the lead additive used to boost octane in gasoline.[…]The manufacturer, Virginia-based Ethyl Corp., says MMT is completely safe. Health Canada agrees with the manufacturer. But U.S. government officials and health and environmental activists on both sides of the border warn that unless MMT is removed, Canadians could face a potent health threat similar to that triggered by leaded gasoline, which caused birth defects.[…]MMT has never been used in the U.S. And though a court ruled last November that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency didn't have the authority to outlaw the chemical, the agency is still fighting its introduction. The Canadian government, following the EPA's lead, moved last year to get rid of the additive. It is now added to all gasoline sold in Canada, with the exception of CHEVRON products sold in B.C. But the bill died on the order paper in the last parliamentary session.[…]Environmentalists recall the story of leaded gasoline, introduced in 1922 with similar claims of safety by Ethyl Corp., which also happens to be the lone manufacturer of MMT.[…]

title: Courts in chaos pending State appeal
news: […] One high-profile case due to be heard yesterday may have come within days of having to be dropped. A Health and Safety Authority (HSA) prosecution against the owner of the Killiney Court Hotel in Co Dublin, relating to an incident last year in which a woman died in a fire, was dismissed because of the McCracken ruling.The time limits involved in health and safety cases give the HSA until this Friday to bring the case again. Another major case, the Environmental Protection Agency's prosecution of the multinational PROCTER & GAMBLE, over pollution of a public water supply in Nenagh, was adjourned yesterday until February, pending the outcome of the Supreme Court appeal.[…]

title: Carbon trade may hit mega-projects
news: BILLIONS of dollars in investment remains at risk despite the country's biggest polluters receiving generous tax breaks to offset the cost of carbon trading. A suite of companies -- including Alcoa, BHP, Rio Tinto, Woodside, ExxonMobil, BP and Santos -- are expected to review key investment decisions as the push to ``go green'' forces up the price of doing business.[...] The Government has moved to soften the impact of its emissions trading scheme by issuing ``free'' permits to heavy polluters subject to international competition. But business remains uncertain about carbon trading.[...] After heavy lobbying, the Government has sought to minimise the impact of emissions trading on a raft of industries, including aluminium, steel, petroleum, oil and gas, and cement.[...] While environmental groups and the Greens accused the Government of caving in to industry, business leaders remain wary and claim some investment decisions will remain on hold.[...] How the scheme works * Government sets a cap on the total amount of carbon in covered sectors. * Government issues permits up to the annual cap each year. * Polluting industries will need to acquire a permit for every tonne of greenhouse gas they emit. * Quantity of carbon pollution by each firm to be monitored and verified.[...]

title: Brazil ups fines on CHEVRON for oil spill
news: BRAZIL'S environmental protection agency has slapped a new fine on CHEVRON for what it says was the US oil company's poor handling of a spill last month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro state. CHEVRON was fined 10 million reals ($A5.4 million) due to an alleged ``breach of its environmental licence'' . It did not have the necessary equipment and was slow to respond when the leak was detected, the agency announced on Saturday on its website. [...] The government agency had already fined CHEVRON 50 million reals for the oil spill, which began at the site of a CHEVRON appraisal well about 370km off the coast. Earlier in the week, federal police asked that prosecutors charge CHEVRON and Transocean with crimes against the environment. Authorities also asked that charges be filed against 17 people for allegedly failing to provide relevant information to the police. Among those cited is George Buck, chief operating officer for CHEVRON Corp's Brazilian division. If indicted and convicted, he and the others could face jail terms of up to 14 years each.[...]

title: Portrait: On the couch with Neutron Jack: Powerful. Dynamic. Ruthless. Jack Welch sacked 10% of his staff every year - and it made him the most successful businessman of the 20th century. Now he's been paid Dollars 10m for his autobiography. Simon Hattenstone gets physical with a surprisingly cuddly corporate monster
news: Neutron cancels the 7am interview. Too busy, down the gym pumping iron. He may be able to squeeze us in on a journey to a book signing. Nope, sorry, security problems. Then we get the call. Be there, two hours prompt. Neutron Jack, aka Jack Welch, aka the world's toughest CEO, will see me. The press officer leads me to the suite in the hotel. The corridor is daunting. So are the security men propping up the door. The suite looks like the Oval Office - guards and personnel scattered strategically. In the centre, a smallish, sixtysomething man stands, one arm across the other, bossing the remote control. "Jeezus." Click. " Jeez ." The news, of course. Welch turned General Electric into the world's most successful company. In its various guises, it is now responsible for fridges and cookers, jet engines and diesel locomotives, Friends and ER, CT scanners and nuclear medicine cameras. And he did it by sacking the worst 10% of his staff every year. He was a rationaliser extraordinaire - cutting the workforce from 411,000 to 299,000 in five years. The environmental groups may have despised GE for clogging up the Hudson with toxics; there may have been a bond-trading scandal at Kidder, Peabody & Co that led to the dismantling of the investment bank Welch bought in 1986; there may have been criminal indictments relating to military contracts; but he guided GE's revenue from Dollars 15bn in 1981 to more than Dollars 419bn last year. […]

title: Obituary: Victor Mills
news: Victor Mills, chemical engineer: born Milford, Nebraska 1897; twice married (one daughter); died Tucson, Arizona 1 November 1997.  Victor Mills led an engineering team that invented the first mass-market disposable nappy.  In his 35-year career with PROCTER & GAMBLE, Mills had a hand in developing products that ranged from Ivory soap to Pringles, the stacked crisps.  He also helped refine the manufacture of synthetic rubber, but none of his products had a more dramatic impact than disposable nappies, which have come to symbolise the modern culture of convenience.  The first challenge to cloth nappies was imported from Sweden to the United States by Johnson & Johnson in the 1940s. But it was Pampers, devised by Mills's team and introduced by PROCTER & GAMBLE in 1961, that ended the dominance of the cloth variety.  Today, disposable nappies dominate the market, with the French, for example, using them in 98 out of every 100 nappy changes, while in the United States they are chosen about 95 per cent of the time. Though the throwaway nappy has been a target of environmental groups because of its stubborn refusal to degrade in landfills, other studies have shown they tend to improve health and cleanliness in children.[…]

title: Blast rekindles terrorist fears
news: AN explosion at a Staten Island fuel storage complex sent a huge plume of black smoke over New York yesterday, unsettling nervous residents. With the US on terror alert, many assumed the worst after the blast shook nearby homes.  Flames and billowing smoke could be seen from the southern tip of Manhattan.  Mayor Michael Bloomberg was quick to act as 150 firefighters battled the blaze. He called a hastily arranged press conference to allay fears. "There is absolutely no evidence and no reason to think whatsoever that this is anything other than a very tragic industrial accident," Mr Bloomberg said. "Two people are missing and we fear the worst for them." Investigators have yet to determine the cause of the blast, being described by police as a refuelling accident. A barge was loading 15 million litres of unleaded petrol at the Port Mobil fuel storage complex when the cargo ignited, burning for several hours. As well as the workers believed killed, a third with severe burns was rushed to Staten Island University Hospital in a critical but stable condition. Mr Bloomberg said fire marshals were interviewing workers to determine the explosion's cause. Those presumed dead were working on the barge, employees of transportation company Bouchard. Thirty Exxon Mobil staff at work at the time have been accounted for. Some residents who live near the industrial site were evacuated as New York's Department of Environmental Protection set up air monitoring and advised people to stay indoors. Mr Bloomberg was telling New Yorkers once again to "go about your business" -- the same plea he was making a week ago when a new terror alert was issued. At the height of the blaze, airspace over Staten Island was closed and bridges shut to non-emergency traffic.

title: ExxonMobil says meeting Billings-area product needs
news: Nearly a week after the closure of its 70-mile Silvertip crude oil pipeline, ExxonMobil declined 7 7 to specify how operations at its 60,000 b/d Billings, Montana, refinery have been affected but the company insists it is still meeting customer needs. "We expect to meet our contractual obligations for the foreseeable future," ExxonMobil spokesman Kevin Allexon said 7 7. But "obviously we've had some impact at our refinery," he said, declining to elaborate. [...] Allexon said the company was continuing with cleanup operations along the pipeline, which spilled an estimated 750-1000 barrels late 7 1 near Laurel, Montana, in the iconic Yellowstone River, the largest undammed river in the continental US. [...] Sarah Elliott, a spokeswoman for Montana Governor Brian Schweitzer, said 7 7 that oily water that has arrived in North Dakota some 200 miles away will be tested to confirm if the source is Silvertip. [...]

title: On the coast of broken dreams
news: SCOTLAND has more than enough scenery, huffed and puffed a politician (Labour it must be said) of my acquaintance in the early seventies. He was justifying the quixotic determination of politicians and planners to bring heavy industry to the Firth of Clyde at its prettiest reaches between the Hunterston peninsula and Inverkip.[…]Then came the proposal of the American oil company CHEVRON to build an oil refinery at Portencross on the Hunterston peninsula to the south of the nuclear station. After a public inquiry that absurd plan was quashed. However, the lure of deep water facilities and the equally absurd idea of relocating the whole Lanarkshire steel industry on a green, seaside site combined in an unstoppable momentum. Fairlie, picturesque haven of yachts and the Arran ferry in bad weather, was disfigured by the dust and visual aggression of a giant ore terminal. Two direct iron reduction plants were plonked on adjacent reclaimed ground at the beauty spot of Black Rock Beach. […]In the event, the direct iron ore reduction plants never reduced a thing - except the appeal of the landscape. The complex, with its dark towers and sloping gantries, is grotesquely at odds with its setting overlooking the Cumbrae islands. The only consolation for the residents of Fairlie and Largs is that its pollution has remained merely aesthetic.[…]

title: Nigeria; Oil Leak - Exxonmobil Shuts in Production
news: After almost two weeks of battling oil leak at its Ibeno facility offshore Akwa Ibom State, the Nigerian unit US-based Oil giant, ExxonMobil, is forced to shut down production. Refraining from disclosing how much production was affected in spite of prodding, the oil company in a statement, yesterday, "declared force majeure due to the difficulty in meeting projected liftings because of repair work on a section of pipeline affected in a November 9 oil release incident." [...] It was the second major oil spill near Exxon facilities in three months. At the end of 8, an oil spill left a slick running for miles along the coast. Oil spills are common in Nigeria, where enforcement of environmental regulations is lax and armed gangs frequently damage pipelines to steal crude. Oil majors say thieves are responsible for most of the spills on shore. [...] Oil major BP Plc this week agreed to pay $4.5 billion in penalties for spilling nearly 5 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Despite thousands of barrels a year spilt by oil majors in Nigeria, none has ever been forced to make a financially significant settlement. [...]

title: Greens slam CHEVRON over breaches'
news: Strict quarantine and environmental controls to protect Barrow Island's A-Class reserve status were failing, the Greens said yesterday, with the State Government admitting there had been a string of critical breaches since September. It is also understood a Gorgon project worker was sacked after he found a suspected rare eel during drilling and threw it back into the well. [...] The revelations follow Environment Minister Donna Faragher admitting there had been many incidents, including four classified as critical and two major in the same period. The critical incidents include seeds found inside bags of sand, soil contamination on concrete blocks, bark and mould on beds and unapproved road base material being delivered to the island. [...] A worker linked to the project, who did not want to be identified, made claims to The West Australian that CHEVRON sugar coats reports to the DEC on environmental breaches and workers on the island did not understand the implications of quarantine breaches, with many newer workers treating the regulations as a joke. [...]A CHEVRON spokesman said the company had been committed to protecting the environment for the past 45 years. Every person who works on Barrow Island is aware of their responsibility to protect its unique environment, he said. Greens MP Robin Chapple said CHEVRON's environmental practices were inadequate and labelled the breaches an expected failure  predicted by the EPA.[...]

title: $3.5 Billion Africa Pipeline Expected to Pass
news: With American support, the World Bank is expected to approve on Tuesday a $3.5 billion project to develop an oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about the potential for corruption and environmental damage. The Clinton administration will vote in favor of World Bank sponsorship after specifying an unusually detailed list of safeguards that officials hope will earmark the oil revenues for development projects and ward off abuse, a senior American official said today.   Although the project does not have united European support, the United States, as the major shareholder in World Bank, is confident that there will be enough votes for a loan to pass, the official said. EXXON MOBIL is the lead company that is seeking the loan. The World Bank is generally expected to contribute $90 million to $200 million. The proposed 663-mile pipeline, which would link oil fields in landlocked Chad to the Atlantic Coast of Cameroon, has stirred an outcry among environmentalists and antipoverty crusaders. They say the project will provide a boon to corrupt African officials, dislocate indigenous peoples and harm ecologically sensitive areas.[…] EXXON MOBIL has insisted on World Bank participation as a hedge against instability, Ms. Horta said. She referred to the bank's role, which represents less than 10 percent of the project, as "political risk insurance" for investors.[…]

title: Oil Spill - Group Advocates New Compensation Agency
news: All may not be well in the Niger Delta now, as a coalition of leading Nigerian and international human, children and environmental rights groups has raised serious concerns about ongoing oil spills in the region.[...] Referring to BP'S Gulf of Mexico disaster, the coalition said it has heightened international concerns about the environmental dangers of offshore drilling around the world and has led to President Obama declaring it America's "environmental.[...] Patrick Naagbanton, coordinator of the Centre for Environmental, Human Rights and Development (CEHRD) and spokesperson for the group, said, "While the American government has secured a $20 billion package from BP to compensate the communities affected by the Gulf of Mexico spill, communities in Niger Delta are offered little or no justice. "The recent devastating oil spills by ExxonMobil in Akwa Ibom State highlight this case perfectly. While we welcome the Nigeria Oil Spill Response Agency (NOSDRA) taking a greater interest in these recent oil spills, we are calling for urgent action as there is clearly a failure by both regulatory bodies and oil companies to achieve even basic outcomes in response to oil spills and their prevention.[...]

title: AN OLYMPIC SETBACK FOR NEWTOWN CREEK
news: THE CITY'S FAILED 2012 Olympic bid may have cost more than a stadium on Manhattan's West Side: The cleanup of the highly toxic Newtown Creek is again bogged down, critics charged. "It shouldn't take an Olympic bid to get the city government's attention focused on an environmental disaster," said City Councilman David Yassky, (D-Greenpoint), chairman of the Council's Waterfronts Committee. The Bloomberg administration and the state Department of Environmental Conservation have done little to clean up the industrial dumping - including the 17-million gallon oil plume that began leaking under homes in Greenpoint and into the creek in the 1940s, Yassky charged. […] "We never would have gotten involved in this case if the state had been doing its job," said Basil Seggos, an investigator for the watchdog environmental group Riverkeeper, which sued ExxonMobil last year. Riverkeeper filed a lawsuit against the company, claiming gases from the spill threaten workers and residents. ExxonMobil officials yesterday defended their efforts at Newtown Creek. "ExxonMobil takes its environmental responsibilities seriously," said spokesman Brian Dunphy. He said that 8.8 million gallons of petroleum have been removed since 1979. […]

title: South Africa; Oil-Refining Capacity Still Tight
news: NEWS that energy giant CHEVRON may sell two of its refineries to focus on the Asia-Pacific market can only strengthen the impression that downstream assets such as refineries are being neglected as independent oil companies restructure their assets. Inadequate refining capacity poses a serious threat to security of supply.  It is little wonder that various governments have gone to greats lengths to ensure investment in refineries. The snag, however, is the cost of the exercise, as refineries are not cheap to set up. Several African countries have announced plans to lure investors who will revive their ailing oil-refining sectors. Nigeria is one which has been grappling with problematic oil refineries. [...] The Nigerian government's efforts to give the oil refining sector a new lease on life have included privatising it. However, there has not been a big rush by oil companies or the oil majors - to be specific - to invest in refineries. One of the reasons given for the lack of refinery investment is poor financial return. Strict environmental rules have also been blamed for a lack of investment in the US and Europe. The US - the world's biggest economy - has not built a new refinery since 1976. The move towards cleaner fuels requires owners of existing refineries to modernise and upgrade their assets if they are to remain globally competitive. Energy analyst Cornelis van der Waal of Frost & Sullivan says oil companies with refineries in SA will have to make investments in preparation for the introduction of new fuel emission standards, known as the Euro 4, by 2012. The new standards will require either the construction of new refineries or the upgrading of existing ones. Companies are likely to opt to refurbish existing facilities. [...] In SA, where security of supply is a great concern, the oil industry will be under pressure to upgrade its refineries. The switch to cleaner fuels led to fuel supply disruptions in 2005 as the petroleum industry had to modify its refineries. [...] Recent comments by CHEVRON executive John Watson about the company's intentions for its refineries have fuelled speculation about the fate of the company's refinery at Milnerton in Cape Town. [...] Mkhize says the quest for financial sustainability has independent oil companies eyeing the more lucrative upstream activities, namely the search, recovery and production of crude oil and natural gas. [...]

title: As Garbage Piles Up, So Do Complaints
news: It is nearly noon, prime time for unloading garbage at the BFI waste transfer station in the South Bronx. City sanitation trucks back into a cavernous warehouse and dump their loads onto the concrete floor. Bulldozers rumble across, pushing trash toward a 20-foot high mountain of garbage. Soon it will be compacted, loaded onto trucks, and driven to landfills in the Midwest.     With the recent closing of the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island, this scene is repeated more frequently than ever at the plant in Hunts Point and at the 12 other land-based transfer stations. They are now handling about 13,000 tons of residential garbage a day, nearly double what the stations got when they processed only commercial garbage.   The waste stations have long been a grievance for residents of the South Bronx and Greenpoint and Williamsburg in Brooklyn, where most of the stations are clustered. But now there has been a sharp increase in foul odors, truck congestion and pollution from diesel exhaust. And complaints have increased accordingly. The city argues that trucks and transfer sites are a gritty fact of urban life. At BFI Waste Services of New York, in the Bronx, trucks back up to the doors and dump 2,990 tons of garbage a day. Fast-moving bulldozers rush in, pushing the trash into the towering garbage mountain stretching the width of the warehouse. What seems to be just a malodorous mush turns more colorful from just a few feet away. Scraps of fabric and gift wrapping pour from plastic trash bags, mixed in among crushed paper PEPSI cups and cracker boxes.[…] Residents of the South Bronx and Brooklyn blame garbage truck exhaust and the polluted air around the transfer stations for the high rate of asthma in their neighborhoods.[…] Mark Izeman, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization, called waste transfer sites "among the most detested and unwanted land uses in the city." In addition, he said, "They are disproportionately sited in communities of color and low-income neighborhoods."[…]

title: Underwater Line Is Wet Kiss for U.S. Supply
news: Independent transmission developers in both the northeastern and northwestern U.S. looking to bring Canada's renewable electricity resources to power-hungry regions south of the border are installing hundreds of miles of line by using the path of least resistance--underwater. «There's a trend toward acceptance of this technology and this market,» says Christer Erikkson, director of business development at ABB Power Systems, a division of ABB Group, Zurich, Switzerland. The firm is one of the major manufacturers for high-voltage, direct- current (HVDC) lines and converter stations. «It's easier to lay a cable underwater, and it's generally better accepted because it's out of sight, out of mind,» he adds, noting that in some cases, an underwater cable is the only option. […] Unlike alternating-current (AC) lines, direct-current lines must have expensive converters at each end to convert the power. However, DC lines can carry electricity an almost infinite distance without losing much, if any, of the current, making them ideal to carry large loads of electricity over long distances. AC lines cannot carry power farther than about 40 miles, says Steve Eckroad, superconductivity program manager at Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, Calif. The Champlain-Hudson would be almost a direct line from new hydroelectric power and other renewable sources in upper Quebec and upstate New York to metropolitan areas. The cable would begin in the Richelieu River in Quebec and then travel south through Lake Champlain and along railroad rights-of-way, avoiding environmentally sensitive areas such as the GENERAL ELECTRIC Co. PCB cleanup site in the upper Hudson River. The cable would enter the Hudson River south of Albany and deliver power to converter stations in Yonkers, N.Y., and Bridgeport, Conn. Jessome says Transmission Developers is still in discussions with HVDC providers and contractors but has completed engineering studies of the route. Installing the cable would require use of a highly specialized boat that can carry about 60 miles of cables. Using global positioning systems and thrusters, the ship is able to lay the cable within 1 meter along the route. A special water jet, or water plow, digs a trench ranging from 3 ft to 6 ft to lay the line, which must be buried deep enough to avoid colliding with an anchor. […]

title: Looking after the web of life
news: Environmentalist David Suzuki has some green advice for Australian businesses, writes Vince Chadwick. FRANKNESS is a trademark of David Suzuki. So much so that, when he was invited by soft drink maker PEPSICO to speak about sustainability, he told his hosts their company should cease to exist. "PEPSI is sugared water and it is creating unbelievable health problems," he told his hosts.   "I find it hard to justify a company like yours existing." In April, Dr Suzuki will bring his trademark frankness to Melbourne for the Corporations, People & the Planet conference and trade show. The three-day event, featuring celebrity activists Bob Geldof and Sigourney Weaver, offers attendees the chance to "increase your business's profit margin by implementing sustainable business practices". […]

title: Nigeria; Fresh Alarm Over $400m West African Gas Project
news: Lagos - The Environmental Rights Action (ERA) group, a non-governmental organisation concerned with environmental protection, has raised fresh alarm over the proposed $400 million West African Gas Pipeline (WAGP) project. Which is expected to transport natural gas from Nigeria to choice consumers in Benin Republic, Togo and Ghana. In a recent booklet titled: "PIPE Dream. The West African Gas Pipeline Project and the Environment", ERA stated that environmental degradation of monumental proportion will hit the entire West African sub-region, should the WAGP project as presently conceived, be allowed to continue. Aside from fear of possible environmental degradation, ERA further contended that the project, would lead to escalation of communal conflicts and the dislocation of local communities. […] Citing the 1995 World Bank report which indicated that claims made by oil companies that gas projects would eliminate flaring were made to deceive the people, ERA said: "Without any clear plan of eliminating flaring of associated gas, CHEVRON is attempting to deceive the world into believing that the West African Gas pipeline will result in the immediate reduction of gas flaring." […] The WAGP projected is being floated by a consortium comprising CHEVRON Nigeria Limited (CNL), Nigeria National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), Shell Petroleum Development Corporation (SPDC), Ghana National Petroleum Corporation (GNPC), Societe Togolaise de Gaz (SOTOGAS) and Societe Benioise de Gaz S.A. (SOBEGAZ). […]

title: Agency withholds key elements in plans for spills; Lack of disclosure is inexcusable, critics say
news: The watchdog agency that oversees oil drilling off the coast of Newfoundland is keeping secret key information about how companies would respond to a spill, including details about who would be in charge of the cleanup and where spills are expected to drift. Canadian regulators insist they are being as transparent as possible within the law. But critics say the lack of full disclo-sure is inexcusable at a time when the public's confidence in offshore drilling has been shaken by the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. [...] In CHEVRON's response plan, for example, a section labelled "project emergency and spill response teams" has been blacked out. Other sections in the CHEVRON plan have been censored, including information on the "spill notification process" and an entire appendix on "oil-spill trajectories."[...] But Gail Fraser, an associate professor in environmental studies at York University, said the public has a right to know about projects that could pollute our natural resources: "We're permitting these operators to pollute in federal waters. These are public resources, and the potential impact of these various impact can be enormous." [...]

title: PanAfrica; Statement of Salih Booker, Executive Director of Africa Action, On U.s. Secretary of State Colin Powell And the World Summit On Sustainable Development (wssd)
news: Today, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell unfortunately preoccupied with Iraq and his own retirement plans leads the American delegation to the World Summit on Sustainable Development (WSSD) in Johannesburg, South Africa. His trip is "a day late and a dollar short" as far as making a positive difference is concerned. He is supposed to announce new multi-year spending plans for supporting development in Africa that the White House has crafted using Arthur Andersen-style accounting methods (i.e. counting old money several times and using projections for sums that don't yet exist). Arriving after all the major issues have already been addressed, he will mainly defend the U.S. opposition to setting goals and time frames for achieving progress on most environmental and developmental matters by falsely suggesting that the U.S. is leading the world in support for sustainable development. […] Secretary Powell is attending only the final two days of the summit. He is representing President Bush, who refused to attend the summit. Last year Bush prevented Powell, the first African American Secretary of State, from even attending the World Conference Against Racism also hosted by South Africa. […] Powell's decision not to visit Nigeria, the most important African country, may have been influenced by the hundreds of Nigerian women that recently took over several oil platforms of CHEVRON/Texaco to protest their exploitation of Nigerian resources and pollution of the environment while failing to invest in the development of local communities. In Angola, Secretary Powell is unlikely to address the moral demand for U.S. reparations to help the country rebuild itself following decades of war covertly financed by Washington.

title: Gore's oil pledge
news: Vice President Al Gore says that as president he would do all that he could to block oil drilling off the coasts of Florida and California. […] Vice President Al Gore has built a political career partly on his reputation as a staunch environmentalist. But until recently he equivocated on an issue that should be fundamental to his green philosophy: offshore drilling for oil and gas. In a speech last week, Gore finally broke his silence. A Gore administration, he pledged, would do everything it could to block all drilling off Florida and California.  Until his campaign speech Thursday, Gore had been conspicuously vague on the drilling question. As the debate raged over whether the U.S. Commerce Department - an agency that falls under Gore and President Clinton - should allow CHEVRON USA to drill for gas off the Florida Gulf Coast, the vice president said a law prohibited him from taking a position. Gore did not exactly address the CHEVRON question head-on, but his call for an all-out ban on granting new leases and acting on existing ones clearly covers it. "I will take the most sweeping steps in our history to protect our oceans and coastal waters from offshore oil drilling," Gore said. […] Gov. The bill provides mandatory standards for operating the nation's power grid, a measure designed to prevent the spread of blackouts. U.S. lawmakers dealt a blow to the bid by China National Offshore Oil Corp. to acquire Unocal Corp. by adding wording that would require a 120-day review of China's growing energy demands before any CNOOC deal could close. This study is in addition to Washington's planned national security review of a CNOOC acquisition and would further impair the Chinese company's ability to close a deal. By delaying the close of any deal with CNOOC, the move by Congress would make the Chinese company's offer significantly less attractive to Unocal investors - and so give a boost to the competing bid from CHEVRON Corp., which could close in weeks. Representatives of other energy producers, including oil, nuclear, coal and solar energy - along with ethanol-producing farmers - were pleased, too. A number of problems affecting these groups have evolved from a lack of federal energy policy. title: THE AD CAMPAIGN; McCall Criticized on Education
news: This is a new 30-second commercial released yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. In addition to this spot, which focuses on the record of the governor's Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, the Pataki campaign re-released an older advertisement emphasizing the environment, health care and education. Both ads will be broadcast downstate. […] ACCURACY: One-sided. The environmental votes referred to mostly involved shareholder resolutions aimed at forcing companies to adopt Ceres, a set of environmental standards. No proxy votes have resulted in a victory for Ceres, at any company, and the New York City Pension Fund is the only large public pension fund that routinely votes in favor of such social issues. Mr. McCall has said that his duty as trustee of the New York State Pension Fund is one of fiduciary guardian, not social activist. But he also takes credit for using the millions of General Electric shares under his control to pressure that company into decontaminating the Hudson River of PCB's. The Pataki campaign's figures on education have also been challenged before. While over all the student-to-teacher ratio increased, the average class size in kindergarten through third grade, where researchers contend that smaller classes are most important, shrunk to 24.5 students from 25, and in grades four to six it went down to 28 from 30. Class size did increase slightly for middle and high school grades. SCORECARD: The governor goes after Mr. McCall by remote control. Upstate, Mr. McCall, according to Mr. Pataki, is a tax-and-spend liberal. Downstate, he is weak on Democratic basics like education and the environment. The problem with these attacks is that there is not much there there. But the commercials may hurt Mr. McCall, given that Mr. Pataki has the means to run them frequently enough to drill them into people's heads.   SHAILA K. DEWAN

title: Oil giant in environmental gun
news: Environmental groups are gathering evidence for an unprecedented legal battle to pin part of the blame for global warming on a single company, Exxon Mobil. A report by New Zealand's National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (Niwa), released by Friends of the Earth in London last month, says Exxon Mobil's oil products have caused between 4.8 per cent and 5.5 per cent of the global increase in carbon dioxide in the past 120 years. The director of the London-based Climate Initiatives Fund, Simon Retallack, says research is under way to prove direct economic costs of the resulting rise in global temperature. […] The case against Exxon Mobil is based on two reports. The first, by a researcher at Colorado's Rocky Mountain Institute, added up all emissions by Exxon Mobil, its predecessor companies and their customers since their original ancestor, Standard Oil, was formed in 1882. It found that the company's main effect on global warming came from carbon dioxide emissions by customers who burned its oil. The company had a much smaller effect on global levels of another greenhouse gas, methane, and its effect on nitrogen oxide levels was "negligible". Niwa scientists Jim Salinger and Greg Bodeker then put these results into a global climate model and calculated that Exxon Mobil could be blamed for between 3.4 per cent and 3.7 per cent of the 0.6C rise in global temperatures since 1882. They said the company also accounted for about 2 per cent of the 8cm average rise in sea level in the same period. […]

title: The next colonial scramble; LEADING ARTICLE THE ARCTIC

Shell has quietly spent $2bn (£1bn) acquiring drilling leases off Alaska. ExxonMobil and BP have spent huge sums on exploration rights off Canada. [...] Environmental arguments - about the need to preserve this final pristine wilderness and to protect endangered species and the 160,000 remaining Inuit who have lived in the High Arctic for thousands of years - are being brushed aside, as ever. But the context is different now. The Arctic is one of the most prominent battlegrounds in the fight against global warming. It is a bitter irony that oil extraction is now more feasible, and economic, than before because the ice has been melted thanks to climate change. The further release of methane trapped in the thawing permafrost could accelerate that, perhaps uncontrollably. Instead of scrambling into Arctic exploration what governments and energy companies should be doing is exploring al-ternatives to oil.[...]

title: THE BIG CLIMATE CON
news: No, it's not abstract, up there in the clouds!" exclaimed Talita Beck. "I can see it. I can measure it." We were talking about carbon emissions; Beck is an emissions assessor, a profession that did not exist a decade ago. Several times a month, she leaves her office in SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil, in search of greenhouse gases - or, more precisely, to visit sites that have promised to emit less of them. Such commitments, whether made by malodorous pig farms, squalid city dumps, or rural sugarcane-processing mills, can be transformed into money by companies thousands of miles away, in Britain or Germany or Japan or any other country that has ratified the Kyoto Protocols. Carbon trading is now the fastest-growing commodities market on earth. Since 2005, when major greenhouse-gas polluters among the Kyoto signatories were issued caps on their emissions and permitted to buy credits to meet those caps, there have been more than $US300billion worth of carbon transactions. Major financial institutions such as Goldman Sachs, Barclays and Citi now host carbon trading desks in London; traders who once speculated on oil and gas are betting on the most insidious side effects of our fossil fuel-based economy. Over the next decade, if US President Obama and other advocates can institute a cap-and-trade system in the US, the demand for carbon credits could explode into a $US2 to $US3trillion market, according to the market analysis firm Point Carbon. title: A WINNING BLUEPRINT PATAKI'S POINT MAN MUST FOLLOW THE LESSONS OF ROBERT MOSES
news: Back in the 1920s, when Gov. Alfred E. Smith wanted to build a cutting-edge parkway (the Northern State) and public beach (Jones), he dispatched one of his closest aides, Robert Moses, to get the megaproject done. And Moses did not disappoint, using the immense power Smith invested in him to redraw, literally, the map of Long Island and build what became a landmark in the annals of American public works. […] No doubt, the move is long overdue. The Port Authority, the Lower Manhattan Development Corp. and leaseholder Larry Silverstein all hold some claim over Ground Zero. Confusing, isn't it? They need an enforcer, an overseer who can make a decision and hold all to account. That will be Cahill's job. "He's the best we've got," said one Pataki associate, noting Cahill's role in burnishing Pataki's environmental credentials by orchestrating 900,000 acres in state open space acquisitions, and helping prod GENERAL ELECTRIC into an unprecedented cleanup of PCBs from the Hudson River. With his new assignment, Cahill will have to take his game to the next level. To do that, he should follow Moses' rules. Moses had his designers work 24/7. He wouldn't take no for an answer and fired anyone who did. And he deftly turned public opinion against anyone who dared stand in his way. That's asking a lot of anyone, even Cahill. But if he wants his boss, Pataki, to have something to dedicate before his term ends next year, Moses is the model.
