title: Hudson River Decision To Have Broad Impact
news: Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Christie Whitman's decision to go ahead with the dredging of the PCB-contaminated Hudson River bed will have massive ramifications for the nation's rivers and ports. It will also send potentially responsible parties for other large Superfund sites scrambling for cover as General Electric (GE) is forced to foot the $460-million cleanup bill. Under the EPA plan, GE will have to dredge 2.7 million cubic yards of sediment laced with 100,000 pounds of PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls)"probable carcinogens"along a 40-mile stretch of the Hudson north of Albany, making it the largest hazardous waste cleanup in the history of the Superfund program  And that's likely to be just the beginning. The EPA is shifting its attention to the nation's biggest Superfund sites"those for which remediation costs would run to an average of $140 million. Contaminated sediments account for the majority of such "megasites." The total volume of contaminated sediments nationwide"covering a range of pollutants from oil to DDT"amounts to some 1.2 billion cubic yards. The shift in emphasis stems in part from complaints from small businesses that they've been carrying more than their share of the cost of Superfund cleanups. That's because the EPA has focused in recent years on cleaning landfill sites, where small businesses are identified as contributing polluters. The EPA has mostly finished its work on such common landfills, and in the megasites that remain, large manufacturing companies are often primarily responsible for the pollution that needs to be cleaned up. news: Shell and its partners today struck a deal that will finally see the go-ahead for the world's biggest new liquefied natural gas (LNG) project. The British oil giant owns a 25% stake in the proposed Gorgon LNG project in Australia, and, along with CHEVRON and ExxonMobil, has agreed to build it at a lower-than-expected cost of £37 billion.[...]While the go-ahead, which follows years of delay, will bring relief to Shell, CHEVRON and ExxonMobil, it will be seen as a catastrophe by environmental campaigners, who have cited serious concerns about its location on Barrow Island off the coast of Western Australia. It was also hampered by concerns about building costs, although the recent downturn in the oil and gas industry has reduced this.[...]

title: Renewables policy under attack
news: THE nation's biggest oil and gas lobby group has attacked the Rudd Government's renewable energy policy, citing a consultant's report that says the policy will cost $1.8 billion to the economy and 3600 full-time jobs. The attack comes from the Australian Petroleum Production & Exploration Association, which represents some of the biggest fossil-fuel companies in Australia, including Shell, BP, CHEVRON, Woodside and AGL, which produce and supply almost all the country's oil and gas. The association's chief executive, Belinda Robinson, included the criticism of the Government policy in its submission to the Government's climate change review headed by Professor Ross Garnaut. The Prime Minister, Kevin Rudd, promised during the election campaign to lift Australia's renewable energy, including solar, wind, geothermal and hydro power, from 2 per cent to 20 per cent by 2020, and the target would be mandatory. The aim is to try to reduce the country's soaring greenhouse gas emissions from the burning of fossil fuels. The target was strongly backed by environmental groups and the then chairman of the Clean Energy Council, the AGL chief executive, Paul Anthony, who has since resigned and returned to Britain. An association spokesman said it was not opposing policies to invest in renewable energy but raising concerns about the 20 per cent target, which will pressure energy companies to source their power from renewables.

title: Bush turns up the US energy powerhouse
news: Warning of a "darker future" unless the United States aggressively drills for more oil and exploits fossil fuels to keep up with its galloping energy demands, President George Bush has unveiled his long-awaited energy plan. The plan, developed by Vice-President Dick Cheney and announced by Mr Bush on Thursday, provides $US10billion ($19billion) in tax credits for environmentally friendly measures like "hybrid" cars and solar panels on houses, but its emphasis is on increasing the supply of energy from fossil fuels.[…] Environmental groups reacted with fury, saying the conservation sweeteners were a smokescreen for a generous handout to the energy industry from a vice- president and president who both once worked in the oil business. Democrats dismissed the report, printed on glossy paper with pictures of bears in forests and happy fishermen, as "full of pretty coloured pictures". "It really looks like the EXXON MOBIL annual report," the Democratic House leader, Mr Dick Gephardt, said. "And maybe that's really what it is."[…] But environmentalists said the plan proved the Administration did not taking global warming seriously.[…]

title: EXXON'S RAYMOND: OIL INDUSTRY KINGPIN
news: Lee Raymond, the hard-charging oil exec who will run the combined Exxon Mobil, is legendary in the industry but practically a nonentity outside of it. […] A detail-oriented exec, Raymond personally negotiated the $ 900 million settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1990.

title: PepsiCo plans to satisfy munchies with chickpea-based products
news: While potato and corn tortilla-based snack foods have long dominated supermarket snack shelves, PepsiCo is hoping to transform the industry with a new, billion-dollar investment that may produce a raft of foods from a different kind of food staple: chickpeas. [...] Meanwhile, Coca-Cola also announced it had awarded $9.6 million in grant awards to 40 global community groups, including water stewardship projects, educational initiatives and nutrition programs. The company has also had to blunt criticism from environmentalists over its bottled water brand Dasani. Water advocates say bottled water undermines confidence in the public water supply and creates unnecessary waste with plastic packaging. Dasani sources their water from the local water supply and is filtered using a process called reverse osmosis.

title: Global companies snub survey on climate change
news: More than 100 of the world's largest companies have been accused of not facing up to global warming after they snubbed a global survey of corporate attitudes to climate change. Aerospace company Boeing, computer giant Apple, online retailer Amazon and News Corporation, which publishes the Sun and Times newspapers, are among the organisations that failed to respond to a survey from the Carbon Disclosure Project, which launched a report on its findings yesterday in New York. Acting on behalf of institutional investors with combined assets of more than £11 trillion, the London-based project asked the heads of the largest 500 companies how big a risk climate change posed to their business and what they were doing to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Of the 354 firms that responded, 90% said climate change posed commercial risks or opportunities and 63% claimed they were taking steps to cut emissions. […]

title: China warns Rudd of LNG deals risk
news: Kevin Rudd is under international pressure to protect the liquefied natural gas industry from a full emissions trading regime, with China and Korea warning that multi-billion-dollar LNG deals with North-West Shelf suppliers could be at risk. [...] It is understood the Chinese told Mr Rudd that though they regarded Australian LNG as crucial to their efforts to reduce carbon emissions, they would not buy it at any price. [...] The pressure is evidence the LNG industry is briefing its biggest customers on ramifications of the Government plan to reduce greenhouse gas pollution. Under the Government's green paper, LNG producers were surprised to learn they would not be eligible for free pollution permits, despite LNG being much cleaner than coal. The producers, led by Woodside, are lobbying for free permits, arguing the viability of offshore projects including Browse, Gorgon and Pluto, worth at least $60 billion combined, would be threatened without them. [...] To increase the pressure on the Rudd Government, the Australian Petroleum Production & Exploration Association will send a letter to the Prime Minister early next week demanding protection for the LNG industry from the ETS. Signatories include the chairmen or chief executives of Apache, BHP Billiton, BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil, Inpex, Shell and Woodside. The letter calls for the formula to be changed so LNG can be granted free emission permits.

title: Tech giants are still using toxic chemicals, says Greenpeace
news: Technology giants including Samsung, Sony and Panasonic are among the firms still using hazardous chemicals that are contributing to a "growing environmental crisis", a major new report has found. While there has been some progress in recent years, the latest Greenpeace Green Gadgets report shows that leading consumer electronics companies are continuing to use toxic chemicals in smartphones, televisions, tablets, computers and cables. […] However, Greenpeace attacked Microsoft for dropping a previous "phase-out commitment" and Amazon for "failing to provide any information to the public". […] Spokespeople for Samsung, Sony, Panasonic, Amazon and Microsoft were yet to respond for requests for comment last night. […]

title: Special report: Oil industry: Greenpeace occupies rig in protest at Arctic drilling: Activists board mobile platform off Turkish coast Delay could cost Cairn Energy millions of pounds
news: The fight to stop the global oil industry exploring the pristine deep waters of the Arctic has been dubbed the new cold war, and early yesterday it escalated as environmental activists from 12 countries occupied the world's second largest rig on its way from Turkey to Greenland to drill among the icebergs.[...] But the Arctic venture, say environmentalists, is just the start of what is planned to be a risky offshore oil rush. Shell, Exxon Mobil, Chevron and others have licences to explore in Baffin Bay, mostly above the Arctic circle. [...] But for Greenpeace and others the risk of a devastating spill is too great, raising the spectre of the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska in 1989 when more than 1m barrels of oil were spilt, and the $40bn (£24bn) disaster in the Gulf of Mexico last year.[...]

title: Checking in to the Hibernia 'hotel'  Life's pretty good on the huge oil platform, even though it's 315 kilometres offshore
news: STEVE Coady once hauled fish from the waters of the North Atlantic, but he now makes his living inserting oil pipe into the ocean's depths.[…]During their three-week shift, workers have to cope with living two people to a room in units reminiscent of a university dorm. They must adhere to a strict safety regimen, with frequent evacuation drills, and submit to random testing for drugs and alcohol. […] As well, they have to get used to operating 100 metres above the Atlantic in a workplace that poses such hazards as fires, chemical spills and poisonous gases. Last week, 93 workers were taken by helicopter to a nearby drilling rig for a short time as a precaution when methane gas was released accidentally through a pressure valve in a shaft 70 metres below the main platform.[…]Hibernia facts. Location: On the Grand Banks 315 kilometres east of St. John's. […] Owners: Hibernia Management and Development Co. -- owned by Mobil Oil Canada -- 33.125 per cent; CHEVRON Canada Resources 26.875 per cent; Petro-Canada, 20 per cent; federally owned Canada Hibernia Holding Corp., 8.5 per cent; Murphy Oil, 6.5 per cent; Norsk Hydro of Norway, 5 per cent.

title: Exxon in US oil spill court win
news: EXXON Mobil tonight won a major court battle over the bill it was forced to pay for the Exxon Valdez oil spill almost 20 years ago. The US Supreme Court cut to $507.5 million the $2.5 billion Exxon was ordered to pay victims. The original $5 billion charge, made in 1994, was halved by a federal appeals court. Some 1300 miles of Alaskan coastline were polluted when the Exxon Valdez ran aground at Prince William Sound in March 1989 in the worst oil spill in American history. The ships captain, Joseph Hazelwood, admitted drinking vodka before boarding the vessel

title: Industry saw Rudd's ETS as best deal on offer: US
news: [...] Most of Australia's major industry groups supported the former Rudd government's emissions trading scheme as "the best deal they will get," according to United States embassy cables posted online by WikiLeaks. A three-year document trail shows the US embassy in Canberra took a close interest in federal climate change policy, initially describing it as "an area of major disagreement" with US policy. [...] The documents also reveal intense lobbying of the Rudd government by global gas and oil companies, including Exxon, Woodside and CHEVRON, to be listed as emissions intensive trade- exposed industries so they would receive compensation and free carbon credits An embassy briefing note sent to White House senior climate change adviser Landon Van Dyke in Washington described industry compensation as "the single greatest lightning rod" in the Rudd government's proposed emissions trading scheme.[...]

title: Gas project put before rare turtles
news: THE country's biggest energy project is expected to get approval, despite environmental concerns over a rare species of turtle, as the West Australian Government bows to business pressure. Premier Alan Carpenter indicated yesterday he was prepared to overrule advice from the state's Environment Protection Authority that the $11billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas project not be allowed to proceed. While Mr Carpenter stopped short of providing a guarantee the project would go ahead, he said it involved ''massive economic and social benefit'' for the state. The Gorgon development, promoted by partners ExxonMobil, CHEVRON and Shell, will produce 10million tonnes a year of liquefied natural gas. But the proposed site is on environmentally sensitive Barrow Island, off the Pilbara coast, and EPA chairman Wally Cox warned of the dangers. Work done by the joint venturers as part of the environmental review and management program had ''further highlighted the terrestrial and marine conservation values of Barrow Island and the adjacent waters'', Dr Cox said. […] CHEVRON rejected the EPA's assessment that the development would threaten the breeding area for about a third of the region's flatback turtles. […] Mr Carpenter pitched the environmental issue in the context of the uranium debate, saying the Gorgon project would provide even more gas to meet Australia's future energy needs. […] But she said if the Government did override the EPA, ''they will have lost any shred of environmental credibility''. […]

title: South Africa; Activists Question the Commitment of Africa's Biggest Carbon Polluter
news: Activists have reacted with alarm to the South African intention to burn 32 billion tons of coal by 3011 and have questioned SA's glib commitment to carbon capture, saying the process is untested, expensive and dangerous. South Africa is Africa's biggest emitter of carbon dioxide, accounting for 80 percent of the continent's output, says the SA goverment. South Africa is ranked by climate activists as the 11th biggest emitter in the world, higher than a number of European countries. s emissions, SA Environment Affairs Minister Edna Molewa said at a media briefing at the UN's COP17 climate change conference yesterday. "That is a human and climate time bomb," says Climate Action Network (CAN) member, Heffa Schucking of German-based NGO Urgewald.[…] Bank Tracks' Yann Louvel says South Africa's commitment to renewable energy contributing 9% of the total energy mix over the next 20 years was very unambitious. Germany's renewable energy consumption is already at 20% of their national total.[…] They criticized State power company Eskom's "gargantuan" new coal plant projects, Medupi and Kusile, saying they alone would eat up the carbon emission savings of the million solar heaters the SA government intends installing. Bank Tracks says a reading of the portfolios of banks around the world reveals that since 2005 Eskom has been funded mainly by three banks; Crédit Agricole (489 million Euros), JP Morgan Chase (424), Deutsche Bank (408). The second tier comprises Barclays (291 million Euros), HSBC (285), BNP Paribas (276), Group BPCE/Natixis (276), BANK OF AMERICA (265), Société Générale (204) and Standard Chartered (199). A third tier is headed up by Standard Bank (99 million Euros), KfW (85), Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (85), Nedbank (85), Commerzbank (75), UniCredit/ HVB (75). The rats and mice are made up of Citi (27 million Euros), Royal Bank of Scotland (27), ING (13) and Morgan Stanley (4).

title: Cairn Energy cheers investors and chills green activists with oil strike in the Arctic: Discovery is the first to be made off Greenland Shares rise by 2% amid hopes of huge reserves: Fuel gauge
news: The Scottish oil producer Cairn Energy yesterday said it had found oil in the untouched waters off the coast of Greenland, a discovery that will alarm environmentalists, although it was welcomed by local officials and investors. However, the company, which had previously announced a gas find in the pristine region, said that it had abandoned that earlier test well after deciding the volume was not commercially viable.[...] But the discovery will raise concern among environmental groups, which are opposed to drilling on the grounds that any accident would be disastrous. Opposition has grown, particularly to deepwater drilling, in the wake of the Gulf of Mexico disaster. [...] Yesterday, Greenpeace members boarded a CHEVRON-operated ship to protest at drilling operations in British waters off Shetland. CHEVRON is exploring in depths of about 500 metres (1,600 feet). BP's Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico was 1,500 metres deep. [...]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
news: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12 Moscow Meeting Ends Without Defense Accord President Clinton and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia concluded two days of talks with mutual praise and two agreements, but without narrowing the differences over the limited missile defense system the United States wants to erect. Officials described the atmosphere between the two leaders as businesslike, though not necessarily warm.   A1 Security for Barak Increased Israel's secret service has tightened security around Prime Minister Ehud Barak, news media reports say, as some Jewish settlers warn that the domestic climate has the potential to turn ugly if Israeli-Palestinian peace talks move forward.   A6 […] NEW YORK/REGION   B1-12 E.P.A. Poised to Order Cleanup for PCB's A long tug of war between environmental officials and the General Electric Company over what, if anything, to do about the Hudson River's last big chemical stain is almost over. The E.P.A. appears poised to order a cleanup of what it calls a persistent threat to people and wildlife: the polychlorinated biphenyls that lace the river bottom north of Albany and contaminate many kinds of fish throughout the river.   A1 Parade Turns Political Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio stood side by side at New York City's annual Salute to Israel parade. The division within the Jewish community over the United States Senate candidates was starkly on display, and some organizers said the political jockeying overshadowed the purpose of the event.   B1 […]

title: Multi-million bio-piracy lawsuit over faded jeans and African lakes
news: FROM Britney Spears to Eminem, Busted to the Libertines, no self-respecting pop star would be without a pair of faded jeans in their wardrobe.  Now the iconic trousers are at the centre of a 'bio-piracy' row with Kenyan authorities claiming Leicester University and a US biotech company illegally acquired a unique method of giving denims the naturally worn look.  Last week the Kenya Wildlife Service launched a multi-million dollar claim in the US to share in profits of Genencor from chemicals the Californian firm patented that are used to wash and fade jeans. […]  Not only did Grant find an organism that survives such environments, but also one that softens the fabric and 'eats' indigo dye from jeans, giving them the faded look. Another organism from the lake helped remove biological stains from cotton products.  Genencor bought the samples from Grant, patented them and went on to clone them on an industrial scale at laboratories in Holland and California. The company has since made more than $ 1m in sales to detergent manufacturers and textile firms.[…]  One Genencor client is US multinational PROCTER & GAMBLE. KWS alleges the Kenyan micro-organism was used in Tide washing powders. This is denied by PROCTER & GAMBLE and Genencor.  KWS has instructed lawyers for Public Interest Intellectual Property Advisors to pursue the claim. For the US group, spokesman Michael Gollins said: 'All downstream users who benefit from use of genetic resources should confirm that the material was obtained responsibly, with fair sharing of the benefits, or they may face legal repercussions or hostility from consumers.'[…]

title: Barrow won't have to go back to square one
news: THE Gorgon LNG partners will not have to restart the clock for environmental approvals for their plans to expand the controversial proposed processing facility on Barrow Island.[...] There was intense opposition to the plan from conservationists, who complained that a major industrial facility on Barrow Island would be environmentally unsound and ran the risk of destroying rare and endangered flora and fauna. Barrow Island has attracted international recognition for environmental management because it hosts Australia's longest operating oil field, which began production more than 40 years ago. [...] The revised production level followed discussion between Chevron and its partners, Exxon Mobil and Shell, after a realisation that the approved plant size was too small to justify vastly increased construction that had occurred since the Gorgon proposal was put to the Government in 2003.[...]

title: Green: the color of controversy
news: What a paradox that Apple Inc.'s iPhone has become at once the gold standard for wireless devices and, according to critics, plaintiffs' lawyers and others, all that is wrong with a mobile-phone industry that conscientiously controls what goes into the phones and onto networks. […] By mid-December, or about the time LG's Voyager and other new Verizon Wireless phones are well into their rollout, the Center for Environmental Health is set to pull the trigger on a suit alleging the levels of phthalates in the iPhone violate the California law known as Proposition 65. Prop 65 requires businesses to disclose information to Californians about significant amounts of chemicals in products known to cause cancer, birth defects or other reproductive harm. Can an iPhone do all that, too? ``There is no reason to have these potentially hazardous chemicals in iPhones,'' said Michael Green, executive director of Oakland-based CEH, when giving Apple the required 60-day notice of its intention to sue a couple weeks back. ``We expect Apple to reformulate their products to make them safer from cradle to grave, so they don't pose a threat to consumers, workers or the environment.'' The action is based on a Greenpeace study. Apple has said nothing publicly, though Jobs vows to continue pursuing a greener Apple.

title: Nigeria; Akwa Ibom And EXXON MOBIL to End Gas Flaring By 2004
news: Akwa Ibom State government and EXXON MOBIL have expressed commitment to end gas flaring in the state by 2004 with the state commissioner for environment calling on Mobil to ensure a zero gas flare status by 2004. Expressing governments commitment to seeing the end of gas flaring in the state while receiving the technical report of findings on "Air Quality, Precipitation and Corrosion Studies" of the Oqua Iboe terminal gas flare in Uyo recently, the Commissioner for Environment, Mr. Obong Isidore Akpan Ebie, said the state government would assess the report and make its position known in due course. Commending EXXON MOBIL for its quick response to the problem of gas flaring in the state, he urged the oil company to comply with the Federal Government directive on gas flaring as the practice would not be tolerated by the Akwa Ibom State government beyond 2004. Ebe said gas flaring leads to the corrosion of zinc roofs, acid rain, thermos stress, disruption of biochemical disorder in man amongst other unwholesome pollutions, and should be stopped to mitigate its negative effects on the communities. Presenting the report on behalf of Mobil, Mrs. Idoria Essien, manager, environmental operations, informed the commissioner that the company was committed to a zero gas flare status in the state, indicating that Mobil only currently flared 3 per cent of its produced gas.

title: U.S. says Exxon deal rules out Valdez suit
news: Exxon Corp. yesterday waived its right to challenge a law banning the Valdez from the Alaskan waters where the ship spilled almost 11 million gallons of oil in 1989, U.S. government lawyers argued yesterday. Exxon sued to overturn a 1990 law that bans from Alaska's Prince William Sound any oil tanker that has spilled more than one million gallons of oil. While the law doesn't name the Valdez specifically, the company says it targets Exxon's tanker, in a violation of the U.S. Constitution. At a hearing yesterday, government lawyers and a group of Alaskan residents tried to convince U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin that Exxon gave up its right to challenge the law when it settled the U.S. government's claims against the company in 1991. […]

title: $10bn India sale for Gorgon; ASIA RESURGENT
news: CHEVRON has secured an agreement to sell 1.5 million tonnes of liquid natural gas (LNG) from its Gorgon project to India over 20 years, in a deal worth about $10 billion. The West Australian Government has just granted final environmental approval for the $50 billion Gorgon project and revealed the conditions that will apply.[...]WA Environment Minister Donna Faragher said higher levels of protection had been agreed to, including an extra $30 million to protect a colony of endangered flatback turtles near Barrow Island. She said coral lost because of dredging would be limited to 3 per cent of the total coral area off the east coast of Barrow Island and that monitoring would be extended outside impact zones.

title: Gas pact signed with African nations  CHEVRON, Royal Dutch/Shell in venture to develop $400-million pipeline
news: After 10 years of wrangling, four African nations along with CHEVRON Corp. and Royal Dutch/Shell Group are scheduled today to sign a pact to develop the West African Gas Pipeline, a $400-million (U.S.) project that could spur an additional $1.2-billion in industrial development. Natural-gas companies from Benin, Togo, Ghana and Nigeria are set to sign a joint-venture agreement with CHEVRON and Shell to create the consortium that will develop the 950-kilometre pipeline along the West African coast from the Nigerian oil fields to Ghana. Officials from the four countries will sign a memorandum of understanding giving the venture the right to develop the pipeline. […] Once the consortium finds natural-gas buyers, the oil companies can count the natural-gas reserves among their assets, a potentially large windfall for their balance sheets equivalent to almost 350 million barrels of crude oil for CHEVRON alone. The pipeline, which will have an initial capacity of 120 million cubic feet a day, would help rid the oil companies of the embarrassing environmental issue. Flaring, or burning off excess gas, significantly adds to global warming and has become a point of friction with local and international environmentalists. The dispute over flaring has curtailed the development of further oil reserves in Nigeria.

title: CHEVRON releases video it says implicates judge
news: CHEVRON has released videos it says implicate a judge in Ecuador and a senior official of the country's ruling party in a $3 million (U.S.) bribery scheme related to a lawsuit alleging that the U.S. oil company should be held liable for $27 billion in environmental damages in Ecuador's Amazon region. The case has drawn attention because of the size of the claim against CHEVRON and the damage the proceedings could do to Ecuador's bid for most-favoured-nation status if the oil giant convinces members of Congress and the Obama administration that the country's legal system lacks integrity.[...]

title: Life: Cover story: The beginning of the end: Oil production could peak next year, reports John Vidal. Just kiss your lifestyle goodbye: Crude alternatives
news: "Unconventional" petroleum reserves, which are not included in some totals of reserves, include: Heavy oils. These can be pumped just like conventional petroleum except that they are much thicker, more polluting, and require more extensive refining. They are found in more than 30 countries, but about 90% of estimated reserves are in the Orinoco "heavy oil belt" of Venezuela, which has an estimated 1.2 trillion barrels. About one third of the oil is potentially recoverable using current technology. Tar sands. […] Oil shales. These are seen as the US government's energy stopgap. They exist in large quantities in ecologically sensitive parts of Colorado, Wyoming and Utah at varying depths, but the industrial process needed to extract the oil demands hot water, making it much more expensive and less energy-efficient than conventional oil. The mining operation is extremely damaging to the environment. Shell, Exxon, CHEVRONTEXACO and other oil companies are investing billions of dollars in this expensive oil production method.

title: Nigeria; The Case for Asari Dokubo's Release
news: An all-out war in the Niger Delta will not do the nation any good. Just as Nigerians were heaving a sigh of relief that good sense had finally triumphed in the corridors of power and that Armed Forces commanders have recognised that at the heart of the crisis in the Niger Delta is gross political marginalisation and can only be addressed through civic engagement, President Olusegun Obasanjo threw this kernel of wisdom out of the window and ordered renewed military crackdown in the region. On 20th 8 a contingent of the Joint Military Task Force ambushed twenty Ijaw youths near Letugbene in the creeks of the western delta and shot them to death. The dead men had embarked on a peaceful mission, at the behest of Shell and Ijaw elders, to negotiate the release of a Shell worker who had been held hostage by elements alleged to have been members of the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND). MEND is an armed militia, drawn largely from the Ijaw, and fighting for the Ijaw right to self-determination, a fair share of the oil receipts, and environmental justice in the region. The militia came into existence last February. […] Militants, using explosives, destroyed several of the oil company's pipelines, flow stations, and loading platforms. Facilities of such other foreign oil companies as ENI and CHEVRON were also hit. […] Several Niger Delta activists including Asari Dokubo have indicated their desire to contest for public office in 2007, and that all they ask is for a level playing field that will enable them present their programmes and policies to the electorate in the Niger Delta. […] I am not saying that the participation of Asari Dokubo in politics will instantly transform the turbulent Niger Delta into a haven of peace. It took fifty years of uncontrolled oil production to reduce the region to the environmental and social mess it is today, and repair will take a while. But this journey can commence by beating enraged swords into ploughshares. […]

title: Apple's dirty data centres send it to bottom of green league: Yahoo first in Greenpeace's table of technology firms Companies urged to cut reliance on coal power
news: Apple has come bottom of the most comprehensive green league table of technology companies because of its heavy reliance on "dirty data" centres. The list, which was compiled by Greenpeace and released in San Francisco yesterday, shows that the company relies heavily on highly polluting coal power at the sites that house its banks of servers. Greenpeace's report, How Dirty is Your Data?, reveals that the company's investment in a new North Carolina facility will triple its electricity consumption, equivalent to the electricity demand of 80,000 average American homes. […] The report estimated dependence on coal for Apple's data centres at 54.5%, followed by Facebook at 53.2%, IBM at 51.6%, HP at 49.4%, and Twitter at 42.5%. Top marks in another table, Greenpeace's clean energy index, went to Yahoo, followed by Google and Amazon. Greenpeace is also campaigning for Facebook to "unfriend coal" and use cleaner energy to power its servers. […]

title: Apple condemned for consigning toxic computers to China
news: Apple, the celebrated computer company, has been rated worst among major electronics firms for its environmental policies by the pressure group Greenpeace. In a new survey of 14 major companies, the manufacturer of the Mac, the Powerbook and the iPod was put bottom of the list for its policies on the elimination of toxic substances and recycling. It was an unaccustomed stain on the halo for the firm with the highest brand and repurchase loyalty of any computer manufacturer, a glittering reputation as a design leader, and a fan base as enthusiastic as any rock band's. Greenpeace charged that Apple "scores badly on almost all criteria" in a detailed survey of its environmental attitudes and practices, ranging from timetables for phasing out hazardous chemicals to the adoption of the precautionary principle. The ranking was made in the updated version of Greenpeace's Guide to Greener Electronics, which was published yesterday on the Greenpeace International website.  When the guide was first published, last September, Apple was ranked 10th; now it is ranked 14th out of 14. In a surprise first place on the list was the Chinese PC maker Lenovo, which displaced Nokia. […] The background to the dispute between Greenpeace and Apple is the growing concern about the phenomenon of e waste - electrical and electronic goods which have come to the end of their lives. The production of all these devices, from computers and printers to CD players and mobile phones, is the fastest-growing sector in the manufacturing industry in the industrialised countries. The United Nations Environment Programme estimates that between 20 and 50 million tons of them are thrown away as obsolete every year - with potentially serious risks to human health and the environment. This is because they are classed as hazardous waste for the toxic chemicals they contain, and so are expensive to recycle properly. Instead, huge amounts are shipped (especially from the US) to China and India, where they are broken up for scrap, often by children, in dumps. Greenpeace is mounting a two-pronged campaign against what it says is an environmental disaster in the making by pressuring the manufacturers both to phase out the toxic chemicals inside the products, and to take responsibility for disposing of the products at the end of their lives by taking them back from customers and recycling them. […] But even more eye-catching is the bottom rating awarded to Apple which, says the group, "having made no progress since the launch of the Guide in 8 2006, continues to languish in last place". Greenpeace charges: "Apple fails to embrace the precautionary principle, withholds its full list of regulated substances, and provides no timelines for eliminating toxic PVC and no commitment to phasing out all uses of brominated flame retardants. Apple performs poorly on product takeback and recycling, but it does report on the amounts of its electronic waste recycled." […] Greenpeace is inviting owners of Apple hardware to write to Steve Jobs, the company's founder and boss, asking him to provide "greener" products.

title: Ontario pressed to dismantle pollution laws
news: Responding to an invitation by the Ontario government, dozens of wasteemitting industries are urging Premier Mike Harris and his Progressive Conservatives to dismantle the province's stringent antipollution laws. Mining companies, including Inco and Falconbridge, are proposing an end to tests on the toxicity of waste from their operations. Chemical companies want to loosen rules for monitoring illegal dumping of hazardous wastes. And Pepsi-Cola and COCA-COLA want an end to the requirement that they provide pop in refillable bottles.

title: A city tour that's ahead by a nose
news: Brooklyn's Dumbo neighbourhood is famous for its visual treats: its art galleries and a magnificent view of the Brooklyn Bridge. But over the weekend, as part of the 11th-annual Art Under the Bridge festival, a pair of artists invited visitors to experience the area as Marcel Proust might urge if he were alive: with their eyes closed. The project's name? The Smelling Committee. It all began a few years ago when Michael McBean was doing research into the history of oil refining in the city and stumbled upon a reference to a band of citizens in 19th-century Brooklyn who were so traumatized by a persistent industrial stench that they took a boat ride up Newtown Creek to divine its source. Back then the five-kilometre creek, an east-to-west tributary which divides the boroughs of Queens and Brooklyn, was home to so much industry that residents had to keep their windows shut through the summer months. In 1891 the volunteer members of the ad hoc Fifteenth Ward Smelling Committee put their paddles in the water and their noses in the air and went up river to discover that the worst stink came from John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil refinery. The refinery issue is still alive in Brooklyn because of a 17-million-gallon oil spill in the 1950s caused by ExxonMobil. The spill, which stretches for 55 acres along the shores of Newtown Creek, wasn't discovered until 1978; they're still cleaning it up. On some days of heavy rain, residents are overpowered by the smell of gasoline. […]

title: Nigeria; 'We'll Stop Ogun, Ondo LNG Projects'
news: Militants in the Niger Delta, under the aegis of Joint Revolutionary Council, comprising the Dokubo Asari-led Niger Delta Peoples Volunteer Force (NDPVF), Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND), and the Martyrs Brigade, have vowed to sabotage the Olokola Liquified Natural Gas Projects in Ogun and Ondo states. They, therefore, called for the cancellation of the project and termination of its Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), or have the multinationals involved witness the "fiercest showdown" by their forces, which would also punish their Nigerian collaborators. […] They also threatened Shell Development Corporation, CHEVRON, and the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), for entering into such venture , which they said was anti-Niger Delta. […] The statement which was signed by Cynthia Whyte called all who have hands in the projects as collaborators against the interest of the Niger Delta people who they said would not go unpunished for being indifferent to the plight of the region. "We will like to state in very clear terms that Shell and CHEVRON will not go unpunished. For more than 40years, our people have been subject to the worst levels of environmental degradation and despoliation. We have borne acid rains and have stomached putrid water. Farmlands have been destroyed. Seas have been polluted. Vegetations have been devastated. Yet the infidel partnership of NNPC, Shell and CHEVRON still seek to short change our people and deprive them of that which should be given them. […]

title: In a Season of Gifts, a Push for More Sustainable High-Tech Devices
news: LONDON -- From solar-powered Christmas lights and cellphone chargers to smart home thermostats, there are plenty of gifts available for technology lovers interested in saving energy.[…] Mr. Dowdall, of Greenpeace, agreed that there had been significant progress, citing the efforts of companies like Google, FACEBOOK and Apple to convert their power-hungry data centers to renewable energy sources. He said Apple also deserved credit for removing many toxic substances from its products and for buying devices back from consumers. Still, he said, ''the way the business is structured is not ultimately sustainable.'' ''Rather than just little sustainability things on the side for just a small portion of their audience, they need to be thinking about how do we offer this to everyone, so its something that happens across the board,'' he said.

title: CHEVRON Richmond refinery project is uncertain: CEO
news: CHEVRON has "not reached a final decision yet" on whether to move ahead with its Richmond, California, refinery project, CEO David O'Reilly said late 6 10.  A California judge recently ruled that the project's environmental report needs to be reworked (ON 6/9).Several environmental groups involved in that court case plan next week to submit a proposed order to halt construction of that project, said Will Rostov, attorney for environmental law firm Earthjustice that is working with the plaintiffs. He said in an interview 6 11 that Earthjustice is not working on any other cases relating to US refinery projects.[...] The Commonwealth Club event featured a debate between O'Reilly and Sierra Club Executive Director Carl Pope on climate issues, but a number of other contentious issues were discussed. O'Reilly acknowledged that he was not optimistic about the outcome of a 16-year-old lawsuit in Ecuador involving environmental damage allegedly left behind in Ecuador by TEXACO, since acquired by CHEVRON. The case is expected to be decided by an Ecuadorean judge late this year. In late May, CHEVRON shareholders rejected a resolution asking the company to detail its policies to protect human health, the environment and its own reputation, a move linked to the environmental concerns in Ecuador.[...] As O'Reilly weighed in on the Ecuador lawsuit in San Francisco 6 10, protesters in the audience stood up, displaying T-shirts with the message "CHEVRON's $27 billion secret in Ecuador."Asked where he believes most of CHEVRON's business will come from in a carbon-constrained world, O'Reilly said currently most of the business is based outside the US, and that he imagines that trend will continue. In 20 years, CHEVRON "will be a much bigger natural gas player," according to O'Reilly.

title: Economists put pressure on US over emissions
news: GLOBAL WARMING: The US government came under more pressure yesterday to start dealing with global warming when 25 prominent American economists, including three Nobel laureates, warned of the high cost of doing nothing.[...] Calling for a market-based approach to reducing emissions, along the lines of the EU carbon trading regime, they said this would provide "clear incentives for changes in business practices and the development of new technologies" to replace fossil fuels. [...]This runs contrary to President Bush's claim that signing up for the Kyoto Protocol would damage the US economy - a view propagated by its most profitable oil company, EXXON MOBIL, which has been thanked by the White House for its input into climate policy. Last Monday, the Washington Post highlighted links between EXXON MOBIL and Harlan Watson, the chief US negotiator at the Montreal summit, saying the company had proposed to the White House in 2001 that he should be involved in climate change talks.[...] Yesterday, Mr Watson was stalked all day at the Palais des Congres by an environmental group, the Expose EXXON Coalition, which is dedicated to highlighting the company's role in encouraging the US to shun the Kyoto Protocol.[...]

title: EXXON must pay the price for carefree capitalism
news: With all the hype about the causes and blame apportionment for the Longford disaster, it is easy to overlook the fact that Esso Australia Ltd and its parent, EXXON Corp, are perhaps the premier examples of the true meaning of conservation. They have steadfastly conserved the principles of laissez-faire capitalism that old J.D. Rockerfeller would be proud of. These are the very same principles that led to the Sherman anti-trust laws some 109 years ago in response to the unacceptable corporate behaviour of the then Standard Oil Company of New Jersey One need look no futher than EXXON's published primary strategic objective to "provide shareholders a secure investment with a superior return" (Strategic Management, Concepts & Cases, tenth edition, Thompson & Strickland 1998) to realise what sort of corporate animal one is dealing with.Not for them such namby-pamby mission concepts as delivering superior customer value, growth by enhanced human resources or innovation or with ecological sustainability. This is the sort of corporate mission statement that will inevitably, almost by definition, lead to Longford and Alaskan-(EXXON Valdez) style disasters in relentless pursuit of profit maximisation.This corporate animal has been consistent for over a century in the way it does business. Its mission statement is a self-fulfilling horrorscope.[…]

title: LOO'S WHO; BITTER RIVALS ON A ROLL TO PERFORATE POUNDS 16BN MARKET
news: […] Even worse for Andrex, their tissue has been ranked bottom in an environmental survey by WWF that assessed recycling and the impact on the world's forests. The charity says the equivalent of 270,000 trees are flushed away every day. But even the most bog-standard toilet paper has only been around for 50 years. Before then we had to grin and bear it with shiny, hard paper - while the less-well-off redeployed their daily newspaper.[…] In 2000 Andrex was accused of being behind a dirty-tricks campaign designed to discredit rival PROCTER & GAMBLE with a story that claimed its new toilet paper could block drains. In 1995 American researchers spent pounds 87,000 making the discovery that three out of four people handle their toilet rolls so the paper is pulled down to be torn off rather than up. And research by Charmin found the average person uses 8.6 sheets per trip - a total of 57 sheets per day and an annual total of 20,805 sheets. A standard roll usually lasts five days.[…]

title: Apple faces legal threat over 'toxic' iPhone
news: * Environmental group demands 'green' changes * Challenge follows Greenpeace report Environmentalists have threatened to sue Apple if it does not make its iPhone a "greener" product or tell consumers of the toxins allegedly used in the device's manufacture. The Centre for Environmental Health (CEH), a campaign group based in Oakland, California, said that it would launch legal action in 60 days unless Apple took action.  The threat comes after a report by Greenpeace, the environmental group, which alleged that the iPhone contained dangerous levels of bromine, chlorine and phthalates chemicals used to increase the flexibility of plastic. […] The level of phthalate esters, a chemical linked to birth defects, in plastic coating of iPhone headphone wires is greater than that allowed in toys or childcare items sold in Europe, Greenpeace alleged. […] The campaigners' action may prove embarrassing for Al Gore, a member of Apple's board, who last week won the Nobel Peace Prize for his environmental work. Apple has sold more than a million iPhones since the device's launch this summer in the United States. In that time, the gadget has proved itself a magnet for lawsuits - some of more apparent merit than others. This month an iPhone buyer that said she was suing Apple for $1 million (£ 490,000) after the company cut the price of the device by $200 only 68 days after its American launch. Only hours after Steve Jobs, Apple's chief executive, unveiled the gadget in 1, Apple was sued by Cisco, which claimed that it owned the "iphone" brand. The technology companies settled out of court. Apple said yesterday that its delayed next-generation operating system, Mac OS X Leopard, will go on sale at 6pm on Friday. In April, it was forced to push back Leopard's release date from 6 to ensure the timely release of the iPhone.

title: Legacy of Poison in Twice-Excavated Yards
news: Tom Harrington's backyard in Queensbury, N.Y., looks much as it used to, except for a few telltale signs: the maple tree is smaller, the swing set is in a different place, and the lawn has strange lines running through it, like a bad hair implant. Last fall, most of Mr. Harrington's yard was dug out and replaced by the State Department of Environmental Conservation, at depths up to 20 feet, because it was contaminated with PCB's. So were the yards of several of his neighbors in Queensbury, a blue-collar suburb of Glens Falls in Warren County. Decades ago, many local people, trying to make a little extra money, took apart PCB-laden electric capacitors to remove the copper inside and sell it. They let the chemicals drip into the soil, leaving future generations a toxic legacy.  Yesterday, two neighborhood residents filed the first of what their lawyer said would be more than 100 personal injury and property damage lawsuits against General Electric, which manufactured the capacitors until 1977 at its nearby plants in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls in Washington County. Many of the residents say they have skin eruptions and other health problems associated with PCB's. Several appeared yesterday at a news conference in Albany with Walter Hang, the director of an environmental group, Toxics Targeting, that has released a report on PCB contamination in the area. […] In 1999 the agency came back to do a routine check and found that the soil was still contaminated around seven homes, though the source was not clear, Ms. Meicht said. The levels varied from one part per million -- the state's minimum for a cleanup -- to 1,500 parts per million. Anything over 50 parts is classified as toxic waste. Again, the state's contractors dug out all the yards where they found the chemicals and filled them in with clean soil, Ms. Meicht said. Michael Mabb, whose yard next to Mr. Condon's was also dug out, said he thought the excavation stopped only because it was taking too long and was running over the budget. "It was coming winter and they just wanted to get out of here," he said.  Mr. Mabb's wife, Penny, has scars and boils on her arms and legs that are consistent with high-level exposure to PCB's, said David Carpenter, a professor in the School of Public Health at the State University at Albany. […]

title: The PCB War Heats Up
news: The ecological recovery of the Hudson River is by now a well-documented success story. What was little more than a 350-mile-long sewer stretching from the Adirondacks to Manhattan's Battery has been transformed over 30 years into a river pulsing with life. There remains, however, one huge blot on this otherwise happy history -- the polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, that were discharged into the upper Hudson from two General Electric manufacturing plants in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls and that now lie on the river bottom. The compounds were banned 20 years ago, but enough escaped into the river to pose a potential cancer risk to humans who eat fish caught in the upper Hudson.  Under the Federal Superfund law, G.E. must clean the river of PCB's or find some way to neutralize them. The company has never denied its legal responsibility, but for two decades it has wrestled with state and Federal agencies over scientific questions involving the toxicity of the chemicals and the practical question of how best to purge the river. This struggle has now reached a new and more intense phase with the release last week of a report from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which has the authority to tell G.E. what to do. The report makes two key points, neither of them comforting to G.E. […] The E.P.A. regards this theory as improbable. Environmental groups, most vocally Scenic Hudson, see it as another smokescreen for G.E.'s endlessly resourceful environmental team. But wherever the truth lies, it is clear that the Federal Government is conducting a far more careful investigation of a potentially grave environmental problem than it did during the Reagan years. It is also clear that it has turned up the heat on G.E.

title: Could bottled water be heading down the plughole?
news: Brands such as Danone and Nestlé are fighting back as consumer money worries and environmental concerns hit sales, writes Jenny Wiggins ELIZABETH ROYTE'S book, Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It, is causing waves. [...] But now they are fighting back. All companies are impressing on consumers that they can drink bottled water with a clear conscience if they recycle the packaging. Coca-Cola, the owner of the Dasani water brand, is opening what it claims is the world's largest plastic bottle recycling plant in South Carolina early next year. Companies are also trying to position themselves as guardians of the public health by arguing that their bottles of water can help defeat the obesity epidemic. [...]

title: Desperate times for sinking Pasminco
news: Pasminco is facing the sale or closure of its three Australian zinc and lead smelters as it struggles to avoid being put into liquidation because of a crippling $2.8 billion in debts. The company has already put several of its mining operations up for sale but they are not expected to raise enough to prevent a corporate collapse and the loss of 1,800 jobs across the country.[…] Analysts expect the company's banks, including CITIGROUP, Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, National Australia Bank, ANZ, Deutsche Bank and BankWest, to carry a large part of Pasminco's $2.79 billion in accumulated debts, despite the asset sales. Analysts believe Pasminco's smelting operations, on a stand-alone basis, are not viable and will have to be closed, potentially leaving either the company's financiers or State governments with closure and environmental clean-up costs.[…]

title: Steady Build-Up Of Shale Hopes
news: [...] Oil majors Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron are the likely winners of Ukraine's two shale gas fields tendered in an auction that opened in February 2012, according to Reuters' Ukrainan government source. Shell is likely to be awarded the Yuzivska field and Chevron the Olesska field, seeing-off competition from other international oil companies (IOCs) that include ExxonMobil, Eni, and BP's Russian Joint Venture (JV) TNK-BP. [...] Interest from these IOCs in Ukraine is unsurprising, with the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) putting Ukraine's recoverable shale gas resource estimate at 1.2tcm, which is just behind France and Norway in Europe (after Poland's downgrade of its recoverable shale gas resources estimate from that of the EIA's has been taken into account). France and Norway have been lukewarm to their shale potential - environmental worries about groundwater pollution from hydraulic fracturing (fraccing) had led to a moratorium on shale gas exploration in France, while the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate has yet to show signs of interest in tapping into Norway's shale resources. title: HIPPIE HANG-OUT LOSES CHARM BUT KEEPS A DIRTY SECRET
news: THERE IS a sinister undertow to the shimmering beauties of Avila Beach, a tiny speck of a town on one of the most stunning stretches of California's central coastline. […] "The beach community that used to exist has been bought out or pushed out. What you see now is so different," said Matt Fleming, president of the local Surfrider Foundation, an environmental group interested in catching waves but also in keeping them as clean as possible. […] This stretch of coastline could easily have ended up as prized for its natural beauties as Big Sur 100 miles further north. Instead, it bears a legacy of oil spills and ground contamination, of effluent pumped into the ocean and marine life perishing as a result. […] The energy companies first came into the area during the Second World War as a natural extension of the military- industrial complex built up around the ports of San Francisco and Long Beach. Avila Beach, for example, was a refuelling point for the Navy during the war. The area was sparsely populated and politically weak, which allowed Unocal, CHEVRON and others to muscle their way in without much trouble. And now the price is being paid. Avila Beach is no longer used as an oil storage facility but its problems may not yet be over. Despite the clean-up, a further 63,000-gallon plume of oil has been detected beneath the pier and Unocal has been exempted from getting rid of it - mainly because of the prohibitive cost. […]

title: British oil disaster could cost taxpayer billions: MPs fear voluntary fund cannot cover clean-up bill Doubts over effectiveness of spill plans in North Sea
news: British taxpayers could end up footing the clean-up bill from any major oil spill in UK waters because current rules allow companies to dodge their environmental responsibilities, according to MPs investigating BP's Gulf of Mexico disaster. The government ought to require companies to prove that they can pay out billions of pounds in clean-up costs before they are granted exploration and production licences, recommends the committee's final report, which is published today. It also points to "serious doubts" over whether companies' plans to respond to spills - by capping leaking wells and skimming oil from the sea surface - would work in the rough Atlantic waters off the west coast of Shetland. The report points to the "limitations" of the computer modelling used by oil companies to predict the long-term effects of spills at sea. Last month the Guardian obtained documents relating to the oil spill response plan of US firm CHEVRON which in October was given consent to drill off Shetland. It showed its modelling software could not simulate spills lasting more than 14 days without crashing. The Gulf of Mexico spill lasted almost three months.[...] The report also says that EU legislation obliging companies to meet their responsibilities over a spill is vague and inconsistent and "unlikely to bring to account those responsible for environmental damage caused by an offshore incident such as happened in the Gulf of Mexico". It adds that the government should work with the EU to draw up new legislation based on the "polluter pays" principle. It says that a moratorium on drilling in Britain, as some environmentalists have recommended, would be bad for the British economy. In December, Barack Obama angered the oil industry when he banned new drilling off the east coast and the eastern part of the Gulf of Mexico.[...]

title: PCB Cleanup May Include Less Dredging
news: With a decision imminent on dredging PCB's from the upper Hudson River, the Bush administration is seriously considering a plan to do a fraction of the dredging that the Clinton administration proposed last year, Democratic elected officials and environmentalists said today. Several of the people making that claim said they had heard it from people who had had contact with the office of Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, who will make the decision. But none said they had learned of the plan directly from Mrs. Whitman's office.   Mrs. Whitman's office did not return two calls today seeking confirmation of the plan. She said last week that she would make a decision by the end of this week, and would send it to the Pataki administration for comment. "It is our understanding that this plan is under serious consideration," Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said. But when asked whom his sources were, he said, "I will do everything I can not to edify you on that one." In December, under President Bill Clinton, the E.P.A. proposed a clean-up plan whose centerpiece would be dredging 2.6 million cubic yards of contaminated sediment from the river at several "hot spots" about 40 miles north of here. The cost, estimated at $480 million, would be charged to General Electric, the company whose plants dumped polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, a class of cancer-causing chemicals, into the river legally from the 1940's to the 1970's. The plan said to be under consideration by Mrs. Whitman would address only the most contaminated site, a part of the river known as the Thompson Island Pool, near the town of Fort Edward. It would involve removal of about a half-million cubic yards of sediment -- considerably less in some versions of the plan -- and would cost $100 million or less. The results of that dredging would then undergo years of study before a decision was made on whether to proceed with more. G.E. has gone on a multimillion-dollar advertising and public relations campaign against the December E.P.A. plan, asserting that there are better ways to remove the contamination and that dredging would actually worsen matters. A spokesman said today that the company had no idea what Mrs. Whitman would do. […] Two United States representatives from the Hudson Valley, John E. Sweeney and Maurice D. Hinchey, both of whom have met recently on the issue with Mrs. Whitman, said they, too, were in the dark. Mr. Hinchey, a Democrat, supports December's more aggressive plan, while Mr. Sweeney, a Republican whose district includes the most contaminated stretches of the river, has been promoting a narrower dredging plan like the one said to be under consideration.  Several environmental groups called a news conference here today to attack the scaled-back dredging plan, and to pressure Mr. Pataki to take a strong stand against it. The governor did not say until late last year that he favored dredging. He has not, however, said whether he supports the December plan, or how much dredging he thinks is appropriate.

title: Oil spill undermines lucrative traders at BP; A major source of profit, unit is losing contracts as rivals court the staff

title: Fee sought for disposal of electronics
news: Manufacturers seek standard across country Suggest adding $25 to price of TVs, computers. Hoping to have a say in how "e-waste" legislation is crafted across the country, Canada's top computer and electronics manufacturers have come together to promote a national program for disposing of old cellphones, monitors and television sets. Preliminary proposals include a $25 e-waste fee tacked on to the price of computers and TVs that would be used to fund safe disposal programs at the municipal level. The fee would be lower for smaller items such as printers and hand-held gadgets. […] Members of the European Union are required by law to have electronics waste management programs. In North America, initiatives have been largely industry driven, with companies such as Hewlett-Packard and IBM Corp. setting up their own company programs.[…] Environment Canada estimates that nearly 200,000 tonnes of old computer equipment and other e-waste require proper disposal before 2006. Today, landfills get most of the junk - and the lead, mercury and cadmium that come with it. These toxic substances can leach out and contaminate ground water.[…]

title: My Say: Polluters must pay
news: When BP and its drilling partners caused the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, the US government demanded that BP finance the clean-up, compensate those who suffered damages and pay criminal penalties for the violations that led to the disaster. [...] The same standards for environmental clean-up need to be applied to global companies operating in poorer countries, where their power has typically been so great relative to that of governments that many act with impunity, wreaking havoc on the environment with little or no accountability. [...] Nigeria has been Exhibit A of corporate environmental impunity. For decades, major oil companies, including Shell, ExxonMobil, and Chevron, have been producing oil in the Niger Delta, an ecologically fragile environment of freshwater swamp forests, mangroves, lowland rainforests and coastal barrier islands. [...] Indeed, just as BP was being hit with new criminal penalties, ExxonMobil announced yet another pipeline leak in the Niger Delta. [...]

title: Nigeria; Niger Delta - Group Slams $1 Billion Suit on FG, Oil Firms
news: A civil society organisation, Socio-Economic Rights and Accountability Project (SERAP), at the weekend, dragged the Federal Government and six major oil companies operating in Nigeria before the ECOWAS Court in Abuja, seeking to compel the defendants to individually or collectively pay monetary compensation of $1billion and other forms of reparation to the people of the Niger Delta for the pollution and associated human rights violations in the region. The defendants in the suit are President Umaru Yar'Adua, the Attorney General of the Federation, Mr. Michael Aondoakaa (SAN), the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC), Elf Petroleum Nigeria Ltd, Agip Nigeria PLC, CHEVRON Oil Nigeria PLC, Total Nigeria PLC, and Exxonmobil Corporation. In the suit filed by its lawyer, Mr. Femi Falana, the plaintiff is accusing defendants of failing to address the impact of oil-related pollution and environmental damage on agriculture and fisheries; oil spills and waste materials polluting water used for drinking and other domestic purposes, and to enforce laws and regulations to protect the environment and prevent pollution.It is alleging that the defendants are individually and collectively responsible for serious violations of the right to an adequate standard of living, including the right to food, to work, to health, to water, to life and human dignity, to a clean and healthy environment; and to economic and social development of the people living in the region. [...]It added that the people of the oil-producing areas of the Niger Delta have suffered for decades from oil spills, which occur both on land and offshore.Citing specific cases, the SERAP stated that a culture of impunity had been reinforced for oil companies in the region because of a lack of any adequate sanctions for bad practice that damages human rights.

title: A pro-business agenda is succeeding quickly
news: Big business is riding a small wave of success in Congress these days, and corporate America may well thank seven of President Bush's judicial nominees.[…] On Wednesday, the Senate voted to allow EXXON MOBIL Corp. and other companies to tap into an estimated 6.3 billion barrels of oil in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which has been off limits to oil companies since 1980. title: Pepsi True back on AMAZON after product disappeared from catalogue amid environmentalist campaign against drinks giant;  Pepsi True is sold exclusively through AMAZON.com
news: AMAZON has reinstated Pepsi True's page on its website, after it appeared to have been removed the listing following negative reviews from environmentalist groups over Pepsi's use of palmoil. The campaign was led by activist group SumOfUs.org and the Rainforest Action Network coinciding with the launch of Pepsi's stevia drink- Pepsi True- which is sold exclusively on AMAZON. They inundated Pepsi True's page with hundreds of 1-star negative reviews, criticising the American drinks giant for its "failure" to commit to more sustainable palm oil policies. Searches for Pepsi True redirect users to AMAZON's homepage and the product has vanished from its catalogue entirely, effectively shutting its distribution channel. "Pepsi can't hide from the destruction that it refuses to eliminate from its supply chain" said Kaytee Riek, campaign director at SumOfUs. "It could rise above its competitors and do the right thing, but instead it has relied on half measures." She added: "It remains to be seen whether Pepsi True will be reinstated on AMAZON, but one thing's for sure - when consumers can interact with brands in such an immediate and direct way, at least they'll have to rethink their policies first." In May, Pepsi pledged it would only use palm oil from suppliers who are members of the Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) by 2016, but environmentalist groups argue its policies don't go far enough to guarantee its supply chain will be free from deforestation and social conflict. Sum of Us said it would continue to campaign until Pepsi takes a more "responsible" approach. PepsiCo nor AMAZON were available for comment.

title: Going, Going, Trying to Go Green
news: DUPONT this week announced a ''sustainability'' initiative, making it the latest big company to jump on the green bandwagon. […] Last year, GENERAL ELECTRIC introduced its ''ecoimagination'' program (ge.ecomagination.com), which puts money and research behind energy efficient and ''environmentally advanced'' products. Wal-Mart, Ford and BP have all announced similar programs in recent years. While some environmental activists tend to label such initiatives as mere ''greenwashing'' -- that is, more public relations than anything else -- many mainstream environment watchers praise them as at least a step in the right direction. Still, given that such companies are industrial conglomerates that create huge amounts of waste and burn huge amounts of fossil fuels, they will probably never totally remake their image.    As one commenter on Joel Makower's blog about sustainable business put it, ''a company that finances its green with funds generated by brown will always be a villain'' (makower.typepad.com). Now about $2 million in debt, the Sacramento resident has done what any blue-blooded young American would do in such a situation -- he started a blog. […]

title: Linda McQuaig argues that a global problem requires a global solution
news: By now, most people acknowledge the dangers of global warming and the need for the sort of collective action set out in the Kyoto accords. But some powerful corporations still hope to head off any such action. Having exhausted just about every other stalling tactic, they cling to the argument that Kyoto is flawed. [...] Kyoto's main opponents are huge corporations, led by EXXON-MOBIL, which just reported a recording-breaking $25 billion annual profit. These corporate mega-giants have enormous sway over governments. From their viewpoint, then, it's ideal to leave the tackling of global warming up to individual governments.[...] Linda McQuaig is a Toronto-based author and commentator.

title: FILMMAKER CLAIMS 6,000 OIL AND GAS SPILLS IN 2012, MORE LIQUID SPREADING THAN 1989 EXXON VALDEZ
news: "We had 6,000 oil and gas spills in 2012" with "more oil and gas spreading in the United States than the entire Exxon Valdez spill." title: With Biofuels Backlash Growing, EXXON Reveals Its Greener Side
news: "EXXON MOBIL Sees Growing Role for Biofuels" -- now there's a headline that begs to end with a question mark. Is it possible that EXXON is joining the likes of BP and Royal Dutch Shell in a greener era? Given the politically incorrect public persona of former chief executive Lee Raymond, you have to wonder what he makes of this latest development. To be fair, however, after castigating the Kyoto treaty, Raymond subsequently softened his stance, admitting that global warming did need further study. But while he applauded voluntary curbs in carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) emissions, he drew the line at mandating curbs through regulation; and he did little to move EXXON beyond its core business of bringing oil and gas to market. Given the environmental bashing EXXON has taken, it's little wonder that a post-Raymond EXXON might be trying to come across as a bit greener. The latest indication of a significant shift came from protracted comments on the risks posed by rising CO 2 emissions by Jaime Spellings, EXXON's general manager for corporate planning.[...]

title: Nurturing doubt about climate change is big business
news: On a cloudless morning in 6, Tim Ball has joined a hundred-odd members of the Comox Valley Probus Club for a buffet of coffee, cinnamon buns and pink lemonade. As this group of retired business people wraps up its monthly meeting, Dr. Ball surveys the crowd and runs a hand over his suntanned dome. [...]  Nurturing doubt about climate-change science has become big business for public-relations companies and lobbyists south of the border. From 2000 to 2003, EXXON MOBIL Corp. alone gave more than $8.6-million (U.S.) to think tanks, consumer groups and policy organizations engaged in anti-Kyoto messaging, according to the company's own records. Those groups promote the minority of scientists who still dispute the IPCC consensus on climate change, creating the appearance of widespread scientific disagreement. [...]

title: Fossil-fuel will dominate even in 2030: ExxonMobil
news: According to ExxonMobil's "Outlook for Energy: A View to 2030", in that year the combined demand for oil, coal and gas will remain at about 80 per cent of overall fuel needs, even with the increasing supply of nuclear, hydropower, biomass/wastes and other renewables."[Despite the sharp growth of other types of fuel], they will grow from a very low base," Rob Gardner, manager of the Economics and Energy Division of ExxonMobil's Corporate Strategic Planning Department, said during a recent briefing to the Nation Group. [...] Gardner said the increase in global demand posed a significant challenge of meeting the energy needs of a growing global population while also reducing the impact of energy use on the environment. [...] The outlook includes an assessment of how potential carbon-emission reduction policies will affect future energy demand and impact the fuel mix. Gardner admits that it is, however, hard to predict these policies. For example, Europe is going to levy a carbon tax, which will raise the prices of fossil fuels to levels that make the cost of renewable energy worthwhile for investment. Policies will also drive nations to switch to less carbon-intensive fuels such as natural gas, which can help meet growing electricity demand and help reduce power-generation emissions by up to 60 per cent versus coal.[...]
