title: Australia Promoting Its Natural Gas in U.S.
news: Geoff Gallop, the state premier of Western Australia, is visiting the United States to help CHEVRONTEXACO sell Australia's natural gas. Between meetings with oil executives in California and energy officials in Washington, he visited Baja California, Mexico, where CHEVRONTEXACO hopes to build a terminal to receive liquefied natural gas shipped from a huge $7.9 billion gas project off the coast of Western Australia called Gorgon. That field plus a group of adjacent gas fields known collectively as Greater Gorgon, all operated by CHEVRONTEXACO as part of a consortium it leads with Royal/Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, represent Australia's largest known gas reserve. […] Gorgon still needs environmental approvals to build its liquefaction plant on land near the field, saying it is the only feasible site. But that land, Barrow Island, is a nature reserve. Choosing Barrow was not only about saving steps; it was about disposing of Gorgon's carbon dioxide. […] Environmentalists condemn the plan, saying that it will further disturb Barrow's ecology and will encourage the introduction of other gas-related industries. Western Australia's Environmental Protection Agency has advised against using Barrow. But in September Mr. Gallop gave Gorgon approval in principle to use the island, and last month, the state's Parliament passed legislation allowing Gorgon to do so. […]

title: Nigeria; Militants Bomb More Oil Fields
news: Despite ongoing negotiations between the Federal Government and militant Ijaw youths, leading to the release of six of the nine hostages, two oil facilities, the Agge and Agoro manifolds in Bayelsa State were Saturday bombed, an idication that the war along the creeks of the Niger Delta was not over. The bombings were followed by threats from the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger delta (MEND) to halve the country's daily oil production in order to persuade the Federal Government to act more quickly on its demands for a better deal for the people of the region. […] Meanwhile a massive oil spillage has occurred on a Shell pipeline at Otokutu Village in Delta State. The spillage occurred as a result of sabotage on a Shell pipeline that passes through the community, said Harriman Oyofo, the company's spokesman. […] Most of Nigeria's remaining production comes from the eastern side of the Niger delta where Shell, U.S. giants ExxonMobil and CHEVRON, Italy's Agip and France's Total operate fields. Two abandoned oil pipeline junctions operated by Shell in the western Niger delta were attacked by unidentified saboteurs on Saturday, but output was unaffected because the area had been evacuated, military and industry sources said. The militants have demanded the release of two ethnic Ijaw leaders, compensation for oil pollution to region's villages and more autonomy over its huge oil income. The government has called them oil thieves, but they have accused government and security officials of being complicit in the trade of stolen oil from Nigeria, worth hundreds of millions of dollars every year. Ijaw activists, however, say the attacks will encourage other regions to take their decades-long fight for more autonomy seriously at a time when the constitutional provision on wealth distribution is also under review. […]

title: Nigeria; Lagos Government Threatens to Shut Oil Coys Over Land Use Charge
news: LAGOS State Government has threatened to shut down oil companies operating in the state over their refusal to pay the Land Use Charge it introduced recently. Governor Bola Tinubu, who issued the threat Wednesday while playing host to the Managing Director of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), Mr. Jackson Gaius Obaseki, in his office, said the state government would no longer tolerate a situation where oil companies operating in the state continue to violate the law. He singled out CHEVRON and Shell as two companies that have remained intransigent to government's entreaties for companies and individuals alike to pay the land use charge. […] On the menace of Area Boys to petrol tanker drivers on the Island, Governor Tinubu said the government had set up a surveillance committee, comprising men of the Rapid Respond Squad (RRS) and the Environmental Sanitation Task Force, charged with the responsibility of combing all black spots in the area, with a view to dislodging them from their hideout. He also assured the drivers of their safety in the area henceforth. […]

title: Too green to be true?
news: To borrow a phrase from fashion parlance, green is the new black. In other words, saving the planet is all the rage. In New York City, the green movement is being played out on many fronts-from the construction of environmentally friendly hotels to the proliferation of ryegrass and lavender on rooftops to Mayor Michael Bloomberg's 127-point plan to dramatically reduce the emission of carbon gases over the next two decades. But the phenomenon has a dark side. The rush to go green has gained momentum, and so has the making of exaggerated, misleading or downright deceptive claims-a practice known as greenwashing. Here's a snapshot of what various sectors of New York's economy are doing to keep temperatures from rising and ice caps from shrinking, along with Crain's best estimates of the effectiveness of those efforts.  [...] In February, CITIGROUP Inc., J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. and Morgan Stanley-with input from EDF and the Natural Resources Defense Council-released a set of guidelines for underwriting energy projects that will, in fact, make it more difficult for the banks to finance smoke-spewing, coal-fired power plants. It remains to be seen whether Wall Street's embrace of the green movement will have any meaningful impact on the environment. In fact, critics characterize Wall Street's eco-effort as "greenwashing" and say it jeopardizes shareholder value without evidence that actions will improve the environment. [...]

title: Exxon gearing up to give cleaner diesel a big boost
news: Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's biggest oil refiner, will spend more than $1US billion ($1.78 billion) in the next couple of years to increase its global production of cleaner-burning diesel by about 10 per cent.[…] When the upgrades are completed in 2010, Irving, Texas-based Exxon Mobil will account for about 8 per cent of the world's diesel output, up about 1 per cent from present levels, says Sherman Glass, the oil giant's president of refining and supply.[...]While acknowledging the global economic downturn and its significant impact on energy consumption, Glass said there was growing global demand for ultra-low-sulphur diesel, also known as ULSD.[...] ULSD, which helps reduce emissions, was introduced for highway use in 2006 and is available at service stations across the US. By December 2010, it will be the only highway diesel available at retail outlets, as mandated by the US Environmental Protection Agency.[...]

title: Bottlemania; BOOKS/Nonfiction
news: To paraphrase an old axiom: You don't buy water, you only rent it. So why did Americans spend nearly $11 billion on bottled water in 2006, when we could have guzzled tap water at up to about one ten-thousandth the cost? The facile answer is marketing, marketing and more marketing, but Elizabeth Royte goes much deeper into the drink in ''Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It,'' streaming trends, cultural, economic, political and hydrological, into an engaging investigation of an unexpectedly murky substance. Partway through her undoctrinaire book, Royte, a lifelong fan of tap water, refills her old plastic water bottle, reflecting that ''what once seemed so simple and natural, a drink of water, is neither. All my preconceptions about this most basic of beverages have been queered.'' And by the end of the book she will have discarded the old plastic bottle too, but not the tap. […] Let's talk about those evil marketers. In 1987, Americans drank only 5.7 gallons, or 22.8 liters, of bottled water per person per year, but the cumulative impact of ad campaigns and the vision of Madonna fellating a bottle of Evian in ''Truth or Dare'' more than doubled consumption by 1997. In 2000 the chief executive of Quaker Oats bragged to analysts that ''the biggest enemy is tap water.'' By 2005, the enemy had become the consumer's bladder; and in 2006, PEPSI, which owns Aquafina, spent $20 million suggesting that Americans ''drink more water.'' That year we drank 27.6 gallons each at a rate of about a billion bottles a week. But marketing swings both ways. As quickly as bottled water became a symbol of healthy hyperindividualism a backlash turned it into the devil's drink. In 2006, the National Coalition of American Nuns came out against bottled water for the moral reason that life's essential resource should not be privatized. New numbers surfaced: each year the bottles themselves require 17 million barrels of oil to manufacture, and, one expert tells Royte, ''the total energy required for every bottle's production, transport and disposal is equivalent, on average, to filling that bottle a quarter of the way with oil.'' Mayors from San Francisco to New York suddenly became aware of the new symbolism of bottled water as a waste of taxpayer money, a diss of local tap water and a threat to the environment. […]

title: Metro Business Briefing; G.E. SUES OVER SUPERFUND LAW
news: General Electric Company filed a lawsuit yesterday asking that provisions of the federal Superfund toxic waste cleanup law be declared invalid. G.E. is arguing that the Superfund's provisions give the Environmental Protection Agency "uncontrolled authority to order intrusive remedial projects of unlimited scope and duration in nonemergency situations." The company is battling with environmentalists and regulators over the cleanup of the upper Hudson River, where the company discharged polycholorinated biphenyls decades ago. Environmentalists and the Pataki administration want the company to dredge the river, which could cost hundreds of millions of dollars. The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to make a decision on the dredging in the next few weeks.

title: Rising cost of shipping drives new strategies; Oil prices help push relocation of factories closer to consumers
news: When Tesla Motors, a pioneer in electric-powered cars, set out to make a luxury roadster for the U.S. market, it had the global supply chain in mind. Tesla planned to manufacture 1,000-pound battery packs in Thailand, ship them to Britain for installation, then bring the mostly assembled cars back to the United States. […] Rising concern about global warming, the reaction against lost jobs in rich countries, worries about food safety and security, and the collapse of world trade talks in Geneva last week also signal that political and environmental concerns may make the calculus of globalization far more complex. ''If we think about the Wal-Mart model, it is incredibly fuel-intensive at every stage, and at every one of those stages we are now seeing an inflation of the costs for boats, trucks, cars,'' said Naomi Klein, the author of ''The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism.'' […]

title: Fuel for the pollution debate
news: Let's throw another spanner into the debate over managing our air quality. I call on the Hong Kong government to ban industrial-grade diesel so that only ultra-low-sulphur diesel can be used.  Before explaining why I say this, let us review recent news reports.  Hong Kong Disneyland will not install a cleaner and less noisy air launch system for its nightly fireworks, while CLP Power says it alone cannot be expected to reduce emissions to meet overall targets.   Unhelpfully, DISNEY executives said a fortnight ago it was simply too complicated to explain why the new technology it uses in California - which can reduce emissions by 60 per cent and is apparently almost smokeless - could not be applied here. Discovery Bay residents are pressing DISNEY to use it, but all of us have an interest in companies doing their best to reduce pollution.  However, DISNEY is not going to do it in Hong Kong, because it doesn't have to. Last week, it said what it planned to do would meet local regulations. Are Hong Kong's regulations set too low, or are we not paying enough attention to specific cases, such as Disney's, to negotiate the best possible performance?[…]

title: US COURT REJECTS PUNITIVE AWARD FOR EXXON SPILL
news: Federal appeals court again strikes down a punitive-damages award against Exxon Mobil Corp for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, meaning the oil company may end up paying only a fraction of the jury's original $5 billion penalty (M)

title: Oil Industry Hesitates Over Moving Into Arctic Refuge
news: More than three decades ago, the world's largest energy companies led the charge to drill for oil on the North Slope of Alaska. But now, as the debate rages over opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration, those same companies remain surprisingly silent. Drilling in the Arctic refuge, which has already been approved by the House, has become a touchstone issue for the Bush administration, and the issue promises to produce a nasty fight in the current debate over the energy bill in the Senate. Publicly, the biggest multinational petroleum companies, like EXXON MOBIL, Royal Dutch/Shell, BP and ChevronTexaco, back the Bush administration's assertion that developing the oil in the Arctic refuge is critical to the American economy. But privately, many large companies say the prospect, solely on business terms, is not terribly attractive. […] The fight over oil drilling in the refuge has flared in Congress every few years, and so far, opponents of drilling have kept the area off limits. Now, proponents of drilling smell the sharpest whiff of victory ever.[…] The battle centers on drilling on the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow ribbon of land that stretches about 110 miles along the Beaufort Sea. Environmentalists and wildlife biologists say that in the summer, the coastal plain teems with caribou and millions of migratory birds. Drilling for oil there, they argue, would ruin one of the few pristine wilderness areas left on the planet.[…] Even without lawsuits by environmentalists, the earliest any oil from the wildlife refuge would make it to market is 2010, industry executives said. But development efforts could drag out well beyond that date. "To protect the refuge," said Deborah Williams, executive director of the Alaska Conservation Foundation in Anchorage, "national environmental law firms and Alaskan environmental groups will find every opportunity to challenge drilling."[…]

title: Keystone XL foes try to stop project financing
news: New York--After winning alliances with national lawmakers, environmentalists who oppose the Keystone XL project are taking aim at a new target--the banks that help finance the company whose pipeline would deliver heavy Canadian crude oil from Hardisty, Alberta, to the US Gulf Coast. At a Citigroup shareholders' meeting this spring, Keystone XL opponent and Texas landowner David Daniel cited what he described as TransCanada's bullying tactics against him and asked Citigroup to reject funding any Keystone XL-related loans.[…] In a 12-page letter to Citigroup, Daniel said TransCanada has "violated trespassing laws, broken agreements, and filed temporary restraining orders against Americans who question their authority." TransCanada disputes the claims.[…] Environmental activist group Rainforest Action Network has also targeted Citigroup and JP MORGAN CHASE about their financing of TransCanada. JP MORGAN CHASE did not respond to requests for comment. In a letter last October to Citigroup CEO Vikram Pandit and JP MORGAN CHASE CEO Jamie Dimon, RAN's Executive Director Rebecca Tarbotton had a "concern" about the banks having been underwriters for a $1 billion TransCanada bond and having each bought $295 million in the transaction. Tarbotton referred to "environmental commitments" of the banks and said "we understand that in addition to minimizing the bank's environmental footprint, these commitments also advance the bank's business interests in limiting its exposure to litigation, future regulation and other risks posed by environmentally dubious activities." Tarbotton also asked Citigroup to "review its relationship with TransCanada and request full disclosure of risks associated with the Keystone XL project."[…]

title: Park is asked to stop sale of water; Environmental concerns cited in appeal to Independence Park
news: Several environmental and other groups are teaming up Wednesday to ask that Independence National Historical Park, along with several other iconic national parks, stop selling bottled water.  If they succeed, visitors will be left with a situation - an absurd one, critics say - where they can buy sodas, juice, and other drinks in plastic bottles. But visitors who want water will have to buy a reusable bottle and fill it at a water station with Philadelphia tap water.  The effort is being led by Corporate Accountability International, a nonprofit whose Think Outside the Bottle campaign promotes public water systems.  At People's Plaza in the park on Wednesday, organizer Caroline Wooten and others plan to deliver a 3-by-5-foot card with signatures of park-goers and others representing about 50 groups and businesses.  "It sends the wrong message about our national commitment to tap water for parks to sell and promote bottled water," said Tina Shelton, a Havertown resident with Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, which supports the effort.  The groups say water is a "human right" that should not be treated like a commodity, never mind that Philadelphia meters it and charges residents, businesses - and the park - for using it.  "It really comes back to who is providing our water," Wooten said. "Is it municipal water systems . . . accountable to the public? Or is it Nestlé, Coke, and PEPSI who are accountable to their bottom line?" […]  Industry advocates say the environmental footprint of bottled water keeps shrinking. The recycling rate is close to 40 percent, according to industry tallies, and in the last 11 years, the average weight of a half-liter PET container has fallen by nearly 50 percent.[…]

title: Will Big Business Save the Earth?
news: THERE is a widespread view, particularly among environmentalists and liberals, that big businesses are environmentally destructive, greedy, evil and driven by short-term profits. [...] The embrace of environmental concerns by chief executives has accelerated recently for several reasons. Lower consumption of environmental resources saves money in the short run. Maintaining sustainable resource levels and not polluting saves money in the long run. And a clean image -- one attained by, say, avoiding oil spills and other environmental disasters -- reduces criticism from employees, consumers and government. [...] Global climate change is making water scarcer, especially in the densely populated temperate-zone countries, like the United States, that are Coca-Cola's main customers. [...] Hence Coca-Cola's survival compels it to be deeply concerned with problems of water scarcity, energy, climate change and agriculture. [...]

title: Assisting the inquiry
news: SIR - After reading your March 8 article 'Toxic sites could cost a bomb,' I felt it necessary to clarify factual errors within the piece. Firstly, Solutia Inc, of St Louis, Missouri, United States, filed for certain protections available under Chapter 11 of the US Bankruptcy Code in December 2003, which provides certain protections to companies while they attempt to reorganise their financial and business holdings. Solutia Inc is undergoing such reorganisation with a view to emerge this year. Solutia's UK subsidiary did not file for such bankruptcy protection. I would also like to clarify that Solutia is not part of the current Monsanto Company. The former Monsanto Company was renamed Pharmacia Corporation and ultimately merged with PFIZER Inc in 2003. Accordingly, the ownership of the businesses of the former Monsanto Company is complex due to changes in corporate ownership over the years. Solutia's corporate headquarters in St Louis can provide more details on the bankruptcy protection process and ownership changes. Solutia has owned and operated the former Monsanto site at Newport since 1997. We have provided archived information to the Environment Agency Wales and to Monsanto in an effort to assist the agency's ongoing investigation into historical waste disposal at Brofiscin quarry.[…] Although apportionment of liability for the disposal activities has not been finally determined, Monsanto Company, on behalf of Pharmacia Corporation, is co-operating with the Environment Agency Wales, to resolve the issues at this site. For more information regarding the historical waste disposal of the Newport facility, please contact Monsanto directly. To view a statement from Monsanto regarding this topic, please visit: http://www. monsanto.co.uk/news /ukshowlib.phtml?uid=11224.[…]

title: AGREEMENT SIGNED; WEST AFRICAN GAS PIPELINE GETS GO-AHEAD.
news: One of West Africa's most significant regional energy projects, the West African Gas Pipeline (WAGP), received the green light from the governments of Benin, Togo, Ghana and Nigeria to proceed with development planning after the signing of an historic document in Benin last month. CHEVRON said the memorandum of understanding between the four governments and a consortium of six energy companies grants the rights to develop the WAGP to the consortium, and establishes the initial legal framework for development of the pipeline. […] The pipeline, which is expected to cost around $400 million, will initially ship some 120 million cu ft per day of Nigerian gas for sale to power generation customers in Ghana, Togo and Benin. […] In addition, the WAGP is expected to have a permanent impact on the environment resulting from its 100-million-tonnes reduction of greenhouse gases. Commenting on the project's environment benefits, Kirkland said: "the availability of natural gas for power generation will reduce the need to use less environmentally friendly fuels, further decreasing air pollutants. Indeed, it is because of these benefits, we believe, that WAGP could qualify as one of the world's first clean development mechanism (CDM) projects under the Kyoto Protocol. The WAGP also dovetails perfectly with CHEVRON's phased Escravos Gas Project (EGP), which exemplifies our commitment to commercialise the vast natural gas resources of Nigeria" […]

title: Major banks lead way in disclosure; Reporting - CARBON DEBATE
news: Australia's biggest banks are among the world's leaders in reporting carbon emissions and integrating climate change issues into their business strategy. However, other companies in the retail, telecommunications and mining sectors are lagging behind, according to a major global report.  "There is certainly room for an improvement," said James Day, Australia and New Zealand director of the Carbon Disclosure Project, an international initiative which studies the emissions performance of the world's 500 biggest listed companies.[…] All 13 Australian companies in the Global 500 group responded to the survey, while some notable international ones did not, including Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, Apple and AMAZON.com in the US, Russian oil giant Rosneft and Bank of China. Part of the pressure on companies to lift their game was coming from investors, while tougher regulations and increasing demand from consumers for low-carbon products and improved performance were also playing a part, Mr Day said.[…]

title: What's News
news: Exxon Mobil Corp. said it plans to appeal a Louisiana appeals-court decision that held the oil giant liable for more than $100-million (U.S.) in damages in an environmental case. The court reduced an earlier award Thursday, trimming punitive damages awarded by a jury to $112-million from $1-billion, and leaving $56-million in compensatory damages unchanged. But Exxon Mobil, of Irving, Tex., insisted punitive damages weren't warranted and said the compensatory award exceeded cleanup costs. The case involves land leased by former Jefferson Parish district judge Joseph Grefer to Intracoastal Tubular Services Inc., a company contracted to clean and refurbish Exxon's pipes between the 1950s and 1992. Judge Grefer argued the oil industry knew since the 1930s that its pipes were filled with residue containing significant amounts of radium, a carcinogen, and Exxon said nothing in hopes of avoiding liability for cleanup costs.

title: TALE OF TWO VISIONS; Behind the De Soto debacle
news: Pinellas County's move to expand concessions at Fort De Soto Park died a sudden death last week after residents raised a full-throated outcry. The County Commission office was swamped with more than 1,000 telephone calls and e-mails within a week. Some commissioners said the outpouring topped any in memory. While the Fort De Soto plan shocked some, it was rooted in a yearslong effort to expand county park services and to open public land to moneymaking ventures that offset operating costs. "It wasn't like we sat around one night and said, yeah, let's do this," said assistant county administrator Jake Stowers, after the commissioners' decision. "It was a thought-out process. And quite honestly, I guess we misjudged some of the feeling in the community."[…] By 6 2005, the county had assembled a master plan that Stowers said reflected comments from the workshops. The plan called for "energizing" parks such as Fort De Soto with outdoor concerts, cafes and art exhibits.[…] Enlisting private companies to boost services at public parks is nothing new, said Paul Cozzie, Pinellas' parks and recreation director.[…] St. Petersburg environmentalist Lorraine Margeson helped rouse the opposition. She said the county failed to understand how precious unspoiled land in development-heavy Pinellas is to residents. Some plan advocates said embracing Hollywood's ideas would have little impact on the park, whose 1,136 acres are home to a beach ranked the best in the nation last year. Margeson finds that laughable. "I'm sorry, but that is just such baloney," she said. "These were not modest improvements." The county is now negotiating with PEPSI, Pinellas' official soft drink, about expanding the number of soda machines at parks. The arrangement could be worth $3.2-million to the county over 10 years. Other than the PEPSI deal, county officials say there are no plans to allow private businesses to operate in parks. They are not backing away from the concept, however - the current concessions at Fort DeSoto will be offered for the time being - but officials say they will act cautiously after the Fort De Soto plan backlash.[…]

title: Big firms, small expectations at APEC summit
news: TWO corporate giants who are among the biggest contributors to global warming, America's General Motors and CHEVRON Oil, are the major sponsors of the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-Operation business summit which will debate climate change next month. Both companies' recent efforts to get out a cleaner, greener message reflect a "sense of urgency" about climate change, said Mark Johnson, who chairs the APEC business advisory council. But in remarks that will further lower expectations for the summit, Mr Johnson told a business forum this week that US business believes there will be little chance of a clear US policy on climate change until after the 2008 presidential election. […] While US President George Bush is due to attend APEC next month for climate change discussions, there are seven different proposals before the US Congress on the issue, including several promoting mandatory targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions, a policy Mr Bush has previously threatened to veto. Just two months ago, Prime Minister John Howard heralded the meeting as possibly the most important on climate change since the Rio Earth summit 15 years ago that established the United Nations framework on climate change. But since then APEC has been overshadowed by Mr Bush's plans to hold a climate summit in Washington in late September and an agreement by the world's leading industrial countries to keep the key climate negotiations inside the UN. […]

title: Climate control is a lot of hot air
news: [...]IF I'M very, very good in this life and get choose what I'll be in the next, I choose to be a bear. I can't think of anything better: I'd have a sweet tooth, almost no predators and sleep snugly in a cave during the coldest months of the year. I hate winter. I hate wet winters and I hate dry winters. I hate ones with sunny blue skies and ones with howling winds. I hate being cold. And when the only warm place in my house is right in front of the heater, I wish climate change would speed up a bit so the temperature in my bedroom could be a little more temperate. I'm not an out-and-out denialist, but I'm not yet convinced that pollution is the only cause of climate change. Pollution's bad for the planet, humans, plants and animals and the world would be a happier place if we could have everything we need without sending smog signals into the sky. […] This week, former US vice-president Al Gore revealed that climate change denialists - led by ExxonMobil - are funding a disinformation campaign to the tune of $10m a year for research that debunks the link between carbon pollution and climate change. […]

title: Retailer set to recycle fluorescent light bulbs
news: Some big U.S. retailers are pushing compact fluorescent light bulbs as a way to save energy. But improper disposal of the bulbs creates a hazard, because they contain small amounts of mercury. Recycling them is about to get easier. Home Depot was due to announce Tuesday that it would take back old compact fluorescents in all 1,973 of its stores in the United States, creating the nation's most widespread recycling program for the bulbs. 'We kept hearing from the community that there was a little bit of concern about mercury in the CFLs,'' said Ron Jarvis, Home Depot's senior vice president for environmental innovation, using the industry abbreviation for the bulbs. ''And if the CFLs were in their house, how could they dispose of them?''  Until now, consumers had to seek out local hazardous waste programs or smaller retail chains willing to collect the bulbs for recycling, like Ikea and True Value. Some consumers have waited for retailers like Wal-Mart to have a designated recycling day. Others bought kits to mail the bulbs to a recycling site. […] Both Home Depot and Wal-Mart, the largest U.S. retailer, have vigorously promoted the bulbs as part of their commitment to the environment. Wal-Mart announced in October 2006 that it wanted to sell 100 million compact fluorescents by the end of 2007. It has far surpassed that goal, selling 193 million bulbs to date. […]

title: The ethical hijackers
news: Greenpeace protesters were last night holding a GM crop ship hostage after hijacking it as it tried to enter dock in Bristol. In a dramatic coup they boarded the Panamanian-registered vessel Etoile shortly after 6pm yesterday using inflatable speed boats as she approached Avonmouth docks.[...]  Greenpeace said that veteran campaigner Reverend Malcolm Carroll was one of those leading protests on board the vessel.[...]  Baptist minister Mr Carroll was one of 28 demonstrators acquitted of theft and criminal damage charges following an earlier anti-GM rally in 1999.[...] Last year Mr Carroll was also one of two Britons arrested with 30 Greenpeace protesters at the US headquarters of EXXON MOBIL, in Irving, Texas. The group dressed in tiger suits as part of an ongoing campaign against the Esso group and the company's "extreme global warming policy".

title: BARGE BLAST ROCKS NEW YORK OIL PORT
news: A MASSIVE explosion on a barge carrying 100,000 petrol barrels started a raging fire in New York yesterday. The shipment was docking at an oil storage terminal off Staten Island when the barge caught fire.  Police are adamant it was an accident and not the work of terrorists. The blast sent flames and huge clouds of black smoke billowing into the sky about 25km off the southern tip of Manhattan. Initial reports from the New York fire department said the barge was carrying propane or heating oil at the Port Mobil terminal owned by Exxon Mobil Corp. The company later said it contained unleaded petrol. One person was seriously injured in the fire and two other terminal workers were unaccounted for. Initial fears of a terrorist strike sent a wave of panic over the city with its stock market, The Dow Jones, increasing the price of oil.

title: Exxon Corp. to appeal spill judgment
news: Exxon Corp. of Irving, Tex., said yesterday it would appeal a $5.06-billion (U.S.) 1 judgment against the company for the 1989 Valdez oil spill. Exxon said it would base its appeal on juror misconduct, jury instructions, compensatory damage errors and what it referred to as the "excessiveness" of punitive damages in the case. The largest oil spill in U.S. waters dumped 35,000 tonnes of crude into Alaska's Prince William Sound in 1989. Exxon said it had submitted an appellate brief of its case to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, listing 11 legal issues. The filing follows the company's February filing of a notice that it would appeal the judgment.

title: Four Years After Macondo Spill, Response Skill Evolves, Improves
news: Mar. 24, 1989: the supertanker Exxon Valdez, en route to refineries in Long Beach, California, runs aground in Prince William Sound, Alaska, spilling enough oil to effect 300 miles of coastline and 11,000 square miles of water. [...] The Marine Spill Response Corp. (MSRC), Marine Well Containment Co. (MWCC) and the Helix Well Containment Group are each prepared, like encamped armies, for the call that the unthinkable has happened again. [...] However, even these preparations may not be enough, Mark Floege, a senior investigator for Greenpeace, told NGW. While the lessons from the Exxon Valdez accident were more "limited and local" in nature, Exxon took them seriously, he said. [...]

title: Farmer cleared of assault claims state tried to destroy his business
news: A FARMER who won Ireland's most celebrated environmental law case has accused the state of trying to put him out of business after he was found not guilty of assaulting a Department of Agriculture official. Judge Tom Teehan told the jury who unanimously acquitted John Hanrahan at Clonmel circuit court last Wednesday that there was "antipathy" towards the farmer from the department.  Hanrahan, of Ballycurkeen, Carrick-on-Suir, became a national figure after winning a 10-year legal battle and IR£1m ((EURO)1.2m) in damages 23 years ago against MERCK Sharp & Dohme, then the world's largest pharmaceutical multinational. He claimed toxic emissions from the company's plant at Ballydine were causing birth deformities and sickness in his farm animals, and ill health to himself and his family. However, he then fell into a legal dispute with the department over animal welfare and milk-quota payments. It had been alleged that on May 22, 2007, Hanrahan assaulted Eamonn Quirke, a department vet. Evidence was given in the six-day trial that the farmer, who has skin cancer, drove a Volvo farm loader through a closed gate, striking and injuring Quirke. The vet was among a group of departmental officials who had arrived at Hanrahan's farm to carry out an inspection of dead cattle.[…]

title: Gorgon approval close but pipeline talks continue
news: West Australian Energy Minister Clive Brown is finalising a state agreement enabling CHEVRONTEXACO to site its $11 billion Gorgon gas project on Barrow Island as state cabinet prepares to give the project the green light. The proposal already has the strong backing of West Australian Premier Geoff Gallop, Deputy Premier Eric Ripper and Mr Brown, who are satisfied CHEVRONTEXACO can manage the environmental issues on Barrow Island, an A-class nature reserve. […] Former West Australian premier Richard Court , who now works as a consultant in the oil and gas industry, said the Gorgon development still faced a series of hurdles even if cabinet approved the Barrow Island development proposal. "Environmental issues are one of the issues, [and] the large multinationals have got too much at stake not to be exemplary citizens," Mr Court said. […]

title: Canada's energy firms so far unhurt by oil spill; Analysis

[…]The accident killed 11 and left as much as 40,000 barrels a day of crude flowing into the Gulf. A number of countries, including Canada and the United States, are reviewing regulations governing offshore explora-tion following the disaster. New rules haven't been set but it's likely companies will face increased scrutiny and greater delays in their offshore operations. [...] The Obama administration has imposed a six-month moratorium on new deepwater exploratory drilling in the Gulf and new rules for operating in the petroleum-rich region. [...] Canadian regulators have also been more accommodating than their U.S. counterparts on allowing deepwater explora-tion to continue. Last month the province of Newfoundland and Labrador, home to all of Canada's offshore oil projects, allowed CHEVRON Corp. to begin drilling an exploration well in waters nearly twice as deep as the BP well, though with toughened conditions and more frequent inspections.[...]

title: Vending machines drawing fire

With more than 5.5 million vending machines in operation nationwide, Japan has a reputation for being an automated heaven, where anything from beer to toothbrushes is sold in vending machines. [...] But street corner vending machines selling Coca-Cola, Suntory and Kirin products 24 hours a day have come under fire from those outside the capital who have mounted an international campaign to try to get Coca-Cola in particular to turn off its machines. title: New Halls River plan draws fire
news: The second coming of Halls River Retreat opened to bad reviews Thursday as Citrus County planning officials and residents panned the 54-unit condominium project. The proposed time-share complex, which had riled the community and thousands of petitioners staunchly opposed to building on the 9.5-acre site along the Halls River in Homosassa, was killed by a judge's ruling in 2002.[…] Reeves responded by saying developers are willing to pay for all infrastructure improvements needed to support the project. He said the complex would actually improve the Halls River's water quality because of a strict Southwest Florida Water Management drainage plan. Bob Jeeves, secretary of the Homosassa River Alliance, an environmental advocacy group with more than 1,000 members, said the project would be a disaster when coupled with Crystal River's recent annexation of about 520 acres near the coast on which a Wal-Mart Supercenter has been proposed. Priscilla Watkins, who lives near the Halls River site, said the project would cause too much traffic and could endanger neighbors and residents during a hurricane. […]

title: EXXON sued by state of Texas over disputed royalties
news: THE US state of Texas is suing EXXON MOBIL, the giant oil company, for tens of millions of dollars in compensation to recover royalties it claims are due on oil and gas production.[…] EXXON MOBIL has threatened exhaustive appeals to overturn the Alabama verdict, which awards punitive damages against the oil company for alleged underpayment of about $ 40 million in royalties on natural gas produced from wells in Mobile Bay. The jury awarded $ 87 million in compensation and added $ 3.4 billion in punitive damages by tripling the value of EXXON's annual production from the 13 gas wells.  The fine scales similar heights to those of the penalty levied against EXXON for the Valdez oil pollution disaster, which cost the company $ 5billion in punitive damages.[…]

title: ExxonMobil hit with US$4.5b damages ruling
news: (PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND) Picture shows tug boats towing the oil tanker Exxon Valdez off Bligh Reef in Prince William Sound to a harbour near Naked Island for repair and salvage efforts, two weeks after the tanker ran aground on 24 March, 1989, and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil. ExxonMobil was ordered in court to pay US$4.5 billion in punitive damages and US$2.25 billion in interest for the Exxon Valdez oil spill, David Oesting, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said. The money would go to 32,000 fishermen, natives, landowners, small businessmen and municipalities in south central Alaska who were affected by the spill, but ExxonMobil is expected to appeal the ruling, Mr Oesting said.

title: Rockefellers tell Exxon to green up its act
news: EXXON Mobil last week announced it made $10.9 billion (Euro 7 billion) in the first quarter of this year, one of the biggest hauls in corporate history. It took a Rockefeller to tell the company that money isn't everything. Last Wednesday in a midtown Manhattan hotel 15 members of the Rockefeller family went public in an attempt to get Exxon to face up to the realities of climate change. The descendants of John D Rockefeller, America's first and biggest oil industry magnate, said that the oil dinosaur faces extinction unless it steps up the search for alternative fuels. "Kerosene was the alternative energy of its day when he realised it could replace whale oil," said Neva Rockefeller Goodwin, great-granddaughter of the Standard Oil founder.[...] Goodwin, an economist and environmentalist, said that Exxon was blinkered by its short-term pursuit of profits. Until relatively recently, Exxon was chief cheerleader, and fundraiser, for the anti-global warming crowd. [...]Greenpeace labelled Exxon the "number one climate criminal" and said its lobbying was instrumental in the US's refusal to sign up to the Kyoto protocol, which set targets for reducing pollution in December 1997.[...]

title: Hudson River PCB Cleanup Projects Under Construction
news: Construction is accelerating at two Hudson River cleanup projects designed to capture and treat PCBs that for years had been discharged into the river from manufacturing operations. A large sedimentation dewatering facility and a collection-tunnel complex are to begin operating next year. Contractors working for GENERAL ELECTRIC Corp., Fairfield, Conn., will start dredging a 40-mile portion of the upper Hudson River north of Albany next May. GE now is building a 41,000-sq-ft dewatering plant and a transportation facility on a 110-acre site near the Champlain Canal at Fort Edward.  The river bottom will be scoured with clamshell-bucket dredges. Sediment will be dewatered using 12 hydraulic plate-filter presses. Water will be treated to drinking-water standards and returned to the canal. Dried sediment will be sent for disposal at a Texas hazardous-waste landfill. A joint venture of Merco/Obayashi, New Lebanon, N.J., also is mining a tunnel complex 80 ft beneath the river to collect PCBs infiltrating from GE's Hudson Falls site. A 24-ft-dia, 200-ft-deep shaft will lead to two, X-shaped 1,500-ft-long, 10-ft-dia tunnels. A series of wells and horizontal drains will steer the PCBs into the tunnels where it will be pumped to two on-site water treatment plants. […] The project is the result of a contentious battle between GE, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and New York state on how to remediate PCBs, used as insulating fluid in capacitors and now considered a probable carcinogen. About 1.8 million cu yd of sediment containing 248,600 lb of PCBs discharged from the 1940s until 1977 will be treated. […]

title: Racial Rift Slows Suit for 'Environmental Justice'
news: For the 1,400 residents of Kennedy Heights and the many people who have taken up their cause, the Federal court case unfolding here should be a national landmark in the drive for "environmental justice," a legal strategy based on claims that racial minorities are disproportionately subjected to pollution hazards.[…]CHEVRON Corporation, the company that acquired Gulf Oil and is now the defendant in the residents' lawsuit, insists that documented illnesses in the neighborhood do not exceed the average for similar neighborhoods, and that there is no proof of significant oil contamination or that contamination could have caused any illness there. […] While environmental and civil-rights groups have come together in recent years to argue that pollution disproportionately harms minority groups, and the general contention was backed up a few years ago by a major Environmental Protection Agency report, the claims have rarely translated into specific legal awards. In Kennedy Heights, the Gulf memorandum laying out an option to sell the property to a developer of housing for blacks represents an unusual attempt by plaintiffs to use corporate documents to prove environmental racism. […]CHEVRON insists that there is no concrete evidence of excessive health problems in the neighborhood, no evidence that oil or other wastes have contaminated the water supply, and thus no evidence of environmental harm, let alone racism.[…]

title: New effort to turn palm oil 'green'; Growers, under pressure, produce a trickle under rigorous review process
news: Idyllic scenes of palm trees swaying in the breeze over sandy beaches have long decorated brochures designed to lure tourists to Indonesia and Malaysia. But few visitors see the giant palm plantations away from the shore. Each year, the farms produce millions of tons of palm oil, which has soared in popularity since the 1970s and is now found in foods like margarine, potato chips and chocolate, as well as in soap, cosmetics and biofuel. Palm produces more oil per hectare than other oil crops, making it a cheaper alternative. […] Last year, the British cosmetics company Lush introduced a soap made from a base free of palm oil. Last month, Cadbury New Zealand bowed to consumer pressure and reversed a decision to replace cocoa butter with palm oil in its chocolates. And the Melbourne Zoo began a campaign to have palm oil clearly labeled on food products to ensure that consumers know what they are buying. The increasingly vocal protests are not what the industry expected five years after it began developing a certification system for producing environmentally sustainable palm oil. In 2004, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil formed, representing palm-oil producers; consumer goods manufacturers including Unilever, Johnson & Johnson and Kellogg; environmental groups like the World Wide Fund for Nature; and social and development organizations. Membership in the roundtable is voluntary, and producers must meet its criteria before their oil can be certified as sustainable. The group's secretary general, Vengeta Rao, said new plantations could not be established on primary rainforest or lands with ''high conservation values'' like those with rare or endangered species. […]

title: The Teflon Shield
news: IKEA is a curious success story. The lines at the Swedish stores are endless, its furniture requires an engineering degree to assemble, yet its $8.5 billion global sales empire is expanding rapidly. […] That may not last. Activists were emboldened by Seattle, and are no longer wary of taking on complex industries. In recent months, groups like the National Wildlife Federation and Friends of the Earth have started targeting banks that "fuel the chain saws" and offering activists seminars on sorting through financial records. On April 11, American activists will launch "Spank the Bank," targeting CITIGROUP on a rainbow of issues--including financing of the controversial Three Gorges Dam in China. Pretty soon, no multinational will be able to rely on circumstance for cover. "This year's Teflon companies could be the hardest hit 10 years from now if they aren't careful," says John Elkington, founder of Sustainability, a British firm that advises companies on social responsibility. IKEA learned that lesson the hard way. For years it had a naturally "green" reputation, loosely based on its roots in conscientious Sweden and its preference for untreated blond wood. That started to erode in the late 1980s when the finish on IKEA bookshelves was found to have illegally high levels of formaldehyde. Then Greenpeace started leaning on companies, including IKEA, to stop using PVC, the hazardous plastic. […]

title: Ontario pressed to dismantle pollution laws
news: Responding to an invitation by the Ontario government, dozens of waste-emitting industries are urging Premier Mike Harris and his Progressive Conservatives to dismantle the province's stringent antipollution laws.     Mining companies, including Inco and Falconbridge, are proposing an end to tests on the toxicity of waste from their operations. Chemical companies want to loosen rules for monitoring illegal dumping of hazardous wastes. And Pepsi-Cola and Coca-Cola want an end to the requirement that they provide pop in refillable bottles.

title: Court cuts Exxon's damages
news: EXXON Mobil Corp's $10 billion bill for punitive damages in the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, the largest in US legal history at the time, is excessive and must be reduced, a federal appeals court ruled today.  The court returned the case to a federal trial judge in Alaska with instructions to bring the award against the largest oil company into line with constitutional limits. The ruling follows US Supreme Court decisions in 1996 and 2001 that set guideposts against excessive punitive damage awards. "The $US5 billion ($10 billion) punitive damages award is too high to withstand he review we are required to give it," US Circuit Judge Andrew Kleinfeld wrote.

title: 'Bottlemania' questions water's 'green' impact; Packaging concern grows as sales surge
news: Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It. By Elizabeth Royte. Bloomsbury, $24.99, 256 pages. In perhaps the biggest marketing coup since DeBeers convinced consumers that diamonds are the must-have gemstone for lovebirds, beverage companies have transformed water from a free, simple thirst-quencher into a colossal moneymaker.In fact, sales of bottled water have surpassed those of milk and beer, Elizabeth Royte writes in Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It.  And although soft drinks are  still No.1, water isn't far behind. […] The "green" movement has raised Americans'  consciousness about carbon footprints and recycling. Water has become another green concern. Natural supplies of clean, fresh water  could dry up if we don't start paying attention to where water comes from, what we do to it and why we drink it.[…] In Bottlemania, she explores how water is accessed, packaged and sold; compares tap water with bottled water; and muses on the commodification of a natural resource. She raises questions about bottled water's surging sales and its impact on society and the environment -- and explains what she's learned in a straightforward, conversational voice that makes even the densest statistics and scientific explanations accessible (well, almost). Royte traveled to Fryeburg, Maine. An aquifer there is a source for Nestle-owned Poland Spring, which built a bottling plant in nearby Hollis. Fryeburg residents are at odds about whether they should welcome or shun the corporate interloper. Royte writes about Coca-Cola (Dasani) and PEPSICO (Aquafina). Both draw, bottle and sell water in America and abroad and have triggered conflicts over water rights, taxes, traffic and pollution.[…]

title: Tanzania; Inadequately Tested GMOs Are Sneaking Into Supermarkets and Being Sold As 'Food'
news: I CAN never be sure what my editors will do with an article I send in. They often help. But they also have rules which I do not know. If I send a photo that is not mine for example, they appreciate if I have received specific permission to use it. Last week they printed the caption of the photo: "Deaths of female rats being fed with a diet partially consisting of GMO corn were linked mostly to large mammary tumors such as suffered by study participant 9255 GMO." [...] Rats are a model for mammalian health and are thus helpful in modelling environmental risks for wildlife mammals. Ethically human experiments must be preceded by animal studies - knowing that rats are only a model; human reac-tions may be different. Moreover, previous research was at the most 90 day feeding trials, which is before the tumors even appeared in the research being reported. Plus the current research was conducted for the lifetime of the rat, about two years, which is a big improvement over the 90 day trials - but far different from the lifetime of a human being. No scientific testing has been done on human beings. This means GMOs are being allowed into the environment and even for human consumption virtually without having been tested. Meaning that corporations which produce and sell "food" (e.g. Monsanto, Syngenta, Coca Cola, PepsiCo, American Garden, Kellog's, General Mills, Nestles) and their fronts (e.g. Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, AGRA, USAID, CIDA, and Geoffrey Sack's Earth Institute), have been so eager to gain profits and control of the food chain that they have cajoled and bullied governments to be given permission to push their products on unsuspecting people and the environment. [...]

title: Response to Lantau green reports cool; People 'fail to see direct impact'
news: The two environmental reports on the DISNEY and North Lantau projects attracted only seven public submissions during a one-month consultation which ended on Tuesday. Environmentalists said the lukewarm response from the public might be related to the technical nature of the Environmental Impact Assessment reports, which total 3,000 pages. Ng Cho-nam, president of the Conservancy Association, criticised the Government for not taking the initiative to seek public opinion on large-scale strategic development.  Mr Ng, who is an associate professor of environmental management at Hong Kong University, said the public were not interested in studying the two assessments as they could not see the direct impact the projects would have on them. Among the 31 other environmental impact reports released for public consultation in the past, 19 received no response.  The remaining 12 received between one and 11 submissions. An Environmental Protection Department spokesman said the public consultation aimed to ensure transparency of the assessment process and they would study every comment in detail. The seven Disney-related submissions raised many questions over the findings of the reports, which concluded that the Disneyland theme park, due to open in 2005, should be able to comply with environmental laws. One submission was from the group, Hong Kong Dolphinwatch, which criticised the findings that there would be a limited impact on dolphins as "misleading and inaccurate". Another submission from a lecturer from the General Education Centre of the Polytechnic University, Dr John Babson, urged the Director of Environmental Protection not to issue environmental permits to the Disneyland project without a full assessment of the ecological and cultural heritage of Penny's Bay. A submission from the Citizens Party also criticised many of the Disneyland report's findings and statements as speculative and misleading. The department will decide whether to endorse the two assessment reports and issue permits after listening to the Advisory Council on the Environment, which will discuss the issues on Monday.

title: Green will be the colour of more data centres; Tech firms going green are offering more energy-efficient data centres, writes WINSTON CHAI
news: REDUCING the appetite of power-hungry data centres was a key focal point for enterprise networking and hardware makers this year as customers are becoming increasingly aware of the benefits of energy-efficiency on the environment and their own bottom lines. As the repository for critical business information and IT systems, data centres are typically packed with racks of servers, networking and storage equipment that are sapping electricity round-the-clock. To add to the consumption, such facilities often require special cooling systems to dissipate the heat generated by the towers of machinery, making them prime targets for power conservation.'The increased emphasis on green IT has propelled data centres to the limelight. With data centres consuming more energy than any other IT environment, both users and providers of technology have been placed under scrutiny,' said Tom Cheong, Cisco System's managing director of Singapore and Brunei. 'There is now an urgent need to review processes to ensure environmental sustainability, and the technology industry has been looked upon as the catalyst for this positive change by providing environmentally-friendly solutions,' he added. Against this backdrop, US authorities are even thinking of allocating energy ratings to IT equipment like servers. As a result, network equipment suppliers like Cisco, as well as firms like Sun, Hewlett-Packard (HP) and IBM have all released new products and services this year that promise to slash the electricity bills for their customers.[…] To add to the business opportunities presented by the eco-friendly IT movement, companies like HP, IBM and Cisco also have two major local government projects to look to boost local sales over the next 12 months. […]

title: A hard rain is gonna fall
news: Ireland has had the wettest year on record - and that's official. Figures released by Met Eireann this week show most of its weather stations registered higher than average rainfall, in some cases the highest since records began more than a century ago. 2002 was the ninth year in a row the weather was milder than usual. […] More accurately, what's happening is climate change. Because as the temperature of the Earth's surface increases, we are subjected to increasingly frequent and severe "extreme weather events", often with catastrophic consequences. Even by the end of October, the global bill for such natural disasters was estimated at  EUR 70 billion.[…] Three years earlier, a $ 7 million campaign by the American Petroleum Institute aimed to "maximise the impact of scientific views consistent with ours" (by recruiting sceptical scientists who dissent from the IPCC consensus) with a view to "erecting a barrier against further efforts to impose Kyoto-like measures in the future". Greenpeace produced its own assessment of Exxon's "weapons of mass deception" last October, with a foreword by Bianca Jagger complaining about "powerful agents with vested interests who continue to wage a cynical, self-interested war" to derail the Kyoto process. "The worst of these is Exxon-Mobil," Jagger declared. Though other leading oil companies, such as Shell and BP, withdrew from the Global Climate Coalition and began diversifying into alternative energy, Exxon-Mobil still concentrates its efforts on lobbying against concerted international action to deal with climate change. No wonder environmentalists are running a "Stop Esso" boycott. […]

title: Oil burn causing slick in forests
news: While showering a few weeks ago, I realised I had run out of conditioner. So I reached up and grabbed my wife's bottle Clairol Herbal Essences Rainforest Flowers, "with essences of nourishing palm". The label caught me slightly by surprise. As an environmental journalist, I've been writing about the ecologically destructive effect of palm oil for some time now. Whether it's used as an additive in soap, cosmetics or food, or processed into a biofuel, palm oil is one of the worst culprits in the climate crisis. Most of it comes from the disappearing, ultra-carbon-rich rain forests of Indonesia and Malaysia, of which around 65,000sqkm have been cleared and burned to make way for palm oil plantations.[…] Unfortunately, most of the food and cosmetics conglomerates are more interested in covering up the environmental destruction than replacing the problem ingredient. Kellogg's, Kraft Foods, Unilever, Nestle, PROCTER & GAMBLE and others (including the Girl Scouts) assure the public that such environmental concerns don't apply to them because they (or their suppliers) are members of the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, an industry group (with a handful of environmental members) that sets guidelines on growing and selling palm oil. Unfortunately, as a recent Greenpeace report revealed, the Roundtable's standards are almost meaningless because they don't include inspections of the palm oil tree plantations. The Roundtable plans to address this problem in the next few months by certifying a small amount of oil that it says has been verifiably produced according to some sustainable standards. But even Roundtable vice president Darrel Webber acknowledges that the process "isn't perfect," in part because liquid oils are easy to mix and nearly impossible to track.[…]

title: The Coffee Crunch: Part One: Java drinkers may not realize it at the cash, but world prices are in the cellar -- along with the farmers trying to grow the beans
news: […] In the grim words of an official from the human rights organization Global Exchange: "The coffee we enjoy every morning is tainted with suffering." The bad news for coffee farmers today is that the commodity market price of coffee has dropped more than 60 per cent in the past three years. This is due mostly to increased production from relatively new coffee producing countries that are flooding the market with cheaper beans. […] In nature, coffee grows best under shade. But it  can be grown quicker and more economically in open sun and with the assistance of copious amounts of insecticides and pesticides. This is how most coffee consumed in the western world is grown -- on plantations throughout the Third World producing for a handful of major trans-national corporations which control the coffee business: Nestle, Philip Morris and PROCTER AND GAMBLE prominent among them. According to analysis, the poisons do not make it into our cups, partly because the beans are so well protected by their natural outer coat and partly because harmful residue evaporates in the intense heat of roasting. But the environment, and workers using the poisons, don't escape so easily. Hundreds of workers have been poisoned, some have died, but according to aid agencies, the casualties are much higher because most cases go unreported. Contaminated drinking water in many coffee producing countries has been linked to birth defects and developmental problems in children.[…]

title: Biggest oil company puts its faith in algae
news: After years of sneering and dragging its feet, the world's biggest oil company has declared its love for renewable energy: ExxonMobil is teaming up with Craig Venter, the biotech entrepreneur, to develop new road fuels using photosynthetic algae. The oil multinational, despised by green activists for its support of scientists sceptical of climate change, plans to invest $600 million (£370 million) in a joint venture with Mr Venter's company, Synthetic Genomics. The thinking is that algae is a more efficient source of fuel than conventional biofuels, such as ethanol made from corn or sugar cane and biodiesel made from wheat or palm oil. Algae can be processed into fuels similar to petrol and diesel - and it consumes carbon dioxide as it grows.[...] Greenpeace was sceptical yesterday.[...]

Initial output of 100,000 barrels of oil a day may not start until early 2012, he said. [...] Imperial is owned 70 per cent by Exxon Mobil Corp., the world's largest oil company.[...] The project was delayed by about two months by a court fight over water permits to drain the mine's marshy site in northern Alberta, March said. title: Home: News: Trudie Styler: why I had to use my celebrity to try to save the rainforest: The film producer, champion of ecological causes and wife of Sting, talks about the environmental outrage at the heart of her new screen project, and why - as a frequent flyer - she dismisses carbon offsetting as 'a crock'.
news: [...] Her latest project is Crude , a critically acclaimed documentary film that tells the story of one of the most controversial environmental lawsuits in recent history. For the past 15 years, 30,000 residents of the Ecuadorean Amazon have been fighting a legal battle against the CHEVRON oil company. The plaintiffs allege that, over the course of operations dating back to 1964, TEXACO (acquired by CHEVRON in a 2001 merger) dumped more than 18 billion gallons of toxic waste directly into the streams and rivers on which people rely for drinking, cooking, bathing and fishing. The dumping alone was 30 times more oil than was spilled in the Exxon Valdez disaster, with one crucial difference: while Exxon Valdez was an accident, the plaintiffs claim that TEXACO's dumping was a deliberate strategy to reduce costs [...] It is a troubled region - this month, Prince Charles visited Ecuador to highlight the damage done by climate change. The impact of the oil-drilling has been similarly devastating. Cancer rates have rocketed, blighting a region with little or no access to adequate medical care. There are high levels of leukaemia, miscarriage and birth defects. Five indigenous groups have lost 95 per cent of their ancestral land. In 2008, a court-appointed technical expert estimated that the contamination had caused 1,041 excess deaths from cancer. [...] The problems have been further exacerbated by the existence of 917 unlined waste pits, filled with toxic sludge, that allow millions of cubic metres of poisonous gas to escape into the atmosphere. Although TEXACO reached a $40m settlement agreement with the Ecuadorean government in 1995, in which the oil company agreed to clean up the well sites, the plaintiffs allege that the process was partial and inadequate. CHEVRON claims that it is Petro Ecuador, the statde-owned oil company which took over TEXACO's operatdions in 1990, that is to blame for the current pollution. [...]

title: Brazilian Officials Warn CHEVRON Over Offshore Spill
news: RIO DE JANEIRO -- CHEVRON came under intense scrutiny in Brazil on Friday over an oil spill at an offshore field the company operates, with federal investigators here threatening fines for CHEVRON and potential prison terms for its officials if they are found guilty of violating environmental contamination laws.[...] While the spill, from an appraisal well in the Campos Basin, is thought to be much smaller than BP's oil spill last year in the Gulf of Mexico and is said by CHEVRON to have almost dissipated, it also presents an additional challenge for CHEVRON in Latin America. In nearby Ecuador, CHEVRON has faced seething resentment and a protracted legal battle over oil contamination in the country's rain forest.[...] Despite CHEVRON's assertions that the problem was contained, it faced mounting criticism from various other quarters in Brazil. Legislators said they would summon CHEVRON officials to appear for questioning. And here in Rio, where Brazil's energy industry is largely based around Petrobras, activists from Greenpeace emptied black ink on Friday in front of CHEVRON's headquarters to protest the spill.[...] Several Brazilian news media reports referred to information from SkyTruth, an environmental group in the United States that uses satellite images to track oil spills and other accidents. John Amos, the group's president, said he estimated that the spill was perhaps 10 times larger than CHEVRON's estimates, meaning it extended over about 918 square miles.

title: Labor starts new carbon probe; Coalition names climate advisers
news: A FRESH investigation will be launched into the impact of a carbon price on the coal-fired power industry under a series of commitments made by the federal government to electricity company bosses. The government had previously refused to release the report, citing its commercial sensitivity. Meanwhile, the Coalition announced the members of a business group advising it on climate policy, including the president of a climate sceptics group, carbon tax opponents and advocates for soil carbon and solar power. The panel was initially planned to build support for the Coalition's climate change policy, but the 15 members have agreed only to examine the opposition's "direct action" plan. The Coalition has been struggling to win public support from business leaders for its plan for a $10 billion fund to pay for cuts in carbon dioxide emissions, with former Reserve Bank board member Dick Warburton last month telling The Age he had not convinced any business leaders to openly back the policy. Members of the panel include Mr Warburton and ex-Western Mining chief executive Hugh Morgan, president of the climate-sceptic Lavoisier Group. Also involved are Coca-Cola Amatil managing director Terry Davis, Australian Food and Grocery Council chief Kate Carnell, National Farmers Federation president Jock Laurie and Andrew Dyer, director of solar company BrightSource Energy. title: Business & Media: Business: Mammon: A pinstriped rainbow warrior: Robert Napier once headed firms seen as destroying the planet: now he leads the Worldwide Fund for Nature's UK operation. Ben Wootliff is convinced by his conversion
news: […]  The WWF is campaigning against the Baku-Tiblisi-Ceyhan pipeline, which connects the Caspian to the Mediterranean sea. The pipeline is being built by BP, whose chief executive, John Browne, sat on the board of Redland with Napier for several years. The WWF says the pipeline is an act of environmental vandalism that belies BP's claims to be the most green of the world's major oil companies.  'The pipeline goes through an area of Georgia that's of immense natural importance - it's like building a pipeline through the Malvern Hills.'  Indeed, from the WWF's description, the pipeline appears to be a foolhardy venture, passing through earthquake zones, revolution hot spots and disputed borders. In normal times it might be an absurd project, but these are not even normal times. 'It all comes down to American geopolitics. They wanted to reduce their dependence on Middle Eastern oil so they have turned the whole planning process upside down.'  The concerns could sound incongruous when they come from a man who lunches at the Reform Club, is wearing pinstripe suits, and has a house in well-heeled Sussex, but they don't.  The infrastructure for the pipeline is largely built. However, the battle is part of the larger campaign. By making the project so controversial and so expensive for its supporting banks - ABN Amro, CITIGROUP, Societe General, and Japan's Mizuho - as well as BP, Napier hopes to make future environmentally dubious pipelines unfeasibly expensive.[…]

title: Niger Delta oil companies at 'breaking point': official
news: Oil companies in the troubled Niger Delta have reached the "breaking point" but the government has ruled out full-scale military action to help curb the mounting chaos that has engulfed parts of Nigeria's oil-producing region, a senior government official said May 9. […] President Olusegun Obasanjo, who is to step down May 29, in the early years of his tenure deployed thousands of troops to parts of the Niger Delta, a move that generated even more resentment among the communities of the oil-producing region. Igali also downplayed fears the surge in violence would force oil companies to evacuate more staff from the oil hubs of Port Harcourt and Warri. Shell was forced to pull out around 330 families from residential compounds in the Niger Delta early in 2006 when the militants first struck. […] In the latest incident, four oil workers were abducted in the Delta when militants attacked a vessel near the CHEVRON-operated Escravos terminal, the US oil major said May 9. […] A second incident occurred on the Walvis 6, a drilling support vessel working in the Meren field. The vessel was boarded by unknown assailants with an apparent intention of robbery. "We are not aware of any hostages being taken from the vessel," CHEVRON said. The company added May 9 there were currently no threats to oil production and exports at the Escravos terminal after the attack. CHEVRON, which produces about 360,000 b/d in Nigeria, was forced to shut down its 42,000 b/d Ebite flow station on May 7 because of a community protest. Villagers, who wielded machetes and sticks, were protesting what they said were delays in compensation for an oil spill. The company last week had to shut in its 15,000 b/d Funiwa field after militants attacked its Oloibiri floating production, storage and offloading vessel.

title: $30,000 is ridiculous sum for feasibility study

As for all the increases in taxes for various city services  needed because the investments aren't producing money, what about the poor taxpayer who has the same problems? How do we get compensated? title: Still Singing
news: I saw Pete Seeger Sunday night, alive as you and me. They threw a birthday concert for him at Madison Square Garden. John Seeger, age 95, said from the stage that he expected his 90-year-old younger brother to make 100, which seems reasonable. Standing there, banjo off his shoulder, head thrown back, Pete looked eternal, in that pose so engraved in American memory it should be on a coin. […] The evening was, after all, a benefit for Clearwater, the name of an organization and a boat, both built by Mr. Seeger, that have fought for decades to rescue the Hudson River from life as an industrial sewer. The job isn't done. Remember PCBs? GENERAL ELECTRIC  dumped tons of them in the river. The company is about ready to dredge them out, but for now they are still there, seeping downriver and into fish. That's one hot issue. But issues and leftist anger were mostly confined to the first half of the evening. Under a sweet, heavy nostalgia glaze, the show summoned but never lingered on bygone days when folk singing was considered both relevant and dangerous. […]

title: Tech industry gears up to lead by example; SUSTAINABILITY: SPECIAL REPORT
news: The technology industry finds itself in an interesting bind. As increased attention shifts to the environmental impact of business, IT is considered to be one of the big energy consumers inside a corporation, yet technology suppliers also recognise the tantalising opportunities in being part of the cure. IT research firm Gartner estimates that business use of servers and PCs accounts for 0.75 per cent of all global carbon dioxide emissions and other estimates assert that IT uses up to three-quarters of a business's electricity in service-based industries. Many of the technology sector's biggest names are getting their own environmental house in order, so they can then make hay by helping everyone else do the same. As a result, chief information officers and others managing the technology strategy of Australian organisations now find themselves faced by a barrage of potential suppliers who have re-invented themselves as environmental pioneers. Among the wave of recent proclamations, Google has pledged to be carbon neutral by the end of the year, Cisco is targeting a 10 per cent reduction of carbon emissions this year, Sun Microsystems will reduce its 2002 level carbon footprint by 20 per cent by 2012, IBM has committed $US86 million ($100 million) to construct a giant data centre to house greener technology and EDS has undertaken to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 25 per cent by 2010.[…] Google has sought to use redesigned components in its servers to produce more performance per watt of power. Other companies will not have the luxury of building new data centres, of course, but hosted facilities such as those managed by IBM, EDS, Telstra, Macquarie Telecom and a number of others are an alternative option.[…]

title: Ghana; The Devastating Effects of Electronic Junk
news: It is very disheartening to know that African countries and other under-developed countries have become a dumping ground for expired and used products - electronic industrial junk - which no longer conform to the standards of the developed countries, which keep on changing, as technology improves.[…] During periods of heavy rainfall, most of the site becomes flooded, and during these times, dust and soil containing chemical contaminants from the computer junk are carried into the adjacent, low-lying lagoon and the Densu River, which flow into the sea.[…] In the opinion of the United Nations Environmental Programme, 20-50 million tonnes of electronics are discarded each year, with 70% of these products being shipped to the poor countries, including Ghana. One might wonder how these computer junks find their way into developing countries like Ghana, despite the Basel Ban Amendment, under the Basel convention, which forbids the exports of e-waste from developed to developing countries. According to Mike Anane, a United Nations (UN) environment laureate, business people get round the Basel Ban by labelling shipments as usable second hand goods or donations. "Research shows that about 90% of the computers are junk, they just do not work, they are obsolete, not functional and they contain an array of toxic materials, including lead, mercury and brominated flames retarded and they are destined for disposal in their countries of origin." Anane said he was once surprised to see some foreigners at the Tema Port selling used computers as low as GH¢4. The funny aspect was that, these foreigners insisted they would not allow testing of the products at the site, and to the dismay of buyers, the majority of these computers are not usable. They included brands like Toshiba, Dell, Philips, Sony, Sharp, IBM, Hewlett Packard, and many others.[…] Effects on environment […] Effect on children […]

title: THE GREAT GREEN MYTH
news: MOST 'green' claims for household products are 'misleading, meaningless or even downright dishonest', a government-sponsored report says today.  Those responsible include some of Britain's biggest companies and best-known household names, says the National Consumer Council, after the largest survey of its kind.  'It would be wrong to single out individual manufacturers for particular criticism,' said a spokeswoman. 'They are all doing it.'   The report focuses on the claims manufacturers make to lead shoppers into thinking products do not harm the environment. It says: 'Of the claims currently being made ... many are confusing, a fairly large proportion are misleading, or potentially so, and a few are downright dishonest.'  Generally, such claims are 'unverifiable, vague, woolly, specious or misleading'. Detergents, aerosols, packaging and claims about recycling were all involved, the report says. The council says it was struck by the low level of knowledge about environmental issues among consumers, and calls for a coherent government information campaign to remedy the situation.[…]  THE CLAIMS, AND THE REALITY: WE NAME THE NAMES […]  Tesco own brand washing powder: 'contains no unnecessary ingredients:'  NCC: That is just absurd. Do other manufacturers use unnecessary ingredients, then? […] Ariel:  Less powder per wash. New Ariel Future uses more effective ingredients which allow you to use less powder per wash than with Ariel Ultra....' Logo WWF Panda. title: FOREST'S GRIM FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
news: […] This week Friends of the Earth will launch a campaign against the proposed pipeline and against the oil company behind the project, Exxon, which trades in the UK as Esso and Mobil.
