title: PGE's agreement on Boardman coal plant closure leaves EPA violation pending
news: An agreement between Portland GENERAL ELECTRIC and environmental groups to settle a 2008 lawsuit over alleged Clean Air Act violations at PGE's Boardman coal plant will not end a separate but similar Environmental Protection Agency action against the utility. title: CLEAN-FUEL RULES TO STRAIN REFINERIES, EXXON WARNS
news: DALLAS (AP) - The chairman and chief executive of EXXON MOBIL Corp. says he can't imagine anyone building new refineries in the U.S., warning that clean- fuel rules will further strain gasoline-making capacity.[…]  Raymond made the comments Wednesday after the meeting of EXXON MOBIL shareholders, where he announced a two-for-one stock split and an extra 2- cent-per-share dividend. title: Pension funds fall short on ethical investment
news: Staff pension funds for Aviva, Co-operative Group and Marks and Spencer have performed poorly in a survey of how schemes are incorporating environmental and social concerns into their investment decisions. Many of the biggest pension funds are failing to implement policies to incorporate environmental, social and governance (ESG) considerations into their investment decisions, a survey has found.1   Campaign group Fair Pensions, which is supported by environmentalists and trade unions such as WWF and the GMB, assessed the 30 largest UK staff pension funds worth over pounds 350bn. The assessment was based on published information, a questionnaire and interviews.   Fair Pensions says it found a 'striking disparity' between the best and worst schemes - a dozen scored over 50% but 18 scored less (see table).  The Universities Superannuation Scheme, BT's pension fund and Scottish local council Strathclyde's scheme were ranked highest. Power company Eon, financial services firm Prudential and steelmaker Corus had the lowest-ranked schemes. The Coal Pension Trustees scheme and pensions funds for IBM, Unilever, BAE Systems and Lloyds TSB did not participate in the survey and publish little or no information on their approach to responsible investment Fair Pensions says a lack of transparency is 'often allied with ineffective policy'. The most remarkable finding was that pension funds for insurers Aviva, Co-operative Group and Marks and Spencer also scored poorly despite the reputations the companies have built for good ESG performance, such as M&S's 'Plan A' environmental strategy (ENDS Report 384, pp5-6). […]

title: World banks club together to turn their notes green
news: A new code of conduct provides stricter guidelines for projects in developing countries, writes Aaron Patrick in New York. Can banks make money protecting the environment and powerless communities? The world's largest financial institution thinks so, and is trying to use its financial muscle to reduce the damage from dams, power stations, mines and other infrastructure projects. CITIGROUP and nine other international banks this month adopted the Equator Principles, a code of conduct requiring them to follow standards laid down by the World Bank for infrastructure projects. Led by Chris Beale, an Australian who is CITIGROUP's head of project finance, the banks have vowed to cut off money to companies that break the rules, including independent studies for the most sensitive projects. The move follows environmental group criticism of banks for harming developing countries by funding destructive development projects. So far, only one Australian bank, Westpac, has signed on.[…] CITIGROUP and the other signatories provide about 30 per cent of the financing for the world's infrastructure projects and say they are prepared to withdraw money during construction if the rules are not followed. "We will not provide loans directly to projects where the borrower will not, or is unable to, comply with our environmental and social policies and processes," the principles say. Environmental groups have welcomed the agreement but are cautious about how it will work. "It is going to be really hard for a bank like CITIGROUP, which is really committed to make the Equator Principles work, when you have to question what these (other) banks' commitment is," Michelle Chan-Fishel, a program manager for Friends of the Earth, said. Among the first tests will be the $A4 billion Camisea natural gas project in Peru, which cuts through the Amazon rainforest. Friends of the Earth and other groups have asked CITIGROUP to withdraw its support for the two pipelines, wells and processing plant, which are slated to be built in a region with 198 species of bird per hectare, 118 varieties of fish and 152 plant species. The groups say equipment has fallen from helicopters into populated areas, drunk workers have entered isolated communities that had little previous outside contact and some indigenous women have resorted to prostitution. CITIGROUP points out that it helped the developers respond to the concerns by arranging meetings with local and international groups.[…]

title: Court won't rehear village's lawsuit over energy companies' CO2 emissions
news: A tiny Alaska village that says the nation's largest energy producers are subjecting it to coastal flooding via their greenhouse-gas emissions lost a legal battle last week, as a federal court said it would not rehear the village's arguments that the energy companies should pay to relocate the community to higher ground. The village of Kivalina, Alaska, had petitioned the San Francisco-based 9th Circuit Court of Appeals to rehear its case claiming that energy companies, such as ExxonMobil, Shell and American Electric Power, are subjecting it to flooding and other coastline damage through the their CO2 emissions. [...]

title: European utilities step up imports of U.S. coal as crude prices rise
news: Now that the price of coal is at a historic low relative to oil, there is no stopping consumers and producers alike from embracing Al Gore's nightmare. A ton of U.S. coal is so inexpensive, at about $47, that European utilities will pay $50 to ship it across the Atlantic, according to Galbraith's, a 263-year-old London shipbroker.[…] Proposed U.S. coal plants may not be completed because of regulatory and environmental opposition. Kansas regulators last month rejected a permit for a coal-fueled plant because its carbon emissions were deemed a health hazard. New cleaner-burning technologies for coal, including one that converts the fuel to a synthetic gas, have been delayed or rejected as too costly. Financing new coal plants may also become more difficult as environmental groups step up efforts against lenders including Citigroup and BANK OF AMERICA. Despite that, coal producers in the United States say sales in emerging markets are rising.[…]

title: Nigeria; Nigerians Constitute 90% of CHEVRON Nigeria's Workforce
news: CHEVRON Nigeria Limited (CNL) said Nigerians constituted about 90 per cent of its workforce. This revelation was made by the company's Government and Public Affairs Manager, Mr Deji Haastrup, during an official visit to THISDAY Corporate headquarters in Lagos.  Haastrup said CHEVRON was doing a lot in the area of community development, saying the oil giant spends more in community development in Nigeria than it does in other countries where it operates. […] In his words, " We have tended to be humble about our contribution to the community of the Niger-Delta area. For the fact that the area is a remote area people hardly know about our assistance to the environment. Bad news they say fly faster than good one as such people only hear about oil spillage and not about efforts we have been putting in place to develop the area". Haastrup said because of the environmental degradation of the Niger Delta, people hardly see the efforts the company has been putting in place in terms of development. He added that CHEVRON will continue to do its best despite the fact that many of the good things they have been doing in the area is not celebrated.

title: After spill, officials reopen Wissahickon for recreation
news: State officials yesterday announced they had reopened recreational uses on the Wissahickon Creek, which had been closed since a 6 13 discharge of a cyanide compound from the MERCK & Co. Inc. facility in West Point. The spill killed several hundred fish in a two-mile stretch downstream from the Upper Gwynedd wastewater-treatment plant, which receives MERCK's discharges. It also caused the Philadelphia Water Co. to close its Schuylkill water intakes, downstream from the Wissahickon, until officials determined there was no impact on the Schuylkill.A multi-agency investigation into the discharge is continuing. Even though conditions on the creek have returned to normal, the Department of Environmental Protection and Montgomery County health officials continue to advise caution. All urban streams are considered dangerous because they are not monitored by lifeguards and because of the possibility of submerged objects, strong currents and other hazards. Swimming is not permitted except during organized events.

title: Bottomless cup of protest
news: Protests against Starbucks never seem to go away. It's just the causes that change. A year ago, the coffee chain was besieged by demands that it pay more for its beans and stop serving products containing growth hormones or genetically modified foods. Today, Starbucks buys a million pounds of Fair Trade coffee a year -- at nearly three times the world price. It uses the toughest labelling requirements in the world for GM products. And it offers customers soy and organic milk as substitutes. […] There are two reasons why the protests against Starbucks are endless. First is its track record of giving in on nearly every demand. There is nothing more satisfying to a protester than forcing a company to capitulate, and Starbucks serves up capitulation like it does cappuccinos. Second, easy victories against Starbucks quickly become ammunition against other, bigger, targets. If Starbucks bans growth hormone milk, Kraft might be next. The Fair Trade coffee campaign is to springboard from Starbucks to PROCTER & GAMBLE. It's not just Starbucks that comes across as a dupe, guilelessly trying to purchase peace from protest. McDonald's dropped its polystyrene clamshell packaging in response to (meaningless) environmental objections[…]

title: Nigeria; 60 Oil Workers Held Hostage, Freed
news: MORE than 60 workers of US oil group EXXON-Mobil were taken hostage and later freed in Port Harcourt, Rivers State, officials said yesterday. The workers, who were mainly local employees and contract staff, had been held hostage since Monday by youths demanding jobs, money and amenities in Finima, near the oil city of Port Harcourt, the company said.[…] EXXON-Mobil is among the major oil companies operating in Nigeria, accounting for over 600,000 million barrels of the country's around two million daily output.[…] Meanwhile, President Olusegun Obasanjo has said that the oil companies operating in Nigeria must do more in the battle to control oil spills.[…]

title: $2m so we can cash in on cans
news: […] NT Environment Minister Territorians will be able to collect containers and receive refunds as usual[...] THE Territory Government is to pay to keep the cash-for-containers scheme afloat. It will pay the 10 deposits and a ``reasonable'' recycling depot handling fee for about eight weeks until national legislation makes the NT scheme legal. Environment Minister Peter Chandler said the subsidy would cost taxpayers an estimated $2 million. ``Territorians will be able to collect containers and receive refunds as usual,'' he said. The Government acted following a decision by Coca-Cola to pull out of the scheme despite knowing that it would be operational again as soon as the Territory was given exemption from the Mutual Recognition Act, the federal law that says products must be badged the same in all jurisdictions. Mr Chandler said there were fears other drinks companies would follow suit and the recycling system would collapse. He said Coca-Cola may now slash prices to try to prove that cash-for-cans was expensive and the Government risked being taken to court by recycling depots. […]

The oil escaped during a transfer of about 1.5 million gallons of oil from a barge, the Coast Guard said. The cause was under investigation. Coast Guard officials said CHEVRON assumed responsibility for the spill and contracted with two companies to help the cleanup. L.A. County transfers inmates after violence. […]

Findley, has embarked on a $1US.5 million waste water treatment plant at its compound in Paynesville. [...] In recent times, USTC has donated drugs to the John F. Kennedy Medical Center worth over $50US,000, education materials worth US25, 000 to 15 public schools, and has also donated $45US,000 in supporting HIV/AIDS sensitization and awareness campaigns in 25 communities including orphanages around Monrovia. The waste water treatment plant being constructed by the company followed concerns raised by a local environmental group, Action against Climate Change in Liberia that waste water from Coca-Cola factory was posing problem for the Welkarmah community.[...]

title: WEEKENDER: environment; Visayas does part in move to phase out CFCs
news: TACLOBAN CITY - The Environmental Management Bureau (EMB) in Eastern Visayas has started to conduct a survey of chillers among big industries and companies operating in the region as part of the National Chlorofluorocarbons Phaseout Plan (NCPP). Letecia R. Maceda, EMB regional director, said the Pollution Control Division conducted last week a survey on the use of ozone-depleting substances in building chillers. The survey sought details such as type and refrigerants used, cooling capacity, power consumption, operation and maintenance. "We also asked the respective company's chiller replacement plans in accordance with the national chlorofluorocarbons (CFC) phaseout plan as mandated by our central office," Ms. Maceda said, referring to the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR). Among the companies surveyed were McDonald's, Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines-Tacloban Plant, Robinsons Land Corp., Gaisano Tacloban, Gaisano Ormoc, Specialty Pulp Manufacturing, Inc. (Baybay City), Leyeco III, Jollibee, Hotel d' Angelo, Visayan Oil Mill and McMai Cebu Trading Corp. (Isabel). The objective of the NCPP is to completely phase out CFC consumption in an orderly and cost-effective manner without disruptions to important functions in the society and with minimized demand for illegal imports of CFCs. CFCs are chemicals identified as the main cause of ozone depletion in the earth's atmosphere. They can be used as refrigerants, air-conditioning coolant, aerosol propellants, cleaning solvents and in the manufacture of foam. [...]

title: JOURNALS
news: BUSINESS COLAS CAUGHT OUT. A REPORT by India's Centre for Science and Environment that found a ''cocktail of between three to five different pesticides'' in samples of PEPSI, Coca-Cola and their aerated water products had kicked up a minor political storm, Frontline reported. Though the Supreme Court had directed the companies to reveal their secret recipes for the first time in 120 years, it was powerless to rule on the issue. ''In India, the absence of notified standards has made regulation of the soft drink industry impossible.'' While Coca-Cola and PEPSI were useful ideologically charged targets, they were on the fringes of the pesticide debate. ''The bigger story is India's unregulated use of pesticides in general, and their seepage into fresh fruits, vegetables, foodgrains, tea, milk and meat. A standards regime makes sense only when it is uniform and universal ... Stringent standards should be complemented by a clearly thought out toxin management policy. The colas have been caught for now, but a longer shadow looms.'' RIGHTS CRACKDOWN ON DISSENT. ALTHOUGH Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak acquiesced in February 2005 to allow a contested presidential election, when international attention turned elsewhere he moved to crush Egypt's fledgling opposition, Jeffrey Azarva wrote in Middle East Quarterly. title: Environmentalist fury as Bush gives energy industry the green light
news: Warning of a "darker future" unless the United States aggressively drills for more oil and exploits fossil fuels to keep up with its galloping energy demands, President George Bush has unveiled his long-awaited energy plan. The plan, developed by Vice-President Dick Cheney and announced by Mr Bush on Thursday, provides $US10billion ($19billion) in tax credits for environmentally friendly measures like "hybrid" cars and solar panels on houses, but its emphasis is on increasing the supply of energy from fossil fuels.[…] Environmental groups reacted with fury, saying the conservation sweeteners were a smokescreen for a generous handout to the energy industry from a vice-president and president who both once worked in the oil business. Democrats dismissed the report, printed on glossy paper with pictures of bears in forests and happy fishermen, as "full of pretty coloured pictures". "It really looks like the EXXON MOBIL annual report," the Democratic House leader, Mr Dick Gephardt, said. "And maybe that's really what it is."[…] But environmentalists said the plan proved the Administration did not taking global warming seriously.[…]

title: Reply Letters and emails: Take alarmism out of climate debate
news: George Monbiot accuses me of attacking the Royal Society (Comment, September 26). Strange that, because I thought I was defending the society from the false claim that it was warning EXXONMobil to stop funding climate science deniers. Because my original letter (September 21) was abridged, the removal of a critical element led to an implication that the Royal Society smeared opponents and stifled legitimate debate. Instead, my target was journalists, like Monbiot, who berate and castigate "climate change deniers" as being funded by the oil industry and who are being smeared by associ-ation with tobacco companies. Monbiot writes that "climate deniers sponsored by EXXON and Philip Morris have dominated the (climate) debate" - a truly Orwellian claim. The truth is that the climate change lobby representing the "consensus" is extremely well endowed and has overwhelmed most opposition. Monbiot (and apparently elements within the Royal Society) know the truth about climate change and view anyone with different opinions as a dupe of industry. [...] Alan Kendall School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia

title: EXXONMOBIL agrees to clean refineries to end clean-air lawsuit from EPA
news: EXXON MOBIL Corp. agreed last week to spend more than $570 million to settle a government lawsuit alleging that it violated the Clean Air Act at seven of its petroleum refineries.[...] EPA accused EXXONMOBIL of violating the Clean Air Act's "prevention of significant deterioration" provision, part of much-debated New Source Review program. PSD requires firms to obtain permits and install the "best available" pollution-control technology when undertaking "major modifications" to their facilities. The government says EXXONMOBIL failed to do that at its refineries, allowing "significantly" more emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and other pollutants than they otherwise would have. The complaint also accused EXXONMOBIL of violating other environmental laws, including the Clean Water Act. All told, the government leveled 13 separate claims against EXXON MOBIL, which, according to the complaint, subjected it to civil penalties of up to $422,500 a day for every day it was in violation of the laws. [...]

title: PEPSI aims to cut plastic use with lighter bottles
news: PEPSICO Inc. is reducing the amount of plastic it uses in bottles of some non-soda drinks, in the latest move by beverage companies to appeal to consumers concerned about environmental waste and global warming. The new half-litre (16.9-oz.) bottle contains at least 20 per cent less plastic than the one it is replacing, and it will be used for some versions of Lipton iced tea, Tropicana juice drinks, a flavoured water called Aquafina FlavorSplash and an enhanced water known as Aquafina Alive, PEPSI said. […]  PEPSI, Coca-Cola Co., Nestlé SA and others have been shrinking the weight of polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, bottles in recent years as public criticism of plastic bottles has grown. Environmental activists say plastic bottles create waste and increase consumption of oil, the basic ingredient. Last year, Nestlé introduced a 12.5-gram half-litre bottle for its Poland Spring, Deer Park, Ozarka and other brands. Coke has "lightweighted" its Dasani bottle. The moves also help companies reduce costs as they grapple with increased prices of commodities.  Critics call moves to reduce the amount of plastic in beverage bottles welcome but not enough, as they don't address the problem that few plastic bottles are recycled, they say. […]  Gigi Kellett, national director of Think Outside the Bottle Campaign for Corporate Accountability International, an organization that urges consumers to drink tap water, said that while reducing plastic in bottles is welcome, "Less plastic doesn't increase the rate of recycling...and it does not reduce the energy use to recycle it." PEPSI and others oppose bottle- and can-deposit bills, which have boosted recycling rates in states where they have been passed. The companies say they are taking other steps, including promoting recycling programs and stepping up use of recycled material. PEPSI urges consumers to recycle with advertising on its PEPSI-Cola and Diet PEPSI aluminum cans. The company uses 10 per cent recycled material in its plastic soda bottles, and it is working on increasing that amount. Coke uses about 5 per cent recycled content in bottles of sodas, teas, water and other drinks. The company says it has invested in recycling programs and is building a plant to recycle bottles.

title: Gas gets green OK
news: CHEVRON Australia says it is closer to reaching a final investment decision on its proposed $25 billion Pilbara gas plant after the project received preliminary environmental approval. WA's Environment Protection Authority yesterday recommended the Wheatstone liquefied natural gas project go ahead, with conditions. The project includes a 25 million tonne per annum LNG plant, domestic gas facility and offshore infrastructure. It is expected to generate greenhouse emissions equivalent to 10 million tonnes of carbon dioxide a year. EPA chairman Paul Vogel said: ``The assessment of this proposal was complex as it involves impacts and risks to thousands of hectares of marine and terrestrial habitat.'' [...]

title: FRIEDLAND WINS COURT BATTLE: Ontario Court judge lifts freeze on US$152M of financier's assets, blasts U.S. Justice Department for 'a material misrepresentation of the facts'
news: An Ontario judge has lifted a court-ordered freeze on US$152 million of financier Robert Friedland's assets, dealing a stunning blow to efforts by the U.S. Justice Department to hold him to account for a toxic spill at a Colorado mine. Justice Robert Sharpe of Ontario Court, general division, ruled yesterday that evidence compiled against Friedland by the U.S government was at best incomplete and at worst distorted. […]  In reaching their decision, courts in Ontario and B.C. ignored the following evidence:  - Other parties may be liable for contributing as much as US$50 million to the cost of cleaning up Summitville. That includes the state of Colorado, which is obliged to put up 10% of the cleanup costs.  - BANK OF AMERICA, which played a key role in financing the operation, had to use its own consultants to approve the design of the mine.[…]  In addition, when Mangone was asked to provide an enforcement strategy with respect to Summitville, she determined that BANK OF AMERICA and U.S. engineering firm Bechtel Corp. were sufficiently capitalized to cover cleanup costs.[…]

title: ExxonMobil shuts Fawley UK refinery, petchem plant following fire
news: ExxonMobil has temporarily shut down the majority of its 300,000 b/d Fawley refinery in the UK after a fire struck a unit that manufactures steam on Wednesday (7 25) morning local time, the company said in a statement. "Following the incident the majority of both Esso Refinery and the ExxonMobil Chemical manufacturing sites have been temporarily shut down," it said. "We are conducting an assessment of the impact of the incident on product supply. However, currently there is no immediate impact on supplies available for our customers," ExxonMobil said [...] The fire broke out at 06:30 GMT and was extinguished at 07:40 GMT, the company said. The UK's Environment Agency and the Health and Safety Executive have been informed, the company said. "An investigation into the cause of the fire is being carried out, in full co-operation with the relevant authorities," it said. […]

title: Gas deal clinches PNG pipeline go-ahead / TROPICAL NORTH QUEENSLAND - A SPECIAL REPORT
news: Viability studies are imminent on a project of economic importance, writes  Stefanie Balogh BACKERS of the planned $3.7 billion Papua New Guinea-Queensland gas pipeline, which has now signed enough commitments to embark on its engineering viability study, claim that over the next decade it will provide the single biggest contribution to reducing Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. […] The State Government estimates Queensland will become the fastest-growing gas market in Australia, with a four-fold increase in consumption over the next 10 years. […] The project was effectively given the green light in mid-8 when it secured its critical foundation customer base after Ergon Energy signed a preliminary agreement with the operators of the pipeline, CHEVRON Services Australia Pty Ltd. […] The agreement enables CHEVRON to proceed with a $94 million engineering study of the project. […] The PNG Gas Project's director, John Powell, says the significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions will come because "gas-fuelled cogeneration plants deliver a 75 per cent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions compared to a coal-fired station of the same size". […]

title: Nigeria; Tales of Woes, Ruins, Destruction
news: Much of the landscape could qualify for Franz Fannon's description as the "Wretched of the Earth". Perhaps, no description could be more apt for this deprived enclave. Crops hardly yield there, a situation that has relegated farming to the background as a worthless enterprise. As a largely riverrine area, the inhabitants can hardly practice the pre-dominant occupation of fishing because the rivers are despoiled. The environment itself is no better. The cocktail of toxic substances, which has been emitted in the gas flares for over 40 years, including benzene and particulates, has exposed Niger Delta communities in Nigeria to health risks and property damage. "It is shameful and indefencible stain on the reputation of western oil companies. The appalling waste of greenhouse gases in one of the world's poorest countries is a violation of the human rights of those subjected to the flaring. It is astonishing that it continues on such a scale when Nigerian regulations have prohibited the practice in general since 1984". These were the words of Mr. Peter Roderick, coordinator of the Climate Justice Programme, when he came to Nigeria recently to support the coalition of Niger Delta communities, who have taken the legal recourse towards stopping gas flaring in the area. […] This age-long suffering and livelihood as endangered species has triggered a legal action from eight communities in the Niger Delta. The communities with the support of Environmental Rights Action/Friends of the Earth Nigeria (ERA/FoEN) filed a legal action last week at the Federal High Court, Benin City against Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC), TotalFinaElf Limited and Nigeria Oil Company Limited. Others are CHEVRON/TEXACO Nigeria Limited, Mobil Producing Nigeria Unlimited, Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) and the Attorney General of the Federation. […]

title: CHEVRON seeks source of Burrard Inlet leak
news: Traces of fuel and crude oil from decades of refinery operations on the shores of Burrard Inlet have been detected seeping into the ocean, and the refinery's owner has not determined the source of the contaminants. "It's an ongoing effort to pinpoint where it might be coming from, or has been coming from over time," said CHEV-RON spokesman Ray Lord, adding that the company has seen a gradual reduction in the volume of material since im-plementing containment measures last month. [...]CHEVRON notified regulators and politicians of the problem last month but did not make a public statement, although Mr. Lord said the company updated a community advisory panel on the situation last week. The amount of material involved is believed to be less than 50 litres. Public disclosure is required for spills of 100 litres or more. The company's muted response flies in the face of heightened public concern over the oil industry and the damage even small amounts of oil can do to marine ecosystems, said Christianne Wilhelmson, executive director of the Georgia Strait Alliance. "By calling this a seep, they're trying to minimize this," Ms. Wilhelmson said. "There seems to be no appreciation at all for the cumulative impact that this kind of pollution can have." [...]

title: Leader upbeat on Gorgon
news: [...] COLIN Barnett says he is confident Chevron's massive $50 billion Gorgon LNG project -- Australia's biggest single resources project -- will go ahead, despite outstanding approvals. As green groups yesterday threatened legal action against the project on the environmentally sensitive Barrow Island off the Pilbara coast, the West Australian Premier was unfazed.[...] Mr Barnett said approval from the state was ``not quite'' a rubber stamp, but it would happen and he also expected federal approval to be given.[...] World Wildlife Fund director Paul Gamblin said the approvals process had become a cynical exercise and created a worrying precedent. Legal advice was being sought after formal appeals against the assessment process were dismissed by Environment Minister Donna Faragher.[...] But Mr Barnett said the project met world's best practice environmental standards. He defended Ms Faragher's decision to water down conditions recommended by the Environmental Protection Authority, which would have required the proponents, Chevron, ExxonMobil and Shell, to slash artificial light to protect the turtle rookery.[...]

title: Biotech industry blooms in Bay Area
news: The San Francisco Bay Area is world-famous for the almost undistinguished stretch of land positioned at its southernmost point and nestled between two mountain ranges (and earthquake faults). If you are into computers, you know about Silicon Valley. However, the Bay Area is home to more than just computer and chip makers. It is also one of the leading regions in the growing field of biotechnology and genetic engineering. Genetic engineering has been in the news quite a bit lately, with the most recent attention focused on the trade battle forming between Europe and the United States concerning the sale of so-called genetically modified (GM) food.[…] The outspoken Mayor Brown is known for a certain amount of hyperbole, but nevertheless, Mission Bay could be an important development solidifying the Bay Area's leadership in biotechnology. Plans already call for UCSF to build a new research and teaching facility on the former 121.2 hectares railroad yard and industrial area. Brown and others then envision the surrounding area being developed as a biotechnology business park, capable of attracting the best talent from around the world. Several major European pharmaceutical companies have already expressed interest in locating in Mission Bay, and the BANK OF AMERICA recently donated 5 million dollars to UCSF for the development of its new campus at the site.[…] Notwithstanding all the excitement surrounding biotech, the technology does involve dangers and controversy. Recently, Cornell University scientists discovered an unintended side effect of a genetically modified corn that was originally designed to repel bugs but was also found to indirectly kill monarch butterflies in laboratory studies.[…] This kind of indirect cause and effect is very difficult to predict, and has led many critics to call for a slowdown or outright moratorium on most forms of genetic research. They cite claims that biological agents could potentially be more hazardous than chemical pollutants since biological systems are capable of reproducing and often migrating in some form.[…]

title: Foreigners to study depot
news: The country's "Big Three" oil companies are now looking at tapping foreign organizations for an independent evaluation of the Pandacan oil terminal's safety and pollution control measures. "[We are looking at firms] not just Asia, [but those with] global operations. Initially we are looking at 10, that's where we're starting off," Antonio V. Nebrida, CHEVRON Philippines, Inc. communications manager, said. [...]"We did a rundown - academe, several in government and also from the stakeholders on the ground [like] the local government. We're getting positive responses from quite a number, particularly from the academe and government," Mr. Nebrida said.[...]"We will recommend the list, then the selection, [but] the process for selecting the assessor is something that we would leave to the committee," Mr. Nebrida said. CHEVRON, Petron Corp. and Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp. announced in 6 the formation of a third-party risk assessor in the hopes of finally settling fears regarding the safety and pollution measures at the Pandacan oil depot. The oil companies have repeatedly stressed that the depot meets international and Philippine standards on safety and pollution controls.

title: Officials advise No vote; Proposed merger would hurt NRC, some ex-leaders say
news: Several former board members and past presidents of the National Recycling Coalition Inc. are urging NRC members to vote against the proposed merger with Keep America Beautiful Inc., scheduled for an electronic vote next month. "This proposed takeover will eliminate NRC as an independent voice for recycling" and leave recyclers with "just a limited advisory role in an organization that has historically failed to support the structural changes that are essential if progressive recycling policies are to be adopted in this country," said Clifford Case, former NRC president and founder of the Save the NRC Coalition in a letter sent 7 9 to acting NRC executive director Ed Skernolis and acting NRC board president Melinda Uerling. "This is precisely the wrong way to go."[…] One of the main objections the Save the NRC Coalition has to the merger is that the two groups have different agendas because their membership bases are different.[…] Pat Farrell Franklin, former NRC board member and retired executive director and founder of the Container Recycling Institute, agreed. "KAB, on the national level, is dominated by contributing commercial interests" such as Coca-Cola, PEPSICO, Anheuser-Busch. Nestle Waters North America and McDonald's, said Franklin, "most of whom are unwilling or unable to address the systemic changes needed to improve recycling. Their investments are designed to limit and control a necessary conversation for change.[…]

title: Oregon Nuclear Reactor Goes Gentle (Very) Into the Night
news: Entombed in concrete and six-inch-thick steel, the radioactive reactor of the largest American nuclear power plant ever to be shut down was loaded onto a barge today for a 270-mile river journey right through the heart of metropolitan Portland. It is the first time a commercial reactor of this size, and level of contamination, has passed through a major American city, said officials at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the agency overseeing the shutdown of the Trojan Nuclear Plant. The move worries environmentalists. Lloyd Marbet, who led three unsuccessful ballot initiatives to shut the plant down before a deteriorating steam generator ultimately forced the decision, said, "I'm not saying if the reactor falls off into the water, everybody would have to be evacuated from Portland, but it would not be good for the Columbia River to have a reactor vessel sitting in it." "The fact of the matter," Mr. Marbet said, "is that the interior of the vessel contains a very high level of radioactivity." Moving the Trojan reactor, which weighs 1,000 tons, is contentious because environmentalists had urged the power company, Portland General Electric, to mothball the entire site for at least 50 years and wait for the radioactive isotopes to cool before dismantling the plant. […]

title: Cash for cans' backlash
news: Three of Australia's largest beverage companies have put competitive rivalries aside to challenge the Northern Territory's "cash for cans" recycling scheme in the Federal Court. Coca-Cola Amatil, Schweppes and Lion Co are challenging the legal validity of the container deposit scheme, which was introduced last year and mirrors one operating in South Australia for years. They claim the scheme has pushed up the price of commercial beverages and has been an environmental failure, with two out of three containers sold in the Territory not being recycled, well below the national average and below recycling rates in 2010-11. […]

title: Nigeria; Bayelsa - Militants Kidnap Lebanese
news: Some militants yesterday in Sagbagria, Kologuma/Opokuma local Government Area of Bayelsa State, kidnapped an expatriate construction worker with Elite Construction Company. The hostage, who was taken to an unknown destination by the gunmen, is a Lebanese simply identified as Mr. David.  [...] When contacted, the Joint Task Force (JTF) through its spokesman Col. Rabe Abubakar confirmed the incident, saying that "it was the work of some criminal elements who are trying to portray the region as hostile and unsecured for human living and investment". [...] In a related development, the JTF has raised alarm over the heavy pollution occasioned by deliberate sabotage of CHEVRON crude oil pipeline between Opia and Tambolo community in Bayelsa State. Meanwhile, the coordinator, Joint media campaign of the JTF Col. Rabe Abubakar, said the spillage in these communities was the handiwork of illegal oil bunkerers. [...] He added that with this kind of damage to environment, these illegal bunkerers should be seen as enemies of the people that do not mean well for the emancipation of the locals in the Niger Delta. "The situation is worrisome, especially as it affects the source of livelihood of the communities around the sites and it further shows that the illegal oil bunkerers do not mean well for the emancipation of the locals in the Niger Delta region," he said. Abubakar further said that the contamination and pollution of water and soil which affect the survival of water animals and soil bareness are consequence of spillage into water and land. He urged all well meaning Nigerians to "condemn the negative activities of the illegal bunkerers instead of pointing accusing fingers on the oil companies who are here to boost our economy".

title: Pipeline spill exposes inspection flaws; Sophisticated detection tools 'have limitations,' report says
news: A month before a 1940s-era pipeline running through Mayflower, Ark., burst, it was inspected using a high-tech device that traversed its length, checking for defects. But on March 29, 2013, ExxonMobil's Pegasus pipeline spilled about 5,000 barrels - nearly 800,000 litres - of oil in a residential neighbourhood in the town of 2,300. As the Mayflower spill shows, the high-tech inspection devices are not perfect. [...]

title: Bush critic appointed top scientist at Defra
news: An outspoken critic of President George Bush's approach to combating global warming has been appointed to advise the British Government on climate change. Bob Watson was voted out of his job chairing the United Nations-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in 2002 after incurring the wrath of the Bush administration. He will take over as chief scientific adviser at the Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) in September.[...] Environmental groups uncovered a memo from the US oil corporation ExxonMobil, a major contributor to Mr Bush's election campaign, asking the White House to unseat Dr Watson.

title: Solutia forges two settlements
news: In an effort to shore up its proposed reorganization plan, bankrupt Solutia Inc. is seeking court approval of two key settlements. According to a settlement with Solutia's former parent, Monsanto Co. has agreed to take responsibility for the debtor's legacy tort liabilities and a substantial portion of its environmental liabilities. In return, Monsanto would receive 20% of common stock in the reorganized Solutia. […] Solutia, a St. Louis-based chemical maker, filed for Chapter 11 on Dec. 17, 2003, with assets of $2.85 billion and debts of $3.22 billion.Solutia was formed in 1997 when PFIZER Inc. subsidiary Pharmacia, once part of Monsanto, spun off most of its chemical businesses to shareholders as an independent entity. That spinoff left Solutia with hundreds of millions of dollars each year in liabilities for environmental cleanup, litigation and healthcare for former employees.

title: Huge gas plant gets qualified pass mark
news: CHEVRON Australia's Wheatstone proposal for a $25 billion gas plant on the Pilbara coast has been given conditional approval by Western Australia's Environment Protection Authority (EPA). The 25 million tonne- a-year liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant is proposed for a site near Onslow. EPA chairman Paul Vogel said the authority recommended the proposal could be implemented with stringent conditions to limit environmental impacts. It included one of Australia's largest marine dredging operations, involving 48 million cubic metres over three to four years, with impacts and risks to marine habitat, including coral reefs. The dredging program alone was equivalent to filling a football oval to the top of the goal posts more than 120 times. Greenhouse emissions equivalent to 10 million tonnes of carbon dioxide a year are expected at the new plant. The EPA's report to the WA Government will be subject to a two-week public appeal period, closing on 6 29.

title: Using biofuel in cars may speed loss of rainforest, watchdog says
news: Using biofuel in vehicles may be accelerating the destruction of rainforest and resulting in higher greenhouse gas emissions than burning pure petrol and diesel, a watchdog said yesterday. The Renewable Fuels Agency also warned that pump prices could rise in April because of the Government's policy of requiring fuel companies to add biofuel to petrol and diesel. [...] The agency's first annual report revealed that fuel companies had exploited a loophole to avoid reporting the origin of almost half the biofuel they supplied to filling stations last year. The origin of fuel from land recently cleared can be described as "unknown". [...] CHEVRON, Murco, Topaz and Grangemouth refinery had "failed to demonstrate the sustainability of their biofuels", the report said. ConocoPhillips was the only big oil company to meet the three voluntary targets the Government set the industry: for 30 per cent of the biofuel to meet a minimum environmental standard, for it to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40 per cent compared with fossil fuel and for the source of at least half the biofuel to be reported.[...] From March 2011 companies will be required under a European directive to report the previous use of all the land from which they derive their biofuels. However, they will also gain an additional loophole because they will not have to admit using rainforest land if the trees were removed before 2008.

title: Candlelight vigil held at incinerator
news: IT COULD have been an advertisement for cola - about 150 people standing in a circle holding candles. Someone had the bright idea of passing out paper Coke cups to shield the candle flames from the breeze.But Saturday night's gathering was a protest by campaigners outside an incinerator on Hanover Quay in Ringsend, Dublin. It was the end of a day in which 40 groups of campaigners opposing incinerators, dumps and industrial pollution around the country met to share information on their battles. Organised by Colaiste Foin - in Finglas, the conference in the Mansion House, called "150 Years On: Progression to a New Famine", heard submissions from both veteran and novice campaigners. "Today is about telling stories," said Ms Claire O'Grady Walshe of Greenpeace.The Tipperary farmer, Mr John Hanrahan, who took a case against the MERCK Sharpe and Dohme plant over emissions which affected his family and livestock in the 1980s, said that he was no longer seen as a crank. "We're now in 1995 and pollution has to be taken seriously.  I can see why there was reluctance with our case, because there was very little known about pollution."[…]

title: GE sought to derail anti-smog controls; Efforts at odds with conglomerate's environmentally friendly campaign
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC Co., which is running a marketing campaign promoting itself as environmentally friendly, has pushed to weaken tough anti-smog controls for train locomotives in rules about to be proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency. The rules, which could take effect between 2011 and 2017, are designed to cut smog and soot levels and would replace standards adopted in 1997. Since the rules would apply to new locomotives and could require changes on older ones, they would have a big effect on GE, which dominates the $2-billion-a-year (U.S.) locomotive market. While the nation's other locomotive maker and diesel-engine makers say they are prepared to meet the proposed new standard, GE argues it is "unlikely to be achieved" and has proposed a weaker one. [...]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
news: […] $5 Billion Valdez Penalty Voided A federal appeals court in San Francisco struck the $5.3 billion in punitive damages assessed for the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989, the worst in the nation's history. The court agreed with Exxon Mobil that the award was excessive, and it ordered a judge to reduce it. […]

title: Turtles to share WA island with $50 billion gas project
news: THE orange-bellied parrot may be enough to derail wind farm proposals, but it appears the endangered flatback turtles in Western Australia are no barrier to Gorgon's $50 billion liquefied natural gas project proceeding. WA's Environmental Protection Authority has given a highly conditional go-ahead to the project at the contentious Barrow Island site off the state's north-west coast. The CHEVRON Australia, Shell and ExxonMobil joint venture had to seek EPA approval after the proposal was expanded from the original two-train project to include a 35million tonnes a year LNG train. Barrow Island is a controversial site because it is also home to the flatback turtle, which has been classified as vulnerable to extinction in the area. EPA chairman Paul Vogel said the authority believed, as it did in 2003 when the project was first proposed, that industry should not be located on the island. But he said the proposal "could meet the EPA's objectives, provided stringent conditions are imposed". [...] Colin Beckett, CHEVRON Australia's general manager for Gorgon, welcomed the decision. He said the joint-venture partners would work with all levels of government. [...] "We have been operating an oilfield on Barrow Island since the 1960s ... and we maintain that it has been our stewardship of the island that has actually maintained (its) environmental values for over 40 years." [...] The environmental considerations would not slow Gorgon's schedule, he said. A final investment decision was expected later this year. WA Premier Colin Barnett said the Government would ensure the "highest environmental standards for the project are met".

title: Tale of two potential NYC Superfund sites
news: [...] In a curious twist, New York City has moved to support a Superfund designation at Newtown Creek, a city water body, while upholding its earlier opposition to a Superfund cleanup at the nearby Gowanus Canal. A Superfund cleanup of the creek could further involve majors ExxonMobil, BP and a Chevron entity. The three, and two other companies, are now engaged on a "work plan" for Newtown Creek. [...] Newtown Creek runs about 3.5 miles and straddles the New York City boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens. To the south lies the Gowanus Canal, a 1.5 mile body of water. Both Newtown and Gowanus were dumps for industrial waste for once gritty and industrial Brooklyn, which has since morphed into a borough for millionaires, and bohemians priced out of Manhattan.[...] The five companies began working together in 2007 on Newtown after New York state officials filed a notice of intent to sue, said Sam Ostrow, a spokesman for the five companies, who declined to "characterize" the nature of the potential suit. "The five companies met with the [New York] Attorney General's office and the [state Department of Environmental Conservation] and agreed to work collaboratively," Ostrow said December 28.[...]

title: Parties to MTBE settlement accountable for future contamination
news: The proposed $423 million settlement of lawsuits over the contamination of drinking water by MTBE by 13 oil companies will keep them responsible for wells contaminated by the oxygenate over the next 30 years. The lawsuits, filed by 153 water providers in 17 states, were consolidated in a single federal case. The settlement was submitted May 7 for review to the US District Court in the Southern District of New York.[...] The companies that did not settle are ExxonMobil, Crown Central, Giant, Total, Irving, and Lyondell, which manufacturers MTBE, according to Summy. ExxonMobil will continue to contest the about 85-90 MTBE contamination claims filed against it, said Perm Nair, a company spokeswoman.[...]

title: Hong Kong Power Regulations Based in Part on Emissions
news: Hong Kong's two electric power companies agreed on Monday to a new regulatory system that sets their rate of return on assets based partly on how much pollution they emit, an approach that could someday be a model for mainland China's giant power sector as well. [...] Western regulators increasingly impose complex environmental incentives and penalties on power companies. But regulators in mainland China and in Hong Kong, a former British colony, have tended to rely mainly on fines on companies that fail to meet basic regulatory standards. [...] Smog has become a chronic problem in the city. CLP and Hong Kong Electric, the two local power companies, have denied that they are the main sources of pollutants, while hinting that nearby factories and power plants on the mainland may be responsible instead. Exxon Mobil owns 60 percent of a power-generation joint venture, while CLP owns the rest and all of the distribution grid serving three quarters of Hong Kong's population.[...]

title: HP joins other tech companies going green(er)
news: SAN FRANCISCO -- Tech is gradually becoming greener, and some of its biggest companies are leading the environmental push.Hewlett-Packard today plans to announce that it is putting recycled plastic into the ink cartridges for its printers. Although ink cartridges are small, there are so many of them they can be a sizable environmental problem. […] Intel and IBM are also announcing new environmental programs. Such moves may help improve the tech industry's reputation for often causing harm to the Earth.[…] IBM this month launched the Eco-Patent Commons, a program to help inventors share environmental knowledge. Anyone who has patented a green process or product can contribute it to the commons. There, the patent is made available for anyone to use, for free. IBM contributed a patent for a green cleaning process used in electronics manufacturing and one for environmentally friendly packaging materials. Nokia, Sony and Pitney Bowes have also donated patents. Since companies usually guard patents, "It's a little counterintuitive," says IBM spokesman Mike Maloney. But it's a way to "team with other like-minded companies to see what we can do," he says.[…] Environmentalists applaud the moves but say much more needs to be done. "There needs to be a major paradigm shift, and right now we're just trimming around the edges," says Sheila Davis, head of the Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition, an advocacy group. Tech is still not very Earth-friendly, Davis says. Most computers and electronics contain dangerous heavy metals and un-recyclable plastic. Semiconductor manufacturing requires lots of water and dangerous chemicals. Computer data centers, which power most big websites, use massive amounts of electricity. And while tech firms are happy to put out green-themed press releases, they're often reluctant to release statistics about their environmental impact. HP won't say what percentage of its print cartridges will be made using the recycled plastic, for example. Companies "really need to look at their entire footprint," Davis says.

title: McGreevey, Focusing on Environment, Enlists in 'War on Sprawl'
news: […] Business groups have so far been wary of the new leadership in Trenton. Although they praised Mr. Campbell, the environmental commissioner, for encouraging debate on matters of enforcement, they are unhappy with some of his agency's more aggressive tactics, including the sweep in Camden and another incident, in which the drug company PFIZER was fined $538,000 after officials voluntarily reported an improper discharge of wastewater into a municipal sewer system. "There is a lot of apprehension out there," said Edward Hogan, an environmental lawyer who leads a business round-table group. "Early on, there was a feeling that Campbell had allied himself very closely with radical environmental groups, but at least he's listening."Mr. Campbell and his boss stand by their record so far, saying that the administration will work hard to streamline the state's environmental bureaucracy, but maintain an iron fist when it comes to rule-breakers. "Governor McGreevey has become the national leader in terms of aggressive environmental protection," he said. "After eight dismal years, I think we've restored the public's faith. They know that the environmental cop is back on the beat."[…]

title: Refund scheme not to beverage makers' taste
news: Beverage manufacturers have stepped up a campaign against a law that would force them to offer a 10Â¢ refund on almost every can and bottle sold in Australia. State and federal environment ministers will meet next week to consider the scheme. The Australian Food and Grocery Council, which represents beverage manufacturers such as Coca-Cola Amatil, Foster's and Lion Nathan, said a cash-for-cans-and-bottles scheme backed by environmental groups would cost society almost $700 million a year. [...]

title: Apple opens in-store product recycling programme; Apple is to offer free in-store gadget recyling facilities to encourage responsible recycling
news: Apple has launched a gadget recycling programme designed to help customers dispose of their old devices in a responsible way. iPhones, iPads, Macs and PCs can all be recycled through the programme, whether the device is in working condition or not. Customers will be able to recycle their old products through visiting one of Apple's 37 retail stores across the UK. The initiative also applies to stores across the world.  Apple's latest Environmental Report claims the company's data centres are powered by 100 per cent renewable energy, and claims to be the only company to do so. Today's iMac uses 0.9 watts of electricity in sleep mode - 97 per cent less than the first iMac introduced in 1998, and claims the cost to charge an iPhone 5s once a day in the US is 51 cents per year. The company also conducts factory audits and tests components within independent laboratories to hold suppliers accountable for creating cleaner, safer materials for their products. […] Greenpeace recently named Apple as the tech company leading the way towards a greener, more sustainable internet . The report concluded Apple was "the most innovative and most aggressive" in achieving the goal of 100 per cent renewable energy, and declared the company had "helped set a new bar for the industry".  Greenpeace had previously criticised Apple for using coal power for services such as iCloud and the voice-controlled "personal assistant", Siri, more than its rivals.

title: Is this in Florida's future
news: As a stiff wind from the Gulf of Mexico whipped his snowy beard sideways, Tony Amos stepped over the clumps of gooey tarballs dotting Mustang Island's beach. […] Over the past 40 years, companies like Halliburton have drilled about 10,000 wells across the western and central gulf. Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama were willing to overlook the trash and tarballs to reap a rich bounty of cash and jobs. But strong opposition from Florida's business and political leaders have kept the eastern gulf largely off-limits to drilling - until now. […] Meanwhile the U.S. Department of Commerce is weighing whether to allow CHEVRON USA to drill for natural gas 25 miles south of Pensacola. Florida officials have opposed CHEVRON every step of the way, and CHEVRON has sued the federal government over the delay in making a decision. Both developments have heightened concerns about the environmental impacts of drilling in the comparatively pristine waters of the eastern gulf. When people in Florida talk about the environmental effect of drilling, they usually mean they fear a massive oil spill will ruin the beaches, kill the wildlife and drive off the tourists. […] But the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency took the opposite stance two years ago, opposing CHEVRON's application to drill near Pensacola. […]

title: Bottled water awash in a sea of controversy; Environmental impact, source issues bubble up
news: Some of the same health-conscious consumers who helped make bottled water a $15 billion business now are among those worried about its environmental impact -- its 38 million plastic bottles a year made with 1.5 million barrels of oil.Questions also have been raised about the need for a relatively costly convenience product that in many cases is purified municipal tap water. Top-selling Aquafina recently was the latest brand to put that origin on its label, after prodding by consumer group Corporate Accountability. The PEPSICO brand saw a sales dip from the negative publicity and has replaced scheduled ads for the next few weeks with one about its seven-step purification process. "It's a tough time to be in bottled water," says Joseph  Doss, CEO of the International Bottled Water Association. "We're facing a great deal of controversy." Even some city governments are joining: Last month, San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom banned city buying of bottled water for its facilities. Last week, a Chicago councilman proposed a 10- to 25-cent tax on bottled water to help pay for a $40 million water and sewer fund deficit -- partly due to less tap water consumption.[…]

title: Shareholder messages coming in louder, stronger than ever
news: Well into this season of annual shareholder meetings, the dubious award for "a CEO's most difficult moment" must go to Jim Mulva, chief of ConocoPhillips in Houston. Thursday in front of shareholders, a widow surprised Mulva by presenting him a box she said contained the ashes of her husband, who worked at the company's oil and gas refinery until he died from esophageal cancer.[…] But other conflicts played out at annual meetings around the country. At COCA-COLA's annual meeting in Delaware, more than two dozen activists last week protested outside the Hotel du Pont about COKE's alleged complicity in union violence in Colombia and overuse of water in parched areas of India.In California, more than 100 people ranging from street theater performers to people in penguin suits protested last month outside of ChevronTexaco's annual meeting. They tried to press the company over pollution in the Ecuadorian rain forest allegedly caused by a former Texaco subsidiary.[…]

title: Investors Target Business Ethics: More Shareholder Proposals Address Social Responsibility
news: Socially responsible investors and activist groups are playing an increasingly significant role in the current proxy season.This year, they have filed more than 250 shareholder proposals regarding ethical business practices, an increase on last year's figures, said Suzanne Fallender, managing director of Institutional Shareholder Services' social investment research unit.[…]Another important environmental topic is corporate recycling. This year, socially responsible investors are also targeting computer companies."We have seen recycling proposals in the past. But this year, we are seeing more proposals targeting major computer companies. Their recycling policies should keep pace with old, used computers generated by technological advances," Fallender said. Some of the companies being targeted include Apple Computer Inc., Hewlett-Packard Co., Dell Computer Corp., Gateway Inc. and INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES Corp.Food and beverage companies are also under pressure to explain the efforts at recycling their product packaging.[…]

title: EXXONMobil to appeal $ 3.5 billion Alabama verdict
news: EXXONMobil Corp. plans to appeal a $ 3.5 billion verdict awarded in a case that alleged predecessor EXXON Corp. defrauded Alabama of royalties on production from 10 gas wells in state waters in Mobile Bay, company officials said. That judgment is six times the previous record for civil damages in that state. Jurors awarded Alabama $ 87.7 million in compensatory damages and $ 3.42 billion in punitive damages. The award approaches in scale the $ 5 billion in punitive damages awarded in 1994 by a federal jury to 34,000 fishermen and other Alaskans following the EXXON Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound in 1989.  EXXONMobil's appeal of that judgment is still pending.[…]

title: TRENDS   RAIN-FOREST CHIC   Maybe Ben & Jerry's and The Body Shop set themselves up   for a fall by appearing to have a monopoly on making an   honest buck. But their struggles are a lesson on how   little we know about the minefield of "ethical" marketing
news: […]  Baby boomers now seem less interested in sixties ideals of changing the world than "shopping for a better world"-the title of a popular "green" buying guide. But the inconvenient reality is that it's difficult for consumers to identify the "good guys" even with a scorecard. For instance, which companies are more "ethical" in dealing with the following two controversial issues:. GILLETTE Co. and PROCTER & GAMBLE Co., which spend millions of dollars on safety-testing of their products and have pioneered in research and development into alternative cosmetics, but perform government-required animal tests; or The Body Shop, which has stimulated a useful public debate but relies on tested-on-animals ingredients and has been attacked by former allies in the animal-rights movement for oversimplifying this complex issue for commercial gain.. Monsanto Co. and DuPont, which have innovative pollution-control practices, yet have been guilty of environmental violations; or Ben & Jerry's, which publishes an annual audit of its corporate conduct, but sometimes ignores its most important conclusions.[…]

title: Challenge to oil spill verdict
news: Houston OIL giant Exxon was seeking to overturn a $US5 billion ($A6.7 billion) civil judgment by an Alaskan jury over the grounding of the supertanker Exxon Valdez and the country's worst-ever oil spill, the company said yesterday. The company brief, challenging the verdict on 11 substantive legal issues, was filed in the US Circuit Court of Appeals Exxon says the punitive damages award of $A6.8 billion was excessive because it had spent $A4.7 billion in cleaning up Alaska's Prince William Sound. The Exxon Valdez tanker ran aground in March 1989, releasing nearly 38 million litres of oil into the ecologically sensitive waterway.

title: Natural gas to overtake coal as worldwide energy source by 2030: Exxon
news: Economic growth worldwide will drive demand for electricity powered by natural gas over the next 20 years, according to an annual outlook published by ExxonMobil on 1 27.[...] That demand will increasingly be met by burning natural gas, which is expected to overtake coal as the second-largest energy source behind oil, the outlook predicts.[...] As countries adopt policies to limit the increase of greenhouse gasses, natural gas will become the fuel of choice to meet that demand, the outlook predicts.[...]

title: Creepy-crawlies hold up Rio's expansion but probably not for long
news: The miner is set to appeal the EPA decision and can take heart from recent state decisions, writes Elizabeth Gosch. THIS week's decision to knock back Rio Tinto's $12.5 billion Pilbara expansion to save a tiny, blind scorpion-like creature has resurrected questions about balancing Western Australia's biggest-ever mining boom with environmental concerns in a region of great biodiversity. […] In December last year, the WA Government overruled the EPA's decision against CHEVRON's $15 billion Gorgon gas plant on Barrow Island -- an A-class nature reserve. The EPA rejected the proposal -- to extract, pipe, liquefy and export 10 million tonnes of natural gas per year from the Greater Gorgon and Jansz gas fields using facilities offshore and on Barrow Island -- on a number of grounds, including the impact on the island's rare flatback turtle. The environment minister at the time, Mark McGowan, approved the project with a list of environmental protection conditions. In 2003, the discovery of a rare, small, leafless shrub almost derailed Portman Ltd's Windarling Range iron ore project. The EPA said the project would adversely impact on the Tetratheca paynterae -- a spiny flowering bush that only grows on the cliffs and hills of the Windarling Range. […] Environmentalists also questioned an EPA decision that went the other way -- in favour of a controversial project. In September last year, the EPA recommended Woodside Energy's proposed Pluto gas processing plant should go ahead on the western side of Burrup Island -- a project the National Trust warned would result in the destruction of up to 100 rock engravings dating back thousands of years. And, as the head of the EPA himself has pointed out, the state Government makes the final decision and takes into account social and economical factors. […]

title: Kenya; How Kenya's Biological Wealth Was Taken Away
news: Scientists at Kenyatta University (KU) have been linked to an international deal leading to the extraction of biological wealth from lakes Bogoria and Nakuru in the early 1990s. Prof Wanjiru Mwatha, chair of Kenyatta University's Botany Department, is claimed to have been party to the research expedition that resulted in Genencor International Inc - a US-based biotechnology company - scooping samples of extremophiles from the two lakes and developing the industrial enzymes it has been selling for millions of dollars.[…] Conservationists say Genencor's action is contrary to the spirit of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), which KWS is banking on to get a share of the proceeds generated so far. Ratified by more than 180 countries since its declaration in 1992, the convention recognises the rights of countries to benefit from any commercialisation of their biological resources. But Genencor - which is based in California and has offices in New York and the Netherlands - has denied any wrongdoing. It has also denied that it has sold any such enzyme to its principal business partner - the US multi-billion-dollar giant, PROCTER & GAMBLE (P&G). It has also disputed claims that it contravened the CBD provisions.[…]

title: Oil giant CHEVRON in $11bn spill row
news: RIO DE JANEIRO: Prosecutors in Brazil have called for a shutdown of CHEVRON's activities nationwide and said the US oil giant should be fined $A11 billion for damage from an oil spill last month. Prosecutors took legal action against CHEVRON, its Brazilian unit and contractor Transocean over the spill at a production well at the Frade field, 370km off Rio de Janeiro state. They want federal judges to ``suspend all the activities of CHEVRON'', which would have to pay $277 million daily if it failed to comply.[...] Authorities had already suspended CHEVRON's drilling operations and denied it access to huge new offshore oil fields, which Brazil's national petroleum agency said had reserves that could surpass 100 billion barrels of high-quality recoverable oil. CHEVRON faces fines that could exceed $146 million from federal and Rio state authorities.[...]

title: NuCoastal "will talk with Samui people on drilling"
news: General manager John Griffith said yesterday the demonstration against petroleum exploration near Samui and Phangan islands had occurred only last week. The company has not considered yet what to do next to resolve this problem. However, it will definitely try to contact the local people to explain and communicate with them immediately so they will understand that its drilling technology is safe. NuCoastal held public hearings one or two times. It received both positive and negative feedback from residents. It has already completed the environmental impact assessment. [...] A conservation group in Samui last week demonstrated on the island against the granting by the Energy Ministry of four exploration concessions to CHEVRON Corp, Pearl Oil Amata, Salamander Energy and NuCoastal.[...]

title: EARTH WEEK DIARY OF THE PLANET
news: […] Marine Noise Warning: The International Whaling Commission (IWC) says it wants the oil and gas industry to find ways to reduce the impact on marine mammals by seismic air guns, which are used across entire oceans to search for oil. The IWC statement says loud noises that the devices produce have been found to damage hearing and migratory patterns of marine mammals, and are also responsible for reduced fish catches. A statement later issued by ExxonMobil Corp claimed the company was unaware that the use of seismic guns had adverse effects on marine wildlife. […]

title: Top of the drops! Keep Britain Tidy lists the most-dumped brands
news: Litter louts are most likely to dump Coca-Cola cans, Cadbury wrappers and Walkers crisp packets, a survey has revealed. The branded packaging was found strewn across parks, beaches and river or canal banks during a national litter-picking exercise. Volunteers scooped up more than 37,000 pieces of rubbish in the latest Keep Britain Tidy campaign - more than 10 times the quantity picked up in previous years, according to the charity.[…] Phil Barton, chief executive at Keep Britain Tidy, said: "These results should be a wake-up call that we all need to do more to love where we live. "Litter is not just an environmental problem. It affects perceptions of safety and costs Government nearly £1 billion a year to clean up." He added: "This survey provides us with a snapshot of what people have littered in communities across the country. "It also gives 37,000 reasons why we all need to do more to make littering socially unacceptable - to reduce the environmental, social and financial costs of this national problem."[…] More than 500 volunteers enlisted for this year's litter count, which was previously carried out by Keep Britain Tidy staff.[…] The brands dumped most frequently were: 1. Coca-Cola. 2. Cadbury. […] 10. PEPSI

title: US WATCH
news: Research biologist Brenda Ballachy reports sea otter population of Prince William Sound in Alaska has recovered from Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989 (S)

title: Mount Franklin in deep water over Landcare logo
news: AUSTRALIA'S oldest and largest environmental organisation faces mutiny in its ranks after its pledge to plant a tree for every bottle of water sold was branded a clear-cut case of greenwash. A senior official who works under the umbrella of Landcare Australia has blasted the company for allowing Coca-Cola Amatil to use its logo on a marketing campaign for its water brand, Mount Franklin. Coca-Cola pays Landcare Australia $150,000 to plant 250,000 trees to offset greenhouse gas emissions generated by making and distributing 8 million plastic bottles. But Nanette Lamrock, based in the northern NSW region around Armidale, yesterday said the tie-up gave Coca-Cola full power to "almost rape the environment", only for Landcare volunteers "to put it back together". [...]She said other volunteers had expressed unease at companies using the Landcare logo, but whose operations damaged the environment. [...]

title: Oil firm forks over for spill Valley Stream district to get 419G
news: AN UNDERGROUND oil spill in 1992 created cramped quarters for students in Valley Stream District 30, who were moved around as a precaution to avoid potentially dangerous classrooms. But the recent settlement of the long-running lawsuit between the school and ExxonMobil will give students and staff even more room to move. […]

title: Test results fail to silence DISNEY fireworks critics
news: Unconvinced by Disney's latest fireworks test results, environmentalists and a councillor have renewed their calls to suspend the theme park's daily display when there is high air pollution.  Test results completed on 8 3, 4, 7 and 8 indicated no breach of environmental standards in noise and air-pollution levels in Discovery Bay and Peng Chau.  The average 24-hour level of respirable suspended particles was 20 to 33 micrograms per cubic metre, compared with the ambient-air-quality target of 180 micrograms, while the noise was between 43.7 and 53 decibels, also lower than the legal limit of 55 decibels.  The results were submitted to the Environmental Protection Department and Advisory Council on the Environment yesterday.  But the department and DISNEY agreed that only the data from 8 8, when the loudest noise was recorded, would be presented.[…]  Mei Ng Fong Siu-mei, director of Friends of the Earth and an advisory council member, said the latest tests still failed to show conclusively that fireworks did not pose a health risk for nearby residents.  She criticised DISNEY for arbitrarily choosing the detailed air and noise data obtained on 8 8 to submit to the council and failing to take into account a worst-case scenario in which the fireworks plume would be blown directly from the theme park to Discovery Bay. "The data is still inconclusive while there are doubts and hidden problems," she said.[…]

title: Browse decision delayed
news:
Environment Minister Bill Marmion has thrown a spanner in the expected environmental approval of Woodside Petroleum's Browse LNG project by delaying a decision from the environment watchdog that was to be released today. Mr Marmion announced late yesterday that he was seeking legal advice on whether Environmental Protection Authority chairman Paul Vogel should be allowed to take a solo vote on the $40 billion development, given public disquiet this week over the matter.[...] This proposal is extremely complex and I want to ensure due process has been followed at all levels, he said.
[...] Greens MLA Robin Chapple attacked the EPA's processes. He said EPA board member Chris Whitaker had first declared a conflict of interest in the Browse development on October 1, 2009 because he and his wife owned Woodside shares. [...] Woodside and its partners do not expect to make a final investment decision until the first half of next year, assuming the project is viable. The partners, including CHEVRON, Shell, BP, BHP Billiton and Mitsui-Mitsubishi, are receiving tenders for both onshore and offshore components. [...]

title: India rules Coke and PEPSI are safe; Pesticide residues found in some samples tested, but not at the high levels alleged by NGO report
news: NEW DELHI - The Indian government has declared that the soft drinks made by Coca Cola and PEPSI are safe after their samples, tested in state-owned laboratories, did not contain high levels of pesticide residues as alleged by a non-governmental organisation here. Samples of 12 brands of the soft drinks were tested at the Central Food Technological Research Institute in Bangalore in the southern state of Karnataka and at the Central Food Laboratory in Calcutta in the eastern state of West Bengal. The tests followed allegations by the New Delhi-based Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) two weeks ago that the soft drinks contained pesticide residues that were 30 to 45 times higher than the safe limits prescribed by the European Union.  Federal Health Minister Sushma Swaraj told Parliament on Thursday: 'The test results clearly show that all the 12 samples do not have pesticide residues of the high order as was alleged in the CSE report.[…] The CSE report sparked countrywide protests and a ban on the sale of the soft drinks in government offices, schools and college campuses. Members of the Indian Parliament were the first to banish Coca Cola and PEPSI from their canteens.[…]

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at the superfund; Deep Within Superfund Bill Are Goodies for Montana
news: As if banished to a legislative limbo, bills to extend the toxic waste law known as the Superfund have languished in three successive Congresses. If Republican leaders have any hope of rescuing the latest version, they can scarcely afford to alienate Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the ranking Democrat on the committee considering the bill. […] "We completely overlook the intrinsic value of a remote mountain wilderness," he objected, "and the same would be true of a damaged river or a seacoast." A damaged river like the Hudson, for instance, in a situation that recently led Gov. George E. Pataki to signal New York State's intention to sue General Electric for natural resource damages from a company plant that leaked toxic PCB's into the river, closing it to fishing. Or a seacoast like California's, where DDT and other toxic chemicals were dumped by several companies near Palos Verdes, which has set off another prospective battle between the state and the polluter. Potential damages in both of those cases, and in others, would be limited by several provisions of the Senate bill. "What it does is severely hamper the state's effort to repair the Hudson," John Cahill, Commissioner of the New York Department of Environment and Conservation, said in a telephone interview today. "What this proposed legislation would do is place the burden squarely on the back of the New York State taxpayer to pay for the restoration." […]

title: The Selling of an Energy Policy
news: Under the presidency of George W. Bush, the environmental and energy policies of our government are completely dominated by a group of current and former oil and chemical company executives who are trying to dismantle America's ability to force them to reduce the extremely dangerous levels of pollution in the earth's atmosphere. The first step was to withdraw from the agreement reached in Kyoto to begin limiting worldwide emissions of greenhouse gases. Then the administration cancelled an agreement requiring automobile companies to make the leap to more fuel-efficient vehicles. Other acts of sabotage are taking place behind the scenes.
