Just as Enron executives were allowed to interview candidates for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission -- and to veto those they didn't think would approve of Enron's agenda -- EXXONMobil has been allowed to veto the United States government's selection of who will head the prestigious scientific panel that monitors global warming. Dr. Robert Watson, the highly respected leader of the Inter-Governmental Panel on Climate Change, was blackballed in a memo to the White House from the nation's largest oil company. The memo had its effect last Friday, when Dr. Watson lost his bid for re-election after the administration threw its weight behind the "let's drag our feet" candidate, Dr. Rajendra Pachauri of New Delhi, who is known for his virulent anti-American statements. Why is this happening? Because the largest polluters know their only hope for escaping restrictions lies in promoting confusion about global warming. Just as Enron needed auditors who wouldn't blow the whistle when the company lied about the magnitude of its future liabilities, the administration needs scientific reviews that won't sound the alarm on the destruction of the earth's climate balance.[…]

title: From TVs to cellphones, we're throwing it all away: Repairs are passe - it's easier to buy new, but the rejects, full of recyclable parts and toxic chemicals, are piling up as e-waste
news: […] Rapid advances in technology have led to a dramatic increase in our reliance on electronic products - and to shorter lifespans for everything from televisions, CD players and fax machines to cellphones. All that stuff is piling up like never before. It even has a new name:e-waste. Environment Canada estimates more than 158,000 tonnes of broken or outdated computers, cellphones, televisions, stereos and small home appliances accumulate in Canadian landfills each year.[…] These electronic devices contain materials like lead, mercury, cadmium, beryllium and PVC plastics that cause significant environmental and health risks when they end up in landfills. They also contain valuable materials that can be recycled, among them aluminum and copper. But there are relatively few recycling facilities in Canada, so very little is recovered. Growing piles of e-waste have rung alarm bells around the globe. Europeans, light years ahead of North Americans in recycling, have a number of e-waste recycling programs.[…] Manufacturers are beginning to get involved in what's known as an electronic product's "end of life." Hewlett-Packard and IBM, for instance, will take back old components for recycling. And Dell Canada recently announced a new computer recycling program that allows customers to hand in their old computer monitors or printers for recycling or donating to charity.[…]

title: Nigeria hits Shell with $5 billion fine on Bonga oil spill
news: Lagos--Nigeria has imposed a $5 billion fine on Shell as a penalty for an oil leak at its Bonga deepwater oil field in December last year, though Shell responded by saying the move had no legal merit as the leak had had no impact on the environment. [...] Nigerian media described the offshore spill as the worst in a decade since ExxonMobil's Idoho spill when more than 40,000 barrels spilled into the Gulf of Guinea after a leak in the pipeline linking the Idoho platform to ExxonMobil's Qua Iboe export terminal in 1 1998. [...]

title: DIGITAL PHONE ERA DAWNS IN PINELANDS TO CLEAR THE WAY, OFFICIALS WILL ALLOW SIX MORE TOWERS AND 63 ANTENNAS. SOME ENVIRONMENTALISTS OBJECT.
news: Digital phone service soon will be available throughout the forests of South Jersey's 1.1-million-acre Pinelands preserve.The Pinelands Commission voted unanimously Friday to allow six towers to be built and 63 antennas placed in Camden, Burlington, Gloucester, Cumberland, Ocean and Atlantic Counties.According to the plan, Sprint PCS, Omnipoint and AT&T are among the companies that plan to use the towers for their customers.[…] The antennas will provide users of digital phones with service throughout the Pinelands, Eisenstein said. Commission members were concerned that pristine areas of the Pinelands would be marred by the presence of the six new 200- to 300-foot towers. Last year, the Pinelands Commission approved the construction of 17 similar towers for cellular service. Seven of those will also be used for digital service.[…] He said that nowhere in the public record had digital communication companies made a scientific case for the number of towers needed at the locations planned. "There's no proof that there would be gaps in service with fewer towers," Montgomery said. "And they want to put these things up in scenic places, like near the pygmy pine forests." He and other environmentalists also doubt the towers will ever come down, because once digital-phone technology changes and towers are no longer needed, they fear cable companies and wireless Internet services will need them.[…]

title: Business pushes for clarity at Bali 'As global companies, we're not standing in your way, we are expecting you to take your responsibility and come to an agreement'
news: With climate talks teetering on the brink of failure, an influential group of business leaders is among those pushing for a deal at the Bali conference. The business community is as divided as the politicians on whether to forge an ambitious set of mandatory targets for cutting greenhouse-gas emissions.[...]  Exxon Mobil Corp. The world's largest oil company has resisted calls to release a comprehensive tally of its emis-sions, or a plan to reduce them. [...]  BP In 1998, the British energy company achieved a 10-per-cent reduction from 1990 levels in greenhouse gas emissions, and has targeted to keep overall emissions at or below 2001 levels. It was a pioneer in emissions trading markets.

title: Companies go proactive, prep for carbon taxes
news: At least 150 major companies worldwide -- including ExxonMobil, Google, Microsoft and 26 others in the United States -- are already making business plans that assume they will be taxed on their carbon pollution, a report out Monday says. The U.S. has yet to impose a price on heat-trapping carbon dioxide emissions, but other nations are starting to do so as a way to address global warming, so U.S.-based companies are factoring an eventual one into their plans, says the international non-profit CDP, formerly known as the Carbon Disclosure Project. The report is the group's first one to look at corporate carbon pricing on a global scale. [...]

title: Who Cooked The Planet?
news: Never say that the gods lack a sense of humor. I bet they're still chuckling on Olympus over the decision to make the first half of 2010 -- the year in which all hope of action to limit climate change died -- the hottest such stretch on record.[...] If you want to understand opposition to climate action, follow the money. [...] Look at the scientists who question the consensus on climate change; look at the organizations pushing fake scandals; look at the think tanks claiming that any effort to limit emissions would cripple the economy. Again and again, you'll find that they're on the receiving end of a pipeline of funding that starts with big energy companies, like Exxon Mobil, which has spent tens of millions of dollars promoting climate-change denial, or Koch Industries, which has been sponsoring anti-environmental organizations for two decades.[...]

title: Kimberley plan to test Greens alliance
news: WOODSIDE'S controversial $30 billion proposed gas hub at James Price Point on Western Australia's Kimberley Coast will be the first real test of the partnership between the Greens and the minority Labor government, the businessman Geoff Cousins, who is campaigning against the project, says. [...] The Aboriginal law man Joseph Roe has lodged a native title claim over the land and is suing the land council in the Federal Court.[...] The new federal environment minister, Tony Burke, has final say over the James Price Point project, which requires approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. The site is part of a strategic assessment of heritage values as a precursor to possible inclusion on the national heritage list. A number of environmental groups held initial briefings with Mr Burke this week and it is understood the James Price Point development was a key issue. An Australian Conservation Foundation campaigner, Denise Boyd, said the group asked Mr Burke to commence the West Kimberley heritage listing within 30 days, raised the issue of compulsory acquisition and asked for consideration of alternatives such as offshore processing or a pipeline to an existing plant at Karratha. Mr Cousins, a Telstra director who was formerly Optus Vision chief executive, ran a high-profile campaign against the forestry company Gunns's proposed $2.2 billion pulp mill at Bell Bay, in the Tamar Valley in Tasmania. Siding with Mr Roe, he said he predicted there would be a similar Gunns-style campaign targeting Woodside and its shareholders and joint venture partners including Shell, CHEVRON, BHP and BP if a political resolution could not be found.

title: A colour controversy; Battle against artificial food dyes rages on
news: […] Some companies, bowing to consumer pressure to be green, are switching a smattering of products to natural colours, usually derived from spices or plants. Loblaw's announced in 2012 that it would remove artificial colours and flavours from its President's Choice line, and by the end of 2013 had reformulated 150 products, says Kevin Groh, Loblaw's vice-president of corporate affairs and communication.[…] In the European Union, products containing artificial food colours must carry the warning "may have an adverse effect on activity and attention in children." Rather than carry such a label, some manufacturers have switched to natural food colours for products sold in Europe, while selling the synthetic-dyed products here. This isn't the first time Europe took the anti-additive lead. Brominated vegetable oil - the chemical recently dropped from Coca-Cola's and PEPSI's sports drinks after a teen's petition - is not approved for soft drinks in Europe. And azodicarbonamide, the "yoga mat chemical" that Subway ditched from its bread this winter after a food blogger's crusade, is banned in Europe. "North American consumers are left to wonder why they deserve less protection than Europeans enjoy," says Toronto environmentalist Rick Smith, co-author of Toxin Toxout. "People are focused on elevating standards," adds Smith, executive director of the Broadbent Institute. "The call here is: 'Dear company, can you please take a look at this chemical.' And 'Dear government, can you please do your job properly.' "[…]

title: Left to pick up the pieces
news: [...] While the plastic in our waterways accumulates, however, our leaders dither. State and federal governments have completed a three-year consultation process to devise a national anti-litter policy. Ten models were considered, including a government-funded campaign, a voluntary industry scheme, a flat fee on all packaging manufacturers, and a container deposit scheme (such as the popular 10 cent system in South Australia). In April, all state and federal environment ministers met to consider the options, but they deferred a decision. Five months later, there has been no progress. The final policy recommendations have not yet been made public. [...] The industry favours a voluntary scheme administered through the Australian Packaging Covenant, which is signed by more than 900 businesses. It has consistently campaigned against container deposit schemes. In early 2013, legal action by Coca-Cola Amatil put a temporary halt to the Northern Territory's cash-for-containers program. [...]

title: Pesticides in sodas rekindle Indian ire
news: HIGHLIGHT: Coke and Pepsi face bans and government takes heat following a study last week. After investing more than $1 billion in India over the past decade, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have found themselves once again in the center of a debate over pesticide residues in their products and corporate responsibility to protect customers. Surveying Coke and Pepsi products from around the country, the Center for Science and Environment found pesticide residues in the products of the two soda giants - which together dominate more than 90 percent of the growing Indian soda market. The report, coming three years after CSE's first study found pesticide traces, shines light on India's weak food-safety laws, and threatens the profitability of two of India's biggest foreign investors. […]

title: Montana: Assessing Damage From Spill
news: Almost four days after an Exxon Mobil pipeline broke and spilled some 42,000 gallons of crude oil into the Yellowstone River, government officials and wildlife advocates struggled Tuesday to evaluate what the impact to water, birds and fish would be. Some 350 emergency personnel are working to ease the effects of the spill -- absorbing pooled oil and conducting aerial flights to spot oiled birds and other damage. [...] Amy Cilimburg, an organizer with the conservation group Montana Audubon, confirmed that few oiled birds had been spotted and said that the group was concerned about contaminants' entering the food chain in the long term.[...]

title: Warming fears do not add up
news: [...] A FRIENDLY word of advice this Christmas: relax and enjoy it. Don't feel guilty about taking home your Christmas turkey in a plastic shopping bag or turning on the lights on the Christmas tree. They aren't acts of environmental vandalism, or likely to accelerate global warming.[...]There are too many of examples of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change trying to suppress dissenting voices, and it isn't the only one. Recently, Britain's Royal Society wrote to EXXON MOBIL demanding that it cease funding for groups that ''misrepresented'' the science of climate change by denying the evidence.[...]

title: Scientists Say a Quest for Clean Energy Must Begin Now
news: Meeting the world's rising energy needs without increasing global warming will require a research effort as ambitious as the Apollo project to put a man on the moon, a diverse group of scientists and engineers is reporting today.[…]  Without prompt action, the atmosphere's concentration of greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels, is expected to double from pre-industrial levels by the end of this century, the scientists said. […] The researchers, a team of 18 scientists from an array of academic, federal, and private research centers, said many options should be explored because some were bound to fail and success, somewhere, was essential.[…] As they now exist, most energy technologies, the scientists said, "have severe deficiencies." Solar panels, new nuclear power options, windmills, filters for fossil fuel emissions and other options are either inadequate or require vastly more research and development than is currently planned in the United States or elsewhere, they said. The assessment contrasts with an analysis of climate-friendly energy options made last year by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, an international panel of experts that works under United Nations auspices. That analysis concluded that existing technologies, diligently applied, would solve much of the problem. One author of the new analysis, Dr. Haroon S. Kheshgi, is a chemical engineer for EXXON MOBIL, whose primary focus remains oil, which along with coal generates most of the carbon dioxide accumulating in the air from human activities.Still, Dr. Kheshgi said on Thursday that "climate change is a serious risk" requiring a shift away from fossil fuels. "You need a quantum jump in technology," he said. "What we're talking about here is a 50- to 100-year time scale." Dr. Martin I. Hoffert, the lead author and a New York University physics professor, said he was convinced the technological hurdles could be overcome, but worried that the public and elected officials may not see the urgency. […] "Techno-fixes are pipe dreams in many cases," said Kert Davies, research director for Greenpeace, which has been conducting a broad campaign against EXXON MOBIL. "The real solution," he said, "is cutting the use of fossil fuels by any means necessary."

title: Greens pump up EXXON-Mobil focus
news: Green protesters have widened their world-wide boycott campaign against EXXON-Mobil. Although analysts said retail sales showed no sign of suffering, they warned some damage longer term might occur to the oil giant's famous brand, Reuters reports. In New Zealand, Mobil public affairs manager Anna Schulze, said yesterday there had been a few protesters in Auckland, and three protesters outside Mobil's offices in Wellington. EXXON-Mobil has drawn the wrath of an international alliance of green groups, politicians, and celebrities since it backed Washington's decision in April to withdraw from the global treaty on climate change, the Kyoto protocol. The boycott notched up a gear yesterday when non-profit group Pressurepoint said it was co-ordinating an international day of action which involved 100 protests in 17 countries. In London, protesters leafleted staff at EXXON-Mobil's offices and activists said banners were unfurled over buildings and motorway bridges in Britain and Germany. Greenpeace said that the British 'Stop Esso' boycott had spread to Norway and Finland, and was beginning to establish itself in Germany and the Netherlands.[…]

title: Barrow Island turtle issue overblown: study
news: The Gorgon gas partners said yesterday new research suggested the number of endangered Pilbara flatback turtles nesting on Barrow Island, the preferred site of an $11 billion gas development, was about half previous estimates. A Gorgon spokesman said early results of an ongoing three-year study by consultant environmental scientist Kellie Pendoley suggested about 12-15 per cent of the Pilbara flatback population nested on the island, in contrast with earlier estimates that up to a third of them relied on the A-Class nature reserve as a breeding ground. In 6, the Environmental Protection Authority cited the potential threat to the turtles as a key reason for its opposition to construction of the massive liquefied natural gas venture on the island. Gorgon's spokesman said Dr Pendoley's report had been forwarded to State environmental appeals convenor Garry Middle, who is considering the Gorgon partners' appeal against the EPA's decision. […] Gorgon partners CHEVRON, Shell and ExxonMobil argue that building the gas plant elsewhere would add at least $1 billion to the cost, believed to be facing a potential $4 billion-plus blowout. […]

title: Margin Pressures Force More Consolidation
news: THE SHELL-EXXON plan to combine their lubricant additives businesses (CW, 7 17, p. 9) is the latest consolidation by producers seeking to cut costs, boost efficiencies, and increase market share. Analysts say that in an industry hobbled by tight margins, short product cycles, and intense competition, consolidation is the key to staying in business. Five producers -- Lubrizol, Exxon's Paramins division, Ethyl, CHEVRONs Oronite unit, and Shell's petroleum additives business, -- account for more than 80% of the $ 6-billion/year lubricant additives market (chart), and the number of producers will shrink, analysts say. […] ROUGHED UP. […] The bane of the industry is environmental regulation, which has raised performance requirements higher and faster than ever before. Emissions requirements and Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) requirements set by EPA and the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration have necessitated redesigns in engines and transmissions. That has led m changes in lube additives formulations and manufacturing techniques. […] DON'T STRAY[…]

title: The battle of the blue box  Question the merits of curbside recycling and you risk the combined wrath of environmentalists, politicians, waste managers, packagers and homeowners. Why is the act of placing junk in a box so fraught with emotion?
news: […] WHEN John Styth Pemberton, an Atlanta, Georgia, pharmacist, invented Coca-Cola in 1886, it was a fountain soda sold at the counter. Soon, along with countless other brands, the product was sold in bottles. It then became a two-tiered business: Brand owners distributed their heavily marked-up, proprietary flavoured syrups across the United States; smaller independent bottlers blended the syrups with sweetener and carbonated water and trucked the pop to local stores. The bottling business was high-volume, low-margin. To keep their material costs down, bottlers used refillable glass bottles and charged small deposits on them to make sure they were returned. That changed in the 1970s and '80s when the soft-drink industry shifted to steel cans and throwaway plastic bottles. These were convenient for consumers but, more importantly, they allowed soft-drink giants such as Coke and Pepsi to vastly increase their market share. Not having to rely on local bottling plants meant they could flood whole regions of North America with their products though massive one-way warehouse distribution systems. Their increased market clout -- made possible by the new packaging and economies of scale -- allowed them to push competing mom-and-pop local brands out of the market. Today, there are hundreds of soft drinks, iced teas, fizzy juices and isotonic sports drinks, but most are owned by a handful of huge companies. Bottle deposits went the way of the dinosaur. The companies got into trouble when the convenient throwaways became litter at the same time that the modern environmental movement started. Soon, states and provinces introduced "bottle bill" legislation to force deposits on soft drink containers. The common "return for deposit where applicable" stamp was born. Today, 11 American states and every Canadian province and territory except Ontario and Manitoba require deposits on pop containers. Activists love them because they divert very high volumes of containers from landfill to recycling (often more than 90 per cent). The bottle goes back to the store, and the store sends it for recycling. But soft-drink companies and retailers hate deposit-return schemes since these complicate their otherwise efficient one-way distribution systems. […] Faced with the threat of deposits and an increasingly environmentally sensitive public, the soft-drink industry, its packaging suppliers and the grocers got together and devised a solution. They renamed their throwaway containers "recyclable" and formed associations to fund municipal curbside recycling programs. Activists had promoted residential recycling for years, but programs usually failed due to lack of markets for the scrap material. The pop companies had an ingenious idea: They agreed to switch from steel to aluminum cans so that revenue from this high-value metal would offset losses from the other junk. The so-called "basket of goods" approach was born in which the declining value of some recycled commodities is balanced out by the rising value of others.[…] So what's the problem? Activist groups such as John Jackson's Citizen's Action Committee on Waste and Gordon Perks' Toronto Environmental Alliance argue that the rate that garbage is recycled has stalled at less than 50 per cent, even in the best-run curbside programs. They'd prefer to see pop containers (and wine and liquor bottles) placed on deposit to get more of them back.[…]

title: Greens 'lost' as growth prevails
news: It may be reaching a bit, but when one of the world's leading climate alarmists and activists -British author and journalist George Monbiot -declares that he and his environment movement colleagues "are lost" in a world that still believes in what many environmentalists do not believe, namely growth and prosperity, it is almost certain that global warming is in decline as a political issue. In a column this week in The Guardian, Mr. Monbiot laments the failure of green activists to reach beyond a "set of deep beliefs ... that in some cases remain unexamined." Mostly, he said, the battle over energy supplies and carbon emissions has plunged the environmental movement into choosing objectives that "are at odds" with one another.  Green predictions of collapse have not materialized as the global carbon-based economic expansion continues. "The problem we face," he said, "is not that we have too little fossil fuel, but too much." As conventional oil declines, economies will switch to tar sands, shale gas and coal. If coal runs out, other fossil fuels will take its place. Because the greens can't get their political and ideological acts together into a world economic view that makes sense, Mr. Monbiot sees the world heading for "environmental destruction." Mr. Monbiot's defeatism in the face of economic and technological reality represents just one aspect of what appears to be a giant shift in the political and economic environment around climate change. Another portent: Jeff Immelt, the CEO of global industrial giant GENERAL ELECTRIC, publicly recalibrated GE's approach to climate issues and government intervention to control carbon emissions. In comments reported this week by Reuters, Mr. Immelt -an outspoken climate-change activist and advisor to President Barack Obama -said: "If I had one thing to do over again, I would not have talked so much about green." […]

title: Quebec producers eye big opportunity; Retail giant invites natural-foods firms to participate in 'green fair' in Montreal
news: Francois Deragon sees the future of organic food on the shelves of the world's largest retailer. As deputy director of a medium-sized dairy processor in Drummondville, Deragon already sells organic milk to large retailers across Quebec. So when Wal-Mart Canada Inc. approached the company - Laiterie Lamothe et Freres Ltee - about selling its organic milk at stores across Quebec, Deragon was intrigued. […] "We realized that people across the country - but especially in Quebec - are concerned about the future of the planet." News of the green fair was met with skepticism by critics who allege Wal-Mart's efforts are tantamount to "green-washing." Some advocates of organic farming question how the retailer's pursuit of low prices could be compatible with an industry that puts environmental considerations before the bottom line. "I don't expect a lot of producers will be interested," said Frederic Pare, co-ordinator of agriculture and food programs for Equiterre, a non-profit group that supports fair-trade and organic farming. "We don't want to allege bad faith on the part of Wal-Mart, but we'll have to see how serious this effort is. "It would be up to Wal-Mart to demonstrate its good faith." After reporting sluggish sales since last fall - and a spate of bad publicity over the retailer's treatment of workers on both sides of the border - Wal-Mart is working to revamp its image. […]

title: Rezoning just another plan for money
news: Editor: The proposed rezoning of 40 acres next to the new Wal-Mart Supercenter at U.S. 19 and Osowaw Boulevard appears to be another attempt by the landowner to fill his pockets with money. Also, to further destroy the local environment and create more hazards with a proposed strip mall or big-box store next to the giant that opened Wednesday. […] As members of the Hernando County Democratic Executive Committee for more than two years, we were appalled when we read Dom Cabriele's approach to push through a half-cent sales tax. When contacted, numerous members of the Hernando County Democratic Executive Committee who are members of two years or longer, no one can recall ever having the Hernando County Fine Arts Council's Nimmagadda Center discussed in any detail, or remember ever having a vote in favor of a tax increase to help raise the necessary dollars needed to proceed with this project. […]

title: Drink container levy to be examined again
news: Federal and state governments have ordered further study into a national deposit levy for cans and containers, in a blow to attempts by the drinks industry to kill the plan. The beverage industry says consumers would pay for a container deposit levy (CDL) scheme through higher drink prices and that an expanded kerb-side recycling program would be a more efficient way to lift recycling rates. But environment groups welcomed the decision to order a new study into the issue, arguing the analysis should demonstrate the environmental and economic benefits of imposing a 10Â¢ levy on bottles, cans and cartons. [...] A CDL is opposed by the country's biggest drink makers, such as Coca-Cola Amatil, Foster's Group and Lion Nathan, which say customers would wear the cost through higher drink prices. [...]

title: Gas developers' plan to save world a load of hot air; ANALYSIS
news: DURING the Vietnam War the apocryphal order, "we have to burn the village to save it", became shorthand for the flawed thinking of commanders.The Environment Minister, Peter Garrett, might well contemplate this after yesterday giving his conditional approval to clear the way for the unique nature reserve on Barrow Island to become a massive processing hub for the Gorgon gas project. In Canberra, the justification for sacrificing Barrow, a refuge for animals rare or extinct elsewhere, is that the developers, CHEVRON, ExxonMobil and Shell, want to help save the planet. [...]Gorgon was cheered on by WA's politicians even though the state's Environmental Protection Authority emphatically opposed it. WWF and other environment groups pleaded for the processing hub to be moved to the mainland. But the Howard government and then federal Environment Minister, Malcolm Turnbull, endorsed the original proposal.[...]Garrett's limited intervention yesterday was largely to call for better monitoring of the fragile wildlife on the island.But there are doubts that the companies' climate-friendly plan to bury its greenhouse gases under Barrow will be successful. An expert panel found that some leakage of carbon dioxide is possible. And even if the plan meets expectations, it will still only reduce the project's overall emissions by 40 per cent. It's estimated 5.45 million tonnes of carbon pollution will still be released by the Gorgon project each year helping to make WA one of the most carbon intensive states in the world.

title: Sakhalin Energy saves whales, cuts CEO adrift
news: It was a case of save the whales but lose the CEO on the island of Sakhalin off the far-east coast of Russia last month. Sakhalin Energy, a multi-billion dollar oil and gas project whose majority shareholder is Shell, is rethinking plans to build an offshore pipeline in the Piltun-Astokhskoye field "to ensure minimal disturbance to the western grey whale". Environmental NGOs are concerned that the Sakhalin projects, both those of Sakhalin Energy and of a consortium led by EXXON-MOBIL, will disturb the endangered species: scientists believe there are fewer than 100 individuals extant. title: We've seen the oil spewing ... where's the public outcry?
news: [...] Yet almost two months after BP's Macondo well erupted, the oil continues to gush into the Gulf of Mexico and there seems to be little sense of genuine crisis. In spite of its wildly optimistic statements about the ability to stop the leak that has created the worst oil spill in American history, BP continues to make fortunes. [...] Compare this to two far less severe environmental events, where widespread public concern, mixed with a healthy dose of rage, made corporate giants buckle and triggered sweeping changes. The first was the 1969 oil spill off the California coast, near Santa Barbara. A drilling rig operated by Union Oil of California (later Unocal, now part of CHEVRON) botched a well. About 100,000 barrels of oil escaped over 10 days, creating a slick that blackened beaches in the Santa Barbara Channel. The images, broadcast on a relatively new inven-tion - colour TV - greatly upset Americans, as did the pictures in the same year of Ohio's effluent- and chemical-laden Cuyahoga River in flames. They demanded environmental protection legislation and President Richard Nixon respond-ed. In came the National Environmental Policy Act, followed by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Clean Air Act.[...] Given the damage caused by the blowout of the BP well, whose relief wells will not be finished before 8, it's remarkable that the anti-BP and anti-deepwater drilling protests have not been widespread, energetic and angry. Forty-one years ago, a relatively minor spill ushered in the great American environmental movement. Fifteen years ago, a boycott forced one of the world's mightiest oil companies into a humiliating U-turn.[...]

title: Water stewardship better than footprinting: NGOs
news: [...] Just as companies begin to catch on to the idea of water footprinting (ENDS Report 411, pp19-20), two NGOs have recommended a different approach. Sustain and the Food Ethics Council (FEC) have published a report suggesting water stewardship labels akin to those for timber and fish would be better than footprinting.1 The impact of water abstraction depends on location and timing. This makes footprinting difficult and expensive, especially for products with multiple ingredients, says the report. The results may also confuse consumers. A single footprint gives no indication of how efficiently something is being produced; this can only be discovered by comparing several similar products, says the report. Methods for measuring and reporting footprints are not consistent and do not take into account alternative uses to which the same water could be put. [...] A few high-profile firms including SAB Miller, Coca-Cola and Nestle have long been advocates of footprinting. They were joined last year by Marks and Spencer (ENDS Report 404, pp24-25). [...]

title: Pollution: The wasteland: how years of secret chemical dumping left a toxic legacy: Explainer: What are PCBs?
news: Polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, are stable man-made organic compounds. That was their value to industry and in the past few decades that has been the problem. They were used from the 1920s as cooling and insulating fluids for transformers and capacitors because they did not burn easily, but eventually it was discovered that they also did not easily biodegrade. Although most were banned in 1986, they linger on in detectable levels in animals, fish and humans. When they are incinerated, they can produce dioxins, which are some of the most toxic substances known to science. The biggest manufacturer of PCBs was Monsanto, which marketed them as Aroclor from 1930 to 1977. GENERAL ELECTRIC had a rival product called Pyranol. They were used in an enormous number of products, from lubricants to pesticides, paper, adhesives, plastics, paint and flame retardants. But the concerns began when high levels of PCBs were found in fish, particularly in the great lakes of north America. Work in the 1970s and 1980s established that the man-made chemicals dumped as waste in Lake Michigan were accumulating not just in the fatty sport fish caught there but in the breast milk of nursing mothers who had eaten them. Their children showed higher rates of development and learning disorders than those of local women who had not eaten the fish. […]

title: A radioactive peril that's 'worse than a meltdown'; More people and land at risk of exposure when spent fuel rods burn
news: FULL TEXT Even as workers raced to prevent the radioactive cores of the damaged nuclear reactors in Japan from melting down, concerns were growing that nearby pools holding spent fuel rods could pose an even greater danger. The pools, which sit on the top level of the reactor buildings and keep spent fuel submerged in water, had lost their cooling systems, and plant operators have been unable to take emergency steps because of the multiplying crises. By late Tuesday, the water meant to cool spent fuel rods in the No. 4 reactor was boiling, Japan's nuclear watchdog said. If the water evaporates and the rods run dry, they could overheat and catch fire, potentially spreading radioactive materials in dangerous clouds.  Shigekatsu Oomukai, a spokesperson for the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency, said the substantial capacity of the pool meant that the water in it was unlikely to evaporate soon. But he said workers were having difficulty reaching the pool to cool it. Temperatures appeared to be rising in the spent fuel pools at two other reactors at the plant, No. 5 and No. 6, said Yukio Edano, the chief cabinet secretary. Meanwhile, workers continued to pump seawater into the No. 1 and No. 3 reactors, where cooling systems remained unusable. The pools are a concern at the stricken reactors because at least two of the three have lost their roofs in explosions, exposing the spent fuel pools to the atmosphere. By contrast, reactors have strong containment vessels that stand a better chance of bottling up radiation from a meltdown of the fuel in the reactor core. Nuclear experts said that if spent fuel rods in such a pool were to catch fire, the high heat would loft the radiation in clouds that would spread the radioactivity. ''It's worse than a meltdown,'' said David A. Lochbaum, a nuclear engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists who worked as an instructor on the kinds of GENERAL ELECTRIC reactors used in Japan. ''The reactor is inside thick walls, and the spent fuel of Reactors 1 and 3 is out in the open.'' […]

title: How healthy is our city?
news: James Woodford on the 10 biggest environmental issues facing Sydney. They are Sydney moments: catching a bus to Bronte Beach at the end of a hot day and body surfing until it is nearly dark, then washing off the salt under the outside freshwater showers. Or, perhaps, watching dawn over the rock platform at Long Reef.[…] The four million tonnes of waste produced by Sydney's residents largely consists of the discards from the ridiculous amounts of packaging that products are wrapped in. Billions of plastic bags are handed out every year by the major supermarket companies - destined, at best, for landfill and, at worst, the innards of a sea creature. The single biggest water user in Sydney is BlueScope Steel, formerly BHP Steel. However, it is not just the big dirty factories that guzzle water. Office buildings swallow immense quantities as do leagues clubs, soft drink companies (COCA-COLA Australia uses one billion litres of water every year) and almost every other industry in the Sydney Basin. There is an immense amount of waste - it is especially worrying that clean drinking water is used in factories and to provide air-conditioning to skyscrapers. Developers also need to take much greater responsibility for the types of houses they build, ensuring that new homes consume a minimum of energy and water and do not destroy the habitat of wildlife.[…]

title: GAS WARNING IN BROOKLYN

title: Greenpeace challenges deepwater oil licences
news: THE safety of deepwater drilling near the Shetland Islands, where BP, Total and CHEVRON operate, will be challenged in a landmark court case brought against the British Government. The environmental group wants a moratorium on all new deepwater licences. Greenpeace will argue that the Government is failing to carry out "appropriate assessment" of the risks that new drilling may pose, after the US accident that caused an environmental disaster and killed 11 men in April. It will refer to disaster plans by companies currently drilling in UK deep waters that show an oil spill in the North Sea could be even worse than the Gulf of Mexico disaster. CHEVRON believes that, in a worst-case scenario, a North Sea well could release 77,000 barrels a day - 25pc more than gushed into US waters this year. The US oil giant has also admitted in its official documents that oil from a spill near the Shetland Islands could theoretically reach Greenland and the Norfolk coast line. Greenpeace's challenge may halt new licences being granted and potentially mean that permission for new deepwater licences granted since April could be withdrawn. title: So, what misery does your pension pay for?

title: Climate Camp in London: What's not to like?
news: Their tie-dye T-shirts and festival hats may be no match for Otis Ferry's tweeds, but the youthful environmentalists who have set up a Climate Camp in Greenwich Park are giving other campaign groups a lesson in non-violent protest. [...] But what of their claims to represent the scientific consensus?As my Telegraph colleague James Delingpole explained so forcefully on Any Questions over the weekend, not all scientists believe in man-made global warming. But 90 per cent of those whose job it is to study the earth and its climate do. Like James, I studied a wishy-washy humanity at university. Like James, I've never conducted my own global warming research. On fiendishly complicated scientific issues like this, we ignorant laymen face a choice: either accept the opinions of 90 per cent of the scientific community; or throw our hat in with the remaining 10 per cent, some bloggers, the founder of Weather Channel and the board of ExxonMobil. Challenging received wisdom is undoubtedly tremendous fun. And climate change scepticism remains a surefire way of driving web traffic, given the strength of hostility to the theory in the US's vibrant Right-wing blogland. But when it comes an issue as important as the future of the planet, shouldn't we put our devastatingly amusing contrarianism aside and listen to the hippy with the PhD in Greenwich Park who, y'know, has actually studied this stuff?

National Oil Spill Detection and Response Agency (NOSDRA) on Monday confirmed the oil spill and said it had com-menced an investigation into the incident. Communities near the oil facility operated by the oil company have recorded four oil spills in the past six months. The spills occurred on Dec. 4, 2009, March 24, May 1, and 6 21.[...] It attributed the situation to a pipeline damage at the Qua Iboe Oil Fields offshore Akwa Ibom shoreline. MPN, an affiliate of US oil firm ExxonMobil, said that the force majeure it declared on its Qua Iboe crude streams on May 12 was yet to be lifted.[...]The May 1 spill sparked off a protest by Mobil's host communities, which compelled the state government to convene a mediatory meeting to resolve the conflict between the oil firm and its neighbouring communities. [...]

title: Safety of Alaskan oil line 'in question', report finds
news: Michael Sean Gillard, Melissa Jones and Andrew Rowell. The safety of the ageing Alaskan oil pipeline owned mainly by BP Amoco is 'in question", an internal report has found. The report, presented this week to the US congress and government regulators, is a response to and confirmation of many allegations made by six Alyeska whistleblowers which the Guardian investigated and published last 7. The whistleblowers had written to BP Amoco chief executive SirJohn Browne warning of an 'imminent threat" to human life and the environment from irresponsible oil operations in Alaska - the scene 10 years ago of the Exxon Valdez catastrophe. […]

title: Drink makers accused of recycle profiteering
news: THE country's largest beer and soft drink makers have been accused of profiteering from recycling schemes. A report by more than 20 conservation groups was sent to the ACCC last week and accuses Coca-Cola Amatil, Schweppes and Lion Nathan of overcharging for the cost of the schemes. It claims price increases of drinks such as Coke and PEPSI, as well as beers including some Tooheys brands, were double the actual costs of the schemes to the companies.  Federal independent Senator Nick Xenophon said the ACCC needed to investigate.[…]

title: A winning pitch for changing times
news: It is brave enough to open a retail store in this frigid economic climate - doubly so if you are Wal-Mart opening its new Supercentre store in urban Vancouver. […] And Mr. Cheesewright is not shy in touting what he sees as Wal-Mart's main environmental virtue: If consumers make one trip to a mega-store, rather than several trips to many small stores, they ease the burden on the planet, particularly if that giant store is at the end of an ultraefficient supply chain. Big, in his view, is not just better - it's greener. (He does concede that there is a "general suspicion of big.") That argument makes sense, to a certain point, although it is hard to believe that it will sway any hard-core opponents. Much more likely is that it gives consumers who do a modest amount of shopping at Wal-Mart the moral green light to spend even more there, says John Williams of retail consultancy J.C. Williams Group. "They convince you that you're doing the right thing." But if you want to know why anti-Wal-Mart feelings may have eased in Vancouver, and elsewhere, look no further than the logo appended to the new Vancouver store: "Save money. Live better." It's amazing how a downward-spiralling economy can make saving money - and creating a few hundred jobs - a winning pitch. Numbers-wise, those new jobs won't do much to offset surging layoffs in British Columbia. But the launch of a new store in Vancouver does provide a counterweight to the mass of bad news sweeping the province: stalled or abandoned condominium projects, intensifying forestry layoffs and a withering construction sector. In that environment, the lure of saving money is likely to dissolve any snob factor that kept consumers out of Wal-Mart. "This is the right store for the times," Mr. Williams says. "Consumers are cranky ... they are insecure." […]

title: Race to save wildlife zones after crude oil spill
news: DALLAS - Crews worked yesterday to protect two sensitive wildlife areas after a crude oil spill shut down parts of a major southeast Texas port, state Land Commissioner Jerry Patterson said. Plastic walls known as booms and oil-sucking skimmer boats were used to safeguard a lake that is a crucial breeding ground and a wildlife management area that lost its protective gates when Hurricane Ike roared ashore a year and a half ago, Patterson said. The United States Coast Guard said about 1.75 million litres - or 11,000 barrels - of oil spilled into the water on Sunday when a 245m Malaysian-flagged tanker headed for an Exxon Mobil Corp refinery in Beaumont collided with a towing vessel pushing two barges near Port Arthur, about 145km east of Houston. It was the largest spill in Texas since 1994, but still well shy of one 20 years ago involving Norwegian tanker Mega Borg that leaked 16.28 million litres of crude oil about 95km off Galveston. The crew of the damaged tanker, the Eagle Otome, said the remaining 69,000 of the 80,000 barrels of oil in the ship were pumped out, according to the Coast Guard.

title: Soft-drink giants accused over pesticides: COKE and Pepsi residues posed health risk, say Indian MPs
news: COCA-COLA and PepsiCo sold soft drinks containing pesticides harmful to human health and misled India's 1 billion people over claims that their products were safe for human consumption, Indian MPs concluded yesterday. Their report recommended stringent new regulations for fizzy drinks which would "seek complete freedom from pesticide residues (in) aerated beverages".  An estimated seven bottles of cold drinks are sold to every Indian each year in a market worth £900m. COCA-COLA and PepsiCo account for more than 80% of the market, The row between soft drink makers and campaigners erupted last summer when a Delhi-based environmental group, the Centre for Science and Environment (CSE), claimed that COCA-COLA and PepsiCo products manufactured in India contained toxins far above the norms permitted in the developed world. Tests by campaigners showed Pepsi's soft drinks had 36 times the level of pesticide residues permitted under EU regulations and COCA-COLA's had 30 times the level.[…]  The cross-party committee has been convened only three times before, and experts say it is inconceivable that India's government would not act on its findings. Evidence to the committee suggested that even the toughest safety requirements would cost companies less than half a penny for each bottle sold. COCA-COLA and PepsiCo have contested the claims, even wheeling out the Bollywood stars Amir Khan and Shah Rukh Khan last year to reassure consumers.[…]  The two US companies were also attacked over the running of two bottling plants in the southern Indian state of Kerala. MPs said COCA-COLA's and Pepsi's operations had resulted in pollution of water, depletion of ground water, reduced yield in crops, skin disorders and other ailments.[…]

title: Total warns against drilling for offshore oil in Arctic over fears of damaging environment
news: TOTAL SAYS energy companies should not drill for crude in Arctic waters, marking the first time an oil major has publicly spoken out against offshore oil exploration in the region. Christophe de Margerie, Total's chief executive, said the risk of an oil spill in such an environmentally sensitive area was simply too high. [...] ExxonMobil, Eni of Italy and Norway s Statoil have all signed deals to explore for oil in Russia's Arctic waters, while others have secured licences to drill off Greenland. [...] His comments were welcomed by environmental groups that are opposed to Big Oil's presence in what they see as a near-pristine wilderness. The rest of the oil industry should heed his warning, said Ben Ayliffe, head of Greenpeace's Arctic campaign. [...]

title: Oil giant gave £1 million to fund climate sceptics; ExxonMobil broke its pledge to halt payments Esso's owner gave £1m to global warming sceptics
news: One of the world's largest oil companies has broken its pledge to stop funding groups that promote scepticism about man-made climate change. ExxonMobil, parent company of Esso, gave almost £1 million last year to organisations that campaign against controls on greenhouse gas emissions. Several made outspoken attacks on climate scientists at the University of East Anglia and argued their leaked e-mails showed that the dangers of global warming had been grossly exaggerated.  The scientists were exonerated this month by an independent inquiry but groups funded by Exxon have continued to lambast them. The Media Research Centre, which received $50,000 last year from Exxon, called the inquiry a "whitewash" and condemned "climate alarmists". Some of Exxon's largest donations were to groups that lobbied against a global deal on emissions being reached at the climate summit last December in Copenhagen. Exxon could see the value of its oil and gas investments fall sharply if governments adopt aggressive plans to reduce their dependence on fossil fuels.[...]

title: Paradise stained
news: An oil spill is threatening an obscure but environmentally sensitive coastline in Angola. The slick is coming ashore near the oil-rich enclave of Futila, killing large quantities of fish and other wildlife. Local reports say the spill also threatens Mandarin near the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo. A spokesman of the Cabinda Gulf Oil Co., a subsidiary of CHEVRON, says the spill is being cleaned up.

title: Animal magic casts its spell on a divided nation
news: LAST week Americans mourned the death of Bobo, a tiger shot dead by police when it escaped from an animal sanctuary in Loxahatchee, Florida, run by a former Tarzan actor, Steve Sipek.[…]  Indeed, National Geographic magazine estimates that there may be more pet tigers in America today than remain in the wild in Asia. Big cats have become fashion accessories. "It's an ego thing," said Ron Asvestas, who tends 90 abandoned big cats in his Wild Animal Orphanage in San Antonio, Texas. "It's great to be able to walk down the street with a tiger cub on a leash."  You can blame this state of affairs, perhaps, on Walt Disney, whose anthropomorphised cartoon characters launched a worldwide love affair with animals. Since Mickey Mouse arrived on the screen in 1928, Disney's animal characters with human personalities have spawned a global media empire.[…]

title: LOO'S WHO; BITTER RIVALS ON A ROLL TO PERFORATE POUNDS 11BN MARKET
news: YOU only miss it when it runs out. Then, stranded helplessly on the loo, you wonder how anyone ever survived without a roll of toilet paper to hand.Bog roll is the third-biggest-selling household commodity, with sales exceeding pounds 11billion worldwide. The average home uses 159 rolls and we get through nearly 1.5 billion - more than 200,000 tonnes of paper - a year.[…] Even worse for Andrex, their tissue has been ranked bottom in an environmental survey by WWF that assessed recycling and the impact on the world's forests. The charity says the equivalent of 270,000 trees are flushed away every day. But even the most bog- standard toilet paper has only been around for 50 years. Before then we had to grin and bear it with shiny, hard paper - while the less-well-off redeployed their daily newspaper. […] In 2000 Andrex was accused of being behind a dirty-tricks campaign designed to discredit rival PROCTER & GAMBLE with a story that claimed its new toilet paper could block drains.[…]

title: Going, Going, Trying to Go Green
news: DUPONT this week announced a ''sustainability'' initiative, making it the latest big company to jump on the green bandwagon. […] DuPont's ''2015 Sustainability Goals'' (introduced via a Webcast linked at gristmill.grist.org) include plans to derive $6 billion or more in new revenue from products that create energy efficiency or reduce harmful emissions, as well as those made from ''nondepletable'' resources. Last year, General Electric introduced its ''ecoimagination'' program (ge.ecomagination.com), which puts money and research behind energy efficient and ''environmentally advanced'' products. Wal-Mart, Ford and BP have all announced similar programs in recent years. While some environmental activists tend to label such initiatives as mere ''greenwashing'' -- that is, more public relations than anything else -- many mainstream environment watchers praise them as at least a step in the right direction. Still, given that such companies are industrial conglomerates that create huge amounts of waste and burn huge amounts of fossil fuels, they will probably never totally remake their image. […]

title: Greenies rubbish razor packaging
news: A razor encased in plastic, cardboard and paper has been named as the worst offender for environmentally damaging packaging by Victoria's peak environment body.  The Gillette Fusion razor, made by PROCTER and Gamble, won Environment Victoria's Golden Dump award for its "gratuitous use of packaging", and the award for Excessive Use of Material. The annual Dump (Dangerous and Useless Materials in Packaging) Awards expose the seven worst types of environmentally damaging packaging being sold on supermarket shelves.Environment Victoria said the award judges found the razor's packaging demonstrated the unsustainable trend for encasing goods in far more packaging than required to protect, transport and market them. The Likely to be Littered Award went to the Heinz Little Kids Mini Meals, due to the multiple types of plastic they contain, including a plastic eating utensil.[…] The main winners are: * Golden Dump Award: Gillette Fusion razor (PROCTER and Gamble). * Excessive Use of Material: Gillette Fusion razor (PROCTER and Gamble) * Poorly Designed for Recycling: Equal Cafe Sticks 60g (Merisant Manufacturing Australia). * Going Backwards: Woolworths Apple Snacks (Woolworths Australia). * Judges' Special Mention: Nescafe Short Black (Nescafe).

title: In New Orleans courts, the legal gusher BP cannot contain
news: After a blowout at its Macondo exploration well killed 11 workers, set fire to the Deepwater Horizon oil rig and triggered a massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a contrite BP vowed to "make things right" and set aside $42.5 billion to do so. [...]Exxon Mobil spent two decades fighting claims from the 1989 Exxon Valdez tanker spill off Alaska; 8,000 original plaintiffs died while awaiting compensation, BP's Web site notes, calling it "a legacy that BP sought to avoid." [...]

title: Water shortage may last weeks
news: It could be several weeks before Nenagh's polluted water supply is again fit to drink, and the affected source may have to be abandoned altogether, the Environmental Protection Agency has conceded. The EPA said there was "no doubt" that a PROCTER  and GAMBLEcosmetics plant leakage was a factor in the pollution. But "very sensitive testing" of the site is continuing, and the agency is investigating the possibility that effluent from a second factory may also have contributed to the problem.

title: CHEVRON homes in on Perth
news: US energy giant CHEVRON, which is leading the $11 billion-plus Gorgon gas project off WA, has pledged to make Perth one of its global technology headquarters. Announced last night at a welcome reception for today's Asia Pacific Gas Forum, the new Energy Technology Centre is expected to employ 100 oil and gas technology experts and provide research, development and technical services for CHEVRON in the Asia-Pacific region. The new centre, and another to be opened in Aberdeen in Scotland, will complement CHEVRON's existing technology centres in California and Texas. It will open early next year. The announcement comes as CHEVRON awaits the outcome of its appeal against the 6 decision by the Environmental Protection Authority to reject plans to build the Gorgon liquefied natural gas plant on Barrow Island because of the potential risk to the island's flora and fauna. CHEVRON's appeal against the EPA ruling is now being considered by appeals convener Garry Middle, who will report to State Environment Minister Mark McGowan later this year. Unlike the EPA, the Minister will also consider the social and economic implications of blocking the Gorgon project, and is widely expected to approve the venture subject to strict conditions. CHEVRON and partners Shell and ExxonMobil hope to be able to approve the Gorgon project early next year in a bid to start production in 2011-12. The timing of CHEVRON's announcement echoes that of Shell's decision in 2000 to make Perth one of three "global centres of excellence" for its worldwide exploration and production activities at the height of its failed bid for Woodside Petroleum. […]

title: EXXON DAMAGES FOR VALDEZ SPILL ARE CUT IN HALF
news: Ninth US Ciruit Court of Appeals cut in half a $5 billion jury award for punitive damages against Exxon Mobil Corp for the 1989 Valdez oil spill, finding the award excessive (L)

title: Exxon warns against regulatory backlash on deep-water drilling after BP disaster
news: America's largest oil company, ExxonMobil, pleaded with politicians and regulators to hold off on new rules to curb drilling until the lessons of the Deepwater Horizon disaster have been fully understood. Executives from the firm said they fear that the horrors of BP's Gulf of Mexico oil leak could prompt a rush of new legislation or regulation, causing long-term damage to the industry. Speaking at the Asia Oil and Gas Conference in Malaysia, Andrew Swiger, a senior vice president of Exxon, said talk of imposing new restrictions on drilling was "premature".[...] The Obama administration introduced a moratorium on new deep-water exploratory drilling in the US for six months, pending the findings and recommendations of a presidential commission investigating the causes of the explosion in April that sank the Deepwater Horizon rig leased by BP, killed 11 crew members and ripped open a hole in the seabed.[...] Following the order to idle 33 deep-water rigs, Royal Dutch Shell, Exxon, Chevron and other firms have begun curbing Gulf of Mexico operations. [...]

title: Firms accused of rewriting their entry on Wikipedia
news: A host of blue-chip companies have altered their entries on Wikipedia, the online encyclopaedia, in an attempt to cover up embarrassing episodes in their history. The discovery was made by WikiScanner, a site that traces the source of changes to the world's largest online reference work by matching edits -which, famously, can be made by anyone - to a database of the unique IP addresses of the computers that were used to make them.[…] A machine that belongs to ExxonMobil, the oil giant, is shown making sweeping changes to an entry on the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989. An allegation that the company "has not yet paid the $5 billion in spill damages it owes to the 32,000 Alaskan fishermen" was replaced with references to the funds the company has paid out. […] * Wikipedia original text about Exxon: 'Mobil has not yet paid the $5 billion in spill damages it owes to the 32,000 Alaskan fisherman' * Wikipedia text about Exxon after alteration: 'ExxonMobil paid $300 million immediately and voluntarily to more than 11,000 Alaskans and businesses affected by the Valdez spill'

title: Marine Contractor Helix Reaches US Gulf Spill Containment Agreement
news: A marine contractor that assisted with containment operations during the BP oil spill has reached an agreement to provide deepwater containment services on an as-needed basis to industry group Clean Gulf Associates.[…] Clean Gulf Associates bills itself as a cooperative enterprise owned and operated for the benefit of those utilizing its services. The organization is not affiliated with the non-profit Marine Well Containment Co. launched by Exxon Mobil, CHEVRON, ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell in 7 to reduce the environmental impact of a Macondo-style blowout and lighten the oil industry's financial exposure to such a disaster. "Despite extreme cautions, the possibility of an oil spill exists. [Clean Gulf Associates] is on 24-hour alert from bases throughout the [Gulf of Mexico] providing coverage from Brownsville, Texas, to Key West, Florida," the organization says on its website.[...]

title: Corporate aid or plain hypocrisy?
news: CHARITIES and other non-governmental organisations have been significant forces behind the rapid growth over the past decade in the corporate social responsibility movement, encouraging companies to heed the social and environmental impact of their operations, Alexandra Frean writes. But now many of these very same organisations may be wishing they had not been so eager to lend their names and reputations to a cause that has become increasingly tarnished and that is so often the excuse for rank corporate hypocrisy. In the past week, two leading development charities have published reports illustrating, on the one hand, how easily the corporate social responsibility movement has been hijacked by companies more keen on maintaining a carefully manufactured public image than on making the world a better place, and on the other, how far it has to go if its -ostensibly sensible -aims are ever to be embedded in the collective corporate and consumer consciousness.  In Behind the Mask, Christian Aid puts forward a convincing case for international laws to control multinational companies' operations in developing countries, arguing that voluntary social and environmental initiatives, parading under the banner of corporate social responsibility, have proved wholly inadequate. The report uses case studies involving British American Tobacco, COCA-COLA and Shell to demonstrate its belief that the rhetoric of responsibility can mask corporate activity that makes things worse for for communities where they work. The report alleges that in Nigeria, Shell fails promptly to clean up oil spills that ruin villages, despite claims that it strives to be a "good neighbour". […] And while COCA-COLA emphasises "using natural resources responsibly", the report alleges that a wholly owned subsidiary in India has been accused of depleting village wells in an area where water is scarce, and has been told by an Indian court to stop drawing ground water.[…]

title: Waste talk deadline nears
news: A WORLD-first market-based scheme to trade rights to generate waste appears to be the last hope for peace between Australia's governments and the packaging industry, which are struggling over the crisis-ridden kerbside recycling system. Federal and State environment ministers have slammed the industry, including giants COCA-COLA Amatil, Visy and Southcorp, for stalling talks on improving kerbside recycling and reducing packaging waste.They have threatened to impose mandatory recycling targets unless a new system can be agreed to by Friday. […] Mandatory recycling targets were proposed by governments last year in an effort to meet an Australia-wide commitment to reduce waste to landfill 50 per cent by 2000. Industry promised to meet the commitment through a voluntary system, but has since baulked at setting any obligations on itself. […] NSW Environment Minister Pam Allen said industry's likely failure to agree on a voluntary system brought into play current NSW laws that included sanctions such as product bans if mandatory waste reduction plans failed. "The refusal of industry to embrace responsibility for their wastes, even on a voluntary basis, meant that the community and government was unfairly carrying the full financial burden of ensuring effective recycling systems across Australia," Ms Allen said.

title: Nationalist hurdles threaten Indonesia's investment boom
news: [...]  Last year, Indonesia implemented import restrictions on horticulture products, a move that has since prompted the United States to complain to the World Trade Organisation.[...]  And last month, oil and gas company CHEVRON warned Indonesia's upstream oil and gas regulatory body that it might pull out of the country entirely due to a deteriorating investment climate. CHEVRON is embroiled in a dispute with the government over an environmental remediation project in Sumatra. [...]

title: The new ethical management
news: What is it? 'BDF: babies, dolphins and forests' was how one (enlightened) business figure once characterised corporate social responsibility. CSR, and ethics in business, tend to provoke a 'yadda yadda yadda', fingers in the ears, 'not listening!' response from many business leaders. [...] In fairness, there has been dramatic progress. Coca-Cola, for example, which used to have no idea how much water it consumed in making its product, found out in a hurry when protesters pointed out how damaging its processes could be for water tables. But, in general, business has been grudgingly slow to embrace a more ethical approach. Even Unilever's Paul Polman is viewed as a maverick for daring to promote sustainability.

title: P&;G updates palm oil policy
news: The PROCTER &; Gamble Co. has updated its policy on palm oil following high-profile protests by Greenpeace at its Cincinnati headquarters. The world's largest consumer products company said Tuesday it has adopted a "no-deforestation" policy for its palm oil products. That includes working with those in its supply chain to ensure that by 2020, its products do not contribute to deforestation. The moves came after weeks of pressure from Greenpeace, which unfurled huge banners from the company's corporate offices last month. Police arrested the activists on burglary and vandalism charges. Greenpeace says Tuesday's announcement is a huge step toward protecting Indonesia's rainforests and the communities that depend on them.

title: Reverse vending machines hit the slot
news: A City of Sydney trial of reverse vending machines that could form the backbone of a state-wide container deposit scheme has proved a resounding success, attracting enthusiastic reviews on social media. Just two of the machines that provide a monetary or other reward for bottles and cans - one at Circular Quay and another at Haymarket - have collected more than 40,000 bottles since 7. The news will not please the beverage industry, which has been lobbying furiously against a scheme that would require a 10Â¢ payment for the return of bottles and cans. Such a scheme has operated in South Australia for 37 years. Coca-Cola Amatil unsuccessfully challenged in court the recent introduction of a container deposit scheme in the Northern Territory. A NSW Liberal MP has claimed she was threatened by the drinks industry with an adverse advertising campaign in the 2011 election if she supported a deposit scheme. The Baird government is considering a container deposit scheme and has Coca-Cola, Lion Nathan and CUB, as well as Clean Up Australia, Greenpeace and the Boomerang Alliance in recent months. [...]

title: EU study dampens hope of European shale gas boom
news: [...] The first of three studies, by the EC's Joint Research Centre, examines the potential impact of EU shale gas on the energy market in the light of unconventional gas development in the US rising dramatically to meet over 50% of domestic production in 2010. [...] Poland is thought to have the EU's largest shale gas reserves, but estimates of total accessible reserves vary widely and some initial exploration has not yielded the expected results--with UK-based 3 Legs Resources relinquishing one of its Polish licenses in 8 after disappointing results and ExxonMobil quitting the country. The two other reports focus on potential climate and environmental risks, with one, by AEA Technology, focusing on the risks brought by fracking, the process used to extract the gas. "The risks posed by high volume hydraulic fracturing for unconventional hydrocarbon extraction are greater than those of conventional extraction," it concludes. It highlights the need for large volumes of water and access to land (with an impact on biodiversity), as well as noise pollution, potential chemical spills and releases of gas and pollutants to the air, and potential for surface and ground water contamination. [...]

title: Cairn Energy expects go-ahead to start drilling off Greenland
news: Cairn Energy s $400 million (£277m) oil exploration adventure off Greenland is set to begin next month, despite envi-ronmentalist and Canadian government fears about the consequences of a future oil spill in the pristine waters of the Davis Strait.[...]Cairn insists that it has taken the precaution of hiring two new  state-of-the art drilling rigs to ensure there is no possibility of repeating the recent disaster which has devastated the Gulf of Mexico.US President Barack Obama  has suspended exploratory oil drilling in the Arctic Ocean off Alaska until at least 2011. Shell was due to start drilling there  next month. Last week, the Ottawa government asked Greenland for more information about Cairn Energy s drilling before an emergency meeting between the two countries on Wednesday. Canada shares the Davis Strait s territorial waters with Greenland and is said to be  keen to hear  what precautions Cairn has put in place. Meanwhile Peter Wadhams, professor of oceanography at Cambridge University and the man who discovered the thin-ning of the arctic ice cap, said that it was  madness  to allow drilling to continue off Greenland until safety fears were allayed. The oil companies have so far downplayed the risks of drilling through Greenland,  added Rasmus Hansson, chairman of WWF s arctic programme.[...]Apart from Cairn, a number of exploration licenses have been awarded over the past five years to EnCana, ExxonMobil, CHEVRON, DONG and Husky Energy.[...]

title: Activists Hit Us Firms
news: Esso became the target of environmental campaigners when activists staged a protest at a service station in Bristol.  Citing alleged links between the petroleum giant, global warming and the war in Iraq, the protest group handed out hundreds of leaflets spelling out their case yesterday. The action was organised by Greenpeace, which has called for a public boycott of the garage in Henleaze and other Esso forecourts. The organisation has accused Esso's parent company EXXONMOBIL of sabotaging international efforts to combat global warming. Greenpeace spokesman Charlie Routh said: "We want people in Henleaze to know that there is a company right in their midst which is doing more than any other to keep the US hooked on oil.  "For decades Esso has opposed policies that would reduce the USA's need for oil."[...]

title: Investors turn up heat over carbon emissions
news: In the Wells Fargo logo, a stagecoach races in front of a pristine blue sky. Bed Bath & Beyond, meanwhile, is touting the "environmentally friendly" nature of many of the products it sells. And ExxonMobil, in its guiding principles, lists running an "environmentally responsible operation." But Tuesday, a group of investors put these companies, as well as seven others, on a new "climate watch list," labeling them as laggards in their response to climate change. This is just one example of how global warming is starting to hit corporate America between its pinstripes. This year at corporate annual meetings, shareholders will present a record 42 resolutions asking for more disclosure of company carbon emissions and potential financial exposure to new regulations. Some companies are finding themselves named as defendants in class-action lawsuits accusing them of heating up the planet. This week, Congress will begin hearings on global warming and is expected to hear from companies such as GENERAL ELECTRIC and Nucor Steel. "A lot of people are wondering if [climate change] will be the calamity du jour," says Sam Stovall, director of investment strategy at Standard & Poor's in New York. "It could end up having a very severe impact on economies and fortunes." Environmental groups maintain that corporate America should begin preparing for some form of restraints on carbon emissions. "Most are betting it will be some form of cap," says Andrew Aulisi, director for US climate policy at the Earth Resources Institute in Washington. […]

title: GE LAWSUIT ON PCBS TOSSED
news: ALBANY - A judge has tossed out a controversial lawsuit filed in an effort to force General Electric to pay for the cleanup of a PCB-contaminated upstate portion of the Hudson River. State Supreme Court Justice Stephen Ferradino said the suit, brought by state Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, was "meritless."  The lawsuit, which had been criticized by the Pataki administration, was the first legal action ever taken against GE for discharging polychlorinated biphenyls - PCBs - into the Hudson and the 35-mile Champlain Canal. […]

title: COURT REFUSES TO REVIEW EXXON DECISION
news: WASHINGTON (AP) - The U.S. supreme court has refused to free Exxon Mobil Corp.  from having to pay $7.6 billion in damages for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, the worst such spill in U.S. history. The court, acting without comment yesterday, let stand the award stemming from the tanker spill that polluted more than 1,600 kilometres of shoreline, killed tens of thousands of birds and marine mammals, and disrupted fishing. The oil company still has a variety of other appeals pending, and the high court ruling does not obligate the company to pay anything right away, company spokesperson Tom Cirigliano said. […]

title: The latest Cameron mantra: Praise a Page 3 girl
news: UNDER David Cameron, the Conservatives have made huge efforts to be seen as the 'green' party of British politics. After unveiling their tree logo this year, the Tories' latest environmental publicity stunt will cause more raised eyebrows among traditional supporters.[...] Among those branded ' environmental zeros' by the Tories were oil giant EXXON MOBIL for funding thinktanks denying the effect of human activity on climate change and Iceland's government for whaling. Shadow environment secretary Peter Ainsworth said: '2006 was the year when the environment took its rightful place at the centre of British politics. 'Climate change is an enormous issue requiring urgent action to prevent an ecological, economic and social catastrophe. 'This list is by no means comprehensive, but takes a look at some of those who have been a part of the solution in 2006, and some who are still part of the problem.'

title: Pilot scheme for recycling PCs
news: The growing stockpile of discarded computers lurking in home garages and corporate storerooms throughout the country poses a significant environmental threat, according to a report commissioned by the national agency, Environment Australia. The report, Computer & Peripherals Material Project, by the infrastructure and environment group of consulting engineers Meinhardt, warns that millions of computers are becoming redundant, but programs for re-using or recycling of their heavy metal, plastic and glass components are "limited".It says manufacturers should do more to support "take-back" and recycling programs, possibly funded by a deposit fee included in the purchase price.The report says the computers contain heavy metals such as lead, zinc, nickel, mercury and cadmium, along with potentially hazardous plastic resins and flame-retardants.[…] Durie says manufacturers responsible for producing up to 65 per cent of the machines in Australia, such as Dell, IBM, Compaq and Apple, are talking to the association about the pilot project.[…]

title: CHEVRON Aims At an Activist Shareholder
news: [...] Trillium oversees $1 billion in assets and specializes in what is known as sustainable investing. It focuses on environmental, social and governance factors in its investments and pursues shareholder advocacy programs on these issues. In an interview last week, Jonas Kron, Trillium's director of shareholder advocacy and corporate engagement, declined to discuss the subpoena. But it is part of a Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations lawsuit CHEVRON has filed against an army of parties involved in bringing an environmental case against the company in Ecuador almost two decades ago. In February 2011, the court in Ecuador ruled against CHEVRON, awarding the plaintiffs more than $18 billion. The Ecuadorean matter centered on claims that TEXACO Petroleum, which CHEVRON acquired in 2001, had polluted sections of a remote region in the Amazon. CHEVRON maintained that TEXACO successfully remediated the site years before, in a $40 million cleanup.CHEVRON has not paid the judgment. The company has said it does not believe that the Ecuador judgment is enforceable ''in any court that observes the rule of law.'' It maintains that the Ecuadorean case was riddled with fraud and says it will ''continue to pursue relief against Ecuador in our pending arbitration and against the plaintiffs' representatives in our RICO action pending in New York.''[...] Trillium is not a defendant in CHEVRON's RICO suit. But it, along with other shareholders, has questioned how CHEVRON has handled all this. [...]

title: EXXON MOBIL WILL PAY $11.2 MILLION SETTLEMENT IN WASTE-DUMPING CASE
news: EXXON MOBIL Corp has agreed to pay $11.2 million in cash penalties and environmental-restoration-and-protection costs in one of the largest hazardous-waste settlements in history; the consent decree closes a 1996 case involving the dumping of benzene into the Arthur Kill waterway (S)

title: For 2 Giants of Soft Drinks, A Crisis in a Crucial Market
news: TWO of the world's biggest brand names, known for wooing customers around the world, are facing a credibility crisis in one of their crucial emerging markets.    The Center for Science and the Environment announced in 8 that drinks manufactured by Coca-Cola and PEPSICO in India contained on average more than 24 times the safe limits of pesticides, which could come from sugar, water and other ingredients.When those reports appeared on the front pages of newspapers in India, Coke and PEPSI executives were confident that they could handle the situation.
