[…]"In India, for example, water extraction by Coca-Cola for Dasani bottled water and other drinks has caused water shortages for over 50 villages," the study says. […]

title: BRINGING UP BABY THE GREEN WAY
news: […]  But there is a new trend emerging and it may surprise older generations: thousands of parents are turning their backs on disposables and are looking for alternatives.[…] So it was no surprise that when the first disposables came onto the market, they were an immediate hit. They revolutionised baby care, offering a quick and labour-saving alternative to the real thing. But it is only in the past few years that stories of their environmental impact are being told. More than eight million of them are used every day and 94 per cent are tossed into the household rubbish and disposed of, by local authorities, into landfill sites.  According to the The Women's Environmental Network, disposable nappies constitute at least four per cent of British household waste and cost a typical local authority between pounds 100,000 and pounds 200,000 a year to dispose of them.[…] Although environmental factors are the main concern, using cloth also has financial benefits.[…]  But what about washing and drying? A study by PROCTER AND GAMBLE in 1993 found that washable nappies did not use more fossil energy than disposables.  Miranda said laundry adds between pounds 100 and pounds 365, depending on how often washing is done and whether or not they are tumble dried, the savings are clear.[…]

title: Focus: Climate in crisis: It's apocalypse now as world overheats; Scientists fear that global warming has gone beyond the point of no return
news: IN MOZAMBIQUE, 300,000 people are left homeless and hundreds have been killed in devastating floods. In France, storms cause 90 fatalities, destroy 270 million trees and trigger pounds 7.5 billion worth of damage. In Austria, a series of avalanches sweeps 11 people to their deaths. And in the Arctic, scientists discover that over the past two decades the polar ice cap has thinned from a modest 10ft thickness to a flimsy 6ft. And that is just a brief selection of the environmental horrors that have beset the planet over the past few weeks, although it is enough to confirm meteorologists' worst fears. […] THE WORLD COULD BE slightly encouraged were it not for one major blot on the political landscape. Although President Clinton signed the Kyoto Treaty, committing the United States by far the biggest carbon dioxide polluter in the world to reduce emissions by 7 per cent, Congress has simply refused to ratify the agreement or cut US carbon dioxide output by a single tonne. This failure can be traced to US experts who claimed that signing the Kyoto treaty would cost every American $ 2,000 a year in higher fuel bills, a line that was promoted with particular vigour by the Global Climate Coalition, an alliance of car manufacturers and oil companies, including Peabody Coal, the powerful Western Fuels Association and EXXON. The coalition's aim as revealed in internal documents has been to turn global warming from a 'fact' into a 'theory' in the minds of the American public.[…] THE CURRENT IMPASSE over Kyoto can be attributed to a number of factors, including 'the political influence of the fossil fuel industry and its friends in Congress, coupled with the inability of the Clinton Administration and its own personal entwinement in the corporations themselves', as Hertsgaard put it.  The world's bid to reduce its headlong flight towards climate disruption, rising seas and drowned coastlines has been thwarted primarily by this depressing combination of effects. Just as it has done with moves to curb gun use, the US has stubbornly refused to accept what the rest of the world, and its own liberal politicians, have been saying: that it has to change its ways drastically.  However, this deeply depressing situation has been lightened by recent encouraging signs. The global climate coalition, the nemesis of environment campaigners, is beginning to show signs of instability. General Motors, Ford, Shell, Amoco and BP have recently quit the organisation, although others, such as EXXON and MOBIL, remain.[…]

title: DISPOSABLE NAPPY FIRMS SLAM REUSABLES SCHEME
news: The UK's trade organisation for disposable nappies, the AHPMA, has attacked plans by the Local Government Association (LGA) to roll out a scheme for councils to pay families up to pounds 80 to opt for reusable cloth nappies. Seventeen local councils have already signed up to the initiative. The LGA claimed the scheme will reduce damage to the environment and save councils money by reducing volumes at landfill sites. It said: 'Nearly 3bn nappies are thrown away in the UK each year, with 90% ending up in landfill.' However, the AHPMA has responded that reusable nappies do as much harm to the environment through increased consumption of water, energy and detergent. Last year, the Environment Agency concluded that 'there is no significant difference between the environmental impacts' of either disposable or reusable nappies. The AHPMA, which represents Pampers owner PROCTER & GAMBLE and Huggies manufacturer Kimberly-Clark, said similar schemes had been unsuccessful. A spokesman said: 'Disposable nappies are the preferred choice of more than 95% of parents as they are quick, clean and easy to use. Parents should not be made to feel guilty about using them as they have no greater impact on the environment than cloth nappies.'[…]

title: Greens seek Keystone delay; arkansas spill
news: WASHINGTON . Environmental groups on Monday asked the Obama administration to extend the approval process of the Keystone XL pipeline, using last month's spill of heavy Canadian crude oil in Arkansas as their latest reason to delay the project. The Obama administration is deciding whether to approve the Canada-to-Nebraska leg of TransCanada Corp.'s proposed pipeline, which would link Canada's oil sands, the world's third-richest crude oil deposit, to refineries in Texas. [...] Exxon Mobil Corp's Pegasus pipeline, which runs from Illinois to Texas and can transport more than 90,000 barrels per day, remains shut after 22 homes were evacuated as a result of the oil-spill. [...] Environmentalists say that oil sands petroleum and diluted bitumen from Canada is corrosive to pipelines.[...]

title: Fireworks on - regardless of pollution
news: Fireworks displays at the Disneyland theme park would be staged regardless of high air pollution levels, unless it could be proved that they directly contributed to the poor air quality, an environmental chief said yesterday.  His remarks came as the Advisory Council on the Environment endorsed a report carried out for DISNEY on the latest fireworks test results. But the council called on the entertainment giant to improve monitoring and to consider new fireworks technology if possible.  Under requirements set by the Environmental Protection Department, DISNEY will have to increase monitoring, modify displays or even stop the shows if noise or air pollution affecting nearby homes exceeds set levels.[…]

title: Rats fuel fear over Barrow's gas plant
news: Two baby rats and a rat's nest found in a helicopter on Barrow Island have renewed concerns about future potential quarantine breaches if a controversial gas project goes ahead. Oil company CHEVRON has operated an oil field under strict quarantine controls on the Pilbara offshore A-class nature reserve for 40 years. It is also a major partner in the proposed Gorgon Gas project, which would see a big gas processing plant built on the island by up to 3000 workers. The rat presence, discovered on November 27, comes as the State and Federal governments assess the Gorgon proposal for environmental approval. Conservationists object to the proposal because they say there is a high chance it will lead to the introduction of weeds or feral animals from the mainland, potentially wiping out Barrow's unique species. CHEVRON WA oil asset manager Greg Harrison admitted it was the worst animal quarantine breach he could recall since the early 1990s. […] But Conservation Council director Chris Tallentire said it showed how difficult good quarantine was. "Our concern is we have a small, experienced, well-trained workforce now but with Gorgon, we would have a much bigger, short-term workforce," Mr Harrison said. "We have fears you could not possibly keep up robust quarantine procedures." […]

title: A nation turns on bottled fizz
news: All the Indian front pages are today filled with the banning of Coke and PEPSI by several Indian states from school premises and government offices following a report by a Delhi-based group, The Centre for Science and Environment, that the drinks contained levels of pesticide residue exceeding international standards. PEPSI and Coke deny the allegations which the CSE says were derived from tests on 57 cola samples from 12 Indian states. I can't vouch for the CSE, but they were the same organization that made similar alarming allegations in 2003.   Whatever the scientific truth  and no doubt this will emerge through rival tests over time  the reality is that Coke and PEPSI are taking a bashing. Sales are down 10 per cent and some dealers report wholesale up-take down 20 per cent.[…]

title: Tom fuelery
news: [...] Eight months ago, CHEVRON, the oil giant, lodged a complaint charging that Controller Tom DiNapoli violated ethical standards by pressuring the company to settle a major court case after taking contributions from CHEVRON's opponents. The company filed its accusations with the ethics watchdog called JCOPE, which Cuomo and the Legislature promised would be a tough sheriff. Among its disappointments has been a failure to pursue the controller's muscling of CHEVRON. Boy, did DiNapoli get in over his head. In a cause célèbre lawsuit, environmental activists alleged that decades ago CHEVRON's predecessor company TEXACO despoiled a vast region of Ecuador. A court there hit CHEVRON with an $18 billion judgment in 2011. Lawyers behind the suit enlisted DiNapoli to use his power as sole trustee of the state pension fund to push the company toward a settlement. From 2008 through 2013, they contributed $68,000 to DiNapoli's campaign accounts.[...]

title: ENVIRONMENT; WILLAMETTE FALLS; ACCESS ALL AREAS.
news: Debra Flickinger reports on PGE's efforts to improve fish passage in the relicensing application for its T.W. Sullivan plant. Portland GENERAL ELECTRIC's (PGE) longest-running generation facility, one of the three oldest hydroelectric plants in the US, is headed for another 30 years of operation. On 2 February 2004, Portland, Oregon-based PGE submitted an agreement to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), that will be a key step in renewing its license for the 16MW T.W. Sullivan plant. Under the agreement, signed by a variety of governmental, environmental and tribal organisations, the Willamette Falls power house will operate with enhanced production capacity and environmental protections. It provides for several improvements to assist the downstream passage of juvenile fish. In addition, PGE will assume maintenance and any necessary improvements to the facility's fish ladder to help adult salmon and steelhead move upstream. Improvements to the downstream facilities include moving fish through a tunnel currently used to take water around the plant. A gated opening, or 'flow structure' will also be created at the top of the falls to better direct fish downstream. The goal is to achieve a safe passage rate of 98% or better. […] History In 1883, the dam at Willamette Falls was constructed to exploit the hydro power potential of the site. The 899.2m-long dam uses the hydraulic head of the falls, a natural horseshoe-shaped cascade approximately 12.2m in height. The dam runs along the top of the falls between two power houses, varying in height from 1.8-6.1m. The dam maintains a consistent water level (but does not provide water storage) to which the hydroelectric projects, several mills and the US Army Corps of Engineers navigation locks are built. […]

title: Megastorage starts to take green byte; Data management firms use offsets, energy-efficient equipment to counter environmental impact
news: As companies store more data, the systems to hold all that information, as well as the computers employees use, are becoming a larger environmental concern. ``IT hardware and data centers are a surprising leading national contributor to carbon emissions,'' said Vini Handler, vice president of product management and marketing for server and Web hosting firm NTT America Inc. […] Desktop computers waste nearly half their power, while servers lose about a third, through heat loss, according to the Climate Savers Computing Initiative, spearheaded by Google Inc. and INTEL Corp.Simply engaging power management systems on computers can have a significant impact on the environment, not to mention the pocketbook. Some 90 percent of desktop personal computers are operated with the power management systems turned off, said Alyson Klein, manager of the technology and software strategy team for INTEL's Digital Enterprise Group.[…]

title: CHEVRON fights case that led to $19B ruling in Ecuador
news: For years, CHEVRON Corp. has insisted a sprawling environmental-pollution lawsuit in Ecuador initiated by a Philadelphia law firm that resulted in a $19 billion judgment was riddled with fraud. Now, the company is trying to prove its case in a closely watched civil trial in federal district court in New York that could establish new limits on when and where U.S. companies can be sued over claims they caused environmental harm in foreign jurisdictions.[...] The CHEVRON lawsuit names plaintiffs' lawyer Steven Donziger, a onetime classmate of President Obama at Harvard Law School, and his clients as defendants.[...] Donziger's defense team, many of whom are volunteering their time or working at reduced rates, accuse CHEVRON of trumping up fraud charges as a way to discourage others from suing the company. In his opening statement, Richard Friedman, the lead lawyer, even compared Donziger to the late Supreme Court justice and civil rights leader Thurgood Marshall for standing up to CHEVRON and seeking to redress the environmental harms allegedly caused by the company.[...]

title: SPRING GREENING
news: […]  In fact, the product contains formaldehyde-melamine-sodium bisulfite copolymer, which poses no risk, according to PROCTER & GAMBLE's website. But Begg's reaction to the toxic potential of her cleaning cupboard highlights a growing consumer concern.  Inspired by Mesley, Begg purchased the CancerSmart Consumer Guide, published by the Labour Environmental Alliance Society. Now, Ecover is her dishwasher soap and Nature Clean is her laundry detergent. Begg even uses Natura Static Free Reusable Dryer Sheets - much to her husband's chagrin as his sweatshirt remains clingy.   Add water, rinse and repeat enough times and you've got a new definition of greenwashing. While its original meaning refers to companies promulgating misinformation to appear environmentally conscious, greenwashing version 2.0 is practised by people who use non-toxic, mostly natural alternatives, whether store-bought or homemade, to do the housework. […]  Green thinkers belong to an increasingly important market segment called LOHAS (Lifestyles of Health and Sustainability), a concept originated about seven years ago from the work of sociologist Paul Ray, co-author of The Cultural Creatives: How 50 Million People are Changing the World. […]  Confusion is bound to continue over what constitutes "green" as long as companies are not required to list ingredients. "The argument for not listing is trade secrets," says Madeleine Bird, a co-ordinator for health and environmental awareness projects at McGill University's Centre for Research and Teaching on Women. "That's understandable but not valid because you need the instructions, not just the ingredients, to complete a recipe." […]

title: (AMM) Energy infrastructure poised to grow next year, Fitch says
news: Natural gas demand is expected to be flat next year compared with 2010, but production trends will drive energy infra-structure development, fed by advancements in horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, Fitch Ratings Services said in an outlook report on natural gas. [...] However, as shale development moves forward, "growing environmental and safety concerns will likely alter, raise the cost of and possibly mute the infrastructure build-out for both the oil and gas sectors," the report said.[...] Then there is BP Plc's catastrophic oil spill, along with potential water contamination from Marcellus Shale production. Each incident "has generated media headlines and great political interest. New federal legislation and tighter regulation are sure to follow," the report said.[...] On the positive side, the participation of major suppliers in shale development through recent acquisitions - namely ExxonMobil and Chevron - improves counterparty credit exposure, and future Marcellus production will likely displace traditional supply sources. On the regulatory front, "the passage of federal carbon legislation seems less likely than it did at this time last year, (but) the Environmental Protection Agency is expected to more aggressively target emissions through its proposed Clean Air Transport Rule," according to the report. Additionally, "pipeline safety legislation is working its way through Congress with bills in both the House and Senate focused on increasing pipeline oversight and accountability for safety infractions. Fitch expects the passage of safety legislation," it said.[...]

title: Price carbon and spread the load, says climate chief; POLLUTION
news: THE former United Nations climate change chief has warned Australia not to be "too radical" in designing its carbon tax but urged the federal government to proceed with the policy. [...] The calls for a clear direction on climate change were echoed by Coca-Cola Amatil's chief executive, Terry Davis, who said while Australia should not lead the push to cut emissions, the country needed policy certainty. [...]

title: Arctic oil spill could spread thousands of miles in a winter
news: The risks of drilling for oil in the Arctic have been exposed in industry documents that reveal the clean-up after a major spill might have to be suspended throughout the winter, allowing the oil to spread thousands of miles. Techniques used to contain the oil spilt in last year's Gulf of Mexico disaster, such as using boats to skim off the slick and lay protective booms, would not work in the Arctic because the region is covered in ice and shrouded in darkness in winter.  [...] CHEVRON admits that it might have to wait until the following spring to clean up oil spilt in the Canadian Arctic in late summer. It says the oil could become trapped under drifting ice. It concludes that the lack of daylight and extremely low temperature in winter could force it to "delay direct intervention to the spring when working and flying conditions are more favourable". [...] Peter Wadhams, Professor of Ocean Physics at the University of Cambridge, said that the worst-case scenario was a well blow-out late in the year, when efforts to drill a relief well could be impeded by the formation of sea ice. [...]

title: CITI'S GREEN PUSH UNDERWHELMS ENVIRONMENTALISTS
news: CITIGROUP announces wide-ranging plan to spend $50 billion on climate-change issues over next decade and support investment in alternative energy sources, but environmentalists say Citi should do more to curb its involvement with businesses that contribute to global warming and devote more effort to getting its clients to do same (M)

title: Greens and Chevron set to face off over Gorgon vision
news: Chevron is set for fresh battles with WA's powerful green lobby after the US giant said yesterday it wanted to nearly double the size of the $50 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas project on environmentally fragile Barrow Island off WA's North-West.[...] But Chevron's admission that it is already considering trains four and five for Gorgon is likely to spark fresh outbursts from environmentalists, who remain up in arms about Chevron's original two-train proposal for Barrow, a pristine island that is home to rare and endangered species and a major nesting site for flatback turtles.[...]  After years of delays, Chevron and its Gorgon partners Royal Dutch Shell and ExxonMobil expect to push the go-ahead button for the project this year, which could cost $50 billion. [...]

title: UK biofuels use exceeds target in second quarter 2008
news: [...] Under the UK's Renewable Transport Fuels Obligation (RTFO), refiners and fuels suppliers are obliged to supply 2.5% biofuel in UK road fuel in the year to April 2009.[...] During the first three months of the obligation, the average carbon reduction achieved by the use of biofuels was 44%, above the 40% target set by the government for the first year of the RTFO, the agency said. It said, however, that almost all the oil majors retailing fuels in the UK except Shell fell below the non-binding target of 40% greenhouse gas savings. The agency said ExxonMobil and Swiss-based Petroplus also failed to meet two further targets--that at least 30% of biofuels supplied met environmental targets and a 50% minimum threshold on reported sustainability data.[...]

title: Oil spillage in Bass Strait shuts down Cobia rig
news: Federal agencies are investigating an oil spill in Bass Strait after they were alerted to problems at one of the offshore platforms owned by Exxon Mobil and BHP Billiton. Exxon, which operates the rigs, said the "Cobia" platform had been shut down recently after an oily sheen was observed on the surface of the ocean about 70 kilometres off the eastern Victorian coast. [...] Exxon was confident the spill was not large, saying an aerial survey on Monday had suggested the sheen had dissipated, and estimating that only 750 litres had leaked. [...]

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
news: [...] To the Editor: ''The Big Spill'' (editorial, Sept. 30), about the seepage of oil into Newtown Creek, did not mention key facts. You state that ''the spill is believed to have originated 57 years ago.'' But no single event caused the underground plume of petroleum products that accumulated gradually over more than 140 years as a result of multiple releases from multiple contributors. This was stated in a recent study conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency. You refer to ''a huge pool of oil'' at the bottom of Newtown Creek. Both the New York State Department of Environ-mental Conservation and the E.P.A. agree that there is no evidence to support this claim. You also claim that ''one major concern is the reported leakage of chemical vapors into homes.'' In fact, vapor intrusion studies on 52 Greenpoint homes done by the New York State Departments of Environmental Conservation and Health concluded there were no petroleum vapors present. You conclude that the cleanup has been ''ineffective.'' To date, more than nine million gallons of petroleum products have been recovered using state-of-the-art technology. Andrew Warrell  Global Remediation Manager Exxon Mobil Corporation Fairfax, Va.

title: Eco-activist should be deported, judge rules
news: An environmentalist who is on the FBI's 10 Most Wanted list should be extradited to the United States to face arson charges, a B.C. Supreme Court judge ruled yesterday. Justice Kristi Gill said there was enough evidence for Tre Arrow to stand trial on arson charges in the U.S., but the final decision on whether Arrow will be extradited rests with Justice Minister Irwin Cotler. Arrow, 30, is a well-known environmentalist from Oregon who fled to Canada after he was charged with conspiring to commit arson against two logging companies in the Portland area and causing $250,000 in damage. […] Arrow is seeking refugee status in Canada because of his fear of persecution in the United States. Arrow has made a name for himself as an extremist environmentalist. As an animal rights activist in 1998, Arrow was arrested in Cincinnati wearing a pink bunny suit outside a PROCTER & GAMBLE executive's home.He then moved to the Portland area, where in 7 2000, he climbed the U.S. Forest Service regional headquarters building and lived on a 23-centimetre ledge for 11 days.[…]

title: Planet-friendly panache; Oakville's Green Rooms proves that environmentally friendly furniture doesn't have to sacrifice design
news: "I've been sent here to buy towels," the young man in jeans says to Green Rooms owner Jackie Crawford. "My wife really likes the feel of the organic cotton." Crawford begins to show him all the colours available but his orders are simple. "White," he says. "All white."  As Crawford gathers the towels, he tells her he was actually supposed to buy some furniture as well for their new house in High Park. "I'm a bit nervous. I don't really know much about green furniture." He stands looking at Crawford, hands in his pockets. […] "I'm aware that people with low incomes can't afford these prices," Crawford says. "That's a problem. But when you go to Wal-Mart, things are priced artificially low because there are low safeguards on environmental control and on the health of workers. "People need to support green businesses so (the businesses) can grow enough to bring prices down. As the demand goes up through people willing to pay, prices will fall." […]

title: BP ignored plenty of warning signs; Lengthy catalog of crises and near misses led up to Gulf of Mexico disaster
news: In little more than a decade, BP grew from a middleweight into the industry's second-largest company, behind only Exxon Mobil, with soaring profits, fat dividends and a stock price to match.[...] BP is hardly the only oil company that has taken on difficult projects with a shaky safety net. But the company's attitude toward risk stands in contrast to that of its competitors, most notably Exxon Mobil, whose searing experience with the Exxon Valdez spill in 1989 spurred a wholesale change in its approach to safety.[...]

title: A Tale of Two Shorelines
news: AT the Larchmont Yacht Club one day not long ago, near the wide veranda of an elaborate Victorian clubhouse overlooking Long Island Sound, well-dressed parents and well-mannered children chatted on the deck of a sparkling pool. In the seawater below, boats rocked gently on the tide as further out in the haze, in a scene that might have been a backdrop in an F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, a flotilla of sailboats raced in distant circles. It was not quite as Gatsby-esque on an overcast Saturday at the minuscule Hudson River beach at the Philipse Manor Beach Club in Sleepy Hollow, just behind the Metro-North railroad station. There, a man wearing scruffy black water shoes climbed into a shiny white kayak and pushed off the muddy bank, while a pregnant woman played with her cranky 4-year-old in the coarse, sticky sand just north of the Tappan Zee bridge. Lifeguards watched languidly as a smattering of members ate at picnic tables, read or docked a small powerboat.  […] In the late 1960's, "the Hudson River was a virtual biological desert," agreed Cesare Manfredi, a retired engineer for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. Several decades ago, he said, there was a continuous oil sheen on the water, and a factory near Peekskilldumped molasses waste into the river that was so thick "you couldn't get a boat into the water." During the 1900's, Hudson pollutants included waste from the General Motors plant in Sleepy Hollow, the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company in Hastings, Standard Brands in Peekskill and GENERAL ELECTRIC in Fort Edward. Between 1947 and 1977, the GENERAL ELECTRIC plant leaked 1.3 million pounds of toxic PCBs into the river, and was ordered by the Environmental Protection Agency to clean up 40 remaining hot spots by the end of 2012, according to Manna Jo Greene of the Hudson River Sloop in Poughkeepsie, a group working to improve water quality.  In the 1960's, several rivers flowing into the Sound "were literally open sewers," said Mr. Manfredi. The four Sound-side sewage treatment plants in Westchester County dumped barely treated sewage into the water. The water has improved, he added, although Mamaroneck still has sewage spills.  Until the blackout on Aug. 14, only seven beaches, all on the sound, had been closed this summer, including Harbor Island, Shore Acres, Beachpoint, Mamaroneck Beach and Cabana, Orienta, Echo Bay and Hudson Park, according to the Westchester County Department of Health. After the blackout, the county closed all 56 county beaches as a precaution, including all those on the Long Island Sound, the Hudson River, and on inland lakes, according to Gabe Sganga, beach program director for the Bureau of Public Health. By Sunday, Aug. 17, all county beaches had been reopened, he said.   CARIN RUBENSTEIN

title: Bill gives 'real teeth' to environment penalties
news: [...] PROPOSED amendments to environmental laws could see polluters facing criminal liabilities of fines up to R10m, or 10 years in jail. The Department of Environmental Affairs yesterday called for public comment on the National Environmental Management Laws Amendment Bill, which environmentalists have commended, saying it gives real teeth to environmental laws. According to the bill, no person may unlawfully and intentionally or negligently pollute or degrade the environment - through an act or omission. A first-time offender could be liable for a fine of up to R5m, or five years in jail.[...] While he welcomed the bill, the World Wildlife Fund's head of the Living Planet unit, Saliem Fakir, said yesterday that the liability should not be a set amount and should be determined by a court. You don't know if R5m is sufficient.... It sounds heavy, but it depends on the unlawful act and who is carrying it out. For individuals like you and me it's significant. But if it's big corporations with big chequebooks he said. To Exxon Mobil, R10m would mean nothing. [...]

title: Who should pay for climate change disasters?
news: [...] If countries can sue each other at the UN, then why shouldn't private citizens take actions against energy companies? A few tried in the US courts after hurricane Katrina in 2005. So far, none have got very far, with courts ruling that climate change is a political rather than a legal issue. But, with or without a new political deal in 2015 on "loss and damage", that could change. Last week, Richard Heede of the Climate Accountability Institute, an evidence-based NGO in Snowmass, Colorado, tracked 63 per cent of carbon emissions in the past 250 years to just 90 corporations and state enterprises. CHEVRON, ExxonMobil, Aramco, BP and Gazprom topped the list. The aim, Heede said, was to "apportion responsibility for climate change". [...]

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT Pedal power
news: Scores of bike riders turned out Friday for the Bronx's annual Bike to Work Day, aimed at showcasing the borough's expanding Bronx Greenway Path for bicyclists, a portion of which runs along the Grand Concourse. The event, part of the New York City's annual Bike To Work Week celebration, kicked off at the historic Edgar Allen Poe Cottage on Kingsbridge Road and the Grand Concourse, and ended at the Bronx County Building at 161st St., where Bronx Borough President Adolfo Carrion hosted a special power breakfast.  "Thanks to a growing Bronx Greenway Path and an increasing number of bike lanes, bicycling is a great way to get around the Bronx year-round," said Carrion. Richard Gans, chairman of the Bronx chapter of Transportation Alternatives, also presented Carrion with the group's Friend of Cycling Award. Firms pay up Thirty-one companies that sent waste to an old Westchester County landfill have paid $9.4 million to reimburse the state Superfund for cleanup of the toxic site. The old Croton Point Landfill on the Hudson River, which was cleaned up in the 1990s and is now a county park, accepted industrial waste from 1928 to 1986. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced this week that his office and the state Department of Environmental Conservation tracked down companies that generated or dumped the waste, including Consolidated Edison, Exxon Mobil, General Motors and IBM, and negotiated the settlement. The money will go into the state Superfund to help pay for cleanup of other toxic sites, Spitzer said.

title: Apple goes for greener image
news: WITH his company under attack for its environmental record, Apple chief executive Steve Jobs has attributed the issue up to a public relations problem, but vows to make changes. In a letter published last week on Apple's website, Jobs details the company's efforts to encourage the recycling of its products and to phase out toxic chemicals from its products and manufacturing processes. Apple has already committed to phasing out many toxic chemicals and has been ahead of the industry in doing so, Jobs says. Apple will now go further than it had previously announced to recycle products and eliminate chemicals such as mercury, he says. It also plans to update consumers and investors about its environmental policies. Indeed, investors are due to vote this week on two shareholder-backed environmental proposals calling on Apple to report on its so-called e-cycling efforts and the steps it's taking to eliminate the use of toxic chemicals. The proposals follow a report from environmental group Greenpeace in December that ranks Apple last among 14 major manufacturers for its seeming lack of progress with e-cycling and eliminating chemicals. […]

title: Party 'damaged' by shares issue
news: The Green MEP, Ms Patricia McKenna, conceded yesterday that the party had been damaged by the disclosure about the make-up of the share portfolio held by its former environment spokesman, Mr Ciaran Cuffe TD. She said that Mr Cuffe was guilty of not having the "cop-on" to understand that holding shares in companies with questionable environmental records was a "political timebomb”. During a briefing for Irish journalists in Brussels, Ms McKenna was particularly critical of Mr Cuffe for leaving the matter unresolved for so long. Mr Cuffe has apologised to the party and has promised to review the composition of the portfolio, which he inherited three years ago from his mother. The disclosure that his E1.3 million portfolio included shares in six oil companies - CHEVRONTEXACO, BP Amoco, Exxon, Schlumberger, Smith International and Unocal - led him to resign as the party's environment spokesman. He also owns shares in the US multinational Sara Lee, a group blamed by environmentalists for paying poor prices to Third World coffee farmers. Ms Nuala Ahern, the Green MEP for Leinster, said she did not believe that the party had been damaged by the disclosures.

title: IN BRIEF; Car Plan Not Practical
news: The arguments of conservationists notwithstanding, INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES has rejected a proposal -- sometimes referred to as a cash-out plan -- to pay workers to use public transportation or join car pools. At least at its Somers offices, where workers travel from different suburban spots, driving one's own car to work seems to be the most efficient mode of transportation, Jim Ruderman, an I.B.M. spokesman, said last week. Mr. Ruderman said that I.B.M.'s office building in Somers, which will be adding up to 300 workers from other locations in the next several months, had asked local zoning board officials to approve a proposal to enlarge the company's parking lot. […]

news: Environmental groups petitioned FCC to require environmental assessments under National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) for 5,797 antenna structures on Gulf Coast that they said were harming migratory birds.  Broadcast, public safety and wireless towers challenged by American Bird Conservancy, Friends of the Earth (FOE) and Forest Conservation Council cover coastal region that spans 6 states and includes towers owned by American Tower, Alltel, AT&T Wireless, BellSouth, Crown Castle, Pinnacle Towers and SpectraSite as well as Ala. Power Co., state of Tex., U. of Fla.FCC had ruled earlier this year that Friends of the Earth and Forest Conservation Council lacked standing to object to 29 proposed antenna structures, prompting petition for reconsideration by those groups that still is pending.  […]

title: FOCUS: HOW GREEN IS OUR SILICON VALLEY?
news: […] That sort of problem is typical. The computer industry is not and never has been very green. In its early days, computers were enormous things which occupied entire rooms or even floors, needing their own special power supplies. The early valves and other components were potential hazards. In those days, nobody had thought about landfills or the greenhouse effect.[…]  In 1982, the Intel processor in the first IBM PC ran at a stunning 4.77 megahertz, or millions of cycles per second. These days, you can buy them at 800 MHz, and the processors alone suck up more than 50 watts. So making power savings at the office should include more than just turning out the lights: there's a very important reason too to turn off computers, or at least put them into a "sleep" mode.[…]  Yet the demand for power is still there. An office block with 1,000 people generates about 6,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions a year, the equivalent of driving 1,300 petrol cars around the world. In other words, environmental problems such as global warming and the destruction of the countryside are not just down to manufacturing industries. The computer used to be one of the most prolific users of CFCs, the chemicals which damage the ozone layer. They were used to wash circuit boards before and after soldering operations (such as attaching chips). Since the mid -Eighties, they have replaced those systems with non-CFC-based production, and in closed systems to minimise pollution. (The story goes that against regulations, IBM workers used to wash their hands in CFC trays because the chemical was non-toxic and dried almost instantly.)[…]

title: It's business as usual
news: It was years ago today that the Exxon Valdez oil tanker hit rocks in Prince William Sound, Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of oil into pristine waters and devastating both wildlife and the local economy. More wildlife was killed than in any other American environment disaster - half a million birds alone - and the area has still not recovered. Only 3% to 4% of the oil was ever recovered. The Exxon Valdez Spill Trustee Council reported recently that only two out of 28 injured species have recovered. Numbers of many species, including killer whales, are still declining. And commercial fishermen are still earning less than in 1989. […] Exxon can afford to clean up its act, but it chooses not to. A similar disaster could happen in Scotland at any time. And Exxon is one of the most aggressive lobbyists against efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and slow climate change. In fact, Esso's bosses find it convenient to believe that global warming is not taking place, against the views of the vast majority of scientists. Exxon was behind plans, exposed in 1998, for a $ 6m PR campaign to undermine climate science. Mobil argued recently in the US that dirty air does not necessarily cause significant health damage. The intransigence of Exxon is breathtaking. Unlike Shell and BP, it remains a member of the fossil fuel lobby group, the Global Climate Coalition, it refuses to support political action on climate change, and it is not investing significantly in renewable energy. Friends of the Earth calls it "probably the worst oil company in the world". […] In the US, Exxon was sued for up to $ 4.7m for nearly 200 violations of the Clean Air Act and, with a partner company, $ 4.8m after toxic discharges in San Francisco Bay. In Columbia, it sacked many thousands of workers at the El Cerrejon coal mine for trying to unionise. The list goes on. […]

title: International: ExxonMobil is still funding groups that question warming
news: The world's largest oil company is continuing to fund lobby groups that question the reality of global warming, despite its public pledge to cut support for climate change denial. A new analysis of company records shows ExxonMobil gave hundreds of thousands of pounds to such lobby groups in 2008. These include the National Centre for Policy Analysis (NCPA) in Dallas, Texas, which received $75,000 (£45,500), and the Heritage Foundation in Washington DC, which got $50,000. According to Bob Ward, policy and communications director at the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment at the London School of Economics, both the NCPA and the Heritage Foundation have published "misleading and inaccurate information about climate change".[...] The NCPA and Heritage Foundation are included among groups funded by Exxon Mobil, according to its 2008 worldwide contributions and community investments report published recently.[...]

title: Firm says cause of incident was not its responsibility
news: PROCTER & GAMBLE said that a foul drain within the industrial estate which was not its responsibility - was behind the incident. The company added that it understood the frustration caused by the interruption of the water supply. Ms Sally Woodage, public affairs manager of the company, said it was clear from the EPA report that further investigation would be necessary to establish how the contamination had occurred. PROCTER & GAMBLE, she added, valued its role in the Nenagh community and would continue to assist the EPA in its deliberations. Process effluent from the plant was discharged into the foul drain with the permission of the local authority, a statement from the company explained. The EPA report had referred to a "small leakage" within the P&G site, but this had been dealt with quickly "Nevertheless, the company is concerned that any leakage has occurred and has taken steps to ensure it will not happen again.SFADCo said that independent tests by consultants had confirmed that no effluent was leaking from its pipes. It added that if further tests revealed any leaks action would be taken. A spokesman for Tubex said late last night that the company was surprised at the contents of the EPA report which it received yesterday. It had contacted experts in the relevant field yesterday and would be contacting the EPA as soon as possible on Monday to obtain their assistance.[…] Nenagh Urban District Council said the question of prosecuting SFADCo and Tubex was being examined both by the UDC and Tipperary (North Riding) County Council. An alternative borehole had been drilled, the UDC added, and further tests would be carried out by the health board before the supply was declared fit for human consumption. Despite a request to do so, the UDC did not deal in its statement with the EPA suggestion that its own sewer may have been a contributory factor to the pollution.[…] Greenpeace said that the EPA report had left questions unanswered.  "In particular, the report calls into question the effectiveness of a system which has allowed industrial operations to continue unlicensed, and therefore presumably unmonitored, while posing such a serious threat to public health and the environment. Greenpeace requests the EPA to state on what legal grounds operations are to be allowed to continue until a decision is made whether or not to issue a licence," it said in a statement.[…]

title: Nigeria;A Festering Sore
news: The Mobil Idaho spillage which occurred when a 12-inch pipeline belonging to Mobil Producing Nig. Unlimited, ruptured in 1 1998 is on record as one of the worst singular cases of oil spillage in Nigeria. […] Available data put the number of oil spill incidents in Nigeria between 1976 and 1996 at about 4,560. About 2.6 million barrels of oil were recorded as having been spilled during this period. A survey carried out by Dr. Alex Chindah and Solomon Braide of the Institute of Pollution Studies, Rivers State University of Science and Technology, Port Harcourt claimed that over 80 percent of the oil spilled were left unrecovered in the areas affected. The CHEVRON Nigeria Limited's Manager Safety and Environment, Mr. Charles Morris, confirmed these findings in an interview he granted an environmental magazine, 'NatureWatch' some time in December last year. Asked about CHEVRON 's response to incidents of oil spillage, Morris explained that the oil firm had installed some equipment in all its areas of operation in order to effect a zero spill. But he admitted that oil spill in some areas like the mangrove swamp is left to "biodrade itself than to destroy the natural habitat." […] It is not clear if the immediate community in Akwa Ibom where the incident took place have been duly compensated. According to a human rights activist/lawyer and Mr. Femi Falana, this is largely due to the attitude of the federal government which gives moral support to the activities of the oil companies through its 1978 Land Use Act which turns any oil exploration area to a federal government zone. […]

title: Fujian villagers suffer myriad pollution problems living in shadow of refineries
news: Had there not been dozens of petrochemical plants and tanneries plaguing the environment with a combination of air, water, light, noise and heat pollution, tens of thousands of peasants living in Quangang district of Quanzhou, Fujian, might not have left their homes or fought to be moved by the local government.[...] "The stench emitted by the nearby 'integrated chemical plant' is so vigorous all day long that I can't get rid of it, even though I tightly shut the door and all the windows in my home," said the woman, who identified herself only as Ms  Zheng. The plant she referred to is owned by Fujian Refining and Petrochemical Company and is next to Shicuo. It is a joint venture approved by the State Council in 2007. The partners in the company are Sinopec and the Fujian provincial government, which combine to own half - though the exact shares are not known - and Exxon Mobil and Saudi Aramco  each with a 25 per cent stake.[...] Another resident of the same village did try to voice his frustration. Shi Bixiang , 46, said he had called the provincial environmental protection hotline in 6.[...]

title: CHEVRON confirms Gorgon delays
news: CHEVRON, the leader of the Gorgon LNG joint venture, has formally admitted to customers that it is not likely to meet the 2010 timetable for deliveries. Confirmation of the huge project's inability to meet its previously announced deadline came only 10 days after 25 per cent Gorgon partner Exxon Mobil said a likely delay in the project's final investment decision beyond the end of this year would not affect delivery schedules for 2010. […] It was also learned yesterday that environmental regulatory authorities remain unconvinced that Gorgon's environmental management plan for the LNG plant on Barrow Island satisfies concerns about the effect of dredging on the marine habitat, particularly a nearby nesting area for threatened flatback turtles. Both of these issues could lead to federal Environment Minister Ian Campbell requesting more detailed plans before the project can be approved under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Act. Barrow Island is a Class A nature reserve but the West Australian Parliament has passed legislation that allows the 10 million tonnes a year capacity LNG plant to be built within a footprint of 300ha but only under the strictest environmental controls. The Gorgon partners spent three years developing Australia's most comprehensive draft environmental statement, which runs to more than 3000 pages. Yesterday they released their responses to public submissions on the project's final environmental impact statement. […]

title: Food Corporate Giants Should Reverse the Bitterness of Sugar
news: […] In particular, Oxfam wants these global companies to avoid buying from suppliers that have acquired land from small-scale food producers without these producers' free, prior, and informed consent. Where land has already been acquired without such consent, and the acquisition is in dispute, Oxfam wants the corporations to insist on fair dispute-resolution procedures. "Behind the Brands" includes a score sheet, ranking the Big 10 on a range of issues, including their impact on workers, water, land, women, and climate change. On land issues, Oxfam rates PEPSICO, and ABF either "poor" or "very poor." Nestlé scores better, because its guidelines for suppliers - used for the sourcing of sugar, soy, palm oil, and other commodities - require that they obtain the free, prior, and informed consent of indigenous and local communities before acquiring land.[…]

title: Gas project gets final go-ahead
news: THE CHEVRON-led Gorgon gas project could begin before Christmas if the three joint venture partners follow the Government's final tick of approval with a decision to invest in it. Federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett yesterday announced final environmental approval for the $50 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) project on Barrow Island, off Western Australia's Pilbara coast.Mr Garrett said the island, an A-class nature reserve with several threatened species, would be ``properly protected'' by 28 additional conditions placed on the project partners.[...]CHEVRON greater Gorgon area general manager Colin Beckett said it had already committed to $2 billion of contracts.``By Christmas, we would be starting to do some of the initial work on Barrow Island, while in other places we complete our design and get on with the procurement activity.''

title: Letters: Anger simmers over energy bills; These letters appear in the Friday 18th October edition of the Independent
news: […] Ending our addiction to fossil fuels, slashing energy waste and developing the United Kingdom's huge renewable energy resources would not only provide us with an affordable energy system, it would also help combat the growing threat of climate change. Last month major financial institutions, including the BANK OF AMERICA and the insurance giant Aviva, accused the Government of scaring off investment in Britain's renewable energy sector because of its refusal to include a power-sector decarbonisation target in its Energy Bill. Many peers in the House of Lords are known to share this view, and look increasingly likely to reverse the Government's block on a decarbonisation target later this month. Faced with fresh scientific warnings about the impacts of climate change and the urgent need to fix our broken energy system the Government must drop its opposition to a clean power target. Andy Atkins, Executive Director,  Friends of the Earth,  London N1. […]

title: BHP, Exxon set to approve $9.5b floating LNG venture off WA coast; Resources
news: BHP Billiton and ExxonMobil could approve a new $US10 billion ($9.56 billion) gas project in Australian waters as early as next year, documents published on Tuesday show. The companies released planning documents for their proposed Scarborough joint venture, off Western Australia's coast, and declared that a floating LNG system was their preferred option for developing the resource. [...] In documents submitted to the federal Environment Department, Exxon and BHP said the floating platform would be 495-metres long and 75-metres wide, and would house the equipment needed for gas treatment, liquefaction and transfer into vessels that will ship the product to market. [...]

title: Diverse groups support Labor's Cape blueprint
news: THE Queensland Labor Party has won widespread backing for its blueprint to secure a viable economic future for Cape York without upsetting its culture and environment. Building on the ground-breaking co-operation of the existing Cape York Heads of Agreement, the plan has been developed in consultation with Aboriginal, environmental and industry interests. […] Opposition Leader Peter Beattie said last night the deal meant major developments could proceed under a Labor government instead of stalling because of native title uncertainty. "The CHEVRON gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea, Alcan's bauxite mine, an expanded live cattle trade out of Weipa and space launch facility near Weipa will be able to move forward," he said. […]The conservation groups said the deal boosted the prospects for reconciliation and the Cape's protection and was a commonsense approach compared with the Borbidge Government's divisive approach.[…] Mr Beattie, who will release his "new directions statement" today, said it would allow development within a sound environmental framework, protect the rights of traditional owners and follow processes laid down in the land use study's stage-two report.[…]

title: How to fight a green backlash
news: PRWeek and research firm Populus surveyed consumers on changing attitudes to the environment. Arun Sudhaman examines what the findings mean for communicators. It is not easy being green. [...] Already this year, there has been a backlash against recycling from newspapers pointing to a collapse in the world market for recycled material. Firms such as Microsoft are believed to be taking a long, hard look at their corporate social responsibility (CSR) PR budgets (PRWeek 24 April), while NGOs have accused corporations of cutting spending on environmental schemes. [...] On the other hand, the downturn in recycling has forced recycling bodies such as WRAP, and local councils, to rethink their comms strategies. 'It's about positioning the work in terms of wasting less,' says Coca-Cola citizenship manager Liz Lowe. [...] Coca-Cola is part of the Together partnership - an industry group Lowe says is very focused on a 'value message'. 'It's not just save the planet, but it's save money.' [...]

title: Chevron Stays in Poland; PLN100bn on Army
news: Poland has received 10 new applications for shale gas concessions, including offshore exploration. Chevron will obtain the permit for deeper wells, announced Deputy Minister of Environment Piotr Wozniak in response to MEP Boguslaw Sonik's predictions that Chevron might cancel its shale gas activities in Poland should the law remain unchanged. [...] Some cases require a full environmental report, including a one-year-long site observation. [...] ExxonMobil, Talisman Energy and Marathon Oil have already withdrawn from shale gas investments in Poland due to negative drilling results and corporate savings. [...]

title: Hammer isn't enough to buy their mine rights; Letter from Indonesia
news: Titus Natkime, 31, the son of a tribal leader who encountered the first Americans to walk into the wilderness of Papua nearly 50 years ago, shared some dispatches from his employer, the American mining company, Freeport-McMoRan. For generations, Natkime's clan has laid claim to much of the land in the Indonesian province of Papua, where Freeport mines some of the world's largest copper and gold reserves. Now it is time for a payback, he said. A draft document showed Freeport's recent offer: $250,000 to set up a foundation for the clan, plus $100,000 annually, a sizable amount in Indonesia's most remote and poorest province. […] That said, the protests in Papua have shown what can happen when a natural resources company, backed by an unpopular central government and a heavy-handed military, fails to pay careful attention to the local people whose lives have been disturbed, and who feel the riches in the ground are theirs, not the foreigners. This month CITIGROUP echoed the theme, saying in a report that such companies could no longer afford to ignore environmental and social issues. ''In recent years, a groundswell of public opinion has caused sustainable development to become a serious business consideration for investors,'' the report said. Mark Logsdon, an American geochemist who has visited the Freeport mine, agreed. Mining companies must seek and take seriously the ''consent of the governed,'' he said. ''Whether in Indonesia, Latin America or Africa, the increase in communications capability means that the essential isolation of 'resource colonies' is largely a thing of the past.'' […]

title: Pepsi 'cracks code' with all plant bottle
news: Pepsi unveiled a new bottle yesterday made entirely of plant material that it says bests the technology of competitor Coca-Cola and reduces bottles' carbon footprint. [...] Coca-Cola said it welcomed advances in packaging, noting it has scaled up use of its own plant-based bottles. It also says it has demonstrated a 100 per cent plant bottle in the lab and is still ensuring it is commercially viable. [...]

title: Run, don't walk, to greenhouse solutions; CAPITAL IDEA
news: […] As is apparent from a report released recently by CITIGROUP's broking arm, companies slow to deal with global warming will suffer financially. […]Wind power looks increasingly viable as a minor renewable player (other than on calms days). Solar power is undeniably renewable but still expensive after decades of research. For large-scale use to occur, a commercial breakthrough needs to happen within a few years, not a few more decades. This leaves six plausible ways of generating electricity regardless of the weather - coal (dirty or clean), natural gas (dirty or clean), geothermal and nuclear. The latter two have the advantage of zero emissions at the generating stage, unless coal or gas are cleaned up by removing the carbon dioxide produced in generating power. […]

title: A Safe House?
news: FELICIA BUSTO-FRAIM always kept her Flushing, N.Y., home clean with traditional brand-name cleaning products like Windex and Fantastik. But her attitude changed the day her daughters' school switched to environmentally friendly cleaning products.    ''You could tell the difference,'' said Ms. Busto-Fraim, 37, a former prosecutor who now stays at home to care for her three children. ''You didn't have that disgusting disinfectant smell when you walked into the bathrooms anymore.''[…] There is no government organization that evaluates both conventional and ''green'' products and rates their safety. Enesta Jones, a spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Agency, said it was not possible to say if ''green'' products are safer than traditional cleaners without knowing the specific product chemistry.   The Consumer Product Safety Commission requires the labels of products that are potentially life-threatening to include signal words like ''danger,'' ''poison,'' ''warning'' and ''caution.''  Federal law doesn't require full disclosure of all the chemical ingredients. Ross Holthouse, external relations manager for fabric and home care at PROCTER & GAMBLE, which makes Tide and Cheer, said that listing the 300 to 400 raw ingredients in detergent, for example, could be confusing to consumers and might reveal trade secrets. PROCTER & GAMBLE lists active ingredients as well as substances such as dyes or fragrances that could be important to consumers with allergies, Mr. Holthouse said. He said that PROCTER & GAMBLE employs ''Ph.D. toxicologists both from a human safety standpoint as well an environmental safety standpoint to make sure our products are safe before we even think about putting them on the market.''   A Kids Safe Chemicals Act, proposed in 2005, would require that all chemicals used in the home be evaluated for their safety to children, and require companies to list ingredients containing mutagens, hormone or endocrine disrupters, neurotoxins or carcinogens. Senator Frank Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat, said he planned to re-introduce the legislation this year. […]

title: Uganda; Caltex Gets Modern Terminal
news: CHEVRON Uganda, the parent company of Caltex, has commissioned a modern loading terminal at its depot in Industrial Area, Kampala. The $1m (about sh1.7b) terminal is expected to enable the company dispense petroleum products more safely and efficiently. Kamanda Bantaringaya, the mineral development state minister, commissioned the terminal on Wednesday. Bantaringaya said the amount of money that CHEVRON invested in the project is a reflection of the confidence the company has in the country. George Wall, the CHEVRON Global Logistic general manager, said environment protection is very key in the way they conduct business. "Proving products and services safely and reliably with a view to protecting the environment is very important to CHEVRON. "This new terminal was designed and developed to meet the highest standards of operations," he said.

title: Synagro to sell in Chapter 11
news: Carlyle Group-backed Synagro Technologies Inc.on Wednesday, April 24, filed for bankruptcy protection to sell its assets in a deal valued at $455 million.[…] To complete the deal, Synagro has lined up a $30 million debtor-in-possession loan from certain existing lenders led by BANK OF AMERICA NA. Founded in 1986, Synagro is a renewable energy company that converts industrial and municipal waste into environmentally sustainable resources. The company said it is the largest recycler of organic byproducts in the U.S., serving more than 600 municipal and industrial water and wastewater facilities.[…]

title: Gorgon gas scrutiny
news: CHEVRON CASTS ITS GAZE OVER EXPENSIVE PROJECT. Resources. THE $15 billion yet-to-be-launched Gorgon gas project off the coast of Western Australia is under review following a string of cost blowouts in major oil and gas projects worldwide. CHEVRON chief executive David O'Reilly told analysts in New York that the company was having another look at Gorgon, the most expensive project in its pipeline. […] CHEVRON may also consider reworking the design of the project after completing tests on the Clio-1 gas discovery in the heart of the Gorgon project area, which the company has described as ''one of the top wells in Australia in terms of total net pay''. CHEVRON vice-president George Kirkland told analysts the Gorgon project faced a number of challenges, including market-related cost increases. However, he said the company expected a decision on permits for the project by mid-year. The WA Government had threatened to block the Gorgon project due to concerns it posed a threat to an endangered species of turtle, but gave it the green light after CHEVRON put up an extra $60 million for conservation programs. CHEVRON also confirmed reports in the United States that it had dropped plans for an offshore LNG terminal off Mexico which was to have taken gas from Gorgon. […]

title: True Green: Lessons from 1960s'-70s' Counterculture Archiecture
news: […] Notions of sustainability, ephemeralization, simplifying life, and reducing our carbon footprint have come full circle and seem more urgent today than ever before. But while the shaggy '60s may be up for review, they come with a haircut, shorn as they are of the social/cultural revolution that drove them. And the question remains, can you have one without the other? True sustainability without sweeping social change? True green without revolution? Consumers beware: When one hears companies like Exxon, General Motors, and MERCK Chemical talking green, then you know it's probably time to check in with Alice and slide back down the rabbit hole.[…]

title: So How Contaminated Is the Old Nuclear Plant?
news: […] From 1952 to 1966, when operations ceased and the plant was torn down, the Hicksville factory worked mostly with uranium and thorium, churning out nuclear reactor fuel for research and possibly for government manufacture at other sites of plutonium used in nuclear weapons. In the process, it vented gas into the air and discharged wastes laced with industrial solvents and radioactive substances into recharge basins and leaching pools. Now, 50 years later, radiological and chemical contamination of soil and groundwater remains at the former plant -- one of a string of low-profile nuclear weapons sites across the country that came to light in an article published by USA Today in 6. There are disagreements over the threat this contamination poses. The state Department of Environmental Conservation, the government agency most directly involved, says it is confident the risk is low. "We have studied this thing inside out and continue to do so, and we are not finding contaminants that pose a substantial risk, or pathways of exposure," said Mark Lowery, a department spokesman. The department said it was stringently overseeing a voluntary cleanup being carried out by VERIZON, Sylvania's corporate successor, and would see to it that all necessary remediation is done.[…] But the Star Foundation of East Hampton, a group involved with nuclear contamination issues and headed by a former Energy Department official, contends that a problem of unknown but potentially significant dimensions is being glossed over.The foundation says that far greater government effort, including federal involvement, is needed to find out the full extent of the contamination, to gauge the threats to wells supplying drinking water and to assess past and present health risks. […] Leaders of a civic association in Jericho Gardens, a Hicksville neighborhood west of the site, said that they, too, were satisfied with the state and VERIZON efforts. "I don't see any reason for concern," said Cynthia Perkins-Roberts, a past president. "Maybe if someone can show some documentation, we'll feel differently."[…] Sharon Cohen-Hagar, a VERIZON spokeswoman, confirmed that the company was cooperating with the state in a voluntary cleanup. She said that GTE Operations Support was carrying out the work. GTE, which acquired Sylvania, merged two years ago with Bell Atlantic to become VERIZON.[…] There is some disagreement about what the Hicksville plant made. Ms. Cohen-Hagar said it was the company's understanding that it manufactured reactor parts including nuclear fuel rods that were used for electric power generation and research. She said that a search of company records found no evidence that nuclear fuel was recycled at the site.[…]

title: DISNEY plans new attractions
news: Highlighting the changes to come at Animal Kingdom will be a midway-styled park and a 1,293-room, four-star hotel. WALT DISNEY Co. is adding midway games and a pair of new rides in a retro carnival setting to Disney's Animal Kingdom to pep up the park's appeal.[…] While the park's attendance has met DISNEY expectations, many younger patrons find the focus on ecological education, passive attractions and a few rides too boring. The new carnival setting is aimed at winning their favor, but it posed creative challenges to DISNEY designers who are obsessed with honoring founder WALT DISNEY's anti-carnival sentiment.[…]

title: Al Ahlia Gulf Line Reduces Energy Consumption By 20%
news: HIGHLIGHT: UAE-based Al Ahlia Gulf Line, a licensed bottler and distributor of The Coca-Cola Company brands in the UAE and Oman, has reduced its energy consumption by 20% following an upgrade of its water production line with Sidel's ECO Booster services. [...] Al Ahlia Gulf Lines' plan to lower its carbon footprint and energy consumption is in line with the ecological initiatives of the local government, according to Factory Manager Ravikanth Uppaluru (Packaging News). 'We are committed to produce in an environment-friendly manner, reduce our environmental impact and use resources efficiently,' Uppaluru added.

title: Rogers AT&T rejects role of ecoterrorism in disruption
news: A group of would-be ecoterrorists upset with the U.S. government's withdrawal from the Kyoto climate-change accord is claiming responsibility for playing havoc with Canada's largest cellular-telephone network over the weekend.  And though officials with Rogers AT&T said they appreciate the group's attempt to take the blame, they said the problems that left a large number of Canadians without cellphones on Saturday were Rogers' own. "It's nice of these people to claim responsibility for the trouble our customers encountered, but the buck stops here," said Heather Armstrong, assistant vice-president of communications for Rogers AT&T Wireless. "This problem was an internal processing error and we take full responsibility."  The problems began around 3:30 Saturday afternoon when some of the company's 2.6 million cellphone users were prevented from making or receiving calls because of internal computer problems with the Rogers AT&T Wireless network.[…]  Yesterday, someone called The Globe and Mail claiming to be from a group called Students Defending Canadian Air and, with the voice digitized as a disguise, said the group was responsible for the shutdown. "George Bush declared environmental war on Canada by withdrawing from Kyoto and promoting additional fossil-fuel use, especially coal," the electronic voice said. "Its poison gases are coming into Canada in increasing amounts.  "We will continue attacking American companies such as AT&T in order to fight back against the poisoning of our people," the voice added. "We gave Rogers advanced notice. They chose not to warn their customers." […]  Restoring the network took 12 hours because every component of the computer system need to be examined, Ms. Armstrong said. Rogers AT&T Wireless's network is set up so that problems can be anticipated and fixed before they affect the customer, but this particular one caught experts by surprise. […]

title: Gorgon LNG gets environmental approval; Western Australia imposes stringent conditions on CHEVRON-operated project
news: The Western Australian state government gave its environmental approval for the proposed Gorgon LNG project on Barrow Island September 7 after Environment and Climate Change Minister David Templeman signed off on a set of stringent conditions for development. The approval was the second piece of good news for the multi-billion-dollar Gorgon project for the week, following Shell's announcement September 4 it had agreed to sell 1 million mt/year of its equity output to Chinese state-owned oil and gas major PetroChina (ON 9/5). The project still requires environmental approvals from the Australian federal government. […] CHEVRON said the Western Australian state conditions were some of the most stringent imposed on a major project anywhere in the world for Barrow Island, which is a nature reserve. Among the 36 state ministerial conditions are requirements that the joint venture establish a reservoir carbon dioxide injection system, as well as expert panels to protect the unique biodiversity of Barrow Island and the surrounding marine environment. CHEVRON previously had said it expected to spend a total of A$850 million ($704 million) on the Gorgon carbon sequestration project, which has the potential to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions by up to 3 million mt/year. The Gorgon project is held 50% by CHEVRON and 25% each by Shell and ExxonMobil. CHEVRON's plans for the development, based on offshore gas reserves totaling more than 40 Tcf, currently envisage construction of a two-train liquefaction plant on Barrow Island to produce 10 million mt/year of LNG. […]

title: Three firms make record bid to explore offshore Nfld. for oil
news: Three major petroleum companies have bid a record $672.7-million to explore for oil in the Orphan Basin in the Atlantic Ocean, forming a joint venture to drill deeply into offshore fields believed to contain huge reserves. The Canada-Newfoundland Offshore Petroleum Board said yesterday that the bidders captured eight exploration parcels, where the waters are 2,000 to 3,000 metres deep. New seismic surveys indicate enormous oil deposits could be buried another 2,000 to 5,000 metres beneath the ocean floor. CHEVRONTEXACO Corp. has a 50-per-cent stake in the venture, while Exxon Mobil Corp. and Imperial Oil Ltd. each hold 25 per cent. […] The Orphan Basin is located north of the relatively shallow waters of the Jeanne d'Arc Basin, home to the Hibernia and Terra Nova oil projects. A seismic study shows that there could be at least four pools of oil that may each be larger than the Hibernia field, which is listed as having held up to 884 million barrels of recoverable reserves. Another 11 oil deposits in the Orphan Basin also appear to be large, according to seismic data. "On a cautionary note, this environment is challenging," said Paul Barnes, manager in Atlantic Canada for the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers. "There are environmental challenges that increase costs and also a heavy regulatory burden that the government is working to address." […]

title: Small firms urged to use green technology
news: Small and medium enterprises (SME) should invest more in green technology which, while more expensive, will translate to bigger savings and help the environment in the long run, information technology (IT) experts said yesterday. Small businesses can also save energy by optimizing the use of available hardware, experts at the Ayala ICT (information and communications technology) forum in Mandaluyong City said. Alex SL Tay, IBM Asia-Pacific regional manager of facilities and services, said the "motivation [to go green] is the avoidance of some kind of pain." For some companies, he added, being more efficient and cost-effective is a matter of survival.[…]

title: Front: Carbon bubble 'creates global economic risk': Economists fear massive losses on overvalued oil, coal and gas reserves
news: The world could be heading for a major economic crisis as stock markets inflate an investment bubble in fossil fuels to the tune of trillions of dollars, according to leading economists. […] The stark report is by Stern and Carbon Tracker, a thinktank supported by organisations including HSBC, Citi, Standard and Poor's and the International Energy Agency. The Bank of England has also recognised that a collapse in the value of oil, gas and coal assets as nations tackle global warming is a potential systemic risk to the economy, with London being particularly at risk owing to its huge listings of coal. […] The world's governments have agreed to restrict the global temperature rise to 2C, beyond which the impacts become severe and unpredictable. But Stern said the investors clearly did not believe action to curb climate change was going to be taken. "They can't believe that and also believe that the markets are sensibly valued now." […]

title: BHP seeks greener ways to mine; As carbon tax nears, it invests to develop cleaner processes; BUSINESS ASIA by Bloomberg
news: BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, said Monday that it would spend $300 million developing technology and projects to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions as governments widen moves to put a cost on carbon. [...] The risk to earnings from climate change comes from a cost being placed on carbon emissions or from physical weather effects, CITIGROUP said in a Nov. 30 report. The main earnings risk for BHP may come from its coal and petroleum product exports, the report added. [...]

title: Vast central Queensland LNG project may go into mothballs
news: THE multibillion-dollar liquefied natural gas scheme for central Queensland may be shelved because of plunging energy prices and stubbornly high capital costs, broker CITIGROUP said yesterday. A day after Santos lodged its draft environmental impact statement with the State Government, CITIGROUP said weak spot prices for LNG and the collapse of the Japanese economy ``make it increasingly difficult for buyers to agree in price and terms for greenfield volumes''. [...] ``The economics of approving expenditures for new projects have deteriorated to the point where risks have risen significantly enough that projects will be deferred until costs come down further or energy prices rise,'' CITIGROUP said. [...] CITIGROUP also said memories of the North-West Shelf partners' decision to accept contracts at low prices might prompt Santos and others to defer rather than sell. [...] CITIGROUP said long-term prices for LNG were sound.

title: U.S. concerned with Sakhalin shutdown
news: The Bush administration is "very concerned" about the Russian government's decision to revoke Shell's environmental permit for the Sakhalin 2 oil and gas project, the State Department said Friday. "While we're not aware of any similar actions taken against EXXONMobil or other U.S. companies involved [in Russia], we do believe that the actions that have been taken against Shell are concerning," department spokesman Tom Casey told reporters. "And we call on Russia to uphold the commitments on energy, including its commitment on upholding contracts that they made at the St. Petersburg summit." [...]

title: PFIZER Says It Donated to Group That Paid for Two Pataki Trips
news: Another large New York-based corporation with significant interests in Albany said yesterday that it had contributed to a nonprofit trade group that paid for two trips by Gov. George E. Pataki to Hungary. The corporation, PFIZER, the pharmaceuticals conglomerate, said it had given $5,000 to the group, the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce of New York and New Jersey, shortly before the Governor's first trip in 1995. "We did make a contribution back then to the trip," said Bob Fauteux, a spokesman for PFIZER. "We were happy to support the Governor in his outreach to Hungary."  PFIZER, which owns factories in New York and is closely regulated by state environmental officials, is the fourth corporation to disclose its involvement with the chamber and trips. The others are another drug company, Bristol-Myers Squibb; Philip Morris, the cigarette maker, and Pepsico. All four companies were also big donors to the private corporation that Mr. Pataki set up to pay for his 1995 inaugural.[…]

title: Japan players targeting eco-friendly role on world stage
news: Japan players targeting eco-friendly role on world stage  Japanese electronics makers are positioning themselves to prosper in the coming era of LED lighting. Given tough overseas competitors, however, and the fact LEDs are not regularly replaced like incandescent lamps, their business model faces challenges.  [...] However, major foreign producers seem already well-primed for the LED battle, given that they have had to satisfy environment-minded Western consumers and compete with start-ups, according to Kota Ezawa, an analyst at Nikko CITIGROUP Ltd. Philips has gained a large number of next-generation lighting technologies through corporate acquisitions. The electronics giant now plans to fully enter the Japanese lighting market in a tie-up with a Yamagiwa Corp. group firm[...]

title: The hardest working pill on the market; Viagra can do much more than just save your sex life
news: […] Now, there seems to be another good reason to appreciate them -- they may help to save some of the planet's endangered animal species. Evidence is mounting that men who used to rely on concoctions such as tiger penis soup and powdered rhinoceros horn are finding the convenient and fast-acting pills a good alternative. One landmark study, done in 2004 by Australian researchers led by William von Hippel, involved 256 Chinese men, aged 50 to 76 years. All were receiving treatment at a traditional Chinese medicine clinic in Hong Kong. The scientists found these consumers reported selectively switching to Western medicines to treat erectile dysfunction or ED, but not to treat other health ailments, such as gout and arthritis. And, while they acknowledge it is hard to get data on the trade of contraband animal parts, they found the price of the male genitalia of Canadian seals remained low in 2001 and 2002, despite improved markets for pelts and oil from these animals.
