They conclude that "this depressed trade in seal penises, in combination with our survey of traditional Chinese medicine consumers, indicates that Viagra [which was introduced in 1998] and other new erectile dysfunction drugs may be having a conservation benefit, at least with regard to certain animal species." Critics, including Craig Hoover of the World Wildlife Fund, have challenged von Hippel's interpretation of the data, noting other factors -- such as ice conditions and the ending of Canadian government subsidies on seal meat -- may have affected the seal harvest, which is primarily about pelts and not penises anyway. Still, if even some habitual users of endangered species' organs switch to a pill, it's a step in the right direction.[…] Many thoughtful analysts feel Asian men who have been steeped in this tradition will not be interested in taking a pill that, according to its manufacturer PFIZER Inc., "enhances the effect of nitric oxide by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5, which is responsible for degradation of cGMP in the corpus cavernosum." In fact, there may be even some movement from Viagra to herbal measures. A Calgary-based talk radio station has been running ads for a herbal preparation for erectile dysfunction. The company even has a 1-800 number for a free sample by mail. Cost may also be a consideration, since sometimes, herbal preparations are cheaper than prescription drugs.[…] As Viagra passes its 10th anniversary of commercial availability, work is ongoing to make it even better. PFIZER has patented a water soluble form of the drug that could be put into a fast-acting nasal spray. Comedy sketch writers will probably have a field day describing guys falling out of bed while groping for their inhalers.[…]

title: Natural gas's green image could be hot air, say scientists; Natural gas has been touted as a vital stepping stone in the transition away from petroleum, but a new study suggests that without clear policy gas could divert investment in renewables.
news: Natural gas may not be of much use as a "bridge" fuel en route to achieving significant cuts in greenhouse-gas emissions unless its use is accompanied by rigorous policies aimed at curbing emissions - policies that some analysts say should be designed to harness gas as an ally of renewable-energy sources, rather that as a competitor. […] Another approach, suggested by analysts at Citi Research, a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc., would relegate gas to a supporting role [for] to renewables. Under that model, gas-fired power plants would provide the additional electricity needed to meet demand only during times when wind or solar sources are least productive. […]

title: Push behind IGCC technology strengthens, with 2,900 MW of projects under study
news: The combination of high natural gas prices and mounting concerns over coal emissions is putting integrated gasification combined-cycle power generating units on the map, all the more so as General Electric is getting behind the technology. Currently, there are only four coal-fueled IGCC facilities operating around the world, with just over 1,000 MW of capacity in aggregate, that were brought on stream between 1994 and 1997. Now, following the two-year run-up in natural gas prices in North America, at least five new IGCC facilities with a projected total capacity of roughly 2,900 MW are under study. In recent months, IGCC advocates in academia have surfaced, arguing on behalf of the technologies' relative environmental cleanliness. Financial analysts have run the numbers and argued that as long as natural gas prices remain above $4.50 to $5.00 mmBtu, the economics of IGCC look favorable. Companies have, as well, been tapping the willingness of the U.S. government's Dept. of Energy to provide seed money for clean coal projects. […] Last spring, GE Energy, a division of General Electric Co., launched its purchase of CHEVRONTEXACO's gasification technology business. […] With its acquisition, GE joined ConocoPhillips, Royal Dutch/Shell and Krupp Uhde as active IGCC technology vendors. GE said the acquisition would enable it to "create an even broader portfolio of products and services for energy and industrial applications worldwide," though John Rice, CEO of GE Energy, conceded that full commercialization may still be a year or two away. […]

title: IN BRIEF
news: [...] $50b gas project The West Australian Government has given final environmental approval to the nation's biggest resource project. Environment Minister Donna Faragher announced yesterday the latest step in the process towards development of the expanded $50 billion CHEVRON-led Gorgon liquefied natural gas project on Barrow Island. Ms Faragher said final approval for the project was granted with "strong, new environmental conditions to provide higher levels of protection for regionally significant coral reefs and flatback marine turtles". The project's environmental approval process is now in the hands of federal Environment, Heritage and Arts Minister Peter Garrett, who visited Barrow Island last week.[...] . Barton robbery Police are searching for two robbers who mugged a man in Barton, grabbed his neck before stealing his backpack. The 21-year-old victim was walking along Brisbane Avenue on Sunday evening near Young Street when he was attacked. The victim reported the incident to the nearby AFP college. [...]

title: CAPE CRUSADERS
news: The Cape York Heads of Agreement signed between local Aboriginal groups and pastoralists early this year was hailed as the way ahead for land rights negotiations. But controversy remains about the role of government, especially that of the Borbidge Coalition. […] During the past few months, a group including Pearson's Cape York Land Council, the Alcan aluminium company, Korean proponents of a space base, pastoralists and a clutch of environmental groups have settled on an agreement for the development of Queensland's northern peninsula. The agreement is intended to build on the widely publicised Cape York Heads of Agreement which was pushed as a model for negotiated settlement of native title rights between pastoralists and local Aborigines.  […]Peak environmental groups were dealt into the agreement with the promise that the entire Cape region would be assessed for World Heritage values.[…] Key aspects of the latest agreement include brokering support for the return of some Aboriginal land, upgrading pastoral leaseholder tenure, finding an acceptable site for the much-touted Cape York space base and facilitating the CHEVRON gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea.[…]Management of the diverse interests in the harsh Cape country always has been difficult. For decades, the history of such development has been marked by conflict among environmental concerns, the pastoral industry and traditional communities. […] According to Beattie, the agreement negotiated "is the sort of model that can break through all the political nonsense"."It allows jobs and protects the indigenous culture and the environment. It locks up certain areas, upgrades infrastructure, allows big development projects to proceed and improves the tenure for pastoralists. It's a win-win situation for everyone."[…]

title: Report says officials are shortsighted big spenders
news: Government officials are guilty of wasting money on low-quality projects in order to improve their political records, according to a Xinhua commentary.[…]  Huang Yiping, China economist with CITIGROUP in Hong Kong, said the problems carried serious economic consequences and put pressure on an already fragile banking system.  He said local governments were often eager to impress the central leaders and had splashed out heavily to push up growth rates.  "They seldom think about efficiency and are not willing to put money into projects that do not generate visible benefits, such as environmental protection and social security," he said.

title: China and the US clean up on emissions; The scale of the two nations' agreement is breathtaking - but it serves their interests, too
news: Suddenly, a low-carbon world seems possible. Yesterday the United States and China - responsible for some 40 per cent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions, and long the world's greatest climate adversaries - agreed to clean them up, and far faster than expected. […] Where we, and Europe, do outpace the US is in the short term. Calculated from the same baseline, Britain is committed to reducing emissions by 24 per cent by 2020 and 42 per cent by 2025, compared with 17 and 26-28 per cent by the US. So, is it better or worse to take early action? Studies show that it is cheaper, but climate sceptics say that economic growth will make us richer in the future, when we would therefore be in a better position to bear the costs. But the sums aren't outrageous. A report by representatives of the World Bank, the OECD, the Bank of England, the BANK OF AMERICA and other luminaries concluded last month that the cost by 2030 would be just 1.7 per cent of global consumption, equivalent to delaying a given level of prosperity by six months. Of course, some energy-intensive industries could suffer disproportionately, but the cost of carbon in Britain is about the middle of the global range.[…]

title: Petrodollars
news: Poland may claim its newly-presented draft hydrocarbon tax regime makes it one of the most attractive places to explore for shale gas in the world, but the country is still reeling from a huge loss of confidence in the sector after a major reserves downgrade and the exit of ExxonMobil. [...] "We did not observe a basic commercial level of hydrocarbons flow in our two wells in the Lublin and Podlasie basins," Adam Kopysc, a spokesman for ExxonMobil Exploration and Production Poland, said of its decision to leave Poland. [...] Another obstacle to a large-scale gas producing business is the fact that the ownership structure of property in Poland is different from the US: explorers do not own the land and have to pay royalties. There are also other environmental factors--the availability of water could be a concern given that hydraulic fracturing requires large volumes of water. [...]

title: Lenovo to reduce GHG, recycle computers
news: Lenovo Group Ltd. is taking steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and has implemented a free consumer electronics recycling program.  The computer maker joined the The Climate Group, a nonprofit organization that helps businesses switch to a low-carbon economy. As part of its membership, Lenovo unveiled a program to reward consumers for recycling old devices and offers them incentives to power their new computers with renewable energy.[…] Separately, the company is working with ECO International, a Vestal, N.Y.-based asset management and electronics recycling company, to offer consumers and small businesses free recycling of Lenovo and IBM products.

title: For Urban Wastelands, Tomatoes and Other Life
news: On an industrial strip in Buffalo, where just over a year ago the remains of a steel mill sagged on an oil-soaked lot, bumblebees now dance among the yellow blossoms of 170,000 tomato plants growing in artificial soil in a computer-controlled greenhouse. This month, 125 workers will start picking what the greenhouse company says will be at least seven million pounds of vine-ripened tomatoes each year.[…] Adding momentum to the shift, many private environmental groups that once aggressively fought to have all contaminated parcels cleaned to a single high standard now are supporting state and Federal efforts to set different standards of cleanliness depending on the eventual use of each site. In other words, dirt under a new parking lot need not be as clean as dirt in a new playground. The technology of cleaning spills and other contamination has also improved, lowering costs."There was a time when many people saw a leaking underground tank as a half-million-dollar issue," said Randy Muller, vice president of environmental services at the BANK OF AMERICA, in Chicago. "We see that as a $35,000 issue."The condition of abandoned industrial sites still varies tremendously from state to state and city to city. Some spots with severe liabilities will never find a market. And even in places where sites are being restored, mainly the most valuable ones -- "the low-hanging fruit," in the words of one Federal environmental official -- have been rehabilitated so far.[…]

title: Miners to bear cost of climate toll
news: RESOURCE companies, along with transporter Toll and insurers such as QBE, are expected to be among those Australian companies hardest hit by the effects of climate change, according to a study by investment bank CITIGROUP. The bank this week will release what it hails as the first major study into the expected effect of global warming on the top-100 companies listed on the Australian Securities Exchange.[…] The CITIGROUP report will coincide with an expected announcement from the federal Government, which this week will table the details of its business-aligned task force into a carbon trading system.[…] CITIGROUP director of global strategy Bruce Rolph said investors were beginning to exert pressure on asset managers to assess the effect of global warming on their share portfolios. […] The CITIGROUP study also found parts of the health sector could benefit from climate change because of a forecast jump in tropical diseases. […]

title: Chile's Guacolda shortlists banks to fund $300 mil project financing
news: Chile's Electrica Guacolda SA shortlisted three bank groups to provide $300 million in project financing backing the $400 million construction of two plants and the expansion of existing units. The bidders are CITIGROUP/BNP; Calyon; WestLB. Guacolda is to make a decision imminently. The winner would provide $300 million in project financing, but at this point, the composition of the tranches has yet to be defined, a source close to the deal told Platts. […] The two plants, Nueva Ventanas and Guacolda-III with total installed capacity of 450 MW are under going an environmental impact review process. […] Guacolda is based in Huasco, 700 kilometers north of Santiago. It comprises two coal-fired plants and was designed to use a wide range of coals.

title: Sparks fly as Beattie warns on power play
news: PREMIER Peter Beattie has warned that the creation of a deregulated national electricity market will hammer state budgets by slashing dividends to taxpayers from power companies. He has also foreshadowed a new approach to power industry policy to protect taxpayers from the impact of possible cuts in government income. It will include a stronger push for the use of gas for electricity generation and Government insistence that new power station proposals include private investment. Mr Beattie said yesterday that he was looking forward to reductions in power costs for consumers expected from the deregulation. […] The strategy would link with a plan under consideration to cut greenhouse gas emissions in the electricity industry by requiring retailers to source more of their supplies from gas generation. It involved further pursuit of gas supplies such as that which would come from the proposed CHEVRON Gas Pipeline from Papua New Guinea to Queensland. "Gas-fired electricity has the potential to reduce greenhouse emissions of any new power stations by up to 60 percent," Mr Beattie said. […]

title: Customers want evidence for green claims; Special report In association with Carbon Trust Green growth Genuine eco credentials help businesses to build a loyal customer base, says Andrew Stone
news: UK consumers are highly suspicious of corporate greenwash and British firms have an uphill battle convincing their customers that their efforts to be greener are genuine. Only 7pc of the public believe company claims to be acting on climate change, according to a survey carried out by the Carbon Trust. However, it's not all bad news for companies that are deciding to go green. The same study discovered that while consumers may be sceptical, they are not cynical. It found a growing urge from consumers for companies to improve their environmental records and to help them make greener choices when they shop. […] Companies such as the John Lewis Partnership (or John Lewis and Waitrose), which manage to align their environmental activities in a way that complements the brand and the products they sell will be the ones that succeed, says Peter Walshe, global director of BrandZ, a global brand equity study. Without this link there's a risk that environmental messages will get lost or that they will be dismissed as greenwash, says Mr Walshe. "Just saying something is green is not enough, it needs to be meaningful for the consumer. The Co-op has upped the quality of its game in this respect and it's interesting to see what IBM is doing with its smarter planet agenda - that's beginning to resonate with people. "Our research shows that taking action on climate change represents a 2pc sales increase or decrease for businesses to play for. As awareness rises of the considerable role of business emissions in climate change, I expect an imminent backlash against companies that do not perform or cannot prove their actions are measurable and authentic." The companies that attract and keep the most customers will be the ones that demonstrate a long-term vision and commitment to sustainabiliry, while those that merely seek incremental change will lose out to the visionaries, says Mr Morrison.[…]

title: BP Wind: Green and black
news: BP's response to the Gulf of Mexico attracted much negative public attention, and its likely bill for clean-up costs left it looking financially vulnerable. But during this difficult period, when an independent BP looked in doubt, it still managed to close a pair of wind financings. As it moves to sell $30 billion in assets to pay the bill for the spill and rebuild its public image, its wind portfolio continues to grow. [...] While everyone from investors to rating agencies expressed concerns over the long-term viability of BP, project finance banks did not. Pricing on bank loans for both the Fowler Ridge (closed 20 8) and Goshen (closed May) plants was 275bp over Libor, in line with other wind deals that closed at the time. For example, a $496 million loan for phases two through five of Terra-Gen's 726MW Alta wind plant priced at 275bp over Libor in 7. Credit Agricole was administrative agent for the loan that complemented a $580.2 billion bond issuance arranged by Citi, Barclays Capital and Credit Suisse. The bond carried a 7% coupon. [...]

title: Tesco adopts revised carbon footprint label
news: The Carbon Trust has revamped its controversial Carbon Reduction Label - dropping the arrow symbol in favour of a footprint. The new-look black and white label, displays the CO2 emissions of the product in grams and has already been adopted by Tesco, which this week started displaying the symbol on 20 products across orange juices, potatoes, light bulbs and washing detergents. Last year suppliers including PROCTER & GAMBLE criticised the old label, saying it was "too complicated for consumers". The Carbon Trust said it had revised the label to make it clearer.  "Our aim is to establish the best possible form of communication that appeals to consumers and encourages them to factor carbon impact into their purchasing decisions," a spokeswoman said. Companies including Walkers and Innocent, which currently use the old label, would soon switch to the new label, she added.  Tesco's decision to adopt the scheme is a boost for the label because the retailer had considered launching its own rival scheme. Tesco shoppers will now be able to compare the carbon impact of similar Tesco products for the first time. The label for chilled orange juice, for example, states ambient orange juice has a footprint of 240g per 250ml serving compared with 360g per 250ml serving for chilled orange juice because less energy is required to transport and chill ambient juice.

title: IN BRIEFEnvironment
news: Jacobs lands PFIZER oxidiser contract. PFIZER has awarded a subsidiary company of Jacobs Engineering Group a contract to design and build a thermal oxidiser unit that will collect and pretreat vent emissions from five production areas. Once the project is complete, PFIZER will comply fully with the UK's Solvent Emissions Directive and Pollution Prevention Control legislation. The project will be completed in early 2007. ACC makes call for security mandate. The American Chemistry Council (ACC) is calling for federal regulation mandating that chemical facilities adopt a strong national security standard. […]

title: Pecem 1: Long-term coal
news: MPX Energia and Energias de Portugal (EdP) closed the dollar- and reais-denominated long-term financing for their $1.36 billion Porto do Pecem project in Brazil on 10 7. The financing is the first for a coal project in Brazil, at least for a large one running on imported coal. The deal's terms are generous to the sponsors, but no longer reflect those available to Brazilian borrowers since the terms were locked in May 2008. [...] The sponsors moved quickly to hedge the foreign exchange and Libor risk associated with the equipment that would have to be paid for in dollars, by executing both interest rate (10-year) and foreign exchange (five-year) hedges through CITIGROUP. In February 2008, Citi was mandated as financial adviser, and also arranged and syndicated a bridge loan for the plant, which allowed the sponsors to make progress payments on their longer lead-time pieces of equipment. Participants in the $270 million bridge were Citi, Banco do Brasil, Banco Espirito Santo, Banco Comercial Portugues, ING, and West LB. [...]

title: A man with his foot on the gas
news: The global energy big league is in reach of Woodside's chief executive but this week's share price slump will remind him the journey may be hard. Don Voelte says he has no plans to become the "king of Woodside", but for now he is overlord of a giant global energy realm and has plans for further territorial conquests. The chief executive and managing director of Woodside Petroleum, Australia's largest independent oil and gas producer, aims to make Woodside Australia's biggest liquefied natural gas producer. In doing so, he will vault Woodside into the top league, making it one of the world's top three publicly owned LNG companies. […] With vastly less greenhouse gas emissions than coal, Voelte argues it's a perfect "transitional fuel" between the waning of the coal age and the dawning of a clean future fuelled by hydrogen or some, yet to be discovered, energy technology. […] While Voelte accepts the very real threat of global warming and says he is concerned about it, he is also a pragmatist. Climate change may not benefit the planet but it is an opportunity for the gas industry - and Woodside. Australia, he says, has an opportunity to become one of the world's leading LNG producers as the world scrambles for more environmentally friendly fuels. […] In the meantime, Voelte is in the mood to spend and is holding one of Australia's fattest cheque books. He is unfazed by the prospect of spending $15 billion on projects that will take Woodside into the top bracket of international energy companies. He has already written a $333 million cheque for his company's share of the latest expansion of the North West Shelf LNG project in Western Australia, which Woodside operates on behalf of some of the world's biggest petroleum companies including Shell, BHP Billiton, BP, CHEVRON, Mitsubishi and Mitsui. […] If Voelte's plans to boost Woodside's LNG output are fulfilled, Woodside will rank behind only its partner, and 32 per cent shareholder, Shell in world LNG production terms and ahead of BP, CHEVRON, ExxonMobil and BHP Billiton.

title: Heat on Aussie mining giants
news: MINING giants Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton are among six Australian companies most at risk to the impact of climate change, a report says. Among the ASX top-100 listed companies, those involved in emissions-intensive industries are most at risk to climate change, says CITIGROUP research. […]

title: Industry voices fears over PAS 2050 carbon standard
news: Concern is mounting over the implications for the packaging industry of a new carbon footprint standard that is due to be published next month. A number of senior industry sources have expressed doubts over Publicly Available Specification (PAS) 2050, a standard being developed by the British Standards Institute for Defra and the Carbon Trust that will measure the exact carbon footprint of any given product. [...]  PAS 2050 - Project led by the Carbon Trust, Defra and BSI; - Aims to create a standard method to measure and communicate the carbon footprint of any product; [...] - Brands including Danone Water UK, British Sugar, Walkers and Coca-Cola are reported to have tested the standard.

title: Quality, safety come first
news: CHEVRON's integrated compliance management system requires staff to be multi-faceted, writes SUSAN TSANG. CHEVRON Chemical (Far East) Pte Ltd's commitment to quality, safety and the environment can be gauged by the fact that the chemical manufacturer brought on board quality assurance and compliance specialist Peter Tang in 1997. This was two years before their plant on Jurong Island started operating. […] As there is some overlap among all three, the quality, environment and safety systems are being put in place in parallel. "It reduces the documentation requirements if you integrate," explains Mr Tang. It may save on documentation to implement everything in parallel, but it does increase the complexity of the process, and requires the staff to be quite multi-faceted. […] The ISO implementation was done almost completely in-house, so the cost was minimal. […] The extra effort is coming in handy now that CHEVRON is in the process of implementing the ISO 14000. However, there is still plenty of legwork to be done, as they study the impact their processes may have on the environment. […] CHEVRON expects to achieve ISO 14,000 certification sometime in 2001.

title: Utilities turn on the power / POWERING THE NATION - A special advertising report
news: FOUR industries are combining to provide one trade show, UTILICON 2000. National Power, National Gas, National Water and Utility Direct will present their products, services and technology for the rapidly changing and converging electricity, gas, telecoms and water markets. […] This year's conference will concentrate on competition reform, the regulatory environment, regional reviews and the environmental challenges, as well as other issues of concern.[…] Speakers will include the manager gas strategy, TXU Trading, Andrew Brown, who will speak on the increasing diversity of supply in the gas industry; the project director, PNG Gas Project, CHEVRON Australia, Dr John Powell on opening the eastern gas market to increased competition; the executive director of the Australian Cogeneration Association, Ric Brazzale, on expanding the Australian gas market through cogeneration; the South Australian Minster for Primary Industry and Resources, Robert Kerin, on the outlook for the South Australian gas industry; and the Queenland Treasurer, David Hamill, on an update on the changing Queensland gas sector. According to AGL's annual report: "The PNG-Queensland natural gas project is the largest single gas pipeline to land on the drawing boards in Australia. It will have a carrying capacity equivalent to the total volume of natural gas sold annually in NSW." […]

title: Carbon trading turns City green
news: Huge salaries are on offer for the new breed of specialists who know how to trade carbon credits. Report by Zoe Thomas and Jonathan Leake. City fat cats and environmental campaigners may make unusual bedfellows, but efforts to slow down climate change are having far-reaching effects. [...]Among the recent big moves were Abyd Karmali, who switched to global head of carbon at Merrill Lynch from ICF consulting in the middle of last year. Garth Edward, formerly head of global environmental products trading at Shell, has moved to CITIGROUP to be head of emissions markets. Similarly, Laurent Segalen has moved from Price Waterhouse Coopers, where he was head of climate change, to Lehman Brothers. [...]

title: Poland Wants More Control Over Shale Gas Concessions
news: Deputy Environment Minister Piotr Wozniak says Poland should have bigger control over resources on its territory. His comment regards uncertainty about concessions held by Exxon Mobil. The U.S. energy giant is going to resign from Polish concessions for explorations of shale gas. The final decision will be probably taken in September. The Environment Ministry is concerned it may have no impact on what will happen with Exxon Mobil's concessions if it decides to deprive of them. The law allows Exxon Mobil for three solutions: returning the concessions, which would be cancelled, but Wozniak admits this is the rarest form; ceding it on a partner or sell a unit owning the concession to other company. The precedent has been just set in Poland, as Lane Resources has decided not to continue exploration works on one of its Polish concessions and give it back to the Environment Ministry.

title: CHEVRON files to expand Gorgon LNG project
news: Sydney--US major CHEVRON has applied for federal environmental approvals to add a fourth LNG production train at its Gorgon project, currently under development on Barrow Island off Western Australia. In an application filed with the Australian environment department May 2, CHEVRON sought approval to add the 5 million mt/year LNG train to the 15 million mt/year foundation project, which is already being constructed. The project is particularly environmentally sensitive, as Barrow Island has been a Class A nature reserve since 1910 and is home to at least 24 unique plant and animal species.[...]

title: Contour Peru subsidiary puts green bond tag on new issue
news: Energi­a Eolica (ESSA), the owner and operator of Peru's two largest wind farms, has called its proposed issuance a "green bond" in its draft prospectus and in a note to investors because proceeds will be used to refinance existing debt relating to "green assets".  ESSA, which does not yet have a rating but whose parent company Contour is rated B3/B+, is meeting investors with BANK OF AMERICA Merril Lynch and Goldman Sachs ahead of a proposed $200m senior secured issue due 8 30 2034. "It is definitely Latin America's first green bond," said one LatAm portfolio manager. "The deal is too small for us to look at but we will be keeping an eye on whether there is any reaction from the market to the green bond tag."[…]

title: ExxonMobil stops shale gas exploration in Polish concession areas
news: [...] The largest US fuel corporation is pulling out of shale gas exploration in Poland, because it has not discovered enough gas to make mining it profitable. This may come as a cold shower to those Poles who hoped that shale gas would soon turn us into the sheikhs of Central Europe. "ExxonMobil confirms that it has completed its shale gas exploration in Poland after fulfilling, together with its partner, the required programme of work, which was carried out in keeping with environmental regulations," we were informed yesterday by Adam Kopysc, external relations adviser for the company Exxon Mobil Exploration and Production, which sought gas deposits in Poland's shale rocks. [...] ExxonMobil received six concessions for exploring for natural gas deposits in Poland's shale rocks in late early 2009 and early 2010.  [...]

title: Oil industry wants tax relief to fuel GDP growth
news: AUSTRALIA'S oil and gas industry has released a six-point action plan that it says will deliver big economic benefits while slashing greenhouse gas emissions in the Asia-Pacific region. But the plan relies on tax breaks that Canberra would be reluctant to concede, given the industry's record profit levels. The plan was unveiled yesterday by the industry's peak lobby group, the Australian Petroleum Production & Exploration Association (APPEA), on the eve of its annual conference in Adelaide, a talkfest attended by more than 1500 delegates. APPEA's sales pitch relies heavily on the critical role that the industry believes gas can play in reducing carbon emissions while the transition to "clean" coal and other cleaner fuel sources is made. […] APPEA chairman Colin Beckett, who is general manager of CHEVRON's proposed $13 billion Gorgon LNG project, said the adoption of the action plan would deliver major economic rewards. "We can look forward to a substantial increase in Australia's wealth - $55 billion in GDP in net present value terms - and an improvement in the country's annual trade balance of $1.6 billion, by 2017," Mr Beckett said. "This nation faces stark choices if it is to achieve its potential to be a major energy exporter of greenhouse-friendly LNG." But the action plan comes at a cost to the federal budget. The key proposal is for the adoption of accelerated (five-year) depreciation regime for big gas projects.

title: Momentum Grows In Quest To Commercialise Oil Shale
news: [...] The US Bureau of Land Management (BLM) awarded ExxonMobil and Natural Soda Holdings, a baking soda producer, leases for oil shale development in the Western United States. [...] Commercial production of oil shale remains a distant prospect, with high extraction costs, environmental risks to groundwater and wildlife, and the high sulphur (among other chemicals including arsenic) content of the resources a threat to extraction efforts. However, the US Energy Policy Act of 2005 directed relevant agencies to determine whether production was viable, resulting in a number of research projects in the Green River Formation. [...]

title: Getting into podcasting
news: Everyone seems to be tuning in to the digital- audio craze of podcasting, with computing giant IBM joining other major companies in reaching its stakeholder community through the burgeoning broadcast medium.In case you've missed the hype so far, podcasting is the digital-audio technology that allows you to download audio off the web to listen to at your convenience on a portable music player. IBM said on Friday that it would be posting audio think-pieces on its investor-relations site, providing an alternative to the print "white papers" -- technical documents -- that most high-tech companies produce. A more interactive and engaging way to reach an audience , podcasting is also popular with large United States companies, and PepsiCo, General Motors (GM) and, of course, Apple -- the company partly responsible for creating the modern audio phenomenon with the launch of its iPod digital-audio player -- are leading the way with corporate podcasts.Addressing the problem of environmental damage and the difficulty of capturing the attention of their customers, one IBM spokesman said the company had "killed our fair share of trees and people" with white papers.[…]

title: Chesapeake to Allow EPA Water Testing at Shale Drilling Site
news: Chesapeake has agreed to allow the US Environmental Protection Agency to conduct water sampling tests at one of its drill sites as the agency works to complete a report on the environmental impacts of shale oil and gas development, according to the Wall Street Journal (WSJ). [...] Chesapeake is the second largest natural gas producer in the US, behind supermajor Exxon Mobil. But the company has been seeking to boost its crude oil output in recent months as domestic natural gas prices remain stubbornly low ( NGW Nov.5'12 ). [...]

title: Making it new for our twenty-first century economy
news: [...] A soft drinks company might not be the kind of firm you think about as a manufacturer. But today the food and drink industry is the country's biggest manufacturing sector - accounting for some 15 per cent of total output. And Coca-Cola Enterprises - the company I work for - is the biggest soft drinks company in the country, with a rich history of operating in Great Britain. In fact, more than 95 per cent of the 4bn cans and bottles we sell each year are made in this country at our six manufacturing sites. We're a growth business and last year invested £50m in our manu-facturing base, with substantial investments at our sites in East Kilbride, Wakefield and Sidcup. As well as enhancing our productivity and competitiveness, this investment supported our ongoing efforts to minimise our environmental impacts. [...] Roman Manthey is group operations director GB for Coca-Cola Enterprises. He is speaking today at Editorial Intelligence's Comment Conference on the Manufacturing Economy. www.commentconference.com

title: UK parliamentary panel criticizes carbon price floor policy
news: The UK government's decision to set a minimum trading price for carbon, the only such decision among EU states, could have a "devastating effect" on UK industry and will artificially raise electricity prices for consumers while having no overall impact on emissions, Parliament's Energy and Climate Change select committee said 1 26. [...] Peter Atherton, an analyst at Citigroup Global Markets, said in a research note issued 1 26 that a backlash had been expected to the UK carbon price floor plan and that if the EU carbon price remains low, the debate over the UK measure will only increase. title: Regulators approve Hebron field; Set conditions

Federal and provincial regulators have conditionally approved development of the Hebron oil project off Newfoundland, a field estimated to hold just over 700 million barrels and worth an estimated $20-billion over 30 years. The Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Offshore Petroleum Board approved Thursday an application by a group of oil companies led by ExxonMobil Canada Ltd., subject to 16 conditions. They include requirements for plans to deal with skilled labour shortages and environmental issues. [...]

title: Business & Media: Business: Good Companies Guide: Ethics still matter in hard times: The difficult economic climate makes corporate integrity more important than ever, since many investors and customers base their decisions on social and environmental issues. news: The Co-operative Asset Management The UK is mired in the most difficult economic conditions for three decades and many businesses are struggling for survival. Citi's analysis also suggests that two-thirds of green and ethical funds are still seeing money flow in from investors, suggesting that socially concerned shareholders are committed for the long haul - though, given the market mayhem, there is no guarantee an ethical investment will pay financial dividends. title: PM's hard sell in talks with Arnie
news: AUSTRALIA's push to become the logical supplier of liquefied natural gas to the US West Coast has taken a diversion with the Prime Minister's visit to California. After meeting California's Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, Mr Howard said on Thursday BHP Billiton's proposal for a floating offshore platform "has the great virtue of establishing a dedicated source of supply to California, which is an advantage compared with other sources of supply of a domestic kind or from Mexico". […] Prior to Mr Howard's visit the Australian Government had been concentrating on developing links with the California administration that would allow Australia's environmental experience with LNG projects to be used a model for future Golden State developments. Australia believes it is a more secure supplier than either Indonesia or Russia, the two most likely competitors for West Coast sales. As a result, Californian officials are scheduled to visit CHEVRONTEXACO in Perth later this month to review Australia's most intense environmental assessment process, for the proposed $6 billion CHEVRONTEXACO-led Gorgon LNG development on Barrow Island. While Barrow Island is an A-class nature reserve that has successfully coped with oil development for more than 40 years, it lacks something that makes the California situation difficult -- people. CHEVRONTEXACO is partnered by Shell and ExxonMobil in Gorgon. […]

title: Asian ethylene firms set for profit boom; Lack of capacity and delays in China's coal conversion projects boost oil-based chemical plants but cheap US gas will pose a threat
news: Analysts expect profits to increase at crude-oil-based chemical plants in Asia over the next three years owing to a lack of new capacity and delays in proposed projects to turn Chinese coal into chemicals. However, they warn the party will end in 2017 when plants fed by cheap natural gas in the United States start to export their chemicals. […] International Power Generation,  which had struggled with low utilisation rates for 18 months at its Duolun coal-to-chemicals plant in Inner Mongolia since  trial production began in March 2012 before achieving 70 to 80 per cent utilisation in September last year, according to a Citi research report. […] Environmental protection has also been an area of concern for coal-to-chemicals projects. Shenhua,  the mainland's largest coal miner, was fined 100,000 yuan in 1 last year  and  ordered by the Ministry of Environmental Protection to shut  its 17 billion yuan coal-to-chemicals project in Baotou, Inner Mongolia. […] A Citi research report said that although four million tonnes of the annual coal-to-ethylene capacity was being built, "delays will be common due to execution risks".[…] But Citi's analysts warned that Asian ethylene makers' margins would be under pressure come 2017 when US surplus supply hits the market. […]

title: HELEN CLARK; Corporate marketing manager, CHEVRON Corp.
news: At the recent AdTech conference in San Francisco, teens speaking out in a keynote roundtable were asked what companies they considered to be environmentally friendly. The answer from one, which took some marketers in the audience by surprise, was none other than oil giant CHEVRON. It was just a small mention, but it appears to underscore the success Helen Clark, corporate marketing manager for CHEVRON Corp., has had with the ``Power of Human Energy'' campaign she launched last year. Like all oil companies, CHEVRON has to deal with high gas prices, high profits and environmental issues threatening its brand image. But after focus groups, Ms. Clark realized CHEVRON's opportunity was in educating consumers about global oil markets. That's also the company's biggest challenge. […] CHEVRON also developed an online game called ``Energyville'' in which players try to balance energy needs with environmental costs. More than 500,000 played in the game's first four months. So far, the effort has received little negative feedback. In fact, it won a silver Effie for effectiveness. IAG Research named an ad from the campaign No. 9 among most-liked new TV spots for Sept. 24 to Oct. 12, 2007, a first for an oil company. Next, watch for a campaign in which an oil company actually calls for conservation. […]

title: Exxon Expects Natural Gas Use to Eclipse Coal in Power Generation
news: Exxon Mobil's latest long-term energy outlook is more natural gas-oriented than ever, reflecting the company's own strategy of building larger US and global gas portfolios to provide fuel for the world's expanding fleet of electricity generation plants in the next two decades. The combination of higher natural gas consumption in developed and developing countries, along with greater energy efficiency for power plants, electrical appliances and cars will mitigate the environmental impact of increased energy consumption, Exxon said in The Outlook for Energy: A View to 2030. [...] Total global energy use will rise 35% in 2030 from 2010 levels, but emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) will rise only 25% because of increased use of natural gas and less reliance on coal, William Colton, Exxon's vice president of corporate strategic planning, told reporters in a conference call to present the company's long-term projections.[...]

title: Global warming a hot spot for investors; Climate issues change the economic landscape
news: Droughts. Hurricanes. Rising temperatures. Melting glaciers. In a world abuzz with talk about global warming, climate change is elbowing aside tech and biotech as the major investment theme of the future. [...] "We are approaching a tipping point when it comes to climate change," says Edward Kerschner, a strategist at CITIGROUP.[…] Despite the forward-looking mindset of Wall Street analysts,  profiting from climate change is still in its infancy. CITIGROUP's Kerschner learned that firsthand at a recent meeting with wealthy clients in Florida, a state known for both its beautiful beaches and run-ins with deadly hurricanes. […]

title: Tender powers Gorgon gas deal
news: THE $11 billion Gorgon gas development in Western Australia has entered a key phase with the imminent appointment of Halliburton subsidiary Kellogg Brown and Root as preferred tenderer for front-end engineering and design (FEED) work. Ahead of the announcement, a team of international engineering consultants has been authorised to begin studies for the huge project, which will be Australia's biggest resources investment. […] The two developments led analysts to predict that the Gorgon partners -- CHEVRONTEXACO, Shell and ExxonMobil -- could move quickly on the investment decision, which has slipped by more than a year. […] In 2001, after the merger of the CHEVRON and TEXACO energy giants, the plan to develop the Gorgon gas reserves was revitalised using a land-based processing plant on the Class A nature reserve at Barrow Island -- the site of a 40-year-old producing oil field. The proposals involved Australia's most intensive environmental assessment process, before the West Australian Government passed laws allowing the development to go ahead. The plan is to build two LNG processing facilities, each with a capacity of 5 million tonnes a year. This would make the Gorgon development slightly smaller than the recently expanded NW Shelf project, but about three times the size of the Bayu Undan LNG facility under construction in Darwin. […]

title: CITIGROUP wants Australia's water supply privatised
news: PRIVATISING Australia's water would cause more efficient use of the increasingly precious commodity and stimulate important infrastructure investment, CITIGROUP says. The local arm of the world's biggest bank is calling on Australia's state governments to leave the pricing of water to competitive market forces. CITIGROUP admitted this would make water dearer but said it would bring efficiency by introducing scarcity into the pricing equation, and encourage development and technological innovation by making investing in water infrastructure worth the initial cost. Most state governments base water pricing on a fixed non-consumption based cost component, and on a block tariff, which rises and falls based on the level of water consumed. ''Given the scarcity issue of water and how climate change is impacting Australia, it's not the most optimal way of pricing water,'' CITIGROUP economist Shane Lee said. ''You really need a price signal to be able to tell consumers to cut back on use when water is scarce.'' Drought-ravaged Australians pay 20 per cent below the OECD average water price, CITIGROUP says.

title: Miners turn blind eye to threat of climate change
news: MORE than 80 per cent of mining companies worldwide say their physical assets will be affected by extreme weather exacerbated by climate change, a new report says. But only 13 per cent are acting to protect their assets. The report, by consultancy firm Acclimatise and sponsored by US technology giant IBM, was based on mining company responses to the Carbon Disclosure Project, which has gathered data on industrial emissions of greenhouse gases.[…]

title: Leaner and Greener; Newsweek's annual rankings reveal the planet's biggest protectors--and polluters
news: […] The good news for fans of the planet is that big business has taken up the torch. Just look at Walmart, the biggest company in the world. It's reducing waste, buying renewable energy, and using its marketing clout to pressure suppliers to be more environmentally conscious, resulting in greener products on store shelves that cost the same, or even less, than their earth-polluting competition.Companies in every industry are realizing that the pursuit of profit is intertwined with environmental and social issues. […] For Newsweek's fourth annual Green Rankings, we've examined the environmental performance of the 500 biggest public companies in America. The result is a comprehensive, objective picture of which companies are leading--and which are lagging. We crunched the data in cooperation with two leading environmental-research firms, Trucost and Sustainalytics, assessing companies' performance in three arenas: environmental footprint, management, and disclosure. (The full list--and our tally of the 500 biggest in the world--are available online at Newsweek.com/green.) […] AMERICA'S TOP 10. No. 1. Coca-Cola Enterprises* Atlanta, GA. Green Score: 68. PEPSICO. Purchase, NY. Green Score: 57. Campbell Soup. Camden, NJ. Green Score: 55 […] TOP ENERGY[ …] Companies were evaluated on three components: environmental impact score (footprint), weighted as 45 percent of the total; management score (policies, initiatives, and controversies), weighted at 45 percent; and disclosure score (transparency), weighted at the remaining 10 percent. For a more detailed explanation and to see the complete rankings, go to newsweek.com/green.

title: Caltex denies crisis profiting
news: […] AUSTRALIA'S largest oil refiner, Caltex Australia, has warned consumers the oil price situation is not improving, while maintaining it is not unduly profiting from the rise because of higher costs. Caltex also confirmed delays and cost over-runs for its clean fuels project would drag down first-half earnings and forecast regional demand for transport fuel to outstrip supply in the next few years. […] Caltex, which is 50 per cent owned by US oil giant CHEVRON, reported a 4 per cent lift in annual net profit to $595 million in calendar 2005. […] Mr Warburton reaffirmed that delays impacting Caltex's clean fuels project, designed to cut air pollution by reducing benzene in petrol and sulphur content in diesel, would have a negative impact on earnings in the first half of 2006. Caltex shares closed 42 or 2.06 per cent lower at $19.98.

title: Comment: Prophetic visions can help to save the planet: Obstacles to climate action are crumbling. 0ur leaders now have an opportunity to marry the moral and economic case
news: The past year has seen the obstacles blocking action on climate change beginning to crumble. Opposition on scientific grounds looks pretty unpersuasive in the light of what has come from the experts on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Their seven-year study states that they are now 95% certain that human activity is a significant and avoidable element in driving climate change around the world. Predicted changes in the climate are now being observed in the most vulnerable countries, confirming the predictive models that have been used. The suggestion that action on this would have too great an economic cost is likewise looking increasingly shaky. This month the New Climate Economy report will be published by a global commission, including Felipe Calderon, the former president of Mexico; Paul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever; the economist Nicholas Stern; and Chad Holloway, the chairman of the BANK OF AMERICA - as well as a substantial number of finance ministers from around the world. This report will show that action on climate change is entirely compatible with economic growth in almost all countries and that the economic benefits, both short and long term, will outweigh the costs. […]

title: Bush plan to put gas pipeline in rainforest; Scheme would enrich his backersScheme would enrich his backers
news: PRESIDENT George Bush is seeking funds for a controversial project to drive gas pipelines from pristine rainforests in the Peruvian Amazon to the coast. The plan will enrich some of Mr Bush's closest corporate campaign contributors while risking the destruction of rainforest, threatening its indigenous peoples and endangering rare species on the coast. Among the beneficiaries would be two Texas energy companies with close ties to the White House, Hunt Oil and Kellogg Brown & Root (KBR), a subsidiary of Vice -President Dick Cheney's old company, Haliburton, which is rebuilding Iraq's oil infrastructure.  The pipeline slices through some of the most biologically diverse places on earth. Their remoteness has preserved an extraordinarily rich ecosystem in the coastal Paracas reserve, which is home to such rare species as Humboldt penguins, sea lions and green sea turtles.  The Camisea natural gas project - with reserves of 13,000 billion cubic feet of gas - has already scared off two big investors, CITIGROUP and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.According to an internal report by the US Export Import Bank, obtained by the lobby group Amazon Watch, proposals to mitigate the environmental impact of the project are "woefully inadequate" and will lead to mudslides, destroy habitats and spread diseases among indigenous peoples.[…]

title: BP oil spill: Tony Hayward faces the City
news: After weeks of vitriolic criticism in the US, Hayward faced the City number-crunchers who recommend when to buy and sell BP shares - and got a remarkably easy ride. There were very few tough questions. No one queried his position as chief executive. There was silence on the fact that BP's plunging market value has left it vulnerable to a takeover. No one actually touched on the sliding share price at all. It sounded like a typical quarterly results conference call.[…]2.27pm Theepan Jothilingam, analyst at Morgan Stanley, asks whether paying a dividend will be politically acceptable in the US. Hayward passes the buck to "my boss", the chairman. Svanberg's answer is unilluminating. 2.29pm A BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch analyst asks how much money will go into the new disaster-tackling operation under Bob Dudley and how the industry will change post the accident.[…]

title: Corporate jets get carbon credits; Carbon credits for corporate jet owners
news: CORPORATE jets used by billionaires the Duke of Westminster and Lord Ashcroft are among the aircraft to be allocated free "carbon allowances" to offset the cost of a new green tax. Almost 200 corporate jet owners, from oil company ExxonMobil to Starbucks and Iceland Foods, will be awarded free permits to compensate them for the new expense of Europe's carbon trading scheme for aircraft. The emissions trading scheme means airlines will have to surrender a permit for every tonne of carbon dioxide they emit, which is expected to raise the cost of flying for millions of passengers.Bigger airlines, such as easyJet and British Airways, have long been preparing for huge bills from the emissions trading scheme. They will get a large number of free allowances in the first few years of the scheme to protect their businesses from becoming uneconomic. However, corporate jet owners will also be able to take advantage of these free allowances, potentially selling them on for cash if they don't use their aircraft as much as in previous years. Dozens of corporate jet owners will get free permits, including Iceland Foods, JP Morgan Chase, Procter and Gamble, Hertz Corporation, McDonald's, IBM and Coca-Cola.[…]

title: Wheatstone to go ahead
news: The $25 billion Wheatstone LNG development near Onslow has been given the green light by the State Government, which yesterday granted environmental approval for the project. Environment Minister Bill Marmion said approval included 25 strict environmental conditions requiring marine fauna, including whales, turtles and dugongs, to be protected. Environmental approval was the final hurdle facing Wheatstone's operator and controlling shareholder CHEVRON and its partners, Apache Corp, Kuwait's Kufpec and Royal Dutch Shell. [...]

title: Giant gas development approved
news: CHEVRON and its joint venture partners in the Gorgon gas project, ExxonMobil and Shell, have welcomed the Federal Government's decision to grant environmental approval for the mammoth development. The project will recover gas from the Gorgon field, Australia's largest known gas resource, which is near the North West Shelf off the Western Australian coast. A gas refining and liquid natural gas facility will be constructed on Barrow Island, where CHEVRON has operated for more than 40 years. WA Environment Minister David Templeman gave the green light last month to the project, which could cost between $15 billion and $20billion. He imposed 36 environmental conditions, which CHEVRON Australia general manager for the greater Gorgon area Colin Beckett described as the most stringent imposed on a large project anywhere in the world. Mr Beckett said federal Environment Minister Malcolm Turnbull's decision was welcome after four years of rigorous state and federal assessment that had produced a comprehensive environmental management regime. Mr Turnbull said, "Strict environmental protection measures will be required to protect Commonwealth environment matters, including listed threatened and migratory species and rare vegetation on Barrow Island." Under the environmental protection measures stipulated by Mr Templeman, the Gorgon joint venturers will spend $60 million to conserve the flatback turtle and other endangered species. They must also submit annual audit compliance and environmental performance reports. […]

title: Profiting in Biofuels
news: The ethanol boom may defy economic logic and could easily drive up food prices. It certainly depends on the generosity of taxpayers, but it makes eminent political sense in Washington, D.C. […] Energetic gains. The production of U.S. ethanol, nearly all distilled from the starch and sugar in corn, is growing explosively--four billion gallons last year, five billion this year, six billion next year, according to Matt Hartwig, of the Renewable Fuels Association. […] Clean burn. But the main impetus behind the surging demand for ethanol this year has been its role as a replacement for MTBE, a clean-burning, high-octane gasoline additive now believed to be a carcinogen. State after state has banned the additive. Ethanol is the only feasible substitute, and many states are mandating at least 10% ethanol content ("E10" at the pump) in gasoline. […] Demand for ethanol now exceeds supply, but dozens of plants are under construction, and supply could catch up by the end of 2008. For now, the established companies are solidly profitable. […] If it's a pure ethanol producer you seek, consider Aventine Renewable Energy. Since going public in 6 at $43, Aventine's shares have slumped to $24, making them far more attractive. Tim Flannery, a hedge-fund manager at Front Point Partners, in Chicago, likes Pekin, Ill.-headquartered Aventine for its strong executive team, marketing skills and distribution capabilities. Anyone can throw up an ethanol plant in midwestern cornfields, but not many suppliers have the infrastructure to move the stuff around and satisfy customers such as ExxonMobil and CHEVRON. […] Despite all the hoopla surrounding alternative energy, the four stocks listed below are not particularly expensive, and one, Petrobras, looks to be dirt-cheap. Only Aventine Renewable Energy is a pure play on biofuels, and it's unquestionably the riskiest of the four stocks. […]

title: Risks are too high for accidents
news: The Montara oil spill off the Kimberley coast of Western Australia could have been so much worse. Australia was lucky: the slick headed north. Indonesian fisheries bore the brunt of it, and the locals want compensation. A sloppy cementing operation on the West Atlas drilling rig owned by the Thai operator PTTEPA led to the accident on 8 21, 2009. Up to 140,000 barrels spilt over the next 74 days. That pales next to the 5 million-barrel spill in the Gulf of Mexico, but the lessons are similar, as we will find when the Resources Minister, Martin Ferguson, finally releases the Montara Commission of Inquiry report he has been sitting on since 6.[...] The area is remote and highly inaccessible. Besides the threat of an oil spill, there is anti-freeze to be piped round the plant. And there is CO2 to be sequestered, somehow. Unlike CHEVRON's $43 billion Gorgon project on Barrow Island, off the Pilbara coast, where there are underground saline aquifers, there is no known way of storing the millions of tonnes of CO2 that will be produced at James Price Point.[...]

title: Investors unmoved as coal stocks drop; SHAREMARKET
news: THE Australian sharemarket was underwhelmed by the revised emissions trading package designed to better protect the balance sheets of emissions-intensive industries. As the political fallout continued in Canberra, investors were largely unmoved by the Federal Government's $7 billion boost to affected industries courtesy of its carbon pollution reduction scheme. Under the revised plan, money for coalminers has doubled to $1.5 billion over five years, while coal-fired electricity generators will get an extra $4 billion in free permits. [...] A Citi analyst, Elaine Prior, said the bank's research before the amendments found the scheme would have a "minor impact" on the earnings of emissions-intensive industries.

title: Combet's climate pitch set adrift by inconsistency; G-BIZ
news: Setting targets isn't the only task the minister is sidestepping for now. THE word is, a new bunch of modelling is being done around a "10 per cent by 2020" target for greenhouse gas reductions - double that of last year - suggesting that, despite all the wailing, the climate debate moves only one way: ever-more pressing, ever-more expensive. That's although the question of targets is firmly in Climate Change Minister Greg Combet's too-hard basket. At a speech to institutional investors in Sydney before Christmas, Combet was keen to emphasise the government could initially put a price on carbon - say at a fixed, rather than market, rate - without stipulating an emissions reduction target.  [...] Citigroup analyst Elaine Prior threw Combet a two-pronged question about (a) whether a carbon price might at first be imposed just to cover the electricity sector, source of most emissions, and (b) the level of compensation for emissions-intensive, trade-exposed industries such as steel and aluminium and the electricity-generation sector in the transition phase. "I'm wondering," she said to nervous laughs, "whether the negotiations held a year ago in terms of transitional assistance, whether that was likely to be as good as it would get for industry - whether the current make-up of Parliament means perhaps industry will regret not agreeing, in a sense, to the proposals that were put forward last year?" [...]

title: Changing crudes, fuel standards will drive future refining investment
news: Future worldwide refining investment will be in response to three trends in the industry: heavier and increasingly sour crude oil processing, greater need for desulfurization, and the reduction of methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) use in the US. Especially in the US, refiners are making lighter fuels with heavier crudes. […] Gasoline and diesel standards. In late 1999, the US Environmental Protection Agency began to implement a rule to tighten average US gasoline sulfur content to 30 ppm from 300 ppm, beginning in 2005 (OGJ, Jan. 3, 2000, p. 26). […] More desulfurization units. […] Refiners can also reduce the gasoline endpoint to meet specifications, although this will reduce yields. Optimization of existing operations and catalysts will also help refiners reduce sulfur from their products. […] There are several offerings from technology licensors to provide refineries with traditional hydrotreating and newer gasoline desulfurization alternatives. For hydrotreating, these technologies come from companies such as CHEVRON Corp., Institut Francaise du Petrole (IFP), and UOP LLC. […] Oxygenates standards. Maintaining desired product qualities in the US will become more difficult if reducing the sulfur from gasoline is accompanied by a phase-out of MTBE. MTBE is an oxygenate that boosts the octane in gasoline, lowers carbon monoxide emissions, and displaces undesirable components such as aromatics and sulfur. […] MTBE, however, has fallen from the public's grace because it has been detected in 5-10% of drinking water supplies in areas using RFG or oxygenated fuel in the US. Although most of these detections have not been a threat to public health, taste and odor concerns and misperceptions about the magnitude of MTBE contamination have prompted outcries to eliminate MTBE. […]

title: Population boom heralds major shifts in global economy
news: Few economists have been as spectacularly wrong as Thomas Malthus, who predicted in 1798 that unchecked population growth would doom the Earth to starvation. As the number of people on the planet reaches 7 billion, his modernday peers are cautiously confident that the English clergyman will remain synonymous with unwarranted doom and gloom. With the global population headed for the 9 billion mark by 2050, economists are pinning their faith on continued technological innovation and the invisible hand of market prices to lead to a more efficient, sustainable use of finite natural resources instead of a deadly fight to the end for the last barrel of oil and drop of water. Still, the rapid economic reemergence of China and India, both with populations of well over 1 billion, is changing the equation. [...] Some countries are introducing carbon taxes to reflect the non-renewability of fossil fuels and induce consumers to change the way they behave. The fact that water is largely free for most farmers, who use 70 to 80 per cent of the world's water, leads to enormous waste, added Willem Buiter, Citi's chief economist. [...]

title: The green scene; Dry cleaners are going environmentally friendly, reports TRALEE PEARCE
news: For years, dry cleaning has been one of those eco-guilt-inspiring luxuries. A few steps below owning an SUV, yes, but just as likely to garner tsks from greenheads.   But really, what are the alternatives? Wear wrinkly cotton all the time? Never buy a lined suit? And yes, we've tried the pretend over-the-counter "dry-cleaning" kits and, well, now we're back at the cleaners.  The problem is perchlorethylene, a chemical that has been used in dry cleaning since the 1930s, and is considered a toxic carcinogen that can harm people, water supplies and the atmosphere. Recent studies have drawn awareness to the effects of PERC-laden clothes in the car (even of its seeping into groceries, yuck) and the home. It seems to have no redeeming qualities, in fact.  "Almost everyone uses dry cleaners, but not everyone knows what it is," says Tim Yoo of Toronto's Eco Cleaners, who recently turned to a new technology because of concern about the effects of PERC on consumers and dry-cleaning workers.  GreenEarth Cleaning, formed in a 1999 partnership between PROCTOR & GAMBLE and General Electric, uses a silicone-based solvent they describe as "liquid sand." Tiny droplets of the solvent seep into the clothes and attach themselves to dirt and oil, which they take with them when they're extracted.  The company says it's non-toxic, non-carcinogenic, non-allergenic and completely biodegradable. Prices so far aren't that far out of whack from what many spend at ordinary cleaners: At Eco Cleaners, a two-piece suit is $17.75, a blouse is $6.85.  Tim Maxwell, the Toronto-based president of GreenEarth, which is headquartered in Kansas, says the company has sold 11 machines across Canada and 1,000 machines worldwide. It's a drop in the bucket: In North America alone, there are 35,000 dry-cleaning machines. […]  Friends of the Earth CEO Beatrice Olivastri is cautious about embracing GreenEarth too quickly.  "What I would say is you're replacing a chemical with a chemical and so it perhaps is a worthy alternative, but I think the jury is out on that," she says from Ottawa. […]

title: Fuel to Burn: Now What?
news: THE reversal of fortune in America's energy supplies in recent years holds the promise of abundant and cheaper fuel, and it could have profound effects on what people drive, domestic manufacturing and America's foreign policy. title: Rio+20 earth summit should look to reduce black carbon through carbon trading; Delegates at the Rio+20 earth summit must look beyond CO2 to black carbon. Reducing black carbon (soot) is easier than reducing other kinds of greenhouse gas emissions. And a market-based international system to reduce carbon emissions is already in place.
news: As delegates in Rio de Janeiro meet today for the 20th anniversary of the 1992 Rio summit on sustainability, there is much to talk about. One of the main items to be discussed at the Rio+20 summit is the status of carbon emissions mitigation, particularly CO2. While initiatives have targeted CO2 emissions with some success, much remains to be done, and countries must now look at other forms of carbon emissions to break the deadlock. One of those emissions is black carbon, commonly known as soot - a recognized public health hazard and contributor to global warming. Fortunately, reducing black carbon is much easier than reducing other kinds of emissions like CO2. And a market-based international system incentivizing reduction of carbon emissions is already in place.[…] The concept of carbon trading emerged from the Kyoto Protocol as a way for countries to trade their greenhouse gas emission rights. With a set number of emission rights, a country that had a hard time reducing its emissions could essentially pay another country to reduce its emissions by the appropriate amount. The argument was that it would be cheaper for a less developed country to reduce emissions than it would be for a developed country, but the goal of emission reduction would still be achieved. […] So a company like General Motors or IBM, seeking to reduce its carbon footprint, might end up buying emission credits in a carbon market, thus monetizing the efforts of some social entrepreneurs who risk their capital in financing carbon reduction projects. If a black carbon reduction project cost the social entrepreneur $10 per carbon ton to pay for engine improvements, he can hope corporate buyers will pay $11 per ton in the carbon markets to allow him to make a $1 profit per ton of carbon that his project was able to reduce.[…]
