title: Environment Agency to Re-Examine System
news: The Executive Director of the Liberian Environment Protection Agency (EPA) says after ten years of operations, the Agency has seen the need to re-examine its system and record of engagements with all stakeholders and set necessary and realistic targets as the EPA executes its responsibilities for the protection of the Liberian environment. Madam Anyaa Vohiri pointed out that the Agency has decided to put in place the relevant guidelines, new fee regimes, restructure category of activities and standardize all of its processes of qualification ranging from evaluator certification to the issuance of permit to proponents because, they are in line with the law of Liberia, and in the best interest of the population and country. Madam Anyaa Vohiri's statement is contained in a release issued at the end of a four day retreat in Monrovia to review the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) process, which forms a core function of the Agency's work. [...] The EPA boss thanked all participants for their input and subsequent endorsement of the document which brings on board further international best practices for EPA and Liberia. According to the release, this initiative involved over forty participants from major international companies operating in Liberia, independent environmental evaluators and the relevant line ministries and agencies to include the Land Commission, the Ministry of Public Works, Aureus Mining, CHEVRON, BHP Biliton, Sime Darby among others. In separate remarks at the program, the various stakeholders congratulated the EPA for its pioneering retreat that invited their comments and suggestions on how the entity can further improve in performance and its relationship with various stakeholders involved with the environment.[...]

title: Centrica signs 5-year purchase agreement with UK's Drax for 300 MW from October 2010
news: UK generator and gas producer Centrica has signed an agreement with the country's largest power plant, Drax, to access 300 MW of baseload power, Centrica said last week. [...] The deal allows Centrica to "lock in dark green spreads that are currently being seen in the market," according to analysts at investment bank CITIGROUP. They said Drax would benefit from the certainty of selling power at predetermined prices from a coal plant during phase three of the European Union emissions trading scheme, so mitigating some of the risks of carbon price fluctuations.  Centrica added that the deal was in line with its "strategy to ensure secure energy supplies for its customers and to diversify its fuel mix, further reducing its overall exposure to the gas price in the UK." Financial terms of the contract were not disclosed and Centrica was not immediately available for comment.  Drax Group operates a 4-GW coal-fired plant at Drax in Yorkshire, northeast England, which is western Europe's largest coal-fired plant and produces enough power to meet 7% of UK needs.

title: All systems go for Wheatstone project
news: ENERGY: US energy giant CHEVRON is expected to announce the go-ahead for its $30 billion Wheatstone liquefied natural gas project next week after the federal government yesterday approved the development under national environmental laws.[...] Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke said he had approved Wheatstone under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act with strict conditions. He said CHEVRON would be required to adhere to 70 conditions, including submitting for approval a range of programs detailing how it would protect the environment.``My decision is based on a thorough and rigorous assessment of the Wheatstone proposal, taking into account the advice of my department and independent scientific advice,'' Mr Burke said.``While I have considered the social and economic implications of this project, my focus has been on protecting environmental matters of national significance through strict conditions to manage any potential environmental impacts.``The strict conditions that I have imposed on the proposed project will help to protect threatened and migratory species such as dugongs, marine turtles, sawfish, dolphins and whales and the marine environment.''[...]

title: Cash portion for CECO buy of Met-Pro oversubscribed
news: 26 8 2013 - Holders of some 66.6% of US product recovery, pollution control, fluid handling and filtration solutions provider Met-Pro Corp's (NYSE:MPR) outstanding stock elected to be paid in cash for their shares in connection with the company's acquisition by CECO Environmental Corp (NASDAQ:CECE), resulting in oversubscription of the cash consideration, the pair said. […] BANK OF AMERICA Corp (NYSE:BAC) pledged USD125m of debt for bankrolling the cash portion of the acquisition, CECO said previously. Through the move, CECO aims to establish a leading market player in air pollution control, product recovery and fluid handling technology, which will generate some USD300m of revenues and will boast stronger liquidity and an expanded product portfolio, it has said. The buyer expects the amalgamation to result in some USD9m cost synergies and provide considerable cross selling and geographic opportunities, seen as conducive to revenue and margin growth.

title: CHEVRON Phillips To Expand Production Capacity At Cedar Bayou Plant
news: News: US-based CHEVRON Phillips Chemical Company has secured Board of Directors' approval and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality's (TCEQ) environmental permits to expand normal alpha olefins (NAO) production capacity at its Cedar Bayou plant in Baytown, Texas, US. The investment will provide an additional 100,000 metric tonnes per year of production capacity. The expansion is expected to be completed in 2015. US-based S&B Engineers and Constructors will carry out the engineering, procurement and construction in the project and expects to hire up to 600 workers during the construction phase. The project will use the company's proprietary NAO technology.

title: Deepwater Horizon disaster: Tony Hayward: How an affable geologist became America's most hated
news: No one would deny that Tony Hayward is at least partly to blame for his status as "the most hated and most clueless man in America", as the New York Daily News has styled him. That "I want my life back" comment, thrown out in response to questions about the impact of the oil spill, will haunt him to his grave.[...] Hayward said he wanted a low profile for himself and a different one for the company. In particular he wanted to eradicate the perception that BP had become so entrepreneurial that it had developed a culture of risk-taking that critics said separated it from rivals Shell or ExxonMobil.[...]

title: Gecko for eco-village G; With St Barbara's new eco-camp in Leonora being recognised by the State for its environmental nous, the Kalgoorlie Miner decided to take a look at what building a sustainable mining village involves and what geckos have to do with it.
news: ECKOS, the daintiest of lizards, are rumoured to be one of the last species to return to an area after a land disturbance, such as mining.[...]The Department of Mines and Petroleum chose the humble reptile as a symbol of environmental performance in 1992 when they launched their Golden Gecko Awards to recognise excellence and leadership and acknowledge the outstanding contribution people have made to balance environmental responsibility with the development of Western Australia's mineral and petroleum resources.[...]St Barbara environmental advisor Amine Fisher said the recognition meant a lot for the company. "St Barbara is honoured to be recognised for its commitment to environmental excellence by the award," Ms Fisher said."The village - the first of its kind in WA - is a demonstration of St Barbara's commitment to sustainable development and the reduction of its environmental footprint wherever possible."Jim Thomson from Outback Energy Supply who installed 32kW of solar panels on the project said the win for the village was excellent, especially considering the competition."That's really a very good win, because they were up against heavyweights like Woodside and CHEVRON," Mr Thomson said.The Golden Gecko Awards recognise advances and innovations in environmental practice.[...]The awards also provide an opportunity to pass knowledge on to others, helping improve environmental performance across the industry.[...]

title: Thermax picks IBM PureSystems and SmartCloud
news: IBM (NYSE: IBM) said that Thermax Ltd. has selected an IBM Smarter Computing solution to serve as both a consolidation platform for existing services and a cloud environment to test and develop new solutions. Thermax is a strategic partner to industry and business in the energy and environmental sectors, designing, implementing and maintaining a range of engineering solutions that ensure reliable and efficient client operations. Thermax chose IBM SmartCloud and PureSystems over solutions from Cisco and Dell, allowing the company to strengthen its IT infrastructure and enable its clients to operate at reduced cost and with greater safety, energy efficiency, reliability and flexibility. Headquartered in Pune, India, Thermax Ltd, a INR 4859 crore (USD950m) company, operates in two segments: energy (heating, cooling, power generation, energy audits and system retrofits) and environment (water and wastewater treatment and recycle, air pollution control, performance chemicals, resource recovery and optimization).For more information on IBM PureSystems visit: www.IBM.com/press/pure

title: Drive for Ireland to become green capital powerhouse; The country could be a global centre for renewable energy finance, writes Mark Paul
news: BRIAN COWEN has asked that a banking and treasury group located within the taoiseach's department examine the possibility of setting up a green version of the International Financial Services centre. "At the suggestion of the High Level Action Group on Green Enterprise, established by the tanaiste Mary Coughlan, my department is currently assessing plans to establish a green international services centre in the Dublin Docklands," Cowen told the launch of a Citi group research centre in Dublin last month. [...] However, green groups, such as Friends of the Earth, say that an increased focus on carbon emissions trading could trigger another financial crisis, with ever more complex derivatives being sold on carbon trading markets.

title: Read my ... er, book: It's the oil, stupid
news: In 2001, the U.S. military had a hell of a problem resupplying its diesel-run military bases in Iraq's Anbar Province with fuel [...] "Green hawks" armed with distributed energy saved lives, reduced carbon and proved that energy independence is not just an economic issue. Being green, in fact, delivered true tactical advantages. Nolan later reflected, "If we can get this out to Iraq, soldiers are going to come back and say, 'Why can't I have this at home.' " This radical story appears near the end of Hot, Flat and Crowded, Thomas Friedman's tour de force on the global implications of too many people wanting to live like fat and lazy North Americans [...] By Friedman's evocative accounting, the globe has now entered the "Energy-Climate Era" and faces several hot emergencies: petropolitics (it gives power and money to leaders who have earned neither); dramatic climate disruption; the rise of middle classes in India and China; and a real weapon of mass destruction, the catastrophic loss of biodiversity in the world's forests and oceans. [...]  For climate doubters and libertarian oil slavers who shout "Drill, baby, drill," Friedman offers a caveat: What's the worst that can happen if climate change magically chills out and oil becomes blessedly infinite? Well, the continent has energy-efficient vehicles, higher prices but lower energy bills and an export industry in clean power products as well as renewed global respect. Code Green, in other words, can only make the United States more resilient.  [...]  "Right now we are having a green hallucination, not a green revolution," Friedman writes. Where, asks the testy New York Times columnist, are the higher efficiency standards, the tougher regulations and ethic of conservation needed to drive a revolution? Where, echoes David O'Reilly, Chevron's CEO, are the leaders who understand the scale and difficulty of the transition? Mao Zedong, an absolutely vile man, got one thing right: "A revolution is not a dinner party." Franklin D. Roosevelt, Friedman says, didn't marshal the U.S. public during the Second World War by writing essays called The Easy Way to Defeat Fascism.  [...]  Renewable energy mandates can also propel the green revolution. Then-governor of Texas George W. Bush proved the point when he signed the Texas Renewable Portfolio Mandate in 1999, to build 2,000 new megawatts of clean energy by 2009. The state surpassed the mandate by 2006. So yes, basic public policy can drive innovation and spur economic diversification. In fact, the market demands it. [...]

title: Green tick as partners ponder gas investment
news: The Federal Government has given the green light for ExxonMobil and BHP Billiton to build the world's biggest floating LNG operation over their Scarborough gas field. But the environmental approval does not guarantee the two companies will push ahead with developing the big but remote gas resources, almost 300km off the Pilbara coast. [...] Signing off on the approval on Friday, Environment Minister Greg Hunt hinted the Scarborough partners were eyeing Exmouth as the supply base for their FLNG ambitions by restricting supply vessel movements in September and October to protect marine life while employing dedicated marine fauna observers for humpback whales. [...]

title: Flora to fit the fauna; Residents of the zoo's new Big Cat Falls will move into the purrfect environment, with more than 300 species of plants to remind them of home.
news: […] The stars of the $20 million Big Cat Falls are the big cats, of course, including the lion who feasted on Bachmann's bush. She and three others join jaguars, leopards, tigers and cougars in the BANK OF AMERICA exhibit, which opens Thursday.[…] More than that, the plantings will illustrate what Chris Waldron, assistant mammals curator, calls "the web of interconnectedness in nature." Once that web was called, simplistically, the food chain.[…] "When we see animals in something that doesn't look like a jungle or a forest, we think something's wrong with the zoo. That's not necessarily so," Hyson says. "As long as the animals' needs are being met, it's fine." And while there's only so much you can do at an urban zoo, he stresses, "it's not just the quantity of space the animals have, but the quality."

title: The answer is lying in the wind - and sun
news: The story "Timing is everything for Whitehaven" (AFR 8 28) justifies the continued expansion of Australia's coal mining and exports with the wonderful fiction that the profits of the coal industry will be used to solve the catastrophic climate change that it is causing. […] Investment analysts from Citigroup, HSBC, Deutsche Bank and Standard & Poor's all confirm that coal demand is slowing globally, and will continue to do so. Australia is in a unique position to profit from renewable energy market growth, which the International Energy Agency calls "the fastest-growing power generation sector" and that within four years, a quarter of the world's electricity will come from renewables. If only we could stop denying the reality of the problem and its solutions, Australia could capitalise on the real opportunities they present. Every other major economy is doing just that and our window of opportunity may already be closing. Timing is indeed everything.

title: Corrections
news: An article on Nov. 5 about the large number of hikers climbing Mission Peak in Fremont, Calif., misstated the job title of one hiker, Shevon O. Korth. She is a contract adviser at CHEVRON's Environmental Management Company, not a supply chain manager.

title: Proposed PNG gas pipeline to Qld may bring $51b income
news: THE Papua New Guinea to Gladstone gas pipeline could generate corporate income of between $34 billion and $51.4 billion over its 30-year life, according to a study by ACIL. […] The report from policy and economic analyst ACIL concluded that even assuming moderate growth in gas consumption in the Queensland market, the pipeline would generate massive benefits for the state. And it forecast the net present value of the investment differential resulting from a "medium demand" for gas along the pipeline's route would be $34 billion. […] The ACIL report also considers the possibility of creating a spur line to Weipa and CHEVRON expects the biggest beneficiary to be Townsville, Mackay and, of course, Gladstone. […] Through the replacement of coal by gas as a major energy source, Australia would also move a long way towards complying with the massive cuts it must achieve in greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Study offers grim energy outlook; Former Exxon chief helped efforts to examine 'hard truths'
news: It started with a simple question by Samuel Bodman, the U.S. energy secretary: What does the future hold for supplies of oil and natural gas? The query was made in October 2005 in a one-page letter sent to Lee Raymond, the former chairman of Exxon Mobil and head of the National Petroleum Council, a U.S. advisory group representing the oil industry. […] Some of the recommendations made by the petroleum council probably far exceed what the administration of President George W. Bush was expecting: for example, calling for a nationwide standard to manage carbon emissions and taking steps to moderate consumption. […] The council report warns of ''accumulating risks'' to energy production, including rising geopolitical barriers, inflation in costs, dwindling numbers of petroleum engineers and growing constraints on carbon dioxide emissions. Although it does not say so explicitly, the subtext of the council's study suggests that high energy prices might be here to stay. […] The list of contributors to the petroleum council's report is a roster of top industry leaders and consultants, including senior executives from Exxon and CHEVRON. But the council also enlisted the help of private research centers, academic institutions, banks, government agencies and environmental groups like Resources for the Future and the Alliance to Save Energy. […] Perhaps the biggest surprise is that Raymond, who was well known for his skepticism about global warming when he was chairman of Exxon Mobil, has given his support to a study that says oil companies and governments need to address carbon emissions and offers some suggestions for how carbon dioxide can be trapped in underground reservoirs. […]

title: New Kyoto targets tipped
news: AUSTRALIA would "probably have to bring in new measures" to meet its Kyoto target on reducing greenhouse emissions, Environment Minister Ian Campbell said yesterday in an apparent shift of the Government's position. […] But former US vice-president Al Gore said Mr Howard's promotion of a new global climate change pact that would protect Australia's economic interests was unrealistic and likely to fail. In Australia this month to help Australians become "climate change presenters", Mr Gore yesterday urged Mr Howard to join the current world negotiations in Nairobi on a tougher, second phase of the international Kyoto Protocol. […] In a major shift in rhetoric, Mr Howard said on Monday that he would form a government-business taskforce to consider a global carbon trading scheme to help tackle climate change. His own Greenhouse Office has researched and made recommendations on emissions trading in papers dating as far back as 1999, but they have been ignored. Yesterday, Mr Howard met business leaders, including BHP chairman Don Argus, Rio Tinto Aluminium chief executive Oscar Groenveld, and CHEVRON oil chief executive Colin Beckett, to discuss emissions trading. It appears that scientists, energy experts and environmentalists will not be consulted, although they have been long-term supporters of such a global scheme. […]

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises pushes green message
news: Coca-Cola Enterprises (CCE), the UK's biggest bottler of Coke products, has appointed Engine to handle its multi-million-pound pan-European sustainability brief. Engine won the business following a three-way pitch against VCCP and Publicis.[...] The ad uses the strapline, 'It's nice to put faces to a name'. It describes the plant as 'one of the most environmentally aware' and flags up the fact that it sends no waste to landfill. [...]

title: Oil, gas sector grows up with mega-projects
news: THE Queensland oil and gas sector has long been regarded as the infant brother of the major mining companies but changing attitudes and some big gambles are bringing massive expansion. […] Gas from the pipeline will eventually power the massive mining projects of the north-west minerals province. The Century zinc project has already committed to taking its power from Mt Isa's Mica Creek power station, which is being transformed to a gas-fired facility. […] Gas will also fire a proposed $1 billion Comalco alumina refinery at Gladstone as well as a much-needed base load power station at Townsville. To get the gas to those two cities, CHEVRON is putting together a scheme to pipe natural gas from Papua New Guinea's massive Kutubu fields across the Torres Strait and down the coastline of Queensland. That alone is expected to cost more than $3 billion and in its environmental impact statement, CHEVRON said the spin-off in associated projects was likely to be about $8.4 billion.[…]

title: Regular flooding could hit Belfast by end of century
news: HUNDREDS of millions of pounds worth of commercial real estate along Belfast's shoreline could be hit by regular flooding by the end of this century. That's the stark warning from Friends of the Earth, which has released a map revealing how Northern Ireland's commercial heartland will be hit every four years on average by what are currently one-in-100 year flood events. [...] Flooding could also affect the area surrounding the £97m Titanic Signature Project, while a host of companies based at Northern Ireland Science Park, including US finance giant CITIGROUP, will also lie in the danger zone. [...] The dangers were outlined by Friends of the Earth and the Town and Country Planning Association, who hosted a climate change conference to examine how our planning system will have to play a key role in reducing emissions and building the resilience of homes and communities. "Climate change will have dramatic implications for all our cities and particularly those vulnerable to sea level rise," FOE Northern Ireland climate campaigner Declan Allison said. [...]

title: Quirky imagery can either bait or baffle
news: We're culturally inclined to come to a dead halt when we encounter red ink on a page because it often indicates a punitive message from a teacher, a professor or a supervisor. It's one of several reasons why we looked long and hard at this breakthrough spread from Microsoft Corp. that parodies a standard-issue editorial profile of the smartest guys in the room. […] Unusual images that prompt the reader to ponder them are no guarantee of success, however. Take this gray-toned ad for IBM Corp. that looks like precipitation on a windshield. Or is it an Arctic ice flow? Or a brain scan? Wrong, wrong and wrong. We are actually looking at packing peanuts. States IBM's headline: ``Depicts 440,000 packing peanuts, equal the number of pounds of CO2 that can be emitted by a single overseas shipment.'' Unsure exactly what was doing the ``depicting,'' we visited the snippet of text, which says: ``What if your inventory knew how to take a shortcut? IBM can help companies restructure supply chains, create shorter shipping distances and consolidate deliveries to cut carbon emissions. Let's build smarter supply chains.'' We still didn't get it and considered a visit to the highlighted Web site, but no time for that. Let's hope the ad registered with its intended targets.A middle ground between IBM's bland, inscrutable image and Microsoft's riveting spread that bleeds red ink is an eye-catcher for Intuit Inc.'s QuickBooks accounting software featuring a dog groomer who has adorned a golden retriever from head to toe with her receipts and invoices. […]

title: CHEVRON has money to burn
news: CHEVRON says it remains committed to Western Australia's $20 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas development despite industry scepticism that cost blow-outs have made it a marginal project. CHEVRON Australia's general manager for Gorgon, Colin Beckett, said the offshore joint venture was spending $US20 million ($22.45 million) a month on engineering and had spent $US60 million on a well to study carbon dioxide storage. […] Last month, the Federal Government gave environmental approval for the first two proposed Gorgon trains, but the joint venture partners, CHEVRON, Shell and ExxonMobil, have yet to approve construction. Only two LNG projects have been approved worldwide since 2005 - one in Peru and Woodside Petroleum's $12 billion Pluto project. Mr Beckett said Gorgon was continuing its front-end engineering and design work, and examining its contracting strategies, given the heated construction market. […] The joint venture selected Barrow Island because it has some existing infrastructure. A separate CHEVRON-led joint venture produces 8000 barrels of oil a day on Barrow Island, down from a peak of 50,000 in the 1970s.

title: Floating LNG Plants Coming
news: Natural-gas liquefaction and gasification plants are huge, expensive and, up until now, land-based. However, in 7 2012, Black & Veatch (No. 14) and Shanghai-based shipbuilder and engineering firm Wison Offshore & Marine Ltd. won a contract to design and construct the world's first floating LNG (FLNG) liquefaction, regasification and storage unit. [...] On April 2, ExxonMobil and BHP Billiton of Australia submitted plans to Australia's Environmental Dept. to build another large FLNG.

title: SMEs told aid money holds better prospects; Exporting - Environmental Management - Vietnam
news: Australian small and medium enterprises would be better served bidding for environmental management contracts funded by international aid. According to Austrade senior trade commissioner in Vietnam Ms Vi Le, many large companies which set up new factories establish their own environmental management projects independently. Corporations like COCA-COLA, for example, often prefer to use their own suppliers which meant that opportunities in the commercial sector were few, she said. "For an Australian small business which is a provider of products and services in the environmental area, the opportunities probably lie more in whatever government projects may exist."[…]

title: Leaders fiddle while the world burns; GREEN BUSINESS
news: THE word is, new modelling is being done on a "10 per cent by 2020" target for greenhouse gas reductions - double that of last year - suggesting that, despite all the wailing, the climate debate moves only one way: ever more pressing, ever more expensive. Even so, the question of targets is in the too-hard basket of the Climate Change Minister, Greg Combet. At a speech to institutional investors in Sydney before Christmas, Combet was keen to emphasise the government could initially put a price on carbon - say at a fixed, rather than market rate - without stipulating an emissions reduction target. That would skirt an ugly stoush with the Greens, soon to hold the balance of power in the Senate, as Combet later explained: "What's evident from the debate we've had over the last few years is it's certainly going to be testing for the government and the Greens to ever come to an accommodation over the level of the target.  [...] A Citigroup analyst, Elaine Prior, threw Combet a two-pronged question about (a) whether a carbon price might at first be imposed just to cover the electricity sector, the source of most emissions; and (b) the level of compensation for emissions-intensive, trade-exposed industries such as steel and aluminium, and the electricity generation sector in the transition phase. "I'm wondering," she said to nervous laughs, "whether the negotiations held a year ago in terms of transitional assistance, whether that was likely to be as good as it would get for industry - whether the current make-up of Parliament means perhaps industry will regret not agreeing, in a sense, to the proposals that were put forward last year?" [...]

title: Big boys clean up in green awards
news: WITH less than three weeks to go before the closing date for entries to The Sunday Times ScotlandKPMG Environment Awards for Business the running still seems to be being made by the major organisations and multinationals. This seems to bear out a straw poll which has been carried out in conjunction with awards which shows that corporate environmental activity is largely driven by legislation and is not being practised by smaller companies.[…] Another company which believes its environmental policies have made a positive impact on profits is Carron Phoenix, a company which used to make cannons for Wellington and Nelson. Now it is a specialist manufacturer of composite, granite and stainless steel sinks employing 300 people in Falkirk.  Its entry is based on a revolutionary moulding process.  Other entrants include: Alcan, Anaplast, Compaq, Gleneagles Hotel, Honeywell, Scottish Hydro, IBM, Mitsubishi, Motorola, Philips Lighting, Scottish Coal, Scottish Courage, Scottish Nuclear, ScottishPower, Stewart Milne Group and Volvo Bus and Trucks. Entries close on November 10. Forms can be obtained from Shona Conacher at KPMG on 0131-222 2000.

title: The eco-friendly face of Coke
news: In terms of corporate philanthropy and corporate citizenship, many Japanese companies still lag behind their U.S. counterparts. Few Japanese businesses, even on their home turf, could beat Coca-Cola, for example, in terms of their contributions to society.[…] What is the current situation concerning the recycling of used cans and bottles? As for cans, more than 80 percent of them are now being recycled. But only 17 percent of PET bottles--which account for about 17 percent of beverage containers--were recycled industrywide last year. One main reason for the low rates of recycling is the lack of what is known as the curbside collection system (type-by-type collection of used containers) in the 3,200 cities, towns and villages across the country. Another reason is that PET bottles cannot currently be recycled for use by different brands--unlike cans, which can be recycled after use by Coke for use by PEPSI, for example. So Coca-Cola (Japan) is now working hard to realize a bottle-to-bottle recycling system for PET bottles, as we expect to see more bottles than cans in future. As no such system has yet been realized, we plan to test a partially recycled PET bottle in the near future. It will be a three-layer one with recycled PET materials sandwiched between new PET materials.[…]

title: Mackenzie pipe report delayed to end-2009
news: […] Canadian regulators handling the proposed Mackenzie Gas Project, slated to deliver Arctic natural gas to southern Canadian and US markets, said December 5 they will not wrap up their work until the end of 2009. The Joint Review Panel, appointed by the federal government to review environmental and social impacts of the $16C.2 billion ($12.5 billion) project, does not expect to complete a "full and fair review" of evidence from 115 hearing days and more than 5,000 written submissions until December 2009, it said in a statement. The panel said it has "carefully reviewed its work plan and its considerable progress so far" in setting a December 2009 target. The new target was seen as bad news by Imperial Oil, lead partner in the MacKenzie Gas Project consortium.[...] In addition to Imperial, the MacKenzie Gas Project partners are ConocoPhillips, Shell, ExxonMobil and Mackenzie Valley Aboriginal Pipeline, representing aboriginal communities in the Northwest Territories offered a one-third equity stake in the pipeline.[...]

title: Russia'damage'charges threat to Shell
news: ROYAL Dutch Shell's Russian Sakhalin-2 venture may face criminal charges of destroying forests in the remote Siberian region. Oleg Mitvol, deputy head of the Natural Resources Ministry, said in Moscow that construction of a pipeline across Sakhalin Island caused at least 11 million roubles (Pounds 220,000) of damage to the forests. [...]US oil major EXXON MOBIL and France's Total have also become embroiled in President Vladimir Putin's programme to increase state control of energy supplies. [...]

title: CAA backs federal plan to ban gasoline additive
news: MONTREAL (CP) - The Canadian Automobile Association has thrown its support behind proposed federal legislation to prohibit the use of the chemical MMT in gasoline.[...]The octane-boosting manganese compound has been at the centre of a dispute between the Canadian auto and oil industries for years. Car companies say MMT causes pollution-control malfunctions that can actually increase emissions. […] MMT has also been criticized by environmentalists because it contains the metal manganese, which can cause nervous disorders. Canadian critics of MMT suffered a setback last week, when the U.S. Court of Appeals re-authorized use of MMT - pending an appeal of the decision by the Environmental Protection Agency. […] A spokesperson for Canadian petroleum companies said his industry would be ready to replace MMT with another additive if an independent study proved it was harmful to a car's anti-emission system. Brandon Hawley said only one Canadian oil company, CHEVRON, currently offers gas without MMT, and only within British Columbia.Canada; regulation; gasoline; chemical; pollution

title: Timetable comes under review
news: The Rudd government's ambitious reform agenda is showing signs of slowing under its own weight, with the release of the first issues paper by the Henry Review of the taxation system among a number of government reports that have been delayed.[...] A review of climate change-related spending programs - to assess whether they will be needed after Australia has established a national emissions trading system - is expected to be handed to Finance Minister Lindsay Tanner, by CITIGROUP's public-sector group head, Roger Wilkins. Prime Minister Kevin Rudd yesterday argued that the global storm clouds gathering had become darker since the government was elected, "reinforcing the urgency for long-term, responsible reform".[...]

title: Trade mission nets deal Contacts leads to $2.1M contract with U.S. firm
news: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina -- All Ronald Allen hoped to bring back from a 1995 Commerce Department trade mission to this country was some contact -- any contact -- with the national and local governments here. "We got more than that," Allen says, in a million-dollar understatement. Make that a $ 2.1 million understatement. Two weeks ago, Allen signed a $ 2.1 million deal with an Argentine firm that will have his company, Alenco International, design and build an industrial waste treatment plant in southern Buenos Aires.[…] CHRONOLOGY OF THE ALENCO DEAL. Early 1992: Alenco sends representatives to Argentina to gauge business opportunities in the region. Mid-1993: Alenco signs a contract to perform a pilot study to determine how to treat waste from a chocolate factory in northwest Argentina. 1 1995: Negotiations begin to hire a local representative in Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital. April 1995: The newly hired local representative brings three deals to Alenco: improving waste treatment at a local COCA COLA operation; building and operating a facility to treat waste from a yogurt factory; and doing a pilot study on treating waste from a Mazola oil subsidiary.[…]

title: Tough action urged on climate change
news: SUPERANNUATION funds and other key investors have backed the Federal Government's planned 2010 emissions trading scheme but want it to consider taking tougher action to tackle climate change. The Investor Group on Climate Change is a collaboration of investors managing $500 billion in funds. IGCC members include AMP Capital Investors, Colonial First State, Vision Super, Merrill Lynch, Suncorp Investment Management and Catholic Super. They say they want strong action to halt climate change because its impacts risk hurting future investment returns. [...] In December a group of senior Australian economists, including ANZ chief economist Saul Eslake, Citi's Paul Brennan and nabCapital chief economist Stephen Halmarick, said a well-designed emissions trading scheme was better than a carbon tax to achieve a low-carbon economy with minimal restraint on economic growth. But they said that the design of the current scheme was flawed in giving shelter to carbon polluters. The economists warned that excluding or giving special concessions ``to particular polluters would come at a very real cost to the community in terms of lost incentives and opportunities to develop new technologies and alternative products''.

title: 'GREEN' ELECTRICITY TO BE SOLD IN REGION
news: For most electricity customers, "going green" means parting with some extra green - to pay the higher cost of cleanly produced energy.But up to 50,000 customers of Peco Energy Co. will get the chance to buy cleaner electricity at no additional charge later this year.Green Mountain Energy Co., a marketer of environmentally friendly power based in Austin, Texas, said yesterday that it had received approval from the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to offer randomly selected Peco customers up to a 2 percent discount from their Peco bills. […] Some Peco customers were confused and upset last month when they were switched to New Power Co., a joint venture of Enron Corp., America Online Inc. and INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES Corp., in a similar bid to encourage competition. Many did not like the idea of being automatically switched to another supplier.[…]

title: A thirsty world is running dry
news: Australia could profit hugely from the imminent end of world oil supplies. THE world's biggest oil company, Exxon Mobil, made a profit of $A13.6 billion last quarter. That works out at $54 billion a year, or $1 billion profit a week. Last week, all five global oil giants reported their quarterly results and all told the same story: Royal Dutch $9.5 billion profit (up 40 per cent); BP $9.5 billion (up 30 per cent); ConocoPhillips, $6.8 billion (up 65 per cent); and CHEVRON, $5.7 billion (up 19 per cent). That's a collective quarterly profit of $45 billion - almost $3.5 billion a week. […] The short-term thinking, the unworldly macho posturing, has been mind-boggling. The invasion of Iraq tops the list of examples. The war on terrorism has to start at the petrol pump. Where do Hezbollah and the mullahs of Iran get the billions needed for waging jihad and building a nuclear weapons program? From oil. All this leaves Australia at a very significant crossroads. The world is clearly running out of oil, running out of time, and running into global warming. Every feasible alternative for generating energy has to be considered - bio-fuels (ethanol), geothermal energy, solar energy, coastal wave energy, wind farming, liquid natural gas and nuclear power. […] But events have conspired to make uranium, which produces about 6 per cent of the world's energy output, appear less evil than the oil-coal status quo. This is what puts Australia at a moral and economic crossroads. When it comes to nuclear power, Australia is to uranium reserves what Saudi Arabia is to oil. […] For this Australia would charge a premium, and pay an environmental price. We become the world's leading uranium cop. All in the name of addressing two greater evils - global warming and global terrorism - while expanding economic growth. That's why the Prime Minister wants a debate on uranium. I think that's what John Howard means when he says Australia could become "an energy superpower". […]

title: Global warming agenda to hit living standards
news: LOOKING at the scale of the fiscal correction needed, does anyone seriously think that a major new burden on the households who rely on benefits the most is remotely affordable? Politicians are clinging to their climate change policies but that is going to become increasingly untenable as the costs mount. Citigroup expect that in order to meet environmental targets, (EURO)229bn (£200bn) will need to be invested in Britain's energy sector alone. Paying for all that investment will take higher profits and higher prices. They believe it will require a 52 per cent increase in dual fuel bills above inflation. The government thinks it can avoid putting more pressure on families by improving energy efficiency. But someone needs to pay for all that investment. Citigroup says that even with energy efficiency gains there will be a 35 per cent increase in bills, and that's before paying for the insulation work which could offset the savings. [...]

title: Green is the new black, darlings
news: […] Trumpeting non-battery eggs in its ready-to-eat meals and promoting the use of Fairtrade cotton has probably done more for the market recovery of M&S than anything, including those advertising shots of Twiggy. "The evidence collected by the company indicates this was the most positive campaign the business has ever run," a report by CITIGROUP analysts said last week. […] Understandably, the open-toed sandal brigade is rather chuffed about being taken up by the Jimmy Choo bunch. Tony Juniper, director of Friends of the Earth, describes the embrace of people such as Gwyneth Paltrow as a "high water mark" for the green moment.[…]

title: Tax warning for gas hopes
news: A FEDERAL government minister has warned that a proposed $5 billion, leading-edge gas-to-liquids project won't be considered for tax relief unless the WA Government "champions" it. Federal Industry, Tourism and Resources Minister Ian Macfarlane is resisting pressure from Sasol CHEVRON to approve a raft of incentives to encourage construction of a plant at Barrow Island off the WA coast. The plan is to turn natural gas into a synthetic product -- using a Sasol proprietary process -- that would deliver clean diesel to help meet an expected shortage of liquid transport fuel in Australia before the end of the decade. […] The minister is believed to have argued that Sasol CHEVRON had not demonstrated the project had high-level WA Government support. […] The WA Government has imposed the most stringent environmental assessment process on the development of Gorgon, owned by a group led by CHEVRONTexaco, because it is proposed that end uses such as GTL and liquefied natural gas would require processing plants to be built on Barrow Island, which is a A-class nature reserve. The Gorgon partners have said that unless Barrow is used exploiting the reserves will be uneconomic. […]

title: Marketplace trading will add value to every drop
news: While large swaths of Britain were struggling under several feet of water this summer, the wider world was on the verge of droughts. That is why water is even more valuable than oil and could end up being traded in a financial marketplace.  An extremely small percentage of the water in the world is drinkable -the rest is saline, ice or locked underground. Last year some of the largest companies in the world, including Shell, Coca Cola and Procter & Gamble, published a three-year study into future water availability. The study outlined three gloomy future scenarios. Without better management and new water-saving technologies, forecasters have suggested that cholera could return to London, Africans could be forced into mass migration, causing civil unrest in Europe, and the booming economy in China could crash in just eight years. [...]

title: Big-brand boost for carbon Courtauld 2
news: Part two of the Courtauld Commitment defied industry sceptics last month when 28 brands and retailers signed up prior to its launch. Household names including Nestle, Unilever, Heinz and Boots have backed the second phase of the grocery packaging and waste reduction scheme, which focuses on carbon rather than weight as the key measure for packaging's environmental impact. A number of major brands have said they will not sign up to the Wrap-led scheme including United Biscuits, Kellogg's and Procter & Gamble, while others such as Coca-Cola have said they will consider the scheme. [...]

title: $25bn GAS PROJECT LNG go-ahead
news: US energy giant CHEVRON has gained environmental approval for its $25 billion Wheatstone liquefied natural gas project in Western Australia. Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke said 70 conditions would apply to the project, off the Pilbara coast. The strictest conditions are intended to help protect threatened and migratory species, such as whales, and the marine environment.

title: CHEVRON flags bigger Gorgon
news: CHEVRON has admitted it has a long-term plan to expand dramatically the Gorgon gas project on environmentally fragile Barrow Island to feed growing demand for liquefied natural gas. The US-based energy giants plan would see output from Gorgon double to more than 20 million tonnes through the addition of a further two production trains at a likely cost of up to $6 billion in todays money. CHEVRON, the project operator, and its partners, ExxonMobil and Shell, have been reluctant to talk up expansion plans, though their environmental impact statement for Gorgon makes it clear that "a third and possibly a fourth LNG train" may be proposed "in the future" on the 300ha A-class reserve set aside for the development. However, CHEVRON chief executive Dave OReilly indicated yesterday that a major expansion was on the long-term agenda for Gorgon, which last week won environmental approvals from the WA Government. […] "The whole LNG market has turned, its not just a function of any one country", he said, adding that demand was also sharply on the rise in Europe, US, Japan and Korea, as well as the boom countries of China and India. "Theres an enormous global interest in gas because its environmentally friendly, relative to some of the alternatives." CHEVRON and its partners must now await federal environmental approvals and incorporate the WA conditions into its development plan. "At the same time we are looking at some of the optimisation work that we have been undertaking to address concerns; we are in a very strong cost increase environment as an industry," CHEVRON Australia managing director Jay Johnson said.

title: Major oil find could boost US reserves by half
news: One of the world's biggest oil companies held out the prospect that the US could increase its domestic oil reserves by up to a half after unveiling positive results from drilling in the Gulf of Mexico yesterday. CHEVRON said it had made significant progress in its exploration of a new oil field deep below the sea-bed, 270 miles south-west of New Orleans. Industry analysts believe that the field could contain up to 15 billion barrels of oil and may overtake BP's troubled Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska as the country's largest. If CHEVRON and others can overcome the technical difficulties in extracting oil, it could also significantly lessen US dependence on foreign oil, and reduce political pressure to open up the environmentally sensitive areas of Alaska. President George Bush has long emphasised the need for the US to reduce its dependence on oil from trouble-spots such as the Middle East, one of the reasons he has supported an end to the ban on further exploration in the Alaskan national wildlife reserve. […]

title: Green groundwork
news: […]  Why design sustainable buildings? According to Wikipedia buildings in the United States account for 39 percent of total energy use 12 of water consumption 68 of total electricity consumption and 38% of total carbon dioxide emissions. Globally the energy consumed within buildings is considered to be one of the most problematic for the environment.  Sustainable design essentially tries to reduce the use of non-renewable resources minimizing the environmental impact of buildings and humans alike. […] Israel recently implemented a voluntary standard for "buildings with reduced environmental impact" that evaluates the environmental sustainability of buildings based on a point rating system. The US green building council rating system was also implemented on several buildings here including the INTEL Development center in Haifa.[…]

title: ExxonMobil plans large ethane cracker in Texas
news: EXXONMOBIL CHEMICAL said 6 1 it plans to build a "world-scale" ethylene plant at its Texas olefins complex and two polyethylene units nearby to take advantage of low-cost natural gas for feedstock. Plans call for construction to begin by next March on a 1.5 million mt/year ethylene-capacity steam cracker at the complex 30 miles east of Houston, a major hub for the US petrochemical industry. Start-up could come as early as 2016, ExxonMobil said in filings with the Environmental Protection Agency and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. [...]

title: Jared Blumenfield: At the cutting edge of climate change
news: […] California-New Zealand cities are also on the front lines in developing innovative and effective environmental programmes. We are cities with a global view. When it comes to the world's most significant environmental challenge, climate change, it is clear that greenhouse gas emissions are all local. There are no international smokestacks and no cross-continental gas-guzzling vehicles. […] As a result in San Francisco we worked with the United Nations Global Compact and a coalition of local businesses to create the Business Council for Climate Change, or "BC3" as it is known (www.bc3sfbay.org). BC3 was based on five principles agreed to by all the 70-plus members. These included taking action in your own business, acting as a community champion, developing legislation, taking collective business council BC3 actions, and providing public information on each company's climate footprint. The first thing we found is that even with large companies like the Gap, CISCO SYSTEMS and Accenture, there was a need to know about government programmes developed to help business with climate issues. For example, many of our businesses do not know there are financial programmes to help with everything from energy efficiency to renewable energy or transportation demand management. There are literally millions of dollars available to help companies to do this, but too often business is unaware. I have little doubt this situation, for example, is replicated in cities across New Zealand.[…]

title: Reserve hit in gas push
news: ENERGY giant CHEVRON has received conditional approval to clear an additional 32ha of land on Barrow Island for the construction of Australia's largest gas project.The WA Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) recommended CHEVRON's -proposal for the Gorgon development be granted conditional approval to undertake clearing and earthworks on Barrow -Island, an A-Class reserve off WA's Pilbara coast. EPA chairman Paul Vogel said the authority had concluded the conditions set out in the original development -approval were effective and should be implemented for the additional development.

title: BP profit slides as Gulf spill charges mount
news: London BP November 2 reported a sharp fall in replacement cost profit for the third quarter after the company booked new spill charges, raising the expected cost of dealing with the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico to $40 billion. BP reported a replacement cost profit, which strips out the value of inventories, of $1.847 billion for the third quarter, down from $4.981 billion in the same period of 2009. [...] Based on the assumption that gross negligence cannot be established by forthcoming US government reports into the incident, CITIGROUP estimated that the cost of the Macondo event to BP shareholders is $40 billion or less. [...]

title: Africa; Investors Push Food Industry Giants for Urgent Action On Transparency
news: Today 33 major investment funds, representing nearly $1.4 trillion of assets under management, called on food industry giants to improve their supply chain policies and transparency. In a statement shared with the ten biggest food and beverage companies in the world, the investors expressed support for Oxfam's Behind the Brands initiative and urged companies to do more to reduce social and environmental risks in their supply chains. "Due to a lack of transparency within the sector, it is difficult to fully evaluate the risk and opportunity that our companies bear within their supply chains," reads the statement sponsored by Calvert Investments and signed by investors including F&C Asset Management, BNP Paribas Investment Partners and Aviva Investors. […] Score increases since February: Unilever and Nestle: 7%. Coca-Cola: 5%[…] PEPSICO, Associated British Foods (ABF) and Kellogg's: No Change[…]

title: Hot decisions ahead at BHP and Rio as the world warms
news: […] That's the conclusion of CITIGROUP researchers who released a report yesterday examining the risks and opportunities that global warming poses for the Australian Stock Exchange's top 100 stocks. Analysts Bruce Rolph and Elaine Prior believe the winners will be alternative energy, sustainable property, recycling, innovative financial institutions and some healthcare firms. […] As the Federal Government increasingly considers carbon trading, which is already well advanced in Europe, CITIGROUP forecasts Australia will adopt the system as early as 2010. While global warming may not affect the short-term bottom line, the report stresses firms which move early stand the most to gain and ''should be best-placed to take advantage of opportunities . . .''. […]

title: Comment: Rio's reprise must set hard deadlines for development: Twenty years ago we saw breakthrough: this time we need follow through. The state of the planet is a shared responsibility
news: […] Second, Rio must set out a plan for the future. The best way to drive progress is through clear ambitions with hard deadlines. […] And finally, we need to bring business in. Using resources responsibly is in business's own interests too. PEPSI depends on water, Unilever depends on fish stocks and agricultural land, and every firm relies on a stable fuel supply. But while nine out of 10 chief executives say sustainability is fundamental to their success, only two out of 10 record the resources they consume. So the UK will press for governments to come together, working with those companies already blazing a trail, to give "sustainability reporting" a global push. By agreeing common standards and practices we can get many more firms on board. And in the UK, from the start of next financial year, all firms listed on the London Stock Exchange will have to report the levels of greenhouse gases they emit.[…]

title: SK Innovation to bask in Sinopec's halted paraxylene plant '
news: HONG KONG (Yonhap) -- Korea's top refiner SK Innovation Co. could benefit from a Chinese state oil firm's decision to scrap a petrochemical plant in eastern China as it stands to enjoy higher margins, a report said Tuesday. BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch said in the report that SK Innovation, along with Japan's JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp., will likely be the biggest beneficiaries of the recently canceled plan to build a new a paraxylene plant in Ningbo. Thousands of people marched through the city over the weekend to protest against the expansion of a petrochemical factory owned by China Petroleum and Chemical Corp. (Sinopec), the country's biggest oil refiner. The protesters argued that the plant to produce paraxylene, a flammable, carcinogenic liquid used in polyester, would cause pollution in the city. Sinopec's existing plant in Ninbo already produces 500,000 metric tons of the product each year. Following the protests, which swelled to clashes between citizens and police, the Ningbo government said it will scrap the 55.8 billion yuan ($8.8 billion) project. "We cautiously reckon there may potentially be pressure on various other paraxylene projects in China," said Kenneth Whee, a research analyst at BANK OF AMERICA."Indeed, plans to build a paraxylene plant in the northeastern port of Dalian were also shelved in 8 last year following public demonstrations."[…]

title: Miners heed storm warnings
news: BHP Billiton recognises the impact of climate change on its business, but the world's biggest miner is not as prepared for the challenges of the issue as rival Rio Tinto.  A CITIGROUP review on the effect of climate change on the world's 12 biggest miners shows many are unprepared for the physical impacts of the phenomenon, and those that believe they're not at risk are simply less aware of the issues. According to the bank, risks come from an increased frequency of severe weather events such as storms, cyclones and floods, changes in fresh water availability, thawing permafrost in frozen regions and increased political instability. In Australia, increased cyclonic activity in Western Australia and Queensland, worse storm surges in Queensland and Victoria, more frequent droughts in NSW and reduced fresh water availability in the south-west of WA loom. CITIGROUP director of investment research Elaine Prior said companies were better prepared for the introduction of a carbon trading scheme within the next five years than the potential impact of climate change on their assets. "I think that the degree of awareness varies from company to company and what I'd also point out is . . . I've looked at large companies . . . and I think it's unlikely smaller companies in Australia would be ahead of the leaders," Ms Prior said. [...] CITIGROUP indicated Rio Tinto was the most advanced in its preparation, having identified a number of areas of assessment and conducted an internal review. [...]

title: China acts to tie up WA iron ore
news: China has underlined its need to lock in additional long-term iron ore supplies by unveiling a string of deals to foster increased production from WAs vast iron ore fields in the Pilbara and Mid-West. The deals come as market analysts predict iron ore prices, which have already more than doubled over the past five years on the back of rampant Chinese demand, will rise at least another 25 per cent next year. Those expectations were stoked by Rio Tinto iron ore chief executive Sam Walsh yesterday after Chinese President Hu Jintao toured the companys $400 million HIsmelt pig-iron plant at Kwinana. […] The iron ore comments came as the Government presided over a 20-year agreement for the Gorgon liquefied natural gas project at Barrow Island to provide China with one million tonnes of LNG a year, despite the project still requiring environmental approvals. A spokesman for Environment Minister David Templeman confirmed that the WA Appeals Convener and the projects major shareholder CHEVRON were preparing a set of conditions for his approval. And CHEVRON conceded that the company was still evaluating the $20 billion project in light of an overheated global construction market. […]

title: BP resumes test on capped Gulf well after latest leak setback
news: BP has begun a "very, very intricate operation" to test a cap aimed at sealing its gushing Gulf of Mexico well, just hours after a leaking valve caused the operation to be delayed. [...] Mark Fletcher, an analyst from Citi also sounded a positive note, estimating total costs for the disaster at $39bn - much lower than the $80bn high end of expert forecasts. [...]

title: Location guide: Andalucia - Andalucia's attraction
news: Three times the size of Belgium, more inhabitants than Switzerland, a higher GDP than Poland, five international airports and an equal number of seaports. Andalucia, the largest of Spain's 17 autonomous regions, is making a big push to attract investment in the aeronautics industry, renewable energy, information communications technologies (ICT) and biotechnology.[…] The regional government is making great efforts to promote the biotechnology industry, which it considers an essential tool for improving the competitiveness of leading regional industries such as agribusiness, health and environmental sciences. The government has set up technology parks to attract investment from abroad, as well as within Spain. A number of major international firms have responded to this initiative, including Montsanto, Syngenta Seeds, Pioneer Hi- Breed International, Dow, Braun Medical, Pfizer and MERCK and Co. There are nearly 60 biotech companies operating in the region, about 19% of all those located in Spain.[…]

title: Miners fail to recognize climate change risks, report warns
news: Mining companies are failing to recognize the risks of climate change, a report says. More than 80 per cent of global mining companies surveyed say their physical assets would be affected by extreme weather events, yet only 13 per cent report taking preventive action, a study funded by IBM Corp. found. The report warned that mining companies need to prepare for anticipated additional costs and challenges created by a changing climate. If not, these companies could see climate change negatively impact their financial and operational performances.David Carter of IBM Global Business Services said miners "need to think about the potential impacts from inevitable climate change resulting from past greenhouse gas emissions." The report said major areas of concern include water management, employee health and safety standards, the risks involved in securing of energy supplies, increases in operating and transport costs, and political instability.

title: Water pollution caused major disruption at INTEL plant
news: EXTREME TEMPERATURES and water contamination have seriously disrupted production at the giant computer chip manufacturer INTEL in Leixlip, Co Kildare. An INTEL Ireland spokesman said the recent cold weather was a  unique situation  and had affected the company severely. This was due in part to rapidly falling temperatures, which at one point reached as low as -12 degrees at the plant. Water contamination caused additional problems for the company, which employs 4,200 people directly and indirectly and is the largest employer in Kildare. The US multinational makes computer chips which are used in 90 per cent of the world s PCs. There were concerns locally that ammonia and nitrates may have contaminated water after local authorities used an agricultural fertiliser to replace the salt component in grit on roads. This was due to a chronic shortage of rock salt. INTEL has its own pumping station on site and tests water for impurities, as extremely pure water is required for its manufacturing processes. However, it is not equipped to test for ammonia, and water samples had to be sent off-site for analysis.[…]

title: Coke and PEPSI under scrutiny for addictives
news: In a major blow to Coca-Cola and PEPSI, India's Supreme Court has ordered the government to investigate whether the soft drinks sold in the country are laced with "chemical addictives" to hook consumers.[…] After a pesticide scare caused sales of their carbonated drinks in the country to dive last year and a parliamentary panel asked for tougher quality standards, the Supreme Court ordered them last month to display warnings on their containers. The exact language of the warning would be determined by the High Court of Rajasthan state, which had first ordered them to show the composition of their drinks on a label, including the presence of pesticides and chemicals. The apex court refused to budge even when counsel for Coca-Cola and PEPSICO blamed Indian farmers for using too much pesticides which found their way into the water used by drinks manufacturers

title: Economics Watch: Surging food prices: blessing or curse?
news: Key points  * Soaring food prices are becoming a major policy issue and risk in 2008. Asian governments are responding with price controls and a mixed bag of trade measures, some of which are protectionist and some trade enhancing [...] On the supply side, climate change is increasing the volatility of weather and rainfall patterns. This vulnerability is being exacerbated by a sharp fall in arable farmland per head of global population by half over the last 50 years. Economic and political impact Whether food production will respond quickly enough to meet rising demand and tame food prices is not clear. However, for now, food prices are continuing their upward trend. This will have a major economic and political impact in Asia, with implications for policy, growth and income distribution. [...] This article is taken from CITIGROUP report dated Feb 14. Chua Hak Bin is director of Asia-Pacific economic and market analysis at CITIGROUP.

title: The red bin lid says stop before you toss your trash
news: […] Auckland city's wastes soared 30 per cent in the five years to 1996, when its population rose by a more measured 13 per cent, to 345,768 residents.[…] What do Auckland city residents throw away and how much is recycled? […] Recycling has become big business. A 1998 survey of the Auckland regional recycling industry found 64 firms employing 1736 people with an annual turnover of $132 million from collecting 641,649 tonnes of material for reuse or recycling.[…] Paper, glass and metals have strong local markets for recycling, and plastics are coming into their own after having to be stockpiled for want of stable demand. A joint venture partner of Auckland and Manukau recycling contractor Street Smart is about to export about 600 tonnes of plastic soft-drink bottles a year to COCA-COLA Amatil in Australia.The company also grinds up bottles for export to Chinese garment-makers, who turn them into polyester fabrics.[…]

title: Environment on the agenda; Reactions Vary as Station Groups, Nets, Media Conglomerates Push Their Initiatives
news: As news pros gather for the 18th annual Society of Environmental Journalists conference in Roanoke, Va., this week, the state of the industry in terms of reporting, broadcasting and covering environmental issues depends on which side of the fence you're on. Tim Wheeler, environmental reporter for The Baltimore Sun and president of the SEJ Board of Directors, is optimistic.[…] Corporate Concern. Almost every major media corporation has the environment on its agenda. NBC Universal's motto is ``awareness, activation, results'' and its ``Green Is Universal'' campaign is evident in all NBC media outlets-from NBC to Telemundo to Bravo, as well as alternative platforms online. […] Another Gannett Group product is Nashville's TennesseeGreen.com. The Web site is part of TeamGreen.com, a Middle Tennessee group that organizes events focused on health, well-being and the environment.[…] The WALT DISNEY Co., including all of its media outlets such as ABC-TV, calls its environmental initiative Environmentality, which it defines as ``attitude and commitment to think and act with the environment in mind.'' The brand represents DISNEY's fundamental ethic that blends business growth with the preservation of nature. Mr. Brent sees a pattern in some environmental coverage. ```Planet in Peril' (CNN), `Powering the Planet' (CNBC), Planet Green (Discovery) ... clearly `planet' is a brand. But what's interesting to me is what I believe to be a misguided notion that somehow we can save the planet, when in fact what we are talking about is trying to save ourselves from ourselves. The planet is too big for many people to care about. Where do you start?''[…]

title: Renewables sector challenged by low gas prices, uncertain US regulation, executives say
news: With low natural gas prices and unclear federal policies, the renewable energy sector faces a period of uncertainty, three utility executives said last week during a BANK OF AMERICA/Merrill Lynch technology conference. The lack of federal policy on greenhouse gas emissions and renewable energy requirements, plus lower load growth create uncertainty for renewables, Mark Stoering, Xcel Energy vice president, said at the meeting in New York City. Further, the stimulus bill's cash grant program for renewable projects ends later this year, he noted.[…]

title: Minister says Romania shares European countries' view on shale gas exploration
news: [...] Romania has a uniform position with the European states in respect of shale gas exploration, discussions on their exploitation going to be resumed after the outcome of the exploration stages, said Economy Minister Varujan Vosganian on Friday [17 May] in a press conference. [...] Prospecting activities for gas and shale will bypass protected areas, will be conducted at a distance of at least one kilometer from the Black Sea shore and will not take place in towns or inhabited areas, reveals an information document made recently available to AGERPRES by the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change (MMSC.) At the same time, exploration operations following prospecting will not involve the use of hydraulic fracturing process. Constanta Environmental Protection Agency recently issued the decisions on the classification stage for CHEVRON Romania Exploration and Production SRL in case of Costinesti and Vama Veche perimeters (southeast), which comprise the seismic prospecting to identify resources. The Ministry of Environment stresses that, for this stage, there is no need for environmental impact assessment because the 'exploration' is made by classical applied methods / wells drilled in Romania for decades. [...]

title: Emissions trading: Scandal-hit carbon market burns out
news: The EU carbon-trading scheme, started in 2005, was intended to be a model for a future global carbon emissions programme. As Barack Obama rose to prominence and was elected US president in 2008, the expectation was that the world's largest carbon emitter would implement legislation for a cap-and-trade system, paving the way for the next big financial market, all in aid of saving the planet. It was a nascent market with huge potential. Investment banks built up large carbon trading, sales and research teams, money poured into green funds, and carbon conferences were the place where those involved in the burgeoning industry gathered in their thousands to discuss that potential. Scandal Things haven't turned out quite as expected. US legislation has hit broad opposition, carbon prices have flat-lined for the past two years and severely curtailed trading revenues, and fund inflows have slowed to a trickle. So the last thing the market needed was a scandal that could undermine the credibility and the future of carbon emissions trading and force the European Commission to suspend spot trading last month. [...] But damage has been done to the market's reputation and the system of governance, says Trevor Sikorski, a director in the commodities research team at Barclays Capital, one of the market's biggest traders. [...] Meanwhile people are leaving the industry. Last year carbon broker Cantor CO2e closed its carbon-trading desk, while another broker, Tradition, lost key staff. As did market makers such as Citigroup, Nomura and BNP Paribas in 2010. [...] "All of the price upside we see in the market is coming from emission reductions, it is one thing seriously driving activity. Outside that, it's just not there," Sikorski says.

title: Romania's development minister, CHEVRON officials discuss common energy projects
news: [...] Bucharest, March 7 (Agerpres) - Romania's Minister of Regional Development and Tourism Cristian Petrescu on Wednesday [ 7 March] met officials of the US company CHEVRON to discuss energy projects the company wants to carry out in Romania. Petrescu voiced in his turn support for the projects that help create jobs that simultaneously meet the highest standards of security and environmental protection. [...]

title: F.T.C. Asks if Carbon-Offset Money Is Winding Up True Green
news: Corporations and shoppers in the United States spent more than $54 million last year on carbon offset credits toward tree planting, wind farms, solar plants and other projects to balance the emissions created by, say, using a laptop computer or flying on a jet. But where exactly is that money going? The Federal Trade Commission, which regulates advertising claims, raised the question Tuesday in its first hearing in a series on green marketing, this one focusing on carbon offsets.   As more companies use offset programs to create an environmental halo over their products, the commission said it was growing increasingly concerned that some green marketing assertions were not substantiated. Environmentalists have a word for such misleading advertising: ''greenwashing.'' With the rapid growth of green programs like carbon offsets, ''there's a heightened potential for deception,'' said Deborah Platt Majoras, chairwoman of the commission. […]   Continental Airlines lets travelers track the carbon impact of their itineraries. General Electric and BANK OF AMERICA will translate credit card rewards points into offsets. […] The F.T.C. has not accused anyone of wrongdoing --  neither the providers of carbon offsets  nor the consumer brands that sell them. But environmentalists say -- and the F.T.C.'s hearings suggest -- that it is only a matter of time until the market faces greater scrutiny from the government or environmental organizations. […]

title: Big banks cool on clean coal plant
news: The backers of a proposed "clean coal" power plant in Victoria's Latrobe Valley face a shrinking field of financiers. Several large foreign banks have signalled they will not bankroll the project. [...] Rabobank has signalled its focus is on renewable infrastructure. Several other banks including Credit Agricole and Citi said they had no involvement while Bank of America and UBS declined to discuss individual projects. [...]

title: The great emissions divide
news: The nation is confronted with two opposing approaches to reducing carbon emissions. Which will work best? There is a seeming paradox at the heart of the bi-partisan support for cutting Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. The Labor government will find it hard to meet its goal of a "clean energy future" for Australia without a higher price on emissions than envisaged. The Coalition's Direct Action plan may work without any price on emissions. However, there is no contradiction. Each side is talking about different prices to meet their common target of cutting emissions by the equivalent of 152 million tones of carbon dioxide by 2020. A Coalition government won't adopt Labor policy of making big emitters pay a price for their emissions, but it will pay a price to buy the much smaller volume of emissions that need to be cut. […] But the future for brown coal looks brighter after AGL decided to buy the Loy Yang A station in Victoria's La Trobe valley. The AFR reported that Citigroup analysts advised AGL that Loy Yang would still be the nation's lowest cost generator with a carbon price of $50 a tonne - well above the $23 carbon tax or a likely permit price. Yet Labor had been confident its emissions price would be high enough to achieve a "clean energy future" by rendering "dirty" generators unviable. […]

title: Oilsands consortium set to add to Athabasca: Proposed Jackpine mine

title: PNG gas pipeline key to Qld future: expert
news: The next six months will determine the future of the Queensland gas industry for the next decade, a key industry observer says. The director of economic and environmental consulting firm Eco Management and former environmental head in the Goss Government, Dr Craig Emerson, said yesterday the Borbidge Government was "hurtling headlong into a greenhouse crisis with its obsession for extra coal-fired power generation". […]"On current projections Australia will record an 18 per cent growth in greenhouse gas emissions in the absence of further policy changes."[…] Dr Emerson said one big decision that would make a huge difference to the Queensland gas market had not yet been made - the $2 billion plus CHEVRON PNG-to-Australia gas pipeline proposal.[…]Dr Emerson said if the PNG gas project did not proceed, Timor Sea gas could possibly come into play but the delivered prices of Timor Sea gas probably would not be low enough to produce a quantum leap in gas demand in the Queensland market.[…]The reasons why the PNG gas project is likely to proceed are: The PNG Government and the project proponents have a shared interest to boost oil revenues and to secure a replacement long-term revenue stream[…] The PNG project offers environmental benefits and avoids costs of having to purchase greenhouse gas credits at some time in the future.

title: Calif.'s energy shortage fuels political tug of war
news: WASHINGTON -- California's electricity crunch and the oil hidden beneath Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge have virtually nothing to do with each other.[…] There have been delays in the construction of new power plants, and environmentalists have caused a few. But more often than not, he says, opposition comes from individuals and businesses that proclaim: "Not in my backyard." title: US Senate passes two bills with implications for the energy sector
news: In a rare holiday session, the US Senate on Columbus Day passed the conference report on the corporate tax bill, which could allow US oil companies to repatriate billions of dollars under a reduced tax rate, and also includes several energy tax credits and incentives. The Senate also passed a conference report on the military construction bill Oct 11, which included a provision authorizing the construction of a pipeline to transport natural gas from Alaska's North Slope to the Lower 48 states. […] Standard and Poor's estimates 26 oil companies sampled would be eligible to repatriate more than $60-bil, with ExxonMobil ($22-bil) and CHEVRONTEXACO ($10.5-bil) accounting for half of the total. The bill also provides incentives for the proposed pipeline to transport gas from Alaska's North Slope and related facilities; tax credits for oil and gas production from marginal wells when prices drop below $18/bbl and $2/Mcf; and extended tax breaks for wind and renewable energy production. […] The provision directs the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to expedite permitting of the pipeline, and designates FERC as the lead agency for the National Environmental Policy Act Process. The House and Senate adjourned, pending an expected lame duck session in mid-November, following the Nov 2 presidential and congressional elections.

title: Disney stages new test, but it's all quiet in Discovery Bay
news: The latest fireworks test run staged at the Disneyland site in Penny's Bay last night passed a noise test in nearby Discovery Bay.[…]  Islands district councillor Amy Yung Wing-sheung said the noise from the fireworks display was acceptable given that the events would be staged nightly after the theme park opens. The Advisory Council on the Environment said in 7 that a fireworks trial on May 6 and 7 met noise and air quality requirements in general but it wanted DISNEY to provide more information.
