news: The Federal Government should block new coal fired power stations in Queensland because of their greenhouse gas emissions, according to the Australian Democrats. The Coalition was "squibbing their national greenhouse obligations" by failing to confront the Queensland Government over the issue, said Democrat spokeswoman Senator Lyn Allison. InterGen's project manager for Millmerran, Mr Chris Colbert, said the company was addressing the greenhouse issue through more efficient power generation technology and through participation in the Federal Government's "Greenhouse Challenge" program. title: High-Country Common Ground; In the Sierras, Growth and Preservation Are Not at Odds
news: In the villages nestled amid the forests and river valleys of the Sierra Nevada, the environment has always been a battleground, with "growth" and "jobs" the implacable rhetorical foes of "no growth" and "the environment." But now, Sierra business leaders are taking the lead in calling for policies to protect the environment, on the ground that the region's grandeur is the key to the success of their businesses. […] The business council was formed in 1994 "to secure and enhance the economic and environmental health of the region for future generations." Its first move was to commission an audit of the natural, social and financial capital of the region. The resulting Sierra Nevada Wealth Index, which was released earlier this year, tracks 42 indicators of the region's well-being, from water quality to school test scores to employment.[…] "This idea has been in the air," said Richard Morrison, senior vice president for environmental policies and programs for BANK OF AMERICA, which is a council member. "But this is bringing it down to where decisions actually happen -- in land use planning -- and that's a local thing."[…]

title: Civic duty starts with humble collaboration
news: THE biggest mistake businesses can make is assume they are responsible for fixing the world's environmental and social problems, says a leading social scientist. Robert Boutilier says companies need to accept they are not omnipotent, they are just part of the problem. They can't fix it by themselves and no one should expect them to. The only way to fix it, he says, is for them to learn how to work with other interest groups, usually lumped together under the category "stakeholders". […] Mr Boutilier has worked with companies including mining giant Placer Dome and at the Antamina copper and zinc mine in Peru. Antamina's shareholders are BHP Billiton, Xstrata, Teck-Cominco and Mitsubishi. He has also been brought in to mediate a peace between environmentalists and logging companies in Clayoquot Sound in British Columbia. In Melbourne this week, he ran workshops attended by companies that included ANZ, BHP Billiton, CSL and IBM. His workshop in Sydney today will be attended by companies such as Westpac, Rinker, Stockland and Lion Nathan.[…]

title: Panasonic to start marketing home LED light bulbs in October
news: Panasonic to start marketing home LED light bulbs in October Long-lasting, efficient new products look like big seller Electronics major Panasonic Corp. plans to begin selling home-use light-emitting diode light bulbs on Oct. 21 under the brand name Everleds. In Japan, incandescent light bulbs will be banned beginning in 2012. Currently, an increasing number of convenience stores and restaurants are installing LED lighting ahead of the implementation of the revised energy conservation law next spring. With moves toward LED lighting also accelerating in the U.S., Europe and Asia, Nikko CITIGROUP Ltd. forecasts that the global LED lighting equipment market will grow to be worth $5.07 billion in 2015 from $457 million in 2008.

title: Misguided Activism
news: The green initiative has become the issue du jour sweeping Wall Street, as environmentalists apparently found chasing after whaling boats to be too dangerous. […] The truth is, a lot of people recognize today that the environment needs work. But I'm having trouble blaming Merrill or any other bank for global warming. By the same token, I wouldn't give them credit for saving the world if they financed a wind farm.[…] If Merrill, Morgan Stanley or CITIGROUP, the three banks said to be financing the TXU plants, were to walk away from the mandate, there would be three other lenders that would gladly fill their shoes - probably some of the same hedge funds that are backing the clean energy initiatives. My point is that environmentalists are barking up the wrong tree. If they want to truly create change, laws need to be made that would fundamentally change the risk profile of the investment. Then, there's a good chance they might get Stan O'Neal's ear.

title: Diesel all set to clean up
news: DIESEL engines will have an extra 70 years of life because of developments in technology. They will be so clean that a handkerchief held to the exhaust will remain white. That's the view of Jim McGeehan, who monitors environmental targets and the engine development required to meet those targets. McGeehan, in Sydney recently, is the global manager of diesel engine oil technology for CHEVRONTEXACO Global Lubricants. CHEVRONTEXACO is a 50 per cent shareholder of Caltex Australia Ltd. For the past 17 years he has chaired the American Society for Testing Materials (ASTM) heavy duty engine oil classification panel, the group responsible for establishing oil categories to improve engine durability and cut emissions. "The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has been driving low diesel emission standards in the US and those standards are the toughest in the world," McGeehan says. "The EPA -- not someone in the engine industry -- has launched the term 'clean diesel'. […] The team must balance the demands of maximising engine performance, fuel efficiency and durability from increasingly hi-tech engines and emissions equipment with operator demands for maximum oil change intervals.

title: Maritime industry should focus on minimising risks
news: WITH no industry spared in the economic downturn, maintaining low costs would seem the best way to go for now. But Alex Walker, vice-president of operations with CHEVRON Shipping Company, sees other options.  Delivering a keynote address to the International Chemical and Oil Pollution Conference (ICOPCE) yesterday, he high-lighted the importance of minimising risk through good maintenance to prevent incidents such as oil spills, collisions and fatalities, rather than solely focusing on keeping costs low. 'If you think maintenance is expensive, try having an oil spill,' he said. 'You are taking a risk of a far more expensive event, and it is good business to protect the environment, not just cost control.' [...] Other risks that need to be protected against include piracy and terrorism, which, according to Mr Walker, could in time have an environmental impact. [...]

title: Securing our shared energy future
news: ENERGY security was one of the key issues on the agenda at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) Business Summit last week in Sydney. This is certainly understandable. Apec represents many of the world's fastest-growing economies, and access to reliable, affordable energy will be needed to power this vibrant region into the future. But energy security now means more than just ensuring ample energy supply. It also means doing so in ways that are environmentally responsible and sustainable. […] We also need to integrate more alternative and renewable sources into the supply mix and continue to develop nuclear power. What it takes. […] Multilateral cooperation also is needed to address climate change. Carbon reduction must be shared equitably by all of the world's major emitting countries, and all governments need to be transparent about the costs, risks and trade-offs associated with climate change policies. The second pathway to overcoming our energy challenges is through the development of new technologies that can help the world expand its energy supply while reducing its environmental footprint. Over the past decade, tremendous advances have been made in deepwater oil production, liquefied natural gas and ultraclean low-sulphur diesel, just to cite a few examples. In Australia, CHEVRON is working with its partners on a massive carbon sequestration project at Gorgon. This technology, which would allow carbon to be captured and stored underground, holds the potential to significantly reduce the carbon footprint of oil, coal and natural gas. […] I am confident that if we respond to energy and climate challenges with collaboration, pragmatism and innovation deeply, our success not only is possible, it is inevitable. Dave O'Reilly is chairman and CEO of CHEVRON Corp

title: South Africa;Sasol To Switch Its Focus To Underused Natural Gas

title: IGCC gathers momentum even as benefits and costs are questioned
news: Integrated gasification combined-cycle (IGCC) technology is being heralded as the solution to several problems. First, it is not natural gas. It uses coal as a feedstock to make synthesis gas that can be burned in a gas turbine. […] The number generally used in the power industry is 20%, that is, an IGCC plant is 20% more expensive to build than a comparable PC plant. But that is a moving target. In fact, the environmental benefits of IGCC are not as clear as they would appear to be at first. Generally speaking, IGCC technology reduces nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide emissions and uses significantly less water than a PC plant. […] In addition, the cost premium of IGCC compared with a pulverized coal plant works against IGCC's environmental advantages. So much so, says John Thompson, advocacy coordinator for the Clean Air Task Force, that PC plants actually have an advantage from a regulatory standpoint because they can meet targeted emissions levels at a cheaper cost. […] A regulatory hedge. […] The fact of the matter is that "nobody knows what a [fully commercial] IGCC plant costs to build, because nobody has built one," says Richard Rapagnani, manager, IGCC, at GE Energy. And no one wants to be the first to put their foot in the water, at least not until there are some reliable numbers, until there is a track record for an IGCC plant. And that is what GE has set out to do. GE, which last year bought CHEVRON/TEXACO's gasification technology business and later in the year formed a joint venture with Bechtel to build IGCC plants, is building a "reference plant." It could be with AEP or Cinergy or with a merchant developer, says Rapagnani; GE is working with many clients. […] Rapagnani said GE would provide guarantees for fixed price engineering and construction, scheduling, emissions and output heat rates. It remains to be seen if that will be sufficient to attract sponsors and to assure the success of IGCC ventures. Give me a break. […]

Put in context, if we look at absolute size rather than growth rates, the green bond market is dwarfed by an average issuance of $100 billion per week in investment-grade bonds alone. VERIZON Communications raised $49 billion in funds & more than the amount outstanding in the total labeled green bonds market & in one short day last year to help fund the acquisition of Vodafone&s 45 percent stake in VERIZON Wireless. If the public sector takes this role, bond markets will be there to provide the senior part of the capital structure. Embrace and leverage that willingness. Our economies need it.

title: Study finds 'prime' type of site for sequestration
news: An International Energy Agency study of carbon dioxide stored in a western Canadian oil field has shown that such formations can safely hold the gas, an Energy Department official said last week. The study, the largest in-field scientific look at CO2 storage ever done, supports government and industry efforts to demonstrate that using oil and natural gas formations to sequester CO2 could significantly minimize greenhouse gas emissions. "They've not found any evidence of leakage or other issues that would indicate that this formation would be a bad storage site for CO2," Scott Klara, a technology manager with DOE's National Energy Technology Laboratory in Pittsburgh, said last week. DOE helped fund the project. The scientific study, at EnCana Corp.'s Weyburn field in Saskatchewan, also enabled researchers to test computer models, measurement tools and other technologies designed to track the movement of CO2 in underground formations, Klara said. […] IEA's Greenhouse Gas Research and Development Program sponsored the study, with funding from 15 public and private institutions. In addition to DOE, the government financial backers included the Alberta Energy Research Institute, the European Community, Natural Resources Canada and Saskatchewan Industry and Resources. Industry participants, besides EnCana, included BP, CHEVRONTEXACO Corp., Dakota Gasification Co., Nexen Inc., Total and TransAlta. […]

title: Australia approves CHEVRON Wheatstone LNG project
news: Sydney--Australian federal Environment Minister Tony Burke September 22 approved CHEVRON's planned Wheatstone LNG project, clearing the way for a final investment decision which was described as "imminent" by a senior company executive earlier this week. Burke approved the project, located in the state of Western Australia, under the federal Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act with "strict conditions," he said in a statement. "CHEVRON will be required to adhere to 70 conditions, including submitting for federal approval a range of plans and programs detailing how it would protect matters of national environmental significance protected under the EPBC Act and implement a biodiversity offset strategy," Burke said. news: ETS will pose varying risks for utilities The upcoming introduction of an emissions trading scheme (ETS) will have a significant impact on utilities' profitability and asset values, but to different degrees. title: CHEVRON expands Gorgon LNG capacity plans by 50%
news: The proposed capacity of the Gorgon LNG project in Western Australia has been increased by 5 million mt/year to a total of 15 million mt/year, a spokesman for operator CHEVRON said December 24. title: Saturday Review: Et cetera: Steven Poole's non-fiction choice: Two Billion Cars, by Daniel Sperling & Deborah Gordon (Oxford, £12.99)
news: [...] Well, there are already more than 1bn cars on the planet, and these authors, energy and transport mavens, see an inevitable rise (largely driven by China and India) to 2bn in a few decades. The twin prongs of a solution are emerging alternative-transportation developments (such as Bus Rapid Transit, platoons of buses in dedicated lanes); and alternative fuel sources for cars, a field distorted in the US by subsidies for one of the worst options, corn ethanol. One industry that gets off lightly here is Big Oil: "By any measure, oil companies are managed responsibly," the authors write soothingly. One of them used to work for CHEVRON. But automobiles, they reckon, will inevitably move to fully electric drive, and governments should get more involved in shaping transport policy through incentives and taxes, because there has been a "market failure".

title: Smaller plants to shut in clean-up of power sector
news: The central government has ordered the closure of smaller  power plants and given priority to energy-efficient and less-polluting plants in selling their output. […] In the long run, listed power firms, which tend to have larger and more fuel-efficient generators equipped with pollution control equipment, would have an edge in a more competitive environment, said Pierre Lau, CITIGROUP's head of regional utilities research.

title: Profits can bloom
news: BYLINE: Generating power by using environmentally friendly fuels and developing new technologies may mean huge dividends for investors, writes Chris Davis [...] Politicians and business leaders around the world are becoming increasingly aware that  how they manage energy   can have long-term economic and social consequences.   Investors are now looking for ways to reap rewards from this growing  awareness. [...] Bruce Schlein,  CITIGROUP vice-president of environmental affairs,  believes burgeoning demand for alternative fuels such as ethanol and biodiesel, offer positive opportunities for a range of sectors, from chemical companies focusing on crop production to biofuel producers. "By using existing crop surpluses and emerging technologies to utilise cellulosic resources, it is quite possible that gasoline consumption could be increasingly supplemented with biofuels," Mr Schlein says. [...]

title: Canberra to cut crude oil excise
news: The Federal Government is expected to reduce the excise it charges on the production of crude oil, in a move designed to provide a tax break to a $3 billion North-West Shelf expansion without breaking international trade rules.  The Government had been struggling to find a way to provide up to $100 million in investment incentives to the proposed expansion, under its strategic investment process. […] The joint venturers have demanded some certainty about future Government greenhouse abatement policies, which they say could significantly effect their costs as they consider signing 20-year contracts. Senator Minchin proposed a set of five principles on future greenhouse policy in a Cabinet submission two weeks ago. The Environment Minister, Senator Robert Hill, opposed aspects of Senator Minchin's plan, and Cabinet requested that the two ministers reach a compromise and report back. They have yet to do so. The companies involved in the proposed North-West Shelf expansion are Woodside Energy, BHP, BP, CHEVRON, Japan Australia LNG and Shell. Shell recently launched a takeover bid for Woodside. […]

title: Trade quality 'key to growth'; China may lead world in value of imports and exports, but it cannot rely on manufacturing cheap goods, says commerce chief Gao Hucheng
news: While China was unsurpassed in the quantity of its trade, the nation must now improve the quality of its goods, Commerce Minister Gao Hucheng  said yesterday in Beijing, where the National People's Congress is holding its annual meeting.  […] But upgrading equipment and technology would be costly, analysts say. For example, the investment required to upgrade steel mills to meet emissions standards could be around 50 yuan to 100 yuan (HK$126) per tonne of steel capacity, according to Citigroup research. That is about four to eight times the net profit per tonne earned by steel producers in 2012, it said. […]

title: Billionaires to be given free carbon allowances to offset green tax on private jets; Corporate jets used by billionaires the Duke of Westminster and Lord Ashcroft are among the aircraft to be allocated free "carbon allowances" to offset the cost of a new green tax.
news: Almost 200 corporate jet owners, from oil company ExxonMobil to Starbucks and Iceland Foods, will be awarded free permits to compensate them for the new expense of Europe's carbon trading scheme for aircraft. The emissions trading scheme means airlines will have to surrender a permit for every tonne of carbon dioxide they emit, which is expected to raise the cost of flying for millions of passengers. Bigger airlines, such as easyJet and British Airways, have long been preparing for huge bills from the emissions trading scheme.  They will get a large number of free allowances in the first few years of the scheme to protect their businesses from becoming uneconomic. However, corporate jet owners will also be able to take advantage of these free allowances, potentially selling them on for cash if they don't use their aircraft as much as in previous years. Dozens of corporate jet owners will get free permits, including Iceland Foods, JP Morgan Chase, Procter and Gamble, Hertz Corporation, McDonalds, IBM and Coca-Cola. […] Meanwhile,politicians were accused of being "schizophrenic" and "inconsistent" about green policies for business in two separate attacks. Neil Bentley, the CBI's deputy director-general, said companies were committed to tackling climate change, "but investors are struggling to understand how to invest against the proposed framework while the resulting costs could damage parts of our manufacturing sector". On Monday, a report from the Environmental Audit Committee blamed the Government for moving goalposts by reviewing the UK's green targets. It said the "Government's somewhat schizophrenic attitude to climate change seems to be undermining confidence".

title: Coal lobby is not being fair dinkum on carbon reduction scheme; G-BIZ
news: The coal lobby trots out some fair dinkum-looking blokes in its TV commercials, but that's advertising. The Australian Coal Association, which hopes to blunt the Federal Government's proposed emissions trading scheme with the ad campaign, is not being fair dinkum with the public, either about what the carbon pollution reduction scheme will do to its business, or what the industry is doing to cut greenhouse gas emissions by investing in so-called clean coal technologies. [...] CITIGROUP's analysts this week criticised the coal industry line. While they recognised some impact of the carbon pollution reduction scheme on the profitability and valuation of coal companies, they said "the scale of the debate may have superseded the scale of valuation impact ... we do not see CPRS as a major negative investment for the coal sector at current share prices".[...]

title: Earth Mother gets wired; Meet the technogaians. They believe machinery can; not only heal our damaged planet, reports DAVID AKIN,; but help us live for 200 years
news: There is a group of people - serious people with money and smarts - working hard to rid the world of pollution, hunger and poverty. And that's for starters.   After that, the group will set its sights on manufacturing a human being who can live for 120 or 150 or perhaps even 200 years. All this will be possible thanks to advances in computing and communication technologies. […]  Because of the link to technology, technogaians, or those sympathetic to their world-view, have ties to the optimistic culture of Silicon Valley. Entrepreneurs, inventors, venture capitalists and artists from northern California - with connections to such companies as Hewlett-Packard or ORACLE Corp. may call themselves technogaians.   As such, they have goals that seem similar to those of the Greens - the elimination of pollution, for example, or hunger - but where Greens are suspicious of technologies grown in corporate labs, technogaians reject the idea that technology is, by definition, a dehumanizing, negating force. […]  Technogaians find themselves generally opposed to what many would think of as traditional Gaian or Green view, held by such groups as the Sierra Club and Greenpeace, that technology is a false god. […]

title: ELECTRICITYDigitising grid 'would cut emissions'
news: The electricity industry could make big savings in carbon dioxide emissions by upgrading and digitising the grid so that it could be "intelligently managed", claimed Guido Bartels, general manager of IBM's Global Energy and Utilities group. He said the UK network had very high reliability, but changes required to accommodate increasing demand, renewable energy and more distributed generation would make it difficult to continue to maintain such a robust grid.Bartels said the benefits of digitisation would be spread across different players. […]

title: OPCSA to the rescue
news: OPCSA to the rescue. WHAT IT MEANS. […] Oil Pollution Control SA (OPCSA), a CEF subsidiary, has served the country well in this area and is gearing up to play an even more important role in cleaning oil spills at sea. "It is always better to clean up the spill before it gets to shore, where the most environmental damage occurs," says OPCSA CEO Pieter Coetzee. […] There is a National Oil Spill Contingency Plan, but different government dEPArtments are responsible for the prevention and combating functions of an oil spill. This is due to the fragmented nature of the different laws governing oil pollution prevention and clean-up in SA. […] OPCSA renders a pollution prevention and clean-up service to CHEVRON SA and PetroSA, a sister company under CEF. This service is rendered on a commercial basis, but is not sufficient to make OPCSA a profitable entity. CEF, as the parent company, has agreed to fund the shortfall of OPCSA to enable it to become self-sustainable. Aside from oil spills, OPCSA also manages the environment liabilities at Ogies in Mpumalanga on behalf of the SFF Association, another CEF subsidiary. This situation arose when the old coal mines, which were once used as storage facilities for crude oil, were emptied. The oil residue remaining in the mines has the potential to pollute the aquifers if it is not managed properly.

title: Gorgon closer after deal to share CO2
news: [...]Prime Minister Kevin Rudd told parliament yesterday that plans by CHEVRON, Shell and Exxon Mobil to reduce Gorgon's greenhouse emissions by extracting carbon from the gas and re-injecting it more than 2 km under Barrow Island, off the WA coast, would help in the fight against climate change.Under the agreement, CHEVRON and its joint venture partners, Shell and Exxon Mobil, will accept responsibility for any damages claims arising from carbon leakage in the expected 30-year life of the project.[...]West Australian Premier Colin Barnett said the indemnity was needed in case damage claims were brought long after the Gorgon project had closed.[...]Peter Cook, head of the Co-operative Research Centre for Greenhouse Gas Technologies, hailed the agreement as a breakthrough for carbon capture and storage. He said although the risk of leakage was very low, it was difficult to proceed with such a major investment knowing that a potential liability could remain indefinitely."It is absolutely essential that government take over liability," Dr Cook said.[...]Mr Rudd said the carbon storage plan was needed because the Gorgon fields had a high CO2 content.[...]

title: Business warns on carbon trade tax
news: A national carbon emissions trading scheme should not be used to boost State Government coffers through more taxes and should focus on environmental objectives, WA industry and business groups said yesterday. […] The possibility of revenue being boosted by an emissions trading scheme has been raised after State and Territory leaders agreed on Friday to adopt a national system by 2010, regardless of the position of the Federal Government. WA agreed to support the plan after being given concessions that energy intensive export industries would be protected by a transition phase which grants them permits to emit while competing countries are not signatories to similar schemes. But the details of how a national emissions trading scheme would work are still being debated. […] The controversial and cutting-edge process of geosequestration, which separates carbon dioxide and stores it underground, remains crucial to multi-billion-dollar plans for the Gorgon gas project on WA's Barrow Island. Scott Walker, spokesman for project proponent CHEVRON, said yesterday the energy giant was confident the carbon dioxide injection scheme - which was a condition of State Government environmental approval for the proposal granted in December - could be achieved. Mr Walker said the conditions of the State approval were being finalised and the project was yet to get Federal environmental approval. The project has been promised a $60 million grant by the Federal Government's low emission technology fund for geo-sequestration, which will require an investment decision on the proposal by the middle of next year.

title: Oil and gas development is key to US future. Don't ban it. Regulate it.; Oil and gas production through 'fracking' and horizontal drilling will improve US energy security - and support US foreign policy. This development should be encouraged. The reasonable response to environmental and health concerns is sensible regulation, not wholesale bans.
news: Hydraulic fracturing ("fracking") and horizontal drilling are allowing the United States to produce greater quantities of domestic oil and gas, bringing closer the once unthinkable prospect of America being a net energy exporter within the next decade. […] Of course, fracking, or more broadly, oil and gas development, is an industrial activity and can cause negative environmental effects. But many modern industrial and everyday activities have environmental or human health risks. The reasonable response is sensible regulation, at both the federal and state level, rather than wholesale bans. […] In short, fracking should be encouraged in a way that rationally addresses public and environmental health while producing the energy needed to meet demand. […] Citigroup also describes the prospects for US energy independence as "real." These predictions are based on the impact of modern fracking technology on the growth of domestic energy production. […]

title: IBM and Dassault System aid in BMW engine design
news: Information technology company IBM (NYSE:IBM) and Dassault Systemes (DS) (Euronext Paris: #13065, DSY.PA) , a provider of 3D and Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) solutions, announced on Thursday (12 March) that BMW has used a single digital software environment for the design of all BMW engines. This covers the engines across its fuel and diesel-powered cars, motorcycles and its newest line of eco-friendly, hybrid cars including the industry's first hydrogen-powered vehicle.[…]

title: M&S turns green to gold
news: […] A research note, published by investment bankers at CITIGROUP, highlighted the success of the 'Look behind the label' strategy. Authors Meg Brown and Bruce Hubbard describe it as 'the most positive campaign the business has ever run'. Slogans include 'It's not just our green dyes that won't harm the environment' and 'We're committed to reduce salt faster than you can say "sodium chloride" '. […] According to CITIGROUP, the 'Look behind the label' campaign has given M&S 'at least a sixmonth lead' over its four main rivals, including Britain's biggest retailer, Tesco. […]

title: New identity comes at a cost; Payoff will take a while for American Cleaning
news: FOR DECADES after it opened in 1932, soap and cleaning-products manufacturer American Wax followed industry trends and made petroleum-based products for its wholesale customers. About five years ago, they began to ask for certifiably eco-friendly alternatives.  That's when the 50-employee Long Island City, Queens, company took a radical turn and launched a subsidiary, American Cleaning Solutions, which now makes Focus, a line certified by environmental groups such as the nonprofit Green Seal. The products, which are biodegradable and made with substances based on corn and other plants, now account for about 20% of the company's sales. We went green because it's the right thing to do, and the industry has changed, says ACS Chief Executive Allen Winik. For a small company like ours, it's extremely expensive, and the playing field is not necessarily even. For Johnson Wax or PROCTER & GAMBLE, greening up their product line costs almost nothing as a percentage of their budget. The company spent about $250,000 to reconfigure and develop the Focus manufacturing line in its 65,000-square-foot plant. The investment is expected to pay off by 2015. Certifications can cost as much as $10,000, though often far less for small companies. […]

title: Name That Dog Park: Suffolk Courts Deals to Raise Cash
news: SUFFOLK COUNTY has invited companies to buy naming rights to the county's parks, part of an effort to generate additional revenue from county property that began four years ago but has become more urgent with the economic downturn.[…] Matthew D. Pace, a corporate lawyer with a specialty in naming rights, said advertisers were looking for nontraditional ways to reach consumers, and at the same time, more people were going to free public parks and beaches. ''In this economy, people don't want to pay to do things,'' Mr. Pace said. ''If they go to the beach and PEPSI, for example, is keeping the beach clean, maintaining the parking lot and generally making that experience better, that's going to work favorably for them,'' he said, referring to advertisers. Conservation groups said they worry about the well-being of parkland if it is parceled up and renamed. ''It does not change the natural resource, but it clearly changes the perception of the natural resource,'' said Adrienne Esposito, head of Citizens Campaign for the Environment, a conservation and environmental group based in Farmingdale. ''It gives a commercial or corporate image to something that is supposed to be public space, and that could open the door for the land to be devalued.''[…]

title: Educating Arnie about LNG safety
news: Energy. AUSTRALIA has offered to send technical experts to the US to convince the California administration of Arnold Schwarzwenegger that liquefied natural gas plants can be environmentally safe and secure. The offer was made as US energy secretary Spencer Abraham told LNG industry officials in Melbourne that there was a market opportunity on the US west coast for Australian LNG, thanks to the special relationship between the countries. […] Proposals for terminals on the west coast are causing environmental and safety concerns in states such as California. […] Both Shell and CHEVRONTEXACO, which operates the Gorgon project of Western Australia, have opened negotiations to sell LNG from huge Gorgon reservoirs to their parents' US marketing operations. After the Melbourne meeting, Federal Resources Minister Ian Macfarlane said the environmental issue was crucial to Australia's LNG prospects in the US. […] "We are ready to provide all the assistance necessary at a government, departmental and company level to reassure the US that our experience with LNG demonstrates it is secure and environmentally safe fuel source," he said. […]

title: IBM to build data centre for Victoria University
news: IBM (NYSE:IBM), an IT technology company, announced today (8 April) that it has been selected by Victoria University of Melbourne, Australia, to design and build a data centre for the university. The 'green' design of the data centre is expected to achieve savings of up to AUD300,000 over the next decade. The project involves IBM implementing a modular design approach to enable the University to minimise start-up energy demands from the existing site electrical supply. IBM will also employ an in-row cooling solution which offers targeted cooling at the heat load source, combined with free cooling chiller plant technology to leverage the favourable Melbourne climate. Smaller uninterruptible power supply (UPS) module sizes will be used to maximise the amount of usable power and UPS efficiency. This will all result in both substantial energy savings and the elimination of hot spots to provide an optimum equipment operating environment.

title: Bilirakis rewards work of ombudsman
news: Convinced that the EPA's ombudsman office did a good turn for Tarpon Springs by investigating a controversial cleanup plan for the Stauffer Superfund site, U.S. Rep. Mike Bilirakis, R-Tarpon Springs, has decided to return the favor. On Wednesday, Bilirakis introduced a bill that would create a more independent role for the ombudsman office, a watchdog arm of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and dramatically increase its budget. Bilirakis and many area residents credit EPA ombudsman Robert Martin with uncovering shortcomings in the EPA's proposed mound-and-cap cleanup plan for Stauffer, including EPA assumptions about whether a mound might trigger a sinkhole and dump contaminants into the drinking water supply.[…] The office was thrown into turmoil in December when a high-ranking EPA official reassigned Martin's lone investigator and right-hand man, Hugh Kaufman.[…] EPA officials in Washington did not return a call seeking comment on the bill Wednesday afternoon. But in his statement, Bilirakis said he met with new EPA Administrator Christine Todd Whitman last week and said she "expressed her support for efforts to increase the independence of the office of the ombudsman."[…] Kaufman said he intends to subpoena several high-ranking EPA officials, including Whitman and her husband, John. Kaufman said he plans to explore a possible conflict-of-interest  resulting from John Whitman's financial interest in CITIGROUP, which is responsible for cleanup of the Shattuck Superfund site in Colorado. The ombudsman's office played a key role in  persuading the EPA to change its mound-and-cap cleanup plan there, and negotiations over financial responsibility for cleanup are continuing.[…]

title: All's well that ends well: Santos to bury carbon dioxide
news: Energy. SANTOS has revealed ambitious plans to build a carbon dioxide holding facility in the South Australian outback. The $714 million plan, already discussed with the federal Government and called the Moomba Carbon Storage project, could see 400 million tonnes of carbon dioxide stored deep underground in empty gas and oil wells. Polluters along the eastern seaboard would have access to the storage facilities, piping the carbon dioxide to Moomba. The plan is still very much in its infancy and the federal Government has made no commitment to funding the project. Santos hopes to have a demonstration plant running by 2010 and to prove the concept is viable by ''sequestering'' or burying one million tonnes of carbon dioxide a year, the equivalent of taking 250,000 cars off the road. Santos was keeping quiet on the finer details of the project yesterday, but the final scheme would require a carbon trading system with a fixed price on the pollutant. […] A domestic carbon trading scheme should be in place by 2012, according to Prime Minister John Howard. A joint venture between CHEVRON and Hydrogen Energy is investigating a similar carbon sequestration scheme. […]

title: MARKETING & ADVERTISING   Cott, industry group clash over dues
news: THE battle that pits the giant soft drinks, COKE and Pepsi, against private-label pop producer Cott Corp. appears to have flowed to the level of the industry association.[…] The association, controlled by COCA-COLA Beverages Ltd. and Pepsi-Cola Canada Beverages Ltd., both of Toronto, along with smaller producers, helps promote good public relations and deals with recycling and other environmental and politically sensitive issues."We don't feel we should be paying that (full) amount unless our customers who own these brands are represented on the board," Mr. Latta said. "Their interests should be represented along with ours and COKE's and Pepsi's."[…]

title: Queensland steps on the gas
news: THE Queensland Government has set up a special task force to work with Comalco and US energy giant CHEVRON after a collaborative development agreement between the latter two involving inter-dependent potential projects worth more than $3 billion. Comalco has been considering whether to establish its $1 billion aluminium refinery at Gladstone on Queensland's central coast or Sarawak in Malaysia, which has cheap gas. But CHEVRON is proposing to lay a 2500km gas pipeline from Kutubu in Papua New Guinea to Gladstone at a cost of $2 billion if it can lock in sufficient demand, so the two have agreed to co-operate and expedite their respective prefeasibility studies. However, the pipeline project will require a formal environmental impact assessment to be conducted jointly by the Commonwealth, Queensland and Papua New Guinean governments, federal Environment Minister Robert Hill said. "We expect (CHEVRON) to meet high standards of environmental protection, and in return the Howard Government is committed to implementing a process that eliminates unnecessary delay and cuts out any intergovernmental duplication." […]

title: Growing money on trees
news: […] Companies chasing carbon dollars, including the Australian concerns Macquarie, Carbon Conservation, New Forests and KeeptheHabitat, started signing agreements with local governments, teaming up with conservation groups and putting staff on the ground to oversee projects. But the nascent industry has suffered a series of setbacks in recent months. The global financial crisis sapped funding sources as companies focused on economic survival rather than their green credentials. At the same time, global talks about the inclusion of forestry carbon credits in a new Kyoto agreement faltered, the European Union signalled its intention to exclude those credits from its emissions trading system until 2020, and Australia's 5 per cent emissions reduction target fell far short of expectations.[…] "Most banks are now under incredible financial stress," says Tom Houston, managing director and general counsel for Global Eco Rescue, which has set up a project covering 300,000 hectares in Kalimantan. "Financial institutions are not going to be a long-term source of funding for this area. Merrill Lynch and others that have been active have had to pull back." The financial crisis is certainly making life difficult. While Sun is confident Merrill Lynch, which is being taken over by the BANK OF AMERICA, is still committed to the Aceh deal, all marketing efforts by the investment bank for the project have been frozen until the deal takes place.[…]

title: NW Shelf partners review options for LNG expansion
news: DIVERSIFIED miner BHP Billiton expects partners in the North-West Shelf liquefied natural gas joint venture to make a decision on its expansion in the middle of next year. Joint venture operator Woodside Petroleum had previously announced the decision on a $1.6 billion fifth LNG processing train was expected by early 2005 at least. The North-West Shelf, off the northern coast of Western Australia, currently has three trains at full production and a fourth expected to reach full capacity by mid next year. […] The proposed fifth train could have a capacity of about 4.1 million tonnes of LNG a year and would raise the North-West Shelf project's annual capacity to about 16 million tonnes. The partners in the venture also include BP Developments Australia, CHEVRONTEXACO Australia, Japan Australia LNG (MIMI), and Shell Development (Australia). Mr Aiken said LNG was a strategic growth product of BHP Billiton's future and the company was looking at several options in that area. BHP Billiton chief executive Chip Goodyear told energy congress delegates fossil fuel and renewable energy needed to co-exist if the world was to meet energy needs in a sustainable way that did not compromise economic benefit. "What we are seeking is a low emission future and we believe society can have that while continuing to use fossil fuels," he said. […]

title: How to Make A Buck Green
news: So where's the money in climate change? Investors sense a tumultuous market in the making, if they can only hit it right. "Sometimes I feel like a fly on the wall, watching a new era unfold," says Rona Fried, editor and publisher of Progressive Investor, a six-year-old newsletter that follows the field. "We're almost past the final hurdle of 'Do we really have to change?' Yes, we do, and we're going to get there." Wall Street's own change in climate is nothing less than astonishing. Save-the-planet investing has suddenly, well, heated up. Four major investment banks--CITIGROUP, Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and UBS--have recently issued fat global-warming reports looking at stocks and industries likely to gain or lose. [...] Investing in climate change isn't the same as traditional green investing. You go green by choice, to reflect your values. But there's nothing optional about global warming and what it might do to the bottom line. Greenies want mutual funds that screen out polluters, oil and mining companies, heavy chemicals, hamburger cartons and other planetary offenders. They generally hate nuclear, too, because of the toxic waste and the risk of a calamitous accident. But existing, clean-burning nuclear plants are "climate friendly," says Edward Kerschner, investment strategist at CITIGROUP. So are mines that improve their processes, even though they're still unclean. [...]

title: Power Plays: As alternative energy becomes more cost competitive with fossil fuels, investors are taking notice of the sector.
news: It may hardly be news that oil prices rose 36% in 2005 and natural gas prices jumped 49%, but coal? According to the Casper (Wyoming) Star-Tribune, contract prices were about $7 per ton at the beginning of 2005, spot prices were $22 in early 2006 and some utilities "are currently signing new multiyear contracts for $25 per ton." […] As conventional sources of energy get pricier, "alternatives" may become more attractive-for investors as well as for consumers. "There may be volatility in the short run, but the long-term trends are favorable for investments in alternative energy," says Richard Stuebi, president of NextWave Energy, a consulting firm in Denver. Even President Bush is promoting the sector. […] Bush also unveiled plans to expand clean-energy research at the federal level and touted zero-emission, coal-fired power plants, solar and wind technology and "clean, safe nuclear energy." DEFINING THE ALTERNATIVES. […] "Anything different from the norm might be considered alternative energy," Stuebi says. "That could mean anything other than coal or natural gas for power generation or refined petroleum for transportation." Such a definition might embrace oil from shale or tar sands, so-called "clean coal" processes or even nuclear power. […] The alternative-energy space can cover a lot of territory, and by most definitions, that space is expanding. Clean Edge, for example, sees the clean-energy market as threefold: solar, wind and fuel cells (which make electricity from hydrogen and oxygen). […] WHERE TO LOOK. If today's solar and wind companies will become tomorrow's ExxonMobils and CHEVRONs, financial planners might want to allocate some client dollars to this sector. […]

title: No charges over radiation leak
news: SCOTTISH Nuclear has escaped prosecution for a radioactive gas leak suspected of contaminating supplies to food and drinks firms because a delay in reporting the incident meant potential evidence was lost.  Pollution specialists who investigated the carbon dioxide leak from Hunterston power station last February believe the 13-day delay meant the contaminated gas was diluted dozens of times over in a large storage tank. There was a national outcry led by the then Scottish Secretary Michael Forsyth after it emerged that radioactive CO2 had leaked from the plant's cooling system into a gas tanker which could have affected supplies to 11 companies including COCA-COLA, Scottish Brewers, Barrs - the makers of Irn-Bru - and Marshall's Chunky Chicken. Newspapers warned that beer and soft drinks cans could be radiation hazards. […]

title: State may get $8bn fighting fund - ELECTRICITY RETAIL SALE COULD BOOST ELECTION COFFERS
news: KRISTINA Keneally could receive an $8 billion boost to her fighting fund on the eve of next year's state election. New research by leading investment bank CITIGROUP cites the $8bn figure as the estimated value of the state's electricity assets currently on the auction block -- a full $2bn more than previous projections. [...] But the CITIGROUP research is less encouraging on the shape of the NSW electricity sector after the sale, suggesting the entire industry could be dominated by just two large companies, AGL and Origin. According to CITIGROUP, the public float of a combination of retail and generation assets -- which the government is holding in reserve if a trade sale does not attract new entrants to the market -- would be unlikely to produce value for taxpayers. ``We cannot ascertain how an initial public offering of a business that lacks scale, market positioning, geographic and fuel diversification could achieve a higher transaction price than a trade sale with parties that have the ability to realise operational synergies,'' CITIGROUP says. The CITIGROUP research concedes the ``complexity of the gentrader structure'', along with uncertainty around the Rudd government's planned emissions trading scheme, make a valuation of the sale difficult. [...]

title: Lithuanian Energy Institute calls for exploration of shale gas reserves
news: [...] VILNIUS, Aug 28, BNS - The Lithuanian Energy Institute (LEI) proposes that the country should explore its shale gas potential and possibilities of using it in the energy sector. [...] The Environment Ministry prepares to issue a new shale gas exploration tender. Deputy Environment Minister Daiva Matoniene has told BNS that a new tender will be announced after the parliament passes a legislative package that, among other things, allows shale gas producers not to pay taxes in the first three years. That would be a second shale gas exploration tender in Lithuania. Following more than half a year of discussions among politicians, scientists and local communities, the Environment Ministry in September 2013 recommended that the government name CHEVRON, the sole bidder, the winner of the first tender. [...]

title: Self-chilling cans get the big freeze
news: A REVOLUTIONARY self-chilling drinks can could be banned from Britain.  The can's contents turn ice-cold when the consumer presses a widget on the base, releasing a gas which freezes on exposure to the air. […]  But environmental campaigners say the gas used in the cans - a hydrofluorocarbon called HFC 134a - is 3,400 times more harmful to the atmosphere than carbon dioxide, the chief greenhouse gas, which countries are trying to slow down.  The Government appears intent on blocking sales in Britain, and Environment Minister Michael Meacher will press for a Europe-wide ban at his first EU Environment Council meeting which begins today in Luxembourg.  The invention, adding 10 pence to the cost of a can, has been launched by the Mitchell Company of California. Beverage giants such as Coca Cola and PEPSI have studied it but none has so far declared an intention to market it, though at least one company is thought to be set to sell the can in the United States.  Christine Milburn of the British Soft Drinks Association said yesterday that all major companies in the UK had rejected it as too expensive as well as environmentally harmful.  A spokesman for Friends of the Earth said: 'The cans represent a serious risk and we welcome efforts by the Government to get them banned. Allowing these cans will undermine the efforts already in place to tackle climatic change.'

title: Meltdown: ETS winners, losers
news: Kevin Rudd and Penny Wong were probably a little too busy trying to get their compromise carbon pollution reduction scheme proposal through parliament to appreciate the irony. A shipping alert from Maritime New Zealand warning fishing boats, cruise ships and other vessels to watch out for icebergs was issued not that long after the NZ National Party government struck a compromise with the minority Maori Party that should allow its amended emissions trading scheme (ETS) to get through parliament this week. An oceanographer from NZ's National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research told Bloomberg there were four icebergs, between 100 metres and 250 metres in length, about 250 kilometres off the South Island. "Is it another sign of global warming? I would sit on the fence on that," he said. [...] A "screening analysis" conducted by CITIGROUP, for example, found that carbon costs "are unlikely to be material for many S&P/ASX 100 companies, and will often be passed on to customers".[...]

title: Personal Wealth: Investors warm to water as shortages mount
news: As liquidity is drained from credit and money markets and pours into oil and gold, another asset class that could offer long-term returns to the discerning investor is water. Water shortages are on the rise - stemming from soaring demand, growing populations, rising living standards and changing diets. A lack of supply is compounded by pollution and climate change. [...] China is a particularly strong example. It has a fifth of the world's population but just 7% of the water. Most of the length of the country's five main rivers is unsafe for direct human contact, and the country will have to build 1,000 wastewater treatment plants between 2006 and 2010 to meet national pollution targets, say CITIGROUP analysts. But not everyone will benefit. title: Euro deal in the Cannes for Arlington
news: THE development of Europe's largest business park was recently announced to a group of influential property media as the champagne flowed on board a tycoon's yacht at Cannes.  Parc d'Europe is to be built at Marne-la-Vallee, near Charles de Gaulle airport. It represents the fruition of a year's negotiations by a man virtually unknown in Scotland, even though he was reared in Dunbartonshire.[…]  Arlington, who will mastermind the park with EuroDisney, was involved in drafting a meticulous planning convention with the EPA France, the central public development authority, as well as local authorities in the Ile de France region. The site could employ around 20,000 people if companies can be persuaded to set up in this unprepossessing swathe of moor and farmland to the east of Paris. Such is Arlington's reputation as a developer of quality parks that few at Cannes were surprised at their selection by Disney as partners in the development. Arlington's record in the UK, with sites such as Aztec West and the massive Birmingham Business Park, shows that planning authorities welcome the high level of environmental improvement their business parks provide. An Arlington site guarantees a high ratio of green space, planting and water features to buildings. Consequently they are popular with business too, with tenants such as Colt, Compaq, Sun Micro, Novell and PEPSI. However, for this quality of development, occupiers would usually have to pay more in rent than they would in the centre of town.[…]

title: Mining giants top list for climate-change risk
news: COASTAL Queensland has been labelled ''high-risk geography'' in a new report on how global warming will affect Australia's top 100 public companies. The study from investment bank CITIGROUP, released yesterday, said BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto and other mining giants were among those most at risk from climate change. Those most threatened included emission-intensive companies, facilities exposed to severe weather damage, insurers who miscalculated risk, and water-intensive industries such as agriculture. WInners would be alternative energy, sustainable property, recycling, innovative financial institutions and several healthcare companies. Firms with the most to gain included Investa Property, Origin Energy and metals recycler Sims Group. An analysis of companies with longer-term high risk singled out Queensland, citing those ''exposed to high-risk geographies'' (for example, near the coast) or at risk from ''severe weather and flood events''.

title: Abbott's idea of direct action is business as usual; G-BIZ

This is the same ACA, mind, that played fast and loose on the likely job losses if the government's emission trading scheme was introduced. Its campaign claimed the ETS could cause 16 mines to close by 2021, with the loss of up to 9,000 jobs. Citi's environment, social and governance analyst, Elaine Prior, was sceptical: "We assess potential CPRS impact on ASX companies' coalmines under various CPRS designs - for BHP, Rio Tinto, Wesfarmers, Centennial & Macarthur. Our results don't lead to significant concerns about mine closures." We think additional research is required to be confident." Noting there was no clear fallback if the cost assumptions, many based on letters from industry bodies, proved optimistic, she concluded: "The proposals do not present a clear path towards substantially lower emissions in the industrial and electricity generation sector." title: We need smart debate, not self-centred rhetoric; GREEN BUSINESS
news: As the row continues about how to best address greenhouse emissions, it is worth considering fundamental flaws in the debate. Or maybe that introduction should read: "As the worldwide conspiracy to perpetuate the myth of global warming continues, the real truth needs to be exposed." See how tricky the "debate" can be? Australia's chief scientist, Ian Chubb, doesn't think there is much of a debate to be had. At the National Press Club this week, he declared the "science is in on climate change". "I don't think that's partisan.  [...] The economic reality is quite different. As entertainingly outlined by Citi's chief economist, Willem Buiter, this week: "You must make sure that when you tax the natural resources sector you don't eat into the required return on capital required to extract it and the labour required. But, apart from that, the rest [of the profit] is anybody's. You can leave it to the companies, who would undoubtedly like to take it home and give to their shareholders, or you can try to take it for the taxpayers." In a self-interested manner - along the way somehow wrapping the Australian flag around themselves - the miners ran a strong campaign and retained a greater share of the resources boom's super profits. title: Opportunities for auditors seen to lie in sustainability
news: When 17 socially responsible investment firms of the Social Investment Forum issued a joint recommendation that public companies adopt the sustainability reporting standards of the Global Sustainability Initiative, they foresaw not only better reporting, but new opportunities for auditors.Speaking for the forum in a multinational teleconference, Dave Stangis, director of corporate responsibility at INTEL, said that as the Global Reporting Initiative guidelines become the de facto international standard on sustainability reporting, their use is likely to become more widely demanded.The GRI is a nonprofit institution that has developed a comprehensive and widely accepted set of standardized guidelines for sustainability reporting. The standards use indicators including economic performance (such as total payroll and community donations), environmental performance, labor practices, human rights, social behavior and product responsibility.  "There is a growing market in the auditing of GRI guidelines and reports," Stangis said. "We've talked with several accounting firms, but we have not had a third-party audit of a non-financial statement. Very few of our stakeholders ask for that, but it is an ongoing discussion we have with the social analyst community and with a growing number of stakeholders who are developing more robust auditing standards around these kinds of reports."[…] INTEL's Stangis said that producing sustainable reports can consume substantial amounts of time inside the corporation, and that external verification can add a "big chunk of cost" to a report, depending on what kind of accounting firm and what kind of service the company uses. That big chunk of cost, which Stangis pointed out can be turned into value in credibility and corporate culture, translates into a revenue opportunity for audit and accounting firms. […]

title: Viagra saving animals from being hunted for male organs, says maker

title: Council plans a lighter footprint with Big Blue - GREEN IT - SPECIAL REPORT
news: KEEPING the technology systems humming in a large organisation is always a challenge, but when you add the need to make them environmentally sustainable it gets even tougher. title: Business & Media: PFIZER shuns UK for Germany to escape planning shambles: Britain losing 'hundreds of millions' as companies site bases on the continent

The decision not to locate in Surrey, which will cost the British economy hundreds of millions of £, has come to light in a government policy paper outlining options for sweeping reform of planning rules.[…] A senior industry source played down fears that the planning system, which developers complain is holding back the building of new homes, is costing the British economy dearly. 'They're shooting at the wrong target. It's too easy to shift the blame on to planning. What's holding us up is the Highways Agency and the Environment Agency. It is frustrating some of the steps we have to go through but we're trying to create sustainable communities,' he said. A spokesman for PFIZER confirmed: 'The expansion would have taken place over several years, but the business planning required a commitment from the UK management within a couple of months that they could deliver the required facilities in due course. However, experience of the timescales and uncertainty in planning applications in the region meant that the UK management was unable to give such an undertaking in the required time, and the opportunity was declined. 'Instead, the company decided to distribute the jobs in other EU countries, and the opportunity to develop a genuine EU-leading role for the UK site was lost.'

title: FERC backs Cheniere plan to build Louisiana LNG plant
news: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission Dec 15 gave final approval to another Gulf Coast LNG import terminal, granting Natural Gas Act authorization for Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass project and a related pipeline. title: UK firms want incentives to go low carbon
news: SOME of the biggest names in British business are ready to revolt against what they claim is a failure of the UK government's low-carbon policies. In a report to be published later this summer, the businesses will call on energy and climate-change secretary Ed Miliband to introduce firm prices for carbon, extra tax breaks and a raft of other incentives, including better capital allowances for green technology investment. The report, tentatively titled Lessons from UK Climate Policy, is being prepared by a loose coalition of businesses and pro-business lobby groups, representing all sectors of industry from manufacturing to finance. It is likely to come as an embarrassment to the British government, which earlier this month published its eagerly awaited low-carbon transition strategy. Ministers said it would pave the way for a new era of investment, creating 400,000 jobs in green industries. Members of the coalition, however, say the strategy falls short. "The UK's current climate policy has some way to go to incentivise businesses to green their operations," said Walter Todd, vice-president of operations for PEPSICO, one of Britain's largest food manufacturers and a member of the group. He believes the government needs to take a carrot-and-stick approach to climate policy. This means providing a stable carbon price, a move that would encourage companies to curb their carbon-dioxide emissions or pay the price. Todd said the model should be the landfill tax, which has rapidly increased the cost of sending waste to landfill.[…] Earlier this year, PEPSICO announced plans to convert oat husks from the manufacture of its Quaker Oats cereal into a low-carbon fuel that would then be used to power one of its plants. This would have cut the annual carbon emissions from Quaker Oats production by 9,000 tonnes. However, Todd said the plans had stalled because the scheme would cost too much.[…]

title: How business felt winds of change; Perspectives

title: Why rhinos recommend Viagra
news: FOR all the hype, you might think that Viagra is the first drug designed to help men achieve and sustain an erection. In fact there are many rival products. Traditional Chinese medicine, especially, claims numerous treatments for invigorating the organ in question. Yu Han, a Chinese-medicine specialist based in London, notes that most such medicines are parts of plants -- lotus stems, for example. Since plants have also yielded many drugs recognized as effective by Western medicine, it is likely that some of these herbal cures would withstand scientific scrutiny. But the distinction between medicine and magic is often a fine one, and when "cures" are based not on the chemical diversity of plants but on the alleged attributes of wild animals, the success of any treatment is surely all in the mind. Which is not much comfort to the animals involved. Take tiger-penis soup, for instance -- and some apparently do. It is supposed to endow men who consume it with the prowess of that mighty beast. Tigers are not amused: […] On the face of it, then, Asia should be a fertile market for Viagra, and tigers, rhinos and civets might thus have some of the pressure lifted from them. But maybe not. Asians do not doubt the virtues of Western medicine. Many, however, assume that traditional varieties are better for certain kinds of problems, "vigour" among them. Still, Viagra -- unlike the folk remedies -- has clinical trials to prove that it works. At a dose of 100 mg, PFIZER reports that 82 per cent of men had improved erectile performance. (It also notes, deadpan, that the drug is "not indicated for use in newborns, children or women.") Stag-penis soup, on the other hand "didn't do a thing for any of us who had it for dinner," says Dr. Baker.

title: Profiting as globe runs short of water
news: As liquidity is drained from credit and money markets and pours into oil and gold, another asset class that could offer long-term returns to the discerning investor is water. Water shortages are on the rise, stemming from soaring demand, growing populations, rising living standards and changing diets. A lack of supply is compounded by pollution and climate change. [...] Water shortage is already a serious problem in many regions of the world, as underlined in a December report from Sustainable Asset Management, based in Zurich. These regions include southern Spain, the Maghreb area of Northern Africa, the Middle East, Central Asia, Pakistan, southern India and northern China. In the Americas, the U.S. Midwest, Mexico and the Andes are the worst-hit areas. Eastern Australia is also badly affected. China is a particularly strong example. It has a fifth of the world's population but just 7 percent of the water. Most areas of its five main rivers are unsafe for direct human contact, and it will have to build 1,000 wastewater treatment plants from 2006 to 2010 to meet national pollution targets, CITIGROUP analysts say. But not everyone will benefit. While some Chinese cities are now investment hot spots, rural areas are being bypassed, underscoring a trend toward insufficient financing in poorer regions and in countries most vulnerable to shortages. [...]

title: Financial: Investors urged to back climate change awareness with action
news: There has been a major increase in the number of top institutional investors waking up to the financial risks of climate change for the businesses in which they own shares, a report out today shows. More than 225 investment houses including Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and AIG have signed up to the government-backed Carbon Disclosure Project, which produced the latest 2006 annual survey.[…] Many financial institutions including AIG and Goldman Sachs have produced dedicated climate change policies in the past 12 months. Meanwhile, Citigroup, JP MORGAN CHASE and Morgan Stanley have published equity research reports on the emerging carbon trading markets.

title: Green scene Lincoln Center gets environmentally correct at tomorrow's EcoFest
news: It's not easy being green, to quote a ­famous frog puppet. Fortunately, tomorrow's EcoFest is looking to make it a bit simpler for everyone.[…] DRESSING THE PART. EcoFest also hosts a day-long conference with leading environmental experts discussing the most daunting challenges facing New Yorkers and others. title: Obama must set out energy plan: Chevron CEO; 'Opportunity to make realistic changes,' David O'Reilly says
news: NEW YORK - The head of oil giant Chevron Corp. yesterday called on president-elect Barack Obama to create a national energy policy that promotes efficiency, opens up new areas for oil production and sets a clear policy on carbon-dioxide emissions.  "The new administration has an opportunity to make realistic changes to our approach to energy and to create a comprehensive energy policy," David O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of Chevron, said in a speech to the Council on Foreign Relations. "And we need this new energy policy to be addressed as a strategic economic priority as well as national security priority," he said in a prepared text [...] While the United States should develop alternative energy such as wind and solar, experts estimate the world will still get more than 80% of its energy from oil, natural gas and coal in 2030, he said. The United States can moderate its demand by increasing energy efficiency, he said, and should diversify its energy supplies. "Our path to energy security cannot rely on just one option, it must pursue many options," he said. Along with that, the country must make a renewed commitment to energy trade and investment and bolster science and engineering capabilities, Mr. O'Reilly said. He also called for a transparent, predictable policy for carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas emitted by burning fossil fuels that is blamed for contributing to global warming.

news: Exxon Mobil can start building the infrastructure needed to support its exploration project on the Point Thomson oil and natural gas field on the eastern portion of the North Slope of Alaska. title: CHEVRON plans $3b pipeline for gas from PNG; OIL AND GAS

CHEVRON expects the power station will be gas-fired for environmental reasons.[…] The group's project manager, Dr John Powell, said yesterday that the target was to have all approvals (government and environmental) and agreements (marketing and landowners) in place by the end of next year. title: CHEVRON to Begin Looking for Shale Gas in Poland in Autumn
news: On Tuesday, CHEVRON representatives met with the representatives of the Lubelskie provincial authorities. The US company has obtained licence's for shale gas exploration in four locations in the province. According to its representa-tive John P. Claussen, it is currently working on a detailed exploration programme, with the first seismic measurements to be made in autumn. The first boreholes will be drilled 12 months later. In total, research and exploration work is to take four years. Claussen refused to reveal both the cost of the whole operation and the expected size of the deposit. At the same time, he underlined that CHEVRON would use modern, environmentally-friendly methods in the process. The licence for shale gas exploration in the Lubelskie province is CHEVRON's first attempt to find this valuable natu-ral resource in Europe. The company is currently working on similar projects in Texas and Canada.

It said the Kogan Creek project would be detrimental to Australia's greenhouse emissions target and was "not in the spirit" of the gas pipeline agreement signed by the Queensland Government and the companies involved in the CHEVRON project.

title: US trials backyard power plant; Fridge-size Bloom Box produces clean, off-grid energy
news: A mini-power plant roughly the size of a small fridge is set to drive a global green energy revolution by literally bringing power to the people.The Bloom Box, unveiled yesterday by Silicon Valley start-up Bloom Energy, is a stack of wafer-thin solid oxide fuel cells that generates electricity by combining natural gas or biofuels with oxygen via a chemical reaction. The "electricity in a box" breakthrough will allow homes and offices to generate electricity on site, reducing dependence on coal-fired power and centralised electricity generation. It also needs far less land than solar arrays and wind farms.The technology was launched at eBay's headquarters in California by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger who described it as "a shining star" of clean energy innovation.[…] The technology has been tested for the past 18 months by a who's who of commercial customers in the United States that includes Google, FedEx, Walmart, eBay, Cocoa-Cola and the BANK OF AMERICA. Bloom Energy's board members include former US secretary of state General Colin Powell and the managing director of global financial firm Morgan Stanley, Eddy Zervigon.[…]

Since then we have had three more chancellors but no change in the final result. title: Oil driller gives seabirds a slick new home - MATTHEW FLINDERS CIRCUMNAVIGATION VOYAGE 1802-2002
news: THERE'S one way to prevent seabirds from frying on Barrow Island -- and the resident oil company has found it. A network of perches has been erected across the class-A nature reserve to provide the ospreys with an alternative nesting place to the potentially deadly high-voltage power poles. US oil company CHEVRON began the initiative 12 years ago and now has nine "mono-pods" dotted across the 230sq km island. The pods are one of many environmental programs run on the ecologically sensitive island midway between Dampier and Onslow off the West Australian coast. […] CHEVRON operates under environmental standards and has an obligation to care for the ospreys as well as other animals, including a unique subspecies of wallaby. Les McClements is responsible for monitoring 15 species of land mammals, seven marine mammals, 110 species of bird and 40 reptiles. He works with celebrity naturalist Harry Butler, who has been hired as an environmental consultant since the drilling licence was granted to CHEVRON in the mid-1950s.

title: Oil sands growth taxing infrastructure: AEUB
news: Alberta's energy regulator, in approving an expansion of Shell's Canada's oil sands operation, has issued its second warning in two months that "immediate" government attention is needed to ease the pressures from rapid oil sands growth.  It said future projects will have greater difficulty gaining approval because of the burden placed on the environment and community services. The Alberta Energy and Utilities Board, along with federal officials, said December 21 that governments do not have "sustainable long-term solutions" to manage the explosion of oil sands development. The regulators said there must be "priority attention to critical challenges" related to the environmental impact of projects and the "acute" issues faced by the Fort McMurray region of northeastern Alberta. […] Work on the Shell project, carrying an estimated cost of C$13 billion with CHEVRON Canada and Western Oil Sands each holding 20%, is scheduled to start early in 2007. Up to 7,000 construction workers will be involved in increasing production from the Athabasca operation by 65% to 250,000 b/d of refinery-ready synthetic crude and prepare the way for further expansions to 500,000 b/d.

title: Caltex petrol pumps $414m - Prices spike profit

Caltex also confirmed delays and cost over-runs for its clean fuels project would drag down first-half earnings and forecast regional demand for transport fuel to outstrip supply in the next few years. The replacement cost of sales operating profit, which strips out oil price volatility, rose 18 per cent to $414 million. Mr Warburton reaffirmed that delays affecting the clean fuels project, designed to cut pollution by reducing benzene in petrol and sulfur content in diesel, would have a negative impact on earnings in the first half of 2006. Australia imported almost 25 per cent of its transport fuel last year and its reliance on imports will continue for the forseeable future. title: Vioxx and risk
news: Re: Terence Corcoran, "MERCK Takes CSR, Suffers Major Stroke," Nov. 16. Mr. Corcoran often writes colourfully and provocatively, but in my own opinion, his liberal use of sarcasm has led to substantial inaccuracies and odd gaps of logic. He states that the goal of SustainAbility "is to drill corporate social responsibility" into the "thick skulls of the greedy and polluting Neanderthals." I suppose I inhabit a substantially different place then Mr. Corcoran, as I see the goal of SustainAbility and other groups (such as the World Business Council on Sustainable Development and the Global Resource Institute) is to ensure that investors have as complete a picture as possible of a corporation's business so that the total level of risk that the corporation has undertaken may be determined. This should allow the entire system of markets to operate more efficiently then it currently does as it could approach closer to the ideal where the rewards an investor can receive are proportional to the risk he takes. There need be nothing soft and fuzzy about this. If a corporation engages in practices that are going to increase its future exposure to expensive litigation or anything else that will reduce future earning potential, as an investor I would like to understand that upfront.[…]
