title: Kashagan set to shift balance of oil power
news: Oilmen reckon great discoveries are never easy or geographically convenient. The Kashagan oil field offshore Atyrau in the Kazakh waters of the Caspian, arguably the most important find since World War II, certainly fits that bill. Complicated logistics, icebergs, Siberian gales, tidal shifts, shallow waters and environmental considerations make Kashagan one of the most difficult discoveries ever attempted. The field, where Italy's ENI is sole operator, is considered by the world's best oilmen to be the last great find. "Kazakhstan is very likely to exceed all previous expectations," says Pietro Cavanna, ENI's deputy chief operating officer for Africa, Middle East, Eastern Europe and Asia. "It could very well shift the balance of power of oil from the Mideast to Central Asia in the next decade." Nothing has been made easy for those toiling at Kashagan - whose Agip Kco consortium includes Phillips Conoco, EXXON MOBIL, Royal/Dutch Shell, BP, BG, TotalFinaElf, Inpex and Statoil.[…] Apart from the physical dangers are the political ones. The environment is a highly sensitive issue for Agip Kco and the Kazakhstan government. Any serious oil spill or major ecological accident in the Caspian would place the Kashagan project, and even the Kazakh government, in jeopardy.[…] Kenny Hooker, oil installation manager of the oil rig for Parker Drilling, says that Agip Kco has adopted a zero discharge policy, the strictest in the world and only recently established in the North Sea. Under this regime, a rig is not allowed to discharge any waste - not even organic or human waste. "Even a glass of tea thrown into the sea would violate the zero discharge policy," says Middleton.[…]

title: Down Under CO2 store to be biggest in world
news: The State Government's insistence that greenhouse gases extracted from the Gorgon gas field be reinjected into the Earth will make it the world's biggest geosequestration project. But both the Government and proponent CHEVRON believe the project is well suited to the cutting-edge technology because of the limestone aquifer formations below Barrow Island. The Gorgon field contains 14 per cent CO2 which CHEVRON proposes separating from the natural gas and injecting 2000m down where it will be stored for thousands of years. Two weeks ago, Gorgon put the cost of the geosequestration at $850 million but industry analysts say the figure could be double that, threatening the viability of the project. […] The department's deputy director-general Stuart Smith said yesterday he was confident the greenhouse gas would remain locked in its subterranean cage. "When the CO2 gets injected in the first place it will slowly rise within the aquifer to the first cap rock and over time it reacts with the surrounding rock, becomes heavier and sinks," Mr Smith said. "There's four layers of cap rock, so we'd need four failures of all of those for any leakage, alternatively it needs to leak through one of the drill holes that's there, so they'll be monitoring the sites." title: House panel explores ratemaking, technology, other issues to promote smart grid deployment
news: Members of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming heard from technology experts from such companies as GE Energy, IBM and Wal-Mart on new smart grid technologies and how they can be integrated effectively.Committee Chairman Edward Markey, Democrat-Massachusetts, said the hearing would shape the efficiency measures included in "our bold new national energy policy." The grid was designed for a different era, he said, and consumers currently lack the information they need to change their usage. […] Allan Schurr, vice president of strategy and development for IBM Global Energy and Utilities, said that a smart grid should enable more efficient energy use, lower the cost of renewable energy sources, increase operational efficiency for utilities, and improve reliability and quality of electrical service. Such a system would allow customers to manage their energy use better, and would reduce the price of both centralized and distributed renewable energy because installation and interconnection is faster and cheaper."In this world, the cost and environmental impact of large-scale plant transmission interconnection is reduced due to more dynamic loading on existing lines; the process of connecting new rooftop solar systems to the utility grid is as simple as ordering a mobile phone online; and the variability of wind, solar and other resources is managed through tighter integration of these supplies." title: Cabinet burning midnight oil over gas; Capital Moves
news: Federal Cabinet has some tough greenhouse decisions to fight out over the next months, but one of the toughest and most crucial is not yet even on the Cabinet agenda. The Australian Financial Review this week publicly revealed what the Environment Minister, Senator Robert Hill, had been privately stewing on for some time - shocking new figures showing that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions had blown out by dramatic proportions. […] Competitive energy markets were supposed to be a boon for the nation's greenhouse gas credentials because they were supposed to give "cleaner" gas-fired energy a relative boost compared with coal-fired power. […] This is definitely not the view of the deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, who put out an extraordinary statement declaring Senator Hill's trigger an "inappropriate" measure that would cost both investment and jobs in (the electorally-all-important) regions. What had Anderson and the Industry Minister, Senator Nick Minchin, particularly hot under the collar was a memo to Cabinet by Senator Hill which suggested that a new $1 billion coal-fired power station in Queensland be forced to offset its own emissions with greenhouse-abating investments, such as forestry, and which proposed the Government not give $100 million in assistance to the Comalco alumina refinery unless it sources its power from CHEVRON gas rather than coal-fired power. Both suggestions were clearly attempts by Hill to address Australia's spiralling coal-fired electricity related emissions. […] But at some stage Cabinet will have to grapple with how it can possibly keep the Government's dual promises to meet its Kyoto commitments and to protect the competitiveness of Australian industry. It is looking increasingly likely that the answer is it can't.

title: BG rushes in where rivals fear to tread
news: Due to its reliance on gas, Origin could eventually prove to be a net beneficiary of carbon trading [...] CITIGROUP analysts yesterday estimated that Origin would eventually prove to be a net beneficiary of carbon trading. [...] ``Origin's generation portfolio has a lower emissions intensity than average,'' CITIGROUP said.

title: Gas hailed power source of future
news: Australia's gas pipeline industry has been exhorted to push its greenhouse emission advantages as a way to expand the industry. With natural gas producing as little as one-third the global warming emissions of black coal, delegates at a gas pipeline industry function in Brisbane yesterday were told that gas should be marketed as the preferred, environmentally friendly source for electricity generation. But the industry must work on issues such as cost relative to coal-fired power and market efficiency to ensure growth in gas uptake - static in recent years. After the Longford disaster, security of supply must also be re-emphasised. […] "Australian energy is dominated by coal. A transition to gas will dramatically improve our greenhouse performance. More gas requires more pipelines," said Mr Toyne, now a principal of environmental consultancy Eco Futures. […] The most pressing project on the drawing board is a $3 billion-plus proposal for AGL and Malaysia's Petronas to shift gas from CHEVRON's fields in Papua New Guinea to Gladstone in south-eastern Queensland - planned to be commissioned after 2000.But presenters cautioned that the economics of gas must be competitive and sound to sustain the vision of a much expanded gas market with multiple interconnection points, servicing a significant number of electricity generators.[…]

title: Livestock benefit as recycler turns store trash into cash; THE HOT 1000 Companies to inspire Britain SugaRich has proved a winner, with 40pc growth in three years, writes Anna White
news: Scraps of waste bread are a precious commodity for animal food producer SugaRich. The manufacturer of animal feed has spotted an opportunity in the market to turn "trash into cash" by helping supermarkets and food companies to dispose of their unwanted food efficiently by processing it into highprotein meals for pigs, poultry and cattle. […]  "We used to be a company that operated out of sight and behind the factory back door," said Alex Keogh, commercial director of SugaRich, "But now we're very much a part of the factory floor."  Northampton-based SugaRich works with food manufacturers and retailers to transform high calorific food waste into protein-rich animal food. It outperformed in the recession by taking on a double role - helping companies reduce waste before selling it to UK farmers.[…] Retailers such as supermarkets are already adept at managing their card and plastic co-products, therefore Sugarich manages the disposal of their food waste.  "However, over the last three years we have started to operate the ethical disposal of non food stuffs for manufacturers such as PEPSI and Walkers," said Mr Keogh.  The future of the business is also supported by the Government ruling to halve edible food waste by 2020.  "This target is drawing nearer and more has to be done to achieve the UK's ultimate zero food waste to landfill ambition," said Mr Keogh.[…]

title: Delaware County News in Brief
news: The first of four collection days for household hazardous waste will be held from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday at the county transfer station, Sussex Boulevard and Marpit Road in Marple Township, Delaware County, officials announced recently.  There is no charge for the collection, but residents are advised to separate materials into containers with lids. Any household hazardous waste will be accepted, including cell phones, pesticides, lead-acid batteries, small propane tanks, oil-based paint, thinners, antifreeze, and mercury. Items that will not be accepted include those that can be discarded at home, such as appliances and latex paint. In addition, no unidentifiable waste or commercial waste such as gas cylinders and biological material, will be accepted. Information about recycling material is in the back of the VERIZON telephone directory distributed to Delaware County residents.

news: ExxonMobil and BHP Billiton have received a boost to their tentative plans for a massive floating LNG plant off Western Australia, securing environmental approval for the multi-billion dollar venture from the federal government. The approval, which comes with 17conditions, was given after no submissions were received by the environment department on the plan, which would involve stationing a huge FLNG vessel at the Scarborough gas deposit, 220 kilometers north-west of Exmouth. title: COMPANY NEWS; UNOCAL IS SUED TO INVALIDATE A GASOLINE PATENT
news: Six of the nation's largest oil companies have sued the Unocal Corporation seeking to invalidate a gasoline patent that could enable the company to charge competitors a fee for each gallon they sell in California. The suit, filed Thursday in United States District Court, involves a patent for a new type of low-emission fuel that California law mandates be sold beginning on 6 1, 1996. Unocal received the patent in February 1994 and determined recently that it could use it to impose royalties on gas sold by other oil companies. Unocal is apparently planning to put a one-cent-a-gallon charge on the fuel -- an $80-million-a- year bonus for Unocal, the plantiffs' lawyer, John Diaz, contended in the lawsuit. The suit was filed on behalf of ARCO, Chevron, EXXON, MOBIL, Shell and Texaco.

title: Cracking the Energy Puzzles of the 21st Century
news: Not long ago, Chevron's exploration teams were stuck. Several years earlier they had struck oil at a place called Rosebank, 9,000 feet below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean west of Britain's Shetland Islands. But the usual seismic surveys could not make out the location of the field clearly enough for Chevron to decide where to place wells, which can cost $100 million or more apiece. […] No doubt, the use of wind, solar and hydroelectric power and other less-polluting renewable energy sources will continue to grow, as concerns about global warming increase. Hydroelectric dams are still the largest renewable source, though hydropower is expected to grow more slowly than wind and solar. Research into waves and tidal energy is extensive, notably at the European Marine Energy Center in the Orkney Islands north of the Scottish mainland, though output from such technology at present is not significant. […] ''This is clearly the natural gas century,'' said Edward Morse, the head of commodities research at Citigroup in New York. Mr. Morse said that having gas resources, as many countries do, ''frees an economy from worrying not only about security of supply but volatility of price.''

title: Woodside chairman ends his hunt for the right man
news: [...]``PETER who?'' Just like Australia's reaction when off-spinner Peter Taylor was plucked from obscurity in 1987 to join the national cricket team, the business world was bewildered yesterday by the appointment of ExxonMobil executive Peter Coleman to run Woodside Petroleum. [...] But on closer inspection, nobody should be too surprised because Coleman, with a weighty CV dominated by 27 years with oil giant ExxonMobil in Australia, the US, Indonesia and Nigeria, is precisely the sort of candidate Woodside chairman Michael Chaney has been hunting for since October. [...] It will be interesting to see if he tries to bring Exxon's highly disciplined and structured approach to Woodside, where senior executives enjoy more autonomy than at many big companies. Coleman's personal style will be important also in mending fences with Woodside's joint-venture partners in the $30bn Browse LNG project being planned in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. The partners are reluctant to build on the sensitive Kimberley site and environmental activists are predicting a stoush that will last for years.[...]

title: Gorgon LNG project set to test CHEVRON's mettle - MINING & ENERGY
news: ON THE WESTERN FRONT. THE credibility of US oil and gas giant CHEVRON is on the line over its determination to be a major player in the global liquefied natural gas market. To understand the significance of coming events, it should be remembered that the Gorgon LNG project on Barrow Island off the West Australian coast is CHEVRON's No1 future gas project. The past week was not CHEVRON's finest hour for its Australian activities. And the rest of the year holds promise of further challenges that will test its capacity to deliver. For a start, the framework agreement on the Gorgon project ownership structure, signed in 2005 between CHEVRON, ExxonMobil and Shell, is up for review. That agreement, which brought ExxonMobil's giant Jansz gas field into the Gorgon mix, allows for any of the parties to reconsider their position. That's not to say ExxonMobil or Shell will withdraw, but certainly the review process will put the project under a microscope. […] CHEVRON has for several years avoided committing to a FID target date for Gorgon, after saying in 2006 that it was not likely that year. The partners have environmental approval from both the West Australian and federal governments for a two-train, 10 million tonnes annual capacity plant. Last week it was confirmed that CHEVRON had formally requested advice on the level of environmental assessment that would be required to place three production trains on the same site as the two already approved. A third train would lift output to 15 million tonnes a year. The West Australian Government is awaiting advice from the Environmental Protection Agency on how to proceed. If a full-scale environmental impact statement is required, the odds must favour Gorgon being scuttled.

title: Needle edging closer to empty; A refinery shortage looms as investment gets scarce, writes SHAWN McCARTHY
news: Valero Energy Corp.'s new $100-million (U.S.) scrubber at its refinery on the Delaware River can remove 1,600 kilograms of sulphur dioxide from its emissions each hour - but adds not a drop of gasoline to its output. […] In total, Valero has spent $500-million at Paulsboro to reduce air and water pollution, and meet Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) orders to dramatically reduce the sulphur content in gasoline. It will spend up to another $300-million to meet requirements for low-sulphur diesel. […] Refiners have spent about $35-billion in the past 15 years to meet environmental requirements, but only a small fraction of that boosts output to meet rising demand. As a result, the United States is facing a critical shortfall in refining capacity and that means more pain for an energy-thirsty nation already coping with near-record world oil prices. If trends continue, fatter refinery profits will drive pump prices even higher and the country will depend to an even greater degree on uncertain supplies from foreign sources. […] Lawrence Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, was more blunt. He said the major oil companies such as Exxon Mobil Corp., ConocoPhillips Co. and CHEVRON Corp. are "disinterested in refining as a business" […] But again, stricter environmental standards are making it more difficult for oil companies to satisfy motorists' demand. Importers are running up against new EPA standards that dramatically reduce the amount of allowable sulphur in both gasoline and diesel. Many traditional offshore suppliers simply can't meet those new requirements. […]

title: South Africa; Interbrand Releases 2nd Annual Best Global Green Brands Report
news: LONDON, UK: Interbrand, one of the world's leading brand consultancies and author of the annual Best Global Brands Report, has released its 2012 Best Global Green Brands Report. Toyota (#1), Johnson & Johnson (#2), and Honda (#3) top the ranking with Danone (#9), Ford (#15), Starbucks (#36) and UPS (#43) representing this year's top risers.This year's report shows that industries around the world are taking actionable and quantifiable measures to improve both their sustainability performance and their degree of external reporting. As sustainability initiatives continue to gain relevance in the C-suite and with consumers, companies in all sectors are striving to strike a winning balance between building a green business and effectively communicating sustainable practices in the global marketplace. Interbrand's 2012 Best Global Green Brands Report examines the gap that exists between corporate environmental practices and consumer perception of those practices using its 2011 Best Global Brands Report, extensive consumer research and performance data provided by Deloitte - data based upon publicly available information. title: Alcoa to redo its sums on Wagerup
news: Alcoa will conduct a major review of the costs and design of a planned $1.5 billion expansion of its Wagerup alumina refinery after the West Australian government yesterday approved the controversial project subject to a list of environmental conditions. […] The Wagerup refinery has been the subject of controversy for several years amid claims it has damaged the health of local residents. The project was has been stalled during a lengthy approvals process that involved clearance from the state's Environmental Protection Authority in 1. WA Premier Alan Carpenter said yesterday the 42 environmental conditions placed on the refinery would make it the most regulated in the world and ensure no increase in overall emissions from the refinery. […] The government's approval of Wagerup will raise industry hopes that other major resource projects in WA under environmental challenge, including CHEVRON's $11 billion Gorgon gas plant, also will receive the green light in coming months. Mr Osborn said the expansion would involve building a third production unit at the refinery and upgrading the existing plant. Alumina production would rise from 2.6 million tonnes to 4.7 million tonnes per year. He denied claims by environmentalists that pollution from the refinery had made residents around the town of Yarloop sick. The AWAC alliance of Alcoa and Alumina has several alumina developments worldwide, some under construction and others under consideration, and the Wagerup expansion will compete against other projects for funding.

title: Doubts on green energy
news: RENEWABLE energy sources such as wind and solar energy will continue to meet only a tiny portion of world energy demand, despite their impressive growth. That's the bleak assessment of leading energy expert Dr Brian Flannery, of EXXON MOBIL. Speaking at a combined American Chamber of Commerce and EXXON MOBIL lunch in Melbourne yesterday, Dr Flannery said many of the "solutions" being proposed to meet the world's energy demand did not stand up to scrutiny.  Carbon trading, the Kyoto protocol, increased energy efficiency and the rapid increase in renewable energy would all unfortunately not stop greatly increased worldwide production of greenhouse gases. That was because fossil fuels would continue to satisfy the vast bulk of world energy demand.[...]  In contrast, he forecast that wind and solar power together would meet only 1 per cent of the world's energy needs by 2020 -- and that assumed continued rapid growth and subsidies for both. Dr Flannery said he had serious doubts about whether carbon trading would provide the right market signals or that the Kyoto protocol would do much more than slow down by 10 years the projected two degrees of global warning some people predicted for the next 100 years.

title: ENERGY CONSERVATION; Saudi Arabia has a big problem - and it's called oil
news: I knew fuel was cheap in Saudi Arabia, but I had no idea how ridiculously cheap. I found out when the driver of the big BMW who picked me up at the Jeddah airport pulled off the highway and paid the equivalent of $8 (U.S.) for a fill-up. Gasoline in the kingdom costs about 16 cents a litre. Water costs more. […] No wonder there are worries that Saudi Arabia, the world's central bank of oil and OPEC's biggest producer and exporter, faces an energy crisis in a couple of decades. Domestic demand for oil is climbing so fast that Citigroup, in a 2012 report, predicted that the country would be a net oil importer by 2030. […] Still, the Citigroup report, which was dismissed as fantasy in Saudi Arabia, is probably directionally right. […] Officially, Saudi Arabia is making grand plans to reduce the domestic demand for oil, or at least slow its growth. Aramco has launched an aggressive hunt for natural gas that could be used to replace the oil slurped up by the electricity plants. Even before the plants are converted to gas, there is a campaign to make them far more efficient. Nuclear reactors may come and investments are being made in photovoltaic and thermal solar power. If there is one commodity Saudi Arabia has in abundance besides oil, it is sunshine. […]

title: Oil sands firms urged to reveal risks of a carbon crackdown
news: GLOBAL ENERGY REPORTER   Companies operating in Canada's oil sands are facing new pressure to assess and disclose the long-term risks to the value of their crude reserves amid a global effort to address climate change. In a letter to 45 of the world's top energy companies, a coalition of global institutional investors - including some of the biggest pension funds in the United States - said fossil-fuel producers have an obligation to reveal what financial risks they face and how they intend to manage those challenges if world governments adopt aggressive policies to reduce carbon emissions.  "As investors with long-term investment strategies, we would like to understand [the company's] reserve exposure to the risks associated with current and probable future policies for reducing GHG emissions," said the letter, sent last month by two ethical investor groups, Ceres and Carbon Tracker Initiative, on behalf of 70 global money managers.  […] Oil sands companies are particularly susceptible to climate risks because their reserve base is carbon intensive, geared to long-term production, and is among the most expensive in the world to develop, Ceres spokesman Andrew Logan said Thursday. He noted that major brokerage houses like Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Citigroup Global Markets Inc. have raised warning flags about lower-than-previously-anticipated future demand for crude, due in part to climate concerns. […]

title: AMAZON SEEKS TO GREEN ECONOMY
news: MAUES, Brazil - For decades, this remote town overlooking the  chocolate-coloured waters of the Amazon River has been the main  source of guarana, a bright red, highly caffeinated berry that is  believed by many Brazilians to be an aphrodisiac.[…]  ''What better product to represent the Amazon than a natural stimulant that is harvested without harming the environment?" said Valmir Ferrari, an agronomist with Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, a Brazilian beverage company planning to export a guarana soft drink to rich industrialized nations in a venture with PEPSICO. ''This could be bigger than Viagra."  While the libido-enhancing effects of guarana may have more to do with fiction than fact, it is no small wonder that products from the Amazon, a region that has long gripped popular imagination as the world's largest rain forest, are being viewed as a way for the region to develop without harming the environment at a time when other forces are threatening to speed the area's depletion.[…]

title: Codexis Signs Deal with PFIZER; Commercializes Process for Lonza
news: Enzyme discovery firm Codexis says it has signed a multi-year collaboration agreement with PFIZER focused on process R&D for some of PFIZER's small-molecule human therapeutics.  The agreement includes up-front payments, technology access fees, and milestone payments to Codexis, which the company says could total up to $ 40 million over the term of the agreement.  PFIZER will also make an equity investment of $ 10 million in Codexis. PFIZER will have the option to acquire a nonexclusive license to certain of Codexis's MolecularBreeding enzyme technology, under the terms of the agreement.  Codexis says it will receive a license fee upon exercise of that option by PFIZER.  The collaboration involves multiple projects per year, with each product generating additional milestone payments upon U.S. regulatory clearance, as well as ongoing commercial payments on sales, the company says.Separately, Codexis and Lonza say they have commercialized a novel biocatalytic process for the synthesis of a key chiral compound used in a major undisclosed human therapeutic.  Lonza will use the Codexis process for the commercial manufacture of the compound.  The process is entirely biocatalytic, employing three enzyme catalysts, and uses raw materials that are produced locally in bulk by Lonza, Codexis says. "The process is highly efficient and an example of environmentally friendly green chemistry, requiring relatively low energy inputs, mild solvents, and generating minimal byproducts," Codexis says.  The company says it will receive license fees and royalties from Lonza, and will also sell commercial quantities of the biocatalysts to Lonza for use in the production process. Codexis has 10 strategic alliances, including a prior agreement with PFIZER; more than 15 products and processes in development internally and at client companies; and five processes now operating at commercial scale, each generating royalty payments, says Alan Shaw, president and CEO.  […]

title: Biofuels law enforcement faces delay
news: The government may defer beyond the original target of May 6 the implementation of the Biofuels Act of 2006, the law that mandates the blending of biofuels into gasoline and diesel, the Department of Energy yesterday said. "We're still looking at the convenient date for the rollout. We want to ensure the smooth implementation of the law," Energy Secretary Raphael P.M. Lotilla told reporters yesterday. […] But big oil firms have been seeking a delay in the implementation of the new law, arguing that putting the necessary infrastructure, such as storage tanks, in place would take at least one year from the date of enforcement. For example, CHEVRON Phils. and Petron Corp. have voiced their concern over the original May 6 implementation date. CHEVRON country chairman Randy H. Johnson had said his company needed more time to have bio-diesel available in its retail outlets. "Our industry was looking for a longer time period, but the law is the law and on May 6, we will have biodiesel," he said. […] The Biofuels Act initially mandates a minimum of 1% biodiesel blend within three months after the law takes effect, and at least 5% bioethanol blend within two years. The law also mandates the use of at least 2% biodiesel blend within two years upon effectivity and the use of 10% bioethanol fuel within four years. As of yesterday, Mr. Lotilla could not provide a new implementing date.

title: CHEVRON gas project gets state green light
news: SYDNEY: CHEVRON has received final environmental approval from the State Government of Western Australia for its huge Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) project, two sources familiar with the situation said yesterday. The company still needs National Government approval before the project can start. The project was first expected to deliver gas in 2010, but analysts say 2015 is more likely after delays caused by environmental issues. The cost is expected to jump to US$12.4 billion ($18.2 billion), from US$11 billion estimated three years ago. […] One of the sources said the environmental approval was based on the construction of a processing plant for the project's gas on Barrow Island in Western Australia that would have a total liquefaction capacity of 10 million tonnes a year. […] A second source said CHEVRON has already made plans to build a construction camp on Barrow Island to house more than 2000 workers and was expanding port facilities in preparation. […] Barrow Island is a nature reserve and the Western Australian Government had laid down strict conditions to protect the environment. CHEVRON is the operator of the Gorgon project and holds a 50 per cent stake. Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell each have 25 per cent. […]

title: Congress clears way for deepening ports
news: [WASHINGTON] House and Senate negotiators reached agreement on a bill that would authorise deepening several US ports ahead of the expansion of the Panama Canal and the bigger ships that will use it. [...] The Water Resources Reform and Development Act is seen as one of the few examples of bipartisan action in a polarised Congress that's on pace to become the least productive in history in terms of bills passed. [...] The Senate-passed version would have authorised money to take action in response to rising sea levels or increased ocean temperatures resulting from global warming. House Republicans who have resisted new spending linked to climate change rejected that provision. [...] The largest navigation project included in both the House and Senate-passed measures would deepen the Sabine-Neches Waterway, which connects the oil-refining hub of Beaumont and Port Arthur, Texas, with the Gulf of Mexico. The Port Arthur area is home to the southern end of the Keystone XL pipeline. Deepening the port will reduce shipping costs for oil and natural gas processed there by Exxon Mobil, Total and Cheniere Energy. [...]

title: CRIST CREATES LEGAL TEAM ON SPILL
news: Saying he was preparing for the worst while hoping for the best, Gov. Charlie Crist on Monday assembled a small army of generals to provide legal advice to Florida as they brace for a potential legal skirmish with oil giant BP. [...] BP's financial wounds from the April 20 drilling-rig explosion may be serious, but they probably won't be fatal. One analyst report, issued by CITIGROUP, even declared in its title, "Reaction to the Gulf of Mexico oil leak is a buying opportunity." [...] CITIGROUP analysts said that stockholders' reactions seem "disproportionate to the likely costs to the company." It noted that punitive damages against Exxon for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil-tanker spill were originally set at $5 billion in 1994 but were reduced on appeal. The company in 2009 agreed to pay less than $1 billion, including interest. [...]

title: Automakers target emissions as way to stay ahead
news: […] Analysts say one such trend is the emphasis on cleaner cars as regulations on auto emissions are tightened in Europe, the United States and Japan. "Technologies in environmental protection will be crucially important this year," said Noriyuki Matsushima, a credit analyst at Nikko CITIGROUP Ltd. He said that 2007 will be the year for carmakers to establish their technologies in the race to bring eco-friendly cars to market at affordable prices. "If you lose, you'll get kicked out of the market." […] Nikko CITIGROUP's Matsushima pointed to currency fluctuations and soaring prices for raw materials, including steel and nonferrous metals, as particular challenges. […]

title: Climate change possible threat to mining giants, report warns
news: MINING giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are among a group at risk from climate change, according to a CITIGROUP report. The report says companies in the emissions-intensive industry might be penalised by investors if Australia were to adopt emissions trading. […] CITIGROUP Investment Research managing director Bruce Rolph said the immediate risks were about potential investor concerns. However, there was scope for companies deemed to have a higher risk premium to take advantage of environmental forces shaping the investment landscape. […]

title: COMMENT; IGCC REVISITED: THE NEW DEAL.
news: After many years in the wilderness, the prospects for deployment of IGCC (integrated gasification combined cycle) as a clean coal technology seem to be steadily improving. A degree of caution is necessary of course, because people have been saying this for years. […] On the R&D side, as reported in last month's issue, the second round of the Bush Administration's Clean Coal Initiative yielded a healthy crop of gasification proposals. Now, from the all important utility sector, we have the announcement from no less than American Electric Power - the USA's biggest power generator - that it plans to adopt IGCC technology as part of its efforts to keep "coal in the money" as "a low-cost, low emissions energy source." […] An annex of the report provides a useful comparison of IGCC with competing generating technologies, "the good, the bad and the ugly" of IGCC, as it puts it. […] Then there's the ugly, which at least up until recently, has been "the business deal", with "no equipment suppliers, only technology licensers" while "virtually all of the technology and performance risk is on the plant owner." However, with GE's purchase of CHEVRON TEXACO's gasification interests now complete, the balance of risk can be shifted and the business side of IGCC now looks potentially a good deal more attractive. This has paved the way for AEP's strengthened commitment to IGCC, and may enable others to follow. Nuclear rescue? […]

title: Shenzhen Journal; An Age-Old Quest Could Be at an End: Chinese Hail Viagra
news: Buy a pack of gum or a bottle of water in the departure lounge of the Shenzhen airport and -- if you are male -- the saleswomen may well make you another offer: from under the counter comes a pack of four bright blue pills.     "Weige," two chirped in unison, plopping it on the glass top for inspection and using the Chinese nickname for Viagra.  "Cheap -- and real," one whispered of the precious contraband, glancing around nervously. No matter that Viagra is theoretically available only by prescription in China. In this go-go "special economic zone" of Shenzhen, along the Hong Kong border, nearly every sex shop, every pharmacy -- even a large number of candy stores and soda stands -- also offers the wonder drug, or convincing counterfeits. […] In Chongqing, veterinarians last year fed Viagra to a species of endangered tiger in the hopes of raising the males' interest in breeding. (Tt didn't work.) On a brighter note, animal rights groups say Viagra has probably saved innumerable seals from slaughter, reducing the demand for medicines containing seal penis.[…] In a survey by The Shanghai Evening Post last year, 2,000 retail outlets in that city reported selling an average of four pills a day -- 8,000 tablets daily. At the time of the survey, PFIZER, the drug's manufacturer, had distributed only 12,000 tablets in the entire country, according to a Canadian medical journal. The main ingredient of Viagra, sildenafil citrate, can be manufactured by any good-sized drug factory, said Mr. Wang.[…]

title: Oil giants facing £12bn bill for rigs
news: OIL companies will face a total bill of £11.8 billion to decommission their British North Sea oil rigs and gas installations in the coming years, according to industry research.  Since Shell's Brent Spar decommissioning debacle in the 1990s, rulings have been brought in requiring companies to remove completely their offshore oil and gas structures, where before they would simply be dumped at sea. Oil analysts at research house Wood Mackenzie have calculated the costs of dismantling the structures either currently onstream, under development or expected to be developed.  Between 2004 and 2021, they estimate some 298 fields will be decommissioned. EXXON MOBIL and BP Amoco face the biggest costs, with £1.5 billion each in real terms, followed by Shell's £1.3 billion.[…]  However, under British tax rulings aimed at encouraging companies to consider the environment, in some cases companies can claw back up to 60% of the cost of decommissioning from taxes paid during the lifetime of the plant, Wood Mackenzie said.[…]

title: Solar Gains; Royal Dutch Shell looks into a bright future - at the likely expense of oil
news: Solar could overtake oil as the world's dominant energy source by 2060 in one scenario envisioned by Royal Dutch Shell PLC. [...] This is one of the "messy, complicated and patchy" worlds envisioned by Jeremy Bentham and his scenarios team at the company. Shell and rivals Exxon Mobil Corp. and BP PLC make periodic predictions on the energy sector, but Shell's forecast has looked further out than its competitors and also seems to be the most optimistic on renewables. [...] Mr. Bentham expects frequent bouts of commodity price volatility, a bigger voice for the environmental movement, but also greater use in real terms of hydrocarbons and renewables energy in the future. [...] "But flourishing with those business opportunities requires investing in enhanced collaborations, between business, government and civil society." That may be difficult if civil society and businesses don't see eye to eye on key issues. Indeed, Mr. Bentham expects the environmental movement to be more influential in the future, especially in our ever-connected world. [...] But more voices mean more opportunities for opposition, but also herd-like opposition." [...]

title: RE-ENGINEERING MOTHER NATURE: They don't get much notice, but agricultural biologists are engineering everything from cancer fighting canola to hens that can't wait to part with their eggs. They're also heading up some promising young companies.
news: […]  With little fanfare, scientists across North America are experimenting with genetically altered crops at universities, small biotech start-ups and multinational feed and seed companies. Their work ranges from developing herbicide-resistant grains to vegetables that keep their flavor longer and even plants that will grow pharmaceuticals. Over at Biostar, scientists have developed vaccines, chemical alternatives to castration, and other drugs for livestock, with the same sort of recombinant DNA technology used by human-health companies. One of Biostar's immunopharmaceuticals is designed to suppress broodiness in hens. That sounds a little like Prozac for poultry, but the drug is actually designed to encourage hens to lay more eggs, instead of sitting on them until they hatch. Repressing hens' maternal instincts may sound unnatural, but it boosts productivity and and is perhaps kinder to the birds, says president Steve Acres.  Biostar's list of backers already includes MDS Health Group Ltd. and the pharmaceutical giant PFIZER Inc., but the company is contemplating an initial public offering in 1997.[…]

title: Steep rise in pay for green jobs
news: STRONG demand for environmental planning and consulting professionals is pushing up salaries and creating skills shortages across several sectors. Mining and resources businesses are the leading the charge, with highly paid jobs for professionals with experience of environmental approvals.``Mining and resources companies have a lot of projects in pre-feasibility stage, in particular environmental approvals,'' says specialist executive recruitment company EnviroSearchGlobal's director Richard Evans.[...] High-demand jobs include environmental consultants and scientists, contaminated land specialists, EPA auditors, energy efficiency engineers and environmental planners.[...] ``People are being shifted around the country and that is creating competition and pushing up salaries. We have clients who have expressed concern that they can't compete with the likes of [liquefied natural gas companie]) Woodside Petroleum and CHEVRON, who pay retention bonuses and give employees shares.'' [...]

title: Economic development "best way to ensure Mekong peace'
news: Lee Siew Hua, Bangkok Correspondent. BRINGING prosperity to the once-divided nations of the Mekong River basin was the best guarantee of regional peace, Thai Deputy Premier Supachai Panitchpakdi told members of the World Economic Forum on Sunday night.[…]Dr Supachai, who handles the economic-policy portfolio, was briefing international businessmen ahead of their eight-day trip to assess opportunities in Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Myanmar and China's Yunnan province.[…]Dr Supachai, making a pitch for this rapidly emerging region, outlined other growth principles:[…]Social development, such as in Aids control, education and climate research. […] The World Economic Forum is a top-level gathering of policy-makers, businessmen and scholars. The business leaders on this trip include top executives from Olivetti of Italy, Mitsubishi of Japan, CHEVRON Overseas Petroleum of the United States, and Zurich Insurance of Switzerland.

title: Australia Soon Becoming Regional LNG Player with Global Ambition
news: With Indonesia faltering, Australia is poised to become a leading regional supplier, with ongoing and planned projects and expansions capable of exporting more than 5 billion cubic feet per day to markets throughout Asia -- and perhaps the US -- by the end of this decade.[...] Meanwhile, Chevron, Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell just received hard-fought-for environmental approval for its Gorgon Project, which will include two trains each with a capacity of 670 MMcf/d. [...]

title: Canadian expert in charge of trash at Atlanta Games
news: Jack McGinnis is one Canadian preparing for the incredible challenge that will come from participating in the Olympic Games in Atlanta next summer. He won't be marching in the opening ceremonies parade. He'll be lucky if he gets as much as a glimpse of any of the competition. McGinnis is responsible for trash recycling during the Games. […] The best planned event, however, can become a disaster, recalls Pam Epps who worked on the 1995 World Nordic Games in Thunder Bay.Organizers were distraught but helpless when a "$1 million sponsor" decided to hand out thousands of cardboard packages each containing two pieces of gum, she said. "They're still picking up those little boxes," Epps recently told a Recycling Council of Ontario seminar on environmental etiquette. McGinnis notes that sponsors of special events must agree to environmental codes of conduct before signing contracts to avoid any embarrassing problems during an event. "The big dog eats wherever it wants to," said McGinnis, who planned meetings last week with two of the Summer Games' major sponsors and waste generators, the Atlanta-based COCA-COLA company and McDonald's fast food chain.

title: Carbon Market Running In Place Without Legislation
news: Participants in the carbon emissions market tried to chart a course to navigate pending carbon legislation at the Third U.S. Carbon Finance Forum held last week at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Without any laws governing carbon emissions and unsure who would regulate emissions trading, would-be players focused on what the market would need to be successful. The Waxman-Markey Bill, known as The American Clean Energy and Security Act, passed the U.S. House of Representatives in 6. The bill calls for establishing a cap-n-trade system to curb the amount of greenhouse gasses emitted into the atmosphere. The U.S. Senate is expected to debate the bill in coming months. One key point discussed at the conference was whether a carbon market might be forced onto an exchange amid talk of more transparency throughout commodities markets. That would create a problem, said Jason Patrick, v.p., emissions trading, BANK OF AMERICA-Merrill Lynch in New York. "The [over-the-counter] market is crucial not only for carbon but other commodity markets," Patrick said during the "Carbon Trading and the Secondary Carbon Markets" panel discussion. "It's extremely difficult to hedge on an exchange. Project developers need to hedge."[…]

title: Sally Jewell, nominee for Secretary of the Interior, profited from oil, coal and cigarette companies; Sally Jewell, the environmentally-minded business executive nominated to join President Barack Obama's cabinet, has profited from tens of thousands of dollars of shares in oil, coal and cigarette companies, many with questionable ethical records.
news: Financial disclosure forms reviewed by The Daily Telegraph show that Mrs Jewell, Mr Obama 's nominee for Secretary of the Interior, has or recently had investments in more than a dozen of the world's leading oil firms. Mrs Jewell is the chief executive of Recreational Equipment Inc (REI), an outdoor goods company that has won plaudits for its environmental policy and treatment of its employees. [...] Mrs Jewell's financial records show she owns or recently owned up to $200,000 in shares in Chevron, Exxon Mobil, and ConocoPhillips, three oil companies which all deal extensively with the department she hopes to head. In a letter to the department's ethics office, Mrs Jewell promised to divest from all three firms as well as a number of other oil companies. [...]

title: Ethics not profits, say students
news: MORE Australian students want to work for a socially responsible employer than a commercially successful one, according to The Australia and New Zealand Graduate Careers Survey 2004. Asked which characteristics of their first employer final-year university students would describe as "very important", 44 per cent listed social responsibility as their main concern. Another 34 per cent of students listed a job that would allow them to "give something back" to the community and 34 per cent also rated environmental responsibility in their employer as very important. […] TOP EMPLOYERS. 1....KPMG […] 5....IBM  6....Deloitte[…]

title: Second NW Shelf line postponed
news: […] PNG gas line. Chevron has secured approval for its environmental impact statement and from the Queensland regulator for the pipeline's tariff and access agreements. However, the company must also receive parliamentary approval from Papua New Guinea for the project by the end of November, as well as reach agreement for gas supply with Papua New Guinea operators EXXON Corp. and Oil Search Ltd. and convert memoranda of understanding with its five major potential Australian gas customers into "bankable" documents. Finalizing a gas supply agreement with EXXON and Oil Search, owners of nearby Hides gas field in the Papua New Guinea highlands, is particularly crucial, because much of the resource within Chevron's jointly owned Kutubu fields is too inaccessible to be commercially produced.  Papua New Guinea's proven gas reserves are about half what the pipeline project needs to sustain it for 30 years.

title: BP oil spill may hit rig orders; Investors getting jittery as Obama gives British energy giant a tongue-lashing
news: INVESTORS are becoming jittery over the fallout from BP's nightmarish oil spill on the Gulf of Mexico. They are particularly concerned about how the crisis will hit the businesses of rig-builders and marine-based firms, which have until now prospered from the proliferation of offshore oil exploration. [...] According to a CITIGROUP report, the ban on offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico could result in billions of dollars' worth of cancelled contracts for drillers engaged by oil majors. To prevent this from happening, the drillers have been pressing oil majors to use the rigs in other parts of the world, where they are also engaged in deep-water projects. [...]

title: ECO POWER REVOLUTION IN INDIA CAN BRING YOU BIG PROFITS
news: THE debate over energy prices has been heated in recent weeks. A slight reduction in bills has now been promised, but the essential dilemma remains - how can power be both affordable and good for the environment? In India, the problem does not exist. There, green energy is invariably cheaper than coal and gas. The situation presents a massive opportunity for Greenko Group, which specialises in renewable power across the subcontinent. At 148p, the shares offer real growth potential over the next year and beyond.[…] However, there is still an enormous power shortage. The country has to import coal and gas from places such as Australia and South Africa, prices are high and transportation is unwieldy.Renewable energy is different. Locally produced, it is pretty straightforward and reliable once it is up and running. And the power is sold not on the basis that it is green but that it is well priced. Greenko focuses on hydro power and wind, with an element of biomass energy, too. Its hydro plants are located in the north of India, supplied by melting snow from the Himalayas, and in the south of the country, where monsoons are particularly intense.[…] The group sells its energy to a mix of state-owned Indian utilities and the private sector, including an international IT park with big names such as Accenture and IBM. Last week, Greenko unveiled half-year profits up 151 per cent to £8.7 million for the six months to September 30. Brokers expect full-year profits of £12.4 million to March 2014, surging to £33 million in 2015.[…]

title: 'Cleaner' coal gets renewed attention
news: Take dirty old coal and smash it. Add water to make mud. Pour the mud into a 2,700-degree oven filled with pure oxygen. Voila - the coal mixture is transformed into a much cleaner-burning gas. "This is where the magic takes place," said Tom Berry, former chief engineer at the $650 million prototype electric power plant here, which uses the process to light up nearby WALT DISNEY World. "This technology is amazing in what it will do down the road." That is what the Bush administration is counting on. Spurred by the coal industry and senators from key coal-producing states, it proposes to spend $2 billion over the next decade on so-called clean-coal technology. That is atop $1.8 billion in federal outlays since 1985, made largely at the behest of lawmakers from coal states. With money from states and utilities tossed in, $5.4 billion has been spent on clean coal so far.At heart, it is an effort to give an environmental makeover to cheap and abundant coal, which when burned normally spews pollution that causes smog, acid rain and global warming.[…]

title: Not smart!
news: […] As Tom Adams and Kathy Hamilton pointed out on this page on Thursday, the notion of a smart grid covers both ideological thrusts - such as the promotion of electric cars - as well as attempts to compensate for previous policy disasters, such as the promotion of energy storage related to the proliferation of heavily subsidized and inefficient wind and solar projects. […] Technology will obviously continue to shape the city, but the dangers of "overspecification," that is inflexible topdown design, are highlighted in a recent pamphlet, "Against the smart city," by New York based urban designer Adam Greenfield. The pamphlet examines three cities that were planned in minute detail, with predictably problematic results: New Songdo in South Korea, MasdarCity in the United Arab Emirates, and a settlement in Portugal called PlanIT Valley.[…] Mr. Greenfield does a wonderful job of explaining the manifest shortcomings and dangers of the overdesigned smart city, but his critique ultimately flies off the rapid transit rails because he sees these urban monstrosities as an offshoot of the "neoliberal agenda," a Chomskyan phrase that speaks volumes about anybody who uses it. His suggestion that grand plans of city control are intimately related to the promotion of free trade, privatization, lower taxes and deregulation is not just muddled, it's upside down. This "neoliberal agenda" is in fact a response to the economic destruction wreaked by trade barriers, high taxes, and overregulation, not an ideological master plan to conquer the world. Privatization of municipal services isn't a plot to maximize shareholder value at others' expense; it's a response to lousy public provision. Mr. Greenfield conflates this vague neoliberal agenda, which is promoted by unnamed "ideologues," with the alleged dark powers of the companies involved in providing smart-city services, such as IBM, Cisco Systems, Siemens AG, Samsung, Intel, Philips and Hitachi. Corporations are certainly to be feared when they get into bed with government but they have no political power except through government. These companies are ultimately merely responding to demand. The problem is the kind of demand generated by governments. If governments want armaments and surveillance, the private sector will supply it. It will also offer innovation that makes governments more deadly or intrusive, but the fundamental problem lies not with the technology, but its potential abuse by the state. Also, the idea of a city filled with efficiency-checking sensors and carbon footprint monitors is much more closely linked with the neosocialist agenda of sustainability than anything "neoliberal."[…]

title: Labor plan falls short on emissions, say analysts
news: PRIME Minister Julia Gillard's climate policy may help to deliver more gas-fired electricity and more zero-emission power from solar and windfarms. But it won't be enough for the country to meet its own emission-reduction targets, investors and analysts say. [...] CITIGROUP analyst Elaine Prior said the planned constraints on new coal-fired power stations could encourage building gas-fired plants.

title: Oil drills may replace dogsleds with Greenland thaw; High crude prices make it more feasible to go after reserves under the ice
news: In Greenland, locals hunt reindeer for food and use dogsleds to traverse the ice sheet. Soon, they may be working on offshore rigs and counting their money. Oil companies have begun looking for crude deposits off the west coast and Joern Skov Nielsen, deputy director of Greenland's Bureau of Minerals and Petroleum, said there may be more oil there than the entire past production of the North Sea. That's about 50 billion barrels, according to figures from Norway and Britain, the region's biggest producers. […] While geologists have known that Greenland had crude reserves since oil was discovered seeping out of rocks along the coast in the 1990s, the ice surrounding much of the world's largest island made getting to it unfeasible. With crude prices up 63 per cent in the past year to about $103 a barrel and the ice melting, the reserves have become potentially more lucrative. Last October, Greenland's government awarded exploration licences to CHEVRON Corp., Exxon Mobil Corp. and Husky Energy Inc. The companies are collecting seismic data to determine the best drilling locations. Given the icy conditions, oil production may cost as much as $46 per barrel, according to Oil and Gas Journal. While exploration is complicated by icebergs as tall as 15-storey buildings, global warming is helping. […] Those reserves would represent a greater challenge because the water freezes into pack ice that can be three metres thick and thaws enough to allow ships through for one month a year at most. Though global warming may make that oil accessible at some point, "the technology actually doesn't exist" yet to explore through the ice, said Hans Kristian Olsen, chief executive officer of NunaOil, Greenland's state-owned oil company. […]

title: THE HECKLER
news: [...]Coal sinks to new depths JUST as the miners here campaigned vigorously against the resources tax, so the US coal industry has been making its presence felt in the American media, buying ad time on cable networks to tout coal as a clean and safe energy source that creates jobs. The Coal Cares website takes the issue to new heights. Having highlighted the dangers of letting homes generate completely unregulated low-quality solar power, they turn their attention to wind turbines, which kill unwary birds. "Exploding bats are also a growing problem, as vibrations from turbines causes the rodents' lungs to burst apart in mid-flight," the site cautions. A number of energy companies, including BHP Billiton and CHEVRON, according to the green-tinged site, allegedly declare they want to make asthma-related bullying a thing of the past. Showing its social concern, the website offers the Coal Cares(TM) Puff-Puff(TM) line of free novelty-themed inhalers - from "My First Inhaler", to "Twilight", and "the Bieber". These funky designs will transform the inhaler into a cool, fun, stylish accessory for asthmatic children of any age, Coal Cares proclaims. "Pulmonarily-challenged youngsters will now be able to tell uncaring bullies to 'suck it'.[...]

title: PNG gas pipeline takes step closer
news: ANOTHER phase in the Papua New Guinea gas pipeline project was wrapped up yesterday with the delivery of the final environmental impact statement to Environment Australia. Project operator CHEVRON Services Australia Pty Ltd said the federal government department had 42 days in which to recommend to Resources and Energy Minister Senator Warwick Parer that environmental approval be granted for the Australian leg of the project.  The proposed multibillion-dollar pipeline will pump gas from the Kubutu gas fields in Papua New Guinea to Townsville and possibly further south to Gladstone. "We are very pleased with the progress of the environmental approvals for the project," said project director Dr John Powell. The Queensland Department of State Development also received a copy of the EIS.

title: the saturday essayThe water crunch is primarily our problem
news: Food inflation is back in the headlines and as usual the source is water. In 2007 the Australian wheat and rice crop was almost wiped out by drought, coinciding with low rainfall across Canada and Europe. Global wheat prices doubled and Sam's Club in the US began to ration rice. This year Russia is set to lose a quarter of its wheat yield to drought and the floods in Pakistan will cause a $1bn loss of crops.   With the supply of water fixed, populations rising steadily and extreme weather more frequent, the risk of a water crunch is very real.  We simply can't allow this to happen. We are  the world's most important industry, employing a third of the population. And when it comes to water, the food industry is the key player. Agriculture uses 70% of the world's fresh water. According to the International Water Management Institute, it takes 70 times more water to produce the food we eat compared with our other domestic needs, including drinking, cooking, bathing and cleaning.  This isn't just farming's concern; we all share in the consequences. London is designated a "seriously water-stressed" region and the north west is now subject to a hosepipe ban.  According to Walter Todd, PEPSICO's vice president of sustainability for Europe: "In 15 to 20 years, companies in the UK that don't act will only be able to take so much water to run their operations. They may have their hours shortened or could be shut down." […] Joanne Denney-Finch [the author here] is chief executive of IGD

title: Chinese companies' back door to the U.S. stock market; Reverse mergers raise questions over who should protect investors
news: It was the hot new thing on Wall Street - one of those exotic investments that seem to promise untold riches for the lucky few. And, like so many hot new things, it went cold fast. Such was the fabulous stock-market flameout of a company called Rino International, an untested enterprise that, until recently, would have raised nary an eyebrow in the United States. But over the last few years, Rino International and scores of other young Chinese companies slipped into the U.S. stock market through the back door. Rino's American stockholders later lost hundreds of millions of dollars when accusations surfaced that the company had manipulated its books. All told, investors' losses on these Chinese ventures have stretched into the billions.[…] For international investors, Rino, whose name means ''green promise'' in Chinese, was an alluring equation: ''China'' plus ''environment'' equals profit. Like many other Chinese companies, Rino faced obstacles in borrowing money from the state-owned banks. It also confronted hurdles in going public in the Shanghai or Shenzhen markets, where share prices have gyrated wildly.[…] Mr. Little himself was so enamored with Rino that rather than take payment in cash, he asked for shares in Rino. The bankers' pitch seemed irresistible, he recalls, all the more because several big institutions, including BANK OF AMERICA, were investing in Rino, too. ''They gave me a book and it had the two most exciting words you could hear: 'China' and 'pollution,''' Mr. Little said. ''They had audited financials, big-name lawyers and BANK OF AMERICA.'' In October 2007, soon after Rino acquired Jade Mountain, BANK OF AMERICA and about a dozen other investors, including Alder Capital, a hedge fund, bought Rino shares in what is known as a private placement. That sale raised $25 million. Before long, Rino stock was trading on the over-the-counter market for about $4.50 a share.[…] ''You cannot compare the capitalist system in the U.S. with the capitalist system in China,'' he said. BANK OF AMERICA, another early Rino investor, declined to comment.[…]

title: Exxon, biotech pioneer to develop algae fuel
news: After years of hesitation, the world's largest oil company by market value is jumping into the primordial soup of biofuels research. Exxon Mobil Corp. said yesterday it would spend $600-million (U.S.) in a partnership with Synthetic Genomics Inc., a closely-held firm led by biotech superstar J. Craig Venter, to develop fuel from algae. [...]The announcement marks a major turning point for the Texas oil giant - and for the biofuels industry. For years, Exxon stood by as rivals such as BP, CHEVRON Corp. and ConocoPhillips Co. tinkered with different ways of producing ethanol and biodiesel, the most popular forms of fuel derived from renewable sources. Most of these companies' widely-publicized efforts centred around producing these fuels from vegetable waste matter instead of edible crops such as soybean and corn. In 2007, at a major energy conference here, Exxon chief executive officer Rex Tillerson reiterated his company's role as first and foremost a crude oil and natural gas company and added that it didn't plan to invest in biofuels with today's technology. But Exxon at the time was already pondering its move. [...]

title: In granting loans, more banks turn green; Major lenders less willing to finance projects that have environmental risks
news: The blasting off of mountaintops to reach coal in the U.S. Appalachia region or the churning out of millions of tons of carbon dioxide to extract oil from sand in Alberta are among environmentalists' biggest industrial irritants. But they are also legal and lucrative. For a growing number of banks, however, that does not seem to matter.After years of legal entanglements arising from environmental messes and increased scrutiny of banks that finance the dirtiest industries, several large commercial lenders are taking a stand on industry practices that they regard as risky to their reputations and bottom lines.In the most recent example,  in 7, the U.S. banking giant Wells Fargo noted the ''considerable attention and controversy'' surrounding mountaintop-removal mining and said that its involvement with companies engaged in it was ''limited and declining.'' The bank was a small player in the sector, representing about $78 million in bond and loan financing for such companies from 2008 to last April, according to data compiled by the Rainforest Action Network, an environmental group tracking the issue. But the policy shift by Wells Fargo follows others over the past two years, including actions by Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, BANK OF AMERICA and Citibank to increase scrutiny of lending to companies involved in mountaintop removal or to end the lending altogether.[…] A report published in May by the Sierra Club and the Rainforest Action Network estimated that nine banks were the primary lenders for companies engaged in mountaintop-removal mining in Appalachia, and that they had provided nearly $4 billion in loans and bond underwriting to those companies - chiefly Massey Energy, Patriot Coal, and Alpha Natural Resources - since 2008. The Rainforest Action Network, which has headed a campaign to highlight financial institutions with connections to the mining, said  last month that the policy shifts were chipping away at the financing. Citing Bloomberg data, for example, the group noted that BANK OF AMERICA - listed as recently as 2008 as one of the ''syndication agents'' on a $175 million revolving line of credit to Massey Energy - had eliminated that and all other connections to the company. […]

title: Red letter day as Australia Post goes to top of the corps
news: Australia Post has emerged as the clear winner in this year's survey of corporate reputation, shrugging off the challenge to its core business from low-cost rivals email and the Internet. Banks and mining companies were surprise improvers in the Sydney Morning Herald's 2001 Good Reputation Index survey of Australia's largest 100 corporations.But Australia Post's innovative approach to its staff, its treatment of the environment and its business and community relations have won it top spot. The company's managing director, Graeme John, welcomed the findings. "This result confirms that continuous improvement and benchmarking ourselves against world's best corporations rather than other postal services or government business enterprises is the correct approach," he said.[…] Last year's winner, Leighton Holdings, came 11th, while Holden, Queensland Rail, Ford and Telstra retained their positions in the top 10. FIRMS OF REPUTE. Australia Post. Westpac. Fosters. Holden. Queensland Rail. Alcoa. IBM[…]

title: I.B.M. Planning a Scaled-Down New Headquarters
news: I.B.M. is moving forward with plans to abandon its palatial headquarters in Armonk in favor of something next door that is smaller but more serviceable by contemporary standards. Preliminary plans indicate that the building will be as high-tech as the company itself.[…] Tomorrow, I.B.M. is expected to submit its final environmental impact statement, the first step in getting site plan approval for the project. It also seeks a special use permit to construct a helipad that will operate until 9 P.M. Mr. Beerman said the construction of the new headquarters was expected to cost from $60 million to $70 million and take two years to complete.[…]

title: As Polar Ice Turns to Water, Dreams of Treasure Abound
news: It seems harsh to say that bad news for polar bears is good for Pat Broe. Mr. Broe, a Denver entrepreneur, is no more to blame than anyone else for a meltdown at the top of the world that threatens Arctic mammals and ancient traditions and lends credibility to dark visions of global warming. Still, the newest study of the Arctic ice cap -- finding that it faded this summer to its smallest size ever recorded -- is beginning to make Mr. Broe look like a visionary for buying this derelict Hudson Bay port from the Canadian government in 1997. […] With major companies and nations large and small adopting similar logic, the Arctic is undergoing nothing less than a great rush for virgin territory and natural resources worth hundreds of billions of dollars. […] ''Norway's importance to the United States in terms of our national energy policy is increasing with every passing year,'' Mr. Ong said. But the United States' interests go beyond that -- too far beyond for many in Norway. In September, the opening of frontier areas in the Barents and Norwegian Seas emerged as a central issue in elections that brought a leftist coalition to power, with some coalition members favoring a ban on Arctic oil and gas exploration in environmentally sensitive areas. And besides supporting Snohvit, Mr. Ong, a former energy executive, has stepped into disputes between Norway and […] In private, Norwegian officials welcome the heft of the United States in its negotiations with Russia. Norway is eager to resolve the territorial dispute so that some order, and Norwegian drilling expertise and environmental standards, can be imposed on Arctic exploration. Because as large as Snohvit is, it is dwarfed by a far bigger gas field to the east in Russian waters. That field, called Shtokman, is being developed by Gazprom, Russia's gas behemoth. In September, Gazprom selected five companies -- Statoil and Norsk Hydro from Norway, Total from France and CHEVRON and ConocoPhillips -- as finalists in a search for partners to develop Shtokman, in the Barents Sea, 350 miles north of Russia's Kola Peninsula. The development costs are estimated at $15 billion to $20 billion. The field is reported to hold more than double all of Canada's gas reserves. […]

title: US FOOD GIANTS FIGHT SUGAR AND PEANUT GROWERS' SUBSIDIES
news: KEYWORD-HIT US food giants fight sugar and peanut growers' subsidies Food producers came out really hard because they smelled blood CONFECTIONERS, COCA-COLA, environmental crusaders and political conservatives. Odd bedfellows, they're waging a common war on two of US agriculture's most entrenched federal beneficiaries: sugar and peanut growers. After decades of enjoying a government-sheltered market and higher prices, the farmers find themselves on the defensive in a fierce lobbying battle on Capitol Hill. ""It's big food against the farmers," said Dalton Yancey, a lobbyist for the sugar growers, who are searching for compromises that might stave off elimination of their programme. Both sides are hiring lobbying firms, lawyers and public relations consultants. That there is any doubt about the outcome is a sign of the new political climate in Washington. […] The fierce assault against the programmes hinges on three arguments. The food giants such as M and M Mars, COCA-COLA and Nabisco say the government programmes artificially inflate commodity prices, making their products more expensive for consumers. Conservatives argue price supports are contrary to the Republican Party's free-market philosophy. And environmentalists argue the sugar programme has resulted in government-subsidised pollution of Florida's Everglades. […]

title: Laptop may soon tell what it smells
news: […] IN THE next five years, computers will translate baby talk, allowing parents to understand their wailing children. The machines will also predict natural disasters and allow consumers to feel the texture of clothing items bought online, according to IBM. Each December, IBM releases & The Next 5 in 5& the IT company's predictions of innovations that will change people's lives in the next five years. Previous predictions included biometric passwords, cellphone wallets and banking, and that technologies the size of atoms would address the world's environmental problems.[…] Computers will & smell& within five years by sensing the presence of certain molecules. This has numerous applications such as detecting pollution or the onset of illness through & analysing the millions of molecules in your breath& IBM said.[…]

title: With Colorado Projects, Companies Hope to Learn From Mistakes of the Past
news: Oil shale has never made an American company more than a nickel or two; quite a few, in fact, have lost countless millions over the last century trying to cook oil out of the rock. R. Glenn Vawter, who has worked as an executive for many of the losers, knows all that only too well. […] But there are plenty of good reasons no one has ever come up with a profitable, environmentally acceptable method for extracting oil from shale. Not only were the previous efforts too expensive and too energy- intensive to compete with conventional oil resources, they also laid waste to the land, produced lots of air pollution and threatened scarce groundwater in one of the driest regions of the country. So it is no surprise that Shell, CHEVRON and Mr. Vawter's EGL Resources, the three companies that won the 160-acre leases, say they are going to go slow with their experiments before they begin considering commercial production of synthetic fuel. […] The companies hope that approach -- known as in situ, or on site -- will be more efficient and produce fewer carbon dioxide emissions than previous efforts, although some of their experts acknowledge that a method still must be developed to capture and store carbon emissions to ensure that shale oil does not become a large producer of greenhouse gases. […] CHEVRON's approach is still a work in progress. One possible method would use injection wells to circulate hot carbon-dioxide-rich gases through the fractured shale formation. For efficiency purposes, the heated gases from initial chemical reactions would be reused repeatedly to help process new shale. CHEVRON is hoping to aim at smaller portions of shale than Shell to minimize the environmental footprint, and use shale formations themselves as walls to avert seepage into groundwater through monitoring techniques developed at Los Alamos. title: Reversing the Flow of Oil
news: HOUSTON -- The Singapore-flagged tanker BW Zambesi set sail with little fanfare from the port of Galveston, Tex., on 7 30, loaded with crude oil destined for South Korea. But though it left inauspiciously, the ship's launch was another critical turning point in what has been a half-decade of tectonic change for the American oil industry. The 400,000 barrels the tanker carried represented the first unrestricted export of American oil to a country outside of North America in nearly four decades. The Obama administration insisted there was no change in energy trade policy, perhaps concerned about the reaction from environmentalists and liberal members of Congress with midterm elections coming. But many energy experts viewed the launch as the curtain raiser for the United States' inevitable emergence as a major world oil exporter, an improbable return to a status that helped make the country a great power in the first half of the 20th century. […] Many environmentalists say fracking operations endanger water supplies or create other hazards, including air pollution. Ramping up exports of fossil fuels, critics will surely note, is inconsistent with the Obama administration's push for a global climate deal. […] But the wording of the Commerce Department ruling means oil producers can potentially export much more than just condensates, since the department said it covered all crude oil that is processed through a distillation unit. Basic distillation can occur at the wellhead at minimal cost, and the new interpretation is likely to unleash investment in basic processing of oil in the field to meet the export requirements. ''It was another crack in a process that is historic,'' said Eric G. Lee, a commodities strategist at Citigroup. […]
