Hundreds of millions of dollars are at stake. The Exxon Mobil Corporation and four other companies say Unocal's patent is invalid because it was designed to mirror California clean-fuel requirements, forcing other refiners to pay simply for abiding by the state's rules. […] Critics say a Unocal victory would bring higher prices at the pump. A jury in 1997 told rival refiners to pay Unocal 5.75 cents for every gallon of gasoline that was produced in 1996 and infringed on Unocal's patent. The CHEVRON Corporation, Texaco Inc., BP Amoco and the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company joined Exxon Mobil in the Supreme Court appeal.

title: Economic slump hitting EU carbon markets
news: The price of carbon allowances under the EU's emissions trading scheme hit an 18-month low in October due to the economic downturn However, the market is not expected to collapse, due to the tight emission limits under the EUETS from 2013 onwards. Carbon markets are starting to feel the impact of the gathering recession. Demand for allowances to meet targets under the EU emissions trading scheme (EUETS) is expected to drop significantly over the next two years as industry lowers production. The price of carbon credits has already dropped in anticipation.  [...]  IDEAcarbon's analysis was echoed by reports from Deutsche Bank and CITIGROUP. Deutsche Bank has lowered its EUETS total emissions forecasts for 2008-12 by 46 million tonnes of CO2 a year, although it only expects industrial production to drop until 2010. CITIGROUP expects the price of allowances to drop as low as EUR12 (pounds 9.80) in the short term due to lower demand, but to rise to EUR25 (pounds 20.40) by 2012. [...]

title: River of change that became a trickle; CARBON TRADING
news: Canberra's compromise may offer too little incentive to investors, writes Clancy Yeates. While the political brawl over Kevin Rudd's carbon pollution reduction scheme dominates the headlines, accumulated changes have watered down much of its original impact on heavy polluters. [...] CITIGROUP's carbon analyst, Elaine Prior, says investors who want action on climate change are in the minority, but carbon risk was clearly on the horizon. "I think that industry ought to have been aware for quite a number of years that it was quite possible that there'd be some sort of carbon constraint coming," she says. [...] Citi's Prior forecasts most companies' pretax profits will be affected by less than 4 per cent, and often less than 1 per cent once free permits are taken into account. "For most companies, the assistance being given means that the impact on company profits will be relatively small," she says. "I think it's designed with the view that the transition is more likely to gather pace post-2020 than before 2020." [...]

title: Climate Change Initiatives - The Selfish Green - The World Of Green Initiatives Is Opening Up To Investors - Whether Green Or Sceptic - As Banks Create Climate Change-related Financial Products And Indices. Silvia Pavoni Reports
news: Never get emotional about an investment. That is the golden rule for any institution or individual approaching an investment decision. Yet there is an investment area where both logic and emotions have recently come rushing to the fore: climate change initiatives. Climate change has, in the past couple of years, received stronger and stronger attention by policy makers and consumers. Green lobbies aim to create an emotional link to carbon reduction and energy self-sufficiency. Governments encourage rebalancing of energy consumption, too - for example, the UK government has launched an online CO2 calculator so people can work out their carbon footprint and develop a personalised action plan to cut their carbon emissions. [...] Climate change-related financial products are now in abundant supply. Structured products, funds and indices have been put together by many of the providers, from the big international players to the smaller conservative banks. Talking to the experts, it seems that anything related to climate change is largely outperforming the MSCI World Index. Headline-grabbing returns include Credit Suisse's Global Warming Index (up 400% on the MSCI since 2002), HSBC's Global Climate Change Index (70% higher than MSCI since 2004) or even social investment specialist KDL Index, which outperformed the S&P/CITIGROUP BMI World Index by 40% in 2007. The explanation behind such performances lies not only in the policies supporting climate change, but also in the understanding of how their development affects companies. [...]

title: Liberia; Best Contract Ever - Block 13 Nets U.S.$50 Million Upfront, NOCAL Seeks Approval
news: Oil and gas discovery in Liberia bumped into premature hullabaloo with particular attention clamoring over the manner and form that suspected wells of the coveted natural resource were negotiated and handed over to potential investors. [...] Block 13 which had been in the center of controversy and nearly presumed to have been a giveaway has now turned out to be a product of the most lucrative contract ever, with a colossal sum of upfront US$50m signature fees along with other goodies announced. [...] At a MICAT press briefing yesterday, NOCAL Chief Executive Officer, Dr. Randolph McClain, disclosed that renegotiated Block 13 based on various financial provisions of the contract, US$50m is to be received by Government immediately upon ratification and printing into handbills. [...]According to the NOCAL boss the contract has been submitted to President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf following a lengthy period of negotiations between NOCAL, the Canadian Overseas Petroleum Ltd (COPL) and ExxonMobil.[...] NOCAL says the contract places premium on the protection of our environment as more stringent requirements for environmental and social impact assessments and environmental and social management programs are provided for at every step of the oil exploration and development process.

title: S&P launches index of eco-friendly firms
news: Standard & Poor's has launched an index for investors seeking exposure to environmentally responsible investment strategies. The S&P Global Eco index will provide diversified liquid exposure to 30 of the largest publicly-listed companies operating in ecology-related industries. Steven Goldin, vice-president of portfolio service at S&P, said the index would help investors focus their investment decisions on potential environment-related economic benefits. In order to be eligible for inclusion in the index, companies must have a listing on a developed market exchange and a market capitalisation of AGBP500m. Companies must also have a three-month average daily trading value of more than AGBP1m and be a current member of one of the S&P Global Clean Energy, S&P Global Timber & Forestry, S&P Global Water or the S&P/CITIGROUP Global Environmental Services Sector indices.

title: CHEVRON, Osaka in $10bn gas deal
news: CHEVRON has placed all of its gas from the $11 billion Gorgon LNG project with the announcement of a 25-year deal with Osaka Gas for 1.5 million tonnes a year. The deal is similar to that signed with Chubu Electric in late November. Both are estimated to be worth about $10 billion. In October, CHEVRON announced that its foundation customer for Gorgon would be Tokyo Gas, which is contracting to take 1.2 million tonnes a year for 25 years. The rest of CHEVRON's half-share in the planned 10 million tonnes annual output from Gorgon will be placed internally, within CHEVRON, with the expectation it will be marketed in North America. […] The Gorgon project, based on Barrow Island off the West Australian coast, south of the North-West-Shelf gas project, is awaiting formal environmental approvals, expected in February, and undertaking extensive front-end engineering and design studies in advance of a final investment decision by the three partners by the middle of next year. The plant, currently configured as two production trains, is scheduled to be shipping in 2010. […]

title: PNG-Qld pipeline start moves closer
news: THE massive Papua New Guinea to Queensland natural gas pipeline moved one step closer to fruition yesterday with the signing of agreements to supply gas for the project. […] The participants include Exxon/Mobil, CHEVRON, Oil Search, Santos and Orogen as the major resource owners. The $US3.5 billion ($A6 billion) pipeline project will be provided with gas volumes of up to 600 million standard cu ft a day to be available for sale to the Queensland market for a period of 30 years. PNG gas project director John Powell welcomed the agreement and called on all stakeholders to work together to bring the project to fruition. "This agreement is an important step for the project as it provides the volumes required to underpin the market and will bring significant greenhouse benefits to Queensland," he said. Dr Powell also said the project was now looking forward to the release of the Queensland Government's cleaner energy strategy so contracts could be finalised with customers. The strategy is expected to outline which energy sources including coal, gas and coal seam methane will be used for the state's power needs. […] He said the fact the Federal Government was yet to formulate a greenhouse policy to comply with the Kyoto agreement on greenhouse emissions was a major concern. […]

title: Coming clean on climate change; THE ISSUE - GOING GREEN
news: It's risky business when we don't put our money where our mouths are on warming, writes Leon Gettler. HALF of Australia's biggest companies are risking cost blow-outs, an increased regulatory burden and reputational damage from climate change, according to an international report. [...] It does not name any of the high-risk companies. But a report from CITIGROUP released last month found that Australia's 10 biggest greenhouse gas emitters were BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, Bluescope Steel, Qantas, AGL, Alumina, Orica, Santos, Origin Energy and Boral. [...] The CITIGROUP report warns that investors will have to wait until there is more detail on specific emissions caps and permit allocations. "We think the devil is in the detail in terms of actual permit distribution, and thus financial impact on individual companies," CITIGROUP analyst Elaine Prior said.

title: World Economic Forum warns of growing economic risks
news: HIGHLIGHT: Deteriorating fiscal positions, a hard landing in China, a collapse in asset prices, gaps in global governance and issues relating to natural resources and climate are just some of the pivotal challenges facing the world this year. Deteriorating fiscal positions, a hard landing in China, a collapse in asset prices, gaps in global governance and issues relating to natural resources and climate are just some of the pivotal challenges facing the world this year, according to a report released by the World Economic Forum (WEF). Published in cooperation with CITIGROUP, Marsh & McLennan Companies, Swiss Re, Zurich Financial Services and the Wharton School Risk Centre, the report - Global Risks 2009 - predicts that government spending to support ailing financial institutions is threatening the already precarious fiscal positions of countries such as the US, UK, France, Italy, Spain and Australia. [...] In addition to the immediate risks stemming from the financial crisis, the report also cautions against ignoring interconnected risks related to natural resources and climate change. However, according to Hoffman the immediate risk of the financial crisis has meant that government's risk losing the long-term perspective on risks such as climate change. "You may have short-term crisis concerns but because you have short-term concerns the long-term risks remain," he says. "You need to have a long-term perspective and balance those risks."

title: Nuclear hopefuls want some help
news: A STRING of companies involved in developing nuclear technologies are pushing the Federal Government to introduce financial incentives for research aimed at more efficient nuclear power generation and waste management.  The calls come after Prime Minister John Howard at the weekend said the Federal Government would provide ''immediate support'' to help Australia participate in the development of new-generation nuclear reactors. […] Mr White, who is also chairman of international environmental waste management provider Global Renewables, refused to comment on whether the incentives for developers of nuclear technologies should be on a par with, or exceed, government support for gas exploration. However, he said the biggest incentive for nuclear R&D would come in the form of a carbon trading scheme. ''There is only one way nuclear power will ever be economic in Australia and that is through the proper pricing of carbon-based greenhouse gas emissions,'' he said. ''Both political parties are committed to introducing an emissions trading system.'' Another company in line to secure support from the government is Sydney-based nuclear R&D firm NuPower-Green. […] Philip Lavers, one of the directors of NuPower-Green, said the company was in talks with British Nuclear Fuels plc with a view to undertaking joint research. […] ''We are at a very early stage of development,'' he said. ''Thorium and uranium companies will be the Exxons and CHEVRONs of the world in the next 20 years, I'm convinced of that.''But we're not talking about three months or three years of R&D spend here, we're talking about 15-year programs.'' […]

title: Desal trial to benefit parks, gardens
news: SA Water is in talks to use water from a pilot desalination plant to keep parks and gardens alive in the southern suburbs, a parliamentary inquiry into the $9.5 million project has been told. State Parliament's Public Works Committee yesterday heard evidence from SA Water executives about details of the temporary pilot plant, to be set up at Port Stanvac to test technology and study environmental impacts for the planned main $1.1 billion plant, on the same site. The pilot plant is expected to be located on land owned by Exxon-Mobil at Port Stanvac, the ``preferred site'' for the main plant.[...]

title: Polluting companies warned to clean up
news: COMPANIES are likely to be required to cut their carbon dioxide emissions further and faster than many expect and the shelter offered by any free permits to pollute may be less than they hoped and quickly phased out, analysts say. [...] CITIGROUP analysts say Australia's international trade-exposed, high-polluting industries could receive transitional assistance when an emissions trading scheme, or ETS, is launched here in 2010. [...] CITIGROUP said corporate complacency was ``fading fast'', especially given scientific warnings that climate change was happening faster than the rate projected by the UN's climate advisers, bringing greater political pressure on governments to act. ``We believe there is no longer a basis for complacency by either companies or investors,'' CITIGROUP analysts said. ``Investors who think `it's all right, government won't do anything to hurt industry so I don't need to worry about it with my investments' should recognise government must balance the challenges of addressing the climate problem as well as specific industries' concerns,'' CITIGROUP said. [...] CITIGROUP said: ``Keeping alive the `clean coal' concept is important to the coal industry's 'social licence to operate'.'' CITIGROUP listed companies with the largest emissions exposure. BHP Billiton, for example, in 2006 emitted about 51.8 million tonnes of greenhouse gas. That almost matched the entire emissions of Switzerland which were 53.6 million in 2005.

title: Failed Doha Round, climate change key risks for Asia; Participants also view widening income gap, rising liquidity as hazards
news: (SINGAPORE) Asian business and political leaders see the failed trade talks of the Doha Round, climate change, the widening income gap and the rising liquidity in the financial markets as key risks to Asia's prosperity. Neville Isdell, chairman and CEO of The Coca-Cola Company, USA yesterday warned that the flip side of globalisation has been a resurgence of economic nationalism. He was speaking at the plenary session on 'Global Risks: Managing Threats to Asia's Prosperity' at the World Economic Forum in Singapore. [...] Climate change was also seen as a key risk to the sustainable development of Asia. Participants felt that both the government and businesses have to play a part in tackling environmental problems. [...]

title: ExxonMobil wins US BOEM's fourth deep Gulf permit
news: New Orleans--ExxonMobil took honors March 22 for the fourth deepwater permit issued by US regulators this year, having been previously approved for a deepwater Gulf of Mexico well that had been permitted before the 2010 deepwater moratorium but had not yet been spudded when the drilling ban was issued after the BP Macondo blowout and spill. The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement said it considers this permit a "new" well because a rig was on location, but work was suspended when the moratorium was issued.[...]

title: ETS will give to some, but take from many
news: Company earnings could fall if the federal government's emissions trading scheme (ETS) passes through parliament later this week. The coal, aviation and steel industries are likely to be hit hardest. The impact of the scheme has pushed companies to lobby for generous compensation arrangements to limit the costs, but they may not be enough. Australia's biggest carbon emitters are BHP Billiton, Qantas and Rio Tinto. [...] However, not everyone's worried about the introduction of the ETS. For most companies, the cost would be relatively small and be passed on to their customers, CITIGROUP Investment Research director Elaine Prior said. "Even before the changes that were made yesterday, I reckoned that for most companies the impact was significantly less than 4 per cent of earnings and sometimes only a fraction of 1 per cent even for companies in those emissions-intensive industries" she said. [...]

title: [News Focus Viagra vs. Working Out
news: […] Viagra is not for everyone. It is intended for use only by male patients'' who have erectile problems. It does not cure erectile dysfunction but is a treatment for such a symptom, according to its manufacturer PFIZER. It is not a tonic.[…] The marketing of Viagra is certainly a good news for men who used to droop with shame before their wives, as its effect has been well proven by many people, including former U.S. presidential candidate Bob Dole, who visited Seoul to promote the pill several months ago. It may also be good news for some animals like snakes, badgers and frogs which are eaten to increase stamina, and the number of men who go on the so-called tonic tour'' to Southeast Asian countries in search of tonic foods may decrease sharply.[…]

title: UK's Centrica secures 300 MW more baseload power from Drax plant
news: Centrica, which owns Britain's biggest energy retailer British Gas, has signed an agreement with Western Europe's largest coal-fired power plant, Drax, to access a further 300 MW of baseload power, Centrica said November 5. [...] The deal allows Centrica to "lock in dark green spreads that are currently being seen in the market," according to analysts at investment bank Citi. They said Drax would benefit from the certainty of selling power at predetermined prices from a coal plant during phase three of the EU emissions trading scheme, so mitigating some of the risks of carbon price fluctuations. [...]

title: Ghana; Ghanaians Raise Concerns About Safety And Security of Natural Gas
news: On 7 11, 2000, a pipeline explosion in the Niger Delta killed an estimated 250 villagers near the southern Nigerian town of Warri. This explosion occurred just miles from the Niger Delta town of Jesse, where about 1,000 people died in a similar explosion in 1998. […] As Ghana nears the completion of the West African Gas pipeline project, images of the above incidents among other happenings in the Niger Delta are getting closer to the people. This became evident at a Stakeholders meeting in Accra last Tuesday which partly discussed safety, health and environmental measures associated with the over 500 kilometre pipeline from a terminal near Lagos to Takoradi in Ghana with supplies to Cotonou in Benin, Lome in Togo and Tema in Ghana. Owned by Societe Beninoise de Gaz (BENGAZ) from Benin, Societe Togolaise de Gaz (SoToGaz) of Togo, Takoradi Power Company Limited (TAPCo), Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) of Nigeria, CHEVRON, Nigeria and Shell Overseas holdings Limited, WAPCo is to build, own, operate and transport natural gas to help solve the energy needs of the countries mentioned. […] The Deputy Director of Tema branch of the Environmental Protection Agency Lambert Faabeluon was concerned about arrangements for secondary suppliers who will transport the gas from the Tema Port to other industries that might need the gas.[…] Michelle Cowherd, an advisor on Health and Safety from CHEVRON said the company is following the guidelines from the Environmental Protection Agency on safety measures. However, the Health Environment and Safety (HES) Manager of the West African Gas Pipeline Project (WAPCo) Mr. Patrick Akwasi Yeboah appealed to opinion leaders, particularly Members of Parliament who hail from the gas pipeline area to assist in educating the people on safety measures. Speaking at the Stakeholders meeting, Mr. Akwasi Yeboah said "We are interested in protecting people, the environment, assets and our reputation." […] Yeboah said it is the goal of the company to minimize environmental impacts, protect the pipelines, equipment and other facilities.

title: Microsoft And Google In The UK's Wind Power Sector?
news: US-based technology companies  Google and  Microsoft could become the unlikely investors in the UK's wind energy sector that will breathe some life into the market. The  Financial Times reports that the two US technology companies are considering entering the UK wind power market to reduce the carbon emissions from data-centre servers[…] However, John Lynch, the head of the power group at  BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch, said that it is highly unlikely non-energy sector multinationals, such as Google and Microsoft, would take majority equity in a major offshore wind project. However, if in fact the two companies - and others like them - decide to become involved in the UK's wind power sector this would stimulate activity in a sector that needs an estimated GBP100bn in private sector investments but has suffered from reduced availability of capital for new investments, the  Financial Times notes. […]

title: Corporate America's Space Maker; Koll Development Co. Takes Cue from Clients
news: In just a couple of months, Koll Development Co. will finish up a build-to-suit office project for yet another company on the Fortune 500 list - Fluor Corp. The Dallas-based development firm beat out Hillwood to build Fluor's 120,000-sq.-ft. world headquarters in Las Colinas, adding to an already impressive stable of corporate clients such as CITIGROUP and FedEx. […] Build-to-suit activity represents about 50 percent of KDC'S overall business, said Tobin Grove, the firm's president. For example, over the past 18 months, KDC tackled projects for CITIGROUP in Boise, Idaho; Louisville, Ky.; and Greensboro, N.C., completing the development of 531,000 sq. ft. of call center space in just seven months. The projects were so successful that CITIGROUP asked KDC to construct a second building on its Las Colinas campus, taking the complex to 700,000 sq. ft. - all built by KDC. […] The air distribution, combined with other sustainable and green building design, helped the buildings' design achieve certification under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design. Moreover, Intellicenter buildings will offer 25 to 50 percent more parking than conventional office buildings. […]

title: Leaders close the gap;  SPECIAL REPORT - CRI - CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY INDEX
news: […] The index shows Australian companies are finding it easier to run programs with a social impact than address issues such as the environment and climate change. Only five companies, three of which are miners, received a gold medal for environmental management scores of 90 per cent or higher: Anglo American (94.39 per cent), Astra Zeneca (96.45 per cent), BHP Billiton (94.91 per cent), Rio Tinto (94.58 per cent), Toyota Australia (100 per cent) and Westpac (100 per cent). In contrast, companies are doing better in the social impact area and there were 10 gold medallists in this category: ANZ (99.05 per cent), BHP Billiton (96.07 per cent), Energy Australia (100 per cent), Foster's (90.46 per cent), IBM Australia (94.54 per cent), Rio Tinto (92.91 per cent), Telstra (92.67 per cent), ToyotaAustralia (92.56 per cent), Unilever 94.16 per cent) and Westpac (100 per cent). Results table inside.

title: Transport technology must be tailored
news: Commuters in Sydney and Melbourne may love to berate their respective governments over the botched introduction of smartcard transit ticketing systems but it's music to the ears of Scott Belcher. As the president and chief executive of the Intelligent Transportation Society of America, a not for profit association that tries to steer the widely competing interests of the transit technology sector towards public good, Belcher is adamant Australia is on to a good thing.[…] He observes that underneath this paradox are a myriad of independent technology developers all competing for profits by trying to get their smarts - hardware, software and web - into not one but dozens of separate transport systems ranging from rail to road to water. In theory, if the systems all worked together by using data to communicate with each other, a step shift in efficiency occurs that boosts productivity and reduces pollution, a concept championed in feel-good campaigns run by juggernauts such as IBM and Google.But the reality is very different on the ground where philosophical arguments take equal if not greater precedence than those around technology. A key debate centres around the role of roads in cities, including whether continued massive investment in freeways is justified over other modes of transport.[…]

title: Garrett gives Gorgon environmental tick
news:
Work is expected to begin on Australia's biggest resources project by the end of the year after the $50billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas project won environmental approval. Federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett added 28 conditions to the Barrow Island project to protect threatened species, including quarantine requirements.
Barrow Island, off Western Australia, is an A-class nature reserve and home to 24 species, many of which are endangered. The approval was widely expected after the Government announced a $50billion, 20-year contract with PetroChina last week, and a $25billion deal with India a week before that.When asked if the Government promotion meant his approval was inevitable, Mr Garrett said he was aware of the economic size of the proposal and took this into account, as the law required him to, but was confident it would not have a significant environmental impact.The project's proponents CHEVRON, Shell and ExxonMobil are yet to give final approval for the investment, but project general manager, Colin Beckett, said he was confident the deal would go ahead. He was also confident the project could meet the new requirements.

title: Bush touts renewables, urges US to 'get off oil'
news: The renewable-energy industry still faces considerable obstacles around the world, but its future is bright because of the economic and environmental benefits that it will spawn, a host of industry and government officials said at major conference in Washington last week. President Bush, in a speech at the Washington International Renewable Energy Conference, on Wednesday, echoed the optimism that was voiced by many of the 2,900 officials and industry representatives in attendance. The issues that the renewable-energy industry is struggling with today, Bush said, will pay huge dividends decades from now. […] At one point, Bush said the US "has got to change its habits" and "get off oil." […] The promise of renewable energy is its ability to lift people up from poverty, especially in developing countries, speakers said. Agriculture Secretary Ed Schafer said a concentrated effort would provide jobs, investment, energy and income to historically poor areas. "Agriculture and rural areas are the primary contributors to renewable energy," Schafer said. "Renewable fuels provide a wonderful alternative to those tradition fuels." […] The impact that renewable energy has on climate change and greenhouse gas emissions was also extensively discussed. "Any good economist recognizes action now pays off," said Michael Muller, Germany's parliamentary state secretary. International biofuels producers said that a critical area to develop in the coming years was a set of globally recognized biofuels standards. "We need to move to standardized products," said Donald Paul, vice president of special projects for CHEVRON. […]

title: Ratings game; CORPORATE CITIZENSHIP
news: Former teacher and education adviser Laurel Grossman's reinvention as suited social activist has not been smooth. The chief executive of the reputation measurement agency RepuTex Ratings had to dig deep when business and think tanks attacked her efforts to assess the reputations of major Australian companies.[…] Recently, as the cream of Australian business filed into the hip venue Zinc in Melbourne's Federation Square to pick up the 2004 ratings, Grossman felt vindicated. These days RepuTex employs four researchers to conduct the company assessments, and collated results are sold as a $25,000 package. Australia's top 100 companies and New Zealand's top 20 are rated for social responsibility in four areas: corporate governance, environmental impact, social impact and workplace practices. The original ranking approach has been dumped in favour of a ratings system similar to that used by Standard and Poor's. (This year Westpac got AAA; while Australia Post, BHP Billiton, Energex, Hewlett-Packard, IBM, IAG, NAB, Queensland Rail and Visy Industries got a AA.)[…]

title: Approvals delay Gorgon decision
news: A FINAL investment decision on the huge Gorgon gas development off Western Australia will be made towards the end of this year, not mid-year as previously reported. Colin Beckett, the project's general manager, yesterday said the sheer volume of environmental approval assessments meant the previous target would not be met. […] Mr Beckett emphasised that the delay would not affect the project's capacity to begin LNG shipments in 2010. He also said the estimated cost of the project -- now $11 billion -- could rise substantially by the time a commitment was made by the Gorgon partners, CHEVRON (50 per cent) and ExxonMobil and Shell (25 per cent each). About 70 per cent of the project's planned 10 million tonnes a year output has been contracted to markets in Japan, the US and India. Mr Beckett said a recommendation from Western Australia's Environmental Protection Authority on the plan to put an LNG processing plant on Barrow Island -- a Class A nature reserve -- was likely to go to the WA Government in May. The Environment Minister would have until 8 to make a recommendation to the Government. Then Premier and State Development Minister Alan Carpenter would have to sign off on development plans, which are separate from environmental consents. […]

title: Big emitter group warms to Garnaut; CLIMATE CHANGE
news: Industry's peak body on climate change has backed Rudd government climate change adviser Ross Garnaut in his view that government constraints over the new multibillion-dollar carbon market should be minimised. But conservation groups have joined the electricity and natural gas industries to question whether Professor Garnaut's approach is practical. And the federal government, which is waiting for Professor Garnaut's mid-year report before setting interim greenhouse reduction targets, has made it clear his ideas do not reflect its position. […] The Australian Industry Greenhouse Network, which represents emissions-intensive industries such as mining, forestry, aluminium and cement as well as individual companies like BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, ExxonMobil, CHEVRON and Xstrata, said Professor Garnaut was right to look for the lowest cost way to reduce emissions over a long period. As revealed in The Australian Financial Review yesterday, Professor Garnaut believes the cheapest way to achieve lower greenhouse pollution is for the government to set a budget for total emissions over the next 40 years or more and then let the market determine when and how emissions are cut. Professor Garnaut also believes companies should be allowed to "borrow" from future years' emissions allocations if they think the cost of reducing emissions is likely to be lower in the future - providing the carbon market is governed by clear rules and an independent Reserve Bank-style carbon central bank. […]

title: CHEVRON plans to drill another well
news: CHEVRON USA plans to drill another exploratory well later this year off the Florida Panhandle as a possible prelude to natural gas production, a spokesman said Wednesday.[…]Two weeks ago, the U.S. Commerce Department gave Mobil Oil Co. a permit to  drill an exploratory gas well 13 miles south of Pensacola Beach. title: Shell urges Nigeria to step up battle against pipeline oil thieves

title: Beijing bid to boost cleaner energy

title: Carbon Masters eyeing overseas sales of £3.5m
news: EDINBURGH-based Carbon Masters, which advises clients on measuring and managing emissions, predicts it will achieve total international sales of £3.5 million over a five-year period as it undertakes work in South America and India and eyes a move into the US. The carbon management consultancy, which was spun out of the University of Edinburgh in 2009, said it had tracked emissions for US-based pharmaceuticals giant PFIZER at a facility in the Ecuadorian capital of Quito. title: LNG from the gas field to the kitchen: MEGAGRAPHIC - FUTURE OF LNG: SPECIAL REPORT

title: Obama to nominate climate-focused energy team
news: Obama is expected to introduce Carol Browner, who ran EPA during the Clinton administration, as his national energy adviser. It is a newly created position, heading an entity known as the "National Energy Council," which will act as a clearinghouse for energy and environmental policy. The council members will include nearly all cabinet secretaries, the national security adviser, the national economic adviser, and the chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality. It is not clear how the White House Council on Environmental Quality, or CEQ, will be folded into the new entity. Nancy Sutley, the apparent pick to head CEQ, was a top aide to Browner during the Clinton administration.  Industry representatives and environmental groups alike said that forming a new National Energy Council would help streamline policy-making. Karen Harbert, who served as an assistant energy secretary during the Bush administration, pointed to the 2005 and 2007 energy laws as good examples when a coordinating body would help. [...] Frank O'Donnell, president of Clean Air Watch, a Washington-based environmental group, said that battles between EPA, DOE, and the Interior Department could be lessened with a central policy body [...] O'Donnell said Browner was well-suited for the job given her record of environmental protection. "They do need someone pretty senior in that job," he said. "These are really first-tier issues." Industry officials also expressed support for the new energy-related shop that Browner will run. Donald Paul, a former vice president of Chevron oil company, said forming the council would give industry a better sense of what to expect.  "I think it's worth a shot," said Paul. "The current system has not been especially effective." Paul, who now runs a Washington-based consulting firm called Energy and Technology Strategies, added that a "set of coherent federal objectives" would give agencies like EPA, DOE, Interior, Agriculture, Commerce, Defense and others a better direction. "It's the nature of energy," he said. "Everyone has an interest in it."

title: CLEAN-AIR CONFUSION
news: WHEN AMENDMENTS TO THE CLEAN AIR ACT WERE ENACTED IN LATE 1990, COMPANIES braced for the worst.  Riddled with rigid command-and-control provisions, tight timetables, calls for extensive public-review proceedings, and forbidding monitoring, recordkeeping, and reporting requirements, the 700-page statute had all the ingredients of a regulatory nightmare.  Delays, litigation, political wrangling, uncertainty, and -- more than anything else -- high costs seemed inevitable.[…] THE AVALANCHE OF DOCUmentation from companies -- far more than EPA had intended -- prompted the agency to issue a white paper last 7 that clarified minimum federal requirements under the current regulation for permit applications.  A month later the agency released a supplement to its 1994 revised proposal -- "a revision of a revision," environmental managers note -- that gives states greater flexibility to build on their existing permit programs.  The supplement also provides for advance approval of many operational changes at facilities through use of flexible permits that firms could use without having to modify their current permits.The advance-approval approach has been spearheaded by INTEL Corp., which under the original regulation would have been required to apply for hundreds of permit revisions annually and endure a lengthy review process for each by state agencies and EPA.  "It was a threatening process for us," says Tim Mohin, INTEL's government-affairs manager in Washington.  In the ultra-competitive computer industry, he points out, manufacturing-process changes are routine.  "We come out with a new product every 18 months at INTEL," he says.  "Time to market is everything.  We can't afford to wait four to five months every time we make a process change." INTEL worked with EPA and state and local environmental officials to devise the flexible permit system for pilot testing at its chip-manufacturing plant in Aloha, Oreg., which is covered by Title 5.  "We agree to come up with a hard cap on emissions at the entire plant site, set up enforcement provisions to assure that we don't exceed the cap, and undertake a pollution-prevention program that will reduce emissions over time," explains Mohin.  "In exchange for that, we get preapproval of minor changes and flexibility."[…]

title: CHEVRON poised for Barrow Island CO2 coup
news: Emissions. title: WHY 8 MILLION ANIMALS FACE DEATH TO TEST YOUR TOOTHPASTE AND WASHING LIQUID
news: STEVE BOGGAN Clad in her customary white coat, the scientist carefully pulls the latex gloves up over her wrists and walks slowly towards the cage. Reaching in, she seizes one of the rabbits, cowering near the back and clamps it into a testing harness. Taking it over to a sanitised laboratory bench, Dr Tamsin Decker supervises as solution is squirted into the defenceless animal's eyes. She has done this many times before , and will watch as it's done again until the rabbit shows some side-effects: pain, irritation, bleeding perhaps, and eventually, possibly, blindness. For what cause must the animal endure such a wretched, tortured existence? Once upon a time, Dr Decker would have imagined it was to find a cure for cancer, or, at the very least, to test a compound which would relieve suffering. […] Asked whether he understands the frustration felt by some scientists over testing ingredients already agreed to be 'safe', he says: 'If you look at it from a lab or single company's point of view, to their way of thinking it may be frustrating, but to the broader benefit of all of us there is much to be gained by collecting the information. Animal testing is the last resort.' I asked Unilever, PROCTER & GAMBLE, Colgate and the Turtle Wax Corporations, manufacturers of the affected items, how they felt about their ingredients being tested under REACH. Only PROCTER & GAMBLE replied, saying it tests on animals only where required to by law and when all other options have been exhausted. Diplomatically, it pointed out that it has spent 6275 million developing alternatives to animal testing, but it didn't address my direct questioning about the frustrations of animal testing under REACH. However, I was able to gain an insight into how the chemical companies view the legislation through the eyes of a scientific consultant who advises them on how to comply with it. Fearful of speaking out openly against the European Chemicals Agency, he refused to be named, but branded REACH 'an expensive nuisance'. […]

title: A user's guide to saving the planet
news: IT'S A big deal writing a manual to save the Earth and all that lives upon her. But that's Factor 4, the ultimate planetary self-help guide to nurture environmentally aware capitalists. There's 20 handy hints for revolutionising energy productivity, 20 more for material productivity and 10 thrown in for transport. The sheer cleverness of Factor 4 is that we can live twice as well while using only half the resources we currently consume. Vive le futur. The world can bask in a bright 21st century if humanity takes heed (and slows down on the breeding). But the inescapable bad news is that we'll all burn in environmental purgatory if we don't. […] Amory B. and L. Hunter Lovins are a husband-and-wife team. She's a lawyer, sociologist, political scientist and forester. He's a consultant physicist hailed as one of the Western world's leading energy policy gurus. They are the co-founders of the Rocky Mountain Institute, a non-profit think-tank fostering resource efficiency and global security. They've been busy advising big business, ranging from BANK OF AMERICA and Mitsubishi through to major property developers, helping invent future cars and teaming up with Club of Rome member WeizsaÈcker to devise Factor 4. (This book is an official report to the Club of Rome, which arguably set the ball rolling for the sustainable development debate with its landmark 1972 report, Limits to Growth, shocking a world that had never really stopped to think it could run out. […] Unlike the Pulitzer Prize-winning Gelbspan, the Factor 4 team have not sugar-coated their pill with racy writing. What you get is their prescription for the planet, with all manner of hard-to-swallow facts and figures. It means the book is no light holiday read, but then the future without such remedies will be no picnic either. For its content rather than its style, the book is a compelling rebuff to those in denial about the threats to our planet, especially the greenhouse/ climate change scenario, the pollution load, the depletion of non-renewable resources and the loss of biodiversity, life itself.

title: Carbon trading experts try not to succumb to Copenhagen gloom
news: Carbon trading specialists are disappointed with the outcome of the Copenhagen COP 15 summit. World leaders failed to agree on any binding targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions, or on mechanisms for doing so. The Copenhagen Accord, "noted", rather than adopted by the conference, gives a framework for voluntary emissions reductions by developing countries, but what those reductions are is not even mentioned. Abyd Karmali, managing director and global head of carbon markets at BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch, told Futures and Options Intelligence on December 18 that he was not optimistic: "What concerns us is that targets outlined are aspirational as opposed to firm." He said they were "simply insufficient" to provide longevity to the market. Karmali was more optimistic about reform of the Clean Development Mechanism - the scheme established by the Kyoto Protocol under which developed country companies can earn credits to pollute more than their normal allowances by sponsoring projects in developing countries that are deemed low carbon. […] Karmali also spoke hopefully about the chances of a decision on REDD plus - a formula for achieving Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation, in which developed countries would pay poor states to preserve their forests."In the best case scenario, [politicians] may get a package adopted," he said. He added that there may also be a decision on REDD plus. "The way the last text was written, REDD plus can become a market mechanism in some countries," he said. He argued this could be a "new way to deploy capital" and an "opportunity for institutional investors".[…] Yvo de Boer, executive secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, has been quoted as saying that REDD-plus is now "oven ready".[…]

title: Abbott plan to cost WA millions THE BUDGET
news: WA will lose tens of millions of dollars in extra infrastructure spending under a Tony Abbott plan to save $1.2 billion as part of his aggressive push to cut Government spending. [...] Of Mr Abbott's savings, $300 million will come from scrapping the Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute, which Mr Rudd  launched last year as part of efforts to make coal-fired power stations clean and green. Carbon capture and storage is central to CHEVRON's massive $43 billion Gorgon gas project in which $2 billion will be spent on technology to inject C0{-2} beneath Barrow Island.[...] Prime Minister Julia Gillard, who promised her own cuts, said Mr Abbott had wrongly targeted infrastructure, which helped lift productivity and kept pressure off interest rates. On carbon capture and storage, this is an important new technology for the nation's future as we combat climate change, she said. I'm not surprised Mr Abbott would pick it for a cut, given he has been completely dismissive of the science of climate change.[...]

title: Angola; Environment Ministry And 'Fina' Seek Pollution Fighting Strategy
news: Representatives of the Angolan Ministry of Urbanisation and Environment and of petroleum firm "Fina" will meet Tuesday in Luanda to seek ways to avoid practices that damage the environment and the population's health.The information was supplied today to Angop by the national director for environment, Carlos Santos, following a gas leak on Tuesday at about 08:30 pm, during the final stage of the cleaning of the N'Zombo 41 well, operated by "Fina Petroleo de Angola", at Kitona village, district of Soyo, northern Zaire province. […] According to the Ministry official, the representatives of the above mentioned oil firm will be assigned the responsibility to organsise awareness and sensitising campaigns on the forms of prevention in similar situations. Carlos Santos announced that a team from the ministry will travel to Soyo soon, to find out the seriousness of the situation. "In case the extension of the matter proves to be more serious we could file a legal action against "Fina Petroleo", alike what happened to CHEVRON-TEXACO in 2001," he stated. […]

title: New doubts surface over Browse site location; ENERGY
news: GROWING opposition from joint venture partners, a low oil price and expected delays to Woodside's $30 billion Browse Basin project makes a tie-back to the North West Shelf development a more attractive option than the selected James Price Point site, a new economic analysis says. A report led by a Citi analyst, Mark Greenwood, says the advancement of Browse at the controversial James Price Point on the Kimberley coastline is now "less than certain" as a raft of issues including landholder agreements and environmental approval continue to undermine Woodside achieving a final investment decision by 2012. The analysis comes as the actor Michael Caton and the Jabirr Jabirr traditional owner Neil McKenzie stepped up the pressure on the federal government, delivering 12,000 postcards signed by people opposed to the development to the Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, in Canberra. The push back from indigenous and environmental groups is tipped to result in delays to an already tight timetable, Mr Greenwood said.  [...] Modelling by Citi shows that the Kimberley option has a superior discounted cash flow [DCF] for Woodside at $US80 a barrel but that the metrics change at $US60 a barrel. "Under this scenario, the North West Shelf tie-back is the clear winner," Citi said. "Not only is the initial rate of return higher, but the discounted cash flow valuation for the overall project is also higher. Even for Woodside, the DCF of a North West Shelf tie-back would be higher compared with the James Price Point option." Mr Greenwood said the difference would be more pronounced for Woodside, as opposed to its joint venture partners, because the oil and gas giant would forgo a large chunk of the liquefaction return given it has 46 per cent of Browse but only 16.7 per cent of the North West Shelf. A tie-back to Woodside's $13 billion Pluto project, which has struggled to find enough gas for a second processing train, could also be an option, Citi said, if the main prerogative was timely commercialisation. Mr Greenwood said he believed BHP, Shell and Chevron still preferred the North West Shelf alternative. [...] "We can therefore see a final investment decision being potentially delayed until mid-2014 if a joint venture partner were to oppose the James Price Point development option," Citi said. "The longer it takes to make a final investment decision on the Browse project, the nearer we are to declining production at the North West Shelf, and this means the more attractive the relative economics of the North West Shelf tie-back option compared to James Price Point."

title: American Electric Power test burns PRB coal in effort to reduce EPA compliance costs
news: American Electric Power, which already is planning to retire at least 6,000 MW of older coal-fired generating capacity to meet with new and proposed Environmental Protection Agency rules, is test burning a variety of coals, including ultra low-sulfur Powder River Basin coal, to reduce its compliance costs and keep other units running.AEP President Nicholas Akins, speaking at the BANK OF AMERICA Merrill-Lynch 2011 Power and Gas Leaders Conference in New York on September 20, discussed the Columbus, Ohio-based company's generation and environmental compliance strategy.[…]

title: Editorial: Drilling for NZ oil a risk worth taking
news: [...] Undoubtedly, it was unfortunate that Petrobras' five-year prospecting permit was awarded at virtually the same time last year as the impact of BP's massive oil spill became apparent. Equally, it is true that the risk of such episodes has increased as explorers probe deeper and deeper waters in their quest to sate the ongoing global thirst for oil. [...] The rest of the world has now placed the Deepwater Horizon accident in context. Britain, for example, has accelerated deep-sea exploration off the Shetland Islands. This country has too much at stake to step back. Indeed, it needs Petrobras to succeed, given the results of drilling over the past couple of years have not been as encouraging as hoped. Most damagingly, ExxonMobil has withdrawn from the Great South Basin. In many ways, the presence of Petrobras, one of the world's top 10 oil and gas companies, is a much-needed vote of confidence. That is not to say New Zealand should ignore the lessons of the Gulf of Mexico. A far smaller spill here would have devastating consequences for the fishing and tourism industries, and for the country's clean green image.[...]

The agency, which previously handled the brand's media planning business, won the reconfigured account after a four-way pitch against incumbent media buying agency Universal McCann, Starcom and Naked Communications. title: GOING GREEN; And what that may mean to telecom
news: When ``going green'' sometimes means having large polluters pay for lavish advertisements focused on how much they care about the earth, it helps to look beyond platitudes to tangible specifics. Right now, the telecom industry in general is in the early phase of defining what ``going green'' means, according to analyst Jason Marcheck at Current Analysis.[…] ``Corporations are emphasizing their actions to reduce their carbon footprint,'' Marcheck said. ``By and large, everyone has a `green story.' A lot of it now is a marketing story, which makes sense. But it is unlikely that implementing green corporate practices will result in an ongoing competitive advantage for any company.'' As more companies take the marketing angle, companies will try to ``out-green'' each other, the analyst said. For instance, the term ``energy efficient'' gets stretched to the breaking point and there's a danger of rendering marketing messages less effective if a claim doesn't ring true. Meaningful impact. In contrast, making one's product offerings more environmentally conscious can have a more meaningful impact on a company's competitive position, the analyst said. Three main categories present themselves: reducing power consumption, using renewable materials in products and packaging and conformance with government regulations and/or recommendations from advocacy groups. Equipment vendors have always touted lower energy consumption as a means to lower costs for their customers. Now it's got a green spin. So, metrics and definitions should be clear and, in telecom as in other industries, new certifications may be necessary to bring coherence to the issue of green claims, the analyst said. ``CISCO SYSTEMS recently told me, for instance, that a teleconference with 98 participants has the same carbon footprint as one cross-country flight,'' Marcheck said. ``The message there is: companies are trying to quantify their actions to reduce their carbon footprint.''[…]

title: Gas boom as China signs $25bn deal
news: An Australian-based consortium has won a contract to supply China with liquefied natural gas worth up to $25 billion in what will be the nation's biggest single export deal. The contract gives Australia a foothold into what promises to become a highly lucrative market. The gas, from the North-West Shelf off Western Australia, will be worth between $700 million and $1 billion a year for 25 years. […] BHP Billiton Petroleum, BP, CHEVRON, Shell and Japan Australia LNG are the other members of the consortium. […] Environmental degradation and air pollution are acute problems in the world's most populous nation, and liquefied natural gas is much cleaner than coal-based power stations which are common in China. "A foot in the door in China is very significant. It's the most attractive world market for natural gas right now," said Gordon Ramsay, equity analyst from SSB. However, the deal did have its critics, who said the Federal Government had gone silent on China's human rights abuses. […]

title: Gobe partners pin hopes on talks; * PROJECTS
news: Developers of the $US300 million ($378 million) Gobe project in Papua New Guinea will attend a crucial meeting with powerful land owners and government officials this weekend. The meeting is a last-ditch attempt to resolve issues threatening to further delay construction of the country's second major oilfield after Kutubu.Mr Peter Botten, managing director of Oil Search, a major partner in the venture with CHEVRON Niugini, told the Herald that issues relating to the land owners' 2.0 per cent free equity, royalties and infrastructure benefits affecting about 4,000 clan members would dominate the talks, expected to last for three days.[…]The Minister said the Government was still learning lessons from the secessionist crisis on Bougainville, where dissatisfaction over the level of royalties and alleged pollution from the CRA-owned Panguna copper mine were the catalysts for a civil war now in its eighth year. "All the lessons from Bougainville taught us that you look after the land owners," Mr Giheno said.

title: It's easier to bury CO2 than the hatchet
news: […] IT has been touted as Australia's greatest resources project, not only because it is designed to tap the nation's largest known gas reservoirs but also because it was set to be Australia's most important contribution to developing solutions for a carbon-constrained world. But there is speculation the Gorgon gas project, which is scheduled to start shipping LNG cargoes from about 2013, will be further delayed by continuing differences between partners Chevron, ExxonMobil and Shell.[...] The project is set to exploit around 12 fields about 130km offshore and the Jansz reservoir, the biggest yet found in Australian waters, with an estimated 20 trillion cubic feet of reserves, a further 80km northwest.[...] The published development plan is to use Jansz gas to dilute the CO2 content of the Gorgon fields by constructing two separate sub-sea developments supplying untreated gas through independent flowlines to a 10 million tonne a year capacity LNG facility on Barrow Island. This is a Class A nature reserve lying directly between the gas fields and the mainland. For years it has hosted Australia's longest producing oil field.[...]

title: Chu has few allies on White House panel to push for more clean-energy exports
news: With President Barack Obama filling out his export council with 28 business and labor leaders last week, experts said Energy Secretary Steven Chu may have a lonely row to hoe when it comes to maximizing the US' potential to sell clean energy technologies to foreign countries. Chu is one of 10 Cabinet members and government officials on the export council, and though he and the Obama administration have emphasized the importance of spurring US green-technology exports, the country lags behind others in clean-energy development. And though the export council is tasked in part with helping the US grow in this sector, Lou Leonard, director of US climate policy at the World Wildlife Foundation, said the council appears light on clean-energy advocates. "If you look at the rest of the council, [Chu] will be carrying a lot of water on the clean energy side," Leonard said. "Looking at the companies [the appointed members] represent, there aren't as many as you'd hope to see that are squarely in the clean energy export space. You don't have a GE or Applied Materials or those folks that you might otherwise hope to see." Obama announced Wednesday that the council, which will be led by Boeing Chairman and CEO James McNerney and Xerox Chairman and CEO Ursula Burns, will include leaders from UPS, MetLife, PFIZER, Verizon, Archer Daniels Midland, Dow Chemical and other companies. Anthony Kim, an international economics analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, called Chu's seat on the council "a good sign" for the country's clean-energy manufacturing sector. […] Leonard, with the WWF, agreed that the US needs to help develop markets abroad for green technology, in order to boost US exports. But rather than free trade agreements, he said the US should incentivize other countries, particularly developing countries that are expected to greatly increase their energy use over the coming decades, to adopt clean-energy policies.[…]

title: Gwynne Dyer: Fuel companies" carbon bubble greater threat than GFC
news: There are, we are told, only two options. Either we stop burning fossil fuels before our carbon dioxide emissions drive the planet"s average temperature up a full 2C, in which case we will push the world into the biggest-ever recession. Or we continue to burn fossil fuels and push the planet into runaway warming, with lethal consequences for a large part of the human race. […] This is the focus of a new report titled "Unburnable Carbon 2013". The report"s authors, the Grantham Research Institute at the London School of Economics and the Carbon Tracker Initiative, have the support of organisations like the HSBC and Citi banks, the Standard & Poor"s rating agency and the International Energy Agency. Their conclusion is that if we are to have a 50 per cent chance of stopping the warming before +2 degrees, then at least two-thirds of the currently listed fossil fuel reserves will have to stay in the ground permanently. If they cannot be burned, then they have no economic value. Therefore, the market valuation of the fossil fuel companies is three times higher than it should be. […]

title: Rudd's shift strands Turnbull
news: Kevin Rudd bowed to the inevitable yesterday and postponed the introduction of Australia's emissions trading scheme, although he's sticking to the government's planned timetable for introducing enabling legislation in the next session of parliament. Rudd and his climate change crew - Treasurer Wayne Swan, Climate Change Minister Penny Wong and union-friendly Climate Change Parliamentary Secretary Greg Combet - are also taking the opportunity to indulge in a little manana politicking by fine-tuning the details at the same time. [...] CITIGROUP's Elaine Prior has previously noted that Turnbull proffered "only anecdotal comments" on how to achieve tougher cuts than the government's 5 per cent to 15 per cent proposal, and said she doubted that the potential cited by Turnbull for forestry, biochar or energy efficiency in buildings is achievable by 2020. title: Denison working on a deal for preferred shareholders
news: Denison Mines Ltd. is getting set to try to strike a deal with its longsuffering preferred shareholders, after announcing terms of an agreement yesterday with  major creditor Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp.[…]  Subject to certain conditions, Denison said CMHC has agreed to convert the debt to 8% of Denison's  common shares outstanding after Denison completes its restructuring and an $8.6-million note. The note is subordinated to the company's environmental reclamation commitments at Elliot Lake and restructured bank debt.  Under the terms of the note, Denison is required to pay interest at a rate of 6%, starting 6 30, 2000, and make principal repayments of 75% of defined net cash flow beginning on either 6 30, 2000, or after it repays its bank debt.  As a result of the agreement with CMHC, and earlier deals with Toronto Dominion Bank and BANK OF AMERICA, Denison's creditors will own $38.6 million in subordinated 6% notes and 18% of Denison's equity.[…]

title: Crucial month for CHEVRON pipeline
news: Energy. CHEVRON has warned November could be the make-or-break month for its ambitious Papua New Guinea gas pipeline project, claiming it must secure several key agreements in the next few weeks if it is to meet its planned 2001 start-up date. PNG gas project director John Powell told an industry conference yesterday the company had finally secured approval for its environmental impact statement and expected the Federal Government to sign off on it this week.[…] In September, CHEVRON entered into a memorandum of understanding to supply gas to Comalco's proposed $1.4 billion alumina refinery in Gladstone. It has signed similar agreements with Dynegy and Stanwell Corp, the joint operators of the proposed Pinnacles Power Station near Townsville, QNI, NRG Asia Pacific and Queensland Alumina. Finalising a gas supply agreement with Exxon and Oil Search, which owned the neighbouring Hides gas field in the PNG Highlands, was particularly crucial because much of the resource within CHEVRON's jointly owned Kutubu field was too far away to be commercially produced, Dr Powell said.

title: Mackenzie pipeline suffers a setback; Project faces longer wait after panel delays report

The Joint Review Panel, which is examining the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of the Mackenzie Valley Pipeline, said it will release its report in December 2009, several months later than expected.[...] Imperial Oil Ltd., which is leading the five-company consortium looking to build the line, said it does not yet know what impact the delay will have on its plans.[...] Imperial's partners in the pipeline project include Royal Dutch Shell PLC, Exxon Mobil Corp., ConocoPhillips and the Aboriginal Pipeline Group.

title: Shell aims to pump up oil sands development
news: Shell Canada Ltd. and its oil sands partners are considering a three-pronged plan to further develop the companies' Athabasca oil sands properties in Northern Alberta, at a potential cost of more than $3-billion.  Calgary-based Shell, which owns 60 per cent of the Athabasca Oil Sands Project currently under development near Fort McMurray, said in a news release yesterday that it and partners CHEVRON Canada Ltd. and Western Oil Sands Inc., which each have a 20-per-cent stake, have filed with regulators a public disclosure document and terms of reference for environment assessment for the proposed projects, marking the first step in the regulatory approval process. The proposed new developments could eventually add 370,000 barrels a day to the Athabasca joint venture, which expects to begin production late next year at 155,000 b/d. […]

title: Eu bans animal-tested make-up; The blanket restriction on such cosmetics may affect consumers all over the world. GLADYS CHUNG reports on the implications of this move
news: On Monday, the European Commission announced that all cosmetics tested on animals can no longer be marketed or sold in the European Union.  The ban did not come about overnight, though. Since 2004, the EU has banned animal testing in phases, first banning the testing of finished cosmetic products in the region, but not the sale of such products.  In 2009, it banned both animal testing for cosmetic ingredients and the sale of cosmetic products which contain ingredients that were tested on animals. However, animal testing on ingredients with possible complex human health effects were exempted, such as tests on ingredients with potential toxicity that may lead to cancer. Major cosmetic manufacturers had lobbied for this phase to give them more time to come up with alternatives, according to a New York Times report. […] Clarins is another brand which said it stopped animal testing long before the EU law required it to. Its spokesman said the French company has banned the practice since 1987.  But he added: "We do not conduct animal testing on our finished products or ingredients unless in exceptional cases, such as when it is required locally by law."  Clarins' position is similar to that of other top global beauty companies. In response to Urban's questions on their stand on animal testing, South Korean beauty group Amorepacific, Estee Lauder, PROCTER & GAMBLE, Shiseido and Unilever also stated they do not test on animals except when required by the law in the particular country that their products are sold in.  The main country in question is China, which insists on safety reports backed up by animal tests. DrKhaiat, the president of the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Singapore, said no other country in Asia has such laws.  But while the EU laws are in conflict with Chinese ones, Dr Khaiat, who is also a scientist and former vice-president of research and development in quality and technical assurance at pharmaceutical and personal care company Johnson & Johnson, said it is not a major issue.  "In China, companies are required to submit samples of the products they want to sell to the authorities. Companies do not sponsor animal testing. If the regulatory agency does test the sample, this is acceptable in Europe," said Dr Khaiat. […]

title: VIAGRA THREAT TO JAPANESE APHRODISIACS
news: VIAGRA, already a hot black-market item in Japan before its official release, is threatening local sales of tiger and seal testicles, vipers and turtles. Already approved for prescription-based sales, the diamond-shaped blue Viagra pills spell disaster for the Japanese anti-impotence industry, serving an estimated seven million men. Japanese authorities last week approved PFIZER Inc's Viagra for sale after a six-month review, but its reputation has fed an appetite on the black market since mid-1998. The blow to the traditional trade is likely to help the future of endangered animals but declining sales are punishing the entire industry, including producers of a silicon-based contraption, Stand-up.[…]

title: Gorgon will go ahead even if carbon plan fails
news: The giant Gorgon natural gas project on Barrow Island can still go ahead if plans to store millions of tonnes of greenhouse gases under the island fail, according to environmental conditions approved yesterday by State Environment Minister David Templeman. Although Colin Beckett, WA general manager for the Gorgon joint ventures majority partner CHEVRON, said there was no plan B if the controversial geosequestration technique failed, the conditions showed that there was "wriggle room" in the requirement to lock carbon dioxide in limestone reservoirs under the island. But while the conditions, which include strict monitoring provisions and an extra $60 million to protect the breeding grounds of the flat-backed turtle, indicate the company can propose alternatives to geosequestration "if injection is not considered feasible for all or some of the gas", a spokesman for Mr Templeman said the nature of the alternatives was not something that had yet been considered by the Government. Mr Templeman insisted that the project would not proceed if the 36 environmental conditions imposed yesterday were not met. […] Mr Beckett said CHEVRON and joint venture partners Exxon Mobil and Shell had spent more than $100 million on refining the gas injection technology so far and they were prepared to spend the same again to ensure that it worked. […]

title: Some like it hot while others will sweat it out
news: […] Miners, steel makers and oil companies are the most at risk from climate change issues, with BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, BlueScope Steel, OneSteel, Caltex and Illuka set to be among the biggest losers of companies in the Top 100. But property groups, recyclers and alternative energy groups will be the big winners from a greater public awareness of climate change issues and potential tightening of controls by governments, according to a report by CITIGROUP. title: Ghana; Environmental Pollution
news: Residents protest against Printex, Demand proper drainage system. Some residents of Adjiringano in Accra have appealed to the government to advise Printex, a renowned textile company to put up an appropriate drainage system since the lives of the residents are endangered.[…] The Director of EPA, Mr. Phillip Acquah speaking to the paper in an interview, said We have done extensive investigations along that line from Pintex to where the farmers have been using the waste for irrigation which the appeared in the Chronicle's 7 30 edition. He said the EPA has ordered the Printex to provide them with their environmental management plan. He said it was not appropriate for the company to channel their waste through the drainage. title: Lithuania's PM plans to meet with CHEVRON in fall
news:

title: Coke campaign unbottles recycling problem

The higher numbers enable contestants to submit better offers in the COCA-COLA tender" in which prizes range from a vacation for two in Thailand to Sony Playstations and a limousine for the night. "The ministry is demanding that COCA-COLA take every possible step to stop the damage to the bottle collection facilities even if this means stopping the campaign said Goren.[…]

title: Dark clouds linger over thermal coal's outlook
news: It's been a long harsh winter for Australia's struggling thermal coal miners, and there's even less room for optimism about the outlook than when this column last looked at the market four months ago. […] China's new plans to tackle air pollution add to concerns, and, if they are followed through, point to a bleak future for thermal coal. […] By 2016, Chinese coal imports could be almost a quarter lower than this year's 240million to 250 million tonnes. Citigroup is pointing to a possible flattening or peak in China's use of thermal coal in power plants this decade. While this will take a while to play out, the forward market's assumptions of an upturn in prices, looks over-optimistic. […]

title: Pricey oil making geothermal projects more attractive; Unlocking potential in volcano zones
news: Faced with looming energy crises in their developing economies, power-hungry countries like Indonesia and the Philippines are looking deep into the earth for solutions. Both are in the so-called Pacific Ring of Fire, an area peppered with volcanoes and home to the world's biggest reservoir of geothermal power. […] That might be changing, though, as soaring oil prices, surging demand and creaking infrastructure in the power sector make it all the more urgent for Indonesia and the Philippines to find ways to exploit their geothermal reserves.But unlocking the potential is proving difficult. Geothermal projects involve drilling wells deep into the earth to tap steam or hot water than can power turbines. Not all of the challenges are terrestrial in nature. This is a capital-intensive process complicated by bureaucracy and other stumbling blocks. The Indonesian Bedugul project, set among volcanoes in Bali, aims to develop up to 175 megawatts of power, or roughly half of what the resort island needs. But the project is on hold because local residents fear it could damage a sacred area and affect water supplies from the nearby lakes. […] The Indonesian energy firms Medco Energi Internasional and Star Energy, are looking at making new investments, while CHEVRON, the world's largest private producer of geothermal energy, plans to double its geothermal business in Indonesia and the Philippines by 2020 despite the heavy capital outlays. […] Brown, the environmentalist from the Earth Policy Institute, said that this followed a global trend in localizing energy policies as oil prices prod countries to find cost-effective alternatives. ''In Indonesia that means geothermal is going to loom large in the energy economy of the future, and that development could come very quickly once the leadership begins to see the potential,'' Brown added.

title: Gorgon's backers deny squabbles bring delays
news: Proponents of the $11 billion Gorgon gas project have played down industry speculation that they are at loggerheads with the existing oil operation on Barrow Island over the sharing of services and infrastructure on the environmentally sensitive island.But Gorgon has confirmed that no agreement has yet been reached with the separate Barrow Island joint venture more than 18 months after WA's Parliament ratified a State Agreement for the Gorgon project. The State Agreement ratified in November 2003 sets aside 300 hectares of land on Barrow Island needed to build a liquefied natural gas plant. It also requires the Gorgon project to share as much infrastructure with the existing oil operations as possible to minimise the environmental impact on the A-class reserve. […] Gorgon is a three-way joint venture between operator CHEVRONTEXACO (50 per cent), ExxonMobil and Shell, while the Barrow Island oil project is owned by CHEVRONTEXACO, ExxonMobil and Santos, which bought Shell's stake in 2000. title: How to play IT smart by letting hi-tech take a byte out of the bill
news: INFORMATION technology lies at the heart of all business processes and both generates efficiencies and consumes power. So it is no surprise to find that organisations looking to "green up" and reduce their carbon footprint are increasingly focusing on IT. As they do so, two questions come to the fore. One, how can we reduce the power usage of our IT even as our storage and data needs keep on increasing? Two, how can we use IT to facilitate efficiencies that will drive down costs? The first question tends to lie more in the hands of IT manufacturers than users. The second has a variety of answers, of which smart buildings containing computers carry out tasks such as raising and lowering shutters to regulate internal airflow, sunlight and heating, are but one example.  IBM has made a thorough study of the management of workplace IT systems. The aim was to explore how organisations can reduce their carbon footprint in a sustainable fashion, while at the same time cutting their costs.The study was carried out by IBM's UK and Ireland Technical Consultancy Group, with assistance from the Department for theEnvironment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra), which made its sites available for study by the IBM team. The starting point for the IBM team was the idea that being responsible about the environment has much in common with running a business efficiently. In both instances, the organisation looks to cut back on waste, both in terms of materials and effort, and to be responsible. The IBM study looked at all kinds of kit, including both traditional IT equipment such as mainframes and PCs, and photocopiers, fax machines and even power packs for mobile devices. Many of these devices use more energy than people expect, and use it in unexpected ways - it is not just how long they are switched on for, but also the way in which they are used, the authors of the report found. Establishing just how energy- hungry these devices are, and how this consumption can be reduced without affecting performance is a good starting point. IBM itself reckons that as an organisation, by "wising up" to energy waste, it has saved more than dollars 100 million (GBP 57m) in energy costs over the last ten years. Since all such savings go directly to the bottom line, that equates to a substantial increase in profit.[…]
