title: BUSH, THE RAINFOREST AND A GAS PIPELINE TO ENRICH HIS FRIENDS
news: PRESIDENT GEORGE Bush is seeking funds for a controversial project to drive gas pipelines from pristine rainforests in the Peruvian Amazon to the coast. The plan will enrich some of Mr Bush's closest corporate campaign contributors while risking the destruction of rainforest, threatening its indigenous peoples and endangering rare species on the coast.  Among the beneficiaries would be two Texas energy companies with close ties to the White House, Hunt Oil and Kellogg Brown & Root (KBR), a subsidiary of Vice-President Dick Cheney's old company, Haliburton, which is rebuilding Iraq's oil infrastructure.  The pipelines slice through some of the most biologically diverse places on earth. Its remoteness has preserved an extraordinarily rich ecosystem in the coastal Paracas reserve, which is home to such rare species as Humboldt penguins, sea lions and green sea turtles.  The Camisea natural gas project - with reserves of 13,000 billion cubic feet of gas - has already scared off two major investors, CITIGROUP and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. According to an internal report by the US Export Import Bank, obtained by the lobby group Amazon Watch, proposals to mitigate the environmental impact of the project are "woefully inadequate" and will lead to mudslides, destroy habitats and spread diseases among indigenous peoples. Friends of the Earth describes one threatened area as "one of the world's most pristine tropical rainforests", home to the Nahua, Kirineri, Nanti, Machiguenga and Yine indigenous groups. Past contact between indigenous peoples and loggers have proven disastrous - 42 per cent of the Nahua died from diseases contracted from outsiders in the 1980s.[…]

title: Fossils forge planet's future
news: Things really hotted up this week on the issue of global warming. Right said Fred. THE chairman of the Asia-Pacific Partnership for Clean Development & Climate has strongly rejected criticism that Australia and the US are behind the rest of the world on the environment, claiming that, as the world is round, it is impossible to tell who is behind who. ''From our perspective, they (the rest of the world) are a very long way behind,'' said AP6 spokesman Art Fuldodger yesterday in an exclusive interview with the Margin Call Bureau of Climatology (MCBC). ''We've taken giant strides.'' […] And how did the conservation and environmental groups at the conference respond to the initiatives? ''They were quickly moved along by the police.'' Minuscule millions. COULD it work? As the task ahead is saving the world, the funding is certainly worthy of note. Australia is to stump up a total of $100 million over five years on developing low-emission technology. […] Silver lining. ON a lighter note, the one thing to come out of the AP6 which might be useful is the prospect of free technology transfers between companies and nations. If the technology is free, myriad accounting issues arise. Still, without targets and undertakings, and even tax incentives for R&D on renewable energy, it's a big call. Too big a call. Once again, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural & Resource Economics did the Government's modelling on emissions. Bankrolled by renowned environmental and scientific groups Rio Tinto, Exxon, CHEVRON TEXACO and the Minerals Council of Australia, ABARE still found that greenhouse gases would more than double by 2050 -- best case. Most climatologists reckon emissions are too high already to combat global warming so the AP6 is putting a lot of faith in the private sector and its industry chiefs serving their five-year terms. title: Solid waste management efforts through EPR system
news: The reduction and recycling of solid waste has become an ever-worsening global problem in recent years, and Korea is no exception. In response to this reality, the Korean government has been pursuing measures to deal with the country's waste problem since the 1990s. However, there are limitations to how far we can go in alleviating a situation that requires the implementation of measures to enable large-scale waste reduction and recycling in an efficient and environmentally friendly manner. For this reason, the present waste deposit payment system will be eliminated and replaced by the so-called extended producer responsibility (EPR) system in 1 2003. EPR is the extension of producers' responsibility for the environmental impacts of their products to the entire product life cycle - especially for take-back, recycling, and disposal. The EPR system will impose certain responsibilities and obligations on the producers of waste-generating products and packaging, requiring that the producer apply environment-friendly mechanisms to support the reduction, reuse and recycling of solid waste. […] The test project involves the application of the EPR system in seven product categories that must be recycled - glass bottles, cans, paper bags, tires, home appliances, lubricants, and batteries. This group of categories is the same as in the previous system, but will be expanded to also include electronic products (i.e., computers) and plastic packaging. In fact, foreign-invested companies have been playing an active role in leading this recycling revolution in Korea. In May of this year, COCA-COLA Korea Bottling Company, along with other domestic beverage manufacturers, entered into a voluntary agreement for recycling disposed plastic bottles using the EPR system. Disposed bottles are collected, cut, cleaned, processed and finally recycled into polyester fabric. The targeted recycling amount for 2002 is 55,000 tons, or 65 percent of all disposed plastic bottles.[…]

title: 'War' on greenhouse gases hurting oil demand: CIBC; Economist Rubin trims brokerage firm's overweight position in oil and gas stocks
news: Governments around the world are "waging a war" on greenhouse gas emissions, resulting in the first decline in crude-oil consumption in more than two decades among countries of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, or OECD, according to CIBC World Markets. Chief economist Jeff Rubin, in releasing his Canadian portfolio strategy outlook yesterday, described the trend as "policy-mandated demand-destruction." He said the decline in oil consumption, the push for alternative fuels such as ethanol and the likelihood of emissions regulation are expected to take the shine off energy stocks against a backdrop of reasonably healthy economic growth. […] Like RBC, however, Merrill Lynch went underweight in energy about a year ago after stocks and prices in the sector rose "fantastically." The brokerage shifted to an overweight position in the materials sector until last fall and is now underweight on the commodity complex as a whole. The fundamental environment for the energy sector would have to change "appreciably" for Merrill Lynch to move to a higher weighting, said Wolf. Rubin said he wouldn't move to an underweight position in energy, partly because he still expects oil and uranium prices to rise higher. "Also, when you look around, 60 per cent of the world's investable oil reserves are in Canada. The world is shrinking for Exxon and CHEVRON and Total. The future world supply lies in the (oil) sands. You're going to see the multinationals bid very aggressively for that." Throttling that growth will be a carbon cap and trade system, even though Prime Minister Stephen Harper has steadfastly rejected such an idea. Rubin said Harper will have to change his stand to satisfy the increasingly concerned public.

title: Ice Free
news: Greenland's ice sheet represents one of global warming's most disturbing threats. The vast expanses of glaciers -- massed, on average, 1.6 miles deep -- contain enough water to raise sea levels worldwide by 23 feet. Should they melt or otherwise slip into the ocean, they would flood coastal capitals, submerge tropical islands and generally redraw the world's atlases. The infusion of fresh water could slow or shut down the ocean's currents, plunging Europe into bitter winter. [... ]The island's ice cover has already begun to disappear. ''Changes in the ocean eat the ice sheet from underneath,'' says Sarah Das, a glaciologist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts. ''Warmer water causes the glaciers to calve and melt back more quickly.'' Hunters who use the frozen surface of the winter ocean for hunting and travel have found themselves idle when the ice fails to form. The whales, seals and birds they hunt have begun to shift their migratory patterns. ''The traditional culture will be hard hit,'' says Jesper Madsen, director of the department of Arctic environment at the University of Aarhus in Denmark [...]  Geological Survey estimates that Greenland's northeastern waters could contain 31 billion barrels of undiscovered oil and gas. On the other side of the island, the waters separating it from Canada could yield billions of barrels more. And while Greenland is still considered an oil exploration frontier, Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Canada's Husky Energy and Cairn Energy and Sweden's PA Resources are aleady ramping up exploration.

title: What Do We Mean When We Say Socially Responsible Investing?
news: Practitioners of ESG investing (common shorthand for strategies that take into account environmental, social and governance issues) often single out the "S" in that acronym as a particular challenge. […] A recently released report by the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility (ICCR), a long-time presence in the push for better corporate sustainability, seeks to address, and perhaps begin to alleviate, the common frustration around the S in ESG. The main takeaway from the ICCR's "Social Sustainability Resource Guide" is that companies need to do a better job of both considering and reporting on their social impacts. […] In the spirit of this "collaborative, multi-party, multi-sector" approach, the report's authors represent a wide variety of corporations, NGOs, and investment firms. It includes case studies from PEPSICO, Timberland, Merck, Domini Social Investments and others to drill into the details of how various players have tackled the quantification of social issues. And it concludes with a framework to help companies begin to gather around a common model of how to report on the actual impacts of their social programs. But will the report and its framework really help ESG investors get a handle on the social issues most closely tied to companies' core businesses? Take the PEPSICO case study: it's a description of WaterHope, a program established with the help of PEPSICO that provides for the creation of community-owned and operated water stations in poor areas of the Philippines. Even if the ICCR report helps companies to better report on the impacts of programs like this, will it really be helping to pull the S out of the greenwashed cloud of cherry-picked anecdotes? Or will it be giving companies a license to focus primarily on their philanthropic side projects in reporting on their social sustainability? David Schilling, program director at ICCR and one of the lead authors of the report, stresses that he and the other authors of the resource guide don't consider programs like WaterHope to be philanthropic side projects - he says that for a company like PEPSICO, which relies heavily on water to operate, any program that encourages the sustainable use of water is tied to its core business."We're not seeing this as just a nice thing to do in the community, or as philanthropy," he says, "but as a way of asking, 'What can sustain communities?' and 'How can corporations participate in that, while also looking at it from a business risk perspective?'"[…]

title: GE and Bechtel Form Alliance for Coal Gasification Projects
news: GE Energy and Bechtel say they will form an alliance to develop a standard commercial offering for integrated combined-cycle gasification (IGCC) power projects in North America. IGCC systems convert coal and other hydrocarbons into synthetic gas, which is then used as the primary fuel for a gas turbine in combined-cycle power plants.  IGCC systems offer significantly reduced carbon dioxide and other emissions compared to traditional pulverized coal power plants. GE and Bechtel say the alliance will integrate the development, marketing, commercialization, and implementation of GE's IGCC process with Bechtel's engineering, procurement, and construction expertise. GE recently purchased CHEVRONTEXACO's gasification technology business, a leading licenser of IGCC technology.

title: WHAT NEXT?
news: ALTHOUGH AMERICAN INDUSTRY is making progress in ripping down the formidable barrier that separates their environmental activities from their everyday operations and strategic decision-making, much of the job lies ahead.  But what specifically should companies do?[…] But there are still other ways.  One example is offered by INTEL Corp.  Competing in an industry in which time-to-market for new products is critical, the Silicon Valley firm has focused on speeding the process of getting operating permits for its chip-manufacturing emission sources.  It's doing so by working out cooperative arrangements with state and federal regulatory agencies.

title: Companies fight PCB export ban   Quebec industries, Ontario waste hauler   say Copps' ruling favours Alberta facility
news: A group representing many of Quebec's largest industrial companies has joined an Ontario waste-transportation firm to ask a court to overturn a federal ban on the export of PCB wastes.     The group, the Centre patronal de l'environnement du Quebec, says Environment Minister Sheila Copps's imposition of the export ban last month was not done to protect the environment. It says the action was taken to benefit a specific company, ChemSecurity (Alberta) Ltd., which operates Canada's only PCB destruction facility at Swan Hills, Alta., and stands to benefit greatly from the ban.[…] For years, the U.S. government has banned the import of PCB wastes from Canada. But S. D. Myers Inc., which operates a PCB-destruction facility in Tallmadge, Ohio, south of Cleveland, obtained approval from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency this fall to import PCB wastes from Canada as of Nov. 15. Myers was backed by many Canadian industries led by Quebec's Centre patronal, whose 70 corporate members include Bombardier Inc., Hydro-Quebec and IBM Canada Inc. It was also backed by General Waste Transport Inc. of Brampton, Ont., which was planning to haul the PCB wastes from Ontario and Quebec to the Ohio facility.[…]

title: Bank with conscience
news: Corporate social responsibility (CSR) is increasingly viewed as the measuring device to evaluate the way that companies and organisations integrate economic, social and environmental initiatives into their business practices. It has become a key factor in judging the manner enterprises operate, locally, regionally or internationally.  China Construction Bank (CCB), a leading commercial bank on the mainland, in May became the first major mainland commercial bank to publish a CSR report. The report details the various CSR measures the bank has undertaken and marks the latest initiative of submitting to public scrutiny. Through its local, regional and international activities, CCB's business consists of corporate banking, personal banking and treasury operations. CCB is also a leading provider of infrastructure loans, residential mortgages and bank cards. […] BANK OF AMERICA and Fullerton Financial Holdings were engaged in 2005 as strategic partners. By forming alliances with these overseas strategic partners and benchmarking them, the bank has improved the mechanism of its corporate governance processes.

title: FTC may block Unocal patents on clean-fuel formulations
news: Federal Trade Commission antitrust enforcers are recommending a lawsuit challenging some of energy company Unocal's clean-fuel patents, people familiar with the matter say. If the FTC's five commissioners agree, they could block Unocal from enforcing its patents, which EXXONMOBIL has said can add up to 5 cents to the price of a gallon of less-polluting reformulated gas. A successful lawsuit by the government could lead to lower-priced reformulated gas in California and other areas required to use the cleaner fuel. About one-third of gas pumps in the country contain reformulated gas. [...] In 2001, EXXONMOBIL asked the FTC to investigate Unocal. It said Unocal participated in standard-setting meetings for the reformulated gas while quietly seeking patents for the technology needed to meet those standards.[...]

title: BE PREPARED FOR THE COST OF CONTAMINATION
news: Ignored or mismanaged, environmental hazards can create insurmountable costs forcompanies. But if the risk of these hazards is predicted and managed, the benefits can be vast. Jim Finnamore demonstrates the benefits of quantifying environmental risk  liabilities. The issue is as real for owners of single sites as it is for ownersof large portfolios.[…]  Independent research carried out on behalf of CITIbank suggests that around 70% of a company's net worth is determined by the market's perception of the company. The problem is, how can a property firm optimise its commercial position with respect to the environment? The solution involves translating environmental risk into pounds and pence, and providing levels of confidence in these monetary forecasts.[…]  Predicting the financial impact of current environmental risks is a difficult task, full of uncertainty. Add future risk exposures, and the uncertainty increases dramatically. This is because, in many cases, the exposures and their outcomes are unprecedented.  For those that are not, there is limited historic information on reported lossesin the UK on which to base any risk analysis. […]

title: OPEC To Ignore U.S. Demands; Wants More Oil
news: RIYADH - OPEC oil nations plan to ignore U.S. calls to increase production as crude prices remain stuck above $90US a barrel, according to a draft of the group's statement to be released this weekend. The group will instead reiterate a commitment to ensure energy supply and seek to reduce their carbon emissions released from pumping and refining oil and gas, according to the statement to be issued in Riyadh, which was confirmed by three officials from the group who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Their intention to keep production at current levels signals consumers are unlikely to see relief from high oil prices, which reached a record $98US.62 a barrel on Nov. 7 in New York. A pledge to reduce carbon dioxide threatens to force investors in OPEC nations such as Royal Dutch Shell PLC and Exxon Mobil Corp. to incur extra costs at their operations.[...]

title: Put power profits into clean energy: Combet
news: Australia's coal and power generation industries must shoulder a large part of the cost of developing clean coal technologies, investing "billions not millions" to mitigate climate change, ACTU secretary Greg Combet says. […] Speaking from the Hunter Valley, where he was launching a clean coal discussion paper with Opposition environment spokesman Peter Garrett, Mr Combet called for the Federal Government's Minimum Renewable Energy Target for green electricity generation to be boosted from the current level of 2 per cent to 10 per cent. […] Mr Combet said solar energy had "a big role to play" in lowering greenhouse emissions and also called for building codes to be changed to place a stronger emphasis on energy conservation and use of renewable energy technologies. His comments followed the announcement yesterday by federal Industry Minister Ian Macfarlane and Environment Minister Malcolm Turnbull of a $100million grant to HRL Limited to build a 400-megawatt coal drying plant at the Loy Yang coal mine in Victoria's La Trobe Valley. This latest grant, under the Government's $500million Low Emission Technology Demonstration Fund, brings the total invested in clean coal technologies under the scheme to $275million. Four of the six programs funded to date involve clean coal, with $75million invested in a large-scale solar concentrator power station and $60million for CHEVRON Australia's controversial geosequestration pilot project at Barrow Island, off the West Australian coast. […]

title: Sea eagles may be driven out by Disney
news: A pair of rare white-bellied sea eagles may have to move their nest to make way for Mickey Mouse, an environmental report on the future Disneyland said.  But the report, compiled by the Civil Engineering Department, said the birds would only have to move in the worst-case scenario because the potential disturbance caused by the theme park project would be moderate.  The department released two environmental impact assessment reports on Disneyland and related projects on north Lantau yesterday, concluding the developments would comply with environmental laws. […]  If they left, the eagles should be able to find suitable alternative sites.[…]  KEY FINDINGS.  Air quality objectives will be met during construction and operation;  Emissions from firework shows and project-related transport insignificant;  Special mid-level fireworks display will meet noise standards;  Discharges into sea will not damage tides, currents or water quality;  Park's joint-venture company should recycle waste;  A 10-hectare buffer zone recommended for area where a pair of white-bellied sea eagles were found; Waters near park not much used by Chinese white dolphins; Access to pitcher plants to be restricted during construction work; Mitigation measures for heritage resources, such as temporary coverage of archaeological sites, to begin before construction.

title: Nickel price knows no bounds
news: Commodities. NICKEL prices seem unstoppable with the spot price not only blasting through the $US40,000 a tonne level in one night but continuing on to a breathtaking $US41,000. […] CITIGROUP global commodity analyst Alan Heap said yesterday that, while strike threats at the huge Xstrata Sudbury complex -- which supplies 15 per cent of world nickel -- were causing the latest price rise, the metal's value would be underpinned in the longer term by its environmental sustainability. What that means in plain English is that nickel is more conducive to being recycled than many other metals. About 37 per cent of nickel used each year has been recycled, compared with 12 per cent of copper and 7 per cent of zinc. […]

title: Ethiopia; Decarbonisation - Is It About Commitment or Technology?
news: If the world is to solve the climate change crisis, we will need a new approach. Currently, the major powers view climate change as a negotiation over who will reduce their carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions (mainly from the use of coal, oil and gas). Each agrees to small "contributions" of emission reduction, trying to nudge the other countries to do more. The US, for example, will concede a little bit of CO2 reduction if China will do the same.[…] Fighting climate change does de-pend on all countries having confidence that their competitors will follow suit. So, yes, let the upcoming climate negoti-ations spell out shared actions by the US, China, Europe and others. But let us stop pretending that this is a poker game, rather than a scientific and technological puzzle of the highest order. We need the likes of Musk, Lackner, General Electric, Siemens, Ericsson, INTEL, Electricité de France, Huawei, Google, Baidu, Samsung, Apple and others in labor-atories, power plants and cities around the world to forge the technological breakthroughs that will reduce global CO2 emissions. There is even a place at the table for ExxonMobil, Chevron, BP, Peabody, Koch Industries and other oil and coal giants. If they expect their products to be used in the future, they had better make them safe through the deploy-ment of advanced CCS technologies. The point is that targeted and deep decarbonisation is a job for all stakeholders, including the fossil-fuel industry, and one in which we must all be on the side of human survival and wellbeing.

title: Xstrata's Australian bid facing official scrutiny
news: […] However, he suggested keeping uranium deposits in Australian hands would help the country fulfil its obligations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. Uranium is a "clean" fuel that offsets pollution from "dirty" fuels like coal. WMC owns the world's largest uranium deposit. […]A banking adviser to WMC, CITIGROUP's Peter Bacchus, said: "It is entirely a question of value. The board has no objection to a change in control."

title: Oil company relief at biofuel respite but Parliament's support uncertain
news: Oil companies are relieved at a watering-down of a proposed biofuel sales obligation, but the Government has yet to be assured of enough political support for legislation reported back to Parliament yesterday. Although the Green Party has pledged keen support for new "sustainability" clauses of the Biofuel Bill recommended by the local government and environment select committee, National says it contains serious flaws and is promising strong opposition. It said the obligation could impose $240 million of costs on consumers for small, if any, environmental benefits. New Zealand First and the Maori Party have yet to consider their positions, raising uncertainty over whether the Government will be able to pass the legislation, which National environmental spokesman Nick Smith said last night would open the door to unsustainable biofuel imports. Energy Minister David Parker said biofuels were likely to reduce costs while starting to "free New Zealand from the tyranny of the international oil market". […] BP spokeswoman Diana Stretch, while welcoming the reduced target as being more practicable to achieve, said her company would have to recalculate its cost projections before commenting on these. Sharon Buckland of CHEVRON (Caltex) said her company strongly supported moves to biofuels, but was concerned that the start of the proposed sales mandate in October would precede regulations setting sustainability standards by at least nine months. That would make it difficult to enter into long-term supply agreements. The Biofuel Manufacturers' Association fears the oil industry may lock itself into supply chains of imports before a local industry has a proper chance of establishing itself. Spokesman Dickon Posnett said the select committee had done "some good work" on ensuring any biofuels would be sustainable and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. […]

title: AEP test burning Powder River Basin coal
news: American Electric Power is test-burning a variety of coals, including ultra low-sulfur Powder River Basin coal, to allow the company to more economically comply with new clean air rules, a company official said Tuesday. Nicholas Akins, president of the Columbus, Ohio-based company, talked about AEP's environmental compliance plans at the BANK OF AMERICA Merrill-Lynch 2011 Power and Gas Leaders Conference in New York.[…]

title: BESPAK (BPK)
news: This time last year, Bespak was considering takeover offers, but that looks to be a thing of the past. The restructuring programme - following a disastrous 18 months that saw pricing pressures on asthma drug Diskus from GlaxoSmithKline and the collapse of partner Weston Medical - has paid off. Driven by cost savings, pre-tax profits exceeded City forecasts, while operating cash flow surged from £3m in 2003 to £13.2m.  Shares in Bespak have had a good run, boosted by the European filing of PFIZER's inhaled insulin product Exubera. However, 2005 is expected to be subdued and analysts are not upgrading forecasts. Diskus volumes are falling and Glaxo is bringing a second supplier online, which will dent revenues. Also, Exubera will not hit the bottom line until 2006 and, while Bespak will cash in on the US switch from CFCs to environmentally friendly HFA valves, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has been stalling on a deadline. […]

title: Carbon after Copenhagen: Living with uncertainty
news: The Copenhagen summit was a heavy blow to the hopes of environmentalists - and to prospects for a much bigger, more global carbon market. Without agreement on capping emissions, it is hard to know what carbon is worth. But emissions trading specialists are taking it in their stride. As Siân Williams discovers, there is still plenty of momentum in the market - even in the US.[…] Hopes for Mexico. Though Copenhagen was a flop, it is likely that further commitments will be made in the months and years to come. The UNFCCC will meet in Bonn in May and in Mexico City in December, with the hope of brokering further deals - and the debate about climate change will never go away. "I don't think Bonn is going to be that pivotal," says Abyd Karmali, global head of carbon emissions at BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch in London. "More serious action will be taking place in Mexico City." Grattan MacGiffin, head of voluntary carbon markets at MF Global in London, believes that a binding post-Kyoto UN agreement will happen at Mexico and not before.[…]

title: WORLD'S OFFER OF HELP COMES WITH A COST
news: At least 22 nations - including Britain, where BP is based - have offered oil-collecting skimmers, boom, technical ex-perts and more to help the United States cope with its worst-ever environmental disaster. But their generosity comes with a price tag. […] 5 The Department of Interior's Minerals Management Service has signed off on at least five new offshore drilling pro-jects since 6 2, when the agency's acting director announced tougher safety regulations for drilling in the gulf, a McClatchy Newspapers review of public records has discovered. Three of the projects were approved with waivers exempting them from detailed studies of their environmental impact - the same waiver the MMS granted to BP for the ill-fated well that's been fouling the gulf with crude for two months. Of those, an Exxon Mobil site at a water depth of 1,000 feet and a Marathon Oil site at 775 feet are classified as deepwater; the third is a shallow-water project by Hou-ston-based Rooster Petroleum. The MMS also approved two other deepwater drilling plans - for a CHEVRON site 6,730 feet underwater and for an Exxon site at a depth of 6,943 feet - after subjecting them to environmental reviews.[...]

title: Chevron declares war on emissions
news: ENERGY giant Chevron Australia is taking up the fight on global warming, pledging to build the first large-scale carbon dioxide geosequestration project in Australia. The project will be part of its multi-billion dollar Barrow Island Gorgon gas development. Chevron Australia general manager Colin Beckett said the project, to put carbon dioxide underground to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, will be larger than any other geosequestration scheme contemplated or in production.[...] Chevron said its system would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 120 million tonnes over the life of the project, by injecting carbon dioxide 2.5km below the island.[...] In addition to the geosequestration system, the joint venture partners -- Chevron, ExxonMobil and Shell -- must establish expert panels to protect the unique biodiversity of the island and surrounding marine environment.[...]

title: Carbon can't be stored in limbo, but that's where the major parties want it
news: Political inaction makes climate change and the carbon-costing problem all the worse. THE climate change morass, with the two major political parties refusing to tackle the issue, will hurt business and the economy. And business is beginning to demand more than an ad hoc approach that will lead to market failures. The first signs of this are emerging with Standard & Poor's downgrading of one of Australia's biggest emission-generating power stations, Loy Yang B, to just above junk status because of uncertainty over a carbon price.  [...] A recent report by CITIGROUP analyst Elaine Prior says businesses are refusing to invest in low-carbon technologies here because of what she describes as policy and regulatory "limbo". [...] "Many cost estimates come from letters to the shadow minister from interested industry bodies in 1 2010 . . . It is unclear what the 'fallback' policy would be if abatement options proved more costly than projected," the CITIGROUP report says. While the Coalition believes it can achieve soil carbon reductions at $8-$10 a tonne, there's one problem: farmers can make more than twice as much trading credits on domestic and international carbon markets. [...]

title: WA gives thumbs-up to Chevron expansion
news: WESTERN Australia's Environmental Protection Authority has recommended approval of Chevron's proposed expansion of its massive Gorgon liquefied natural gas project on Barrow Island. The next hurdle facing the project, which is worth up to $40 billion, will be a decision by the state's Environment Minister, Donna Faragher, in the next few months, Chevron Australia's Greater Gorgon Area general manager Colin Beckett said yesterday. [...] He said the Gorgon project, a joint venture with ExxonMobil and Shell, would not detract from Chevron's proposed, nearby Wheatstone LNG project.

title: Gorgon seals first gas sale
news: [...] IN A further sign that the massive $50 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas development is building up steam, part owner ExxonMobil has made its first sales deal for the project. Exxon, which has a 25 per cent stake in Gorgon, said it and Indian LNG importer Petronet had agreed on ``intent to supply'' 1.5 million tonnes of LNG a year for 20 years from the project. The pair said they hoped to have binding agreements on the supply, to India's yet to be built Kochi terminal on the country's southeast coast, in 6. Commercial details of the deal were confidential, Exxon said. After decades of planning and delays, Gorgon, Australia's biggest resources development, is due to be approved by its partners Chevron, Shell and Exxon this year. Last month, the project won approval from Western Australia's Environmental Protection Agency to run three production units capable of producing 15 million tonnes of LNG a year from Barrow Island, off the state's coast.[...]

title: ANWR lobby weakens as issue heats up; Majors defect from group, though funding from Alaska stays strong
news: Arctic Power does not disclose which oil companies actively support its lobbying efforts to open the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas leasing, but the number of majors appears to have dwindled to one: ExxonMobil. Arctic Power, which has strong financial backing from the state of Alaska, is the main pro-ANWR lobbying group. The disclosure this week that ConocoPhillips had quit the organization (the company said it actually withdrew in mid-2004), follows BP's withdrawal in late 2002. CHEVRONTEXACO was thought to still be a member, but a spokesman very belatedly revealed Jan 6 the company "withdrew its support for Arctic Power in 2000." The spokesman said he did not know CHEVRONTEXACO's reasons for quitting the group. […] ConocoPhillips "clearly recognized that drilling in the refuge would be a risky business and that participating in Arctic Power's pro-drilling efforts was not ultimately in the company's best interests," said Michael Leone, vice president of Green Century Capital Management, which manages "environmentally screened" mutual funds. […] None of the companies that quit Arctic Power categorically rejected the possibility of drilling on the coastal plan should the opportunity present itself. The BP spokesman said in 2002 that while the company would not join the lobbying effort, "we would consider [drilling] if we could do it in environmentally sound ways, if it makes business sense, and depending on how it looks in terms of our opportunities in the rest of the world." […]

title: Carbon prices fall to record low in the wake of MEP vote; Vote rejected proposals to intervene in carbon credit market
news: Carbon prices fell to a record low yesterday after MEP's voted against proposals to intervene in the carbon credit market by back-loading the auctioning of carbon allowances. […] Emissions ceiling. The EU's emissions trading system, established in 2005, set an overall emissions ceiling. Beneath this ceiling, companies receive or buy credits auctioned by member states. But the economic slowdown has meant that some companies are emitting well below the ceiling, leading to an oversupply on the market. About 100 Irish entities are covered by the ETS, including power stations and big industrial producers such as CRH, Kerry Group and pharmaceutical companies such as PFIZER. The European Commission had proposed that an auction of 900 million carbon allowances scheduled to take place between 2013 and 2015 be postponed to the years 2019 to 2020, in a bid to boost the price. But MEP's yesterday ruled against this, with 334 MEPs voting in favour of an amendment rejecting the proposal, 315 voting against it and 63 abstaining.[…]

title: How to make a business sustainable; To be truly so, a company must optimise offerings in a way that also maximises business performance
news: COMPANIES around the world are wrestling with the issue of how to make their businesses more sustainable - using less energy and water, reducing their waste and greenhouse gas emissions, and improving their impact on society for everything from labour standards to community involvement to product safety.[…] Government regulations on sustainability issues are becoming increasing stringent. Companies that fail to comply face growing financial penalties, restrictions on their business operations, and negative publicity. While this trend has been emerging for quite awhile, a recent IBM Institute for Business Value study, Leading a Sustainable Enterprise, conducted with business leaders from around the world showed that most are unprepared to measure and improve their own sustainability or that of their suppliers. For example, while many companies have ambitious goals to reduce CO2 emissions, in our study only 19 per cent were measuring it often enough to make substantive changes to their operations to lower emissions. […] The author is Senior Vice-President and Managing Partner of IBM Global Business Services. In Singapore for the APEC CEO Summit 2009, he will share IBM's point of view on sustainable development in a panel discussion on 'Meeting the challenge of sustainable development: Are there trade-offs with economic growth? What role does technology have to play?'

title: CHEVRONTEXACO pulls out of Cheniere LNG project, leaving plans in doubt
news: CHEVRONTEXACO dealt a sharp blow to Cheniere Energy's proposed Sabine Pass LNG terminal this week when it pulled out of negotiations for an equity interest in the 2.6 Bcf/day Gulf Coast project. The breakdown is almost certain to delay the project, which received its final environmental impact statement from FERC last month and was expected to begin construction early next year. And while neither company is offering much in the way of explanation, the move raises a host of questions about both firms' future LNG plans. […] New equity. CHEVRONTEXACO's withdrawal "means a whole round of new negotiations with somebody else," said Chris Ellsworth, manager of natural gas and LNG for Science Applications International. "I think it's going to set the project back a while depending on how fast they can find a new equity participant." […]

title: New US envoy takes a clean U-view
news: The new US Ambassador to Australia said yesterday that uranium exports to China would help cure that country's pollution problems. On his first visit to Perth since taking up his post in 8, Robert McCallum Jr said Australia was a responsible member of the international nuclear power community. […] The WA Labor Government has said repeatedly it would not relax its anti-uranium mining policy but Mr McCallum said Australia's safe-guard agreements were a positive thing for Australia and China. "What Australia determines to do in terms of the number of mines and the amount of exports it makes is an internal matter for Australia to determine," Mr McCallum said. "There are obviously risks to nuclear energy but it has certain environment advantages that are generally recognised over the sort of alternatives that exist and the internal environmental problems that exist in China are certainly significant and challenging. "So if they are able to find ways that support their economy that minimise the sort of environmental consequences that they are now experiencing, that would appear to be a very positive thing." Mr McCallum met Alan Carpenter on Thursday and has also met representatives of American oil and gas giant CHEVRON, which is developing the massive Gorgon gas field off the WA coast. […]

title: $15bn gas deal surprise
news: TWO new projects worth $15 billion are set for the North-West Shelf in Australia's biggest ever resources development.In a surprise development yesterday, the Federal Government designated the huge Gorgon liquefied natural gas scheme for environmental assessment. […] The Gorgon development, controlled by the CHEVRON, Texaco, Ampolex Ltd and Shell companies, received formal designation yesterday from the Federal Resources Minister, Mr Beddall, for environmental assessment. Many analysts have predicted that either the Gorgon project or the NWS expansion will proceed. […] Environmental designation under federal legislation "represents an important step in the Commonwealth facilitation and approval of what could be a project of great importance to Australia's economy", Mr Beddall said.[…]

title: Green policies sway the markets; U.S. coal stocks hit
news: […] "We believe climate change is one of the major themes that will drive growth for companies across markets," said Simon Webber, portfolio manager at Schroders PLC, a global asset manager based in London.[…] Auto industry players not focused in this direction, he added, will likely struggle, because "they won' t have the products that consumers want to buy or regulators want in the market." On the retailing front, meanwhile, Mr. Webber believes opportunities to play the climate-change game lie with the big online retailers such as AMAZON.com Inc. and eBay Inc. that have a significantly smaller environmental footprint than do traditional bricks and mortar players. "Online retailers have fewer energy requirements and more efficient distribution, so we think they have an advantage," he said.[…]

title: Energy - The US's energy glut Energy
news: Few Americans, let alone anybody else, would have heard of Williston, a tiny town of 15,000 on North Dakota's prairie. But it is starting to get noticed. While most of the US is struggling amid an economic slump and high unemployment, Williston is booming. Such is the demand for labour that the local McDonald's fast-food restaurant was recently offering USD300 signing-on bonuses, while workers doing night shifts at petrol stations are reputedly being paid USD15 an hour. Roads in the once-sleepy streets are now clogged with traffic. […] Analysts doubt that the trend is a short-term one, given the vast shale oil deposits in the US still to be tapped. "Shale oil represents a paradigm shift," says Seth Kleinman, global head of energy strategy at Citi. "Over the next three to four years, there's the potential to get an extra 3 million to 4 million barrels daily out of the US. That's dependent on prices and regulation, but it's not an outrageous forecast." […] Shale has already had profound consequences in the US. It is not inevitable that its effect on the rest of the world will be as significant. A crash in oil or gas prices could halt shale projects and cause drillers to stop investing in research. The expense of LNG technology will hinder the establishment of a world gas market for years to come. And environmental fears, particularly in Europe, have yet to be allayed. But most people who have had direct experience of shale energy play down such concerns and argue that its impact will be deep and lasting. Peter Voser, chief executive of Shell, an organisation scarcely known for its hyperbole, recently said that "the natural gas revolution is the most significant energy development in decades". So much so that Shell thinks it will, for the first time in its history, produce more gas than oil this year. […]

title: OPEC proposal targets building refineries; Link to investment in drilling possible
news: OPEC nations, holders of about three-quarters of world oil reserves, may link foreign investment in their most profitable drilling ventures to agreements to build refineries, the group's president said. By doing so, the group can revive investment in oil refining, an industry that until two years ago was overlooked because of its poor returns relative to those available from pumping crude oil, said Sheik Ahmad Fahd al-Sabah, Kuwait's oil minister and the current president of the 11-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. […] A lack of investment in new oil refineries in the United States and Europe has contributed to the two-year rally in oil prices, as rising demand strained gasoline supplies. Oil companies such as CHEVRON Corp. will need greater access to OPEC oil deposits to prevent their reserves from declining as fields mature in the Gulf of Mexico and North Sea. […] San Ramon, Calif.-based CHEVRON, the second-largest U.S. oil company, is willing to consider combined investments in oil exploration and refining, said James LeJeune, president of the company's business for the Middle East and North Africa. "If there is a commercial link between the two, that is the issue," he said. Environmental regulations and varying laws on fuel specifications have restricted investment in the oil refining business. No new refineries have been built in the United States in about 30 years. The lack of refining capacity is a concern to OPEC ministers because it's contributing to high crude oil prices, Mr. al-Sabah said. […]

title: Talks to fire up multibillion-dollar California LNG deals
news: WINNING the confidence of jittery Americans was the biggest hurdle to scoring multibillion-dollar gas contracts with California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, Ian Macfarlane said yesterday. The Industry, Tourism and Resources Minister will meet Mr Schwarzenegger's resources secretary, Mike Chrisman, in California later this week to promote BHP Billiton's liquefied natural gas (LNG) project and several other proposals from companies with lucrative Australian gas assets. These companies include Santos, Woodside and global giants CHEVRONTEXACO and ExxonMobil. The meeting with Mr Chrisman follows Prime Minister John Howard's "very positive" talks with Mr Schwarzenegger in Los Angeles last Wednesday to promote BHP Billiton's proposal to ship LNG to a massive floating terminal the company plans to build 23km off the California coast. […] The proposal has stirred up opposition from at least two Californian councils -- Malibu and Oxnard -- and recently 25 US environmental groups sent a letter to Mr Chrisman requesting a meeting. The councils and groups fear the BHP Billiton project, expected to generate $A15 billion in Australian exports if approved, could become an environmental disaster or a terrorist target. Mr Macfarlane said easing US community fears would be the toughest task, although he talked up Australia's long safety record. "The biggest issue is allaying the safety and environmental concerns local people have," he said. […] "I think put that with our cultural alignment with the US and the fact some of these companies that own assets in Western Australia are American based, like CHEVRONTEXACO, as well as global companies like BHP Billiton, we feel we have a good opportunity." […]

title: Green is the colour of money as banks ride new wave; From eco-themed stock indices to green business, banks in S'pore are raising awareness among investors
news: [...] CITIGROUP published a thick report called 'Climatic Consequences: Investment Implications of a Changing Climate' on Jan 19 this year - the bank's first on the subject. And ABN Amro put out its maiden Eco-market Views report on Jan 25, explaining why eco-awareness surged in 2006. Not to be outdone, UBS the same month gave its private clients a 100-page report on 'Climate Change: Beyond Whether', outlining the science behind greenhouse gas emissions, emerging alternative energy technologies and attendant risks. Co-authored by about a dozen analysts across UBS's research groups, the report also featured interviews with the likes of consultant Amory Lovins of the Rocky Mountain Institute in the US and Matthias Kopp, finance and energy project manager for WWF (World Wildlife Fund For Nature) Germany. [...] Other banks are focusing on specific areas. For instance, Citibank's Sustainability Mining Index and Credit Suisse's alternative energy index, both created this year. [...]

title: Majors pass on main lobbying effort to unlock ANWR plain to oil drilling
news: Amid Republican predictions that Congress this year will finally authorize oil development in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge's coastal plain, ConocoPhillips Co., one of four major oil companies operating on Alaska's North Slope, confirmed last week that it has withdrawn from a large lobbying campaign for ANWR development. ConocoPhillips' move left only one of the majors, ExxonMobil Corp., as a participant in Arctic Power. Groups opposed to oil drilling in ANWR, who disclosed ConocoPhillips' departure from Arctic Power, hailed the move as evidence that the majors do not share the same enthusiasm for tapping the coastal plain's oil as do many Republican lawmakers. Michael Leone, vice-president of Green Century Capital Management, which manages "environmentally screened" mutual funds, said Wednesday that decisions by ConocoPhillips, BP and CHEVRONTEXACO Corp. to quit Arctic Power "certainly show that [opening ANWR] is not a high priority for them." […] While ConocoPhillips confirmed last week its decision to quit Arctic Power, the company said it actually left the group in mid-2004. A spokesman for CHEVRONTEXACO said his company dropped out of the lobbying group in 2000, a move that was not publicized at the time. BP pulled out of Arctic Power in 2002, a decision that was widely covered then. […] None of the companies that quit Arctic Power categorically rejected the possibility of drilling on the coastal plain should the opportunity present itself. BP said in 2002 that while the company would not join the lobbying effort, "we would consider [drilling] if we could do it in environmentally sound ways, if it makes business sense, and depending on how it looks in terms of our opportunities in the rest of the world." title: Kenya; Nairobi On List of Worst Places to Park
news: Nairobi drivers are among the most frustrated in the world according to a survey that was carried out by IBM. title: Plan vs oil spill

title: Whitman Cleared of Conflict Over Cleanups

Martin, who said Mrs.  Whitman had a conflict of interest in handling the sites because of her husband's business ties. title: Let's have some clear thinking on carbon price; G-BIZ
news: There's a lot of wild talk that does not help the national debate. THE morbid rhetoric is increasing already, ahead of next year's main game when the new multi-party climate change committee tries to nut out a policy that will put a price on carbon, garner support from the business community and pass through a greens-controlled Senate. One commentator moaned this week the government-appointed business committee on climate change was a "hanging committee" designed to "string up" the foreign owners of coal-fired power stations in Australia. Such hysteria augurs badly, as the fossil fuel lobby - and outright opponents to a carbon price - are very well represented on the committee, and there is nobody representing the renewables sector. NAB and Woodside Petroleum chairman Michael Chaney recently complained about how "thin skinned" politicians were, "threatening" business leaders who expressed their views. [...] Cutting through the climate change rhetoric has been Elaine Prior, head environment, social and governance analyst at CITIGROUP. Last week, in the wake of a Greenpeace report on lending to the coal industry in Australia (covered previously here), Prior and her colleagues tried to quantify the exposure of our big four banks if a price on carbon were to wipe out the value of their loans to coal-fired power stations. This is not far-fetched. As Greenpeace this week leafleted a Melbourne presentation by ANZ chief Mike Smith, and scaled the bank's Brisbane office to unfurl a huge "ANZ: polluting your world" banner . . . the banks are definitely worried - especially in Victoria's Latrobe Valley, where the first plant shutdowns are expected. Bank shareholders are worried, too. [...] After 20 years in broking and four years since she switched to the green side of the sharemarket, Prior thinks most environmental issues are "fairly marginal in terms of the valuation impact". Yes, she says, we've all been reminded of environmental risks by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill but it's easy to say that in hindsight. "What do you and I do when investing now . . . wipe $30 billion off the value of every oil company? No." Generally, however, she's seen some opportunities arising for investors - like renewable energy - and few material risks. [...]

title: Johnny-come-lately sets his sights too low; CAPITAL IDEA

title: H2O SMART; How a fast-growing Alberta town manages its water as if it were liquid gold
news: Dawn Heffernan faces a big challenge. Her southern Alberta town will max out its water supply this year. Since there is no prospect of getting more, there is only one solution: conservation. […]  "The availability of water on the planet is the same as it ever was, but it's often in inconvenient forms and there's more demand for it," says Peter Williams, chief technical officer of Big Green Innovations, an IBM "environmental incubator" set up to create businesses centred on solutions to environmental problems. Like Dr. Hayashi, he's concerned that we simply don't know enough about water, including how the water cycle works in many areas, how human activity affects it, and how we can use less water to do what we're doing today.  Many of his solutions have to do with monitoring water to find out exactly how it moves, how temperatures vary, and so forth. Okotoks knows how important this is, as their newly computerized water system helps them identify leaks. Alberta Agriculture also monitors water use on 1.3-million irrigated acres in a database that measures use on each quarter-section, along with information about crops, and can give farmers advance warning about droughts. title: 5 Injured in Explosion and Fire at Connecticut Chemical Factory
news: Five people were hurt, two of them seriously, when a chemical solvent exploded in a storage warehouse on the campus of PFIZER, the international pharmaceutical manufacturer. The warehouse and surrounding buildings were evacuated and roads to the 112-acre campus were blocked for three hours while the fire was extinguished. title: Innovation breeds optimism

title: Gas storage plan failure would not stop Gorgon
news: The giant Gorgon natural gas project on Barrow Island can still go ahead if plans to store millions of tonnes of greenhouse gases under the island fail, according to environmental conditions approved yesterday by State Environment Minister David Templeman. Although Colin Beckett, WA general manager for the Gorgon joint ventures majority partner CHEVRON, said there was no plan B if the controversial geosequestration technique failed, the conditions showed that there was "wriggle room" in the requirement to lock carbon dioxide in limestone reservoirs under the island. But while the conditions, which include strict monitoring provisions and an extra $60 million to protect the breeding grounds of the flat-backed turtle, indicate the company can propose alternatives to geosequestration "if injection is not considered feasible for all or some of the gas", a spokesman for Mr Templeman said the nature of the alternatives was not something that had yet been considered by the Government. Mr Templeman insisted that the project would not proceed if the 36 environmental conditions imposed yesterday were not met. […] Mr Beckett said CHEVRON and joint venture partners Exxon Mobil and Shell had spent more than $100 million on refining the gas injection technology so far and they were prepared to spend the same again to ensure that it worked. title: Marcellus drillers have ally in Pennsylvania's governor
news: Washington--Pennsylvania's new Republican governor planted his administration's flag firmly in the camp of drillers extracting natural gas from his state's portion of the Marcellus Shale, using his first budget speech to make clear the gas does not belong to the state but to the mineral rights holders. Saying he wants to make Pennsylvania the "Texas of the natural gas boom," Governor Tom Corbett last week unveiled a state budget with no severance tax on gas production while cutting the budget of the state's primary environmental regulator. Corbett also named a 30-member Marcellus Shale Commission that includes nine industry representatives and four from environmental groups. The commission is charged with producing a report by 7 detailing how Pennsylvania can create the most jobs and wealth from shale gas drilling while protecting the environment. Executives from all of the big Marcellus drillers--ExxonMobil, Chesapeake Energy, Range Resources, EQT, Chief Oil & Gas, and Chevron--were appointed, along with midstream operator NiSource. The commission will be led by Lieutenant Governor Jim Cawley.[...]

title: Gorgon decision bogs down
news: A final investment decision for the $11 billion-plus Gorgon gas project off Barrow Island has been pushed back until the end of the year, as the CHEVRON-led venture and government agencies wade through masses of documentation in a bid to secure final environmental approvals. Speaking at an International Business Council breakfast yesterday, Gorgon general manager Colin Beckett conceded it was taking longer than first expected to negotiate the environmental approvals process because of the sheer volume of information that had to be addressed. The Gorgon partners - CHEVRON, Shell and ExxonMobil - last year submitted a 2500-page draft environmental impact statement, which in turn attracted almost 30 responses raising 1100 different issues during a 16-week public comment period. Gorgon had expected to secure final investment approval early in the second half of the year, a target Mr Beckett said was now impossible. "Mid-2006 is not going to be possible, because the environmental approvals will not be granted by that time," he said. "Being realistic, we can't make the final investment decision until we've got the government approvals." Mr Beckett said the Environmental Protection Authority was expected to make its recommendation on siting LNG facilities on Barrow Island to the Government some time in May, which should enable Environment Minister Mark McGowan to make a decision in 7 or 8. title: No cause to stop drilling, N.L. says; St. John's wants evidence on BP spill

The federal-provincial agency that regulates offshore drilling tightened rules for CHEVRON after the Gulf disaster, but insisted it was safe to go ahead and suggested BP may have used questionable practices. CHEVRON will have to provide test results for the blowout preventer and activation systems at the well, after BP's blowout system failed inexplicably. There's discussion about the BOP (blowout preventer) valve not functioning in deep water. We have no evidence of that," Dunderdale said. title: MANAGEMENT; Reassessment After the Unthinkable Happens
news: […] Crisis management, always an important element of any corporate game plan, is suddenly at the center of strategic thinking at businesses across America. Often called business-contingency planning, it encompasses everything from the protection of electronic data to coping with catastrophes that threaten the very survival of a company. Since Sept. 11, many executives are coming to realize that such disasters are not as hypothetical as they once seemed. Hurricanes, floods, fires and violence in the workplace used to top the list of risks; now, of course, terrorist attacks do. Often, the feared episode is less than heart-stopping. Financial institutions, for example, are required by federal law to have disaster-recovery plans in place to protect customer accounts. Oil producers like CHEVRONTEXACO and BP maintain emergency-response networks of lawyers, doctors and even press-relations officials to deal with potential debacles akin to that of the Exxon Valdez spill in 1989. […] Disaster-recovery specialists come from backgrounds as varied as information technology, risk management and auditing. But one thing they have in common is their ability to be generalists, too -- to grasp the big picture of how the various departments of their organization mesh with one another. […]

title: Gain with the wind; INVESTING
news: Human activity may be raising the temperature of the planet, or maybe just the rhetoric is overheated. Either way, the phenomenon of global warming presents some interesting investment opportunities. The most obvious place to seek them out is among producers of renewable energy, like wind and solar power. The case for investing in these industries has hinged on the fact that supplies of fossil fuels are finite and increasingly costly to extract. That has not been enough to make alternatives commercially viable, but their proponents contend that concern about warming will increase demand and change the economics. […] Robb Parlanti, an analyst and fund manager at Turner Investment Partners in Berwyn, Pennsylvania, likes a diverse range of alternative energy producers and related businesses, including Cameco, a Canadian company that controls 20 percent of the world's supply of uranium, and Ormat Technologies, a specialist in geothermal energy. Rather, it lies in the tentative first steps taken to get Australia into the greenhouse gas emissions reduction game. title: Paying for carbon offsets: U.S. agency questions where the money goes; Business of Green
news: Corporations and shoppers in the United States spent more than $54 million last year on carbon offset credits toward tree planting, wind farms, solar plants and other projects to balance the emissions created by, say, using a laptop computer or flying on a jet. But where exactly is that money going? The Federal Trade Commission, which regulates advertising claims, raised the question Tuesday in its first hearing in a series on green marketing, this one focusing on carbon offsets.   As more companies use offset programs to create an environmental halo over their products, the commission said it was growing increasingly concerned that some green marketing assertions were not substantiated. Environmentalists have a word for such misleading advertising: ''greenwashing.'' With the rapid growth of green programs like carbon offsets, ''there's a heightened potential for deception,'' said Deborah Platt Majoras, chairwoman of the commission. […]   Continental Airlines lets travelers track the carbon impact of their itineraries. General Electric and BANK OF AMERICA will translate credit card rewards points into offsets. […] The F.T.C. has not accused anyone of wrongdoing --  neither the providers of carbon offsets  nor the consumer brands that sell them. But environmentalists say -- and the F.T.C.'s hearings suggest -- that it is only a matter of time until the market faces greater scrutiny from the government or environmental organizations. […]

title: CSR today, integrated reporting tomorrow; With companies realising it's not enough to just make profits, their annual reports are set to change in due course

On the other hand, financial reporting on a quarterly or yearly basis has a direct impact on, say, their bonuses or performance shares. On the flip side, although socially responsible investing is increasing, the majority of market participants today are still very much short-term oriented. title: Big hitters aim to clean up on carbon
news: Some of Australia's largest energy companies are positioning themselves for a carbon-restricted world but in the absence of a clear regulatory environment, they are uncertain how much to risk on investments to reduce emissions. Big hitters such as CHEVRON in Western Australia, Santos, Rio Tinto and Worley Parsons are all positioning themselves to take advantage of carbon-related opportunities. BP Australia and Rio Tinto are involved with hydrogen energy with carbon sequestration, also known as geosequestration, where carbon dioxide emissions are captured, compressed and injected deep underground. However, as the industry looks to make incremental improvements, Citigroup director of research Elaine Prior said regulatory clarity was required to formulate the framework for major project decisions. […] Other firms are making moves to pounce on carbon-related breaks such as General Electric's Ecomagination products, which are part of its wider corporate sustainability initiatives targeting renewable energy, clean coal and products ranging from lower emissions aircraft engines and hybrid locomotives to recycled bottle chandeliers and disposable paper office furniture. title: CSG better for the atmosphere, but not a cure-all EMISSIONS - FARMS VERSUS MINES -
news: Coal-seam gas processing requires more wells and drilling, and produces toxic methane THE good thing about coal-seam gas, from a greenhouse gas perspective, is that it contains no embedded carbon dioxide, unlike the nation's gas reserves off Australia's northwest coast and in South Australia's Cooper Basin.  A negative, and what Greens leader Bob Brown has latched on to, is that CSG can require thousands more wells to be drilled to get out the same amount of gas. This means more carbon is emitted when drilling and producing the gas. And there is the risk that the gas -- which is essentially methane -- will escape into the atmosphere before it is burned to provide electricity. [...] Elaine Prior, an analyst at investment bank Citi, released a study this week that analysed the environmental impact statements of the big LNG plants, as well as industry group information on coal and gas. Her findings back up industry claims that CSG plants produce between 50 and 60 per cent of the carbon emissions of black coal, when extraction, transport and power generation is included. Ms Prior said 36 per cent of the emissions from the CSG burned in power plants and production came from production of the gas, processing and transport, versus just 7 per cent in coal-fired stations. On the fugitive emissions, Citi went with industry assumptions that 0.1 per cent of the gas is lost when CSG is produced and converted to LNG for export. [...]

title: Environment considerations remain important
news: Environment, safety and governance issues need to be part of investment decisions, writes Kate Burgess. If anything, the federal government's decision to defer the carbon pollution reduction scheme in March has come as a welcome reprieve, freeing researchers from the machinations of the political game to focus on other environmental issues.  "I'd done enough analysis of the CPRS and worked out the likely impact and how it was structured," CITIGROUP analyst Elaine Prior says. title: CHEVRON boss opens up

[...] In an interview, Mr Watson, 55, has outlined his views on the industry. [...] Q: Do fossil fuel producers bear the responsibility for curbing greenhouse gas emissions? WATSON: We have the responsibility to deliver our energy in an environmentally sound fashion. The greatest advancements in living standards in recorded history have taken place in the modern hydrocarbon era. I don't think that's coincidental. Our leaders have to make a decision. Do they want that to continue or do they have a better solution for us? So it's not my call. Q: How should society go about reducing greenhouse gas emissions? WATSON: If you look around the world, the countries with the best environmental practices are the wealthiest. There's a reason for that. If you're worried about where your next meal is going to come from or shelter over your head, your focus is on those things.[...]

title: Cameroon; WB Group Approves Support for Chad-Cameroon Development
news: Washington - The Board of the World Bank Group today overwhelmingly agreed to support the Chad-Cameroon Petroleum Development and Pipeline Project - an unprecedented framework to transform oil wealth into direct benefits for the poor, the vulnerable and the environment. In addition to the financing, the package of support includes a first-of-its-kind program to direct new revenues to support economic and social development programs in Chad, which is one of the world's poorest countries. The project, which is expected to cost $3.7 billion, will develop the oil fields at Doba in southern Chad and construct a 1,070 km pipeline to offshore oil-loading facilities on Cameroon's Atlantic coast. The sponsors are ExxonMobil of the U.S. (the operator, with 40 percent of the private equity), Petronas of Malaysia (35 percent), and CHEVRON of the U.S. (25 percent). Depending on world oil prices, the project could yield up to $2 billion in revenues for Chad and $500 million for Cameroon over the 25-year production period. […] Protecting the Environment. Any large project of this nature entails risks for the natural environment. From the start, the environmental risks of this project were seen to be significant but manageable. Numerous issues were identified, but in all cases adequate measures have been designed to deal with them. There was considerable work in studying alternative routings and induced - not just direct - impacts. National experts, Bank Group specialists, and consortium personnel walked the entire pipeline route to double-check data from aerial surveys. These analyses were summarized in a 19-volume Environmental Impact Assessment and Management Plan, the first draft of which became available in 6 1998. The final version was made public in 6 1999 and additional information regarding the oil spill response plan was made available in October 1999. These documents were the subject of regular exchanges of views with local and international NGOs. Those discussions were aimed at ensuring that the project planners were studying the full range of potential risks and applying the appropriate standards of environmental protection. […] Human Rights. […]

title: Manufacturers Divided On Emissions Cap

Automakers say oil companies should produce more alternative fuels while the oil industry is pushing for more fuel-efficient cars, the Journal reports. CHEVRON Corp. issued a statement saying, "We have a long history of working with the auto industry to create cleaner, more efficient fuels, and we will continue to support efforts to make the U.S. auto and light-vehicle fleet more fuel efficient." The American Iron and Steel Institute has said it opposes any additional CO2 controls because that's already been addressed through the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The National Association of Manufacturers also has said it opposes an emissions cap. […]

title: Lack of will on climate hobbling carbon trade; Visions of global exchanges disintegrating as countries refuse to adopt strict emission limits
news: Touted by its supporters as the best and cheapest way to fight global warming, carbon trading is losing momentum amid the uncertainty created by the failure of the Copenhagen summit meeting and President Barack Obama's political troubles in the United States. Investors are steering clear of energy-saving projects meant to generate carbon credits, and traders in Europe are hunkering down through a period of consolidation that is disappointing to those who had hoped carbon markets would grow quickly into a $2 trillion-a-year business. […] While green financiers and others are still starting projects in the developing world, those firms cannot count on returns from carbon credits and must find other, more reliable funding streams. Abyd Karmali, the global head of carbon markets at BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch and president of the Carbon Markets & Investors Association trade group in London, estimated that new investments in such projects fell 30 percent to 40 percent in 2009 and will probably slide another 40 percent to 50 percent this year. The failure at Copenhagen also makes it less likely that Europe will adopt a more stringent target for cutting carbon emissions by 2020 than the 20 percent reduction that it has already pledged.[…]

title: Capturing Carbon's Potential INTRODUCTION: Will the chemical industry benefit from carbon capture technology?
news: CARBON CAPTURE and sequestration (CCS) technology might still be at an experimental and development stage, but several companies, including those in the chemical industry, are lining up to take advantage of its opportunities. [...] Post-combustion capture involves chemical stripping of CO2 using amine solvent scrubbing, membrane separation or cryogenic separation after the combustion of the fossil fuel for the generation of power. It can be retrofitted to conventional power plants but is said to be expensive, according to a CCS report from US-based CITIGROUP Research. [...] The process, according to CITIGROUP, involves the removal of CO2 using the same methods as post-combustion, but the fossil fuel is gasified first by reacting with oxygen or steam prior to power generation. Hydrogen is also produced in this process. [...] Oxyfuel combustion, which is still at a demonstration phase, can be retrofitted to conventional power plants, according to CITIGROUP. The process involves burning fuel in a nearly pure oxygen environment, resulting in a concentrated exhaust gas stream of CO2, which is either absorbed using solvents or adsorbed onto membranes and subsequently captured. [...] US-based Eastman Chemical, which has many years of experience in coal-gas technologies to produce feedstock for its chemical processes, also has a big interest in CCS development aside from reducing CO2 emissions, CITIGROUP reported. "Eastman has an interest in the use of CO2 in enhanced oil recovery and is carrying out its project development and testing in the US," CITIGROUP said. Industrial gases companies such as Linde, Air Liquide, of France, Praxair and Air Products, both US, are also expected to gain. Large quantities of oxygen are required for both the IGCC and oxy-combustion processes, according to CITIGROUP. These companies can also deploy their skills in CO2 purification and transport, as well as provision specialized equipment. [...] Both Praxair and Air Products are principally involved in US projects, says CITIGROUP, while Linde is mostly working on European projects. [...]

title: BP shares rebound from low
news: NEW YORK: Shares of BP bounced off a 14-year low yesterday, rising 9 per cent in New York, as the oil giant assured investors that it can deal with the cost of the giant oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Shares dropped 16 per cent to US$29.20 on Thursday - the worst day for BP shares since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded seven weeks ago - and the lowest price for the stock since 1996. [...]In a research note, Citi Investment Research analyst Mark Fletcher said that BP's shares were undervalued. [...]

title: CHEVRON gas surprise hits $12b Woodside Pluto play
news: Woodside Petroleums hopes of securing CHEVRON as a partner to underpin the expansion of its much-heralded $12 billion Pluto project suffered a major blow yesterday when the US energy giant said it would push ahead with a stand-alone liquefied natural gas project in the Pilbara. But CHEVRONs decision to snub Woodside in favour of its own $10 billion-plus on-shore facility to process LNG from its huge Wheatstone gasfield is likely to attract intense scrutiny from WAs environmental lobby, which in the past has raised concerns about development on the Pilbara coast. CHEVRON Australia managing director Roy Krzywosinski would not reveal the potential locations for Wheatstones onshore facilities other than to say he was considering "a handful" of sites. The sites are thought to be along the Pilbaras western coastline from the Burrup Peninsula to Onslow but do not include Barrow Island, where CHEVRON wants to develop on-shore facilities for its Gorgon LNG project. CHEVRON is expected to have a Burrup location at the top of its wish list but it is considered highly unlikely that such a proposal would receive the necessary regulatory approvals given the peninsulas environmental and Aboriginal heritage sensitivities. Any new LNG facility would also include a pipeline coming ashore and a jetty for LNG vessels to dock and be loaded, which is likely to require dredging of a shipping channel. […]
