title: 500 firms back Prince on climate
news: THE Prince of Wales has enlisted 500 leading companies to back calls for concerted action on climate change. Shell, BP, E.ON, EDF, Coca-Cola, eBay, Starbucks and Virgin are among the household names that have been persuaded by the Prince to sign a communique calling on world leaders to commit to cutting emissions by at least 50 per cent by 2050. [...] The statement is the latest move by the Prince of Wales to try to ensure that the United Nations climate change summit in Copenhagen in December delivers results. [...] The communique will be presented today at a UN climate summit in New York, which is designed to intensify the pressure on world leaders to secure agreement on cutting greenhouse gases. [...]

title: Exec: Reduce packaging, gain customers; Manufacturers give their take on the future of sustainability
news: Making value-chain decisions about sustainability requires moving beyond a simple grasp of peak oil, hybrids and carbon offsets. According to top-level sustainability executives at some of the plastics industry's biggest customers, the new must-knows are alternative energy sources, future environmental regulations, and consumer lifestyle changes that will drive future original equipment manufacturers decisions about which suppliers they choose. […] ``Some of the brand owners are actually viewing some of the sustainability benefits as a new opportunity to market and sell products. Historically ... [Dow has] been asked to come on and help the economics of their packaging materials but at the same time now, we're focusing on more of the sustainability and environmental impacts.'' The marketplace is a shifting sandpit of expectations, and standards, with no common solution to sustainability concerns, executives agreed. Mark Kitzis, global account vice president at Alcan Packaging, said in 2006, when Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s sustainable packaging scorecard was new, Wal-Mart's sustainability initiatives were a standard reference for OEMs. That has changed. ``Some are trying to meet Wal-Mart's requirements [but] with the economy where it's been, we've seen a lot of our customers moving away from some of the bio solutions because of the costs and instead focusing on reducing and resizing.'' […] The sustainability panel included executives from some of the world's biggest plastic film buyers, including Kellogg, Frito-Lay North American Inc. and Sara Lee Corp. Brad Rodgers, Frito-Lay's manager of sustainable packaging and advanced material research, said his company is expanding its efforts with suppliers to include their suppliers, for a more cost-effective and earth-friendly approach all along the chain. […]

title: NATIONAL BIKE WEEK: USE YOUR PEDAL POWER
news: NATIONAL Bike Week's principal aim is to get more people to cycle, more often. This aim can be achieved by giving people the chance to rediscover the joys of cycling, raise awareness of health and environmental benefits of cycling and promote cycling as a means of transport and as a leisure pursuit. The programme is fully supported by all NI Civil Service Departments and is financially assisted by a sponsorship package from COCA COLA Bottlers (Ulster) Ltd. This year NICSSA has teamed up with DoE (NI) Transportation Unit and COCA COLA Bottlers (Ulster) Ltd to encourage all members of the public to literally "Get on Yer Bike" as part of National Bike Week.[…]

title: Exxon-Led Group Is Giving A Climate Grant to Stanford
news: Four big international companies, including the oil giant Exxon Mobil, said yesterday that they would give Stanford University $225 million over 10 years for research on ways to meet growing energy needs without worsening global warming. […] The initiative is a small step toward what a diverse group of scientists, writing recently in the journal Science, said must be an enormous effort to find clean energy sources for an expected tripling of global demands by midcentury. In addition to Exxon Mobil, the contributors are General Electric, which said it would give $50 million; E.ON, a large German energy company with nuclear and conventional power plants, giving $50 million; and Schlumberger, the oil-field technology company, giving $25 million. Environmental campaigners noted that Exxon Mobil told investors last month that it was plowing $100 billion over the next decade into a search for new oil and gas reserves. The money for climate research is "only one-tenth of 1 percent of what Exxon Mobil will spend over the same time exploring and developing new sources of oil and gas," said Pete Altman, the coordinator of a shareholder group pressing to change the company's environmental practices. That development, Mr. Altman said, "is what is causing global warming in the first place."

title: Food giants join forces to reduce packaging
news: POWERFUL international food and drink manufacturers have joined moves to cut the amount of packaging they use in a bid to reduce waste. Nestle, Coca-Cola, Oxo, Mars and Hovis are among those who have said they want to stop the increased use of packaging by next year and reverse it by 2010. [...]

title: Judge Blocks Shipment of Oil Equipment Through Idaho Forest
news: SEATTLE -- A federal judge ordered a halt on Friday to more shipments of immense loads of oil field equipment through a national forest in north-central Idaho, pending a broad review of effects on the route.  The review will be conducted by the United States Forest Service in consultation with the Nez Perce Indians, whose tribal rights and lands near the forest route were central to the judge's ruling. The case was brought by the Nez Perce tribe and an environmental group, Idaho Rivers United, charging that the Forest Service had failed to enforce its own rules and standards in protecting the forest and a river corridor through which a first shipment, known as a megaload and bound for Canada's tar sands oil fields, was sent last month. A second shipment was scheduled for next week. The loads are more than 250 feet long and weigh about 644,000 pounds. […] The equipment supplier, Resources Conservation Company International, an affiliate of GENERAL ELECTRIC, said in a statement that the injunction delayed delivery of machinery that could save billions of gallons a year in water, which is used in vast amounts in the type of oil recovery used at the tar sands. The company also said it was reviewing its options. ''There are significant environmental benefits associated with these particular shipments,'' the company said. […]

title: Alcatel-Lucent Introduces New Chip for Greener Internet
news: Alcatel-Lucent has unlocked the potential for radical new Internet applications and services with a technology seen as the key to greater capacity, faster connections and reduced congestion on the web. The next-generation chip is expected to dramatically enhance the infrastructure needed to access rich new online services, from broadcast-quality high-definition video conferencing to applications in the business and professional world. The new 'FP3' chip, according to Alcatel, will eliminate the bottlenecks preventing such services from taking off today, widening the Internet's digital highways while enabling dramatically higher data speeds and improving traffic flow. […] Major telecom operators, including BT, NTT and VERIZON, he said today welcomed Alcatel-Lucent's announcement and its potential to enable faster, smarter and greener networks and applications.[…] Ihab Tarazi, Vice President Global Network Planning of VERIZON, said: "VERIZON continues to enhance the FiOS and wireless data broadband access capabilities for our customers and we have worked with Alcatel-Lucent to deploy next generation Ethernet and MPLS metro technology. In March of this year, VERIZON led the industry with a 100G Ethernet field trial based on Alcatel-Lucent's service router technology with its 100G FP2 silicon engine. We are excited to work with Alcatel-Lucent and continue to push the industry in technological innovation to support the significant growth of access data traffic."

title: Unibail's green bond sets high structural standard
news: Unibail-Rodamco, the French-Dutch property company, sold its first green bond on Wednesday, using a highly developed and comprehensive framework to monitor the use of proceeds, which will set a new reference point for future issuers. Jon Hay reports.[…] Not only is Unibail earmarking proceeds just for buildings that receive a Very Good or better rating for sustainability from Breeam, but it has employed Vigeo, the French sustainability rating agency, to monitor the assets' performance on a host of environmental, social and governance criteria.[…] Like Vasakronan, Unibail already had a strong sustainability track record. It has been garlanded with a string of sustainability and ethical business honours and accreditations, and likes to think of itself as one of the green leaders among European commercial property companies.[…] BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch and Crédit Agricole, the structuring banks, took Unibail on a roadshow from February 10 to 13, during which it presented its sustainable development policy as well as an update on its credit. Unibail is rated A/A+ with stable outlooks by Standard & Poor's and Fitch. Then on Tuesday, the same two banks held a conference call for investors, focused specifically on sustainability, and on presenting a possible green bond issue.[…] "Working out fair value for a 10 year was difficult," said Angus Reynolds, vice president of corporate syndicate at BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch in London, "because Unibail's seven to nine year curve is inverted."[…]

title: Jacob & Co. pumps up profile with Eves
news: Bay Street has a new niche investment bank, and this one wants to snag your power, infrastructure and energy deals. Jacob & Company Securities Inc., founded by Sasha Jacob, who launched the power and infrastructure group at Dundee Securities Corp., is focusing on renewable energy in the geothermal, wind, wave and hydro worlds. [...]

title: Methane Gas Leak Throughout Staten Island, Says Study
news: News: A study by the Environmental Defense Fund and  Google has found one leak per mile on Staten Island in New York City. Google's street view mapping cars, fitted with methane sensing technology was used to create a map of the leaks. 'They're not a threat to public safety but that have a real impact on the environment,' said the fund's associate vice president Mark Brownstein (CAPITAL). The nationwide environmental group is now expecting to work with regulators and utilities to target the leaks and repair the ageing infrastructure which has an environmental and monetary cost, Brownstein stated. In the US, methane leaks from natural gas pipelines account for more than 13mn metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: What's Outside Counts, Too: British Law Spurs Scrutiny of Excess Packaging
news: […] British regulations on excess packaging first took effect in 2003 in an effort to reduce waste, particularly items that cannot be recycled and go into a landfill. Those rules, strengthened two years ago in response to environmental concerns and an awareness that the nation's landfills were reaching their limits, now require that producers keep packaging to the minimum required for ''products' safety, hygiene and consumer acceptance.''[…] Landfills are an environmental concern partly because rotting trash releases methane, a potent greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming. Landfill taxes on unnecessary and excessive packaging will cost local governments about $4 billion per year, according to a study by the Local Government Association. Studies suggest that households could avoid generating more than half the waste that they produce. In the United States, the federal Environmental Protection Agency also encourages efforts to reduce packaging and household waste, but through low-key exhortation rather than inspections and regulations. The United States, unlike Britain, imposes no special federal tax on landfills, and weaker regulation makes it easier to expand them. Still, some companies like Wal-Mart and AMAZON.com are taking steps to trim their packaging for items sold in the United States. In Britain, excess packaging rules are policed by the Trade Standards Agency, whose local officers investigate consumer complaints like the ones that got the beef in trouble, as well as issues like counterfeiting.[…]

title: Wal-Mart plans huge move into organic food
news: Organic Rice Krispies, organic Frosted Mini Wheats and even organic PEPSI may define the future of American eating habits after Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, revealed plans for a huge expansion into pesticide-free foods. The all-powerful supermarket chain argued that its shift would democratise organic food in the US, bringing it within reach of shoppers who could not afford to pay a 20% or 30% premium. But critics say the effect will be to force down organic standards, squeeze farmers' incomes, and undermine health benefits. With up to 100,000 product lines, and almost 2,000 "supercentres" with an average floor space of 17,400 square metres (187,000 sq ft), Wal-Mart's decisions in large part determine the activities of big US food producers. Kellogg and Kraft are already working on organic versions of their products, PEPSI is planning organic products for later this year, and General Mills, which makes cereals such as Cheerios and Cocoa Puffs, will follow suit. "Environmental sustainability . . . will have huge impacts on the way things are made, farmed, packaged, transported, displayed and sold worldwide," the company's chief executive, Lee Scott, wrote recently. The chain has been stung by crit icism of its record in social responsibility - notably in the documentary Wal-Mart: the High Cost of Low Price - and recently opened two stores partly powered by wind turbines and solar panels. Its current move is more likely to have been motivated, however, by a recognition that organic food is now big business in the US. Though it accounts for only 2.4% of overall food sales, it has been growing at 15% a year or more, and is worth $14bn (£7.4bn). But an expansion by Wal-Mart could wreck the market, argued Ronnie Cummins, director of the US Organic Consumers Association. "When Wal-Mart places a gigantic order, the wholesalers start to lobby for lower standards, and outsource to places overseas where the standards are lower or the labour practices are horrible," he said.

title: MANY STATES GIVE POLLUTING FIRMS NEW PROTECTIONS
news: Urged on by a coalition of big industries, one state after another is adopting legislation to protect companies from disclosure or punishment when they discover environmental offenses at their own plants. The idea, advocates of the legislation say, is to encourage companies to monitor their own activities rigorously without fear that what they discover will be used against them. But opponents, including prosecutors, environmentalists, labor unions and lawyers for victims of pollution, say that polluters will exploit the laws to avoid adverse publicity and responsibility for illegal acts.   Alarmed by the trend, the Clinton Administration is warning that if states go too far to protect companies, it will withhold the authority that is commonly delegated to states to enforce Federal laws like the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act. All the important environmental statutes delegate enforcement to the states as long as the states meet Federal standards.[…] But even some big companies have opposed the proposals in favor of working with the E.P.A. to create other pollution-control strategies, rather than becoming adversarial. In Arizona, for instance, the INTEL Corporation came out against the proposed bill, saying the company preferred the E.P.A.'s approach. As the bills have been enacted in one state after another, some members of Congress have sought to put a similar provision into Federal law. It was tacked onto a spending bill in the House, but it was among the policy riders that were stripped when environmentalists protested.[…]

title: G.E. moves to go greener with fleet of electric cars;  Ambitious plan to shrink carbon footprint is also a boon for General Motors
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC announced an ambitious plan Thursday to reduce its carbon footprint - and support its new business in electric vehicle chargers. The company said it would buy 25,000 electric vehicles by 2015, including 12,000 from General Motors, starting with the Chevrolet Volt next year.  The Volt is technically a plug-in hybrid with a limited all-electric range. G.E. said it would convert ''at least half'' of its global fleet of 30,000 vehicles to electric cars, and would also act as a partner with fleet customers. The plan was originally announced in London last month by G.E.'s chairman and chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, but the company has now released details. G.E. said it would add other companies to its order list ''as manufacturers expand their electric vehicle portfolios.'' According to Bloomberg BusinessWeek, Mr. Immelt also said in London that half of the company's 45,000 sales force would drive electric cars. […] Parents of two children named Zoé Renault had argued in court that their children could end up enduring a lifetime of teasing. The families, who have no connection to the car company, wanted Renault to choose another name. Renault also makes cars called the Mégane and Clio, both popular girls' names in France, but there was no organized opposition to either name. The families' lawyer, David Koubbi, said he would appeal the decision.

title: Winemaker combats climate
news: Backsberg has done an audit to realise the carbon emission consequences of its farming. […] The carbon standard applied at Backsberg follows the Kyoto protocol on greenhouse gas emissions. The scientific nature of the carbon audit allows Backsberg to understand the magnitude of the sequestration solutions it needs to seek and develop, in order to reduce its carbon footprint and maintain a status of carbon neutrality going forward. The sequestration solutions developed by Backsberg will involve a greening programme within the nearby village of Klapmuts. This programme will be managed by the internationally respected Jeunesse Park, CEO of Food and Trees for Africa, the nonprofit national greening organisation driving the carbon-standard offset programme in SA. This collaboration will see Backsberg use the Food and Trees for Africa Carbon Standard logo. "We are indeed proud to be associated with Food and Trees for Africa," said Back, who believes that a whole new market sector with the emphasis on care, not only for the wine and the consumer, but also care for the environment is about to open. […] "Trees are the most efficient and simple means for us to store carbon, providing us with the air we breathe and absorbing the carbon dioxide we exhale and that is emitted in large quantities by our carbon based society," says Park, who was honoured with an International CHEVRON Conservation Award in California in October last year for her efforts to improve the quality of life for disadvantaged South Africans through natural resource improvements. Since the start of the Public Benefit Organisation 17 years ago, Food and Trees for Africa has distributed more then 2,5 million trees throughout SA. Whilst tree planting is crucial to the absorption of greenhouse gas emissions, it is equally important to develop more conservation-oriented practices by becoming more energy efficient for long-term sustainability. […]

title: Cashing in on rotting chickens and manure; STOCKS; MARKETPLACE by Bloomberg
news: First Reserve, the biggest private equity firm in the energy industry, expects a fivefold gain from rotting chickens and cow dung. That assumption is looking less preposterous. A consensus is emerging for U.S. legislation that encourages trading of credits earned from projects that reduce emissions of greenhouse gases and curb global warming. ''Giddy returns'' were probable, predicted Glenn Payne, director of First Reserve, who said the first sign of a new law would lead to a quintupling of credit values, to around $20 a ton of carbon dioxide, from $3.75 now. Profits from oil and natural gas over the next five years will increase less than 10 percent, futures prices show. […] GENERAL ELECTRIC, the world's largest maker of electric generators, and AES, a power plant builder, announced last month that they had created a joint venture for carbon emission credits. The venture will develop projects that cut U.S. greenhouse gas emissions by 10 million tons each year, creating 10 million credits, said Kevin Walsh, director of renewable energy at GE Energy Financial Services in Stamford, Connecticut. ''Our goal is to make this a viable business in a voluntary market and be a leader as it becomes regulated,'' he said. E.ON, the German utility that is the largest in the world, said this month that it would acquire credits by investing with banks in projects that curb greenhouse gases in the developing world. Speculators, including hedge funds, are replacing industrial companies as the biggest buyers of carbon credits, said Greg Spencer, chief executive of Blue Source. ''It's more about taking positions in a market that will appreciate significantly over time,'' he said.

title: Wealth awaits willing leaders; Investment - ECO BIZ
news: Some corporate chiefs say the transition to a low-carbon economy is the biggest opportunity they have seen, but Australia risks missing out, writes Steve Dow. Why should a business go green? Many executives are following the pack and spending the bare minimum on environmental sustainability because they fear a backlash by investors if they fail to clean up their company's act. Smarter business heads, however, have taken to heart advice given by two stars of the US business world to take the initiative; the chairman and chief executive of GENERAL ELECTRIC, Jeffrey Immelt, and the Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers venture capitalist John Doerr have nominated the trend towards low-carbon products and services as the biggest investment opportunity they have seen. The key is not only to reduce a company's carbon use but to embrace new and alternative technologies with export potential such as solar and wind power, recycling and clean-coal research that could create wealth back home. […] Australian investment groups are stepping gingerly into the political leadership vacuum. The Investor Group on Climate Change, with a membership of 21 Australian and New Zealand institutional investors managing a total of more than $375 billion in funds, last year issued a report in partnership with the international Carbon Disclosure Project, ranking business green credentials from a survey of 10 questions sent to the top 100 companies on the Australian Stock Exchange and top 50 companies on the New Zealand Stock Market. title: PERRY FARRELL IS BOXED IN
news: When Perry Farrell was getting ready to release the Columbia debut from his new band, Satellite Party, ecology weighed so heavily on his mind that he wanted the project to be available only digitally. But as often happens with well-intentioned environmental initiatives, economics quickly factored into the discussion. Sony Music executives pointed out that such an approach would truncate potential commerce in a world where, based on Nielsen SoundScan figures, digital accounts for about 24% of U.S. music sales. Also, such a move would have presented brick-and-mortar merchants with an uneven playing field. Instead, Farrell and Columbia came up with an eco-friendly, green Digipak made exclusively out of recycled paper.  […] Last October, in response to Wal-Mart's call for suppliers to consider the ecology when making and packaging their products, Universal Music Enterprises repackaged its "Millennium Collection" single-disc greatest-hits series in eco-friendly paperboard, using a PaperFoam tray instead of a plastic one. That package, from New York-based Shorewood Packaging, was about half the four-ounce weight of a normal jewel box CD.UME has also used the eco-pak for its new greatest-hits line, "No. 1's." So far the company has shipped about 5 million copies of eco-pak-encased CDs, UME executive VP/GM Mike Davis says.While a lighter package means less postage and less fuel spent transporting product, current automated loading equipment can't handle the new configuration. title: Shopping trends are getting greener
news: We are consumers all, and nothing says more than the state of our world - except reports on the state of our world, that is - than how we shop. Call it the greening of North America. In most every department store there are clothes made out of sustainable bamboo or organic cotton. In every grocery store there are shelves of organic products and produce. Environmentally friendly detergents and cleaning products are available at Jean Coutu, while the giant Wal-Mart has made a name for itself with its own sustainable practices. At Provigo and other stores, consumers receive a 5-cent discount off their bill for each bag they bring to the checkout, and we learned recently that our own SAQ has taken a great leap forward. As of this month, SAQ customers who ask for a paper or a plastic bag will have to pay, all part of their transition to 1 2009, when the company will completely eliminate single-use bags. […]

title: Uganda picks IBM and Waterfund to benchmark water infrastructure
news: Waterfund LLC and IBM (NYSE: IBM) said that they have signed an agreement with the Ministry of Water and Environment of the Republic of Uganda that makes the country the first in Africa to become a member of the pioneering Water Cost Index (WCI). Waterfund, with IBM acting as calculation agent, will work with the Ministry of Water and Environment to calculate the cost of producing water in Uganda. This work will reflect estimated water production costs measured in US dollars per cubic metre and be published as part of the Rickards Real Cost Water Index, to be updated monthly. The Rickards Real Cost Water Index will highlight the energy costs, interest rate risk, and capital expenditures required to build and maintain large-scale water treatment and delivery networks in Uganda. The FY 2012/2013 budget for the Ministry of Water and Environment to invest in the water sector is UGX 301.9bn (USD153mn), with plans to supply 77% of rural dwellers and 100% of urban dwellers with clean water by 2015. To achieve this aim, however, it will require Uganda to commit at least USD300mn per year of new investment to the water sector until 2020. For more information about IBM Smarter Water, visit www.IBM.com/smarterplanet/water.[...]

title: GE Energy provides clean energy products
news: Korea's first integrated gasification combined cycle power plant, a type of renewable energy production unit, broke ground last month in Taean, South Chungcheong Province. The 300-megawatt "cleaner coal" facility will turn coal into synthesis gas, then remove impurities from the coal gas before it is combusted and turn any pollutants into reusable byproducts, resulting in lower carbon emissions. Korea Western Power Co. picked GENERAL ELECTRIC as the supplier of a 7F Syngas Turbine, a D11 steam turbine, a heat recovery steam generator and associated equipment for the new plant in Taean, about 100 kilometers southwest of Seoul. GE also will provide 10 years of maintenance service for the plant.  "GE's syngas turbine technology underscores our company's commitment to powering the world with cleaner energy products," said Gong Sung-do, president of the Korean arm of GE Energy. "It supports a role for coal, an abundant and cost-effective fuel source, in a cleaner energy economy. We are very pleased that our technology has been selected by KOWEPO for this milestone project, which will demonstrate the important role IGCC can play in Asia's energy future." […] GE Korea aims to more than double its sales in the next three to four years. GE Energy Korea's sales this year are estimated to account for about 30 percent of GE Korea's total of $1.7 billion. GE Korea also has healthcare, aviation, transportation, capital and home and business solution businesses under its wing. […]

title: An offshore power core for U.S.; Transmission line plan would bypass barriers to supply East Coast
news: The proposed $5 billion transmission backbone for future offshore wind farms along the U.S. Atlantic Seaboard could transform the region's electrical map. FULL TEXT Google, Marubeni of Japan and a New York financial firm have agreed to invest heavily in a proposed $5 billion transmission backbone for future offshore wind farms along the U.S. Atlantic Seaboard that could ultimately transform the region's electrical map. The underwater spine, which would run 350 miles, or 560 kilometers, could remove some critical obstacles to wind power development and has stirred excitement among investors, government officials and environmentalists who have been briefed on it.  Google and Good Energies, an investment firm specializing in renewable energy, have each agreed to take 37.5 percent of the equity portion of the project. They are likely to bring in additional investors, which would reduce their stakes. […] Richard L. ''It is an opportunity to kick-start this industry and, long term, provide a way for the mid-Atlantic states to meet their renewable-energy goals,'' he said. title: ABN AMRO issue adds good citizen to Australian CDO market
news: […] The Rembrandt Australia Trust 2005-1 (Responsibility, Ethics, Environment, First [REEF] series 1) senior secured tranche of five-year double-A minus rated floating rate notes offered to investors are linked to the performance of a A$1.1 billion ($830.1 million) portfolio of investment grade CDOs containing companies considered "at the forefront of social responsibility," according to ABN AMRO. The portfolio of CDOs has a probability of default equivalent to at least triple-B minus. […] The 300 corporations referenced met corporate social responsibility criteria set by RepuTex Australia Pacific Pty Ltd, a private research and ratings agency specializing in corporate responsibility and reputation. The agency reviewed some 500 corporations worldwide before trimming the list down to 300 acceptable entities rated single-A minus or higher for their commitment to corporate governance, workplace practices, social impact, and environmental impact, ABN AMRO reported. The addition of social responsibility analysis on top of traditional credit ratings aims to identify broader corporate issues that could affect a company's future performance - such as environmental legislation, workplace cultures, labor markets and political exposure, the company wrote.There is growing demand from most western markets for products that are "as ethically strong as they are profitable," Richard Burrett, managing director at ABN AMRO's sustainable development, said in a May 27, statement. "Sustainability no longer applies to a set of values that shape a company's culture, it is an essential product ingredient demanded by modern markets, regardless of sector," he added.Reference entities in the REEF portfolio include companies from food and drug retailer Albertson's Inc. to telecommunications giant AT&T Corp. to the MBNA Corp. and insurer MetLife Inc. and McDonald's Corp.[…]

title: Support for energy from waste is long overdue
news: It largely slipped under the radar, but back in February the government directed the Ontario Power Authority to set up a program that would support the early development of energy-from-waste facilities in the province. Energy Minister Gerry Phillips, in a letter addressed to power authority chief executive Jan Carr, cited the need to test and evaluate new technologies that can turn municipal solid waste into electricity. Already, he pointed out, the government has streamlined the environmental approvals needed to build and operate such demonstration plants. "The goal of the initiative is to encourage the development of new or improved energy-from-waste technologies with improved environmental performance," wrote Phillips, hinting that the power authority should be prepared to pay 10 cents per kilowatt-hour for any demonstration project that falls within the initiative.  It's a long overdue move for a technology with significant potential. We're not talking incineration here, despite attempts by critics to brand it as such. There's no burning involved. What the technology does is use intense heat to break down the molecular structure of the waste. Once this is done, bad molecules are removed and the rest is chemically engineered into clean-burning synthetic gas - similar to natural gas. This "gasification" process is not squeaky clean, but it's better than the alternatives it aims to replace, including landfills on the waste side and coal on the energy side. […] The fact that GENERAL ELECTRIC is getting into the energy-from-waste business is, on its own, a telling sign that the technology has matured. […]

The world's largest retailer has pledged that all of its US fresh and frozen fish, excluding farmed fish, will eventually come from fisheries certified as being "sustainable" by the Marine Stewardship Council, meaning that the sea areas they come from are not being over-fished. title: PEPSICO UK pimps its ride for potatoes
news: PEPSICO UK estimates it will save one million food miles from British roads by transporting spuds and packaged products together and sharing lorries with the multiples. The PEPSI and Walkers crisps owner has announced plans to combine two thirds of its British potato cargo with its normal deliveries to allow drivers to drop off finished products to supermarkets en route to potato farms.  The integration would save just under 300,000 miles a year, the company said. Other improvements to trucks included low-friction tyres, hi-tech journey planning software and aerodynamic vehicle designs. The remaining 700,000 miles would be eliminated through working with the multiples to share lorries.  "This initiative reduces costs and improves productivity," said Walter Todd, vice president of operations at PEPSICO. "It also reinforces our commitment to cutting carbon emissions and becoming a more environmentally sustainable business." The initiative was warmly welcomed by retailers trying to meet their own green targets. "This is a fantastic partnership and a great example of how companies can work together to minimise their environmental impact," said Dominic Burch, head of corporate communications at Asda.

title: Carbon labelling - Carbon footprinting steps into the limelight
news: While the issue of environmental impact has been making headlines for some time, CO2 labelling on products is still in its infancy. But, says Jill Park, under new government plans, this is set to change. Environment minister Hilary Benn called for the development of clearer carbon labelling when he launched the Food 2030 report on the future of food security last month. But use of the labels is still scarce within the industry. Tesco first dipped its toe in the water by labelling 30 products, including orange juice, light bulbs, laundry, potatoes and tomatoes, in 2008, while Walkers has labelled its crisps. But how close are we to a label for all products and would consumers actually understand what it means? title: Now green costs less; Ecological goods gain as oil prices rise

title: 'Fair trade' brand helping Brazilian farmers
news: Rafael de Paiva was skeptical at first. If he wanted a ''fair trade'' certification for his coffee crop, the Brazilian farmer would have to adhere to a long list of rules on pesticides, farming techniques, recycling and other matters. He even had to enroll his children in school. ''I thought, 'This is difficult,' '' Paiva recalled. But the 20 percent premium he recently received for his first fair trade harvest made the effort worthwhile, he said, adding that it ''helped us create a decent living.'' More farmers are likely to see similar offers as importers and retailers rush to meet growing demands from consumers and advocates to adhere to stricter environmental and social standards.  Starting in November, Paiva's beans will be in the store-brand coffee sold by Sam's Club, the warehouse chain owned by Wal-Mart. Dunkin' Donuts, McDonalds and Starbucks already sell some fair-trade coffee. […]

title: US firms sign agreement on development of Tanzanian power plant
news: Text of report headlined "Giant US firms sign pact on power production in Mtwara" published by Tanzanian newspaper The Guardian website on 21 6 US-based energy companies Symbion Power and GENERAL ELECTRIC International yesterday struck a deal for developing the long-awaited 400 MW gas-fired power plant in Mtwara. The move is seen by many as an important step in the wake of gas driven crisis in the Tanzania's south eastern most region.  A "cooperation agreement" was formally signed by Jay Ireland, president and CEO-GE Africa, and Don Brindle, general manager of Symbion Power Tanzania Limited and witnessed by Energy and Minerals Minister Prof Sospeter Muhongo. The world's power giants signed the multibillion agreement yesterday and the government is calling it a 'testimony of its commitment to respond to the Mtwara crisis'. […] Don Brindle, Symbion Power-Tanzania general manager expressed his company's enthusiasm in continuing its long-term relationship with GE, noting that natural gas is an environmentally friendly and efficient energy source. "Working with GE on the project will make our work much easier as we will have access to proven technology and technical advice that is crucial for accelerated completion of this project," said Brindle. […]

title: Why climate is right for change of attitude; SUSTAINABLE INDUSTRIES LEGISLATION MPs vote means Bill almost certain to become law Carbon-sensitive firms can count on standard
news: The UK's Climate Change Bill now looks certain to become law after MPs voted overwhelmingly in favour of the landmark legislation.  MPs cleared the Bill with a huge majority after ministers moved to include greenhouse gas emissions from international aviation and shipping in carbon cutting targets. […] It's now easier for businesses to assess the carbon footprint of their goods and services with the help of a newstandard launched by BSI British Standards, the Carbon Trust and Defra.  The standard - called PAS 2050 - is a consistent way of counting the greenhouse gas emissions embedded in goods and services throughout their entire life cycle - from sourcing raw materials, through tomanufacture, distribution, use and disposal.  The aimof the new standard is to help businesses move beyond managing the emissions their own processes create and to look at the opportunities for reducing emissions in the design, making and supplying of products.  The Government hopes this will then help businesses make goods or services which are less carbonintensive and develop new products with lower carbon footprints.   The Carbon Trust has already piloted PAS 2050 with 75 product ranges across a wide range of companies including PEPSICO, Boots, Innocent and Tesco.  The trust also worked with Cadbury over the course of late 2006 and 2007 to determine the carbon footprint of a bar of Cadbury Dairy Milk. […]

title: Maryland Adopts Computer-Recycling Fee
news: Starting next year, computer makers that want to do business in Maryland must kick in up to $5,000 annually to help recycle their products under a new state law designed to cope with the roughly 60,000 tons of "electronic waste" that pile up in Maryland each year.[…] California places the financial burden on consumers, charging a $6 to $10 disposal fee on every computer and television purchased. Maine puts the onus on manufacturers, demanding they pay the full cost of recycling their computers or televisions and pick up a share of the recycling tab for products of unknown origin. Computer manufacturers gave a collective sigh of relief when Maryland, after years of debate, rejected Maine's concept and opted for a relatively small annual fee. "It's much more reasonable," Andy Kendzie, a spokesman for INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES Corp., said of Maryland's legislation. "We're very happy with it."[…] In subsequent years, manufacturers can pay a reduced fee of $500 if they have a "takeback" program that allows consumers to return computers for recycling or refurbishing at no cost. The "no cost" part creates issues for firms such as Hewlett-Packard and IBM, which take back computers if consumers pay for shipping. […]

title: Taking charge of electrics
news: Frito-Lay is investing in delivering a clean future. A SNACK food company will have 275 electric trucks on US roads by the end of the year. While the viability of electric trucks is yet to be proven, some companies such as Frito-Lay are getting behind the technology. The potato chip manufacturer, which is part of the PEPSI Co group, has the largest fleet of electric trucks in the country.  It claims the electric trucks produce 75 per cent less greenhouse gas than a regular turbo diesel. The Frito-Lay trucks are produced by Smith Electric Vehicles and run latest-technology lithium ion battery packs, which allow a range of up to 130km.[…] The company will have 105 electric trucks in California by the end of the year, although it is still only a small proportion of its 1800-strong delivery truck fleet. Frito-Lay says it expects its Californian electric trucks will save it 757,000 litres of diesel every year and 2 million kilograms of emissions. Frito-Lay and PEPSI Co also have 267 hybrid diesel electric trucks and 67 compressed natural gas prime movers currently working in the US.[…]

title: The Swamp-Gas Station: Fuel From Landfill Methane Goes on Sale
news: Farmers, waste management companies and the energy industries have long experimented with converting methane, a byproduct of decomposing organic matter, into transportation fuel. Those efforts have met with mixed success, and a renewable natural gas fuel has not been widely available in the United States. But now, one leading supplier of natural gas transport fuel is taking a big step toward changing that. Clean Energy Fuels will announce on Thursday that it has started selling a fuel made of methane from landfills and other waste sources at its more than 40 filling stations in California. The company, which is backed by T. Boone Pickens, is developing a nationwide network of natural gas pumps and plans to introduce the fuel elsewhere as well. The company expects to sell 15 million gallons of the fuel in California this year, more than double the amount of similar fuels the Environmental Protection Agency projected would be produced nationwide. Its customers include companies like AT&T, VERIZON, Mattel and Williams-Sonoma as well as large fleet operators like SuperShuttle and Hertz.[…]

title: ON THE ROAD TO CLEANER DIESEL; CHANCE FOR DRIVERS TO CLEAN UP THEIR ACT
news: […] Ultra Low Sulphur Diesel (ULSD) is the latest weapon in the battle against air pollution but, as the News Letter reported yesterday, pumps dispensing the wonder fuel are few and far between. ULSD is better for the environment because it produces less poisonous sulphur dioxide fumes and less black smoke containing carcinogenic particulates. With some of the most polluted air in western Europe, the drive to freshen up Belfast city is an urgent one but, for the meantime, consumers have little opportunity to buy the cleaner, greener diesel. The reason is that although BP, the largest supplier of fuel in Northern Ireland, is producing ULSD, it isn't bringing it in here and may not be until September. But motorists eager to do their bit for the environment can, if they're prepared to look around as Raymond Reihill of local firm Kelly Fuels explained yesterday. Established in the 1840s the firm has stolen a march on its much bigger rivals because it has been selling ULSD at its retail sites since last December, supplied by the French firm Elf. The problem is there are only six of them, scattered as far afield as Portaferry, Irvinestown, Maghera and Belfast. It has also landed the contract to supply firms like COCA COLA, Marks and Spencer and Translink which is currently trialling the new fuel in its bus fleet. "There's no doubt we've stolen a march on the other firms in the market and we're chuffed about it said Reihill.[…]

title: Google buys drone maker to spread the net wider
news: Google has taken to the skies, buying a manufacturer of mechanical drones as part of plans to bring the internet to remote parts of the world. The search company announced yesterday that it had bought Titan Aerospace, an American company that specialises in producing flying machines powered by solar energy. Google's goal is to create drones that transmit internet signals to far-flung areas. This could ensure that developing countries gain access to the web, without the expense of laying thousands of miles of broadband internet cables.  The deal is the latest example of airborne internet rivalry. Facebook is understood to have been in talks to buy Titan this year, although this month it moved instead to acquire the British drone maker Ascenta, a small Somerset company, in a deal worth $20 million (£12 million). In December, Amazon announced that it was developing a fleet of unmanned drones to deliver packages to millions of people within half an hour of orders being placed. Google said: "It's still early days but atmospheric satellites could help bring internet access to millions of people and help solve other problems, including disaster relief and environmental damage like deforestation." […]

title: Chinese delegation here to explore green building
news: A delegation of planners and builders from southern China arrived in Israel on Monday to explore and learn from the new trend of "green" architecture underway here, due to the increasing demand for such construction there, the Economy and Trade Ministry announced that day. […] The delegates will visit several companies, such as DIP Tech, Tigo and Carmel Chemicals, and will also see green building at INTEL and the new campus for Tel Aviv University's Porter School for Environmental Studies. In addition, they will meet with members of the Israel Standards Institute to learn about Israel's new standards for green building, the Economy and Trade Ministry said.[…]

title: Fight against excess packaging; Yousay IN YOUR OPINION...
news: NO-ONE wants to see Wales awash with rubbish as a result of excess packaging ("We need to debate this important issue", April 16). That's why I was happy to see you tackling the question of packaging in Tuesday's paper - and why I'm happier still to tell readers about the great work which has already been done - and will continue to be done - to prevent waste and save money. Between 2005 and 2010 signatories of WRAP's Courtauld Commitment - including big names such as Marks & Spencer, Coca Cola and Tesco - saved 1.2 million tonnes of food and packaging waste with a monetary value of £1.8bn. In 2010 and 2011 alone they cut supply chain waste by a further nine per cent. This spring will see the launch of the third phase of the Courtauld Commitment - with even more ambitious targets and savings to be had. And WRAP will continue to work with both government and industry to ensure that Wales feels the economic and environmental benefits of using fewer resources and wasting less. ¦ Beth Winkley Head of WRAP Cymru

title: Big firms move to cut emissions
news: Some major U.S. corporations, anticipating that they may soon be facing controls on so-called greenhouse gas emissions at home as well as abroad, are implementing ways to reduce the risks and hunting for ways to make money on the pending regulations. […] "Other companies are taking advantage of certain opportunities for early action and Northeast Utilities will try to do the same things," explained John Russell, manager of environmental compliance for the Connecticut utility, which sells power and other services in 10 states.  The utility is converting a small coal-fired power plant in New Hampshire to burn wood, but it wants to develop a companywide strategy on reducing emissions and energy costs. It is studying strategies developed by Pfizer Ltd. and GENERAL ELECTRIC Co., which are preparing global plans to reduce emissions and energy costs. […]

title: After designing and making goods, some companies pay to recycle them; U.S. food giants joining global movement to pick up and recast packaging
news: A growing number of U.S. food and beverage companies are recycling their packaging after consumers are finished with it, a responsibility long required of packaged goods companies in Europe. [...] ''Local governments are literally going broke and so are looking for ways to shift the costs of recycling off onto someone, and companies that make the packaging are logical candidates,'' said Jim Hanna, director of environmental impact at Starbucks. ''More environmentally conscious consumers are demanding that companies share their values, too.'' [...] Coca-Cola has a whole subsidiary, Coca-Cola Recycling, devoted to its stated goal of ensuring the recycling of 100 percent of its cans and bottles in North America by 2015 and 50 percent in the rest of the world. To that end, seven factories owned wholly or in part by the company toil away around the globe recycling plastic, including one in Spartanburg, South Carolina.[...]

title: Transportation:
news: GE Capital will finance ready-mix concrete firm Ozinga Bros.' purchase of concrete trucks, loaders and other equipment powered by compressed natural gas. The GE financing will also be used to purchase GE's portable "CNG in a Box" fueling station system. Ozinga, which began testing CNG-powered concrete mixer trucks in 2011, plans to have its entire fleet of 500 concrete mixer trucks fueled by CNG by 2020. The company said a key consideration for making the switch is that CNG engines reduce carbon emissions by 80% to 90% while offering the same horsepower and torque performance as traditional diesel engines. * * * PROCTER & GAMBLE will work with eight transportation carriers to convert up to 20% of its North American truck load shipments to natural gas vehicles within two years. P&G plans to convert 7% of its North America for-hire transportation network to natural gas powered trucks during the initial phase.

title: Honda F1 drops sponsor logos for 'green' image
news: The Honda Racing F1 Team will drop sponsorship logos from the chassis of its racing cars for this year's Formula One World Championships in favour of an environmental initiative called 'Our car is your car'. Instead of logos, Honda's cars will display an image of the Earth to align its brand with environmental issues. The Earth image will be created by pixels carrying the names of brands and consumers who make a donation to an environmental charity or visit a dedicated microsite and pledge to make a green lifestyle change. The campaign website, myearthdream.com, launched this week. The concept was devised by 19 Entertainment. Universal Music and Gatorade have become the first big names to sign up to the scheme, which is supported by Honda Racing suppliers Fila, IBM, Instron, Oliver Sweeney, PerkinElmer, Showa Denko, TUV and GF Agie Charmilles.[…]

title: WORLD IN FOCUS; Climate can be big business
news: CLIMATE change is the gathering storm of our generation. And the implications should we fail to act are dire. So what's stopping us? Because, even where we are recognising the potential scale and gravity of the problem and where we know the action we must take, we haven't begun to move with the speed, the urgency or the ambition we need. […] But what is in it for business? Well, on the one hand, there are the risks of inaction. Those include the direct losses - Swiss Re estimates that weather made more severe by climate change could cost the insurance industry $US150 billion a year in the next decade. And we all know that what costs the insurance industry money one day costs all of us the next day. But there are also the losses from increased global risk and from growing awareness and action among consumers and shareholders - both groups are now looking for and expecting the companies they invest in or buy from to be leaders on this issue. Indeed, that was the tenor of the recent ''Call for Action'' when 10 major U.S. corporations joined to form the Climate Action Partnership and urged the federal Government to set mandatory limits on greenhouse gas emissions.[…] The Chicago Climate Exchange is growing by the day. Just last week, INTEL joined the exchange, committing to cut its greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S. by a minimum of 6 per cent by 2010. Clean-tech is going to be a massive market. John Doerr has called energy ''the mother of all markets . . . the largest economic opportunity this century'': and this comes from a man who invested in, among others, Google and Amazon and now sits on the boards of both those companies.[…]

title: Coca-Cola measures its carbon footprint
news: Coca-Cola has become the largest global brand to measure the carbon footprint of some of its most popular products using the carbon footprinting standard PAS2050. PAS2050, published in October by BSI British Standards, should help firms understand product life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions and ways to cut them (ENDS Report 406, pp 26-28). [...]

title: Kenya; Tomato Peels Find Use in Car Assembly?
news: Tomatoes and cars may have nothing in common, but researchers at American based companies, Ford Motor and Heinz, see the possibility of an innovative union. Researchers at the two firms are investigating the use of tomato fibres in developing sustainable, composite materials for use in vehicle manufacturing. [...] Nearly two years ago, Ford began collaborating with Heinz, The Coca-Cola Company, Nike Inc. and Procter & Gamble to accelerate development of a 100 percent plant-based plastic to be used to make everything from fabric to packaging and with a lower environmental impact than petroleum-based packaging materials currently in use. [...]

title: Karex upbeat on beating last year's sales
news: […] He said Karex's new factory in Pontian, Johor is set to begin production in the second quarter of next year. The factory will be equipped with solar panels, enabling the condom maker to save 25 per cent on electricity cost. "We're looking at the Green Building Index certificate for the new factory, as well as the American Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, which will make it the second building in Malaysia to get it after the INTEL factory in Kulim, Kedah." Goh also said he is pleased with the response his company has received at Invest Malaysia."This is our first Invest Malaysia since the listing and the response has been positive," he added

title: Environmentally responsible business awards
news: The Green Awards recognize achievements in the field of environmentally responsible marketing and advertising. For the first time award categories will include educational projects, products and mobile apps. Entries for the Green Awards, which award the promotion of, or innovation in the field of environmentally responsibility, began to be accepted on 8 2. [...] Past winners of the Green Awards include chocolate manufacturer Cadbury, mobile phone companies O2 and Nokia as well as soft drinks manufacturer Coca-Cola. [...]

title: Firms roll in green
news: IRISH businesses saved a whopping Euro 55MILLION by going green last year. And carbon emissions were cut by 430,000 tonnes - equal to taking 100,000 cars off the road. A report from Sustainable Energy Ireland revealed that companies like INTEL, Tesco and Google shaved millions off running-costs by signing up to the Government's green energy programme. Energy Minister Eamon Ryan said: "In the coming years every business will need to use energy more INTELligently." Meanwhile Environment Minister John Gormley got tough with farmers, warning that big cuts in greenhouse gas emissions were needed.

title: VIDEO: How Google Glass is saving rhinos
news: Google Glass has a variety of features that allow users to do everything from read news and take photos to watch videos and tweet. But the wearable computer recently added a new capability: aiding conservation efforts. The World Wildlife Fund has been exploring ways Google Glass can help save endangered species through Google's Giving Through Glass initiative. Their joint efforts led to the development of Field Notes, an app currently being tested in Nepal that enables field researchers to take hands-free notes. The app allows researchers to compile critical information on species by using voice commands to record data like sex, age and unique characteristics, as well as take photos and video and mark locations through GPS. This data can then be sent to a database and shared with other researchers. WWF Senior Research Officer Sabita Malla has been using Field Notes to track and study threatened rhinos in Nepal. […]

title: Nigeria; CHEVRONtexaco Sets Aside $340m to Upgrade Facilities
news: Texaco Nigeria Limited, has disclosed that it has earmarked $340 million to upgrade its facilities in Nigeria. […] The company, according to the newsletter decided to commit the whooping amount as a result of its determination to conduct oil exploration in a safe condition. CHEVRONTexaco assured that this resolve to operate in an environmentally-sensitive manner was irrevocable, adding that its efforts in that regard had been recognised in both the Nigerian Conservative Foundation and the Federal Ministry of Environment. "CHEVRON is proud of its efforts in conducting its operations in an environmentally sensitive manner and, over the past few years, both the Nigerian Conservative Foundation and Federal Environmental Protection Agency, among others concerned with the environment, have recognised these efforts. "CHEVRON integrates environmental protection into every aspect of its activities wherever it operates, and employs high environmental standards throughout its world wide operations. "The company s policy-protecting people and the environment-emphasis safe operations, compliance, pollution, pollution prevention and community programmes. In recent times, CHEVRON has been engaged in the significant upgrade of its production facilities, including the installation of improved equipment to reduce discharges and reduce the risk of oil spills. […]

title: Reply Letters and emails: Making business go low-carbon
news: * Sally Uren's article on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (Hall of shame, November 5) fails to discuss any of the long-term, meaningful actions companies such as ExxonMobil are taking to reduce GHG emissions. GHG emissions are rising globally because demand for energy is rising. The challenge is how to meet this growing demand for energy while reducing GHG emissions. [...] We take the issue of climate change seriously and we are working every day on ways to reduce emissions while supplying the energy needed to improve global living standards. Nick Thomas Director, Corporate Affairs, ExxonMobil

title: Natural gas vies with hybrids in GE vehicle fleet
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC Co.'s commitment to buy 25,000 electri autos, promoted as the largest eve when it was announced more than two years ago, is taking a detour. The obstacle: Customers of GE's corporate fleet-services unit wanted more options, said Deb Frodl, the division's chief strategy officer. So GE has included natural gas-powered pickups and propane-fuelled vehicles among about 11,000 autos - mostly plug-in hybrids and electric cars - already acquired from automakers, including Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Co. The shift at GE, whose 2010 pledge was hailed as a catalyst for bulk buying of electric vehicles, shows how businesses are struggling to balance greater fuel efficiency and reduced emissions against higher sticker prices, limited range and lingering doubts about still-infant technology. […]

title: Razor firm at cutting edge of sustainability; IN ASSOCIATION WITH NORBERT DENTRESSANGLE MOVE YOUR BUSINESS ON Fast-movingconsumer goods In the latest in our series on the supply chain, Huw Waters, product supply director of PROCTER and Gamble, tells Amy Wilson why sustainable logistics and profitability go hand in hand
news: Mention sustainability and people are more likely to think of organic vegetables and independent cafés than global brands and supermarkets.   However, PROCTER & GAMBLE (P&G) has paid more than lip service to the notion of delivering the same goods with far fewer resources.   The maker of Gillette razors, Fairy washing-up liquid and Pringles snacks halved the environmental impact of its business between 2002 and 2011, by cutting carbon emissions by 53pc, and using 52pc less energy and 58pc less water, says Huw Waters, product supply director for P&G in the UK.   Some 96pc of what goes into the company's factories around the world now comes out as part of a finished product and half the remainder is recycled. "We would like to get that down to zero waste," Mr Waters says. […] Case studyThere aren't many freezers in Britain that don't have a packet of Birds Eye peas in them. Founded in 1938, Birds Eye has become an iconic brand and 80pc of households buy its products.  In 2007, the company decided to outsource the freezing of its peas, and looked for a partner who could meet its commitment to freeze every pea within 150 minutes of being picked. The time limit makes sure that peas stay as fresh as possible and retain a high amount of vitamin C.Norbert Dentressangle extended its existing partnership with Birds Eye and committed to a multi-million pound investment in a new £50m pea processing facility in Hull. The site has now been expanded to be the biggest such plant in the world.   "Our decision to work with Norbert Dentressangle was based on its strong track record with us - we had a relationship dating back 40 years for pea processing and storage," says James Young, head of category, agriculture, at Birds Eye. "Norbert Dentressangle was able to meet our specifications on day one."   Norbert Dentressangle managed the building of the plant. Work started in September 2007 and it was fully operational by 6 2008. […]

title: Take Viagra, save a reindeer; Impotence drug may reduce the harvesting of wildlife
news: At an herbal shop on Arch Street in Chinatown, owners report sluggish sales of a red, powdered medicine called "Strong Man." On the docks of Newfoundland, fishermen are finding it harder to peddle the private parts of seals. And on the plains of western Alaska, the trade in reindeer antlers has plummeted. A possible reason behind all three, according to researchers: Viagra.  The popular impotence drug may be reducing demand for traditional Chinese impotence remedies, many of which contain ground-up animal parts. So Viagra may be helping to save world wildlife. The evidence, say researchers Frank and William von Hippel, is that sales of reindeer antlers dropped sharply about the same time Viagra came on the market, in 1998. While antlers were among the products studied because they are legally traded and easy to monitor, there is some early indication that the Viagra effect also holds true for endangered and threatened species, ranging from sea horses to green turtles. Environmental groups say they hope it's true, but animal experts say the impact on reindeer is plausible. Pleased that its flagship product may work wonders both in the bedroom and in the realm of animal conservation, Viagra-maker PFIZER gave the researchers $25,000 for additional study in Hong Kong. Frank von Hippel, a University of Alaska biologist, and his brother, a psychologist in New Zealand, published their most recent paper on the subject, "Sex, drugs and animal parts: Will Viagra save threatened species?", in the September issue of Environmental Conservation.[…]

title: GE makes move into B.C. wind power; Local hydroelectric developer Plutonic Power sees shares jump on partnership deal with U.S. giant
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC  Co. GE-N is set to buy its first wind power project in Canada, another sign the global recession hasn't quashed interest in the fast-growing renewable energy sector. GE, through its energy financial services arm, struck a tentative deal to take over a partly completed, 145-megawatt wind project in northeastern British Columbia. The deal is with upstart EarthFirst Inc., which is under court protection from creditors. If conditions such as renegotiating several existing contracts are met, GE will be joined in the project by Plutonic Power Corp., PCC-T a small Vancouver run-of-river hydro power developer. Plutonic and GE are working together on several run-of-river projects north of Vancouver. (A run-of-river system does not require a large reservoir to provide power.)  About $100-million has been sunk into the EarthFirst wind project. An earlier EarthFirst budget suggested it will cost another $250-million to complete.  GE has been looking at the EarthFirst project since late last year, after Calgary-based EarthFirst filed for creditor protection. "We are seeking ourselves to grow in Canada, in the renewable energy category especially," said Andy Katell, a spokesman for GE Energy Financial Services. […]

title: PEPSICO and Sainsbury's extend sustainability work with farmers
news: PEPSICO is rolling out new agricultural sustainability targets, while Sainsbury's and Morrisons are extending their on-farm initiatives. Efforts by food makers and retailers to improve the sustainability of the UK farms supplying them continue to spread. PEPSICO announced ambitious new targets in October, and Morrisons and Sainsbury's recently extended their farm-outreach programmes.  For most food and drink products it is the agricultural stage of their life cycle that has the biggest environmental impact. This makes it a key target for manufacturers and retailers trying to reduce their products' carbon and water footprints (see table).  With the government applying only gentle pressure on farmers to cut greenhouse gas emissions, there is much scope for improvement (ENDS Report 428, pp38-42).   The aims and approaches of different corporate programmes vary, but most involve benchmarking and sharing best practice.  PEPSICO, which makes Walkers crisps, Quaker Oats and Copella juices in the UK, has set itself firmer targets than most. It aims to work with the 350 farmers it buys oats, apples and potatoes from to cut carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emissions by 50% by 2015. It also wants to reduce the 'water impact' of farms in water-stressed areas by 50% by the same date. The baseline for both targets is 2010. […]  Sainsbury's, which held a conference on the future of farming with 1,000 farmers at the end of October, set up its first farm development group, focused on dairy, three years ago. It has spent pounds 15m on the group so far and has just pledged another pounds 40m for the next three years. […]  Morrisons, meanwhile, is to work with farms supplying its cheese-maker First Milk to trial and roll out wind turbines and heat-recovery systems fitted to milk tanks. This builds on a farm improvement programme launched last year for meat, dairy and poultry farms. […]

title: Lab plays key role in eco boom - Sustainable Queensland - A SPECIAL ADVERTISING REPORT
news: SINCE the very early days of coal mining, birds have been used to provide an early warning of danger. Now, using the very latest smart technology, Queensland's scientists are hoping our feathered friends will deliver clues as to the greatest peril facing today's world: climate change. In a ''virtual lab'', which has been established by a joint venture between the Queensland University of Technology (QUT), Microsoft and the Queensland government, data is being collected and analysed about the movement and behaviour of bird colonies for possible clues as to how climate change might affect their habitat and behaviour.  The research is just one task being performed at the new $2.5 million eResearch Centre, which was formally opened last week at QUT. QUT professor, Paul Roe, said the lab would employ the very latest in IT tools to help scientists, who at present were ''drowning in data''. He said: ''The computing power of this new eResearch center will enable scientists to use their brilliant minds for what they do best-research. Research relies on and is limited by ICT (information and communication technologies). To further science, smarter eResearch tools are required. ''We propose a virtual research lab application for scientists, which will enable them to undertake new science through improved collaboration, data analysis and experimentation.'' […]

title: Action speaks louder than hot air; Geoffrey Lean in cancun
news: It passed almost unnoticed, but an apparently unexciting business announcement on the very first day of the Cancun climate summit may well do more to combat global warming than the two weeks of talks that followed. This is not just because it amounted to rare action amid the millions of words spoken, written and printed on enough paper to require the felling of a small forest - but because it represents an early move in a new, more effective strategy to avert dangerous climate change. Four hundred leading companies - including Tesco, Unilever, Coca-Cola, Kraft, Walmart, Procter and Gamble and L'Oréal - said they would be switching refrigerants within the next five years. Important to them, you might think, but not the sort of thing to stir the blood unless you're the type of person that finds coolants really cool. But bear with me. The chemicals, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), are greenhouse gases. Yet even that is not the point. What makes the announcement exceptional is that they are among a handful of overlooked pollutants whose reduction would reduce global warming far quicker, and with much less fuss, than trying to cut emissions of carbon dioxide, the object of the climate negotiations which have ground on, with little success, for two decades. [...]

title: PSC staff supports new Turkey Point reactors
news: The Florida Public Service Commission staff recommended March 10 that PSC commissioners approve Florida Power & Light Co.'s petition for a determination of need for two new nuclear units at Turkey Point. Before new electric generating capacity can be built in Florida, the PSC must determine that it is needed. The staff recommendation is scheduled to be discussed at the commission's March 18 hearing.  The staff recommended that the commission approve the proposed Turkey Pont-6 and -7 reactors to maintain the utility's fuel diversity and to provide adequate electricity at a reasonable cost over the long term. Turkey Point-3 and -4 are the existing reactors at the site.  The staff noted that there are some uncertainties over the cost of the new units. However, it said, FPL's analysis indicates Turkey Point-6 and -7 "have a high likelihood of providing net savings to FPL's customers over a variety of fuel and environmental cost scenarios." FPL has said the cost for building the two units ranges from $12.1 billion to $17.8 billion for Westinghouse's 1,100-MW AP1000, and $16.5 billion to $24.3 billion for GENERAL ELECTRIC's 1,520-MW ESBWR. The staff said Turkey Point-6 and -7 are projected to produce savings in 17 of the 18 scenarios FPL considered. Those results indicate a high likelihood of FPL's ratepayers realizing net benefits over the life of the project, it said. And, it said, as environmental compliance costs increase, so do the benefits associated with Turkey Point-6 and -7 because nuclear generation is considered a non-emitting technology for greenhouse gas emissions. […]

title: GE acquires ScanWind.
news: GE Energy has added the technology of wind turbine drive trains to its renewable energy technology portfolio by closing a deal to buy Norway-based ScanWind from Morphic Technologies. The deal is part of GE's strategy to boost its position in Europe's rapidly growing offshore wind power industry. ScanWind is a developer of advanced drive train and control technologies that perform the same function as gearboxes in wind turbines. Its products are aimed at the offshore sector, and are currently being demonstrated in 11 turbines operating on the Norwegian coast. GE believes that ScanWind's technology will help to improve the reliability of offshore units and plans to develop it further.

title: A FOREST CLEARING; The UN wants rich countries to pay poor nations to halt deforestation and cut emissions. Is either side interested?
news: […] Flora & Fauna International, a British environmental group, is helping the governor of Aceh province, in northern Sumatra, to develop a Redd project to protect 750,000 hectares of forest around the Ulu Masen mountain. The BANK OF AMERICA has promised to buy £5.6 million-worth of carbon credits from the project, but only if FFI can prove that trees are being preserved that would otherwise be lost, and if it has obtained the consent of indigenous people. FFI says that "ideally" it will demarcate areas where trees can be cut for local needs. But it says that it will take another year or more simply to establish who owns the land. One of the biggest challenges for the Ulu Masen project is defining the baseline deforestation rate. This is difficult because there was little land development during the civil war in Aceh. Normal activity was disrupted again by the 2004 tsunami that killed more than 150,000 people there.[…] Matt Linkie, a zoologist and FFI's project manager for Ulu Masen, acknowledges that unless the rules governing Redd are tightly drawn and enforced it will have little credibility. "Potentially we could let some of the world's biggest polluters off by offering them carbon permits," he says. "But what's the alternative to Redd? Tropical forests are going to hell in a handcart because they depend for protection on donor aid and government budgets, which are uncertain. Redd offers the chance of long-term sustainable finance."[…]

title: Phone-book delivery vanishing; Cities limiting familiar doorstep thud amid green initiatives
news: Phone books, long a staple of U.S. life, are fading quickly  as lawmakers and phone companies see green benefits in limiting their delivery. Most targeted are the residential white pages that list home numbers. An increasing number of states are approving requests by phone companies, which want to stop delivering these unprofitable, generally ad-free books unless requested by land-line customers. The result: Many customers in half of U.S. states will soon no longer hear that multipound thud at their doorstep.Verizon has received the OK to cease automatic delivery from 11 of 12 states where it has land-line customers and expects permission from California and the District of Columbia by the end of September.AT&T expects, by the end of this year, to stop unsolicited delivery in 14 other states where it does land-line business. "We give people the option,"  company spokeswoman Dawn Benton says."We all know fewer and fewer people use the phone book every year.  It's an antiquated industry," says Scott Cassel of the Product Stewardship Institute, a  non-profit  that aims to limit the environmental impact of consumer products.[…]

title: Powering down
news: INBOX: WHILE POLITICIANS and environmental campaigners rail against the transport and power industries, those of us in the technology world may have to start looking at our own actions in helping to save the planet […] In fact, green is the theme of choice at CeBit this year as many of the 5,845 exhibitors from 77 countries tout developments such as servers that use less electricity and data centres that emit much less carbon dioxide. IBM is to unveil an emissions-free computing centre model that uses energy recycling and cools hot-running microchips with water. The Climate Savers Computing Initiative, founded in 2007 with Microsoft, Google, Intel, IBM and others, aims to reduce computer-related emissions of greenhouse gases by 54 million tonnes annually. By a happy coincidence for these firms, however, it is going to take a lot of computing power to work out how to make technology more environmentally friendly.

title: SPECIAL FEATURE: Power and Energy Updates; Greening the Grid
news: Thanks to increasing pressure from both consumers and eco-conscious investors, green initiatives are all the rage in many industries these days. However, more than the benefits it brings to their immediate environment, early adaptors know that betting on the green craze has also become good for business. Helping these ventures go pro-environment are new fiscal and non- fiscal initiatives, such as seven-year income tax holidays for renewable energy developers; reduced corporate income tax to 10% after their income tax holiday expires; duty-free importation of equipment and machinery; and a zero percent VAT rate for power sourced from renewable energy. [...]According to the World Wildlife Fund (WWF)_Philippines' 10-year sustainable energy road map, the country can save as much as $2.3 billion if it taps renewable energy sources. Further, a shift to wind, geothermal, solar and biomass resources will result in lower power costs for consumers in the long run.[...]Dennis Posadas, Cleantech Asia Online editor and BusinessWorld columnist, believes that part of the gamble stems from a lack of supporting data. "Typically, anything that is new and poorly understood is considered risky, but if the information is properly disseminated, the investor can judge for himself if the potential investment in renewable energy is indeed risky," he said.[...]"But we must look at the nature of the renewable energy sources. If the source is geothermal, then this type of renewable energy is often driven by big companies like CHEVRON. If the energy source is solar, wind or biomass, then smaller entities can come in," he added.[...] "The drive for renewable energy was influenced by the rise of crude oil prices in the '70s, but was dropped later. The sector's growth has been in spurts because when the price of oil is low, people don't bother with clean energy," he said.[...]

title: NRG Seeks to Cut 90% of Its Carbon Emissions
news: NRG, which built a leading electricity business from coal and other conventional power plants, is aiming to reduce its carbon emissions 50 percent by 2030 and 90 percent by 2050, the company said on Thursday. David Crane, the company's chief executive, made the announcement at a ceremony breaking ground for the company's new headquarters in Princeton, N.J., conceived as a green-energy showcase that will open in 2016. ''The power industry is the biggest part of the problem of greenhouse gas emissions, but it has the potential to be an even bigger part of the solution,'' Mr. Crane said in an interview before the announcement.  Since 2005, the company has reduced its carbon emissions 40 percent, executives say, and the new goals would use this year's projected level of 125 million metric tons as a baseline. Few power companies have made similar commitments, although they have become common in corporate America and are part of the impetus for NRG's move.
