Businesses like Coca-Cola, Google and Walmart are increasingly looking to buy or produce more green energy as a way of reducing their carbon footprints, creating a potentially lucrative market for companies like NRG. This week, for instance, Ikea announced it had bought a second wind farm in the United States, part of its goal of, by 2020, producing as much renewable energy as the company consumes globally. […]

title: Apple extends trade-in deals; THE EXPERT VIEW - GIZMO GUY
news: Apple has extended its device trade-in program to Australia, offering up to $250 off a new iPhone or iPad to customers who hand over their old one. Introduced in time for the iPhone 6 release later this year, the trade-in scheme accepts all but the first-generation iPhone 3G and iPad 1 - with Apple store staff assessing the returned device's age and condition before determining the trade-in value. It is not possible to trade in a current model iPhone 5S, iPhone 5C or iPad Air for a discount on a replacement.  Traded-in devices are either refurbished and sold online at a 15 per cent discount, or else recycled. The "Reuse and Recycling" scheme is part of Apple's efforts to improve its green credentials, following the recent announcement that all Australian Apple stores now rely on renewable energy, along with more than 140 stores in the United States. The company is working towards "net zero energy" according to its Environmental Responsibility Report, with the new iCloud data centre in North Carolina powered by the country's largest privately owned solar array. The new iPhone/iPad trade-in scheme sits alongside Apple's existing iPod trade-in program, offering up to a 10 per cent discount on new models. Apple also runs a free recycling program for old mobile phones, computers and monitors, regardless of manufacturer. In the US the trade-in program extends to cover old Apple computers, but not in Australia. The iPhone/iPad trade-in program was introduced in the US in 8 2013, and later expanded to Britain, Canada, Italy, Germany and France. Trade-in values have fluctuated over time and Apple has recently cut its US trade-in prices. While encouraging Apple shoppers to recycle their old products, the program also encourages iGadget sales by reducing the size of the second-hand device market.

title: Uganda; Companies Pledge to Go Green At Rio+20
news: Leading international companies have kicked off the Rio+20 drive towards a green economy with huge pledges. At a four-day Rio+20 Corporate Sustainability Forum organized by United Nations Global Compact (6 15-18), Microsoft committed to reduce its carbon emissions. Unilever revealed how it is launching a drive to halve the greenhouse emissions, while Nike's target is to ensure zero discharge of hazardous chemicals along its entire supply chain, both by 2020. […] Hansen said that beyond their immediate impact, the new commitments will serve as a testing ground. "The only way to know if an innovative approach will work is to try it," Hansen said. "The difficulties will teach us lessons, and the successes will snowball." With the world facing a need to double food production by 2050, DuPont, a world leader in market- driven innovations and science, pledged $10 billion in R&D (research and development) to increase productivity, scale up nutrition and cut back on food waste. DuPont will develop 4,000 new products along these lines by 2020. Also looking to product development, Proctor & Gamble promises $50 billion in sales of "sustainable innovation products" by the end of this year, and the clothing house, H&M, will upgrade to 100 percent sustainable cotton, either organic, recycled, or certified in its cotton garments. At least 45 companies, including Levi's, Pepsi and Coca-cola are extending their commitments to water management and 23 companies pledged to transparency and disclosure on their impact on climate change. Joint campaigns are also being launched by businesses participating in Global Compact Networks in Brazil, Uruguay and Japan, among others. […]

title: In search of fuel's holy grail; Companies in Canada are closing in on a profitable way to turn wood waste into ethanol to use as an alternative to gasoline. SHAWN McCARTHY reports on their progress
news: Biochemist Kendall Pye has devoted his long career to the modern equivalent of the alchemist's dream: a commercially viable process for transforming forest wastes into cellulosic ethanol that could replace gasoline. […] Now, with high oil prices and environmental concerns again driving a search for alternative fuels, Dr. Pye, 69, is back in the lab, pursuing the keys to profitable cellulosic ethanol as the chief scientific officer at Lignol Energy Corp., a Vancouver-based company he co-founded several years ago. […] The U.S. government is promoting the ethanol as a replacement for gasoline, both for its claimed environmental benefits in reducing greenhouse-gas emissions and as a replacement for imported oil. President George W. Bush, who has warned of the U.S. "addiction" to imported oil, set a target of 35 billion gallons of ethanol in use by 2017, which represents 30 per cent of current American gasoline consumption. In Canada, both the federal government and the provinces have set ethanol standards, ranging from 5 to 10 per cent of the motor-fuel market. To get there, experts agree, the vast expansion of corn- and wheat-based ethanol will have to be augmented by the cellulosic variety, which can be made from straw, corn stover, switchgrass, wood or even municipal waste. Not only are those biomass feedstocks more abundant than grain, the reductions in greenhouse-gas emissions are far superior over the life cycle of their production and consumption, scientists with the U.S. and Canadian governments have concluded. […] Some of the biggest companies in the world are in the hunt for a profitable method. Last week, forestry giant Weyerhaeuser Co. announced that it is teaming up with the U.S.'s second-largest oil company, CHEVRON Corp., to research and develop technology to produce ethanol from wood fibre and other non-food sources. […]

title: Americans set to protest over curbs on flights
news: AMERICA is to take the unusual step of making a formal protest against Britain's new aviation policy, saying the proposed curtailing of growth risks harming the transatlantic business relationship. The US embassy has sounded out top American airlines, including Delta, Continental and United, and aerospace manufacturers Boeing and GENERAL ELECTRIC, about an official response to the coalition's proposed aviation policy. Submissions are due on October 20.  The coalition has already ruled out a third runway at Heathrow. The proposed new policy announced this year sets out tough environmental curbs on aircraft. It suggests a change to night flight regimes to give more respite to residents, and to set a "noise envelope" in which aviation could increase as noise per aircraft was reduced. American politicians are already irked by what they see as anti-aviation policies in Europe. The powerful Florida congressman John Mica has tabled a bill that would make it illegal for any US airline to take part in Brussels' proposed emissions trading scheme for carriers. Mica - and others in government - say that the project is against international aviation treaties. Concern about the new UK policy has mounted in recent months. Louis Susman, the ambassador in London, summoned the heads of US airlines, BAA, Boeing and GE to a dinner in 7 to discuss the issue - only to call it off at the last minute, when Ray LaHood, America's transportation secretary, was unable to attend. […]

title: Sceptics forced to contain hot air on gases
news: Mounting evidence of global warming is leaving climate-change deniers in the cold, writes Bradford Plumer RED Smith isn't exactly known for his timidity on the subject of climate change. The president of the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a free-market think tank based in Washington, has derided concern over global warming and has gone on television to rail against Al Gore's ''evil consumptive ways''. But in February, when Smith was called to testify before the Senate Committee on environment and public works, he sounded like a cornered man. ''I am aware,'' he began somewhat cautiously, ''that CEI is regarded as a contrarian voice on the science of climate change.'' Senate Republicans had invited him to comment on an emissions-reduction plan put forward by a group of green-minded companies, including GENERAL ELECTRIC and Duke Energy. But with the balance of power having shifted from the climate naysayers, Smith couldn't just launch into his usual tirade against global warming. […]

title: Citi volunteers to mark 200th anniversary
news: More than 4,300 employees of Citi Korea engaged in numerous community services and volunteer activities here on 6 16 to mark the 200th anniversary of the global banking giant. They were joined by more than 100,000 Citi workers in 92 countries worldwide participating a variety of projects and initiatives on the group's annual Global Community Day, which highlighted its commitment to corporate social responsibility (CSR). Joined by family members, outside directors and clients, the Citi Korea volunteers participated in 51 programs at 24 locations in Seoul and its neighboring cities under the slogan of Green Citi, Clean City. […] "Global Community Day is a meaningful occasion where Citi colleagues worldwide gather together with their families, friends and clients to serve their communities. Global Community Day is more significant this year as the event was held on Citi's 200th anniversary with the largest turnout ever," said Citi Korea CEO Ha Yung-ku, who has participated in the group's annual volunteer program for seven consecutive years. […] Citi volunteers throughout Asia Pacific, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Latin America and North America invested their time, skills and expertise to concentrate on local community needs, including financial inclusion, college and career monitoring, neighborhood revitalization, disaster relief and environmental protection on this year's Global Community Day, Citi said in an emailed statement.

title: Siemens touts 'green'
news: Siemens Corp. said yesterday the most effective way to address climate change is "green technology," noting that companies continue to find ways to cut energy costs. Jacky B.T. Chan, president and chief executive officer of Siemens' local unit, told reporters in a briefing green technologies range from "energy-savings platforms" to state-of-the-art water technologies. "We are encouraging companies to do their part in helping address the challenges of climate change by joining the green revolution and switching to eco-friendly alternatives whenever available," he said. He added: "It's about time for the Philippines to take its advocacy on environmental preservation a step further by increasing the presence of green solutions in the industry sector." Siemens said its "Power Management System" will optimize energy use in industrial plants and buildings. The product's power-monitoring device records data such as energy consumption and allows analysis. Siemens said it had provided green technology to Monde M.Y. San Corp., Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines, Inc., San Miguel Corp., and Asia Brewery, Inc., among others.

title: Do ethical investors really think their money should go into fur and oil?: Fund managers may claim to have criteria that make them squeaky clean, but there are sinners as well as winners. Mark King reports
news: Few investors would expect a fund management group that boasts a 25-year record in running ethical products to invest in oil and fur, but F&C Investments has been named and shamed in a new report for doing just that. The F&C Stewardship Growth fund, though not alone in doing so, has criteria that enable it to invest in companies engaged in activities that investors might deem unethical, according to a report by specialist independent financial adviser Barchester Green Investment. […] Neville White, senior SRI analyst at Ecclesiastical, said: "Our published ethical investment policy and screening criteria are clearly articulated for the market. In the case of GE and the JP Morgan Japanese Investment Trust, these holdings fall well within our stated threshold levels for allowable investment. "As well as our exclusion policy, we also look to apply a positive screen whereby we seek to invest in companies making a positive contribution to society. "In the case of GE, they have a number of industry-leading initiatives in place, including their Ecomagination sustainable technology programme. "Our ethical policy may not be a perfect fit for all investors. However, we believe our rigorous ethical investment process makes our funds market leaders and a responsible choice for investors looking for profits with principles." […]

title: Green benefits pay off
news: More and more workers think that it is important for their employer to have responsible environmental policies in place, writes Gabrielle Monaghan The green movement may still be in its infancy at Irish companies, but media coverage of climate change and high-profile documentaries such as Al Gore's An Inconvenient Truth means employers battling for talent in a tight labour market can no longer afford to ignore workers' growing concerns about the environment. Companies without adequate "green" policies in place could be losing talented employees to organisations that do, according to a survey carried out by Ceridian, a global provider of outsourced payroll and HR systems.  Sixty-nine per cent of employees surveyed by Ceridian think it is important for their employer to be environmentally responsible and 57 per cent wish their employers would do more. Some of the world's largest employers are already leading the way. In Silicon Valley, which has some of the worst traffic in the US, internet search engine giant Google ferries about 1,200 employees to and from the office in 32 shuttle buses equipped with comfortable leather seats and wireless internet access. Its aim is to make commuting painless for its employees, reduce emissions, and make the company attractive for new recruits. Google also gets a couple of extra hours' work out of employees who would otherwise be behind the wheel of a car. […]

title: Real broadband infrastructure gains through NBN
news: While a regular reader of Peter Ruehl's column, and fully appreciative of its tongue-in-cheek humour, his comments (April 16) on the federal government's recent $43 billion national broadband network (Mark 11) policy announcements really do require some balancing comment. […] In arriving at this conclusion PwC applied only one prospective benefit of deploying FTTH networks - that beyond 2010 an estimated 10 per cent of the working population with FTTH access would telecommute an average of three days a week because bandwidth improvements will make working from home more feasible. Benefits were calculated from savings estimates related to reduced fuel consumption and savings on road maintenance and construction. A range of major US companies are committing substantial resources to developing service and software solutions that will utilise high capacity broadband networks to help consumers manage and reduce energy consumption. Among others, the major telecommunications carrier Verizon is building a customer service that will do so via its new optic fibre-based network and its Fios broadband platform, while Google is developing additional software products that it projects will allow consumers to manage energy usage and reduce consumption by up to 15 per cent. These are examples that will see "real" broadband infrastructure contribute to better management of several of the challenges facing all countries and all communities.

title: OBAMA ENERGY POLICY: CURE FOR OIL ADDICTION?
news: HIGHLIGHT: Oil is cheap again, but support for clean-energy alternatives remains strong. [...] "The traditional stereotype was that the business community opposes policies that would cap greenhouse gas emissions. That doesn't exist anymore," said Susan Glickman, the southern region director for the Climate Group, which works with Fortune 500 companies like IBM, Dow Chemical and Coca-Cola to build an economic case for taking action against the greenhouse gases believed to cause climate change. [...]

title: Bank of America defines tougher approach to projects, aims to push clean technologies
news: Like other big investment banks that are taking formal stands on financing power projects as climate change programs approach, Bank of America said last week it would start evaluating the unknown cost of carbon emissions from coal-fired generation. But it also said it would steer its utility clients to develop cleaner energy technologies. [...] Lewis' remarks came one week after Citi, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley unveiled their "carbon principles" to evaluate and address carbon risks in the financing of electric power projects (EUW, 11 Feb, 1). [...] Lester Brown, founder of Worldwatch Institute and now head of Earth Policy Institute, last week said that there is growing momentum for a moratorium on coal-fired generation as evidenced by plant cancellations, regulatory rejections of new units and the view from Wall Street. He called the position by Bank of America and the other large financial institutions to require utilities to undergo specific due diligence and carbon mitigation plans "the kiss of death" for the coal industry. [...]

title: World-class environmental laboratory planned for Lake George
news: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, IBM (NYSE: IBM), and the Fund for Lake George said they have launched "The Jefferson Project at Lake George," a three-year, multi-million dollar collaboration with the goal of understanding and managing complex factors threatening one of the world's most pristine natural ecosystems and an economic cornerstone of the New York tourism industry. The collaboration partners expect that this world-class scientific and technology facility at Lake George will create a new model for predictive preservation and remediation of critical natural systems on Lake George, in New York, and ultimately around the world.  For more information on The Jefferson Project at Lake George visit: http://www.rpi.edu/dept/DFWI/ Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, founded in 1824, is the nation's oldest technological research university. With advances in technology -- sophisticated sensor networks, smart meters, deep computing and Big Data analytics -- IBM is helping clients and cities make smarter decisions about water management. For more information, visit www.IBM.com/smarterplanet/water. The Fund for Lake George is a privately funded not-for-profit organization dedicated to the protection of Lake George. For more, see www.fundforlakegeorge.org.

title: Novazone Raises $7 Million to Help Develop Clean Technology for Safeguarding Water, Food
news: Novazone, a provider of clean technology solutions for food and water, including advanced ozone-based applications for cold storage and disinfection, today said it has raised $7 million in Series B financing.[…] New investor Chrysalix Energy led the round with participation from existing investors, Foundation Capital and Grauer Capital. In addition, Greg Sullivan, managing director of Chrysalix Energy, has joined Novazone's board of directors. Noted Sullivan, "Chrysalix is excited about Novazone's potential to transform food and water processing markets with its industry leading, environmentally safe treatment systems. We believe there is a strong and growing need for Novazone's highly effective and energy efficient solutions, and the company is well suited to lead the market."[…] Novazone couples applied food science with patented ozone technologies to provide an environmentally friendly means of reducing water and airborne pathogens without the use of harmful chemicals, making food and water fresh and safe naturally. Customers include Coca-Cola, PEPSI Cola, Sun Pacific, Orchard View Farms, Paramount Farms, Wilson Batiz, Safeway, Colgate-Palmolive, Procter & Gamble, and Wyeth Pharmaceuticals.

title: New Rio trains clean winners
news: Ten of one of the worlds cleanest trains will help boost Rio Tinto Iron Ores locomotive fleet to more than 100 by the end of the year.  The mining giant is spending big on new train technology, which is not only environmentally friendly but will also help keep the company on track to achieve its massive 220 million tonne production target. The new train will slash diesel emissions by up to 40 per cent. Rio Tinto Iron Ore rail operations general manager Richard Cohen said GENERAL ELECTRICs new Evolution locomotives were an obvious upgrade choice. Rumoured to cost about $6 milllion, the trains are easier to maintain, need less fuel and are more powerful than the turbocharged, 16-cylinder DASH-8 model previously used. "As technology improves and we expand our business we are looking to purchase locomotives that deliver both operational and environmental advantages," Mr Cohen said. "We currently run about 80 to 90 locomotives, but this will increase to well over 100 by December, and the new trains will all be Evolution locomotives. The maintenance cycle on these trains is longer, meaning less down-time, and although the number of cylinders has reduced from 16 to 12, they also offer increased horsepower."

title: COMMITMENT Publisher to be carbon-neutral by 2010; News's climate pledge
news: NEWS Limited, publisher of The Advertiser , yesterday committed to an ambitious new program which will see the company slash its greenhouse gas emissions by 20 per cent and become carbon-neutral within three years. The target was announced as part of the launch of a company-wide energy reduction plan, titled One Degree, and follows an announcement by News Corporation last month, committing all parts of the company to becoming carbon-neutral by 2010. […] Several other companies have developed similar initiatives in recent months - internet groups Yahoo! and Google have also announced plans to become carbon-neutral in the future. […]

title: Tracing the steps of carbon footprint labelling
news: Walkers Cheese & Onion crisps became0 the first product to introduce the Carbon Trust label in 2007, with the entire journey of the product scrutinised.Finding that just 30% of the carbon emissions were produced while under the direct control of PEPSICO UK & Ireland, it sparked a programme of supplier education by the parent company.Other suppliers to have adapted the scheme include Kingsmill, which credits it for helping to slice emissions by 20%, while smoothie and juice maker Innocent has worked closely with the Trust to work out the 'carbon footprint' for its entire business system. However, it was Tesco's decision to work with the Carbon Trust that perhaps attracted the most publicity, with potatoes, light bulbs, orange juice and laundry detergent among the first to get labels in store.

title: Rosneft launches most ambitious offshore project in Kara Sea
news: - Russia's state-owned oil company Rosneft has launched the world's most ambitious offshore oil and gas project in 2014, the company's President Igor Sechin said on Saturday. [...] He said preliminary geological surveying conducted by Rosneft and ExxonMobil showed that this would be a highly profitable undertaking. [...] The start of the drilling was launched by President Vladimir Putin during a teleconference with Sechin and ExxonMobil Russia CEO Glenn Waller who were both present in the Kara Sea. [...] Putin said the project was "unique in many ways" and itt will use the latest technology. "A large number of geological surveys have already been carried out, and special environmental protection measures are in place. I know that Rosneft and all of its partners, including ExxonMobil, attach special significance and pay great attention to this aspect, especially in this part of the world with its sensitive ecology," he said. [...]

title: Around the world on electricity
news: Vehicles powered by electricity from renewable energy have begun a race in Switzerland that will run for more than 80 days and cover 30,000 kilometres across 16 countries. The contestants, whose sponsors include the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and Google, started in Geneva on Monday and will pass through Berlin and Shanghai before resuming in Vancouver and Los Angeles, according to the event's "Zero Race" website. The teams plan to converge on Cancun, Mexico, in time for the UN climate conference in November. […]

title: Race is on for greener engines
news: The race for greener engines will get top billing at Farnborough next week. Pratt & Whitney U.S., parent of Montreal's small-turbine maker Pratt & Whitney Canada, and GENERAL ELECTRIC will tout their solutions along with Rolls-Royce and others. Sky high fuel prices and tougher European aircraft emission rules are creating a crisis atmosphere.  Bombardier wants to power its CSeries with 21,000-23,000-pound thrust geared turbofan engines being developed by P&W. Mitsubishi of Japan will use a 14,000-pound version to power its 70-90-passenger regional jet. P&W has spent more than $1 billion U.S. developing its GTF engine. It uses a small gear system allowing the fan to spin at lower speeds and the turbine that drives it at more efficient higher speeds. The result is greater fuel efficiency and lower emissions and noise. […]

title: From trash to an inventor's treasure trove
news: Max Wallack, who's 12, has been dreaming up ideas for new inventions since he was 6 years old. In his living room in Natick, Mass., the ninth-grader proudly displays his prize-winning inventions. Many of them were inspired by his grandmother and great-grandmother, two important role models in his life.[…] But this time, Max had to do something a bit different - he had to dig through the trash to find ideas for his invention. Max, one of five finalists ages 12 to 18, thought of new ways to construct something useful using discarded materials. For his winning idea, Max won a laptop computer and a $10,000 prize from the INTEL Foundation. The contest, which received more than a thousand submissions, was sponsored by the PBS reality TV show "Design Squad," the INTEL Foundation, and By Kids For Kids Co. All contestants were asked to design an invention using trash that people would normally throw away. Did you know that, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, people throw out an average 4.6 pounds of trash every day? About 1-1/2 pounds of it are recycled or composted. Reusing waste (or recycling) helps reduce the amount of trash that eventually ends up in landfills.[…]

title: Biopolymers have plenty of room to bloom; Packaging offers a fertile field as materials emerge
news: […] ``No one biopolymer can do it all,'' said Lindsey.Sister company Meredian Inc. brings a third technology to the table complementing DaniMer and Seluma, explained Lindsey, who also is president of Meredian. That technology is based on polyhydroxyalkanoate biopolymers. The company acquired PHA technology last fall when it bought a technology portfolio from PROCTER & GAMBLE Co. of Cincinnati. P&G developed the PHA technology to make packaging from renewable resources, but never went commercial with it. The portfolio is suited to making films, bottles and rigid packaging.[…]

title: Canal and River Trust launch
news: The Canal and River Trust, the charity managing waterways in England and Wales, announced Prince Charles as its patron when it was launched last week. The charity will take over responsibility for management of the canals from British Waterways, a non-departmental public body and will inherit its assets and staff.  It also unveiled its first appeal, asking for money to support 50 projects to improve wildlife habitats and restore disused towpaths. It also announced a 'friends' programme, which will give regular donors discounts to museums and attractions up and down the waterways. It has already signed three corporate partners: Google, which has included waterways and towpaths on Google Maps, the People's Postcode Lottery and the Co-operative Bank. […]

title: Tidy efforts
news: Spring Clean Tidy Town. – Stanley. COCA-COLA School Environment Award. -- Snug Primary. Tidy Towns Citizen of the Year -- Jack Riddiford […]

title: Energy research centre opened
news: A centre aimed at finding ways to generate energy more cleanly and efficiently was officially opened yesterday. Cardiff University's Gas Turbine Research Centre (GTRC) in Margam, Port Talbot, will test a variety of alternative fuels used for generating power for electricity and aircraft. It will research more efficient fuel use, alternative fuels and the reduction of pollutants.  Two rigs used at the centre were donated by international technology company QinetiQ, which selected Cardiff University's School of Engineering ahead of several other EU contenders. Professor Phil Bowen, of the School of Engineering and the director of the centre, said, "Gas turbines generate something like 20% of the world's power through aircraft or electrical power generation. There are only a few combustion research centres like this worldwide, and the Gas Turbine Research Centre offers some unique features. "We hope to provide significant research and development support to the international energy sector as it strives to meet demanding global challenges ahead and, along with such facilities as the GENERAL ELECTRIC gas turbine power plant at Baglan Bay, establish South Wales as a hub for cleaner power industries." […]

title: W ith the United Nations World Summit in Johannesburg underw
news: […] Showing the outside world that you have a sustainable development strategy in place is now de rigueur. A recent survey by KPMG found that 45% of the world's largest 250 companies now produce a responsibility report. Any corporate web site worth its salt has a blurb on sustainability and social responsibility. Ever more food and drink companies are trying to get into the FTSE4Good and Dow Jones Sustainability indices. There has been a hive of activity in advance of the summit as multinationals try to convince us their corporate plans are compatible with sustainable development. And in the past 12 months two of the world's largest food retailers, Tesco and Carrefour, have produced their first social responsibility reports. Carrefour's ethical commitment. […] P&G argues the business case for sustainability. "We are only starting to see this industry's first thoughts and it is not possible to say at this point how serious they may be," she says. "But when companies like Wal-Mart make efforts on sustainable sourcing, with their enormous supply chains, they have to be very serious as it has a massive impact on the way they operate."In a recent FT article, PROCTER & GAMBLE's European head of sustainable development Peter White says sustainable development is not about morality or even saving money by reducing resource use. It will only work in business if it is an opportunity and is profitable. "We should not have to rely on the moral case or arguments about risk, employee morale and reputation. I am keen to prove the hard business case that we can build revenue," he says.[…]

title: Food firms merge haulage interests
news: THE UK's biggest food and drink companies, from Coca-Cola to Tesco, have clubbed together to share transport in a ground-breaking move forecast to take  800 lorries off Britain's roads this year. The initiative, in response to rocketing UK fuel costs and a growing focus from consumers on the environmental impact of transporting food, has been backed by 37 of the UK's biggest high street names. Those involved include Britain's biggest supermarkets, from Asda to Waitrose, drinks company PEPSI and brewer Coors, food suppliers from Northern Foods to Nestlé, and consumer goods giant Unilever. An estimated 48m road miles and 23m litres of diesel fuel will be saved through the scheme, cutting pounds 30m of costs at today's prices. The companies will also save on haulage, warehousing and vehicle maintenance costs. Companies will save "fuel miles'' by sharing lorries on specific routes. The scheme was piloted last year and saved 16m miles, and will now be rolled out across the UK.[…]

title: DOE awards first grants for r&d aimed at using fuel cells in coal plants
news: The Energy Department last week announced the first two financial awards under a program that supports research leading to the development of large coal power plants that use fuel cells rather than combustion units to generate electricity. At the same time, DOE also disclosed new developments in clean coal projects that promise to make high-moisture coal more attractive to utilities. Teams led by GENERAL ELECTRIC Hybrid Power Generation Systems and Siemens Westinghouse Power Corp. will each receive $7.5 million for their work on solid-oxide fuel cell technology, DOE said Thursday. Fuel-cell systems produce none of the emissions associated with conventional power systems.  The awards, provided under the Fuel Cell Coal-Based Systems Program, are considered likely to provide important building blocks for a proposed project called FutureGen that would be the world's first zero-emission, fossil fuel power plant. […]

title: The growth of green; Natural Disasters, Corporate Initiatives and Growing Awareness of Climate Change Combine to Raise the Profile of Environmental Journalism
news: [...] The recent coverage of Hurricane Dean's assault on the Caribbean region is the latest example of a major weather and environmental story in a period that has seen an explosion of environmental journalism. [...] ``All mainstream media are trying as rapidly as possible to become multimedia platforms for news,'' said SEJ President Tim Wheeler, who covers growth and development as a reporter for the Baltimore Sun. ``We all have to be flexible, embrace change and try to use the power of the media to communicate with the public. It's much more interactive. It's a challenge for those of us who grew up in one type of media, and who are now using different forms. We're helping through SEJ to make those transitions, and helping our members learn more about how to use the Internet.'' [...] Advertisers also are beginning to go green, and to promote eco-consciousness on air and in print-and internally. ``I've been impressed with American companies like Wal-Mart, DuPont and Coca-Cola, who have added corporate environment or sustainability officers and announced serious plans that committed them to reduce their impact on the environment,'' said Mr. Wheeler. [...]

title: Focus on green opportunities
news: OPPORTUNITIES and challenges for new and existing players in clean energy and carbon farming investments in the south-east region will be discussed at a conference to be held in Albany in March. The inaugural one-day Greenstream 2 Mainstream conference will be hosted by the South Coast Natural Resource Management on March 13. Chief executive Rob Edkins said it was an opportunity to move on from the climate change debate and discuss clean energy development including wind and wave power, geothermal technologies and biofuels, as well as exploring sustainable carbon farming in the region.  Two of the keynote speakers will be Ben Waters from GE Australia and Saul Eslake from the BANK OF AMERICA and Merrill Lynch.[…]

title: Green consortium in hunt for agency
news: The Green Grid, a global consortium of companies, government agencies and educational bodies set up to promote more efficient technology, is searching for an PR agency to work across the Europe, Middle East and Africa region.   The non-profit organisation was founded in 2006 by tech-industry heavyweights including IBM, Hewlett-Packard and Dell to tackle growing energy consumption in data centres. Other member partners include Microsoft, Facebook, Google and eBay. The consortium works with partners to address issues around data facilities, which house an increasing amount of energy-hungry IT equipment, becoming more efficient and more environmentally friendly. […]

title: Wind could fuel 20% U.S. electricity: report
news: Wind turbines could provide 20 per cent of U.S. electricity supplies by 2030, delaying development of new coal plants and reducing greenhouse gas emissions, says a U.S Energy Department report. The U.S. would need to add 300,000 megawatts of wind-power capacity to generate a fifth of demand forecast for 2030 by expanding annual installations to 16,000 megawatts in a decade, up from the 5,244 megawatts added last year. Wind will provide more than 1 per cent of U.S. power this year. Wind power is the fastest growing renewable energy source in the U.S., making up 30 per cent of power-plant capacity last year. FPL Group Inc., Horizon Wind Energy LLC and other developers, taking advantage of federal and state incentives, have struggled to keep up with demand. GENERAL ELECTRIC Co., largest U.S. supplier of wind turbines with 45 per cent of the market last year, expanded production and is sold out through 2009.

title: Opposition to two Northwest coal projects solidifying
news: Two integrated gasification combined cycle coal-fired projects are being proposed by two different companies just across from each other on the Columbia River. One site is on the Oregon side and the other, on the Washington state side. In the Pacific Northwest, where a large portion of the population supports "green" energy solutions and conservation, opposition to the projects is solidifying even though IGCC is recognized as the cleanest of the coal-fired power plant options. […] Conservation "is an aid, not an answer," Peck said. Though not a perfect solution, the IGCC project meets three important criteria, he said: It's affordable, reliable and environmentally responsible. Oregon and Washington, both heavily dependent on hydroelectric generation, each have one existing coal-fired plant. In Oregon, Portland GENERAL ELECTRIC operates the 585-MW Boardman plant, which takes primarily Wyoming Powder River Basin coal. In Washington, TransAlta operates the 1,400-MW Centralia plant, which had been taking most of its coal from the nearby dedicated Centralia mine, but is switching to all PRB coal (PCT 11/29).

title: Some utilities need to be more aggressive to be ready for carbon constraints: report
news: Many Western utility resource plans incorporate future carbon regulations but some need to take far more aggressive action to be ready for a carbon constrained world, according to a new report from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The study comes after the BANK OF AMERICA said last month it started evaluating the unknown cost of carbon emissions from coal-fired generation and is steering its utility clients to develop cleaner energy technologies (EUW, 18 Feb, 7). The report examined how 15 electric utilities in the West are preparing for regulations by reviewing the companies' most recent resource plans. […]

title: GE boss sees blue skies
news: Australia's minerals boom is driving profits for some of the world's largest global businesses, with the influential chief executive of the GENERAL ELECTRIC Company predicting local revenue growth of 20 per cent a year. In an exclusive interview with The Australian Financial Review, GE's CEO and chairman, Jeff Immelt, was also critical of federal and state governments' aversion to debt to fund national infrastructure. He said Australia could become GE's third-largest market this year from revenues of $US7 billion ($7.2 billion) and could grow to No. 2 in 2011. "For Australia our three-year plan for this country has its growth potential as bigger than any other country in the world," said Mr Immelt, who is visiting Sydney for the Forbes Global CEO conference. […] GE Capital cut its local lending assets to $19.5 billion from $34 billion at the height of the financial crisis but managed to boost cash profit from $263 million to $571 million in calendar 2009. The company remains Australia's biggest provider of third-party credit cards and a leader in corporate, fleet and equipment financing as well as being involved in booming infrastructure segments. Typical installations include more than $400 million of power generation, gas refrigeration, compression and carbon dioxide injection equipment for the Gorgon liquefied natural gas project. In Queensland GE is providing gasification and carbon dioxide capture and storage equipment to Wandoan Power and a 45.6 megawatt gas turbine generation plant powered by waste coalmine gas to Energy Developments. Mr Immelt foreshadowed investment by GE in engineering and R&D manpower and manufacturing facilities as it became a more fully rounded company in Australia, "definitely in engineering and maybe manuÂ­facturing". He also called for the implementation of a price on carbon, which he said was "absolutely" necessary. "I have been a very lonely voice for five years in the US where it [a carbon price] is broadly unpopular," Mr Immelt said. "I am completely convinced that it would be good for the economy and will liberate technology, create jobs and help the environment." […]

title: Business News in Brief
news: The Philadelphia regional economy is growing slowly with employment levels not expected to return to prerecession levels until the second half of 2013, according to the latest quarterly indicators released by Select Greater Philadelphia, the economic development arm of the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce. A comparison of regional and national leading indicators shows the national economy continuing to recover more quickly than the Philadelphia area, the organization said. Select and IHS Global Insight, an economic forecasting firm that helped produce the data, said a separate set of coincident indicators shows that as of 1, the most recent month covered by the report, the Philadelphia region was exhibiting a 'gradual rate of economic recovery.” - Mike Armstrong Federal ruling helps Atlantic Wind   The U.S. Department of Interior made a critical determination Monday that benefits Atlantic Wind Connection, the Google-funded company that wants to build a sea-floor transmission system to connect offshore wind turbines to the electrical grid. The Interior Deparment's Bureau of Ocean Energy Management declared there to be no competitive interest for the use of certain areas of the outer continental shelf, allowing the government to grant the project a right-of-way once its environmental impact is reviewed. The lack of competitive interest means that delays are avoided. The project aims to connect up to 7,000 megawatts of wind farms planned off the New Jersey, Maryland and Delaware coasts. The 300-mile-long subsea transmission system will be built 12 to 15 miles offshore over about 10 years.  - Andrew Maykuth […]

title: SUPPORT FOR EMISSIONS BILL MELTING AWAY --- Big business quits US climate lobby
news: THREE major US companies quit an influential lobbying group that had focused on shaping Barack Obama's climate change legislation, as support for an ambitious bill to cut greenhouse gas emissions in the US melts away.  Oil giants BP and ConocoPhillips and heavy-equipment maker Caterpillar said yesterday they would not renew their membership in the three-year-old US Climate Action Partnership, a broad business-environmental coalition that had been instrumental in building support in Washington for capping emissions. […] Caterpillar said it planned to focus on commercialising green technologies. ConocoPhillips's senior vice-president for government affairs, Red Cavaney, said the USCAP was focused on getting a climate change bill passed, whereas Conoco is increasingly concerned with what the details of such a bill would be. ``USCAP was starting to do more and more on trying to get a bill out without trying to work as much on the substance of it,'' Mr Cavaney said. A spokesman for USCAP said it intended to continue its work. More than 20 other large companies, including oil company Royal Dutch Shell and industrial heavyweights GENERAL ELECTRIC and Honeywell International, remain in the coalition with environmental groups such as the Environmental Defence Fund and Natural Resources Defence Council. The USCAP said it expected to add new members in coming months. ``We think there's momentum to get (a climate bill) done,'' USCAP spokesman Tad Segal said.

title: IN A FIZZ OVER RECYCLING
news: ENVIRONMENT-conscious Northern Ireland consumers can now recycle their plastic bottles thanks to a new initiative from COCA-COLA Bottlers (Ulster) Ltd and environmental company, Irish Polymers. COCA-COLA 2 litre and 500ml bottles are made from a plastic material known as PET. Most people are aware of glass and can recycling, but do not know that it is just as easy to recycle their plastic PET bottles. Recycling stations can already be found on civic amenity and public sites in council areas including Antrim, Banbridge and Newtownabbey. Plans to increase the targeted areas, so that everyone can benefit from this new scheme, are also underway. Lynne Crowther, public relations manager, COCA-COLA Bottlers (Ulster) Ltd said: "COCA-COLA Bottlers (Ulster)Ltd has always been fully dedicated to protecting the environment and we are very excited and fully support this new partnership. With a policy of 'wash and squash', it couldn't be easier to recycle empty COCA-COLA bottles. It is incredible to think that the recycling of even one plastic COCA-COLA bottle creates enough energy to run a 60 watt light bulb for six hours." Not only can COCA-COLA bottles be recycled for energy, there are many other end products.  Des Mullan, Irish Polymers said people are often surprised to find out what you can do with a COCA-COLA bottle after you have finished your drink. "They can be recycled to make a variety of end products including fibre for sleeping bags, industrial strapping and wall and floor coverings. They can even be used in the making of fleece jackets." Irish Polymers collect a variety of plastic bottles which when recycled produce seven different materials. Their recycling technology means that unlike the collection of aluminium and glass, which have to be placed in separate banks, only one bank is required for all plastic.[…]

title: ANZ tower sets green example; New Economics
news: ANZ'S announcement that it will seek a world-leading sustainability standard for its new complex in Melbourne's Docklands is likely to prompt more companies to invest to reduce their environmental impact, according to the Green Building Council of Australia.ANZ last week said it would build the largest green building in Australia on its Collins Street site. The 10-storey tower will use solar cells and wind power to cut reliance on fossil fuel-generated power by 70 per cent, while recycling will reduce use of mains water by 60 per cent. […] While the project would tap experience gained at the Royal Bank of Scotland's 6 Star-equivalent building in Edinburgh and a counterpart project for the BANK OF AMERICA in New York, Melbourne's hotter climate would require modifications including additional shading for windows, Mr Carolan said.[…]

title: GE to invest in 282 MW of wind projects due online by year end in New York
news: GE Energy Financial Services plans to invest in three wind farms totaling 282 MW in New York being developed by Noble Environmental Power. The plants are due to begin operating by year end and have a value of $564 million, according to the Stamford, Connecticut, subsidiary of GENERAL ELECTRIC. GE EFS is not disclosing details of its investment, said spokesman Ken Koprowski, but it said the transaction gives EFS stakes in 30 wind farms, with ownership equity of more than 2,000 MW (in which it has invested or committed to invest). When it purchased some wind assets in Texas in May, GE EFS said its wind equity holdings were around 1,900 MW. In the transaction with Noble, GE EFS would invest in the Class A equity as the non-managing member, while Noble would hold the Class B equity as the managing member. Noble is the developer and has been the sole equity holder, Koprowski said. To enable GE EFS to invest, the company created a second equity class, of which GE owns 100%. Noble is developing one project of 100.5 MW in Bliss, Wyoming County, in western New York, and two in Clinton County, in the northeastern part of the state. Those will be located in Clinton (100.5 MW) and Ellenburg (81 MW). The company, based in Essex, Connecticut, expects to bring the turbines into service in the fourth quarter. Noble is majority owned by JP Morgan Partners. Noble has already arranged to sell 95% of the renewable energy certificates generated by the projects to the New York State Energy and Research Development Authority, under 10-year contracts. NYSERDA would use these to help meet the state's Renewable Portfolio Standard, which requires 25% of the state's power to come from green energy by 2013 (including large hydro stations already in place). In New York, utilities and retail marketers do not seek their own supplies to meet the RPS mandate; instead, NYSERDA periodically holds bid solicitations for renewable power. […]

title: Be 'climate smart', growers told
news: Growers told to adopt 'climate-smart agriculture' to avoid further worsening of climate change.   The Government's chief scientist, Professor Sir John Beddington, has called for growers to pursue 'climate-smart agriculture' to avoid exacerbating climate change.  […] On sustainability, PEPSICO, which owns the Walkers Crisps brand, has committed to reducing its water use and carbon footprint by 50 per cent in five years, senior agriculture director David Wilkinson told the congress. He said the cost of inputs on UK farms has risen by 42 per cent in five years, adding: 'It's not sustainable for costs to go up by that degree.' PEPSICO is trialling techniques and varieties across Europe. Drip irrigation tests in the UK and Turkey have cut water use by 40 per cent with no yield penalty, he said.  The I-crop tool developed by PEPSICO UK and the University of Cambridge is being used to monitor moisture and water application levels in 10 per cent of its UK crop, said Wilkinson.  He predicted that new varieties will make up 80 per cent of the potatoes used by the company in 2017.  Scottish seed potatoes Record exports.[…]

title: Mapping new ways to save the planet
news: Next week, hundreds of IT specialists, programmers, scientists and environmentalists from around the world will gather in Auckland to discuss saving the planet. More than 340 professionals with areas of expertise including remote sensing, digital mapping and geo-informatics will be attending the Digital Earth Summit on Sustainability at the Aotea Centre from Monday. The Digital Earth movement grew out of a Nasa programme established in the 1990s. Put simply, its aim is to use advances in digital mapping technologies to help solve global issues.  The technologies that have combined to give us applications like Google Earth - the free web-based image of the entire globe created through a merging of satellite images - can be put to myriad uses for solving environmental issues, say Digital Earth's supporters. […]

title: Governors press for 'clean energy,' even as some acknowledge strain
news: The National Governors Association used its winter meeting in Washington last week to heighten its call for adoption of "clean" alternatives to oil, natural gas and coal to strengthen US energy security and reduce carbon emissions. But worries among coal states over the impact of such policies on their economies were evident throughout the three-day conference. "Governors and states are stepping forward to lead an energy revolution that will 'Americanize' our energy production in order to improve our national security, our economic well-being and our quality of life," NGA Chairman and Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty said at the opening of the meeting. Pawlenty, who last year made "Securing a Clean Energy Future" the theme of his one-year term with the association, called on his colleagues to support a diversified list of options for making the US more energy secure, from coal and nuclear energy to alternative fuels and energy efficiency. His and other states have surpassed Washington in setting standards for electricity from renewable energy and for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. […] GENERAL ELECTRIC CEO Jeffrey Immelt told the governors that they should use their state's markets to promote energy options such as wind and solar energy, adding that renewable portfolio standards have been effective in electricity markets. Immelt also said supporting a broad range of energy options, including coal and nuclear energy, is critical to not only US energy security but also to economic development. He said advanced coal and nuclear technologies, some of which GE sells or is developing, "ought to be one of the great export industries of this country." As he has before, Immelt called for national program to reduce carbon emissions, saying they would help his company and others in the US develop and sell innovative technologies for electricity generation and other markets, here and abroad. "At some point, our nation needs to set national standards," he said. Such thinking underlies GE's "ecomagination" campaign, which the company launched three years ago to concentrate on products with less environmental impacts, he said. Some governors were critical of the federal government regarding energy policy, saying it lags the states. "Here in Washington DC we have leaders talking," Montana Governor Brian Sweitzer, a Democrat, said. "Out in the states, we have governors acting. Maybe they can take a few notes from us." "We think of this as one of the most important things we can do in the 21st Century," Colorado Governor Bill Ritter Jr., a Democrat, said. Likewise, New York Times Pulitizer Prize-winning columnist Thomas Friedman said lack of political leadership is impeding technological advances in energy. "We still don't have leaders with political visions to put systems into place that would truly drive innovation," Friedman told the governors. "We have energy politics in this country," he added. "We don't have energy policy."

title: Reader Survey
news: Wholesalers are as concerned about their environmental impact as the multiples and major suppliers. But until now they have been less willing to shout about their achievements. All the wholesalers who replied to our survey agreed they had a duty to reduce their environmental impact.  They had also already taken steps to introduce environmentally friendly initiatives into their businesses and were all planning further developments over the next 12 months. Earlier this year Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda and M&S all grabbed the headlines with major sustainability projects. And in 6 a number of the country's biggest suppliers including Cadbury Schweppes, PEPSICO, Coca-Cola Enterprises and ABF launched major green initiatives. Now it seems wholesalers are also doing their bit to tackle this crucial issue. […]

title: Saving the world's profitable, CEO says
news: Gary Hirshberg cheekily refers to himself as the CE-Yo of Stonyfield Farm, the environmentally conscious organic yogurt maker. With his new book, Stirring It Up, Hirshberg could stick another moniker on his resume: CE-Openly Optimistic about the corporate world's ability to help heal the planet. […] *Wal-Mart. It's good news indeed when the world's largest company starts focusing on sustainability, Hirshberg writes. One reform, doubling the fuel efficiency of its 6,900-truck fleet, comes with a possible annual savings of $300 million, he writes. Wal-Mart also pushes suppliers to reduce packaging, works with the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation to conserve an acre of wildlife habitat for every acre of Wal-Mart development and is replacing incandescent bulbs  with compact fluorescent ones for a $7 million savings in electricity costs. *Interface. This $1 billion company makes Flor carpet tiles and has a goal to become totally sustainable by 2020, producing no toxic waste or emissions and using no oil. Hirshberg cites changes that have the company 40% of the way to achieving sustainability, including the installation of an $8.50 nozzle that changed water flow at a plant, saving water and about $10,000 a year. […]

title: Green office construction works on economics and ethics
news: SWITCHING to green commercial buildings has now become an ethical issue as well as an economic and environmental one, according to a US green building expert. Chief executive of the US Green Building Council, Rick Fedrizzi, told The Age green buildings did not cost more to construct than conventional buildings and were proven to increase the health and productivity of workers. […] He said major banks, including the BANK OF AMERICA, Wells Fargo, PNC and HSBC, were building offices that achieved high green ratings. The new BANK OF AMERICA tower in Manhattan has a platinum rating, the highest green rating achievable under the GBC's rating system, LEED (leadership in energy and environmental design).[…] Mr Fedrizzi said: "If the economics worked for him, the economics will work for everyone. Anyone that uses the excuse that is costs too much to build green is just absolutely wrong . . . It does not cost more to build green at all."

title: The dish on phosphates
news: That white, cloudy residue and streaking that has been showing up on your freshly washed dishes lately doesn't necessarily mean your dishwasher needs to be replaced. The culprit is more likely to be the detergent, thanks to a little-publicized federal ban on phosphate, a popular cleaning ingredient that leaves dishes and glasses with that sparkly shine. "There has been no public campaign to advise people that this has happened," said Bruce Cran, president of the Consumers Association of Canada.  The federal government brought in new regulations last 7 effectively banning phosphorus in most household cleaning products, such as dishwashing and laundry detergents. The new rules prohibit the manufacture and import of these products containing phosphorus beyond 0.5% by weight. Similar regulations in the United States banned the chemical in 17 states. But the government and industry failed to adequately inform the public of the change, says Mr. Cran, leaving frustrated homeowners wondering why their dishes aren't coming out of the machine as clean as they used to be. "It's probably because a satisfactory replacement hasn't yet been found," he said. "This is often the case with industry when things happen that aren't necessarily to their advantage." Excessive phosphorus dumps have become a major problem for Canada's waterways, says Lewis Molot, an environmental scientist at York University. Phosphorus in certain detergents and cleaning products softens water, reduces spotting and rusting , holds dirt, and increases performance. But it is also a plant fertilizer, Prof. Molot says, meaning when it enters a lake, it causes massive amounts of algae to grow. […] PROCTER & GAMBLE Co., maker of Cascade-brand detergent, says on its website it has invested heavily in product research and development over the past 1½ years to develop phosphate-free formulas.

title: Posture on carbon, other environment issues, remains to be seen as Duke, Cinergy progress
news: Environmental strategy is not among the key matters identified so far by executives of Duke and Cinergy as they propose merging to form one of the country's largest electric utilities, but they will clearly have to reconcile some differences in approach to carbon emissions and other environmental issues. Duke Energy Chairman and CEO Paul Anderson, who would serve as the merged company's chairman, came out in April in favor of an economy-wide carbon tax to control greenhouse gas emissions. But Cinergy CEO James Rogers, who is to be the new company's president and CEO, continues to prefer a cap on CO2 and an emissions trading program to help utilities meet the restrictions, although Cinergy has not endorsed any specific plan, a company spokesman said last week. […] "I thought it would be important for our company to partner with a company that has experience in nuclear power plants," Rogers said. For the future, he said, "I believe nuclear will play a role, along with renewables, coal and gas."  Cinergy's subsidiary Cincinnati Gas & Electric tried to build a nuclear unit but abandoned the effort in the early 1980s after construction problems led to delays in regulatory approvals. Rogers said the merger would not change Cinergy's plans to develop a low-emitting integrated coal gasification combined-cycle plant, although Cinergy must reach a final agreement with GENERAL ELECTRIC and Bechtel and get the necessary regulatory approvals. IGCC technology "gives us the ability to modernize our fleet and reduce the emissions from generation in the Midwest, and that's an important part of our objective going forward," he said. Cinergy has said an IGCC plant, possibly in the range of 500-800 MW, could be located at its existing 160-MW Edwardsport coal plant in southern Indiana. […]

title: Kazakh state bodies, GENERAL ELECTRIC sign cooperation accord
news: Text of report by Kazakhstan Today news agency website Astana, 21 February: Kazakh government bodies and GENERAL ELECTRIC International [GEI] signed a memorandum of cooperation today, a correspondent of the [Kazakhstan Today news] agency has said.  The document was signed by the president and chief executive officer of the GEI, Ferdinando Beccalli-Falco; the chairman of the [Kazakh] Samruk [state] holding company, Kanat Bozumbayev; a deputy chairman of the Kazyna sustainable development fund, Kayrat Aytekenov; a deputy [Kazakh] minister of health, Kadyr Omarov; and the chairman of the committee for roads and transport links of the [Kazakh] Ministry of Transport and Communications, Marat Orazbekov. "This document is an important milestone in the development of comprehensive cooperation between the GE and Kazakhstan. It demonstrates the GE's intention to strengthen long-term partnership relations with the country," Beccalli-Falco said after the document's signing ceremony. According to the press release issued by the Samruk holding company, the memorandum envisages cooperation between the parties in such spheres as oil and gas production, transport and processing; production of electricity, bioenergy, environment friendly types of energy; interaction in the sphere of energy saving, mining, metallurgy and metals processing, uranium processing and nuclear energy, financial solutions and investment management, development of transport infrastructure and machinery building and water infrastructure. The parties will also work on identifying and realizing export capacities of the Kazakh industry as well as on developing investment and business technologies in Kazakhstan, the press release said. […]

title: Airlines under pressure to make travel greener
news: Controversy over aircraft emissions has escalated over recent weeks, with disagreement between the European Union (EU) and most of the world's airlines. Closer to home, competition has emerged between airlines pursuing alternative fuel solutions, although it appears to be a David and Goliath contest. On Monday, Sir Richard Branson told a conference in Boston that "early next year" Virgin Atlantic would be conducting a Boeing 747 test flight with one of the renewable fuels his Virgin Group had developed. Noting Air New Zealand's plans for a similar 747 test flight late next year, a Reuters report said "Virgin is trying to beat that airline by testing biofuels first".  The Air NZ initiative was announced on September 28, when the airline signed a memorandum of understanding with its biofuel test partners, Boeing and Rolls-Royce. Virgin's similar agreement is with Boeing and the other major engine manufacturer, GENERAL ELECTRIC. Branson has not given more details, but he pledged last year that over the next decade he would spend the profit from his stake in Virgin airline and rail businesses on fighting global warming. He also created Virgin Fuels, which is investing US$400 million ($533 million) over three years in renewable energy initiatives. Emission reduction aside, this could be a rewarding investment, eventually creating a new fuel giant. […]

title: Pressure cooker INTRODUCTION:
news: Airlines are turning up the heat on engine makers to develop new, more efficient powerplants to drive the development of the next generation of narrowbody aircraft Open rotor engines look futuristic, and even slightly improbable, but there is a very real possibility that aircraft powered by this radical technology could be replacing Airbus A320s and Boeing 737s as the industry's narrowbody workhorses in the coming 10-15 years. "It may well be that somebody, while flight testing prototypes, comes up with a reason why open rotor technology can't work, but starting here and working forwards, it really should be plan A," says Hal Calamvokis, ?strategic planning manager at UK-based ?low-cost carrier easyJet.  As the picture to the right shows, open rotors basically look like fancy propellor-type engines. There are, however, design challenges. For instance, the classic ?underwing mounting position of today's turbofans may not be possible with the large-diameter blades of the open rotor. This points towards mounting the engines on the sides of the aft fuselage or ?beneath a high wing. If the potential can be realised, however, the introduction of open rotor engines would usher in the first all-new propulsion architecture since the late-1960s, when GE's introduction of the CF6 turbofan offered a game-changing improvement in fuel efficiency over turbojets. The issue of new engine technology has come to prominence as several major European and US airlines step up the pressure on airframers to commit to next generation ?narrowbodies to facilitate their domestic fleet replacement and growth. The ideal successor, they say, would provide a quantum leap in economics improvement and emissions reduction as fuel costs continue to slice deep into their bottom lines and regulatory bodies demand greater cuts in ?carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide emissions. […]

title: Green-building advocates take the LEED
news: Many four-letter words are being tossed around these torturous days in the world of commercial real estate. Only one would not offend the polite police. It is, however, prompting considerable debate within companies and among property owners. That word: LEED, for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design. Since its debut by the U.S. Green Building Council in 2000, LEED has rapidly become the rating standard by which green-building advocates measure commitment to the cause. As "going green" has evolved from a fringe lifestyle choice to a widespread initiative, even at work, the pressure has grown for building owners to at least consider LEED certification. […] In the last few years, employers have reported a growing number of job applicants asking about workplace-sustainability efforts. "There's a PR side to this," said Missy Quinn, director of client solutions for Cushman & Wakefield of Pennsylvania Inc., a real estate services company.[…] The total U.S. LEED building inventory is 4,825, with the Merchandise Mart in Chicago and the Getty Center in Los Angeles among the higher-profile examples. In New York, the Empire State Building boasts one LEED-certified floor (based on its commercial interiors) and is now pursuing structure-wide LEED status. In Philadelphia, the COMCAST Tower (with its now-famous waterless urinals) is LEED-certified in the "core and shell" category.  This week, local green-building advocates will again rejoice - over the city's first LEED certification of an existing multi-tenant building, the circa-1969, 36-story office tower at 1601 Market St. Mayor Nutter will join officials from the Delaware Valley Green Building Council for a plaque presentation Wednesday.[…]

title: Plane crazy: spotters out in force as starlet of the skies touches down
news: PLANE spotters are a distinctive breed. Armed with binoculars, telephoto lenses and milk crates (to gain a little extra altitude), they gathered at the perimeter fence at Sydney Airport to witness the arrival of the first Boeing 787 Dreamliner to visit Australia. "I think we smell the fumes.  We're just sort of addicted," Kenny Chung, 26, a hospitality worker who visits this spot twice a week to "spot" new aircraft, said. "It's not just that," his colleague, Alfred Portenschlager, 26, said. "When the plane lands, when it flies ... that grace in the air. Multiple thousands of tonnes just hanging in the air. I remember back in school I skipped class to go watch the first A380 land." As the 210-250 seater plane landed yesterday there were cheers and the click of camera shutters on the ground. Binoculars followed its every move as it taxied into the airport's corporate area on the Australian leg of an around-the-world demonstration tour. Three friends, Ken Sumner, Ryan Phillips and Brad Anderson, took the day off work and travelled from as far as the Blue Mountains for the "historic" event. They would spend the day finding more vantage points and spotting other aircraft. "The first thing I do every morning is log on to the Boeing website and print out their press releases. I've got about 10 crates of press releases from 1987. Every morning, I print out the whole lot," Mr Sumner, 60, a librarian, said. "Some blokes like cars," Mr Phillips, 32, added. "For us, it's aircraft." The men read magazines, scroll through photos and build replicas. Some have visited the facility in Washington where the Dreamliner is built. "You can look at all the pictures but until you see it in the flesh ... it's something else," Mr Anderson, 32, said. The Dreamliner is 60 per cent quieter than the Boeing 767, uses a fifth less fuel and can carry 50 per cent more cargo. "The Boeing 787 ... heralds a new era of quieter, greener aircraft," Kerrie Mather, the chief executive of Sydney Airport, said. Qantas is expected to take delivery of the 787 in 2013. Cabin pressure: stronger composite body allows higher cabin pressure, which helps breathing and reduces jetlag and airsickness. Windows: electronic glass dims automatically. No window shades required. Engines: GENERAL ELECTRIC/Rolls Royce, 20 per cent more fuel-efficient and 25 per cent quieter than comparable aircraft. Performance features Passengers: up to 290 Maximum range: 15,750km Cruising speed: 903km/h Maximum takeoff weight: 247 tonnes […]

title: Big leap into mainstream lures funds - CLEAN ENERGY - SPECIAL REPORT
news: SUDDENLY, renewable energy has come in from the fringe and is now attracting some serious money. Renewables, and clean energy generally, have taken what might be called a quantum leap. This sector is now suddenly of interest at the big end of town.[,,,] Second, there came a large investment from a Canadian pension fund in a US wind power project -- another sign that the rich North American pension funds are showing increasing interest in alternative energy investments. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, which has about $US119 billion under management, will place $US200 million for what it calls a significant minority interest in an environmental power company controlled by JP MORGAN CHASE. Noble Environmental Power is developing wind farms in several states including New York, Vermont, Maine and Texas.[…]

title: Financial: Supermarkets: The big chains all want to be green grocers - but it's nothing to do with that inquiry: Ecology replaces price as the selling point that aims to win shoppers' loyalty
news: For years the supermarkets' main battleground has been price: "every little helps", "everyday low prices", "value to shout about" and "Asda price" have been their cries. But in recent months they have found a new territory to tussle over: the environment. […] Last year Asda and its Wal-Mart parent made a $500m commitment to testing out new environmental technologies and a range of long-term environmental goals. Wal-Mart president Lee Scott promised the chain would be supplied 100% by renewable energy, create zero waste, help restore balance to climate systems, reduce greenhouse emissions and cut dependence on oil. Wal-Mart has given itself four years to reduce the carbon footprint of all its new stores worldwide by 30% and a seven-year target to cut the carbon footprint of its entire chain of 6,000 stores by 20%. This year Mr Scott gained a two-hour audience with Prince Charles to gain royal advice on how to become more ecologically sound. What is driving the determination to be clean and green? Some retail analysts believe Tesco has made a top-level decision to avoid the image problems that beset Wal-Mart in the US, which has been accused of riding roughshod over its suppliers, staff and smaller rivals. […] Sir Terry denied Tesco's initiatives are connected to the Competition Commission investigation and a need to improve the group's image. He added: "Whatever the motivation, if you are looking at the substance, it is substantive." Tesco has committed £100m to sustainable environmental technology, including solar panels and the gasification of food waste to provide power - twice as much as Gordon Brown set aside for similar initiatives in his last budget. Not all the lobby groups are impressed. Andrew Simms of the New Economics Foundation said: "As it stands, the only truly responsible corporate act the big four could do is to ask the regulator to break them up."

title: City to host U.S. green-building conference - and show its stuff
news: As achievements go, it's nowhere close to landing the Olympics. For enhancing the reputation Philadelphia seeks as a leader in the green-building movement, though, the city's selection as 2013 host for the U.S. Green Building Council's 12th annual conference could be a significant event. Quite possibly a game-changer for the region's economy.  But that hinges, its advocates acknowledge, on much work that needs to be done between now and then - in City Hall and the state Capitol, in hospitality and tourism circles, even at the zoo and museums.   When it comes to the region's accomplishments in building more sustainably and with environmental sensitivity - the COMCAST Center being perhaps the most showy example - "green building is a well-kept secret here, and it should not be," said Janet Milkman, executive director of the Delaware Valley Green Building Council (DVGBC), which serves the five-county Philadelphia area and the Lehigh Valley in Pennsylvania, as well as the state of Delaware. […]

title: The tides hold hope as a source of energy; Designs for wave power gain momentum
news: There is more riding the giant waves here than surfers, thanks to a growing number of scientists, engineers and investors. A group of entrepreneurs is harnessing the perpetual motion of the ocean and turning it into a commodity in high demand energy. Right now, machines of various shapes and sizes are being tested from the North Sea to the Pacific to see how they capture energy from waves and tides. The industry is still in its infancy, but it is gaining attention because of inventors like Dean Corren, who have lugged their wave and tidal prototypes around the world, even during the years when money and interest dried up. […] These days, though, growing attention is producing a wide range of prototypes, which are being tested. Wave power designs vary from machines that look like corks bobbing in the ocean to devices that resemble snakes pointing into waves. There are shoreline machines that cling, like limpets, to rocks. Tidal power machines often come in the form of giant underwater turbines, which generate energy by spinning as tides move in and out; but some inventors are testing concrete-and-steel machines that lie on the seabed and pipe pressurized water back to the shore. Even big commercial power companies are joining the movement. GENERAL ELECTRIC, Norsk Hydro of Norway and E.ON of Germany have recently pledged money for projects or investments in tiny marine energy companies. ''It is an untapped renewable energy source,'' said Mark Huang, senior vice president for technology finance in GENERAL ELECTRIC's media and communications business, which is financing marine projects. ''There is nowhere to go but up.'' He added that solar or wind energy should be viewed ''as a case study'' for the direction marine energy could take. […]

title: Cleantech investment hits record
news: Although the amount of venture capital pouring into technology startups has dipped this year, clean technology companies continue to act as funding magnets. According to a report from Ernst & Young LLP, investment in solar, biofuel and other renewable energy companies rose 41% in the second quarter to $961.7 million, up from $683.5 million in the first quarter. Not only is it the highest total cleantech investment on record, it comes in a quarter in which overall venture capital investment was down by nearly 8%. Year-over-year cleantech investment is up 83% over 2007 funding in the sector. "We've seen an increasing number of investments driven largely because the opportunities have become more robust, and there are recent entrants still learning the marketplace and aggressively competing on deals," said Joseph Muscat, Americas director of cleantech and venture capital with Ernst & Young.  According to the New York consulting and accounting firm, which drew on data from Dow Jones VentureOne, energy and electric generation companies attracted the most venture investment in the quarter with $494.9 million, more than 50% of the total amount invested in cleantech. The top three deals were for companies involved in solar technology: SunEdison of Beltsville, Md., which raised $131 million; eSolar Inc. of Pasadena, Calif., $130 million; and BrightSource Energy Inc.of Oakland, Calif., $115 million. All three of those investments involved corporate investors, Ernst & Young noted, with Google Inc. an investor in both eSolar and BrightSource. […]

title: McDonald's scoops up award with lighter spoon
news: SINCE May, fast-food chain McDonald's has been giving out a smaller and lighter spoon made of recycled plastic to those who buy its McFlurry ice cream. Such a change may have been scarcely noticed by customers, but it saved a noticeable $57,000 on the fast-food giant's balance sheet. Yesterday, McDonald's was given an award for its effort to cut down the amount of material used in its packaging. Handed out by the National Environment Agency (NEA) for the third year running, the 3R Packaging Award also went to 18 other companies, including Nestle, Asia Pacific Breweries, Coca-Cola, Starbucks and Tetra Pak Jurong. [...]

title: Africa;  IBM Opens Innovation Centre
news: IBM has opened its Africa Innovation Centre in Johannesburg to help companies develop their IT skills and help workers meet business challenges in sub- Saharan Africa.
