The centre, which opened yesterday, is the first of its kind on the continent, and forms part of IBM's commitment to invest $120m in Africa within the next two years to support the planned expansion of its business.IBM already works with almost 300 software companies in the region and the centre gives it access to a global network of 38 innovation centres and 60 research and development labs around the world.The company said IBM's business partners, software start-ups, hi-tech professionals and academics would be able to use its facilities to develop their skills and create software using IBM's infrastructure.The centre would also be used to demonstrate new technologies and show how they could improve business processes, including next- generation banking systems and environmentally friendly computing designs.[…]

title: Super rich ... and green; Billionaires are becoming a key source of funding for eco projects, writes Ben Marlow
news: Don Runkle desperately needed investors to back his new green invention. The former General Motors executive had developed a "lean engine" with fewer moving parts than a conventional one, making it more efficient. Instead of attracting the usual venture capital investors to fund his EcoMotors firm, he ended up getting the backing of two of the world's richest men. Last 8's investment from Bill Gates, founder of Microsoft, and Vinod Khosla, founder of Sun Microsystems, is part of a growing desire by the world's super-rich to put some of their wealth into green technologies.  Experts predict that some of the world''s richest individuals will help to plug a funding shortfall that is tipped to hit the next generation of green entrepreneurs. Until recently, traditional venture capital and private equity firms had provided the bulk of financing for green start-ups, usually through dedicated green funds. The trend is now changing. […] According to Cleantech, four of the ten largest green investments in the last quarter have been backed by corporate investors in deals with a total value of $226m. They include Intel, Samsung and Unilever. GENERAL ELECTRIC recently sunk a total of $55m into 12 energy-focused start-ups. It also plans to give five $100,000 grants to businesses founded by scientists working on green inventions, including Capstone Metering, which makes water meters powered by flowing water. Other companies that have raised dedicated green funds include Siemens, General Motors and Cisco. "There's genuine interest from companies facing challenges to their business models over the next decade that see this as a big new revenue opportunity," said Lang. "There is a more complex and diverse pool of capital emerging." title: Sierra Club targets Dynegy for its coal projects; says attacks on other companies might follow
news: The Sierra Club on February 20 launched its first company-specific campaign against coal-fired plants by targeting Dynegy, which is co-developing six coal projects totaling nearly 6,000 MW, in the US in a joint venture with LS Power. [...] "Up to this point our members have mainly been involved at the state level, where we have been challenging every [coal-fired] project we can," said Sierra Club spokeswoman Virginia Cramer. The group's goal? "What it comes down to is that we hope Dynegy will come to realize that coal plants are a bad investment," given the likelihood of carbon legislation that will significantly increase the total cost of generating electricity from coal. "Banks and Wall Street already are realizing this," said Cramer, referring to the February 4 announcement by CITIGROUP, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley of "The Carbon Principles," or guidelines for lenders to US power companies for "evaluating and addressing carbon risks in the financing of electric power projects" (GPR, 7 Feb, 6). [...]

title: Nigeria; Biodiversity Gets Corporate Attention
news: Business leaders in biodiversity-rich developing economies are concerned about losses of 'natural capital', a new report highlights. Over 50 per cent of Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) surveyed in Latin America and 45 per cent in Africa see declines in biodiversity as a challenge to business growth. In contrast, less than 20 per cent of their counterparts in Western Europe share such concerns. […] "Better accounting of business impacts on biodiversity - both positive and negative - is essential to spur change in business investment and operations," says Joshua Bishop, the TEEB for Business report coordinator and Chief Economist of IUCN. "Smart business leaders realise that integrating biodiversity and ecosystem services in their value chains can generate substantial cost savings and new revenues, as well as improved business reputation and license to operate." The TEEB report cites the case of the multinational mining giant Rio Tinto as one company that has committed itself to achieving Net Positive Impact on biodiversity. In association with leading conservation experts the company has developed new ways of assessing the biodiversity values of its land holdings, and has begun to apply biodiversity compensation or 'offset' methodologies in Madagascar, Australia and North America. Other companies with similar commitments on biodiversity include Walmart (Acres for America initiative), Coca Cola (water neutral by 2020) and BC Hydro (no net incremental ecological impact). […]

title: Conventions vote for green; Parties embrace eco-friendly alternatives
news: Organizers of the Democratic and Republican national conventions taking place in Denver and St. Paul, Minn., respectively, are promising a ``greener'' experience for delegates and other attendees. [...] ``Green is the new gold of the convention industry,'' said Richard Scharf, convention bureau president and CEO. ``A recent study of meeting planners found that one in three have been told by their delegates to only meet in green destinations, and one in four said that if all else is equal, they will meet in the greenest destination.'' [...] Republican convention organizers announced that Waste Management Inc. and Coca-Cola Recycling LLC would provide recycling services for their convention at the Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul. Waste Management will collect all waste and recyclable material and take it to a facility in Minneapolis where the recyclable material will be sorted and baled. [...]

title: Thinking positively
news: Rewarding good behaviour is more fun than pounding the bad guys - and gives you a chance to deliver your message to receptive ears. Case in point: Brian Mulroney was honoured earlier this year as the "greenest" prime minister in Canadian history. At an Earth Week gala dinner that gave the nation's environmentalists an unprecedented opportunity to mingle with the resurgent Conservatives, Mulroney delivered an impassioned speech about the dangers of climate change while the new Prime Minister, Stephen Harper, sat at the head table, taking notes.[…] Naming names, he's learned, is a stimulant to good behaviour. In the meantime, he gets around. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Heaps celebrated his "2006 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations" rankings with Innovest CEO Matthew Kiernan and INTEL Corp. chairman Craig Barrett as panelists. In adjacent rooms, Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf, Microsoft's Bill Gates and columnist Thomas Friedman hosted concurrent presentations. In recent issues, he's offered "tips for the Feds" on how to eliminate the release of toxic chemicals into the environment. And "The Toxic 50," inspired by a University of Massachusetts "Toxic 100 list." Topping the Canadian list were Inco, Abitibi Consolidated, Alcan, Falconbridge, Imperial Oil.[…]

title: A stunning climb up the green ladder; Personal computers
news: Apple, Hewlett-Packard et al take note: in just one year the Chinese computer manufacturer Lenovo rose from bottom rung on the Greenpeace ladder, which ranks technology companies' environmental friendliness, to the top. The company, which has its headquarters in Raleigh, North Carolina, took over IBM's personal computer division in 2005. It earned praise for its precautionary principle stance - taking responsibility for advocating action such as chemical use even where the scientific evidence of harm is not clear. Lenovo was also lauded for its stance on individual producer responsibility, looking after products at the end of their lives wherever recycling legislation was being considered. Lenovo's director of environmental affairs, Mike Pierce, says the company was at the bottom of the Greenpeace survey of 14 technology companies last year because it had failed to communicate its environmental policies.[…] For 38 years Pierce worked for IBM, in product development, manufacturing and marketing, rising to business unit general manager. He moved to the personal computer division a couple of years before Lenovo took over IBM's personal computer assets in May 2005, when it had become "increasingly clear" personal computers had unique environmental issues such as recycling that needed attention. Pierce provides a global environmental perspective for Lenovo, whose shipping outside China began in earnest just over two years ago. Last December Lenovo began offering a free take-back recycling service within China to business and consumers of Lenovo and IBM computers. In Australia a take-back recycling program is offered to Lenovo's commercial customers as part of a bundled sale deal, which might include credit against a new purchase. Given the company's tiny share of the home consumer market, Pierce says, the recycling scheme offered to Australian consumers is more "ad hoc", but Lenovo will take its branded products back for free from individuals. The fate of old IBM-branded computers in Australia is left with IBM.[…]

title: Making trap for greenhouse gas
news: SYDNEY - New Zealand coal miner Solid Energy has joined other miners in an Australian project to capture carbon dioxide emissions and store them underground to combat global warming. "Our experiments will simulate natural geological processes that trap CO2 for up to millions of years," said Peter Cook, chief executive of the research group conducting the project. "We will be putting the CO2 back underground, from where it came." The A$30 million project - partly financed by companies including CHEVRON, Xstrata and Rio Tinto, as well as Solid Energy - will be carried out by the Co-operative Research Centre for Greenhouse Gas Technologies and will be located in western Victoria. […] CHEVRON, the second-largest US oil company, plans to use underground disposal of carbon dioxide at its A$11 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas project in Western Australia, while so-called geo-sequestration may also be used to reduce harmful emissions from coal-fired power plants. […] Geo-sequestration is one of the technologies to be discussed this week in Sydney by the six members of the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate, which aims to promote clean energy technology as a way to tackle climate change without sacrificing economic growth. […] Government sources said the partnership planned to create a fund to help develop cleaner energy technologies, which Australia would kick-start with about A$100 million. The partnership will also be counting on private support to develop and deliver technologies such as clean coal and renewable energy, and will meet some of the world's top energy companies, including BHP Billiton and ExxonMobil, during the two-day talks.

title: GE tilts at green power protectionism
news: Like Kermit the frog, GENERAL ELECTRIC vice-chairman John Krenicki occasionally laments that it's not easy being green. Mr. Krenicki runs GE's massive energy division - its 85,000 employees posted $37-billion in sales last year - and on the face of it, everything's going his way. Anyone getting into wind power will likely order GE turbines. The same is true on solar, hydro, grids and just about any other technology that keeps the lights on. As a dominant player in green power, Mr. Krenicki would seem to have the world at his feet.  But here's where Kermit's problem comes in to play: It's not easy being green because sustainable power has become such a hot button issues for politicians. No self-respecting leader has a power policy that doesn't include voter-friendly planks, such as local jobs in green manufacturing, or local content in green power projects. Political overlays tend to add inefficiencies to power, and the process-driven GE types just hate inefficiency. […] So on the eve of the G8 and G20 summits last week, Mr. Krenicki did a Canadian tour, to preach the gospel of eliminating trade barriers on green power. (An engineer by training, he recent made the same pilgrimage on the other side of the Atlantic, helping set continental energy policy within the European Union, in part by pitching at the World Economic Forum.)  The core of GE's message is that the power industry rewards scale: Large, integrated markets will get cheaper green power than small, fragmented markets. Policies that put local interests, such as green jobs, ahead of this over-arching goal are bad policy.  In making this case, GE is clearly talking its own book. But consider what Mr. Krenicki is arguing; there's a Buy America policy in Washington in the wake of the recession. A GE executive who should be wrapping himself in the Stars & Stripes hates that nationalist concept. He sees an America-first policy hurting GE in most of the countries it serves, including China, India and Canada. […]

title: Major names join forces in Start Today initiative
news: Procter & Gamble, British Gas and Eurostar are among a coalition of brands launching sustainable-living drives as part of the Start Today initiative.  This week, each participating brand has begun rolling out marketing campaigns, carrying the Start Today branding, urging consumers to take 'one simple step' toward being more environmentally friendly.   Start Today, which was conceived by integrated agency Meteorite, is led by Start, an initiative to encourage sustainable living, overseen by HRH the Prince of Wales, Business in the Community and The Marketing Society. […]  When the plan for the day of action - originally dubbed One Day, 1/11/11 - was revealed earlier this year, the stated aim was for every piece of marketing communications running on 1 November in the UK to include a green message. However, just 10 companies signed up to the scheme.  Cheshire defended the take-up, stating: 'It's a great selection of brands. This is only year one; it came around a bit too quickly for many brands to build it into their marketing plans.'  START TODAY CAMPAIGN THEMES.  - Aviva 'Start dejunking your trunk' […]  - IBM 'Start building a Smarter Planet' […]

title: Getting gold out of green; Companies learn eco-friendliness helps bottom line
news: In the 1990s, corporate America's embrace of the green movement was led mostly by free-spirited, maverick companies such as Ben & Jerry's, Starbucks and Whole Foods. Now, mainstream giants in markets spanning consumer products, banking, airlines and chemicals have sweeping programs to shrink their companies' impact on the environment -- and cash in on consumers' desire to go green. Many see doing so as a virtual necessity as regulators consider limits on greenhouse gas emissions and consumers demand environmentally friendly products. […] Wells Fargo was named the Environmental Protection Agency's No.1 green power partner this year after it offset 40% of its electricity use by buying renewable energy credits, which are certificates that subsidize the cost of wind, biomass or other alternative energy projects. The banking giant also has provided $750 million in loans for the construction of environmentally friendly office and apartment buildings. Bank customers surveyed said installing energy-efficient windows is the No. 1 upgrade they would make with a $50,000 home equity credit line. "This is clearly what our customers ... are focused on, and we're reflecting that," says bank Vice President Mary Wenzel. Others going green: *Marriott hotels are saving 65% on hotel lighting costs after replacing 450,000 bulbs with compact fluorescents last year. The chain also changed out 400,000 shower heads to cut hot water usage 10%. […]

title: Green Bond Market Poised for Growth Spurt
news: HIGHLIGHT: Solactive's launch last month of the first-ever green bond index is a sign that sustainable investment has taken root in the fixed-income market. If 2013 was the year the green bond market finally took root, 2014 could very well be the one it begins to flourish. One sign of the markets maturation is the arrival of the first index dedicated entirely to green bonds. The Solactive Green Bond index, launched March 12 by Frankfurt-based index provider Solactive, comprises bonds categorized as green that is, those that raise capital for a project with specific environmental benefits by the Climate Bonds Initiative, a nonprofit organization headquartered in London. […] The issue was very well received. It was well understood that Toyota has a good following, says Michael Eckhart, global head of environmental finance and sustainability for Citigroup in New York, which served as joint book runner along with Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. This broadened the investor base to some extent, bringing socially responsible investors to a Toyota placement for the first time. […] Eckhart reckons that Citis recent deals have seen roughly 55 percent of allocations come from asset or fund managers, and roughly 45 percent from other investors, such as pensions and insurance companies. […] The development of the Green Bond Principles, which were released in 1, is likely to drive volume, according to bankers. Drafted by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Citi, Crdit Agricole CIB and J.P. Morgan and endorsed by scores of other banks, the principles are voluntary guidelines as to what constitutes a green bond, as well as how to report the ways in which the money raised is being spent. This is important because without transparency, investors cannot ensure a company is actually using a green bond issues proceeds for environmentally friendly projects. [The principles] are what the green bond market needed, says Citigroups Eckhart. It is working right away, and all the feedback that banks are getting is that there are a large number of deals coming pretty quickly. […]

title: The New Greens Like It Big; The green view based on small sources and market power will give way to one based on scale and subsidies.
news: The winds of economic destruction are flattening not just retirement accounts but also naive visions for a green economy. Public support for costly new green mandates is weakening, and government budgets to fund them are bleeding red ink. Plummeting prices of oil and other fossil fuels have made it harder for green to compete in the marketplace. IPOs of firms working on "clean tech" green energy that have fueled fantasies of the coming energy revolution have crashed to a halt. In all the bad economic news, a new face of green is coming into focus. Whereas the old view of green tech was based on many small, decentralized sources of power and a green economy that harnessed the power of the marketplace, the new version will rely more heavily on regulation and subsidies. It will also embrace the wisdom, true in most of the energy business, that bigger is better for weathering economic storms. The market, it's now clear, is not a reliable force for driving the adoption of green technologies. Just as the role of government is rising across banking and other sectors of the economy, new green will be much more wary of market forces as the route to profit. Google dreamed, in its "RE < C" scheme, that if it put enough money into green renewable energy ("RE") that eventually those power sources would triumph over dirty coal. With coal prices half what they were in 7 and the cost of steel and concrete for building coal-fired power plants sinking, that strategy isn't looking like a winner. Supporters of renewable energy have been much more effective in affecting regulation: in most of the United States it is now nearly impossible to get approval to build new coal plants (even when they replace older, less efficient units) and half the states force power companies to buy rising amounts of renewable electricity almost regardless of cost. Obama plans to extend such mandates nationwide. […]

title: US oil industry split over climate change
news: A RIFT has broken out within the US oil industry over a plan outlined in a leaked memo to deploy thousands of workers in so-called  Energy Citizen  rallies protesting against imminent climate change legislation.  The American Petroleum Institute (API), which represents the US oil industry, has written to member companies asking them to  move aggressively  to stage up to 22 public meetings, similar to the recent protests against President Barack Obama s healthcare plans. The move is strongly supported by API core members such as ExxonMobil, which has warned that the legislation could put businesses employing millions of workers  at a disadvantage  with competitors. But the plan is exposing splits in the organisation, as some members belong to another group, the US Climate Action Partnership (Ucap), which supports many of Mr Obama s environmental policies. Shell, a leading member of Ucap, has argued that tackling climate change is  the pro-growth strategy . Other Ucap companies include GENERAL ELECTRIC, Siemens, BP America and ConocoPhillips. Yet all also provide funding to API. […]

title: Interest in energy efficiency recharges Myron Zucker Inc.
news: […] More businesses are heeding the call to reduce their power load, and for good reason, said Jim Newman, owner and managing partner of Newman Consulting Group in Bloomfield Hills. Newman is known as a leading Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) consultant. The LEED green building rating system was developed by the U.S. Green Building Council in 1998 and provides a suite of standards for environmentally sustainable construction.[…] "We're talking about reducing our energy use by 30 percent in this country, which can be done much more effectively by addressing the energy being used in existing buildings and new construction," Newman said. While Myron Zucker competes with such large organizations as General Electric, Eaton Corp. and Square D, it has high-profile clients such as Honda Motors, PEPSICO and Rockwell Automation. Other customers include correctional facilities, such as Oaks Correctional in Manistee, and Naust Marine, a provider of shipping equipment located in Iceland.[…]

title: Wary of climate risk, banks craft plan to guide financing of new coal plants
news: Three large US banks announced a series of principles last week designed to help them evaluate and address "carbon risks" in the financing of coal-fired power projects. The banks ? Citi, JP MORGAN CHASE and Morgan Stanley ? said development of the so-called Carbon Principles was driven by "the risks faced by the power industry as utilities, independent producers, regulators, lenders and investors deal with the uncertainties around regional and national climate change policy." The banks said they developed the principles over a nine-month period in consultation with leading power companies American Electric Power, CMS Energy, DTE Energy, NRG Energy, PSEG, Sempra and Southern Company. Environmental groups Natural Resources Defense Council and Environmental Defense also were part of the talks. The banks said the effort marks the first time a group of lending institutions has come together and consulted with power companies and environmental groups "to develop a process for understanding carbon risk around power sector investments needed to meet future economic growth and the needs of consumers for reliable and affordable energy."[…] The principles include energy efficiency, saying that "an effective way to limit CO2 emissions is to not produce them." The banks said they will encourage clients to invest in cost-effective demand reduction, "taking into consideration the value of avoided CO2 emissions."[…] The White House expressed little surprise in the banks' effort, noting that financial institutions already look at other environmental issues when investing in new plants. "It's sensible that they take a look at it," said James Connaughton, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality.

title: Expecting New Tax, Firm Prepares to Track Carbon
news: If Congress passes legislation that puts a price on carbon emissions, companies will need to track and report the waste from their operations. Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of Silicon Valley's top venture capital firms, is betting that such a cap-and-trade law or carbon tax will open the door for a new kind of software company. [...] The Coca-Cola Company has been using Hara's software as part of a pilot project to track greenhouse gas emissions for its 1,000 facilities worldwide. It helps Coca-Cola keep track of projects that vary by country. In South Africa, for example, Coca-Cola is switching from heavy crude oil to natural gas. In the United States, where plants have not been using heavy oil, the company has been updating its lighting systems.

title: Is green power in your future?
news: More than 300 utilities in 32 states now offer some form of ''green power'' program that allows consumers to support electricity production from renewable resources. In spite of green power's premium price tag, the idea has taken hold at many large firms, and that alone should be enough for every energy company to consider making green power one of its offerings. Other major companies getting into the green business in a big way through their association with the WRI include: -- General Motors Corp., which is already using gas from one landfill to fuel some of its powerhouse boilers. In addition, GM plans to purchase 8 million kWh or more of electricity generated by gas from another landfill in Michigan.  -- IBM Corp. The computer giant's facilities in Minnesota and Texas are buying wind-generated electricity through utility green pricing programs. These facilities now buy more than 5.4 million kWh of green electricity each year.  -- Johnson & Johnson, which has installed photovoltaic (PV) systems totaling nearly 350 kW on the rooftops of three buildings.  -- Kinko's.

title: Teleworking now beginning to make its impact
news: Whether we like it or not, new technology is changing the way we work. Telework will affect the way that the majority of Europe's labour force is employed in the future. The question may not be where will the work be done - at home, with the customer, on the road or in the office - but how and for whom it is done.[…] According to Mr Noel Treacy, Minister of State for Science, Technology and Commerce, the main driving forces behind the rise of teleworking in the US and Britain have been the problems caused by commuting to city centre offices, including stress on workers, environmental pollution and energy and property costs. These influences have a familiar ring about them.[…] But again the research results are positive, with a study at the University of Massachusetts discovering that teleworkers or telecommuters were: as productive as, or more productive than, their non-telecommuting work colleagues, happier, more dedicated employees, better able to balance the pressures of their work and family lives, contributing to reduced overhead expenses and air pollution, traffic congestion and fuel consumption and; improving employee attraction and retention statistics. These findings are supported by a project undertaken by AT&T and the State of Arizona. It found that telecommuters were more available for consultation with clients and their supervisors at home by phone than they were in the office.[…]

title: The greenest laundry cleaner yet from Ariel
news: PROCTER & GAMBLE is launching a version of Ariel that it claims cleans clothes effectively at temperatures as low as 15 degrees. The household goods giant is heralding Ariel Excel Gel as the biggest breakthrough to hit the £961m laundry category to date. It has also had praise from the green lobby.  The newcomer's strapline  'Cold is the new hot', reinforces the message that consumers can save money on energy - and be more energy efficient - by washing their clothes at half the temperature needed for previous products. "[…]  Environmental campaigners WRAP welcomed P&G's move and called for other global manufacturers to be inspired by the innovation. "We hope it will encourage other brands and companies to look at their own product pipelines in a similar way," said Richard Swannell, director of retail & organic programmes. Hugh Jones, director of solutions at the Carbon Trust also praised the launch, describing it as an an example of how innovation in design or services could help to drive carbon reductions. "Businesses that meet their customers' requirements at the same time as helping to reduce their impact on the environment, will be the ones that capitalise on the opportunities created by the move to a low carbon economy," he said.  P&G's previous 'green' initiatives include the 'Ariel Turn to 30' campaign, launched in October 2006.

title: South Africa; Computing Giants Join Forces With WWF
news: AN UNLIKELY alliance has sprung up between the industrial giants Intel, HP and Lenovo and a handful of other hi-tech companies and the bunny-hugging World Wildlife Fund.  The alliance has been created to promote energy-efficient computing and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 54-million tons a year. Others committing to the scheme by forming the Climate Savers Computing Initiative include Dell, EDS, IBM and Microsoft. The goal is to set aggressive targets for energy-efficient computers and components, and promote the adoption of energy-efficient computers and power management tools. […] The initiative licensed its name from the World Wildlife Fund Climate Savers programme, which encourages companies to reduce their carbon footprint. "This is the first time our Climate Savers programme has been applied to an entire sector, engaging manufacturers, retailers, and consumers," said senior vice-president John Donoghue.

title: Razali to discuss Myanmar road map with the new PM
news: […] Meanwhile, Malaysia has established an association, recognised by the United Nations, to further promote caring corporate society in the country. The association takes the form of Corporations with Environmental and Social Awareness (CESA), jointly established by the UN Development Programme with the country's business community. CESA is Malaysia's version of the UN-initiated Global Compact, an international voluntary framework that promotes good corporate citizenship. Companies within the network are committed to nine principles in the areas of basic rights, environmental protection and employee equitability, which are adopted in their overall business strategy and operations.[…] To date, 12 companies in Malaysia are voluntarily engaged in CESA, including Nestle, Ford, BASF and CISCO SYSTEMS.[…]

title: Material benefits
news: Nostalgia for the days of greaseproof paper or even concern for the environment will not cut down the endless litter of plastic covers, Cellophane wraps, and cardboard packaging filling our kitchen binliners each week.  And while we may feel a twinge of guilt (when pressed, two thirds of consumers feel that products are overpackaged), manufacturers aren't going to cut down for our sakes, not while we also admit in surveys that packaging determines what we sling in the shopping trolley.  But industry is worried about overpackaging, and for the very sound industrial motive of cutting costs.  You may not have noticed it (the manufacturers will do their utmost to make sure you don't), but leading brands have been stealthily reducing the amount of material used in packaging.  First of all, says the Institute of Grocery Distribution in a report on Packaging Source Reduction, there's product redesign. Creating a compact product, like concentrated washing powder, seems commercial suicide, given that smaller boxes make a smaller impact on the shelf (or facing, in the technical jargon). But PROCTER & GAMBLE, first on the market, reasoned that fewer raw ingredients and less packaging made for a product cheaper to make and transport. It overcame the value-for-money hurdle in the public's mind and became a winner.[…]  Even Coca Cola has joined the fray, by nipping in the neck of its Coke cans - not merely a design feature, it actually cuts 6% off its aluminium consumption. And when you consider the billions of cans drunk and thrown away each year, it's no small saving for the environment, either.

title: Unibail's green bond sets high structural standard
news: Unibail-Rodamco, the French-Dutch property company, sold its first green bond on Wednesday, using a highly developed and comprehensive framework to monitor the use of proceeds, which will set a new reference point for future issuers. Jon Hay reports.[…] Not only is Unibail earmarking proceeds just for buildings that receive a Very Good or better rating for sustainability from Breeam, but it has employed Vigeo, the French sustainability rating agency, to monitor the assets' performance on a host of environmental, social and governance criteria.[…] Like Vasakronan, Unibail already had a strong sustainability track record. It has been garlanded with a string of sustainability and ethical business honours and accreditations, and likes to think of itself as one of the green leaders among European commercial property companies.[…] BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch and Crédit Agricole, the structuring banks, took Unibail on a roadshow from February 10 to 13, during which it presented its sustainable development policy as well as an update on its credit. Unibail is rated A/A+ with stable outlooks by Standard & Poor's and Fitch. Then on Tuesday, the same two banks held a conference call for investors, focused specifically on sustainability, and on presenting a possible green bond issue.[…] "Working out fair value for a 10 year was difficult," said Angus Reynolds, vice president of corporate syndicate at BANK OF AMERICA Merrill Lynch in London, "because Unibail's seven to nine year curve is inverted."[…]

title: GE 'can help SA with its power crisis'
news: GE 'can help SA with its power crisis' Electricity problems 'not unique' Chief Reporter GENERAL ELECTRIC (GE) CEO Jeffrey Immelt believes his company can help SA ease its electricity crisis. "A company as big as GE, with its expertise, I believe can help address infrastructure problems in SA," Immelt told a news conference in Johannesburg yesterday. GE has already invested in three environmentally friendly projects in SA. […] GE - a diversified technology, media and financial services company - has emphasised creating renewable energy and environmentally friendly industries with high growth options since 2005. This emphasis came at a time when energy costs were escalating and there was world pressure for governments to explore more sustainable energy alternatives. Half of the company's revenue came from markets outside the US, of which the African region made a "significant" contribution, he said. GE last year recorded $173bn in revenue, of which African operations brought in $2,5bn, up 32% on the previous year. GE Energy's biogas generators are being used to power SA's first methane gas-to- energy project at two sites near Durban, as well as an effluent-to- biogas plant that will provide electricity to a gas-to-liquid refinery at PetroSA in Mossel Bay. GE Water & Process Technologies is to construct a reserve osmosis seawater desalination plant and zero-liquid discharge system as part of a larger investment in a new chlorine refinery in the Coega Industrial Zone. The company was also supplying a range of cardiology technology and equipment to the 250-bed Ethekwini Hospital and Heart Centre in Durban. […]

title: Foreign Corporations to Hire Polish Firms to Work on Nuclear Project
news: The following is a summary of an article by Agnieszka Lakoma, featured in Rzeczpospolita. Last week, Rzeczpospolita daily organised a conference devoted to the Polish nuclear project. It was attended by state officials involved in the initiative, as well as nuclear experts and representatives of firms interested in building a nuclear plant in Poland.  Nuclear project to consume EUR13.5bn According to government officials attending the conference, the main priorities of the project are ensuring that the reactors are safe and that domestic firms be strongly involved in the whole operation. Andrzej Chwas from the Economy Ministry stressed that the nuclear project was necessary for Poland to meet the requirements of the EU climate package and CO2 emission policy. "It will be a stable source of energy for many years," he added. […] GE Hitachi has already concluded a preliminary agreement with Poland's Rafako and the local shipyards. According to GE Hitachi Nuclear Energy deputy head David Powell, his company can build a nuclear plant in 39 months, but its co-operation with Polish companies may last much longer. In his opinion, the project may lead to creation of around 6,300 jobs in the industry. At the conference, Areva Polska President Adam Rozwadowski announced that his corporation would consider co-operation with Polish firms provided they met the relevant standards and came up with a competitive offer. He stressed that Areva was more concerned about security than about where the company was from. Rozwadowski also pointed out that the corporation had already co-operated with Polish companies on the Olkiluoto project in Finland. The declarations made by the aforementioned nuclear reactor manufacturers will be put to the test in four years' time, following the completion of tenders for building the nuclear plant and supplying the necessary equipment. So far, PGE has not even launched the tender for the supplying the technology for the project.

title: Exxon calls for regulatory stability in Arctic
news: [...] The oil industry is capable of developing new resources in areas such as the Arctic in a safe, environmentally sound manner, but needs governments to provide regulatory stability, ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson said Monday in comments directed largely at Russia. [...] "Contrary to some claims, [the Arctic] is not unfamiliar territory for our industry," he said. [...] ExxonMobil plans to start drilling in the Arctic's remote Kara Sea this summer as part of a strategic partnership deal with Russian state-controlled Rosneft. [...]

title: Australia"s major banks cop blast from Oxfam
news: Australia"s major banks are scrambling to distance themselves from dealings with companies accused of fraud, stealing land, illegal logging, child labour and other illegal or immoral practices in developing countries. [...] The banks, which Oxfam said had continued supporting land-grabbing companies despite evidence of their activities, have said they will now work with Oxfam on the allegations. Oxfam said a number of major multinationals, including Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, and international financial institutions such as the World Bank, had already adopted tough due diligence policies to prevent their involvement in land grabs. The report said that across Asia NAB had been funding palm oil giant Wilmar, accused of stealing land in Indonesia and Malaysia since 2011. The bank had extended loans to Wilmar last year despite Newsweek magazine"s rating it the least sustainable company in the world for environmental performance. [...]

title: Developers delay $4-billion Bute hydro project; Amid confusion over B.C. energy policy, Plutonic Power and GE decides to wait a year to pursue green power deal
news: Plutonic Power Corp. and GENERAL ELECTRIC Co. will delay their controversial, $4-billion Bute hydroelectric project north of Vancouver, a decision made amid the public-policy confusion that has beset energy development in British Columbia. While Vancouver-based Plutonic insists it could have won a power-purchase agreement from BC Hydro, it has instead decided to spend another year collecting data and conducting other preparatory work, hoping to move to officially win a contract with the provincially owned electricity provider at a later date. With the delay, the earliest Bute could be supplying power is 2014.  Bute was among dozens of projects being considered in a call for green power issued by BC Hydro nearly two years ago. The process descended into chaos last summer when the independent B.C. Utilities Commission rejected BC Hydro's plans as "not in the public interest." The commission also said that hydro could rely more heavily on the half-century-old greenhouse-gas-spewing natural gas power plant Burrard Thermal in Port Moody.  The situation flared as competing jurisdictions around the world - in Canada, B.C.'s chief rival is Ontario - pushed aggressively to attract green energy capital from investors still scarred by the near-implosion of the global economy. Winners in the B.C. clean call are expected to be announced by BC Hydro by the end of this week - Plutonic and GE are still in the running with a small project called Upper Toba near Bute - but the whole drama has led to a rewriting of energy development law in B.C., with Premier Gordon Campbell's Liberal government ready to introduce the Clean Energy Act. […]

title: Climate Savers add to green push
news: Environment. THE Climate Savers Computing Initiative has arrived, with INTEL, Dell, Lenovo and EDS holding a local launch at the Going Green Expo in Melbourne last week. Founded a year ago, the non-profit, industry-wide initiative aims to achieve a 50 per cent improvement in global computer energy efficiency by 2010. The program's goal of 90 per cent performance for PC power supplies, for both business and home users, would cut greenhouse gas emissions by 54 million tonnes a year, and save more than $US5.5 billion ($5.7 billion) in energy costs. Google, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and the World Wildlife Fund also support the local program, launched by Climate Savers global leader Lorie Wigle. […] Participating computer manufacturers are committed to building products that meet or surpass the Environmental Protection Agency's Energy Star ratings.[…]

title: Coca-Cola to get extra fizz from the Olympics; THE BUSINESS OF 2012 The UK economy may not get a boost from the Games, but its corporate sponsors are set for a winning performance, writes Graham Ruddick
news: [...] Coca-Cola is the longest-running continuous Olympic sponsor and has been a partner of the International Olympic Committee since 1928. It is the only sponsor that was also involved in the last London Olympics, in 1948. [...] However, Belfast-born Woods, the general manager for Coca-Cola UK & Ireland, is now also preparing for the biggest operation the UK business has ever undertaken. "The Olympics will be the biggest single catering event in the UK since the Second World War," he explains. The company is seconding 500 people to the Olympic Park during the Games to assist the organisers, Locog. Coca-Cola plans to use the Park as a test bed for new products and methods. For example, it has committed to cutting its carbon footprint at the Olympics by a third against the existing UK business. [...]

title: Mexico to build six to eight nuclear units, says utility official
news: Mexican energy authorities plan to build six to eight 1,400-MW nuclear units, Rafael Fernandez, director of Laguna Verde, which is the country's only nuclear plant, said this week. While no formal plan has been announced, officials from the energy ministry and the Federal Electricity Commission, or CFE, are working on the plan for a nuclear expansion, Fernandez said during a November 8 presentation at Platts Mexican Energy conference in Mexico City. The first two planned units would be built at the Laguna Verde plant in the southern Gulf state of Veracruz, Fernandez said. When the units begin operating, expected by 2024, they will account for more than one-third of Mexico's non-carbon-emitting generating capacity, he said. Fernandez said when environmental costs are included, nuclear is less expensive than combined-cycle natural gas-fired plants that have dominated Mexico's generating capacity in recent years. Unlike the combined-cycle plants, which are built by independent power producers that sell power to CFE under long-term contracts, only the CFE is allowed by law to own and operate nuclear plants. Laguna Verde was built by GENERAL ELECTRIC and has two 682.5-MW units. The second unit was completed in 1995. GE designed a 20% uprate for each unit. Iberdrola and Alstom are implementing the uprate under a $600 million contract. Fernandez said the work is likely to be completed by the end of this year.--Ronald Buchanan, Mexico City Ronald Buchanan

title: Citibank Korea focuses on environmental projects
news: Citibank Korea officials and their families clean the riverside of the Hangang River as part of their monthly Citibank environmental protection campaign in Seoul. (Citibank Korea) Citibank Korea has vowed to take the lead in protecting the natural environment in Seoul as part of its social contribution activities.  The local branch of the U.S.-based bank has carried out multiple environment-related social contribution activities since its establishment. The bank won the Seoul City award for its voluntary work for the environment in 2010. The bank's most recent cooperative pact with Seoul City regarding the environment was signed on May 22. Seoul City, which has likewise been running an environment preservation campaign called "Blooming Seoul," is an active supporter of Citibank's environmental protection campaign. […] Among the oldest environment-related campaigns by Citibank Korea is its decade-old "Protect Seoul Forest Campaign" in Gwangjin District, eastern Seoul, which involves planting trees and fertilizing soil. Besides its back-to-green movement, Citibank Korea has participated in the children's "Hangang River and Nature" program since April. The bank's officials participating in this regular volunteer program have helped city-born children experience nature, such as by feeding silkworms and collecting mulberries. On the global level, Citibank Korea has joined Citigroup's global observation of the annual "Citi Global Community Day" since 2006. The local activities of this global event involve cleaning the environment surrounding the Hangang River and Danghyeon Stream in Nowon District as well as painting frescoes on the walls of isolated areas. […]

title: Rio de Janeiro: Corporate giants pledge to go green; UN's biggest ever global-business event - the Rio+20 forum - sees 1,200 executives make commitments on more ethical, greener ways to work
news: More than 150 commitments to conduct more ethical and greener business will be announced by large corporations at the Rio+20 Corporate Sustainability Forum over the next couple of days. Around 1,200 business executives have joined government and NGO representatives at the three-day conference, which started in Rio on Friday. The Forum, organised by the UN Global Compact, is the biggest event the UN has ever hosted for global business.[…] BANK OF AMERICA has pledged $50bn towards efficient renewable energy and low-carbon economies. The Swiss food and water giant Nestlé, which has faced international criticism and boycotts in past decades for its business in the developing world, now provides clean drinking water and education in Punjab villages; has created farming co-operatives in El Salvador that produce the Fair Trade certified Nescafé; and has helped Brazilian women start a more independent life by packing wagons with consumer goods they can sell.[…]

title: Green energy views 'drowned'
news: Clean energy companies claimed yesterday they were being drowned out by business opponents of the carbon price. Some suggested they needed to do more to make their support heard. Amid concern about a push by the Business Council of Australia to modify or scrap the Renewable Energy Target, multinational GENERAL ELECTRIC and other companies criticised the big business lobby group for not advocating the interests of all Australian business. "There are some businesses that aren't pleased about the carbon price and they have been very effective in having their voice heard [through] big industry associations," GE Ecomagination director for Australia and New Zealand Ben Waters said.  "We are a member of the BCA and we don't agree with their position on the carbon price or the renewable energy target. I sometimes wonder how representative those organisation are . . . they are very susceptible to resistance to any sort of change and that doesn't become a very helpful discussion. "There are always going to be people who are going to resist change and we need both sides to be heard." Greens leader Christine Milne has called for a new organisation for "progressive business" to speak out about climate change and reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. […]

title: Competition for Off-Grid Energy Starts
news: Power Africa, President Obama's initiative to increase access to electricity in sub-Saharan Africa, has launched the second edition of its 'off-grid energy challenge'.  The competition targets off-grid electricity generating companies in six countries across the continent including Kenya. Power Africa seeks to boost access to reliable, affordable, cleaner and more sustainable energy in the region. In the first edition last November, three Kenyan companies - Solar World EA, Afrisol Energy and Mibawa Suppliers - pocketed Sh8.7 million ($100,000) each. Another three firms in Nigeria received similar amounts. The second round of the three-year initiative has been extended to Ethiopia, Ghana, Liberia and Tanzania and is targeting rural and urban populations that are underserved by existing utility companies. Power Africa is supported by three US companies: GENERAL ELECTRIC Africa, US African Development Foundation and US Agency for International Development. "Africans know what works in their communities and this competition encourages these local solutions to power challenges," GE Africa chief executive Jay Ireland said in a statement from Abuja on Thursday. Qualifying companies must submit entries by 6 20.

title: The future of ENERGY
news: The search for the energy source of the future often rests on the presumption of finding the silver bullet or the holy grail, the one breakthrough that will provide abundant, clean energy forever. Truth is, this idea rests in the realm of science fiction, with a big emphasis on  fiction. Change is going to come incrementally, slowly. A decade or two down the line, we'll still be clawing  fossil fuels out of the ground and pumping gas into our cars. That said, each  day a dozen new ideas bubble up - some extreme (drilling 7,000 metres to tap gas reserves), some prosaic (converting cow manure to fuel), still others, outlandish (harnessing the energy of tornadoes!). Consider this a primer on the people, technologies and  ideas - big and small - that are poised to change the way we power the world. […]  Self-sustaining skyscrapers. […]  Extreme Energy.  […]  Solar-powered lights […]  Infrastructure.  Houses that talk to the grid.  GE, Siemens and IBM are just a few of the multinationals working to create a so-called smart grid. It will cut energy consumption and boost the use of renewables, aided by ultrahigh-tech superconducting power lines that carry five times greater loads than copper […]

title: Mid-Atlantic Construction's Best of 008 Awards
news: Despite looming concerns over an uncertain 2009, there remains a lot to celebrate in 2008. The jury for Mid-Atlantic Construction's Best of 2008 awards program had no lack of candidates to choose from when selecting the region's best. In fact, we received the highest number of entries yet in the awards program's history. Our five independent judges carefully narrowed the field to 38 projects in 19 categories, representing the finest examples of design and construction in Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, eastern Pennsylvania and the District of Columbia. Although each winner proved successful in its own right, one project rose above the rest--COMCAST Center in Philadelphia. This 975-ft-tall icon of the Philly skyline symbolizes a new era in design and construction. Not only is it the tallest building in Philadelphia, it was designed as the nation's tallest LEED-certified building and includes innovative post-9-11 structural and security elements.[…]

title: Economic blues leave no room for green; CMO study finds focus on environmentalism waning in tough times
news: The green-marketing movement is taking a hit from the economy. According to a new study by Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, chief marketing officers distracted by the downturn are placing less emphasis on cause-related and environmental issues. In fact, marketing that is ``beneficial for society'' or that minimizes the impact on the environment ranked at the bottom of five priorities listed by respondents for the next 12 months. The shift seemed to reflect changing priorities on the part of their customers. ``If [consumers] can't afford the product, or it's not the quality you want, [they're] not going to be focusing on its environmental friendliness,'' said Christine Moorman, the professor who led the project surveying top marketers at 72 companies culled from both the Fortune 1000 and Forbes' 200 top small firms. […] For example, Wal-Mart Stores, which made sustainability a central feature of its communications strategy in recent years, is talking about it less often lately. An analysis of news stories on LexisNexis shows an average of 73 stories monthly featuring Wal-Mart and ``sustainability'' in the past year but only 37 in the past month. Environmental or sustainability themes had found their way into only 12 Wal-Mart press releases through Sept. 11 of this year (and none since 6), compared with 29 during the same period last year. And when Wal-Mart launched a new campaign targeting opinion leaders around the political conventions last month, the message was about how the company is stimulating the economy by saving people money, with none of the sustainability themes that have been common in such ads in years past. Wal-Mart executives haven't lost all their interest in sustainability, said one supplier rep, ``but I'm not hearing about it nearly as often.'' WPP Group's digital and relationship-marketing shop Bridge Worldwide, Cincinnati, which has made ``marketing with meaning'' its mantra in recent years, isn't seeing clients or prospects back off from marketing that adds value to people's lives just yet. ``But logically, I can see how that would be a gut reaction,'' said Chief Marketing Strategist Bob Gilbreath. ``If you lose your job, you're not volunteering for things. You've got to find a new job.'' […]

title: An Energy Diet for Power-Hungry Household PCs
news: In its drive to go green, the technology industry has so far focused mainly on big targets like corporations and especially computer data centers, the power-hungry computing engine rooms of the Internet economy.   Next come the hundreds of millions of desktop and laptop personal computers in households worldwide.    Microsoft, the nonprofit Climate Savers Computing Initiative and a start-up called Verdiem are combining to put a spotlight on the energy-saving opportunity in PCs, and distributing a free software tool to consumers to help them do it. […]   For more than a decade, the federal Energy Star program has developed voluntary power-management standards for PCs, and suppliers like INTEL and Microsoft have steadily improved the energy efficiency of their chips and software. […]

title: EXXON's climate answer
news: OIL producer EXXON MOBIL Corp said it was new technology, not emissions abatement goals, which held the key to managing global climate change from greenhouse gases. EXXON science strategy manager Brian Flannery yesterday told the World Energy Congress in Sydney renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, were not growing fast enough and were expected to contribute just 1 per cent of global energy supplies by 2020.

title: How Barbie is making business a little better
news: Corporations such as Mattel, Nike and Home Depot are using their clout to improve working conditions around the world The sewing factory in Tepeji del Rio, Mexico, made cute Barbie costumes under a Mattel license, but its workplace allegedly was horrendous. According to a complaint filed last fall with the U.S. Labor Department by a Mexican union, the Rubie's de Mexico factory: employed underage workers, forced employees to work overtime and take pregnancy tests, and subjected workers to chemical smells that caused vomiting and fainting. A Mattel inspection of the plant found violations of Mattel's global-manufacturing codes of conduct. One violation was workers could not choose which union to join, contrary to Mattel's "right to free association" policy, says Mattel and Stephen Coats, head of the U.S./Labor Education in the Americas Project, a labor rights group. […] In earlier decades, businesses viewed such issues -- known as corporate social responsibility, or CSR -- as annoyances. Corporations closed ranks when attacked by labor and human rights activists and environmentalists. Now CSR practices play a key role in business strategy. Companies are closely monitoring their supply chains. They're teaming with activists and government officials to tackle problems. Manufacturers such as GENERAL ELECTRIC and Ford Motor are investing billions of dollars in energy-saving products and plants. "Ten years ago, only a handful of companies looked seriously at this," says Bennett Freeman, a former State Department official who is managing director at the Burson-Marsteller public relations firm. "Now, every major company has to act on the issue. It's a business imperative." […]

title: Vines take the heat
news: Climate change is set to affect our wine industry in ways yet to be defined FROM a fringe issue promoted by tree-huggers to the single most important crisis facing the globe in just a few years, climate change is hot, if you'll pardon the pun. Certainly, it seems that the global wine industry is talking of nothing else. At home, we have just had a vintage that was finished in record time. In many places, harvest had finished by the time pickers were usually just limbering up. […] Makers will not be able to do the ostrich thing. Tesco's, the massive UK supermarket chain is one of Aussie wine's greatest champions but they are bringing in carbon ratings to all their products. The message is clear. If you want to stay on their shelves, it is an initiative that needs heeding. In the USA, Wal-mart will be giving preference to suppliers that aggressively reduce emissions. And so it goes. Elderton and Cullen are two wineries that have achieved carbon neutral status. Every winery in Australia needs to follow their lead.

title: Keppel unit inks $3b gas deal with ExxonMobil
news: KEPPEL Gas has clinched a $3-billion long-term contract to supply natural gas to oil giant ExxonMobil's facilities on Jurong Island.[…] The gas will be used by ExxonMobil to meet its internal fuel requirements. It currently generates all of its electricity through a 150 megawatt power cogeneration unit and the new complex will also include a 220MW cogeneration unit. Cogeneration is the simultaneous production of electricity and steam using natural gas. The process captures waste heat, which otherwise escapes into the atmosphere or is lost in condensing steam back to water, and allows it to be used directly in manufacturing and production facilities. ExxonMobil has said that its cogeneration capacity has the ability to reduce global carbon dioxide emissions by over 10.5 million tonnes annually, the equivalent of taking about two million cars off the road in the United States.[...]

title: Laying waste to yesterday's widgets
news: THE greenies have invaded the computer room. No longer seen as hysterical hippie propaganda, green thinking is becoming increasingly the norm in organisations. Ian Burks, chairman of the Australian Information Industry Association environment special interest group, says its members have shifted their approach to green IT to see the financial benefits."Being green used to be driven by a moral position and now it is driven by a financial one." […] Most global big guns are turning green. Earlier this month, Intel introduced its Climate Savers Smart Computing program to Australia. It was initiated last year in the US by Intel and Google and has support from the likes of Dell, Hewlett-Packard, IBM, Microsoft and Fujitsu. It aims to address the amount of power consumed by PCs and servers. The goal is to achieve a 50% improvement in global computer energy efficiency by 2010. Using less power means fewer carbon dioxide emissions and the program aims to reduce these by 54million tonnes a year by 2010.[…] The Byteback recycling program started by Sustainability Victoria and Hewlett-Packard is run with the Australian Information Industry Association and industry partners including Apple, Canon, Dell, Epson, Fujitsu, Fuji-Xerox, H-P, IBM, Lenovo and Lexmark.[…]

title: Technology to Bring Back Coal Plant to Front Stage
news: By Cho Jin-seo Korea should turn its eyes back to coal mines if it is looking for a next-generation energy source to replace petroleum, the newly appointed chief of GE Energy's Asian division said. With oil and natural gas prices soaring and coal in plentiful supply, the coal-burning power plant will be a reasonable solution until cleaner energies such as wind and solar power become more competitive, according to Choi Chi-hun, vice president of GE Energy. "Nuclear power is the cleanest and the most efficient form of energy. But people feel that building and operating nuclear plants is too dangerous. So, the next best thing is the coal," Choi said, during a meeting with reporters in Seoul on Monday. "When you gasify coal and burn the resulting gas, you can easily remove the hazardous materials from it, such as mercury. We have already developed the gasification technology needed for the power generation. What we need to do is to pull down the cost and find good business partners in Korea, Japan and China." […] Choi, son of a former four-star army general, served as a South Korean air force officer in early '80s after finishing school in the Untied States. With his military experience, he joined GENERAL ELECTRIC's aircraft engine department when the U.S. firm was bidding for Korea's fighter plane program in 1988. The headquarters of GE Energy's Asia-Pacific division will be set up in Tokyo.

title: Joint Venture to Boost Natural Gas Vehicle Use
news: General Motors and Westport Innovations have entered into a research joint-venture with the goal of developing more efficient natural gas-powered engines. In a joint statement, the two companies said their research will be aimed at improving natural gas engine controls and emissions, as well as strategies to take work from the laboratory and put it on US highways and roads. Both companies bring expertise in developing natural gas engine controls, emissions and performance strategies. This technology offers the promises of a cleaner, lower cost fuel and reduced carbon footprint, while advancing the use of domestic energy," said Ian Scott, president of Westport's Light-Duty Division.[...] o Coca-Cola is expanding what is now the largest hybrid delivery fleet in North America. [...]

title: Taking on Big Soap: There's Method in this madness
news: Crystal-Marie Mitchell figures she has been using Tide laundry detergent for almost 27 years, which is to say, since she was born. Next week, though, Ms. Mitchell is preparing to chuck those decades of brand loyalty for a laundry detergent she has never even seen. […] Three years ago, the industry went to a two-times concentration, induced in large part by Wal-Mart's desire to cut down on shipping costs and appear to be more green, but it is loath to increase its concentration because shrinking the bottles, while being more green, could mean giving up valuable and hard-won shelf space.  Rather than play up its concentration, Method is emphasizing what it calls "smart-clean technology," and a plant-based formula. Jaime Hyatt, a 31-year-old mother in Nanaimo, B.C., began using Method products when her son Dylan was born almost two years ago. "A lot of the bathroom cleaners we were using before made me ill - Vim, I couldn't take the smell," she said. "I thought: If it smelled that bad, what was it doing to my insides?" […]

title: Emerald Cities
news: ''Wastewater Treatment Plant'' may not sound like a scenic destination. But some ecologically minded towns have been designing a new breed of wildlife preserve, one that gives recycling a lively twist. Instead of dumping treated water, they return it to nature as the essence of an ecosystem that offers food and habitat to animals. […] A similar panorama greets visitors behind fashionable waste treatment plants around the country. What an admirable trend. Our planet's web of life is so fragile that one can't afford to be a snob about reclaimed land or mind why a business goes green. For instance, pharmaceutical companies -- including giants like MERCK and Bristol-Myers Squibb -- are engaged in high stakes bio-prospecting in some of the world's most endangered rain forests. Working with local shamans, plant collectors, scientists, and others, they examine seeds, nuts, berries and bark for potent medicines in an environmental ''gene rush.'' Mining the wilderness for new formulae, while leaving it intact, they've discovered that a standing forest is more valuable than a leveled one. Another city shade of green comes from derelict railway tracks that have been reimagined as inviting habitats for plants, animals and humans. […]

title: IT leading the green revolution
news: […] Healey said that in data centres, which consume around half of a business' IT-related power needs, and in the office, relatively simple measures could save power and cut waste. HP, one of the world's largest suppliers of INTEL servers, had become expert at virtualisation and so-called high-density computing, where more applications are run on fewer servers using less floor space and power. But its engineers are also getting into the science of thermodynamics to better manage cooling in data centres, which can account for more than 60 per cent of its power costs. For Healey, the key is better educating IT managers on the options for going green both in data centres and in the office, where tightening up workplace policies around printing alone can result in huge power savings.[…]

title: Sustainability now at the fore; Long view
news: Investors are increasingly aware that measuring success in the corporate world is not simply a matter of pure profit and loss or balance sheet analysis. Non-financial considerations are increasingly front of mind. Thus the ease with which a company manoeuvres through the potential minefield that is "corporate sustainability" is increasingly providing a key pointer to share price performance. "Corporate sustainability" reporting and analysis aims to capture the manner with which a company handles a range of environmental, social and governance (ESG) issues. [...] In the past few days, there have been two timely inputs into the corporate sustainability debate - investment bank CITIGROUP's Australian Sustainability and Environmental Opportunities conference and the Group of 100/KPMG publication, Sustainability Reporting - a Guide. The CITIGROUP conference was the latest example of the bank's "value add" in the sustainability area. Senior analyst Elaine Prior and her colleagues in the United Kingdom have proved leaders in the field of aligning sustainability with investor return expectations. This is not to take anything away from other investment banking contributors in the field, such as Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank and ABN Amro. It's simply a recognition that CITIGROUP's commitment to a dedicated sustainability and emissions trading research team has led it to emerge as the dominant player. The conference included presentations from fund managers, companies, government officials and lawyers, covering a range of topics including emerging energy trends and "profitable sustainability".[...]

title: Going green will help save money
news: Companies are using green IT strategies to reduce energy use and cut carbon emissions, according to new research from Deloitte.  The survey showed that 67 per cent of companies questioned had an IT programme in place to monitor environmental performance. […]  Some innovative examples of green IT strategies include INTEL taking the heat its servers produce and redirecting it to warm the cafeteria water supply, and HSBC incorporating environmental standards into procurement criteria to ensure the equipment is energy efficient..

title: TXU's new managers face daunting task: build revenue flows to service big debt
news: On October 11, private equity firms began operating the US' tenth largest integrated utility. The day before, six banks fronted Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, TPG Capital and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners enough money to buy up all of TXU Corp.'s 461 million shares of stock, thus taking the 90-year-old Dallas-based power company private. [...] The three private equity firms, plus investment banks Lehman Brothers, CITIGROUP and Morgan Stanley, now have controlling stakes in Energy Future Holdings Corp., the new name for what was TXU Corp. [...] Also last week, the new owners recalled that, to "earn" the endorsement of the deal from the environmental groups the Natural Resources Defense Council and Environmental Defense, it had made a range of commitments to strengthen environmental policies, make investments in alternative energy and institute corporate policies tied to "climate stewardship." [...] It said, also, that EFH will create a sustainable energy advisory board comprised of individuals who represent the environment, customers, Texas economic development, and the Electricity Reliability Council of Texas, or ERCOT. The new owners said Reilly would lead this board. [...] The six banks ? CITIGROUP, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and Lehman Brothers ? lent the private equity groups a large portion of the $33 billion they needed last Wednesday to pay shareholders for their stock. Those underwriters, however, have not gone to the capital markets to sell debt instruments to other investors that will allow them to transfer the risk and recover the money they have lent. [...] The market was told in an October 5 form 8-K filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission to expect CITIGROUP to lead the effort in securing a $16.45 billion term loan, a $4.1 delayed-draw term loan, a $1.25 billion letter-of-credit facility and a $2.7 billion revolving credit, for EFH. The senior secured cash collateral posting facility will be capped by the mark-to-market exposure of EFH, the filing said. [...]

title: GE to order 'thousands' of electric vehicles; 'A huge step up'
news: GENERAL ELECTRIC Co. may jump-start the electric-vehicle industry with an order that chief executive Jeffrey Immelt said will be the largest in history. GE, whose power-generation equipment provides a third of the world's electricity, will order "tens of thousands" of the vehicles in about a week, Mr. Immelt said yesterday in a speech in London, without giving a total or identifying a manufacturer.  "This is a huge step up," said Brett Smith, a vehicle technology analyst at the Center for Automotive Research in Ann Arbor, Mich. "It's the biggest order to date I'm aware of, by a lot." Expanding the world's fleet of electric vehicles would bolster GE as it expands so-called clean-energy technology such as car chargers, solar panels and wind turbines. For every dollar of electric-vehicle sales, GE estimates it may get 10¢ in revenue, said Gary Sheffer, a spokesman. Mr. Immelt said half of GE's sales force of about 45,000 will drive electric vehicles. The Fairfield, Conn.-based company also has a vehicle-leasing division through its GE Capital finance unit. Financial terms and other details about the order aren't yet being disclosed, GE said. GE is investing US$10-billion over the next five years in clean energy across its business lines, including power-transmission software and so-called smart-grid technologies. Its products include lithium-ion batteries for cars and trucks via a venture with A123 Systems Inc. and sodium-based batteries for use in large vehicles such as locomotives. That spending creates jobs, Mr. Immelt told executives at an event sponsored by the University of Cambridge's Programme for Sustainability Leadership. "GE has been one of the biggest players in this game and certainly has a lot to gain from the electric vehicle," Mr. Smith said. "They've really truly tried to push this hard to get things going, and it seems to be a core corporate value." An order the size of GE's probably would come from several vehicle makers, Mr. Smith said.

title: INSIDE INFORMATION; Your guide to today's Globe
news: Wal-Mart makes environmental vow If companies want Wal-Mart Canada to sell their stuff, they'd better start cutting back on packaging. The giant retailer says it will soon decide what products to sell based partly on a "scorecard" that will assess how each product is packaged, measuring the energy required to produce the packaging, its size, and its ability to be recycled.  […] Think you can spot the next Sidney Crosby? The people who do will be in Columbus, Ohio, for the National Hockey League draft this weekend. Globe hockey writers are also there and will be adding all the rumours and chatter to the Globe on Hockey blog today.

title: Citi Bank to Source U.S.$2.5 Billion for 'Power Africa'
news: Citi has pledged to source $2.5 billion in incremental capital to improve access to electricity for millions of people across Africa as part of the 'Power Africa' initiative. […] Citi, a global bank, in a statement yesterday said it would also leverage its financing expertise in renewable energy to encourage the adoption and implementation of the appropriate technologies for specific markets. The financial institution also pledged to work with key stakeholders in local capital markets to introduce innovative debt securities and to enhance financial infrastructure. […] The Chief Executive Officer of Citi for the Europe, the Middle East and Africa region, Jim Cowles was quoted to have said: "We are proud to be a partner in this phenomenal project, an initiative to double the number of people who have access to electricity across Africa. "Citi has a unique footprint in Africa and a commitment to enabling progress on the Continent through our technical expertise, financing and risk mitigation tools." Citi operates in over 40 countries in Africa with offices in 16 countries, including key markets such as, Nigeria, Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania and South Africa. Over the past two years, Citi has enabled over $1.5 billion in funding for the power sector in Africa.

title: Sustainability - Coca-Cola sets the standard
news: Tom Hall talks to Olivia Knight-Adams, Coca-Cola sustainable Games project co-ordinator. Despite a background including a stint as a marine biologist, Olivia Knight-Adams' Olympics work began when she was a sustainability advisor at the Olympic delivery Authority (ODA) in 2008. Back then, the Olympic Park was a wasteland and the ISO 20121 sustainability guidelines were still in development. Four years on, she joined Coca-Cola to work on their sustainability team, focusing on the 2012 Games. Championing the ISO 20121 sustainability standard at the drinks giant's Games-time events has been a passion for the applied science graduate ever since, and the company was among a select group of pioneers that now sing the praises of the accreditation. [...]

title: Africa; USAID Supports Launch of New Forest Watch Tool
news: Dr. Raj Shah voices USAID's support for innovative new technology working to dramatically reduce tropical deforestation How is the latest U.S. satellite and mobile technology helping 350 million of the world's poorest people - including 60 million indigenous people - safeguard their homes and livelihoods?  More than 300 development experts heard the answer at today's launch of the new high-tech Global Forest Watch tropical forest monitoring tool, developed by World Resources Institute with support from USAID, Google, Norway and other partners. "Global Forest Watch is democratizing information," USAID Administrator Dr. Rajiv Shah told a full house at the Newseum's Knight Conference Center in Washington DC. Juan Carlos Jintiach, a leader of Ecuador's Shuar Nation of peoples, agreed. "Global Forest Watch is a way to share our voices and histories," he told the crowd. […]

title: 'Wet steam' recycling is hot property
news: A SCOTTISH company is attempting to corner a new £2billion ((EURO)2.5 billion) market for turning waste heat into electricity. Heliex Power, based in East Kilbride, near Glasgow, has developed a way of capturing low-temperature steam that is usually discharged by factories and turning it into power. The potential for Heliex's technology has attracted interest from investors including BP's Ventures arm, which backs clean technology innovations. The oil giant first invested in Heliex in December 2010 and stumped up more cash in the firm's latest £5m fundraising.  […] The company plans to either float or sell the business within five years. When the time comes, Wright thinks there will be no shortage of offers. The waste heat recovery market has attracted some big guns of the industry in recent years. GENERAL ELECTRIC, the American industrial conglomerate, snapped up the waste heat power generation business of Florida-based Calnetix in October 2010. For now, the fresh injection of cash will enable Heliex to buy a factory and to start manufacturing. It expects to start shipping generators to customers by the end of the year. These devices will be capable of producing 100 to 150 kilowatts of power, and Heliex has plans to scale up the generators to 1 megawatt for larger industrial sites.

title: Top 10 Trends of 2007
news: NEW YORK. It's a small world after all. Private and public lives are merging on the Internet, corporate giants are embracing environmental initiatives, industry competitors are collaborating, and the transfer of wealth from the developed world to emerging economies is picking up speed at a mind-boggling pace. […] GREEN CAPITALISM. Call it corporate social responsibility or cold, hard capitalism, but marketing a brand or corporation around the environment stepped out of the fringes and squarely into the mainstream, seven years after British Petroleum repositioned itself as "beyond petroleum." Yes, scoring points with environmentalists is important to retailers like Wal-Mart and oil companies like CHEVRON, but the bottom line is there's money to be made in less bulky packaging and renewable energy exploration.
