Citi is also committed to buying 50% of its total energy needs from "green energy" such as those generated by solar or wind-powered operations, even though it costs more than regular energy.  [...]

title: Sales set to bloom as firms turn green - POWER AND COOLING - SPECIAL REPORT
news: They are discovering that marketing their products as environmentally-friendly can boost product sales TECHNOLOGY giants are splashing their sales spiels with green and charging into alliances that promote power reduction technology for data centres and computer equipment. Vendors see green marketing as a way of speeding up their customers' technology refresh plans and ramping sales. All in a good cause, of course.  Many of the industry's biggest names have joined both the Green Grid Consortium and the Climate Savers Computing Initiative. Intel spokesman Bill Calder says Green Grid is focused on increasing energy efficiency in data centres, everything from servers to the data centre itself, design and racks, 'Climate Savers is focused primarily on PC's and also servers,'' he says. Intel has a seat on the boards at both consortiums and, according to Calder, the company outlined the ''original goals, targets, and objectives with Google''. That effort grew out of discussions between Intel and Google, and was expanded to include many other companies and the World Wildlife Fund. ''Essentially, the two efforts are complimentary,'' Calder says. Green Grid is backed by more than 80 IT companies including AMD, Hewlett-Packard, Intel, Microsoft and VMware. […]

title: Bank cited for addressing climate change
news: Citi was chosen by The Banker as the Most Innovative in Climate Change and Sustainability in the recently held Investment Banking Awards 2009. It was the first time for Citi to submit an entry for this category, and Pam Flaherty, president and CEO of the Citi Foundation and director of Corporate Citizenship, credits their win to a host of factors.  "We won for two reasons. First, we've been working on environmental sustainability for eight years and have built a very substantial track record. Citi was the only financial company in the original group that crafted the Equator Principles in 2003." The second reason is innovation, she stated. Ms. Flaherty cited the Noble Environmental Power project, Citi Community Capital's Green Energy Community Investment Fund, Citi's "Project Green" e-statement initiative in consumer and cash management businesses in 28 countries, and Citi's Environmental Products business as reasons the independent judging panel of the Innovation in Banking Technology Awards honored Citi. [...] Sandip Sen, global head of Citi's Alternative Energy business; and Rodney Malcolm of Citi Commodities accepted the award on behalf of Citi. "I had the privilege of accepting this award that Citi has received due to the efforts of many, many individuals around the world - across businesses and across geographies," said Mr. Sen. "We should all be proud and celebrate, but more importantly, we must stay focused and build upon our success by continuing to develop strategies and approaches to address what is, arguably, the single biggest issue facing the world - the issue of climate change." The annual awards program focuses on innovation in products, structures or strategies. In its announcement, The Banker said: "In spite of a governance crisis, awful markets and global recessions, a lot of good business has been done." Citi was cited for its commitment to address global climate change. In May 2007, Citi announced it would direct $50 billion over 10 years through investments, financing and related activities to support the commercialization and growth of alternative energy and clean technology.

title: GE makes green commitment with major capital investment; Aims to achieve $20-billion in sales of environmentally cleaner products by 2010
news: Seeking to make money on the global push toward tougher environmental regulation, GENERAL ELECTRIC Co. plans to roll out today a comprehensive investment, marketing and policy initiative that addresses environmental issues such as global warming and water shortages. The Fairfield, Conn.-based conglomerate plans to more than double its investment, to $1.5-billion (U.S.) by 2010, in technologies that include cleaner coal-fired power plants, a diesel-and-electric hybrid locomotive and agricultural silicon that cuts the amount of water and pesticide used in spraying fields.  GE aims to achieve $20-billion in sales of environmentally cleaner products by 2010, or double the amount it currently has - a target that would comprise as much as 20 per cent of the company's estimated industrial sales. Already, GE, the biggest publicly traded company in the United States, sees a business case for its strategy as utilities such as Cinergy Corp. and American Electric Power Co. line up to build plants using cleaner coal-burning technology.  GE chairman and chief executive officer Jeffrey Immelt plans to urge the U.S. energy industry to take the lead in dealing with carbon-dioxide emissions in a "carbon-constrained world." Carbon dioxide is produced when fossil fuels are burned and is widely believed to be the main global warming gas. GE says it will reduce its global warming emissions by 1 per cent over the next seven years. GE also says it will increase its energy efficiency by 30 per cent by 2012. […] Environmental activists called GE's move significant. "GE is a potent symbol and sends a powerful message to the private sector and the public-policy sector," said Jonathan Lash, president of World Resources Institute, an organization in Washington that works with companies to try to convince them that investing in environmentally friendly technologies can be good for their bottom lines. […]

title: NEA, IBM develop predictive models; Analysis of real-time data will let agency make quick findings
news: THE National Environment Agency (NEA) and IBM are teaming up as part of a three-year research collaboration to develop advanced modelling and predictive capabilities that will tackle major environmental concerns in Singapore.  NEA and IBM will co-develop four sets of predictive models in areas involving the environment or public health risks - such as air quality, weather forecast, dengue prediction and food poisoning.  Real-time data will be analysed and turned into intelligence or predictive insights to enable the NEA or even other public agencies to react quicker and make smarter decisions based on the information available from the models.  One way that the partnership will benefit the public, for instance, is that the forecasting capability will help NEA to better inform the public in advance with regards to changes in air quality.  Social media analytics and public feedback from popular social media platforms such as Twitter could also be used in the creation of models to detect food poisoning incidents at food and beverage outlets early on, enabling the NEA to make more focused and timely inspections.[…]  "We have set out to harness the tremendous capabilities of advanced analytics and develop capabilities that will allow IBM researchers to test solutions in real-world settings and truly leverage Singapore as a living lab," said Janet Ang, managing director for IBM Singapore. The three-year collaboration will cost about $30 million, with $7 million coming from the NEA, some $1.5 million from the Economic Development Board and the remaining funds from IBM.

title: Packaging pros rate Wal-Mart's scorecard
news: Love it or hate it, Wal-Mart's sustainable packaging scorecard is changing the industry, as suppliers scramble to please the retail giant's buyers. Two points of view about the scorecard measure were presented at the Packaging Strategies Summit Meeting 2008, held March 12-14 in Fort Lauderdale. Charles Fishman, author of the 2006 bestseller The Wal-Mart Effect, about the impact of the company's practices on its suppliers, and Julian Carroll, managing director of the European Organization for Packaging and the Environment (Europen), gave starkly different opinions on the scorecard Wal-Mart Stores Inc. implemented in February.  Fishman, editor-at-large of Fast Company magazine, said after his book on the Bentonville, Ark., discount-store chain's global footprint was published, Wal-Mart officials invited him to spend a day at corporate headquarters. One of the topics covered that day was Wal-Mart's commitment to sustainability. Fishman said he came away convinced that the firm's sustainability practices are a stew of more or less equal parts public relations spin, genuine commitment to protecting the global environment and bottom-line Business 101. ``They will change the economy and the ecosystem as much in terms of sustainability as they did in pricing,'' he said. title: Google aims to reform energy grid; Firm hopes to wean U.S. off use of coal and oil for power
news: Google hopes to do for the power grid what it did for the Web. Having conquered the market for Web search by first simplifying how it is done and then making sales of related advertising more efficient, Google is now funding green technology and using its brand power to lobby for policy change. Google introduced a plan Wednesday to wean the United States off the burning of coal and oil for power by 2030 and to cut oil use for cars by 40 percent. Such initiatives could cost trillions of dollars, but Google believes they should ultimately save money. […] Calls for energy efficiency and the development of alternative sources of fuel, once heard chiefly from environmentalists, are now more mainstream after oil reached record levels well above $100 a barrel. Google itself is making improvements on its servers and at its buildings, identifying $5 million in building-efficiency investments that will pay for themselves in two and a half years. New efficiency standards for computers could cut power consumption by the equivalent of 10 to 20 coal-fired plants by 2010, Google said. Google's energy plan calls for stricter building codes, a commitment to wind and solar tax credits that have lapsed and a price to be placed on carbon emissions through a cap-and-trade plan or a tax. Google recently joined with GENERAL ELECTRIC to speed up development of new power grid technology. Echoing calls from the presidential candidates of both major U.S. political parties, Google wants to see more smart meters and real-time pricing to let people see how much energy they use and what it costs. Schmidt, a business adviser to Barack Obama's campaign, was discouraged by talk of ''clean coal'' among Republicans, but he added that he expected changes on energy policy no matter who won the election in November. At the time of Google's initial public offering in 2004, the founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin pledged employee time and about 1 percent of Google's equity - three million shares - plus 1 percent of profits to philanthropy. In 2006, Google converted 300,000 shares into about $90 million to set up Google.org. Schmidt said there was a branding benefit from the effort, but it was ultimately driven by what the two founders wanted, and he doubted investors worried too much about the cost.

title: Exxon gives millions to climate project
news: Long the oil industry's chief global warming naysayer, the Irving, Tex., company yesterday said it is contributing $100-million (U.S.) to a 10-year global energy and climate research project at Stanford University. The money, part of a $225-million contribution from companies including General Electric Co., E.On AG and SchlumbergerLtd., will allow Stanford scientists to investigate everything from hydrogen power to technologies aimed at reducing carbon-dioxide emissions. Exxon Mobil's move is the latest in a string of environmentally friendly gestures that contrast sharply with its position in years past, when it suggested natural climate change, rather than human activity, was causing the Earth to warm. It also comes as the petroleum giant, the world's largest publicly held oil concern, is coming under fire from shareholders on its global warming position and is the subject of a boycott in parts of Europe over the same issue.  Yet despite the tenor of Exxon Mobil's campaign, the company still stops short of saying that the combustion of fossil fuels is responsible for global warming. […]

title: Trading honesty for 'social responsibility'
news: Last September, when the extent of the financial crisis was becoming horribly apparent, Ban Ki-moon, Secretary General of the United Nations, declared "We need a new understanding on business ethics and governance, with more compassion and less uncritical faith in the 'magic' of markets."[…] Nothing better symbolized the murky global business environment than the final communique of the London G20 meeting two weeks ago. It called for "an open world economy based on market principles," even as it projected massive new regulation and declared support for an "inclusive, green and sustainable recovery" and "the corporate social responsibility of all firms." Who knows what that all means.[…] Early last year, the environmental busybody group CERES handed out bouquets to Citigroup, BANK OF AMERICA, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs for being in favour of emissions trading, as if that stance was based on virtue rather than merely the desire to earn profits from any dubious activity sanctioned by the government. title: PEPSI unveils new eco-friendly bottle
news: PEPSI has revealed their latest weapon-the world's first bottle made entirely of plant material. The company succeeded in making a bottle that is made from switch grass, pine bark, cornhusks and other materials in order to reduce the amount of carbon footprint- the 'total amount of greenhouse gas emissions caused by an organization, event, act, or person,' reported the British Daily Mail on Tuesday. The new bottle looks, feels and protects the drink inside exactly the same as its current bottles, said a company spokesman. This discovery potentially changes the industry standard for plastic packaging. Traditional PET plastic is widely used because it is lightweight and shatter-resistant, its safety is well researched and it does not affect flavors. However, it is not biodegradable. Rather it is fully recyclable, a characteristic that will be maintained in the new creation. In addition, PET plastic is made using fossil fuels, like petroleum, a limited resource rising in price. As a result, by using plant material instead, companies reduce their environmental impact. Ultimately, PEPSI plans to also use orange peel, oat husks, potato scraps, and other leftovers from its food business. After the initial testing stage in 2012 with a few hundred thousand bottles and once it are sure it can successfully produce the bottle at that scale, the company will begin converting all its products. Coca-Cola currently produces a bottle using 30 per cent plant-based materials and recently estimated it would be several years before it has a 100 per cent plant bottle.

title: Solar Trend Catches Fire
news: According to Rob Threlkeld, supply contracts and green initiatives manager with General Motors Corp., the Detroit automaker is looking to reduce the financial impact of peak utility rates and energy instability while simultaneously increasing the overall productivity of its global facilities--including millions of square feet of roof space--by installing thin-film solar panels on its plant roofs. "The solar suppliers are interested in selling more of their product, we're obviously interested in installing more and we've got financiers who want to make a stable cash flow off of it," he says, "so between the three of us, we're running models to find out where it makes the most sense." GM's Fontana, Calif., warehouse solar installation, completed through a partnership with Constellation Energy, is just one example of a hot trend that features manufacturers partnering with a growing number of companies that provide turnkey solar installations and power purchase agreements (PPAs).This trend features high-profile manufacturers from PEPSICO Inc. to Estee Lauder Companies to Hewlett-Packard Co., which recently installed a large-scale solar power installation through a PPA with SunPower Corp., that features 5,000 solar panels atop its R&D manufacturing site in San Diego, Calif. "Regardless of what they may believe about global warming, CEOs want to be green because their supply chain and customers want them to, but they don't want to waste money," says Tom Hunton, president of American Capital Energy. "With solar, not only can they be green, but they can have solid ROI, with an average three- to five-year payback on many projects."[…]

title: Green bonds - Banks get climate smart
news: […] Green bond bubbles? Citi, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America Merrill Lynch were planning to roll out their own Green Bond Principles on 1 1, say Citi officials. According to a draft published by EuroWeek, the principles provide issuers of green bonds with disclosure and transparency guidelines. However, the principles leave it up to each issuer, whether a corporate, bank or municipality, to decide which criteria to employ to define the green use of the bonds. (Several climate-friendly and environmental definitions that have already been used in the market by the World Bank, the International Finance Corporation, the European Investment Bank, the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development, and others are listed in an appendix that green bond issuers may refer to if they want). Meanwhile, Christopher Flensborg, head of sustainable products and product development at SEB, says another framework designed for a global green bond market and including input from banks in the US, European and Asia will be ready in "six to nine months". It will be different in other important respects from the Citi, JPMorgan and BANK OF AMERICA endeavour, which, Mr Flensborg says was "too rushed". The Citi officials' response is: "The market is not waiting. For example, Citi already has two mandates to lead manage green bond issues [in 2014]." To avoid the confusion of different definitions of green, it is important to establish a single set of definitions, says Mr Flensborg. Some bankers also think scientists who have knowledge of climate change, but no economic interest in the development of the green bond market, should be involved in the definition and verification of a bond's green use.[…]

title: The weather exploiters
news: Tim Flannery, the radical Australian environmentalist, quoted Adam Smith this week during a CBC Radio interview, thus surely sending the great economist spinning once more in his Edinburgh grave. Promoting his latest book, Now or Never, on The Current, Mr. Flannery cited the Sage of Kirkcaldy's warning against attempts by businessmen to influence policy: "The proposal of any new law or regulation of commerce which comes from this order [merchants or manufacturers], ought always to be listened to with great precaution, and ought never to be adopted till after having been long and carefully examined, not only with the most scrupulous, but with the most suspicious attention." True indeed, which makes it intriguing that Mr. Flannery should regard Al Gore, who has made, and stands to make, hundreds of millions of dollars from promoting government subsidy and regulation, as one of his heroes.  Even more strange, or perhaps just spectacularly hypocritical, that Mr. Flannery-- whose previous book, The Weather Makers, was a bestseller -- should head something called the Copenhagen Climate Council, which is a morass of the kind of corporatist influence against which Adam Smith was warning. The council's members include Combat Climate Change, which represents -among others --GE, Unilever, Citigroup, BP and Siemens. Then there is The Climate Group, whose corporate members include Bloomberg, Coca Cola, Dell, Google and IBM. Another member is the World Business Council on Sustainable Development, which was set up by the UN's former chief Global Salvationist, Maurice Strong, to push the crypto-socialist blueprint hatched by the Brundtland Commission. Then we have the World Economic Forum, yet another mercantilist organization of the self-appointed Great and Good, where Mr. Strong again had enormous influence until he was inconveniently implicated in the UN oil-for-food corruption scandal. The Copenhagen Climate Council's "sponsors" meanwhile consist of a group of mainly Danish corporations who make no secret of their desire to influence policy. "Bioinnovation" company Novozymes declares "[W]e aim at influencing opinion-leaders and... decisions-makers towards an ambitious protocol. The [Copenhagen] conference constitutes a unique opportunity to position sustainable technologies, and an opportunity for Novozymes to brand our bio-technologies, our products, our company and our overall sustainability business model." […]

title: Energy will be a tougher nut for Bill Gates to crack
news: Bill Gates became one of the world's richest men as a business-savvy software guru, but these days the multi-billionaire co-founder of Microsoft Corp. has become more of an energy guru. He's invested in a number of clean energy ventures, including algae fuel developer Sapphire Energy and a nuclear start-up called TerraPower that is trying to develop a reactor that never needs refuelling and uses primarily waste uranium as its fuel. Gates says he has investments in several advanced battery start-ups as well.In 6, he joined voices with a group calling itself the American Energy Innovation Council, which includes GENERAL ELECTRIC boss Jeffrey Immelt, venture capitalist John Doerr and Ursula Burns, the chief executive of Xerox.  The group took issue with the lack of government spending on energy research and development, pointing out that in the United States such annual spending has dropped by nearly one-third since the 1970s. That won't cut it, they argued, if energy security and dramatic greenhouse-gas reductions are serious long-term goals. So Gates and friends publicly urged the government to triple its spending on clean energy R&D to $16 billion (U.S.) a year. […]

title: Environmental group opens shop by Wal-Mart

The move is part of the group's effort to ramp up its cooperation with the mega-retailer and advise it regarding environmental initiatives. ``With 175 million customers a week and a global supply chain of over 60,000, Wal-Mart has unique potential for change,'' said Gwen Ruta, director of global partnerships for Environmental Defense. ``Given this market reach, the ability to achieve powerful environmental progress may be as great in the halls of the Wal-Mart home office in Bentonville as it is in the halls of Congress.'' Andrew Hutson and Michelle Mauthe Harvey will co-lead the Bentonville location. They are advising Wal-Mart on a variety of environmental issues, including climate change, truck fleet fuel efficiency and alternative fuels. […]

title: When the car can drive itself, whose name goes on the traffic ticket?
news: Even as Google tests its small fleet of self-driving vehicles on California highways, legal scholars and U.S. government officials warn that society has only begun wrestling with the changes that would be required in a system created a century ago to meet the challenge of horseless carriages. What happens if a police officer wants to pull one of these vehicles over? When it stops at a four-way intersection, would it be too polite to take its turn ahead of aggressive human drivers (or equally polite robots)? What sort of insurance would it need?  These and other implications of what Google calls autonomous vehicles were debated by Silicon Valley technologists, legal scholars and regulators last week at a daylong symposium sponsored by the Law Review and High Tech Law Institute at Santa Clara University. As Google has demonstrated, computerized systems that replace human drivers are now largely workable and could greatly limit human error, which causes most of the 33,000 deaths and 1.2 million injuries that occur each year on U.S. roads. Such vehicles also hold the potential for greater fuel efficiency and lower emissions - and, more broadly, for restoring the United States' primacy in the global automobile industry. […]

title: Designing Light And Air; How the new BANK OF AMERICA building will save energy and let its occupants breathe easy.
news: When the BANK OF AMERICA Tower opens in midtown Manhattan later this year, it will be a beacon of green. Its design is likely to earn the highest LEED rating--platinum--from the U.S. Green Building Council, making it the most sustainable skyscraper in the country. The building's developer, the Durst Organization and BANK OF AMERICA, favored green principles in the design. Architect Rick Cook, of Cook+Fox, talked to NEWSWEEK about the innovative features of the 55-story glass-and-steel office tower--and about why concern about the environment is central to his practice. NEWSWEEK: What got you so involved in green design? Cook: It was actually our twin 6-year-old boys who were the conversion experience. […] What makes the BANK OF AMERICA Tower sustainable? It will save about half the energy that most buildings its size would use. But the real story is in terms of health, productivity and light--what we like to call "biophilia," a term coined by E. O. Wilson. People feel better when they feel connected to nature. So we've created naturally lit environments, and fresh air of as high a quality as possible, with underfloor air-delivery systems so people can control the air at their workstations.[…] Aren't some other countries much more conscious of green building than the United States? Yes. For example, green roofs are fairly novel here--our office in New York has one of the few. But in Frankfurt, Germany, there are green roofs everywhere. […]

title: FP summary

title: Climate group to unveil firms' emission scores
news: This just in from Climate Counts, the nonprofit group that scores consumer products companies on their green track records: consumer companies are getting greener, but they are still a pretty carbon-intensive lot. On Wednesday, the group will release its second annual ranking of 56 consumer companies on how they measure greenhouse gas emissions, their plans to reduce them and how fully they disclose those activities. Its intention is to persuade consumers to use the scores in deciding which brands to buy.   ''We aren't measuring emissions,'' said Gary Hirshberg, chief executive of Stonyfield Farms and the chairman of Climate Counts. ''We are measuring commitment.''   The average score was 40 out of a possible 100, but most companies scored higher than they did in 2007. Nine had no change. Kraft Foods and Canon dropped slightly, but Wood Turner, Climate Counts's  project director, said that was because their disclosures were less detailed. title: Green is the color of growth
news: TIMES BUSINESS EDITOR UFashion designers are hyping corals, yellows and purples as the "new" colors of 2007. But one color's trumping all. Green. As in business and government suddenly going ga-ga over green buildings, green technology and green sustainability. The green movement in business for years has run on the fringes as little more than a low-grade fever to mainstream corporate America. Now - BadaBoom! - players from top global corporations to Tampa Bay area influentials are aligning with the green theme. Whether it's a fad or an enduring shift in the business force remains to be seen. What is clear is the rapid rise of green issues in business big and small. Consider the range and momentum: - Wal-Mart CEO Lee Scott last week called on the retail giant's suppliers and employees to aid its green campaign. Suppliers eventually must eliminate nonrenewable energy from their processes and products. Wal-Mart will track their progress.

title: Bush's simple pollution solution
news: It worked brilliantly for his father, so why doesn't today's US President adopt emissions trading? A dozen years ago, when I first lived in the US, the great environmental terror was not global warming, but acid rain. Sulphur dioxide pollution from industrial smokestacks and nitrogen oxide, mainly from vehicle exhaust, was combining with moisture in the atmosphere to form acids that killed lakes and forests and threatened human health. I read so many warnings about acid rain that I took to wearing a hat in inclement weather, convinced that my hair was falling out due to gradual chemical erosion.   But then, almost overnight, those looming clouds of acid rain cleared. The tales of acidulous devastation stopped. I gave up wearing my hat. […] By far the largest polluter, of course, is the US, and without American participation the prospect of a genuinely global, properly regulated carbon-trading market seems distant. President Bush remains adamantly opposed to capping emissions, arguing that this would impede the US economy. Ironically, US corporations believe that they could make big money in a global carbon-trading system, but until the US regulates emissions and issues pollution permits, they have nothing to buy or sell. Mr Bush should embrace global curbs on emissions now, because if these do not come during his presidency, they will most assuredly come after it. Already there are signs of a change of mood in the US, in both political and corporate circles. This year more than 150 American cities have signed agreements to meet emission cutting targets, and a growing number of corporate chiefs, most recently Jeffrey Immelt, CEO of GENERAL ELECTRIC, have called for domestic control of CO2 emissions. Last week the US Senate considered two different bills containing proposals, supported by several prominent Republicans, for a US carbon-trading scheme. Would this be as prohibitively expensive and economically damaging to cut emissions as the White House claims? The Economist estimates that copying the system of controls already in place in Canada would cost 0.5 per cent of US GDP by 2025, which seems a mighty small price for a planet. […]

title: IN FOCUS: Green spotlight shines on noise and air qualityKeeping the noise down; Attention may be focused on carbon emissions but the problem of air and sound pollution will not go away
news: "Ecomagination" underpins new GE designs Opponents to a third runway at London's Heathrow airport believe air-quality concerns could help them defeat expansion plans When aviation hits the headlines over its impact on the environment, the focus is usually on climate change and greenhouse gas emissions - noise and air quality are generally overlooked. "When you look at how airlines communicate on their sustainability performance, it looks like we are heading towards a single-issue discussion," says Jeroen Kruijd, an airline sustainability expert at PwC. "We should be careful not to focus only on climate change." PwC report Building Trust In The Air reveals that while 70% of airlines report on their carbon emissions, only 40% report on NOX (nitrogen oxide) emissions and just 33% publish data on noise. However, these issues, the focus of environmental concern for decades before climate change reared its head, have refused to go away. In fact they are often of more concern to airlines and airports, and dealing with them is crucial to the future health of the sector.  "These are areas where we have a bit of a black eye and need to continue to work hard," says Steve Csonka, head of "ecomagination" at GE Aviation. "Noise and local air quality have more impact on the debate in terms of stopping runway development and preventing operation at certain times of the day." Indeed, opponents of a third runway at London's Heathrow airport believe air-quality concerns could help them defeat plans to expand the airport. One of the main air pollutants caused by aviation is nitrogen dioxide (NO2). EU rules based on World Health Organisation guidelines limit the amount of NO2 that can be present in the environment. This limit is consistently broken in London, which has one of the highest NO2 levels of any EU city. Important drivers Environmental group ClientEarth believes any plans for a third runway could be legally challenged because planning permission must be refused if a development is likely to breach air quality limits or worsen air quality where pollution already exceeds the limits. Meanwhile, noise levels are one of the most important drivers of local opposition to airport expansions. The International Civil Aviation Organisation says that by 2020, the number of people affected by "annoying levels of aircraft noise" in Europe will be 40% higher than in 2001. ICAO catalogues the pollutants associated with aviation operations: NOX can cause lung irritation and lower resistance to respiratory infections, and has been linked to acid rain, visibility degradation, particle formation, and ozone formation. Carbon monoxide can cause cardiovascular effects, especially in those with heart conditions. Volatile organic compounds - such as benzene and acrolein - can cause eye and respiratory irritation, headaches, dizziness, visual disorders and memory impairment, and can contribute to ozone formation. Ozone can impair lung function and increase susceptibility to respiratory infection. Lower emissions Innovations in engine technology such as GE Aviation's lean-burn technology help alleviate air quality issues. "We're getting about 50% lower NOX emissions than the latest standards," Csonka says. Fuel efficiency improvements also help - less fuel burnt means fewer emissions. However, Csonka warns that while the emphasis has been on NOX, focus will turn to particulates, where evidence is emerging of serious health effects such as premature mortality and aggravation of respiratory and cardiovascular disease. […]

title: PFIZER greens chemistry INTRODUCTION: The pharmaceutical giant has been developing green solutions for over a decade
news: SOUND STEWARDSHIP of the environment does more than please PFIZER employees and protect the company's brand, it also saves the drug giant tens of millions of dollars every year, and even hundreds of millions of dollars over the lifetime of particularly high-volume products.In other words, green chemistry is not just a moral issue it's also a value proposition. PFIZER began its green chemistry initiative (GCI) in 2001, encouraged by improvements made in the manufacture of sertraline (Zoloft) and sildenafil (Viagra), says Peter Dunn, global green chemistry leader.[…] In the late 1990s, PFIZER chemists developed a more efficient approach that condensed three steps to one, dramatically reducing the consumption of three raw materials and completely eliminating titanium tetrachloride. For every [short] ton of sertraline produced, the new process also saved 60,000 gallons of solvent. For its achievement, PFIZER was awarded the Green Synthetic Pathways Award of the Presidential Green Chemistry Challenge by the US Environmental Protection Agency in 2002. During the same period, PFIZER chemists were greening the manufacture of sildenafil, as well. The new approach reduced waste production and won the Crystal Faraday Award for Green Chemical Technology from the UK Institute of Chemical Engineers (IChemE ) in 2003.To build on these successes, PFIZER institutionalized green chemistry in the GCI, creating the position that Dunn now fills. Working with Steve Brooks, vice president, PFIZER Global Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Operations, Dunn manages a global green chemistry network that extends from central technical and policy communication teams to local teams driving fundamental changes in practice.[…] On the manufacturing side, which necessarily produces the most waste, the goal is set in terms of the "E-factor", a measure of environmental impact that is simply a ratio of the mass of waste produced to the mass of product. Typical pharmaceutical manufacturing processes have an E-factor of 50-100. PFIZER's goal is to lower its own E-factor below 50.[…] Every reaction in pregabalin synthesis is carried out in water - an achievement that may be unique in API manufacturing. PFIZER estimates that between 2007 and 2020, the aqueous process will save 185,000 tons (168,000 tonnes) of solvent and 20,000 tons of reagent. It will also use 83% less energy than before. Because of its high efficiency and reduced footprint, the process also saves PFIZER production capacity. The pregabalin process won PFIZER the IChemE's Excellence in Green Chemistry and Engineering Award in 2006.[…]

title: Green energy: Silicon Valley leads a back-to-basics revolution; Green energy has long aimed to overthrow fossil fuel's stranglehold on world power generation. But for now, Silicon Valley is taking green energy down a different path.
news: Even before Solyndra became synonymous with the perils of the green-technology industry, the industry was changing. Grand plans, like those of Solyndra to bring solar energy to firms nationwide, still ripple through Silicon Valley, but quietly. The current economic slump and Chinese competition have taken a toll. Instead, a new vision for the future of the green economy is emerging - at least for the short term. Instead of transforming power grids, green companies are looking at more incremental advances, whether it's improving light-bulb efficiency or helping Wal-Mart make its supply chain more environmentally friendly. But this more modest outlook is not a retreat, analysts say. Moreover, data suggest that the United States remains the world leader in private-sector investment in clean technology, with Silicon Valley leading the way. "I think clean-tech industry is still a growing area for venture capital investments," says Mark Heesen, president of the National Venture Capital Association. "It is an area fraught with a lot of risks - no question about that - but there are also huge and significant game-changing technologies coming out of venture-backed clean-tech companies." China has invested far more public money into clean-tech industry than any other country, according to Cleantech Group, a global research organization in San Francisco. But the US is still No. 1 when it comes to venture capital. […] "Green is now mainstream and should be measured in private-equity spending and growth in the green offerings of mainstream companies like General Electric and Procter & Gamble," says Terry Tamminen, author of "Lives Per Gallon: The True Cost of Our Oil Addiction." Big companies are spending money to make their own operations greener. Wal-Mart commissioned SolarCity of San Mateo, Calif., to install solar panels on as many as 60 additional California stores this year, meaning more than 75 percent of its stores in the state would use solar energy. But the real trends in clean tech are apparent in the entire "green" supply chain, where Wal-Mart is also a leader, Mr. Tamminen says. "Wal-Mart is pushing everyone in its supply chain to reduce packaging, use more efficient transport systems, replace toxic chemicals with nontoxic alternatives, and secure food from local suppliers," he adds. "It's 'green' but not the typical clean-tech, Silicon Valley high-tech products and investments you typically think of when saying 'green.' " […]

title: WASTE GENERATOR BRIEFS
news: AT&T invests $565M in alt-fuel vehicles. AT&T Inc. plans to invest up to $565 million to deploy more than 15,000 alternative-fuel vehicles over the next decade. The investment will include an estimated $350 million for some 8,000 compressed natural gas vehicles to replace gasoline-powered service vehicles and another $215 million to replace 7,100 of the company's passenger cars with alternative-fuel models. The new vehicles will bring AT&T's alternative-fuel fleet to more than 15,000 vehicles by 2019. The compressed natural gas vehicles are expected to emit 25% less greenhouse gases than their gasoline-powered counterparts. The alternative-fueled cars could be up to 39% more fuel efficient and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 29%. "Economic times are tough, but tough times make it even more important to look for efficient solutions," said Randall Stephenson, chairman and CEO of AT&T. "This is part of a long-term strategy that will help us continue to cut operating costs, reduce emissions in the communities we serve and make our business even more sustainable." WIND ENERGY. S.C. to gauge offshore project's viability[…]

title: Brighten your whites at just 15c
news: A LAUNDRY detergent is promising to remove stains at just 15c. Proctor & GAMBLE says its new product, Ariel Excel Gel, can deliver perfect whites at half the temperature needed by traditional detergents. Launched under the slogan 'Cold is the new hot', the detergent claims consumers can save money on energy bills because it is effective at 15c. Turning down the dial from 30c will also benefit the environment, it says. Irwin Lee, UK & Ireland vicepresident and managing director of P& G, told trade magazine The Grocer yesterday: 'Ariel Excel Gel is a breakthrough development designed from the drawing board for brilliant cleaning at low temperatures.' Hugh Jones of the Carbon Trust, which helps companies cut carbon emissions, said: 'Businesses that meet their customers' requirements at the same time as helping to reduce their impact on the environment will be the ones that capitalise on the opportunities created by a move to a low carbon economy.'

title: Drive under way to cut power wasted by computers
news: Google and INTEL are leading a consortium of major technology companies in an effort to sharply reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers and servers. The energy-saving effort, announced Tuesday, is called the Climate Savers Computing Initiative. It will also include a large-scale campaign to educate consumers and corporate computer managers about technology's role in the emission of greenhouse gases. Companies agreeing to Climate Savers standards will try to build machines that are at least 90 percent efficient in their power use by promoting new technologies, setting new standards and encouraging more efficient use by consumers.[…] The initiative has received the support of IBM, Hewlett-Packard, Dell, Advanced Micro Devices, Sun Microsystems and Microsoft, among others. It is also supported by the National Wildlife Federation and the Environmental Protec-tion Agency. The group envisions better power management in computers, roughly equivalent to taking 11 million cars off the highway, according to Patrick Gelsinger, senior vice president in charge of Intel's digital enterprise group.[…]

title: From CSR to corporate citizenship
news: THE old cosmetic approach to Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), which is merely a necessary cost of doing business separate from your brand, is no longer enough. Instead, Interbrand research showed that companies can use CSR to enhance their brand values, by acting as 'corporate citizens'. […] In the B-to-B world, everyone has a sustainability target to hit, so every customer along the supply chain is demanding more from their suppliers than in the past. The Walmart effect has put a new premium on greening the supply chain. And purchasers understand that they can be held accountable by the public for their suppliers' actions. So pressure that begins externally - in the net's 24-hour court of public opinion and among a press ready to feed the beast - winds up being passed along every link in the chain. […]

title: Sechin attends foundation stone laying ceremony for new production facility
news: Rosneft President and Chairman of the Management Board Igor Sechin took part in a foundation stone laying ceremony that launched the construction of a facility that will produce gas turbine units in the city of Rybinsk in the Yaroslavl region of Russia.  The ceremony took place on Wednesday, October 312, Rosneft said. The facility, which is being built by Russian Gas Turbines (a joint venture between GENERAL ELECTRIC, INTER RAO and the United Engine Corporation), will in begin producing and servicing 77MW low-emission high-efficiency 6FA packaged gas turbine units in the second quarter of 2014 Five packaged turbine units will be supplied by GENERAL ELECTRIC for a thermal power plant at the Eastern Petrochemical Company, a major Rosneft project. The first turbines are expected to arrive in the third quarter of 2014. Rosneft's order created conditions for the launch of the plant, the company said. Rosneft and GENERAL ELECTRIC signed an agreement for servicing five 6FA packaged gas turbine units to be supplied by GE under the agreement signed in 6 for the thermal power plant at the Eastern Petrochemical Company, which is currently under construction by Rosneft. The agreement will run for 16 years and is GE's largest service contract in Russia. The company will provide technical support and full-cycle routine technical maintenance of the turbines, their components and generators. GE will also be responsible for maintaining the availability factor of the turbines, as well as power output and the heat rate. The low-emission and highly fuel efficient 6FA package gas turbine units at the Eastern Petrochemical Company's power plant will operate in line with international environmental standards. […]

title: Building Green; Bigger Projects Have More Sustainable Feature Options
news: Sustainable development may be a hot ticket in the construction world, but one size doesn't always fit all. While projects of every size have options, several New York developers say larger buildings enjoy a broader menu of green systems and features.  An informal tour around some of the largest projects in New York seeking Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design status from the U.S. Green Building Council underscores that big projects - especially those larger than 250,000-sq.-ft. - are able to capitalize on systems like water treatment or power generation that just don't make sense for a smaller structure. Those options in turn help to decide whether a building will have enough features to qualify for the highest LEED designations of gold and platinum.Manhattan has its share of bigger structures seeking the status, including the 856,000-sq.-ft. tower that Hearst, the media corporation, is building over its base headquarters on 57th Street. Others include the 2.1-million-sq.-ft. BANK OF AMERICA tower on Sixth Avenue, a new 299,000-sq.-ft. residential tower at Battery Park City, and the 1.7-million-sq.-ft. 7 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan. Meanwhile, two major planned projects include a 2-million-sq.-ft. headquarters tower at Battery Park City for Goldman Sachs, the financial services company, and the 1,776-ft.-tall Freedom Tower at the former World Trade Center site.[…] The BANK OF AMERICA tower, known as One Bryant Park, is also a high-profile project, because its developers are striving for platinum LEED certification. The 54-story building rising between 42nd and 43rd streets is expected be the first office tower in New York to achieve that highest LEED status upon its completion in 2008.[…]

title: When small things lead to big ideas and a medal
news: RIDHWAAN Suliman, 16, a Grade 12 learner at Pretoria Boys High, has entered the Expo five times. He was awarded a gold medal at the Eskom Expo 2002 and selected to represent South Africa at one of the most competitive science fairs in the world, the INTEL International Science and Engineering Fair. Ridhwaan's study proved that aerosols are causing global cooling and are having a compensating effect on global warming. He also showed that there are high levels of aerosols over the Highveld of Southern Africa, which could seriously affect the climate and aggravate respiratory illnesses. […]

title: ON SALE AT TESCO: THE DESIGNER COLLECTION FASHIONED FROM LANDFILL
news: [...] TESCO today unveiled the first designer supermarket clothing range to be made from recycled fabric. [...] Coca-Cola staff at the winter Olympics in Vancouver also wore uniforms made from recycled bottles and nine football World Cup sides sponsored by Nike will have kit from the materials. [...]A recent report found that the rubbish London sends to landfill generates about 520,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions per year.

title: Corporate: Syed Mokhtar offers FGV 30% stake in Tradewinds Plantation
news: Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd (FGV) is being offered a 30% equity stake in Tradewinds Plantation Bhd, says outgoing president and chief executive Tan Sri Datuk Sabri Ahmad.  But the deal may not materialise because FGV wants a bigger stake to gain control of the oil palm plantationâ  s assets, Sabri adds. […] â  The peat soil component is probably a negative [for FGV],â  Sabri says. This could be crucial for palm oil players who intend to sell biofuel to the European Union, which is very stringent about compliance with sustainability standards. â  Many companies and big multinationals such as Nestle and PROCTER & GAMBLE will not buy unless it [palm oil and biofuel products] is certified sustainable,â  says Sabri. Environmental groups are against the development of peat soil because palm oil producers typically burn peat forests when expanding their plantations, which emit large amounts of carbon dioxide. It is also more expensive to plant on peat soil than on mineral soil as water levels must be maintained via a complicated series of drainage systems. â " By Janice Melissa Thean

title: Companies need a conscience: Hewson
news: Former Liberal leader John Hewson has issued a warning to companies failing to meet their social obligations: starting thinking about the environment and the community, or face rejection by consumers.  A report on Australia's top 100 public and private firms released by Professor Hewson yesterday suggested that Australian companies are lagging behind their North American and European counterparts on so-called triple bottom-line measures.[…] Westpac was rated the most socially responsible company in Australia, and was alone in scoring the top mark of AAA. It rated in the top four on all criteria. Ten companies received AA ratings, including IBM Australia, Australia Post, Shell Australia, Alcoa, Visy Industries, BHP Billiton and Coca-Cola Amatil. Media giant PBL, retailer David Jones, insurers AMP and AXA and private health fund Medibank were among those that rated unsatisfactory.[…] Dr Hewson chairs the rating committee that consulted 19 organisations including Greenpeace, unions, accountants and social services to produce the ratings.[…]

title: China, US coal-bed methane projects awaiting go-ahead
news: Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency). […] Beijing, 6 6 (Xinhua) - Plans to develop two of the 15 large coal-bed methane capture projects, proposed during the Second US-China Strategic Economic Dialogue, are on the drawing board, according to China United Coal-bed Methane Corporation (CUCMC). […] The CUCMC is the only company in China authorized by the government to cooperate with foreign partners in coal-bed methane mining and development. Eleven projects are located in north China's Shanxi Province, with the other four in Anhui, Shaanxi, Jiangxi and Yunnan provinces. CHEVRON has invested in four projects, Greka Energy in five, Far East Energy in three, and MidAmerican Energy Holdings, ORION Energy International and Asian American Gas Inc. in one each. Under the contracts, foreign investors will fund exploration. After the projects go into production and the exploration funding is repaid, the Chinese and foreign investors will share the proceeds according to their investments. Coal-bed gas is a natural product during the conversion of plant material to coal. Utilization of the clean fuel could contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and help relieve China's energy shortages. […]

title: A solid program to reduce waste; Subaru factory sets new standards for going green and reduces costs in the process
news: Beyond the vehicle itself, automakers are "greening" the factories where they're produced. Whether to save money, meet standards or present a more responsible face to the community, auto manufacturers are reducing their energy requirements and the amount of waste generated.The local Subaru plant, which builds the Legacy, Outback and Tribeca, and the Camry for Toyota, became zero waste-to-landfill in May 2004. It was the first automotive plant in the U.S. to be ISO 14001 certified for its environmental management systems, and has a wildlife sanctuary on its grounds. While not unique - all automakers have various environmentally-conscious operations - Subaru of Indiana Automotive (SIA) goes beyond reduce, reuse and recycle at a plant that sits amid some of the country's richest farmland.[…] Other manufacturers have studied the plant for their own operations, including PROCTER & GAMBLE and Frito-Lay. SIA has recycling programs in local schools, including nearby Purdue University. "We have an outreach program to the students in schools," Coogan says. "They come to SIA on Earth Day to give their presentations. On the last one, one student said, 'There are really four Rs, and the last one is responsibility.'" Travel was provided to freelance writer Jil McIntosh by the automaker. jil @ ca.inter.net

title: Businesses' green opportunities are wide, but complex; Efforts must be credible and make financial sense
news: It's not surprising that the pages of Joel Makower's latest book, Strategies for the Green Economy, are printed on paper made from 100% post-consumer, de-inked fiber. That's paper that has been used by consumers and collected through various recycling programs. […] Moreover, around the world, political leaders are realizing that this isn't a topic that will go away --  it's gaining ground rapidly. More suppliers are being pressed to take green action. Wal-Mart, for example, is "pushing its 60,000 suppliers to perform all sorts of sustainability somersaults," he reports. "Corporations and institutional buyers of a wide range of products are looking upstream for solutions, asking suppliers to, variously, reduce packaging, eliminate hazardous materials, use more organic or bio-based ingredients and take other measures to green up their products and operations." […]

title: Guide highlights tensions in corporate engagement
news: A business guide to working with environmental organisations highlights the tensions between firms' need for advice and campaigners' desire for change. WWF and Forum for the Future top the list of groups that companies could seek to work with to reduce their environmental impacts, research by analysts Verdantix has found. The report provides advice for corporate responsibility directors on a dozen organisations with a range of stances on environmental protection Some are campaign groups such as WWF, Oxfam and Flora and Fauna International. Others, such as Forum for the Future and Tomorrow's Company operate like business consultants. Verdantix excluded Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace because they do not have proactive business partnership programmes.  […]  It concludes WWF and Forum for the Future offer a breadth of expertise closely aligned with corporate environmental agendas. For instance, Forum can advise on profiting from a more sustainable business strategy. Both organisations have had a recognised impact on business decisions. For example, WWF's campaign to cut business flights by 20% in five years gained support from several high-profile firms (ENDS Report 414, p11). Both also have a track record of mutually beneficial partnerships with leading brands, such as Forum with PEPSI and WWF with Marks and Spencer (M&S). […]

title: U.N. summit highlights climate risk; Investment community sees 'seminal change' toward addressing GHG emissions
news: Pressure is increasing on the U.S. government and the investment community to address climate change. Some 450 institutional investors, pension plans and corporate executives at a high-profile meeting last month at the United Nations called on Wall Street and policymakers to address the issue. Many of those present said Congress should establish a mandatory national policy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and encouraged the financial community to put a price tag on carbon pollution. […] The meeting was hosted by Ceres, a Boston-based coalition of institutional investors and environmental groups that work with companies to address sustainability issues, together with the United Nations Foundation of Washington. Their efforts may be having some effect. Activists at the U.N. meeting were crowing about the announcement early this month that Citigroup Inc., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Morgan Stanley, all of New York, had adopted a set of principles under which they would factor in the risks of carbon emissions, along with mitigation strategies, used by utility clients. Also this month, Ken Lewis, chief executive of BANK OF AMERICA Corp., said the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank will start assessing the cost of carbon in its financing decisions. ``This is a seminal change in Wall Street's recognition of this as an issue,'' Kevin Parker, global head of Frankfurt, Germany-based Deutsche Bank AG's asset management division, said during a panel discussion at the U.N. gathering.[…]

title: Look before you leap into the green; Climate change funds may be all the rage, but they are not for everyone
news: Climate change has long been a red-hot issue among the green set, but now money managers are jumping on the bandwagon as well. Schroders, HSBC and DWS Investments are among those that reckon there is something they can sell to investors and they have been launching specially tailored funds. Climate change funds work like typical funds, but essentially focus on investing in companies from climate change and environment-related industries. These include renewable or low- carbon energy, energy efficiency, and water and pollution management. […] In 2008, banking giants Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley signed on to climate change industry standards like the Carbon Principles, which aim 'to standardise the assessment of carbon risks in the financing of electric power projects in the US'. Since the principles were released, Wells Fargo, BANK OF AMERICA and Credit Suisse have also signed on. Meanwhile, governments and world agencies are making huge investments to tackle climate change.[…]
